story: One down, 2041 to go. ;).
column3: This one is too difficult to remember. If the other Kanji are this difficult, I'm giving up.
column4: One Line to Rule Them All, One Way to Write it; One Stroke From Left to Right, and With a Pen Lift, Bind it.

story: Two lines.
column3: No wonder the hotel room only cost TWO yen, all it had was a ceiling and a floor.
column4: I have TWO Itchy knees 一 (Ichi), 二 (Ni).

story: One + two = three.
column3: THREE measurements define the female shape: BUST, WAIST, and HIPS. Waist is the smallest, and for most women the HIPS are wider than the chest.
column4: One (一) on top of two (二), gives three (三).

story: FOUR year-olds often put their FOOT (human legs) in their MOUTH - but they are too young to realize.
column3: I imagine a giant devouring a human in four bites. First the giant bites off the person's head, then he bites the torso, then from the waist to the knees, and finally the giant plucks up the remaining portion of the human legs into his mouth. See the fourth bite falling in there?
column4: This is a picture of a slab in the morgue. It is pulled out from the drawer, and it is showing only the dead person's feet. Clearly shi means DEATH.

story: 三 + two vertical lines = 5.
column3: Five - has a THREE, and a small 'h'... 'high five'.
column4: 三 + II= 5.

story: Indicating 6 parts of the human body: head, body, 2 arms, 2 legs.
column3: The Devil, always a gentleman, wears a top hat, but his goat legs, betray the Beast. 666 is his number.
column4: A top hat with animal legs is clearly the work of the devil. Six six six!

story: This kanji is our good old seven, turned upside down.
column3: I wrote it upside down so I crossed it out.
column4: My NANA can't do exercise number 7, so SHICHI-ts.

story: "Hachi" (eight) begins with the sound of the katakana "ha", and it's approximately the same character.
column3: The valcano hasn't erupted for 8 years.
column4: The curtains close at eight.

story: Kinda of looks like the kanji of 1　一 with the kanji of 8 八added. So think of it as 一＋八＝九.
column3: It looks like an elaborate letter "n" for nine.
column4: 九i九e.

story: Two needles crossing marks the spot, or you can use the Roman character for ten (rotated 45 degrees).
column3: I scared away ten vampires with a single cross!
column4: A roman ten (X) standing on one leg.

story: Looks like a huge open mouth.
column3: When you sneeze, your MOUTH forms a square, and you make a noise that sounds like (KUCHI).
column4: （つ゜口゜）つ（Insert something yummy here).

story: Open the window, new day.
column3: =sun; day： Each time the SUN rises a new DAY begins. 日 (#12) is a picture of the sun. Normally we draw the sun with a circle(ㅇ) surrounded by many strokes. But there are no “round” shaped Kanji so we take 口 (#11) instead, and one stroke in the middle (one (#1)) representing all. 日本　Japan,　日曜日（ニチジヨウび）Sunday,　毎日（マイニチ）everyday, 母の日（ははのひ）mother's day,　日記（ニッキ）diary,　三日（ミッカ）three days.
column4: Picture two halves of a 24-hr period: Day & Night.

story: A month is longer than a day.
column3: Am I the only one who sees this as someone sticking their ass in the air "mooning" someone (two cheeks of the butt and the legs coming off of it)? The Moon meaning connects well to the meaning of month, considering that months were traditionally measured by the phases of the moon. Also, the mooning "ass" part of it connects well to Hesig's seemingly unconnected "flesh" or "part of the body" meaning (when used in primitive form).
column4: Month - every MOON cycle, werewolves eat FLESH, and other PARTs OF THE BODY.

story: A rice field divided into four parts.
column3: Ten rice fields can feed many mouths.
column4: Ten people use their mouths to eat the yield of the rice fields.

story: 目_目.
column3: There are 3 sections. Imagine the outer two being the whites of your eye. The middle is the pupil. Fill it in with imaginary color.
column4: Look at those tears in eyes. You moku me cry! .·目_目·.

story: Tombstone and cross on an old man's grave.
column3: You get OLD fast if you have ten open mouths to feed.
column4: Old people tend to talk a lot. Almost as if they had TEN MOUTHS!

story: I have 5 senses.
column3: I eat five times at day.
column4: I consist of five senses to observe, one mouth to speak. For order, remember that observing through the senses should be done before using one's mouth.

story: Don't look at the sun directly with your eyes, it's risky!
column3: You'll risk your eyesight if you look up at the sun.
column4: Looking up at the big sun is a risk to your eye. To remember that the sun primitive is bigger than the eye primitive, imagine making your eyes little (squinting) when you go out in the bright sun to reduce the risk of getting sun blindness. READING: imagine a kid saying "oh that's ぼう (bull as in B.S.), looking at the sun is no risk!" [he's blind now].

story: My companion and I are like two moons side by side.
column3: One moon is lonely. Two moons are companions.
column4: Companion = flesh of my flesh.

story: The sun makes the moon bright.
column3: The sun and the moon are brightest objects in the day and night, respectively.
column4: In the long run, the REAL trouble here is distinguishing it from "shining"/"sparkle". Choose a story to learn how to write 明. To distinguish it, remember the Japanese word 明日 (ashita, "tomorrow") and think of Orphan Annie singing "Tomorrow is a brighter day".

story: Someone chanting with their mouth open for two consecutive days.
column3: The monk opened his month and chanted for two days.
column4: Chants from our mouths are meant to reach the sun and the stars. Stars are just suns just further away so they seem smaller.

story: A diamond sparkles as brightly as three suns.
column3: Nothing sparkles like 3 suns!
column4: Sparkle is a 森 (#209) of suns!

story: Three boxes of goods are devoured by the hungry mouths of waiting consumers.
column3: Three hungry mouths waiting for the goods to come.
column4: Boxes of goods stacked on top of the other.

story: Spine connects head and body.
column3: The spine goes from one opening mouth/opening (mouth/face) to another mouth/opening (genitals). Just think of these openings being enlarged to represent the head and the body. The bottom is bigger because the body is bigger than the face.
column4: The spine goes from one opening mouth/opening (mouth/face) to another mouth/opening (in your ass).

story: If you work from Sun UP to Sun DOWN you will be prosperous.
column3: I kept getting this mixed up with meanings like 'fortune', so here is a fool proof story! Remember the Vulcan salute from 'Star Trek' (a fiction of the sci-fi genre in which heavenly bodies such as SUNS play a huge role) used with the phrase 'live long and PROSPER'? If that's not enough of a visual reminder, the Vulcan salute shows the fingers parted in to 2 sets of 2, and visually kind of looks like this kanji if you think about it.
column4: When you are prosperous, your gold shines as brightly as two suns.

story: The sun up is early, well before ten.
column3: EARLY, is when you have to start your day before 10..
column4: An early sun-flower looks like a miniature sun perched on a needlelike stems.

story: 9am carries with it the rising sun.
column3: Nine planets revolve around our rising sun.
column4: The sun rises before 9am.

story: 3 tens = generation.
column3: They SAY a generation is ten+ten+ten years, with the big first ten providing a grounding, and the next ten providing a little more grounding for the final ten. But I wish the next generation didn't always SAY "yo!". (ON reading is SEI, KUN reading is yo).
column4: That swing has been in that tree for generations.

story: The rice field is harvested once a month to get food for our stomach.
column3: The stomach is the part of the body (月）that tells my brain (田) when to eat rice.
column4: A field of rice could fill my stomach for over a month.

story: A nightbreak happens when the sun rises over the horizon (floor).
column3: The sun rising over the horizon is giving the night a break. -nightbreak.
column4: HINT: You can substitute sunrise in your stories if you don't like the rare (and ambiguous) "nightbreak". Note that 暁 (#1285) is already taken. Don't confuse with 旭 (#27), which is the sun itself, rather than the time of the day.

story: The moon has a lot of gall sticking around after sunrise.
column3: For a month（月）, I was up until nightbreak（旦） because of my gall bladder（胆）.
column4: All the month long I have to start working at nightbreak. This really activates my gall bladder (=I get angry).

story: The sun spans from horizon to horizon in a day.
column3: The span of the day is the time between the sun goes up and comes down.
column4: The sunlight spans from the floor to the ceiling.

story: The letter "U" is concavely written.
column3: Concave has a concave shape.
column4: Stroke order: I took a step down into the cave. A park ranger threw down a line to me from the opposite top ridge, then waited. My friend went down to the lowest passage to look for me, then the ranger threw another line down to her.

story: When I get vexed, I give people the middle finger.
column3: Convex has a convex shape.
column4: Rude Tetris piece.

story: Age 18 = olden times.
column3: The old man with a walking stick kept talking of olden times all day long.
column4: In olden times, gentlemen used walking sticks every day.

story: To use an eyedropper by oneself, aim from above to put a drop into the eye.
column3: I know this, but I am an idiot and forgot.... The way I remember this is to think of the way in which Japanese people point to themselves if they are unsure of who is being spoken to. In the west, we usually say, "me?" and point to ourselves (pointing to the chest), but in Japan, people say, "ore/boku/atashi?" and point directly at their nose, the drop between their eyes. True story.
column4: Eyedrops are applied by ONESELF.

story: A white ray is a drop of sun.
column3: Even a small drop (') of the sun (日) would make you see nothing but white.
column4: It's a nice DAY for a WHITE wedding.

story: 100 turned sideways. sort of the same as what ashoksaraf said.
column3: That dirty ceiling was painted WHITE a hundred times!
column4: The "white year" (99) plus one more. 100!

story: Pocky goes in the mouth.
column3: "SSsshhh!! we are IN the library", she said, expressed with a finger over her mouth.
column4: I use chopsticks to put food in my mouth.

story: It takes many drops of ten to get to a thousand.
column3: One T = one thousand.

story: A thousand mouths speak the same TONGUE.
column3: Thousand mouths, a thousand tongues.
column4: When you drop because you are 古 (#16), you stick your tongue out.

story: It is a thousand or ten? I need my measuring box.
column3: I can fit a thousand needles into my measuring box, but only if I bend the thousand.
column4: A measuring box is a square wooden box that was used to measure one thousand grains of rice (needles) in feudal Japan. It was supposed to be enough to feed a working man for one day.

story: This kanji does not mean "get up" or "awake." It means rising, like the rising of a salary, or a promotion. STORY: You know that your salary has RISEN UP when your MEASURING BOX has enough dollar bills in it to reach the SUN.
column3: In old Japan the villagers used to put their measuring box on an east facing window ledge so that the sun would rise up above it and hence would be the first thing they saw in the morning. This was to remind them to use the box to measure out their kome for asagohan and ensure their store of rice would last the whole week.
column4: If the sun sat on the measuring box made of a thousand needles he would rise up very quickly.

story: Nine plus a drop rounds it off to ten!
column3: Watch out for 太 (#126). Here Heisig could have added a "t" and we would have had a much better keyword : rotund. Rotund is more specific than "round" which begs for confusion with 円 (#1952). A dictionary search on "fat" or "round" doesn't yield this kanji, but "rotund" does! Primitive suggestion: the Laughing Buddha is often depicted as a rotund, smiling bald man in robes with a largely exposed pot belly stomach (symbolizing plenitude).
column4: Cut the tail off of a 9 and it will be round.

story: The decimal system uses drops of ten as a measurement.
column3: Use two lines (X axis and Y axis) to measure the dot (on the graph).
column4: Glue two sticks together to make the best measurement. (I always remember the primitive, but never the original keyword.)

story: The elbow is the flesh that glues together the upper and lower arm.
column3: A body part that's used as a measurement in former days: the elbow.
column4: Sometimes I get carried away and do elbow curls until the point where my forearm snaps off! When that happens I simply pull out the glue and re-attach the elbow to my flesh.

story: After you have chosen your 10 fields of study, measure how good you are at each to find out your specialty.
column3: 10 brains glued together allows you to specialize in any specialty that you want. Imagine each brain having its own specialty.
column4: She's so good at her speciality, it's like ten brains glued together.

story: Ten specialties grants you the title of Dr. with a dot.
column3: Watch for 医 (#1829), the sooner the better! In fact this kanji refers to someone well "learned", with extensive knowledge. This could apply to any kind of field. The kanji 医 ("doctor") is directly related to medicine. I would suggest to take away completely the idea of medicine here, and use a popular character whose name includes the keyword such as "Dr. Who", "Dr. Jekyll", even "Dr. Dobb's" if you're into programming.
column4: Note: Use Ph.D. rather than Dr. to avoid confusion with doctor and to be more in line with common use of this kanji. Ten specialities grants you the title of Ph.D. with a dot.

story: Fortune-telling: using a mouth as a divining rod.
column3: A great number of people who do fortune-telling are "almost old".
column4: To do fortune-telling put a magic wand in your mouth.

story: A magic wand standing on above the floor.
column3: The divining rod is above the floor.
column4: Zombies come above ground at night.

story: Roots are below the ground.
column3: A magic wand hanging below the ceiling.
column4: The divining rod is below the ceiling.

story: The most eminent magician is he who learned to use his magic wand early in life.
column3: The world's most eminent sourcerer, Harry Potter, used his magic wand early in life.
column4: Why is the code word for this "eminent" when it means "table" most of the time? I changed the keyword to "table" since that isn't used. It means "eminent" in two compounds: 卓越 (hiragana たくえつ) excellence, superiority, preeminence (卓越する be excellent; be outstanding; be preeminent) and 卓識 (hiragana たくしき) clearsightedness; penetration; farsightedness; excellent idea. Everywhere else it's table. Using a magic wand to do all the work, the TABLE was set up way earlier than expected.

story: There is mist as the moon fades away in the morning.
column3: Morning has come "ten" hours "early"!!! The "moon" is still in the sky!
column4: In the morning, god picks the sun up to the sky with two needles (because it's too hot to touch by hands) to replace the moon.

story: When I wake up, I am always late, so I hurry to work. With a bad case of perpetual morning breath, I am the subject of derision at my office whenever I open my mouth.
column3: If morning breath emanates from your mouth, you are subject to derision!
column4: Your mouth is full of derision in the morning because you're grumpy.

story: Imagine an animal with only a mouth and legs.
column3: Only your mouth runs faster than your legs.
column4: Tada!... SHE is the only animal with only a mouth on legs and no body! (Kun reading tada, ON reading SHI).

story: Stare at the shellfish, it looks like an eye with legs.
column3: Eye thought I saw a shellfish legging it down the beach!
column4: Remove the eyes and the legs, and a shellfish tastes great!

story: The new generation of pop songs have no depth. They just mouth empty lyrics to get money. Not like the pop songs of my day.
column3: Pop Song = using your MOUTH to get lots of CLAMS.
column4: Out of the mouth comes a pop song and in rolls the money.

story: A magic wand is needed to make a clam stand upright.
column3: Careful! This means upright in character, not in position. So although the magically standing shellfish is a cute image, it doesn't convey the right meaning. This character is mainly used to represent a woman's chastity, purity or fidelity, so I just associate chastity with magic oyster.
column4: An UPRIGHT person is above (上) petty disputes, and always holds their head up (上). Since they live on principle, they are as hard or firm as a shell in their beliefs of what is right and what is wrong. They are wise, because they find the pearls of wisdom in the shells of life; 童貞 (virginity); 不貞 (unfaithful); 貞はる (harp too long on a subject); 貞淑 (chastity, virtue); 貞女 (virtuous woman); 不貞寝 (stay in bed out of spite); .

story: An employee (member of the company) has to clam up his mouth if he wants keep the job!
column3: An employee is basically a shellfish with a mouth.
column4: An employee is a worker. They lend their mouth (口) to spread a message & sell products; eyes (目) to watch competitors & find customers; and eight (八) hours a day. Alt., an employee is a shell (貝) in the ocean of a company; it looks up to the boss's mouth (口) for orders. 医員(doctor); 一員(member); 駅員(station attendant); 委員(committee member);会社員(company employee); 海員(sailor);楽員(band member); 期間契約社員 (fixed term contractor).

story: Fortune teller writes your fortune on a piece of paper and tells you to affix it to a shell and throw into the ocean for it to come true. Picture licking the back of the shell like a stamp and affixing it to the fortune.
column3: To prevent confusion with 附 (#1400) I changed this to "paste (v.)" or "cut and paste" because it is the character for pasting in a PC and in graphic design. Careful 糊 (#2692) Story: You pay money and the fortune teller cuts and pastes a good fortune and prints it out for you on his notebook PC. 切り貼り きりはり cut and paste, 貼る はる to stick/to paste, 貼付け はりつけ (computer file) paste.
column4: To make cash (clams) the gypsy affixed a note / posted a bill to a billboard advertising her fortune telling services (contrast with 掲 (#726)).

story: As a primitive, this is Mike Wazowski from Monsters Inc. (the giant eyeball with legs...) Makes for easy stories later on.
column3: Eyes and legs are all you need to see the world.
column4: Men's eyes open wide when they see the legs of a beautiful woman. (Alternatively, women's eyes open wide when they see the legs of a handsome guy ;) ).

story: In the olden times, a newborn babe came out legs first.
column3: In the olden times, a newborn babe came from between the legs. Now we have cesarean section. [modified rakutenka's story].
column4: In olden times newborn babes were strapped to their mothers' backs, leaving both their legs dangling.

story: In the beginning were just two who walked on human legs.
column3: Every journey begins with your two legs.
column4: In the beginning there were two humans with legs (human legs!) Adam and Eve.

story: A shellfish carrying a page balanced on its head.
column3: One drop of ink from a shellfish can fill a whole page.
column4: 頁岩, 頁, 頁 (#60) ケツ, ページ ... Parts: 一, 丶, 自, ハor 一, 丶, 貝 (cf: 順番, お願い, 頭, 頂く, etc.) ... Tip: This is a never used Kanji, but you are going to see it a few hundred more times in RTK as a primitive. Here's something that I figured out way too late. This is ALWAYS ALWAYS on the right hand side (RHS) of the characters it is a part of. Always.. Learn this primitive cold, and remember, always on the RHS.

story: A stubborn person in the beginning gets something into their head and can't change their mind.
column3: Picture a STUBBORN schoolboy, with his arms crossed and his book still open to the BEGINNING PAGE. Despite the teacher telling him to turn the page, he refuses and keeps his book on the BEGINNING PAGE.
column4: He's so stubborn, he won't read past the beginning page!

story: A drop of breeze is naught but a mediocre wind.
column3: A drop of rain in the wind... what a mediocre rainy season...
column4: Nothing is more mediocre than a single drop in the wind.

story: Tied up, the shellfish had to accept defeat!
column3: The shellfish admitted defeat when they placed a hook on top of his head.
column4: A shellfish bound up in a fisherman's net has been defeated.

story: I bound ten thousand dollars together and hid it under the floor.
column3: It looks like a T and an H put together.
column4: Looks like T and h, sharing the same stem.. Th are the first two letters in thousand.

story: Some Japanese phrases are difficult to wrap your mouth around.
column3: A bound mouth cannot utter a single phrase.
column4: A phrase is a bunch of bound up words coming out of a mouth.

story: When you expose your flesh to the wind it gets textured: goosebumps!
column3: The moon's lack of wind preserves its texture.
column4: Because the moon has no wind the texture of it's cratered surface never changes or erodes.

story: Hint: Here's info from Wikipedia regarding why this kanji exists, which helped me remember it: [Japan also divides the month roughly into three 10-day periods. Each is called a jun (旬). The first is jōjun (上旬); the second, chūjun (中旬); the last, gejun (下旬). These are frequently used to indicate approximate times, for example, "the temperatures are typical of the jōjun of April"; "a vote on a bill is expected during the gejun of this month."].
column3: Hesig should be BOUND for a DAY (or maybe 10 days - a decameron) for calling this Kanji DECAMERON. See 殉 (#872).
column4: If you bind up ten days, you get a decameron.

story: A ladle binds drops together.
column3: Forget about the primative 'bound up'. Imagine instead the shape of a ladle and holding it upside down to drink the last DROP (of water).
column4: I'm bound and determined to get that last drop with this ladle!

story: I managed to hit the bull's eye by throwing my white ladle.
column3: A white, bound up, drop in the center is the bull's eye. (why Heisig had to use "ladle" instead of the original two primitives that make up "ladle" I'll never understand!)
column4: This kanji is used most commonly for 的（てき）or teki, which is the Japanese equivalent to the English suffix '-ly'. Example: 基本的（きほんてき）or kihonteki: kihon means 'basic' or 'standard' so kihonteki means 'basically'.

story: One has a strong NECK if one can carry HORNS on ONESELF.
column3: The V shape is your neck on top of your collar bone, or the straight line. Yourself, or the rest of your body is below that!
column4: When I think of a neck, I think of a giraffe. This kanji is just a pictograph of giraffe's face, with those little horns on top and a big nose.

story: This is a fish hook, that pulls out the fishguts.
column3: Really this will rarely be seen as fishguts as a Kanji, usually it's 2nd party, or latter, generally always meaning 2nd in some way. It's easy to remember this as "2nd" since it looks like a 2. Then just remember it's a fishhook primitive like any other kanji that changes it's meaning as a primitive.
column4: "Knife goes in, guts come out" (-Bart Simpson's mantra as he guts fish in "30 Minutes Over Tokyo"). To be more specific: first, cut a 乙-shape in the belly of the fish, second, pull the fishguts out. (Note that the most common meaning of this kanji is not 'fishguts' as Heisig connotates, but 'second').

story: The riot police broke up the riot by dragging the rioters away by their tongues with fishooks.
column3: A tongue with a hook can cause a riot.
column4: If my daughter took her tongue and pierced it with a fishhook, that would cause her mother and I to riot!

story: If you get a needle in your eye that is hooked in there, get to a hospital straightaway.
column3: I caught a freaky creature with ten eyes on my fish hook, so I threw it back straightaway.
column4: Meanings: (1) Straightaway; straight (ahead); (2) direct; upright; erect; (3) straightforward; honest; frank. People who are frank, honest and straightforward live by the ethos: cross my heart and hope to die; stick a needle in my eye; if I ever tell a lie (the big L is for LIE).

story: Keep an eye on your tools while you work at the table.
column3: You need a strong tool to remove the legs from a shellfish.
column4: One tool nobody should be without - a Mordor-type eye that floats over the workbench. It jerks around, monitoring all who come near, and if anyone so much as removes a stapler from the bench - ZAP.

story: A compass is a tool with a needle on top that points to true north.
column3: Ten tools are all a true craftsman needs.
column4: Ten eyes working together are the best tools to see what's true.

story: I-beams are used to CRAFT skyscrapers.
column3: I consider craft to be one of the harder primitives to use in stories so I've personified it as Bender the crafty robot from Futurama who was designed to bend I-beams.
column4: I crafty.

story: The LEFT side of my brain posesses the faculties needed for logical crafts, like engineering.
column3: The left side of my brain, is for crafts.
column4: FOR THOSE ABOUT TO PUZZLE OVER THE CHANGING STROKE ORDER, IT'S THIS SIMPLE: Look at the second primitive! Here, the first stroke of by one's side should match the first stroke of craft so that the stroke direction alternates in writing. So 左 is written horizontal, vertical, horizontal... 右 is written vertical, horizontal, vertical... 有 is vertical, horizontal, vertical... etc. (The ONLY exception to this rule comes with elbow [雄 (#804) 雄], which is written horizontal, vertical, vertical(ish)...)

story: The right side of my brain is for speaking.
column3: Always keep your right to free speech (mouth) by your side!
column4: By my side is a big mouth who thinks they're always right.

story: Possessed by the Earth's gravity, the moon stays by its side.
column3: To possess = have or own something. In the fight for survival in prehistoric times, the most important thing to possess was meat by your side which could be eaten at any time. Imagine a caveman after a hunt having meat by his side.
column4: The moon stood by my side: I was possessed, a lunatic.

story: If you possess enough shellfish, you can bribe anyone.
column3: To bribe someone, money is a necessary possession.
column4: In order to bribe me you will have to give me all the clams you possess.

story: "This next song is a TRIBUTE to a little SHELLFISH friend of mine who was tragically crushed by an I-shaped table."
column3: Tribute is the craft of raising money.
column4: Tribute is another form of taxation - a crafty way of collecting "clams" (money). 貢献 (こうけん) : contribution, services; 西貢 さいごん Saigon.

story: To write a paragraph is the craft of grouping sentences on a page.
column3: To craft a page well, we need paragraphs.
column4: Page and craft = pacraft -> paracraft; said properly as paragraph.

story: This SWORD is so sharp, it can cut the top part of カ off in カタナ.
column3: Samurai carry two swords on their belt: a curved katana and a straighter, shorter wakizashi.
column4: Looks like the handle on a pirate cutlass, a kind of sword.

story: The part of a sword where a drop of blood can usually be found is the blade.
column3: A drop of blood on the blade of my sword.
column4: How do you know it is a real sword? There is a drop of blood on the blade.

story: The seven samurai used their swords to cut their opponents.
column3: Seven swords cut better than one.
column4: The seven samurai used their swords to cut vegetables. (Easier to remember if it's a little silly. Imagine the seven samurai flailing about the kitchen dangerously swinging their katanas about, to cut stuff up for dinner.)

story: To seduce is to make a sword of one's mouth.
column3: 召す 【めす】 (v5s,vt) (1) to call; to send for; (2) to put on; to wear; to take (a bath); to ride in; to buy; to eat; to drink; to catch (a cold); (P) This kanji isn't anything sexual or anything. It means SUMMON/TO SEND/CALL FOR (as well as honorific form of eat/drink). STORY: A king is having a hard time EATING a piece of of meat b/c it can't fit in his MOUTH, so he CALLS FOR/SUMMONS someone to bring him his SWORD. (this keeps the eat/drink meaning of the kanji true as well).
column4: To seduce is to accomplish with the mouth what cannot (or should not) be done with a sword.

story: Shining is the sun's seduction.
column3: The sun was shining so bright that it seduced Icarus and he flew too close.
column4: The Sun Seduces with its Shining light.

story: When you have both money and the power of the sword, you can make the rules.
column3: The world is ruled by money and sword.
column4: A shellfish with a sword rules.

story: The wealthy guy with the sword standing next to the king, that's the vice-roy who does all the dirty work.
column3: Vice-President Cheney shot a man in the face while hunting, as is common knowledge, I imagine. So think of it like a Clue answer and you will remember the symbol order as well. One shot, in the mouth, on a field, with a gun (a modern-day sword).
column4: TIP: 畐 = Wealth. WEALTH in Japan is interpreted as having a whole rice field 田 for just one 一 mouth 口. STORY: Darth Vader, the vice-ruler in the Galaxy (second only to Emperor Palpatine) protects the wealth 畐 of the empire by wielding his lightsaber 刂.

story: I don't know about you but to me this seems like someone's head is about to be separated from his body. You can see he's kneeling and his mouth is wide open gasping for the last breath he will ever take.
column3: A wise old samurai keeps his hostages (with their mouths bound up to keep them quiet) in a separate room from his sabers. Putting them together would be a silly mistake.
column4: The prisoner with the BOUND MOUTH was separated from his SABRE.

story: Today, the program "Sesame Street" is brought to you by the letter "T".
column3: Two streets make a T-intersection.
column4: The street sign is nailed with a spike.

story: Actually this means town, like one that has lots of streets and is surrounded by all the rice fields.
column3: Getting this one confused with Town is easy, so remember it with this rhyme. "Pillage the village, for the rice and and the tea." the street primitive on the right looks like a 't'.
column4: Note: the keywords of 町 (#96) and 村 (#221) swap places in translated editions of RTK I. In fact, according to different dictionaries, 町 is closer to 'town' whereas 村 is closer to 'village'.

story: A mouth on the street asking for things: "Can I get some help?! Can I get directions, Can I have some money? Can you please speak English?!"
column3: I can eat nails.
column4: A square box can fit in a corner.

story: If I put a street sign on my head what do I get ? A place on the head !
column3: You've probably noticed that even the rudest and crudest Japanese say "Itadakimasu" before every meal. Why? Because each person who failed to say it as a child had a nail driven straight into that tender PLACE ON THE HEAD (i.e. the very top of the head). That's a lesson no one will forget!
column4: Driving down the STREET, looking at a PAGE in the map, I hit another car, and started bleeding from a place on the head.

story: A child who is ten will still ask for his ma (top looks a bit like katakana ma).
column3: A pictograph of a child, with arms outstretched for mother (or perhaps because she is chasing a rat?). Note that this kanji occupies the first space on the Zodiac circle, and is the sign for the rat (such as 2008!).
column4: A ten year old child with a baseball cap.

story: The child's arms flailed around at the sight of the hooked tool the dentist was going to use to fill his cavity.
column3: I warned him about cavities, but the child is still hooked on sweets.
column4: When a child falls into a cavity we need a hook to get them out.

story: The experiment was a complete failure! The child was made without any arms!
column3: A child with the arms inside the blanket will be completely wrapped up.
column4: The child in not complete. He's got no arms!

story: To remember the order of strokes, remember a female ninja is called a "kunoichi". That is, く(hiragana) ノ(katakana) 一(kanji, ichi=one).
column3: My mother taught me that a woman should always sit with her legs crossed (but the arms can be stretched out).
column4: When a woman becomes a ninja she is called a kunoichi (くノ一).

story: A woman is fond of her child.
column3: Your wife and child: the thing you are most fond of.
column4: Women are fond of children.

story: A likeness to the Mona Lisa depends on a woman's mouth.
column3: A woman examining her exact likeness in a simple mirror while she puts lipstick on her mouth.
column4: A woman examining her exact likeness in a simple mirror. (Distinguish from 'resemblance' by thinking exact vs. inexact.)

story: The two breasts of a momma who breastfeeds.
column3: This mama had twins, one mouth for each nipple.
column4: When a woman becomes a mama her breasts grow and fill with drops of milk.

story: Ariel the Little Mermaid's clamshell bra was held to her breasts by piercings.
column3: The sad fate of Mama shellfish was to be captured and pierced to make an earring.
column4: mama pierces her ears in order to wear pearl earrings (which come from shellfish).

story: My elder brother was basically a mouth on legs when he was a teenager.
column3: The pac man's (只) elder brother has to have longer legs than his junior.
column4: Older teenage brothers have big mouths and long, awkward legs.

story: Caution: this means a spell, not to swear. I put a curse on my elder brother so that he can never open his mouth.
column3: There's an ancient curse in this region whereby the firstborn son, i.e. the elder brother, is always born with an extra mouth. And regardless of the elder brother's own personality, the extra mouth is bad tempered and always cursing.
column4: In Harry Potter, Ron tried to put a curse on his older brother, but it backfired and he ended up with slugs in his mouth.

story: Ten elder brothers can overcome anything.
column3: A teenager addicted to heroine must overcome the needle.
column4: Having ten older brothers would be hard to overcome. Ten mouths, and ten sets of legs kicking the crap out of you.

story: A little penguin with its wings at its side.
column3: Little little little drops...
column4: A depressed child, head low and arms hung low, because he's too little to ride the roller coaster.

story: Only a few people can make an ugly face like that.
column3: Few usually refers to three. To emphasize three, we underline the three drops in little.
column4: A happy grin, after a few drinks.

story: A person stretching their arms and legs to look large and scare a bear away.
column3: How large? This large!
column4: Think of a large St. Bernard dog with his paws all stretched out.

story: Two evenings too many!
column3: Many moons ago.. or perhaps it was just a couple of evenings, I can't remember.
column4: This reminds me of a childish pseudo-confucion rhyme: "He who eats many prunes sits on toilet many moons".

story: The evening is young, the moon is not full.
column3: In the evening, the crescent moon hangs in the sky.
column4: When I come back home from work in the evening I say tadaima.

story: Eventide is just another word for evening, and it has the word tide in it which we associate with water.
column3: Drops of water shower the beach as the evening tide approaches: eventide.
column4: Eventide is when the drops of water are attracted to the moon. This is the tide which occurs in the evening.

story: A young magician likes to practice outside in the evening with his magic wand (as opposed to the old magician who wakes early to practice with his wand in 卓 (#52)).
column3: Outside in the dark of evening, only a magic wand can help you.
column4: The evening is magical outside.

story: In the evening, when it becomes dark, open your mouth to say your name so that people can recognise you.
column3: In the evening, her sweet mouth whispered my name.
column4: Because it's dark in the evening, you need to open your mouth and speak your name to identify yourself. (This is a traditional mnemonic for this kanji).

story: Indiana Jones jumps up and grabs the lip of cliff just in time to evade the huge STONE rolling out of the mouth of the cave!
column3: If you pick the right stone, and hit the kanji 右 right on its head really hard, you can chip off the upper stroke from it.
column4: A stone covers the entrance to a cave hidden under a cliff.

story: It doesn't hold a candle to the real thing. They share a resemblance at most.
column3: This kanji bears a resemblance to sparks on a candle. (I always remember the primitive, but never the original keyword.)
column4: A candle bears resemblance to a little light from the moon.

story: That stone has sparks coming out of it! Someone must have poured nitrate acid on it.
column3: Salpetre is the common name for Nitrate coming from Latin "sal petrae" or stone salt. It is also a component of gun powder so including a candle in this kanji can be quite explosive!
column4: That stone resembles nitrate.

story: To SMASH a STONE you need to hit it NINE or TEN times.
column3: The Stones (the Rolling Stones) are 90 aged but they've done a new SMASH hit!
column4: A stone will smash a car-window nine times out of ten.

story: Here's how I remember that stone is on the left. This is because sand starts as stones, and only later they become few.
column3: In good SAND, stones are few, if any.
column4: Over time, rocks are worn down into just a few grains of sand.

story: The jealous woman bashed the brains in of the guy who betrayed her, with a stone.
column3: WOMEN are JEALOUS of the STONE on my wife's ring.
column4: That jealous woman is carrying a stone. Oh shi-.

story: Sparks will fly if you attempt to PLANE your sabre.
column3: Not "a plane", but "to plane". To carve a sculpture from wooden block, you cut it (with a sword) little by little, until there is resemblance with whatever it was meant to resemble.
column4: The carpenter's plane resembles a saber.

story: A ray of light is not a wave but made of little photons with human legs.
column3: The ray from Honey I Shrunk the Kids made people little - ha! look at them run around on their tiny legs!
column4: Imagine a ray gun shooting someone and their body exploding (sparks) and just their legs left.

story: A large person with a big drop of sweat dripping off of him because he is so plump.
column3: To keep this distinct from the primitive meaning of "round" ("fat man") I suggest to use a specific image, such as that of a plump Japanese sumo wrestler, and let the drop between the legs be the loincloth (which compared to their large body size, is quite a drop). To illustrate the importance of this, have a look at the kanji for "tenacious" (frame 1506) and "burdensome" (frame 1986).
column4: PLUMP people are LARGE and SWEAT a lot.

story: Imagine four hungry mouths all sitting around the table. They are all banging their utensils on the table waiting for a big meal to be placed in the centre.
column3: Note: 器 by itself means container/caliber/vessel. And 食器 means eating utensils ("food container", hehe).
column4: Don't limit the meaning of utensil here to forks and knives. This kanji means any kind of gadget, device or instrument. You can use it with 具 (tool) to mean "gadget" 器具 (きぐ), with the kanji of music 楽 it becomes "musical instrument" (器楽 = きがく) and it can even mean "talent" or "capacity". My story: 4 MOUTHS with their utensils/instruments engaged in a BIG activity (either working on a BIG project, maybe singing in a BIG orchestra, or waiting for a BIG meal).

story: The ST. BERNARD DOG lifted his large NOSE high in the air to find out where the stinking smell comes from.
column3: I have just done a big one. It's really stinking.
column4: In German there is the saying "self praise stinks" (Eigenlob stinkt). So, making yourself 自 look big 大 stinks.

story: Your mouth stinks: you need to sniff your breath.
column3: Smell. Mouth agape, nose in the air, a chihuahua smells some BBQ miles away. NOTE: Assigned keyword "sniff" in RTK Newly Approved General Use Kanji Supplement.
column4: Interesting fact: when dogs sniff something interesting, they use both their nose (held high above them), and their mouth too. There's an organ linking the nose and mouth called the vomeronasal organ that picks up extra scents. So think of this next time you see a dog sniffing with mouth slightly open (chihuahua or st Bernard, depending on if you use the unofficial simplified character without dot or not). Of course if the thing is really stinking 臭 (#128), the dog may only need to use its nose alone!

story: Exquisite women are few and far between.
column3: A geisha is an exquisite and delicate (another meaning of this kanji) women, however, even in the past there was only few of them.
column4: Exquisite women are few.

story: You focus by concentrating your eye on fewer objects.
column3: To remember the order: When focusing, keep a few things your TOP priority, so only they come UNDER your sight.
column4: Few distractions will catch your eye if you have FOCUS.

story: The thick cliff walls protected the children from the sun.
column3: In Sparta we throw our Children over a Cliff. Under the Sun, they fight other Children. In the end, if they survive, they sure have thick skin.
column4: The japanese word for thick is atsui which is a homophone for hot, a kid under a cliff with the sun baking down on him would be hot indeed, especially if he had a thick sweater on. An atsui seetaa under the atsui sun.

story: Imagine a ST. BERNARD DOG carrying a CAN instead of a barrel in rescue missions. How strange!
column3: A dog that can do the "Can Can" would be a STRANGE sight indeed.
column4: Big things can be strange.

story: So as not to confuse this with 河 (#157) think of streamers falling down.
column3: There are three default I/O Streams in UNIX, stdin, stdout, and stderr.
column4: Three streams grouped together might cause a flood!

story: There were 3 little islands in the stream who all decided to set themselves up as independent states.
column3: シュウ　The original meaning of this character was "sandbar", and for me this conjures up images of the Mississippi River, which is very wide with many sandbars and which was used to define the borders in ten American states. Picture Huck Finn and Tom Sawyer floating by state after state as they adventure down the mighty Mississippi, occasionally beaching their raft on sandbars.
column4: All powerful STATES grew from a few small settlements along RIVER.

story: "Obey, Obey!" says the brain-washing scientist as he sends a stream of orders to fill your head.
column3: In Japan, obeying means following the stream of collective opinion BEFORE using your own head.
column4: Obey the orders streaming down from head office.

story: The kanji for water is an abstract primitive itself, so unless one is willing to break down its etymological development, it should just simply be memorized by strokes; constructing a story is not necessarily useful unless it strongly denotes its shape (I find that Heisig's story doesn't do this).
column3: For those having issues with this* "A 7K foot pool of water" Notice it looks like a 7, and a K. Might have to practice writing it a few times.
column4: When you squeeze a stream you get water.

story: Icicles start with 1 frozen drop of water.
column3: A drop in temperature turns water into an icicle.
column4: This character and 永 (#139) are somewhat confusing. If you can remember how they're written but often take one for the other, imagine that eternity is above water and all the other elements, while icicles are to the side of a half-frozen waterfall.

story: It would take an eternity to count all the drops of water.
column3: It takes but one drop from the most special water: the fountain of youth (and it is written in a special way to with an extra horizontal line on the top) to live for an eternity. (In order to remember that the drop is at the top, think that the drop must come from the topmost water in order for its effects to be true).
column4: What is your life? A DROP of water on a mini FLOOR when compared to ETERNITY!

story: White is a symbol of purety, so white water is pure water, the precise definition of spring water.
column3: Perhaps the most common appearance of this kanji is in the word 温泉 (おんせん, onsen), a Japanese hot spring. The kanji is an excellent image of someone enjoying a Japanese hot spring: a little white towel on top, water below. (This helps keep all associations: spring, little and onsen).
column4: A fresh SPRING has plenty of frothy white bubbles in its crisp, cool water.

story: A body part that acts like a spring for hormones is a gland.
column3: Sweat and saliva glands act like a spring for fluids. (combining everyone's stories in one mnemonic, thanks mantixen).
column4: Part of your body that springs out sweat, your sweat glands.

story: Follow the springs down the cliff and you will find a nice meadow.
column3: Forget about "spring" because the water primitive is abbreviated to "little". This is easy to forget by the time you've finished RTK1. Instead, imagine standing on an exceedingly high cliff. Not overlooking the sea, but overlooking meadows. And what on earth are those white little things? Wow, they're sheep! This cliff must be really high!
column4: When in a meadow, the japanese girls who are white and small search for the shadow of a cliff to avoid taning.

story: Let's petition to save that beautiful MEADOW from overdevelopment by signing on this PAGE.
column3: Japanese hippies PETITION to save a meadow by getting people on the street to sign their page - as you pass by they call out: "お願いします、おねがいします。”.
column4: To save the meadow from development, a page of signatures was submitted as a petition.

story: If you don't know how to swim, you'll be in that water for eternity.
column3: It'll seem like an eternity in the water if you cannot swim.
column4: There's enough water in the world to swim for eternity.

story: A marsh is where water is seduced into the ground.
column3: The marshlands near Mordor seduce Frodo into gazing upon them, and he falls into the water--splash!
column4: The marsh looks just like dry land. Really it's water and it seduces people to step onto it and they sink to their death.

story: Open sea is a lot of water in the middle of nowhere.
column3: Water in the middle of the ocean is referred to as open sea.
column4: Out in the water, in the middle of the ocean, is open sea with no land for miles and miles.

story: This is pan- as in the prefix meaning "all". I think of Pangea as being a mediocre continent with water covering the rest of the planet. This was before it broke up into the first-class, well-distributed continents we got now.
column3: After Pan-Am crashed yet another plane into the water, their reputation dropped to mediocre.
column4: Peter Pan is pretty mediocre in the water.

story: A CREEK is a small trail of water easily crafted with a stick.
column3: Creeks are small water, easily crossed with a simple i-beam.
column4: Using water and some craft, one can make a creek.

story: I couldn't find any reference to this kanji as meaning cleanse. It seems to be most often used in the following compound 沙汰（さた）to mean affair. The other meanings seem to be closer to 'select' so maybe Heisig meant cleanse in the ethnic sense here.. I'm going to use the keyword "selection", as in natural selection. Story: natural selection first began in the water, and those that were too plump were selected out.
column3: Water is used to cleanse a plump man's colon.
column4: If you are FAT, it takes more WATER to CLEANSE you.

story: To make soup you just take water and add (+) the rest of your ingredients.
column3: To make soup you just take water and add ten tasty ingredients.
column4: Water and ten ingredients can become a good soup!

story: To keep this separated from 砂 (#122): Water erodes away stone a few grains of sand at a time until there is no stone left.
column3: Each water wave washes away a few grains of sand.
column4: This kanji is used in a lot of girl’s names. 理沙(りさ)、沙織(さおり)、沙百合(さゆり). Maybe guys can think of this kind of like the classic advice there a lots of fish in water(ocean), lots of girls out there for you. You might think that it's hopeless and there are only a few girls out there, but girls are like grains of sand. Keep looking for the right one!

story: The morning tide is basically, well, WATER in the MORNING.
column3: If it's not Eventide (汐) it must be morning tide!
column4: The water rises with the morning tide.

story: The water that flows from the meadow is the source of life for the wild antelope.
column3: Water is the source of a meadow's beauty.
column4: The source of clean water is from the 原 (#142): it comes from that spring at the bottom of the cliff. Pay no attention to Julie Andrews lying face down in spring. The water's clean. Trust me.

story: Conversations can become more lively after everyone has had a few drinks. It's because "watery tongues" loosen lips!
column3: Water comes off the lively speaker's tongue.
column4: 氵 (“water”) + 舌 (“tongue”) – a wet tongue. Ancient Chinese thought that a wet tongue was a sign of life.

story: To extinguish a SPARK, you need WATER.
column3: You need a few drops of water to extinguish the candle.
column4: To extinguish fire, use water or something resembling it.

story: If you ask your teenager if what he's drinking is water (and not Vodka), he will answer "but of course".
column3: キョウ But of course, this character really means "situation/condition". "Elder brother gulped some water and said, 'What the hell was Heisig's mental CONDITION when he came up with this definition? Heisig must have a drinking CONDITION. But of course, if Heisig sticks to water, rather than sake (like me, water quaffing, situation assessing, sober elder brother), his SITUATION may improve.'"　[MODEL COMPOUND: 状況　(じょうきょう)　state of affairs; conditions].
column4: Would you like to throw water on your elder brother? But of course!

story: A river CAN exist only if there is WATER.
column3: I kept confusing this with stream. My Japanese friend said that to him this is for an artificial river. Looking at kanji compounds with this there are two that struck me: One is the Yellow River in China (黄河), and the other is the Milky Way (銀河). Now I either think of the Little Engine that could dragging a bunch of stuff down a river in China and polluting it (so it turned yellow) or I see the Little Engine that Could flying across the sky making the Milky Way.
column4: With enough water you can make a river.

story: Please supply a guest who stays overnight with WATER and WHITE sheets.
column3: Overnight water white (it rhymes).
column4: The water is white cuz it froze overnight.

story: This is my favorite story. Simply associate the sad moment of an OLD person, standing near the WATER of the lake and looking at the MOON reflected in the lake. The created primitives themselves are put so beautifully, that you will not forget this kanji.
column3: Water reflects the old moon in the lake.
column4: Tip: Heisig later combines old and moon into 胡 胡 (#2537). Story: Drinking water straight from the lake is rather uncivilized. (OR: Uncivilized communities get their water straight from the lake.

story: A fathom is the unit you use when making rules about water's depth.
column3: You can't fathom how deep this water is. Perhaps you should use a ruler to measure it?
column4: HINT: I find 測 and 則 confusing. For 則 則 (#92)Heisig describes the keyword as a rule (regulation). Then in 測 (#160) he suggests 則 is a ruler or measure! Whatever stories you choose, don't loose sight of the meaning: 則 = rule (regulation, law), 測 = fathom (measure, conjecture).

story: Remembering soil is easy. If soil is soft, you can take a walking stick and plunge it two* feet into the ground.
column3: The grave was marked by a cross sticking out of the soil.
column4: Soil is neither positive nor negative.

story: SPIT goes from my MOUTH to the GROUND.
column3: The only things that come out of my MOUTH and onto the GROUND are spit and vomit. Everything else (words, song) floats on the air.
column4: Means vomit as well. a more decent way to say what you thow up could be "mouth soil".

story: The GROUND at the base of a CLIFF must suffer from enormous pressure.
column3: The cliff exerts a lot of pressure on the ground beneath it.
column4: For physics people: p = F/A (p:pressure, F:Force, A:Area). Where the force is from the immensity of the cliff. The area on the cliff is covered by soil. So the equation becomes p = F/A = cliff/soil which preserves the position of the primitives.

story: This refers to LAND, not the STRANGE gear superheroes wear.
column3: A CAPE is a piece of LAND that stands out STRANGLY in the sea.
column4: Cape Cod "odd" is a land where odd=strange things happen.

story: Before the Great Wall of China, there was a dirt hedge that spanned across.
column3: The HEDGE of roses growing from the castle grounds fully spanned the castle walls.
column4: The HEDGE spans the GROUNDS of the estate.

story: In a hole in the ground, the body of the victim was placed. And then the killer stuffed it up so that the truth would not be found out, he hoped.
column3: For a geologist, inlayed right in the ground is the truth.
column4: This is one of those times when I think Heisig didn't pick up a very good keyword. 填る can mean tons of things, but the keyword here is "to fit". As a passive verb (填る = はまる): 1) to fit/go into 2) to be suited for 3) to get stuck/caught 4) to be deceived; fall into a trap 5) to be addicted to / As an active verb (填める = はめる): 1) to insert 2) to have sex 3) to place an object around something (one that restricts freedom, such as handcuffs) 4) to entrap; to set someone up.

story: Piling SOIL upon SOIL for aeons is how SQUARE JEWELS are formed deep in the earth.
column3: How would you stop someone stealing your biggest square jewel? Bury it deep in the soil under ground. Then plant ivy to mark the spot.
column4: I've found something very useful in the forum: Katsuo said "圭 is a name kanji, and not part of the 1,945 Joyo set. It often appears as part of other characters, and this is presumably why Heisig included it in RTK1. Rather than use "square jewel", however, he assigns it the primitive name "ivy" when forming other kanji. Checking Halpern's dictionary, the original meaning is "ceremonial jade tablet with a rectangular base and pointed end used by the emperor in ancient China in appointing feudal lords."

story: The king used a special seal of ivy leaves glued onto his document.
column3: Squared jewels with the right measurements receive the jeweler's seal of approval.
column4: A bit of ivy glued to a letter can make a lovely SEAL when in a pinch, says Martha Stewart.

story: Try to reverse Heisig's story in this Kanji: imagine being trapped in one of those prison towers on an ivy cladcliff like in the movies. From your prison ontop the ivy clad cliff all you can see in the distant horizon is nothing but water.
column3: Over the WATER and past the HORIZON there is said to be a CLIFF that holds a very rare JEWEL.
column4: Across the water, I can see ivy covered cliffs on the horizon.

story: At the Buddhist temple the monks are seated on the ground, glued there in meditation.
column3: To be allowed to join the Buddhist temple, imagine an aspiring monk being asked to stand still in the soil for a long time in a measurement of his resolve.
column4: It is ironic that the kanji for Buddhist temple is composed by two elements Buddhism is meant to alleviate: earthliness and attachment.

story: When the SUN starts to shine on the TEMPLE, it's time to get up.
column3: In ancient Japan, TIME of ''day'' was announced at the ''buddhist temples''. They did this by ringing large iron bells. This is similar to churches who ring their bells to announce the time of day.
column4: A day at a Buddhist temple is TIME well spent.

story: Soil is scooped up into a ladel. The extra drop is brushed off to make it level.
column3: 匀 = equal, not ladle 勺 = ladle. > so the story would be equal soil is equal to leveled ground.
column4: To remember the extra stroke in the ladle, make a vivid image of a big drop of excess soil fr0m the ladle falling out onto the ground when you level it.

story: For some reason, this kanji reminds me of a person running, her arms (the two drops) raised up, because she caught on fire!
column3: To be honest, it just looks like the flames of a fire to me.
column4: Looks like a flame of a campfire with two drops of sparks flying off.

story: To fight fire with fire would just inflame a situation.
column3: An inflammation can often feel like FIRE upon FIRE burning.
column4: If you have an INFLAMMATION, it feels like there's fire above and below your skin.

story: An anxiety feels like FIRE in the HEAD.
column3: Imagine the anxiety a librarian would feel if the library caught fire and all the pages of his books were burning up.
column4: Many performers get "Michael Jackson anxiety" wherein they fear their head will catch on fire.

story: Drink water and burn twice as many calories as you eat... you'll definitely get thin. Imagine inside your body, all those calories literally being burned from above and below... THAT's what it takes to become thin.
column3: Adding water to an inflammation sure will make it a thin fire.
column4: NB - This Kanji is confusing and doesn't actually mean 'thin' in most examples. It most commonly means pale or plain, as in pastel colours. Here's a story for your new keyword: Drink water if your inflammation makes you pale.

story: Imagine old gas lamps which had a flame to light up the street signs.
column3: A lamp is fire you can hang from a nail.
column4: When this symbol was created, a lamp was simply a fire at the side of the street.

story: Many farms are created by first setting FIRE over the land to clear the land for the FIELDS.
column3: This kanji actually makes a boatload of sense. In Japan, rice farmers are constantly making little fires on their rice farms burning up all the old stalks and things probably to be used as fertilizer. In moving to Japan, I found this practice to be very new and odd to me. So I would venture to guess that's exactly where this kanji comes from. If not, it certainly makes it really easy to remember.
column4: When creating a farm, the prospective farmer must first set fire to the forest to clear the ground. Only then can he plow the fields. Fire before fields to make a farm.

story: What a disaster! First a FIRE, then on top of it came FLOODs.
column3: Don't know about Japan, but here in Australia, flooding rivers and bushfires are the most common natural disasters.
column4: There's a flood upstairs, and a fire in the basement. I think it's safe to say that this is a disaster.

story: The fire underneath the cliff will eventually turn everything above to ashes.
column3: After the cremation fire, many prefer to scatter their loved-one's ASHES from seaside cliffs.
column4: Scene from "The Big Lebowski" : Walter scatters Donny's ashes, but a wind blows much of the ashes into "The Dude" Lebowski's face. Upset, The Dude lashes out at Walter. Walter apologizes and hugs The Dude, before suggesting "Fuck it, man. Let's go bowling." I bet you that The Dude wanted to cremate (fire) Walter right there and then, at the top of the cliff! (thanks Elktapestry).

story: The FORTUNE TELLER was burned by FLAMES on the spot because she was accused of being a witch.
column3: Alternate meaning of the kanji is mark, or points. Like japanese tests are graded from 0 to 100 depending on how many percent of the questions they got correct. Before I learned any alternate meaning to this I took it as percentage = statistics. Now, wouldn't some pure and concrete statistics be just the thing you need to set that fortune tellers mind on fire? Relate the setting him/her on fire to the entry for 煩 (#175) if it helps. :).
column4: This kanji also means grade, or %. てん A student at an exam is like a fortune teller, fired up by enthusiasm and eagerness to get a good grade, red spots lit up on his face from the excitement.

story: SHINING FLAMES illuminate!
column3: The sun was seduced to give us fire, by which we illuminate the night.
column4: Just shining is not enough to illuminate. The shiny thing needs to be even brighter. Maybe set it on fire?

story: The elements of this kanji are bound up, rice field and cooking fire. When I think of bound up cooked rice, it makes me think of sushi, which in turn brings to mind fish.
column3: That fish was caught, BOUND UP, then carried across RICE FIELDS, and finally cooked over an OVEN FIRE.
column4: Bind that FISH and cook his brains! Yarhh!

story: You need WATER and FISH for fishing.
column3: "FISHING For Idiots", Chapter One: Fish are generally found in water.
column4: If you are confusing this with angling like me, take fishing to mean not the act of catching a fish but the act of being a fish not living but fishing (i.e. in the water).

story: The ri is a Japanese way of measuring the area of the GROUND underneath a RICE FIELD.
column3: Hint: Heisig makes here a severe disservice to everyone by using a weird keyword for this character. You'll save a lot (and I mean, a whole lot) of trouble later by giving it instead its intended meaning: House of the Parents.
column4: My parents' house is on a rice field; I compute the ground area being one ri by one ri. 古里 (ふるさと) : home town, birthplace, old village, historic village, native place, one's old home; 郷里 (きょうり) : birth-place, home town.

story: If you burn the GROUND of a RICE FIELD with FIRE, eventually it will turn black.
column3: If your parent's home catches on fire, it will turn black.
column4: Burning a computer is ri-diculous. It just leaves everything all BLACK.

story: Theres BLACK on the GROUND...most likely someone spilt some black ink.
column3: Black ink comes from black soil.
column4: Anyone who has worked with laserjet ink cartridges will know the black ink looks like powdered dirt.

story: Japanese carp are massive fish - they are measured in ri!
column3: Robocarp!!! Part fish, part computer! Visualise him flapping and clanking down the street, with bullets richoting off his scaly armour.
column4: In front of my parents' home is a fish pond full of carp.

story: I did such a quantity of work that when NIGHT BREAK came, I was asleep on the COMPUTER.
column3: A quantity can be a measure of time or space (day/ri).
column4: I have such a huge quantity of kanji to review that night break usually finds me in front of my computer reviewing the kanji.

story: I threw my Rindows computer off a cliff because it kept crashing. Now, after its last crash, it's worth less than a rin.
column3: A computer dropped off of a cliff would be worth about 1 RIN.
column4: Note: The rin is an obsolete unit of Japanese currency equal to yen. Due to the drastic devaluation of Japanese money after World War II, the rin was eventually taken out of circulation at the end of 1953.

story: You can't bury computers underground, because of the dangerous heavy metals, so you hide them behind an equally large mound of soil and hope no-one notices.
column3: I used SOIL to BURY my COMPUTER.
column4: Bury me in the soil beside my parents' house. That's where I want to be laid to rest. 埋め込む (うめこむ) : to bury; 埋蔵 (まいぞう) : buried property, treasure trove.

story: Imagine monks wandering around the monastery. Covered in their hoods and chanting as if with one mouth they all look the same !
column3: One mouth under a hood looks the same as any other.
column4: Everyone looks the same under a hood. All you can see is one mouth.

story: All the animals in the den share the same water.
column3: "Den" and "cave" also make me think of a monk's cell. Monks take vows of silence and fast. So a den is where you'd find nothing but water (to drink) and a monk. 洞 ほら cave, den, grotto; 洞窟 どうくつ cave; 洞察 どうさつ discernment; insight.
column4: Animals always build their den in the same place - beside the water.

story: Dead flesh all looks the same when you chop off everything but the trunk. Yes, I'm appalled at how gruesome this story is too.
column3: A trunk, a trunk // The body of a monk // The body of a monk in a trunk, a trunk.
column4: The trunk (torso) of everyone's body is mostly the same.

story: Look over yonder ! That tiny dot is robin hood at the mouth of his secret cave !
column3: The spaceman died screaming, his MOUTH wide open because someone has cut the oxygen cable from the HOOD/HELMET of his space suit. As his last DROPs of oxygen escaped into the vastness of space he thought to himself, So much for flying off into the wild blue YONDER.
column4: Over yonder usually refers to somewhere far away. For this kanji think of the aliens way over yonder who have an antenna popping out of their helmet which encloses but a single mouth.

story: An especially esteemed alien has three antennae on his helmet.
column3: I have little self-esteem.. so I keep my face under a hood and my mouth shut.
column4: Remember that scene from Star Wars, where Luke is wearing that helmet that only his mouth could see, and was swinging at that little thing buzzing around the room? That was Obi-Wan's trick to get Luke to build his self-esteem, or his confidence in the Force.

story: CHILDren learn Kanji characters underneath a HOUSE.
column3: "Why do I have to wear this roof on my head all the time father?" "Shut up! It builds character!"
column4: The first kanji characters you will learn in Japan is probably learnt at home (in the house of your family) when you are still a child. Imagine a really small preschool child doing this (to prevent confusing house with school like in 学 (#346)).

story: A GUARD is usually "glued" to the house he watches.
column3: A guard provides a measure of security to those under a roof.
column4: A good GUARD should stick to your house like glue and be willing to take any measures to protect you.

story: Make the perfect impression in the beginning by removing your shoes upon entering a Japanese home.
column3: In the beginning, Adam and Eve had a home in Eden. It was perfect.
column4: Their new house was the perfect place to begin a family.

story: You can proclaim your opinions from the comfort of your HOUSE and have it SPAN the entire globe these days via The Internet.
column3: I keep thinking about the Irish one-hit band the Proclaimers, who promised to walk 500 miles -- quite a long SPAN -- to reach your HOUSE.
column4: A local official proclaims a curfew spanning sunset to sunrise - you must stay under your own roof during that time span. I keep wanting to add in the "words" 言 primitive. Don't think about someone reading it aloud - focus on the CURFEW that was proclaimed. I also tend to confuse this one with 詔 (#342). Remember this proclamation comes from a petty local official.

story: I burn the CANDLE in my HOUSE until the WEE HOURS reviewing the kanji!!!
column3: I agree with elktapestry. This kanji really means "early evening", not "wee hours" [Heisig really should have done his homework on this and several other characters (e.g., #145 "but of course" -- what the hell???). Oh well.] "Every house lights candles in the EARLY EVENING which stay lit until the wee hours". E.G. 宵の口（よいのくち）early evening; 今宵（こよい）this evening; tonight.
column4: In the wee hours, you need a candle to see your way around the house.

story: It's funny, Hesig gives no Kanji in his book that means cheap/inexpensive... well... if you were wondering what Kanji would carry that meaning, look no further. Sometimes I wonder if Hesig just thinks our little brains would be too easily confused by multiple meanings. Regardless, think of that woman relaxing. Cheapest place to do that is in one's own home rather than at some fancy resort, eh? 家で休暇を取るは安いですね。.
column3: Cheapest place for a woman to relax is in her own home.
column4: アン、やす・い　The cheapest way to relax is to stay at home with your woman. 安心 (あんしん, peace of mind)…　Pure Group:　案214.

story: The WOMAN spent all DAY preparing a banquet in the HOUSE.
column3: Under the roof, all day long, the woman prepared for the banquet (this wording helps me remember the order of this kanji's elements).
column4: The woman cannot relax 安 in her house because she only has one day to prepare a banquet.

story: The strange house has a sign saying "DRAW NEAR" in its window, instead of a 'Beware' sign. It must be a trick!
column3: Imagine a horror movie set in a haunted mansion. The house is very strange. The characters draw near to one another for protection against the unknown.
column4: There is something strange in this house. Do you dare to draw near?

story: In ancient Japan, a RICE FIELD is a unit of wealth as it can produce enough to feed all the MOUTHs in ONE HOUSE.
column3: Remember Ducktales? That rich duck had that room in his house where he kept all the wealth! He had so much in that house you could even swim in it!
column4: A HOUSE with only ONE MOUTH and a RICE FIELD has a lot of WEALTH.

story: It takes a lot more than one clam of savings to buy a house on a street.
column3: savings = money kept under the roof rather than spent on the street.
column4: My SAVINGS plan - I nail my moneybags up in the rafters below my roof. I'm very secretive about it, and I wear a disguise with a big mustache (another meaning of this kanji) while I stash my loot.

story: If you need a story for a tree, then you need to be hit by one.
column3: Pictograph of a tree.
column4: [Cheat] Remember these as a set: The tree (木) is not yet (末) vermilion (朱).

story: A grove has at least two TREEs.
column3: [ grove = tree + tree ] - a grove is between a single tree 木 (#207) and a many-treed forest 森 (#209).
column4: A grove is smaller than a forest, so the kanji only has two trees.

story: The higher you go up a mountain the less trees there are, that's so u dont mess up with their possition like i do.
column3: Another tree planted within a grove turns it into a FOREST.
column4: Many Trees make a forest.

story: Simple mnemonic : "The Japanese Judas-tree is the tree on which Judas hang himself to the ivy" (Judas the traitor of the Christian bible). Just picture Judas hanging himself, using ivy as a if it was a rope.
column3: A tree covered in poison ivy will quickly betray you, thus the name JAPANESE JUDAS-TREE.
column4: The Katsura (Japanese Judas-tree) is a thin tree (sort of like the stretched out 木 used in this kanji) with little green (the color of an emerald, a jewel) leaves. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katsura_(tree).

story: The wood from oak trees can be used to make barrels in which white wine is aged. What's more, I love white wine with an oaky flavour...
column3: An oak tree is white, from left to right!
column4: [Pokemon] Ash :: "Going to Oak for my first Pokemon!" Mom :: "Oak, Oak? That tree?" Ash :: "Noo! Professor Oak! You know, he always wears a white coat!" Mom :: "Okay dear! Don't forget clean underwear!"

story: wood at 90 (9 * 10) degrees.
column3: Nine out of ten picture frames are made out of wood. The rest are made of metal or plastic.
column4: A good wooden frame has perfect right angles at each corner: ninety degrees at each one. 枠 (わく) : frame, slide.

story: At Christmas time, on the treetops, people used to place great big candles (Now we usually place a star instead).
column3: If you cut off the treetops, they still resemble the trees they used to be part of. Treetops=tree resemblance.
column4: A gigantic candle is standing to the right of the tree, the flame rising higher than the treetops.

story: A shelf is a wooden companion to books.
column3: I think of an Otaku, with a wooden shelf full of anime action figure statures, who are sadly his only companions.
column4: A shelf is made out of wood, and it is a companion to books. But most importantly for me, the two moons look like the spines of hardbound books standing next to one another as companions on a shelf.

story: From the tree straight into the mouth is the best way to eat an APRICOT!
column3: Imagine Totoro sleeping under his tree. As he snores a giant apricot falls nicely into his open mouth and he emits a giant burp of satisfaction. I can hear that music alreay....to - to to - to - ro...
column4: If you eat apricots too fast, you'll end up eating the pits too. And we all know what happens then - an apricot tree will grow out of your mouth.

story: In Japan, a paulownia (きり）is known as the "princess tree". It was once a traditional TREE planted at the SAME time as the birth of a daughter. It would grow fast enough that, at the time of her wedding, it could be used to make a dresser as a wedding present for her.
column3: Paulownia is a Japanese tree which looks same as any other tree.
column4: In the forest, there's a tree that my goofy friend PAUL claims he OWNS. I think he's nuts, because the tree looks the SAME as all the others.In Japan, a paulownia (きり）is known as the "princess tree".

story: Plants don't become trees straightaway.
column3: When you plant plants, you use a piece of WOOD to make the plant grow STRAIGHT.
column4: If you get a new tree it is of course best to go plant it straightaway. Without planting it straightaway the roots won't have enough time to be healthy and strong like the tree needs.

story: To the Japanese, the first time they saw a chair, it looked like a strange use of wood! Probably why they still like to sit on the floor...
column3: Http://www.pooktre.com/. (Then scroll down the page a bit.)
column4: A strange kind of tree grows in the shape of a chair.

story: A tree withers away as it gets old.
column3: When flowers get old they suffer (frame 225), but old trees just WITHER away painlessly. (Picture flowers crying in pain, but a dried up tree silent and sad).
column4: The tree is old and withered.

story: Wooden wands are the crudest. They are nothng compared to their carbon fibre equivilents.
column3: A beginner magician starts with a crude wooden magic wand. Later he'll upgrade to magicite, of course.
column4: You can make a crude magic wand from any tree.

story: If you've ever played an old 8 bit or 16 bit RPG, like Dragon Warrior or Final Fantasy or Inindou, you'll remember that every town was all bordered off by a line of trees with no space in between to get out through. Imagine that the trees were glued together so you could only exit town through the main or side gates, (so you couldn't escape the important scripted scenes.)
column3: Pfft. At it's core, a town is just a bunch of wood glued together. Edit - Stop starring this piece of crap story! xD.
column4: There is a mix up, this kanji means むら=village, not town. The one for town is まち　= 町. 100% shure because my teacher is native Japanese.

story: ソウ/ショウ/あ INTER /MUTUAL /ASPECT /PHASE /MINISTER. "Long ago, before there were telephones, people living far from one another would climb trees to eye each other's aspects and inter-act for their mutual benefit. Those who did this best became government ministers, with the top person (perhaps the one with the longest neck (首, 首 (#74)) becoming the prime minister 「首相 (しゅしょう)".
column3: To avoid INTER-acting with people, I climbed a tree and kept an eye out for anyone coming near.
column4: I changed my story to remind myself there are other primary meanings for this character: The Minister of Trees has a good eye for inter-action.

story: My wooden desk is so messy, it looks like a strong wind blew my things all over it.
column3: The tree was blown down by the wind - so I made a desk from it.
column4: Studying at my wooden desk, a great wind sweeps away all my papers - there goes all my hard work - I can see all the kanji disappearing into the sky.

story: The origin of a book is paper made out of TREEs. ONE tree can make many books.
column3: A book is one slice of a tree.
column4: An axe cutting a tree to make books.

story: Botanists like to identify TREEs by HOOKing tags on them.
column3: Might be good to note that this is also the Kanji for "Paper Money" w/ the reading さつ (千円札＝1000 Yen paper bill)... It also takes on the meaning of Playing Card with the reading of ふだ as in 花札 (Hanafuda cards) or トランプの札 ("trump" playing cards). For the tag meaning I like to think of wooden tags hung on hooks from trees... but for these other meanings I like to think of both paper money and playing cards as paper (tree) products with the ability to "hook you in" so to speak.
column4: In order to put a tag on a tree you need a hook.

story: Years-Months-Days: It takes many years for a cliff to form or erode. A tree takes many months to grow. But days pass by regularly - so in this way, we see the movement of time such as with a CALENDAR.
column3: This is just a picture of a wall calendar with a page for each month. The bottom half has the grid of days, the top half has a pretty picture of a forest this month. The cliff radical here is the top and left edges of the paper. You can see the paper curling up at the lower left where a breeze is trying to turn the page.
column4: Calendar; almanac. A calendar measures time in years, months and days. A cliff (厂) takes years to form; a grove (木木) of trees takes months to grow; but the sun (日) rises and falls every day. All of these periods can be recorded in a calendar.

story: I plan to RELAX on top of that TREE.
column3: Man's plan of life: build a house, find a woman, plant a tree.
column4: Calvin and Hobbes sit in their treehouse, which has a big "no girls" sign on it, deviously making their PLAN for their next water-balloon attack against the 'stinky girls'.

story: Tip: goods + wood/tree : This combination of primitives appears four times in Heisig, so it's worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest "furniture" (a common type of wooden goods). REF: parch (FRAME 215) , 操 (#724), 繰 (#1469), 藻 (#2191). Story: It's been so parched recently that your furniture suddenly catches fire.
column3: When a FIRE is parched, it isn't thirsty for water, it wants to gobble up some WOODEN GOODIES!
column4: Hint: Actually the element - 喿 - is itself a rare kanji, that has the meaning of "chirping of birds" (see these little mouthes on the tree). On - ソウ/ ショウ Kun さわ.ぐ/ かしま.しい/すき.

story: I believe a better version of that by mameha1977: [Cheat] Remember these as a set: The tree (木) does not yet (未) have exremities (末) of vermilion (朱).
column3: This TREE is not yet fully grown: it's only ONE year old.
column4: The top branch of the tree is not yet as long as the bottom one.

story: The tree has reached the extremity of its growth and no longer produces small, new branches at the top. Instead the existing top branch just grows longer and longer.
column3: Another version of that by mameha1977 and dat5h: [Cheat] Remember these as a set: The tree (木) has not yet (未) reached the extremity (末) of its vermilion (朱) foliage.
column4: The tree's top branches have grown to extremities.

story: Something that is obscure has not yet been brought before the light of day.
column3: 'Can't you go outside and get some sun?' 'Not yet, I have to learn all these obscure RTK3 kanji!'
column4: Things look obscure when the sun is not yet out.

story: The extremity of a wave of water is the splash.
column3: A splash is WATER that has reached its EXTREMITY.
column4: Timber! ...the extremity of the tree fell into the water the nearby lake. What a splash!!
