story: My mouth has not yet swallowed the food because the flavor is so delicious that I keep chewing it.
column3: To enjoy a food's FLAVOR, it must be in one's MOUTH but NOT YET swallowed.
column4: My mouth has not yet experienced such FLAVOR.

story: My younger sister is NOT YET a fully grown WOMAN.
column3: My YOUNGER SISTER is a woman who will always be not yet my age.
column4: My younger sister is a woman who is not yet fully grown.

story: It's autumn: only one vermilion leaf on the tree has not yet fallen.
column3: [Cheat] Remember these as a set: The tree (木) is not yet (未)[correction wrong character before] vermilion (朱).
column4: VERMILION is the color of the last leaves on the TREE which have NOT YET fallen in autumn.

story: Which tree would you buy stocks in - the healthy one on the left, or the one with only one vermilion leaf left on the right?
column3: Ideally, one buys stocks when a company is young, "green," and rapidly growing -- then sells them just before the last vermillion leaf falls off, and a period of dormancy or limited growth begins.
column4: I have a hot tip for you. Buy stocks in a company called "Tree and Vermillion Ltd".

story: The young little girl held a cute flower in her right hand.
column3: Young love puts a flower in her right hand (true love puts a ring on her left!!)
column4: Imagine Alice reading a note in Wonderland: 'The flowers on the right will make you younger. Those on the left will make you older.'

story: Grass grows in earlier than flowers.
column3: This grass is very long. The only flowers you can see are sunflowers – the rest are hidden by the grass.
column4: Grass grows early, before the flowers which eventually grow above.

story: Flowers for the old man suffering in the hospital.
column3: FLOWERS SUFFER when they grow OLD. Trees slowly wither(枯) and die. I find I can remember these together.
column4: If someone dies you suffer. You then put a flower on the gravestone.

story: "How many flowers can I stuff in your nostrils? Well I'm just gonna have to go and see." Bullying at its worst!
column3: Lets start a new campaign: Flowers Can Stop Bullying!
column4: The Little Engine that Could, drawing from his own experiences, has become a spokesman against bullying. He visits schools with the slogan "Bullying CAN be stopped," and hands out flowers of peace and understanding.

story: To be tolerant is to see flowers (meaning "beautiful things") in every house, instead of looking for drawbacks.
column3: Kanji Zen: See the flowers in the house. See the good in people. Be TOLERANT.
column4: My wife grows flowers in the house and I see them every day. I don't really like them, but I have to be tolerant.

story: A Dr. missing his needle can only use dilute flower water for medicine.
column3: [As suggested by stehr and on the forum (http://forum.koohii.com/viewtopic.php?id=1079), we create a new keyword 'seaweed' for the flower on top and water below and to the left. See also 落 (#299), 藩 (#1912),藻 (#2035). This story is for people using that idea.] The homeopath (a doctor without any needle) specialises in dilute medicines. This one's an essence of seaweed -- just dip the seaweed into the beaker, swish it about and remove. Barmy!
column4: Note This character belongs to a set of characters which share the flower/water primitive such as:: 薄 (#227), 落 (#299), 藩 (#1912), and 藻 (#2035).... (落 薄 藩 藻) It may be helpful to create a primitive keyword for this occurrence (like seaweed or watering can) which can save a lot of time distinguishing them from characters like Sino 満 and Full 満, where the water primitive is larger than the flower primitive.

story: On top of the leaves a flower appears, promising new generations for the old tree below.
column3: Tip: New primitive: Let Tarzan = generation + tree -- because Tarzan lives with several generations of his family at the top of a tree. (This combination appears five times: leaf (FRAME 228), 蝶 (#560), 喋 (#2280), 諜 (#2757), 牒 (#2934)). Story: In the flower shop you see Tarzan trying on various leaves (which he wears to cover his private parts).
column4: The flower generation spent far too much time up trees trying to smoke leaves.

story: If I find out this furniture you're selling me is made of imitation wood, I'll put you in the graveyard.
column3: The Japanese are so enamored of everything plastic, they even put IMITATION plastic trees in their graveyards! (No, not really, but I wouldn't be surprised).
column4: In graveyards, everything is fake, the flowers, the sun, and the little happy dogs. Heck, even the trees are just imitations. It's a clean aesthetic that's supposed to help people recover, but all the imitation material really unnerves me.

story: The precise locations of sailors who meet a WATERY GRAVE are vague.
column3: The water in the graveyard has worn away the headstones, so the writing is vague.
column4: The mist and fog surrounding the graveyard make things appear vague and unfamiliar.

story: The soil under a graveyard is full of graves.
column3: A grave is a patch of soil in a graveyard.
column4: The flowers were blooming, the sun was shining, when I let my St. Bernard off his leash and he lifted his leg and peed ON some freshly turned soil that was dug out for a grave. [Thanks to dwhitman for the idea of the peeing dog because the way the last stroke for 大 is shifted rightwards would mess me up, but if the dog's got his leg up in the air... it's a nice visual image for the change from the primitive graveyard.)

story: He made a livelihood out of robbing GRAVEYARDS in broad DAYlight.
column3: I like trikatu's simple way to remember this, but just in case the primitive placements confuse you, change it around to this: Before you complain about your livelihood, think about spending your days under a graveyard. Life is always better than death, eh?
column4: Before you complain about your livelihood, think about spending your days in a graveyard.

story: In the moonlight of the graveyard I hear a zombie say, MMMMM..EMM...BRANEsssss.
column3: The membranes in your flesh rot when placed in the graveyard.
column4: マク Membranes (thin layers of connective tissue) are the part of the body that decompose first (i.e., before the organs, ligaments, bones, etc.) after one dies and is buried in a graveyard.

story: If you plant seedlings in a FIELD eventually they will FLOWER.
column3: Crap! There are flowers in the rice field... Who let those seedlings get in there?!
column4: This is obviously a flower sprouting from a rice field, and means "rice seedling" in Japanese. My problem is keeping this kanji distinct from 圥, which Heisig dubs the "rice seedling" primitive (see 陸 (#1631) ff.). It might help to keep in mind that 圥 is a rare kanji (not used in Japanese) meaning "mushroom," so I will call 圥 the "mushroom seedling".

story: A bad portent makes the hairs on your legs stand.
column3: Two persons turning their backs is a bad sign. Hint: Don't use "turtle" as a primitive. You'll save a lot of troubles with following kanji if you give this primitive the meaning "a person's back".
column4: The actual derivation of this Kanji is a pictograph of the cracks on a heated turtle shell which was used in divination. The way the cracks occur on this turtle are a portent of evil bad luck.

story: The pits of a peach tree look like turtles.
column3: If you used the story about hairy woman´s legs for portent, then: PEACH TREE is the TREE that has HAIRY fruits.
column4: King Koopa consistently captures Princess Peach. Eventually he's going to run out of castles and just set her in a tree.

story: Sauron's One fiery eye stare at Frodo and it is a sign of portent. Evil will become whomever the eye is staring upon.
column3: You lost a staring contest with a turtle because you blinked your eye before he did. (The contest wasn't fair, because turtles have nictitating membranes, and don't need to blink so often.) Eye comes first, because stare is most associated with eyes. And compare with 挑 (#710) where this same obstreperous turtle challenges you to a finger wrestling contest. (Sibyl's story with some notes that helped me).
column4: Litterally this kanji reads "eye of portent". Imagine an old lady starring into the crystal sphere trying to portend the future.

story: A large dog, dripping drool.
column3: I don't know why not one single person before me has seemingly thought of this, but when I first encountered this character, it just seemed SO natural for me. It looks just exactly like a guy throwing a stick for his DOG to bring it back to him. Or am I really the only one seeing this picture?
column4: If we remember 大 (#112) as a man with his arms outstretched, the drop represents man's best friend - a dog.

story: It was left to the turtle to make right with the dog and thus maintain the status quo.
column3: A turtle mounting a chihuahua clearly disrupts the status quo.
column4: After beating the hare in a race, the turtle is now acknowledged to be the fastest animal. But the chihuahua is challenging the status quo, demanding a new race. And look - the dog is on the right, meaning he's passed the turtle! Hope he doesn't take a nap.

story: The computer won't stop beeping, which is making the chihauhua bark, and it's driving this guy insane. The only solution he can come up with is to throw them both on the fire and finally enjoy the silence.
column3: Your neighbor is so sick of you playing Led Zeppelin that he takes your copy of the song Black Dog and burns it. Finally, silence in the neighborhood.
column4: A scene of calm SILENC: You're typing away on your COMPUTER, while your pet DOG lies beside, a nice FIRE warms you both. No noise to disturb the SILENCE.

story: Flesh of a dog over a cooking fire = "hotdog". There are all sorts of things in hot dogs. Believe me, you don't want to know what sort of things . Visualize the hotdog curling as it cooks, to remember the unusual way the flesh primitive curves in this kanji. (tweaked version of ziggr's. Thanks!)
column3: There are all sorts of things in hot dogs. (I use hot dog for this primitive (meat of a dog over a cooking fire). I swear I can actually see the 月 here as a hot dog, with its slight curve and grill marks.)
column4: Putting the flesh of a dog on a fire is the sort of thing that will get you arrested.

story: REEDS are the only FLOWERS that WILD DOGS like to FIRE up and smoke while they are playing poker.
column3: A reed is a flower that looks like a hot dog.
column4: I turned 狄 into an element I call "savages" ("savages" are like a pack of wild dogs gathered around a fire. NOTE: 狄 is a kanji depicting a certain tribe of barbarians from northern China. Since both of those keywords have been used in the RTK series, I chose "savages". Reeds are flowers that grow like savages.

story: Actually when hunting it may be a good idea to use a pack of dogs as your personal guard.
column3: After a pack of wild dogs hunt some food, they will guard it fiercely.
column4: In every prison escape movie, the hunt for the escapees involves a pack of WILD DOGS unleashed by the GUARDS.

story: The cat hid in the FLOWERS of the FIELD from the WILD DOGs.
column3: Packs of wild dogs will chase a cat through flowers and fields.
column4: Although it's counter to Heisig, this is one of the few kanji I find easier to remember as a picture; specifically, one of a cheshire cat. The bushy tail is on the left, the flowers at the top are the eyes narrowed to slits, and the rice field is the big, toothy grin.

story: A cow tried to climb up a vermilion tree, but in doing so, it broke its two bottom branches off.
column3: This is a cow... Cow - How you say? Imagine a cow which has just been run over by a steamroller. Now you see, the head to one side, four legs and the tail backwards. Yes that is indeed a cow.
column4: The cow ate the roots of the vermilion tree.

story: Think of not special people, but special animals. The sacred Hindu cows are special - they can wander around the temple without fear of becoming roast beef.
column3: Cows at a Buddhist temple are special - they are holy cows! Sadly a few days later I find the same cows' meat on special at the supermarket. Holy Cow, what have we done!?
column4: The Church Lady is traveling through Japan and notices with distaste a sacred cow relieving itself inside a Buddhist Temple. "Well, isn't that special".

story: The revelation makes the cow's mouth drop down, "Hamburgers are made of what?!"
column3: In ancient times, the words from a primitive cow's mouth were considered a REVELATION because they were the "udder truth."
column4: When you get a revelation, you may drop to the ground with your mouth wide open.

story: I've never seen a cow with human legs before!
column3: Before Human Beings Existed.. Minotaurs Ruled The Earth! Their Top Half A Cow And Their Bottom Half Human Legs! Also: Using Minotaur as a primitive can make stories a doddle!
column4: I've never seen a cow with human legs before! (from gaijinda) I keep mixing this up with 前 (#309). Remember that before sounds like "beef or", so it must be the one with the cow in it.

story: In Japan, you always wash with water from the shower before you enter the bathtub.
column3: You wash things with WATER to get them back to the clean state they were in BEFORE.
column4: WASH with WATER BEFORE doing anything.

story: The two strokes at the bottom look like a J and I, which stands for "jammed in."
column3: Two people jammed in under an umbrella. A woman with a dress and a man (straight). It's always me that ends up getting wet.... but the tail of the skirt is this time!
column4: J and I are "Jammed Into" an UMBRELLA.

story: One Japanese farmer I know is so small minded that he thinks the entire world is JAMMED IN the borders of his little RICE FIELD.
column3: A famous philosopher once said that his world consisted of all the things he could jam into his brain.
column4: If you fit everyone in the world into a rice field, they would be pretty jammed in.

story: Some people think drinking tea is boring and quaint. That's why I spice mine up by adding a cocktail umbrella, which of course is made from a wood-en toothpick supporting a paper umbrella with flowers printed on top.
column3: When I drink herbal tea I like to drink it under a parasol. If it's too hot I go "ho, ho, ho !!" (katakana ホ).
column4: Tea is made from flowers dried under a canopy held up with wooden poles.

story: "Look", says the teacher in biology class. "The spinal column holds your flesh together, just like the metal rod of this umbrella (he demonstrates this with an umbrella covered in I-Ching symbols) holds the umbrella together".
column3: A pictograph of a spinal column. The umbrella representing the shoulder blades, the I Ching as the shoulder muscles and the part of the body as the spine itself.
column4: X-ray of a person 人 with 2 ribs 二 sprouting out on either side of their spinal column. The flesh 月 symbol reminds us that we're seeing through the flesh and this is an X-ray. 脊髄、せきずい, spinal cord (+ marrow).

story: He had such a big mouth that he could easily fit one whole umbrella in it.
column3: Meeting of mouths! We fit together so well, darling ;).
column4: This umbrella is so small you can only fit one mouth under it (one person).

story: In order to build a pagoda in this small Japanese garden everything has to fit: the soil to the left and the flowers in the upper right corner.
column3: A pagoda is a place of harmony in Japan. This means that even the "soil" where "flowers" are planted must "fit" together (good for remembering the order of writing).
column4: Pictograph-o-rama. This is a corner of a Japanese garden, with a small mound of soil on the left, and a little concrete pagoda in the front with flowers behind it. (To my eye, the fit looks a lot like a little pagoda anyway. This may or may not cause confusion for you, though...)

story: A King is one（一） who rules over the land （土soil）.
column3: To be king you have to be a real crafty one !
column4: The king unites heaven and earth. (imagine heaven being the top line over the soil).

story: The king is said to have only one family jewel below the belt...
column3: I can tell you that there is only one thing that Japanese people think when they see this Kanji, and that's BALLS(no joke). Kintama, or gold balls, means testicles. Funny story, we met a European girl not to long ago who had this as a tattoo, and she thought it actually meant JEWEL. But as I said, the Japanese guys wanted to know why she liked BALLS so much. lol (True Story).
column4: The king is said to have only one family jewel below the belt...and he hangs left! (I always screw up the direction of the "drop").

story: On treasure island is a single house - where all the jewels are stored.
column3: Put a "roof" (lid) on your jewels and voila! You've got a treasure chest.
column4: I have treasure: jewels which I hide in my house.

story: The king of the Oysters produces special Vermillion pearls!
column3: Usually pearls are white, or black. Only a very rare, very expensive pearl is vermillion colored. Such a pearl would be fit for a king.
column4: The king made everyone turn a bright shade of vermilion when he showed up wearing a PEARL necklace. (Tweaked for positioning purposes. Thanks ngoli1).

story: The KING ... can SEE clearly the PRESENT state of affairs in the land. (maybe he hees them in the crystal ball on the left?)
column3: Hey, I want my money back! This crystal ball is out of order, I can see the present instead of the future!
column4: Many people claim that Elvis (The KING) has been SEEN walking around in the PRESENT.

story: Even the king played with toys in the beginning.
column3: The ball was the only thing that people at the beginning of time had to use as a toy. Poor cavemen.
column4: 玩 depicts one of the most ancient TOYs known to mankind: MARBLES. The use of such small BALLs for play goes back to the BEGINNING of recorded history. (TOY MARBLES were found in Egyptian pyramids, for example.)

story: Oh no ! A pack of dogs has bitten the king. He has turned into a rabid lunatic !
column3: Think of King Nebuchadnezzar, who for 7 years lost his sanity and had to live like a wild animal.
column4: The wild dog king (Red XIII) had an awesome limit break - Lunatic High!

story: The Sun King (Louis XIV) was known for his effulgent reign.
column3: The sun is the effulgent king of stars.
column4: [+katsuo] This is the Sun King. Sayeth Wikipedia: "The Sun King (in French le Roi Soleil) because of the idea that, just as the planets revolve around the Sun, so too should France and the court revolve around [the king] ("http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louis_XIV_of_France). And just like the sun, he was quite effulgent and actually emitted sunlight.

story: Ancient Rome had Emperors instead of Kings, and they wore white robes. Thus an emperor is a king in white. (make sure you picture a roman emperor not a japanese one and you'll be ok).
column3: I don't think the Japanese would be happy if their emperor was a white king...
column4: An emperor is a holy king. In Japanese Shinto white is the holiest color.

story: The mouth of the king is displaying his bling.
column3: What a pathetic display! The king is sprawled on his throne, head back and mouth wide open, fast asleep. We should never have let him drink so much at that banquet last night.
column4: The mouth of the king displayed what a fool he was.

story: The fat king hogs the whole space under his umbrella. (tweaked version of radical tyro's story. "fat" makes a more vivid image for me.)
column3: The king takes up the whole space under his umbrella.
column4: King Arthur united the whole of England under his umbrella. (The umbrella methophore works pretty good here, due to England's miserable weather).

story: The fat king under his umbrella offers useless advice to the workers. "You'll need the whole tree to plug that gap". Imagine a grossly fat, incompetent king under a parasol giving annoying advice to sweating workers who know what they're doing. (I always have trouble bringing up the "whole" primitive. This story reminds me how to build that part. ).
column3: To plug the hole, you need to use a whole piece of wood - like a cork or something.
column4: Best example of a plug is a cork. A piece of wood that covers the whole opening (else it would leak).

story: The king of LOGIC is the computer.
column3: Computers are ruled by logic (it is the king of computers).
column4: If you used the meaning "House of the Parents" for 里 (#185), you will know then that, as logic dictates, the King must rule on his own Kingdom (the House of his Parents).

story: A lord is a little drop down from King in hierarchy.
column3: A lord only has a drop of the king's power.
column4: Although this kanji's meaning hasn't caused me much trouble, I've had problems remembering the direction of the drop above king, since drops at tops of kanji often seem to appear in different directions. To remember this one, I think of the placement of the drop in jewel (#256). Both of them use the king primitive and include a short drop stroke going from the top left to bottom right.

story: "WATER, my LORD ? I'll pour".
column3: Visualize an idiot trying to figure out how to extinguish a candle. He sees a glass of WATER and decides to pour it onto the CANDLESTICK to put it out. Water spills everywhere.
column4: Like water the hot wax poured down the side of the candlestick.

story: The main pillar in a house should be made of the biggest and strongest tree - the lord of the trees.
column3: "Wood Lord, what a pillar!", she said.
column4: This wooden pillar is like the lord of the house... (remove it and the whole house will collapse).

story: The fat king taking up the whole space under the umbrella actually isn't fat - he just has two big gold bars hidden under his clothes.
column3: Under the umbrella's shade, the king sang, " Drop it to the left, drop it to the right, give me all the GOLD in sight!"
column4: King Midas shelters from the rain under his umbrella. Every now and again he reaches out with his hands to turn a couple of raindrops into gold, and puts them in his pockets.

story: Pig-iron is crude metal (金) before (先) it is refined. If you have trouble with this character, envision a big minotaur (cow head with human legs) as a blacksmith, smelting metals and making swords for war.
column3: 100% of Japanese university graduates claim to have never seen this character, so impress them by remembering it, Pig-iron is metal before it has been processed. (Just a copy of the most common used story but with this little fact added, really impress your japanese friends or teachers by learning this one).
column4: PIG-IRON is the condition of IRON BEFORE it has been processed.

story: This is the BOWL of an alchemist: see how he mixes metals in his bowl, as he follows the instructions from his book?
column3: If I was begging with a BOWL, I would want GOLD and BOOKS.
column4: I actually picture a book made of gold that's been warped (due to the malleability of gold) so that it has a dent in the middle that can be used as a bowl.

story: I can't believe no one has used this one yet: Copper is metal which looks almost the same as gold. Really, look it up on Wikipedia, it's yellow and it's shiny (atleast in some compounds)!
column3: Copper is an excellent conductor. In other words, it's a metal for which the voltage is the same everywhere. That's why it's used for wires.
column4: A metal that looks the same as gold is COPPER.

story: All the people that go to the Japanese festivals to catch fish part time are suckers. Me? I'm a pro. I bring a big-ass golden ladle. I'm a true ANGLING professional.
column3: The easiest angling is pulling goldfish out with a big ladle.
column4: Imagine an effeminate Roman 2000 years ago angling with a golden ladle instead of a rod because it matches his eyes and hair better and it impresses the boys. (Why a Roman? Because 'angling' is just the roman-derived way to say 'fishing' - use this to distinguish fishing from angling.)

story: Remember the story of the needle in the haystack. Why would someone even look for a needle if it wasn't a GOLD NEEDLE?
column3: A golden needle is worth ten times more than an ordinary needle.
column4: The golden needle is the true needle.

story: A piece of metal with a name on it. Well, this is basically the definition of inscription.
column3: I imagine ancient Egyptian inscriptions: Pharaohs' names written in gold.
column4: The gold ring I gave her had an old girlfriend's name written inside. Here's hoping she doesn't notice the inscription.

story: Tranquilize - using a metal syringe to get the truth.
column3: Enough gold can tranquilize the truth in anyone.
column4: No need to tranquilize... enough gold will get the truth out of anyone.

story: When we go out on the ROAD-WAY, we often risk our own necks (that's why I take the train! ).
column3: Good keyword selection by Heisig: while the primitive on the left means road, the whole kanji also has the meaning of way, or 'tao (teaching)'. Thus, road + way. (Check out the wikipedia article on the Chinese Philosophical concept of "Tao": http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tao. It's this character!).
column4: Watch as a villianous fiend stretches a poor damsel's neck over a dusty road. Her ear pressed to the ground, she can hear the rumble of a carriage thundering down the roadway. Will the hero save her in time? Or will her neck be ground into the road, spilling it's precious contents into the dust?

story: For guidance on the road-way, glue a GPS unit to your car.
column3: Good guidance will help you stay glued to the right path.
column4: In his quest, our hero comes to a river of glue that he cannot cross. Desperate, he prays for guidance, and a roadway magically appears over the glue.

story: Cross-road.
column3: This kanji appears in the remarkable compound, 辻斬り 【つじぎり】 (n): killing a passerby in order to test a new sword. Imagine a cross by the road, at a busy crossing, marking the spot of the unfortunate passerby's death.
column4: A crossing is where the ROAD makes a CROSS with another road. Easy.

story: The car went too swiftly through the crossing and was hooked by the cops.
column3: In the Heisig version of Frogger, you can image ten giant fish hooks sweeping across the road, with our hapless hero 'froggy' forced to make a swift crossing or end up as fish bait.
column4: If you spread fishguts all over a crossing, people will definitely want to cross over it very swiftly to get away from the awful smell!

story: A cow creates a road by eating all the grass on its path.
column3: CREATION is the ROAD to REVELATION (if you're feeling artsy) :).
column4: Like Jack Kerouac, you create by having revelations on the road.

story: White lines on the road are there to urge you to stay on the correct side of the street.
column3: When you have the URGE to go to White Castle, you know it's time to hit the road.
column4: The two paths one can take in life are the white road and the dark road. I urge you to take the white road.

story: MARIO KART: When you're blasting down the road in Mario Kart, it's REALLY hard to escape from turtle shells. Especially the red and blue ones!!
column3: I used my pants to make a rope, which I then used to escape from prison; hence the naked, hairy legs running along the road!
column4: Escape down the road when you recieve an omen/portent warning of danger.

story: Caution: this kanji doesn't mean environment; it means "environs; boundary; border; vicinity". To separate the environs, create the border by placing daggers on the road.
column3: To protect the environs around their village, samurai would travel the roads with their swords.
column4: This kanji means area, vicinity. Such as this or that area. STORY: My mom told me not to go across the ROAD because the kids on the other side use drugs and carry KNIVES.

story: The cops don't PATROL anymore - they just flood the road.
column3: The Venice cops patrol on river roads.
column4: Crime has increased so the police have been recruiting PACMAN's to PATROL the STREETS. Here we see THREE of them PATROLLING around with their MOUTHS open.

story: My car is so fast it can go through ten rice fields in ten minutes.
column3: This one is quite simple, it looks like a car from above, with the frame, axis and big big wheels.
column4: Actually, this is a 10x10 car that can get you through a rice field.

story: When you put your car on the road you should always take along a few friends. Don't confuse with 運 (#303).
column3: This kanji also means "linked" or "series" so I've changed the kanji meaning to "GO ALONG (WITH EACH OTHER)." Well, a ROAD and a CAR certainly GO ALONG with each other. And the CAR will help you to GO ALONG the ROAD. This Kanji is the "Union" in Soviet Union and the "United" of United Nations (the countries that "go along with each other" at least some of the time).
column4: When I am on the road I always take along my car.

story: My car got so stuck in a rut it required nine people pushing to get it out again.
column3: My car got so stuck in a rut it required a baseball team pushing to get it out again.
column4: Hitler gets his CAR stuck in a RUT, so he yells "Nein! Nein! Nein! Nein! Nein! Nein!!!!..." Also, the Kanji is made up of NINE strokes.

story: The car is a cattle-car, used to transport animals for the butcher's meeting - a convention on new butchering techniques. Hear the screams of the animals as it pulls up in front of the convention hall, where the butchers are waiting with their knives out front.
column3: The vehicle transports animals for a meeting with the butcher.
column4: When flesh and saber meet... it's probably time to find some transport to the hospital. A car maybe?

story: Metaphorically speaking, all the equipment in your mouth is basically just a meeting of butchers, designed to pulverize whatever meat you put in there.
column3: Metaphor: A good metaphor flows from the mouth like the meeting of flesh and saber, smoothly piercing the listener with its meaning. But a bad metaphor is like when you barely nick the flesh and only spill two drops of blood or when your saber doesn't penetrate at all but rather bends into a くく shape when you whack the flesh. (Note: This story incorporates both the traditional form of the kanji (口＋兪) and the simplified form (口＋俞)) .
column4: A meeting of butchers is a perfect metaphor for the supposed secret talks(mouth) between Hitler and Stalin.

story: If you stand in front of a bull's horns, you are asking for your flesh to be cut (or butchered if you prefer).
column3: IN FRONT of the BUTCHER shop, there is a sign made of HORNS.
column4: At the bullfight, the matador stands bravely in front of the bull's horns. With his sword, he'll dig into its flesh.

story: In many asian restaurants, meat is roasted right in front of you over flames.
column3: "I'm going to roast you over a fire , お前," the angry gangster said.
column4: Put something in front of a fire to roast it.

story: Each person is gifted with a mouth to get us into trouble and a pair of walking legs to get us out!
column3: It's easier for me to remember a concrete object. This combination occurs often enough for me to make it a primitive element. Walking legs and mouth combine to give a "walky talky" or mobile phone. Imagine one of those old big ones which looked like refridgerators. Mobile phones are so popular that each of us seems to want one.
column4: EACH of us learns first to use our legs to walk and then to use our mouths to talk.

story: "Ranger! I want you to go check the status of each tree." "Errr, Each tree sir?" replies the ranger looking out over the vast forest. "That's Right, I want the status of each tree! Move out!"
column3: I find I need a more concrete image for this. EACH TREE has it's own STATUS. For example, the Christmas Tree is holy, the Willow is of high class while the lowly Bonsai is of low class.
column4: A person looking for status wants a tree of each kind in his garden.

story: It might sound simple to bribe someone, but then you have to graft the guy above him and the guy below him, and soon you're just giving shells to each and everyone!
column3: Graft: the acquisition of money, gain, or advantage by dishonest, unfair, or illegal means, especially through the abuse of one's position or influence in politics, business, etc. . STORY: The evil corporate extortionist grafts all who get within his power. He GRAFTs a different amount of MONEY from EACH of his victims. If they have more, he extorts more. He even plots it out on an evil graph!
column4: Graft is like bribing. You have to give MONEY to EACH person. There's a guy with a briefcase full of money and a walky-talky, and he's going around asking on the walky-talky about who he should give money too. "This guy gets money? Roger."

story: There are so many abbreviations and acronyms nowadays that no brain can remember each of them. Mnemonic: ab-brain-each-ation.
column3: A very anal farmer wants to catologue each grain of rice in his rice field. Imagine him scribbling a tiny abbreviation of his name and a number on each grain.
column4: Each landing field has it's own abbreviation; e.g. BNE for Brisbane, SYD for Sydney, DRW for Darwin etc.

story: Each person under my roof is treated as a guest.
column3: In my house I welcome each guest.
column4: Quite a rude guest walking around talking in his walky talky in someone else's home!

story: Sign the guestbook page with your forehead. (Picture a guestbook full of forehead prints like thumbprints).
column3: In New Zealand, people welcome guests by touching their foreheads together.
column4: Thankful guests bow so much, you never see their entire heads, just their foreheads.

story: In SUMMER you are hot from the top of your head down to your walking legs.
column3: One drop of sweat runs into my eye, when I go walking on a hot summer day.
column4: I personally think it was too confusing to try and use head as the primitive. (How am I supposed to remember that the animal legs are replaced with walking legs instead of human legs?) Rather, I think have the image of a hot summer and you want to keep oneself under a ceiling not out jogging around.

story: The best way to dispose of a nasty bit of wind is to let it go and use those walking legs to dissapear. Nobody will ever know it was you.
column3: To dispose of rubbish you should walk it to the bin not throw it to the wind.
column4: Contrast this with 捨 (#707). Disposing of something implies a degree of care, whereas discarding something is generally careless. You want to associate this with a careful way to get rid of something. You throw a piece of garbage into the wind to get rid of it, but remember that you should dispose of it responsibly and your walking legs carry you off to fetch it.

story: They all say they have a TREE between their WALKING LEGS but most only have a TWIG.
column3: Don't confuse with branch or bough - think of snapping twigs. A twig is always the kind of wood that snaps when the hunter's walking legs just barely touch it, making a snapping sound that alerts the prey to the hunter's presence.
column4: I don't believe this means twig as in a tree twig. 条 【じょう】 (n) (1) article (in document); provision; (2) stripe; streak; line. STORY: If TREES had WALKING LEGS they would march right up to congress and demand they put in a new ARTICLE into the constitution against deforestation.

story: Water each flower or the petals will wither and fall.
column3: [It's been suggested on the forum (http://forum.koohii.com/viewtopic.php?id=1079) that flower across the full width of the kanji and water on the left below it should have its own keyword; seaweed is a popular choice. See also 薄 (#242), 藩 (#2061), 藻 (#2191). This story is for the benefit of those using that idea.] Picture a group of Japanese skydivers falling through the sky -- suddenly each one opens, instead of a parachute, an enormous sheet of nori seaweed to carry them safely down.
column4: "Flowers" need "water" "each" day or they'll bend and fall over (helps with the order of writing).

story: The king's crown was blown off by the wind. "Oh well," he said, "it's just a superfluous symbol."
column3: The court jester wears a crown and is full of wind with bad jokes. He is superfluous to the King's court. This kanji is read as "JOU" and commonly used to create the compound for jou-dan 冗談 (jest or joke) hence court jester. Also jou-go 冗語 (redundancy) and jou-in 冗員 (useless workers) 員-員 (#59).
column4: Trying to put a crown on the wind is like gilding the lily: entirely superfluous.

story: The beast of hades one day will wear a crown, and the number of the beast is 666.
column3: In Hades you have to work six days a week before crowning it with something vaguely resembling a weekend. Oh wait, that's Japan.
column4: In Hades, as punishment, souls are forced to wear crowns as hot as the sun for 666 days.

story: British army cars are at the service of the crown.
column3: Imagine a crown is the hood ornament on every army car.
column4: The army has cars that are under the command of the crown - in ancient days these would have been chariots. (NB: "under" to help remember placement of the primitives.)

story: Rays of light emitted from Apollo's chariot = radiance. Don't put the sun into this kanji. The rays are coming from the chariot directly!
column3: Radiance is an army of rays.
column4: Radiance isn't just a few rays, but a whole army of them.

story: Don’t confuse it with “take along” (287). In that one, there was a car so you could take along your friends once you found them on the road. In this one, there is an army chariot just to carry military supplies (sorry no room for you).
column3: Roads carry armies (in contrast to seas carrying navies or skies carrying air forces).
column4: In the past, roads were established mainly to carry the army.

story: Remember the SUPERFLUOUS CROWN that flew away in the WIND? Well now the king is saying "i should have had the thing GLUED to my head from the BEGINNING".
column3: A crown, from the beginning of the new king's life, is glued to him. He must inherit it.
column4: That crown was glued together from the beginning...I swear!

story: Last night's date with Miss Sweden was like a dream. She even laid flowers over my eyes to crown the perfect evening.
column3: In Japan, "flowers over your eyes" is a metaphor for falling asleep and dreaming (just as the sandman is in the West). So we can make a little poem: Flowers over your eyes, The crown of a perfect evening.
column4: Sweet dreams like flowers for the eye are the crown of a perfect evening.

story: A whirlwind digs a hole in the ground throwing out lots of dirt until it ends up with a giant pit.
column3: Tazmanian Devil whirlwinds a pit into the soil. Note: Take care difference between pit and rut.
column4: All the soil was thrown to the left as the Tasmanian Devil's whirlwind swirled out a PIT.

story: Two little aliens in a trenchcoat and top hat, trying to look TALL. The bottom one, in the glass helmet, is under the coat. The top one has his top hat pulled down in disguise, so all you can see is his mouth.
column3: Here we have TWO MOUTHS each wearing a different hat. The top one is wearing a TOP HAT which is know to be as a TALL hat. The bottom one is wearing a SPACE HELMET which is known as an EXPENSIVE hat. (this kanji means both).
column4: Woody and Buzz-light year. Woody (in the cowboy hat) being Taller than Buzz ( in the space helmet) both with big mouths. Thx Minlawc! (adjusted for clarity).

story: In basketball however, tall children receive all the attention.
column3: A word of warning: With Heisig's story I keep associating this with "attention"! I use something closer tied to the word receive: Imagine a bunch of kids finding an old radio. It's antenna is broken, so the tallest kid has to hold it up, and becomes the designated receiver.
column4: Kinda weird but I remember the weird ones best: A giant MOUTH wearing a TOPHAT RECEIVES its next victim to munch on. This time its a small CHILD whimpering under the figure on the floor, scared of what is to come.

story: Welcome to our cram school: you will receive a rounded education on our grounds.
column3: In cram schools tall kids treat the round ones like dirt.
column4: "You can receive a well-rounded education if you study at our cram school" says the advertisement. "Just come to our school grounds and check it out yourself!"

story: Imagine tall children sitting round the fire toasting marsh-mellows.
column3: The cram school (309) tortures its students - especially the tall and fat ones who need to grow up - over a fire until they mellow. (Note that here the keyword 'mellow' only means to mature, ripen, or acquire skill; not the colloquial meaning of 'chill out').
column4: Changed keyword to mature. The tall kids 享 and round 丸 kids went through a trial by fire 灬 which forced them to mature. 熟する、じゅくする, to ripen: ぶどうは秋に熟します, "Grapes ripen in the fall." 成熟、せいじゅく, maturity: 猿は２，３歳に成熟する, "A monkey matures at 2 or 3 years of age." 人の体は３０歳前に成熟する, "A person's body matures before 30 years of age." 熟達、じゅくたつ, mastery, proficiency: 練習は外国語に熟達する唯一の方法だ, "Practice is the only way to master a foreign language."

story: The tallest Pavilion crowns the street.
column3: The Pavillion on crown street is the tallest I have ever seen.
column4: The upper pavilion of Tokyo Tower is very tall. Godzilla attacks Tokyo Tower, wears the upper pavilion of Tokyo Tower as a crown, and then uses the rest of the tower as a spike to skewer some other monster. Avoid 塔 (#254): pagodas are for fitting flowers above the ground, pavilions are from Tokyo Tower to wear as a crown.

story: Tokyo, capital of Japan: tall buildings, small people (compared to the buildings).
column3: The capital is where the powerful act formal wearing top hats, open their mouths, and get little done.
column4: Both the tall and the small are found in the capital.

story: When you're a tourist in the capital during the heat of summer, finding a water fountain is oh, so refreshing.
column3: The water from the capital of Japan, Tokyo, is so refreshing!
column4: It is a well known fact that the most refreshing water of a country can be found in the capital.

story: Imaging the sun rising over the capital--classic postcard scenery.
column3: Anyone who's been to Kyoto doesn't need to think too deeply into this Kanji! Imagine a sunny day in the old capital, and there's no better scenery.
column4: The sun shining over the capital is a nice scenery indeed.

story: If fish were cities, the whale would surely be the capital.
column3: When the whale was first discovered it was the biggest fish people had ever seen. Stories exaggerated its size - people said it was as big as the entire capital city!
column4: When you're saying a whale is just a fish, you're making a capital mistake!

story: The cottage is so small - it has an umbrella for the roof; soil for the floor and room for only one mouth. It's not even a whole shack (シャ). 田舎 いなか rural area; countryside; the sticks (2) ; hometown 宿舎 しゅくしゃ lodging house 舎 しゃ inn; hut; house; mansion.
column3: Picture a lidded crock full of tasty cottage cheese... yum! Now all we need is an umbrella over it to protect the cottage cheese from the sun.
column4: I strongly advise calling the combination of elements 土 and 口 a Hobbit. This will come in use in future stories, and you'll be glad when you get to ring (no. 836 環). The hobbit more often than not has dirt on his head (from living under a hill), and sometimes wears a garment (no.396 衣). The mouth we see is his, grumbling about something or other. Story: The Hobbit built his cottage under the Hill, using an umbrella as a door, to seal the entrance from the elements and intruders.

story: If my LIDDED CROCK has the same CIRCUMFERENCE as my head, I like to use it as a HELMET.
column3: When the ground has an opening (a hole), you need to cover the entire circumference or you will fall in.
column4: You're at a motorcycle store looking to buy a helmet. The only way to check the circumference of your head is to put increasingly larger lidded crocks on your head until one slips on just right. Now you know what size helmet to buy.

story: Imagine a road built so well that it takes only a week to travel the circumference of the earth.
column3: Actually the week is like a never ending road where we travel in a circle through the same seven days again and again, the circumference is always the same. 周 (#339) also means circuit or lap, so that also makes think about the rotations of the moon, sun and the earth -- all important for measuring all kinds of time periods.
column4: This city is so big, it takes a week to travel around its circumference by road.

story: What a handsome gentleman. Standing up so straight, and broad shoulders too!! He's like a modern samurai!
column3: A gentleman has broad shoulders and doesn't soil himself.
column4: Gentlemen are the opposite of dirty.

story: A true samurai gentleman will always mouth, "Good luck" to his opponents before a match.
column3: From the cow's mouth came a revelation. From the samurai's mouth comes just "Good Luck!"
column4: Good luck distinguishing this from lidded crock.

story: The image is a robust green bulging-muscle cartoon turtle. A TMNT with hachimaki. turtle-samurai.
column3: The Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles are robust gentlemen aren't they?
column4: Turtle samurai are more robust than regular samurai, because of their shells. (I'm trying to avoid TMNT here, because I tend to get the order of the primitives wrong. It's TURTLE SAMURAI, not Ninga Turtles).

story: A villa is fancier (decorated with flowers) and more robust than the average.
column3: The teenage mutant samurai turtles live in a villa with flowers on the roof so that the neighbours don't get suspicious.
column4: The villa was full of many gardens of flowers, and was guarded by a robust samurai with his turtle-shell shield.

story: A "samurai" will never sell his "crown" (king), even it meant having both his "human legs" chopped off!
column3: The samurai happened to find an extra large crown that he wore as a belt on his waist, just above his legs. I wonder if he will sell it to me?
column4: The victorious samurai sells crowns and human legs.

story: In the school house there are kids always studying. (BTW, atomiton, this is NOT 字).
column3: Children in schoolhouses are there to study, nothing else!!!
column4: A school house is a place for a child to study.

story: In a schoolhouse in class: 1) you see something on the blackboard, then 2) you memorize it.
column3: You'll never memorize all the kanji by seeing them in a school house. You need Heisig and RtK!
column4: When you are in the schoolhouse you must memorise what you see.

story: The TREES FLOURISH in the CLASSROOM, a little too much perhaps, there's no room for the students any more.
column3: Students are like young trees. They tend to flourish in the schoolhouse.
column4: Within the schoolhouse, the tree of knowledge does flourish.

story: Make sure you practice writing kanji with a brush every day before the sun goes down.
column3: With a brush, it takes all day to write anything.
column4: Imagine dipping a brush into an inkwell full of the sun, so that what you write can be seen at any time of day.

story: A brush laying in dirty water is a haven for bacteria.
column3: The haven for a BRUSH is in WATER.. Otherwise they get dry and withered and cant be used?!
column4: With his brush, Link draws a route over the water to a safe haven. (phantom hourglass).

story: Imagine a taskmaster giving a cow the command to "start breeding, and start doing it now!", except that the cow takes his advice a bit too literally and starts chasing the taskmaster to carry out this command! instead of finding another cow to breed with. Hence, you see the taskmaster running to the right, trying to stay ahead of the cow.
column3: Hint: This is the kanji from which taskmaster is derived. Actually, this kanji has nothing to do with breed, and a lot to do with pastures and shepherds (also for cowboys, japanese and spanish don't differenciate between animals). Think of a cowboy (taskmaster) who brings his cows to the pasture.
column4: The cow is forced by the taskmaster to breed.

story: AGGRESSION is a well-honed craft for any decent taskmaster.
column3: If the task master hits you with an I-beam... I'd say that's aggression!
column4: Aggression is the craft of the taskmaster.

story: The shell who was defeated before (負 (#67)) is being chastised by the taskmaster for his failure to win.
column3: If you end up in failure, you give money to the taskmaster to train you.
column4: Failure occurs if you let money become your taskmaster.

story: The taskmaster is a strict bathroom monitor who hands out only one sheet of really rough, splintery toilet paper per person. You can see the wood fibers.
column3: This taskmaster is the bathroom nazi: he counts how many sheets of toilet paper and tissue you use, and then tells you what % of a tree you just killed.
column4: The taskmaster whips sheets of paper off the tree.

story: An OLD TASKMASTER is no happenstance (coincidence). The older you get the more rigid in your ways.
column3: Only an old taskmaster uses a stupid word like "happenstance" instead of the many less pretentious synonyms for luck or chance.
column4: Need to disambiguate from 敵 (#475) as it's easy to mix up antique and old here. Let's think of an accidental president -- he is an old taskmaster who has managed to win the election by happenstance .

story: The flowery phrases of keigo (敬語) with which you must address the schoolmaster.
column3: 敬 【けい】 (n) reverence; respect. 敬語 【けいご】 (n) honorific; term of respect; (P) STORY: The TASKMASTER demands RESPECT. If you don't talk to him in HONORIFICS and FLOWERY PHRASES you will be sorry.
column4: Hitler's flowery phrases held the nation in awe.

story: A pictogram of someone saying a four letter word from their mouth after the censors have gotten a hold of it.
column3: This is simple a pictogram of a mouth SAYing something. The lines are soundwaves. No need to complicate it.
column4: This is such a hard one for me to remember in stories so I use Socrates to personify say since he is an orator. Just make Socrates the subject of your stories and whenever Socrates shows up you'll know this character should be written. Just picture him in his toga with a hand up in the air looking philisophical. You can try some other well spoken individual as long as they bring to mind speech, words, or say.

story: To admonish is to enforce awe by means of words.
column3: Watch in awe as mom admonishes the rude clerk with words that you've never heard her use before.
column4: Japanese police officers prefer to admonish perpetrators by aweing them with their words. You've never had a talking down to, until you've been a Japanese high school student caught littering in a small Japanese town. Just imagine the talking to that kid would get! Incidentally, this kanji is the first kanji in the word for police.

story: Say-ten's (satan's) evil plot.
column3: This does NOT mean a "summary of a book." It means plan, project, or to measure. STORY: A TEN WORD PLAN is a very efficient PLAN.
column4: It took only the words of ten men to plot the downfall of Caesar.

story: Words that tell you the results of the whole story really elucidate.
column3: Elucidate me. Tell me, in your own words, the whole story.
column4: Saying the whole thing should elucidate it for me...

story: The wild dog family visits their cousin in prison. They exchange words over the interphone at the visiting booth.
column3: Prison is a dog-say-dog world.
column4: The only thing keeping the new chihuahua inmate from being 'initiated' by the pack of wild dogs were his quick words in prison.

story: Revise, revise and revise until you have all the words nailed down.
column3: Remember how Martin Luther revised the words of the catholic church and nailed his 95 Theses at the door of the church in Wittenberg?
column4: You must revise your speech until you've nailed it.

story: Obituary. As a famous man lay dying, the media were already preparing the words of his obituary until a magician, with a wave of his wand, restored the man back to health.
column3: In the Harry Potter world, obituary's are magical. If you wave your wand over them you can hear the person's last words. Creepy!
column4: The words of the obituary were like a magic wand; removing all blemishes.

story: I said some bad words, and my mother chastised me by washing my mouth out with glue instead of soap!
column3: In Colonial New England, people who committed adultery had words glued to them. A famous example is the "A" worn by Hester Prynn for committing adultery (i.e., not being chaste). In this way, words glued to you are supposed to chastise you and prevent further breaches of chastity.
column4: If you chastise someone correctly the words will stick like glue.

story: The best type of Japanese INSTRUCTION is full immersion, which consists of going to Japan and swimming in the stream of words that surrounds you every day.
column3: Instructions are words that guide you, just like the stream would guide your boat.
column4: (technical) A stream of words (byte pairs) carries assembly instructions that are executed upon reception.

story: The mnemonic "words to seduce the masses" was just too vague and I kept forgetting it. So now instead I picture a seductive female reading aloud the imperial edict to the masses, thus "seducing" the masses.
column3: The emperor did not need an imperial edict; his words were more than enough to seduce Anakin to the dark side.
column4: The WORDS of an IMPERIAL EDICT are meant to SEDUCE the people and make them obey.

story: WORDS of GOOD LUCK are PACKED into fortune cookies.
column3: Nowadays, grafitti comes pre-packaged. The factory takes a bunch of words and aerosol cans and then makes sure the words get tightly packed inside. All you have to do is spray and everything takes care of itself!
column4: Words packed into an aerosol can: the tool of the graffiti artist.

story: Tales are always spoken, not written, and because of this, words fly out of your tongue, rather than your pen.
column3: Tales are spoken words, passed on from person to person, eventually being spoken by a thousand mouths.
column4: Tales are words from the tongue.

story: If you study some words for a recitation, there is a good chance they will be stuck in your memory for all eternity.
column3: Don't confuse with 詩 (#370). Focus on the re- part of re-citation: making a citation of words over, and over, and over, and over, and over again, until eternity.
column4: For me, the keyword suggests something not as pleasant as in James's Heisig story. In my mind, a recitation is when someone reads out loud something that they have read, without the slightest bit of improvisation or impersonation, in a very monotonous, and extremely dull manner. Hence, a recitation is a long-winded speech that seems to go on for an eternity (because it's so dull and you're so bored).

story: A poem is a temple of words.
column3: I'm saying this poem just for you, I built this temple from dirt and glue.
column4: WORDS used in a TEMPLE must be very well chosen. That's why most people will speak using a poem if they are SAYING something in a TEMPLE.

story: The simplest word to say is I.
column3: The rap group, the Five Mouths, always go around saying "word".
column4: I, the perceiving subject, need all five senses to learn the WORDS and language of Japanese.... holistic learning, not just rote memory work!

story: People will say (言) almost anything to make a sale (売); don't believe everything you read (読).
column3: Read the WORDS used to SELL things.
column4: Extra! extra! Read all about it! words for sale here.

story: To tune an old-fashioned radio, you turn the dial the full range of the circumference, until you can clearly hear what's being said.
column3: words + circumference The most catchy tunes are words the go round and round the circuference of your head and you can't get it out of your mind.
column4: This kanji also means "to investigate, check up, to search." STORY: You ever get a TUNE stuck in your head that someone was SPEAKING earlier in the day? It runs LAPS around your head and you cannot get relief until you 調べる the song online, download it, and listen t it.

story: Think of an online discussion group where misunderstanding someone's words leads to flaming. An angry discussion = inflamed words.
column3: Internet discussions often involve inflammatory words. Flame war!
column4: Discussing politics on the Internet always leads to heated words and flame wars.

story: The words of the very young are useless without CONSENT from their elders.
column3: Delores might say, "Yes!", but she's way too young give any legal consent.
column4: Consent is words given to the young.

story: A PETA activist speaks at a meeting of butchers to rebuke them.
column3: I imagine Socrates gate-crashing a meeting of butchers and REBUKING them: 'You've been killing things again; you have, haven't you?' while the embarrassed butchers blush and try to hide their knives behind their backs and stand in front of hanging sides of beef.
column4: A good rebuke is like being verbally slaughtered.

story: Each Indian tribe crafts their arrows in a certain style..
column3: The latest style is shirts crafted out of arrows.
column4: Legolas mastered the CRAFT of shooting ARROWS, so shoots with style.

story: In an essay test, you are judged on both your choice of words and your writing style.
column3: The Japanese oral exam was a test of my speaking style.
column4: Tip: This kanji and a few others have keywords whose meanings overlap in English which may be confusing - 試 (#378) 試: test (the water), try (and see), 校 (#1371) 校: examine (text), 検 (#1803) 検: examine, inspect (not a school exam or test), 診 (#1860) 診: (medical) check-up, 験 (#2134) 験: examination, experiment (similar to 試) .

story: II (older form of writing 2). After shooting one arrow (the dash top left), I have 2 arrows left in my quiver (bottom left).
column3: II: To remember this Roman numeral, give each soldier I quiver and II arrows.
column4: Once you have two old arrows left in your quiver, you better start running...!

story: An astronaut lands back at the launch range, kisses the earth beneath him with his mouth, then heads off to a fiesta to celebrate a safe flight.
column3: When the land was within range, the pirates kissed the deck and had a fiesta.
column4: An extra drop on an arrow? That's a spear, Heisig, not a fiesta! The extent of land that is within range of my spear is everything to me, I kiss it (mouth on ground).

story: Burglars... those guys!!! Burglars only want money (clams) so that they can get needles (drugs) and party (fiesta)!
column3: After the fiesta, we found out that some burglar had stolen our money, probably breaking in with a lockpick needle...
column4: The burglar tried to steal my money by using a lockpicking needle, so I impaled him to the wall with my spear.

story: The plantation is where we get our Christmas trees. We pick them out at Thanksgiving to be sure we get a good one.
column3: During Thanksgiving, all the trees on the plantation celebrate the harvest. It's a good time for them, too.
column4: During the harvest festival, all the trees on the plantation celebrate what a good job they did producing fruit.

story: Load the crops into the wagon in preparation for the harvest festival.
column3: Every November I load my car with turkey, ham, sweet potatoes, dressing, cranberry sauce, mashed potatoes, gravy, corn, rolls. There's so much food, it sticks out the windows. I drive to my family's house for--that's right--a Thanksgiving dinner feast!
column4: This kanji means to be published or printed in ink. Imagine a newspaper article about 10 cars being speared by giant swordfish.

story: When your garden gets OVERGROWN, it's like the plants are mocking you. Here, you can see the roses actually parading around the yard, wilfully choking out the other, more docile plants. Then they actually go and parade down the street!
column3: At the flower parade, (hippies' parade) all I can see is walking masses of overgrown hair!
column4: I use scythe as a primitive instead of parade. A scythe is like a spear (see [356]) whose tip has been bent to use for scything. When flowers have overgrown your front yard, use a scythe to cut them!

story: (Using the RTK1 supplement so I haven't had "uncle" yet.) When you take visiting relatives to a parade, hold the little ones up above so they can see over the crowd.
column3: Your half-uncle is leading a parade of your relatives. (Note: 上 + 小 makes up part of "uncle" 叔, so I've called it "half-uncle".)
column4: People carry their small relatives above their shoulders so they can see the parade.

story: It only takes a single stroke of a dagger for a parade to TURN INTO a bloodbath.
column3: An extra dagger makes the scythe turn into a double bladed weapon! (Using the spear - scythe primitive instead).
column4: He was able to turn his dagger 刀 into a spear 戈 by attaching it to a stick 丿 (the first stroke). 成る、なる, to become (usu. kana); 成年、せいねん, adulthood, majority: 娘は今年成年になる, "My daughter will become an adult this year." 成人の日、せいじんのひ, Coming of Age Day; 平成、へいせい, reign of current Japanese emperor, 1989--.

story: The sand castle is just the 土 (#161) that turns into a castle.
column3: "Someday this mound of dirt here will turn into our CASTLE", the ants think to themselves when scoping out a new ant hill.
column4: Sand sculptors can turn even the most ordinary soil into the most beautiful castles.

story: Sincerity happens when what you say actually turns into something.
column3: Sincerity is turning your words into actions.
column4: Words turning into actions is a sign of true sincerity . You do what you say (せい) you will. Marco and (まこと) his Brazilian friends need to learn this - they say they won't smoke pot inside anymore, but still do it -- that's not being very sincere.

story: The march of women - against intimidation in the workplace - is pretty intimidating in itself!
column3: Interesting that this kanji also has the meanings of "dignity" and "threaten." I can see how a march of women in Japan would be seen as intimidating by most men.
column4: I use Grim Reaper instead of march for the primitive, because he's the one holding the scythe (see [360]). Now imagine a female Grim Reaper - that's even more intimidating!

story: Water flows down to destroy the march of fire.
column3: Use a water cannon to destroy a line of marching fire monsters. I keep mixing this one up with 災 (#179) and 壊 (#427). Remember, you DESTROY monsters (think of the Godzilla movie "Destroy All Monsters!"). Fires and floods are natural DISASTERs. And DEMOLITION is something you carefully do while wearing protective garments. (vaguely based on stefanot's balrog story).
column4: Lord of the Rings: Orcs, all carrying torches (in the night, for visuals) and intent on destroying everything in their path, are utterly destroyed by the releasing of the waters (by the Ents).

story: When WATER was tossed on the PROTESTORS (a march of mouths), the numbers began to DWINDLE.
column3: When water supplies dwindled, the population became a horde of dry mouths, marching to seize the water in the neighboring kingdom.
column4: When water supplies dwindled, one mouth raised a cry and led a march on the city!

story: They gays were reviled by society, so they put flowers above their eyes and marched around.
column3: Note: Whether you see a "drop" or a "one" in the bottom left of 蔑 depends on the font your computer is using at the time. Newer fonts prefer the "one".
column4: The hippes, with flowers above their eyes, looked down upon and reviled those who marched into war.

story: Japanese festival floats are often so tall they need wood scaffolds to be completed. (http://www.japan-guide.com/e/e5909.html).
column3: You need a SCAFFOLD made of WOOD to build a FLOAT if it will be several stories high.
column4: HINT: Near as I can tell from the Zhongwen site, the figure that Heisig designates as a "float", actually means "lances broken into pieces" (though there's a third stroke in the Japanese version of the kanji rather than two in the Chinese), thus I'm using broken into pieces to identify that particular pictograph. STORY: A scaffold is made of WOOD BROKEN INTO PIECES.

story: Interesting fact: The Japanese one yen coin is the only coin in the world that can float on water. http://www.hanamiweb.com/floatingyen.jpg.
column3: Gold coins will not float.
column4: Think of the gold coins floating in Super Mario games.

story: The water can't be too SHALLOW if you expect to float.
column3: The water is too SHALLOW to float in it.
column4: A parade float full of devout Christians is attempting to recreate Jesus' walking on water phenomenon. They claim to be able to do it because of faith, but only reason they are managing to do it is because the water is shallow.

story: If you find in the ground a walking stick with a magic wand, STOP! Maybe it's some kind of macumba/black magic/voodoo bad thing.
column3: This looks like a little police officer sticking his hand out (first two strokes) signaling for cars to stop as a schoolboy/girl is following behind (third stroke). The final stroke is the road.
column4: Gandalf took his magic wand, which looked like an old walking stick, and stuck it in the ground, before bellowing, " STOP! YOU SHALL NOT PASS!"

story: When walking your pet, you must stop a few times along the way when nature calls.
column3: When you learn to walk, you take your steps a few at a time. Picture a clumsy but happy toddler who falls every few steps but keeps getting up to try again.
column4: When you take a walk you should stop a few times to smell the roses.

story: A ford is a place where one can walk through the water, a place only a few footsteps deep.
column3: Fording is simply walking through water.
column4: The new Ford Jesus. It can WALK on WATER. (edit on ngoli1. I think negations make stories hard).

story: I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head. I repeatedly walk around hoping this kanji will come into my head.
column3: Are you familiar with the joke about the ditzy secretary who repeatedly walked back and forth forcibly over all the pages of her boss' most important letters. When confronted she just says "Well you said they needed to be stamped before they're mailed."
column4: FACT: Saddam Hussein put a mosaic of Bush on the floor of the Al Rashid hotel so as people would be forced to repeatedly walk on his head. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al-Rashid_Hotel.

story: A secret agreement between a covert gov't agency and aliens states that we will not step foot on the moon again in return for alien technology.
column3: The peace agreement put a stop on the fighting for a month.
column4: Neil Armstrong had an agreement with NASA: I will be the first one to leave a FOOTPRINT on the MOON. REMEMBER the position: the FOOTPRINT is over the MOON.

story: Mary Poppins floated down with her umbrella to undertake the job of stopping the children's misbehaving.
column3: In Resident Evil, you UNDERTAKE a mission to STOP UMBRELLA from infecting the country with the T-Virus.
column4: The Undertaker is an evil WWE wrestler - he beat his opponent with an umbrella until he stopped moving.

story: A CURRICULUM is a calendar that replaces days with reasons to stop having fun.
column3: A curriculum (vitae) is similar to a calendar except that, instead of mentioning every day in your life, it only mentions the main stops. (Compare 暦 (#226)).
column4: A little like a calendar, your CV records your footsteps through time.

story: ONE-ARROW can STOP a warrior.
column3: A great warrior can stop any 0pponent with one arrow.
column4: The traditional warrior carries a quiver of ARROWS. But the warrior must never forget his real purpose: to STOP conflict, not cause it.

story: A warrior stands guard at a bridge collecting shells as a levy for any who want to pass.
column3: A levy is money collected to fund kingdom's warriors.
column4: "Drove my Chevy to the levy but the levy was dry. And those good old warrior boys, drinking whiskey and rye, said pay up the clams or you'll die. Pay up the clams or you'll die..."

story: If you do it correct on the first attempt you can stop.
column3: My (Japanese) wife tells me that Japanese people use this kanji to tally up numbers (instead of 4 vertical lines and a diagonal across). I remember this one by writing the kanji while counting out the strokes to myself and saying this is the correct way to tally numbers.
column4: The correct way to tackle any problem is one step at a time.

story: Your words must be absolutely correct if you plan to use them as evidence.
column3: "If what you say is indeed correct, we could use use your testimony as evidence".
column4: Evidence proves that your words are correct.

story: Those involved in politics are always trying to elect the correct taskmaster.
column3: Insane political correctness on the left, and facists taskmasters on the right- thats politics in a nutshell right there.
column4: Politics is all about electing the correct taskmaster.

story: In The Karate Kid, the boy must prove his determination by MENDING his teacher's HOUSE in various ways.
column3: Prior to buying a home, the home inspector will come into your house and determine everything that needs mending.
column4: 定める 【さだめる】 (v1,vt) to decide; to establish; to determine; (P)The primitive "mend" is too arbitrary and I can never remember it. New primitive meaning: CORRECT PERSON: Do you see the 4th and 5th stroke? They look like the kanji for "person." Therefore, CORRECT + PERSON = CORRECT PERSON. STORY: I DECIDED/DETERMINED I would fix my HOUSE this summer but am still looking for the CORRECT PERSON to do it (i.e. a contractor).

story: Even if you lock up your GOLD, a DETERMINED thief will get it in the end.
column3: A lock is a piece of metal that will determine who can or can't get in.
column4: A LOCK is metal that is determined to keep intruders out.

story: Hint: This kanji is NOT soil on top of mend, as Heisig claims - that would duplicate one of the strokes. Instead, it is 10 on top of mend. So my story is: If you run 10 miles, you will need to mend your socks!
column3: The sports ground needs MENDING after the game as the players have been RUNNING around which has caused the ground to be chopped up.
column4: The soil needs mending after the cross-country run.

story: A successful marathon runner needs to be able to transcend seductions, such as the possibility of rest, shelter from the rain, or a cold beer.
column3: To transcend to a higher path you need to run from the seduction of earthly desires.
column4: To transcend oneself is to reach a higher plane of reality. A head shaven monk is telling me this. We are in a Tibetan monastery. He was once an athlete, a runner. He used to run everywhere, until one day, he saw a beautiful cheerleader along his path. She tried very hard to seduce him, but he forced himself to transcend his urges. He did reach his running goal, and he has became a lonely monk. He wishes now he had just broken down back then and....

story: "Don't run into trouble," Dumbledore tells Harry. "Proceed with caution with your wand out."
column3: You go through airport security. "Proceed," mumbles the guard after he wands you. You run like crazy, because you're late for your flight.
column4: While running, my magic wand tells me where to proceed.

story: The person in charge of running the parade surpassed all our expectations (by just a extra drop...)
column3: The parade of runners are all trying to SURPASS each other - and they end up running all the way to Vietnam (note that this kanji is also used for the country of Vietnam).
column4: A RUNNER will always SURPASS a PARADE.

story: 'Sun' 'Mend' - It just so happens that sunshine can mend your gloomy spirits.
column3: I spent all day mending to make things just so.
column4: My image here is of Fabrice (the guy who runs this website) spending all day obsessively mending the code so this page looks just so...

story: The "TOPIC" of the day's newspaper must be placed JUST SO at the top of the PAGE to attract attention.
column3: You spend ALL DAY, mending your socks JUST SO. Then you have a look at the HEADING of the newspaper. The topic---FREE SOCKS TO BE GIVEN AWAY!!!!
column4: Topic; subject. Combine this (是 - これ) with page (頁) and you have this page. A topic or subject is information on this page (i.e. the current page). Think of the page figuratively as any sort of information - it does not have to be a page - it could be what you are thinking about or discussing. If the sun is shining, you can read the page correctly and understand the topic.

story: Making a dike is all about arranging the soil just so...
column3: The little Dutch boy has his finger stuck in the dike, and that's the only thing keeping his town from going under. He really really needs to go to the bathroom though, so he devises a plan to carefully add a bit of dirt - there, place individual bits in just so - there, I think it's good enough. Pull it out -----yes! Success!
column4: Imagine Indiana Jones replacing a gemstone with a small bag of soil. If he doesn't weigh the soil just so, a huge dike behind the wall will break, washing him away.

story: Build is easy to remember if you can remember that archtiechts have two steps in building. 1. Take a brush and brush out the blueprints. 2. Get a visual image of the blueprints all rolled up like they usually are. The second step is easy, it's just the architecht stretching out the blueprints and showing it to his clients.
column3: A construction worker's classic morning. Stretch, brush his teeth, and then start to build.
column4: To build a skyscraper, you have to stretch it upwards until it brushes the sky.

story: The metal thing you need in order to enter things you build is a key.
column3: In Zelda, the gold key will let you into any building.
column4: 鍵盤鍵 (#418) ケン, かぎ ... Parts: 金, 建 (cf 建物建 (#417), 健康健 (#1048)) ... Story: The most important Metal in any building is the lock on the front door, and without a key you ain't getting in. This kanji means both lock and key to most Japanese people. 錠前 is technically the word for lock but it's not used in daily conversation.

story: Stretching correctly prolongs life. Even the top part of 正 is stretching...
column3: Here's a great mnemonic: "stop, drop, and stretch (!?)." Now let's associate it with 'prolong': if you're ever in an uncomfortable spot, like being asked tricky questions or caught in a lie, just PROLONG the situation - stop, drop, and stretch. They may be confused by your odd behaviour, but it'll buy you a few moments to think up another good lie to get out of the sticky situation!
column4: The inquisitor prolonged the torture because his victim didn't answer the question correctly. He turned the wheel stretching out his limbs even further.

story: Nativity = born, being born. Think of birth as a painful and prolonged event. And of course, all the words and curses being yelled at the soon-to-be father for doing this to her!
column3: When you are being born ( nativity ), your mother's WORDS are PROLONGED. (Thiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiis huuuuuuuuuuuuuurtss a lottttttttt~!! Owwwwwww!!!)
column4: At Nativity (christmas), the priest says more Words (sermon) than the rest of the time, Prolonging mass duration.

story: Features like stones and groves of trees are the cornerstones of a happy zoo.
column3: A zoo which is still under construction is already full of animals. At the moment, only the cornerstone has been set in place. To temporarily keep the animals from escaping, a closely-packed grove of small trees is planted around the stone. (Note that this zoo needs some serious mending.)
column4: Stone Grove Zoo is the new cornerstone in animal exhibits! If you love animals you need to check out Stone Grove Zoo!

story: The only reason anyone talks about a bridegroom is if they're about to or have just gotten married. Of course, then you have to go on your honeymoon. So you take your woman to the zoo for a month. Pretty cool honeymoon.
column3: Imagine a bridegroom having his wedding with his woman in a zoo on the moon. That will impress her! Fill out the details with the bride and groom floating with a menagerie of animals with astronaut helmets floating, bumping and attacking one another.
column4: The bridegroom will take his woman to the zoo for a month long honeymoon. (Simplifying dihutenosa).

story: The only garments allowed in this club are top hat and scarf.
column3: The garments most commonly associated with the craft of a magician are the top hat and the magic wand. (It's a stretch, but the way I remembered this kanji is through that phrase. This way you can remember it through using primitives we have already learned.)
column4: A snowman wears a top hat and a scarf for garments.

story: The tailor was hard at work making sure all the pilgrims were dressed in their best garments for thanksgiving.
column3: The tailor worked hard after thanksgiving to alter garments so they'd fit people who'd eaten too much at their thanksgiving dinners.
column4: My TAILOR made me 10 garments for the upcoming fiestas.

story: The TURTLE SAMURAI needs special GARMENTs for his ATTIRE since his body is much more ROBUST than others.
column3: Attire is more robust than a garment.
column4: The ninja turtles tried to go eat at a fancy restaurant, but they were told to come back after their were dressed in proper attire. However, it's too difficult for them to find proper garments because they bodies are so robust! (sannomiya + drwarrior12).

story: The computer had carefully dressed up in clothes to look human. It was n't until I looked at the back and saw the cables and stuff that I realized what it was.
column3: I'll be back ! says the computer Terminator, disguised with a top hat and a scarf.
column4: The COMPUTER wore a TOP HAT and SCARF to hide it's cables at the BACK. (裏　うら　bottom/back/reverse).

story: If you stand too close to a DEMOLITION site, the dust might sting you like NEEDLES in your EYE and get your GARMENTs all dirty.
column3: Since that needle eye thing turns up a lot, I turned it into Darth Vader. It kinda looks like him to me, with the eye being his metal mouth piece thing. So, Darth Vader swings his cape (his garment) demolishing a nearby building, leaving nothing but a pile of dirt.
column4: During demolition, dirt and debris can feel like needles in your eyes if you're not wearing ther proper garments.

story: One of my friends with a crazy sense of fashion loves to wear a tophat and a scarf so that you can't see his whole face but only his mouth. He thinks it's cool. I think it's pathetic.
column3: A poor, homeless child like Oliver Twist, with a hungry open mouth, is pathetic-- in the original sense of the noun "pathos." The tattered tophat and scarf he wears only adds to the pathos.
column4: Other definitions include grief, sorrow, pathos, pity, and sympathize.
