IMO the english word pathetic is often used nowadays to mean a sort of "contemptuous pity" but I think we need a more compasionate definition to understand 哀 , now and especially later when it starts being combined with other words...So, here's the top part of frame 308 享 (receive) but where the child was is now replaced by a scarf. Whatever fate befell the child is up to your imagination. grief, sorrow, pathos, sympathy, pathetic.

story: Keep distant from a lidded crock on the road wrapped in a scarf. It might be a bomb.
column3: The upper right part means long kimono. 袁 is not in Heisig list, but if you remember it, you have an easier time later on. "Long kimono" is easier than "lidded crock with scarf." For its story look at Kanji 34945. Story for 遠: In distant lands down the road, they were Long Kimonos. As supposed to here in Shibuya, where girls with prurient interests wear mini kimonos.
column4: When traveling to a distant land, what better way of keeping warm on the road is there than carrying a warm lidded crock and wearing a scarf?

story: The MONKEY likes to play hide and seek with the PACK of WILD DOGS by hiding in the LIDDED CROCK. But he is easy to see because the SCARF he always wears is at the base of the LIDDED CROCK.
column3: To catch a monkey, chase him with wild dogs into a lidded crock, then tie it with a scarf.
column4: Honestly, I hate the "Lidded Crock with a scarf" metaphor. It makes no sense, and I just can't get an image that "sticks" with it, at all. Besides, it sounds retarded. The original meaning of the whole right side of this Kanji is "Long Kimono." So, put a wild dog in a kimono, stand him on two legs, and you've got something that looks like a man but still feral - a monkey.

story: "This is the first time we've been out of the Shire, Mr. Frodo!" Says Sam, covering himself with his cloak and clutching his dagger.
column3: Not only did I put on my robe and wizard's hat for my first time, but also my cloak and my dagger. That's when she walked out on me.
column4: The CLOAK and DAGGER trick only works the first time, when the element of surprise is there. Anyone would be a fool to fall for it twice.

story: If it looks like a towel, speaks like a towel and walks like a towel... I wonder why Heisig didn't include this one (as an actual kanji) in RtK 1.
column3: A pictograph of a person wrapping a towel around their waist.
column4: Obvious towel is obvious.

story: A matador holding his red linen by his side.
column3: The first rule of the Hitch-Hiker's Guide to the Universe is "DON'T PANIC!" The second rule, of course, is to always have a towel by your side. Personally, I prefer the linen sort.
column4: A linen towel should always be by your side just in case .

story: A towel makes a mediocre sail.
column3: When stranded at sea, we needed a Sail. The best we had was a TOWEL, which was MEDICORE, only catching a DROP of WIND.
column4: A sail is a piece of cloth used to catch every drop of wind.

story: In the west, the rich use $100 bills to light their cigars... In Japan, after showering, when the wealthy don't have any clean towels, they simply grab a hanging scroll off the wall and use it to dry off!
column3: The towels of the wealthy: hanging scrolls.
column4: Check out http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hanging_scroll to get a visual image of a hanging scroll. The wealthiest man in Japan uses such precious hanging scrolls as towels.

story: If you wear a towel as a cap, you are at risk of being seized and searched in U.S. airports.
column3: Originally the first cap was a turban which was a towel wrapped around the head to keep the sun out of the eyes.
column4: Because it's a risk to stay under the sun in the desert, Arabs use to wear a towel as a cap.

story: There is a graveyard outside my house that scares me, so I put a huge towel over the window to serve as a curtain so I can get a good nights sleep.
column3: When a mobster says "It's gonna be curtains for you!" He means you'll be wrapped in a towel, dead in a graveyard.
column4: If you've read Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (SPOILERS AHEAD!)...think of the curtain in the depths of the Department of Mysteries, and what happens when Sirius encounters that curtain. (Well, yes, it's technically a veil, but since Heisig doesn't use that as a keyword, think of it as a really big...um...towel.)

story: A canopy is a towel to block the suns rays.
column3: From the Hitch-Hiker's Guide to the Universe: A towel is useful, among other things, as a canopy to keep out the sun's rays from your face while napping.
column4: Picture a cafe in wartime Japan. Its' canopy is made of a big beach towel which has the imperial flag (the one with the sun's rays) printed upon it.

story: Brocade is the art of sewing gold on a white towel.
column3: Never heard of this word before encountering it here. So it turns out that the fanciest brocade in the world is actually a towel used by a Turkish monarch. It's embroidered with gold and cocaine. Yes, cocaine - what you thought it'd be something else? That is some true art right there. I think a great many people would want to own this towel.
column4: "Brocade" means 'twisted thread', and is usually made with gold and silver. Here it is written as a towel woven with gold and white.

story: My recurring nightmare: Walking through the market, and suddenly realizing that I'm wearing only a top hat...and a towel.
column3: At the MARKET you find lots of nice TOP HATS and TOWELS.
column4: An investor gets a tip while in the shower. With no time to loose he runs down to the stock market, only wearing a bath towel. And the top hat, of course, according to the dress code at the stock exchange.

story: Nobody buys persimmons at the market, because there's a tree in the middle where you can pick them for free.
column3: Persimmon = かき - they grow on trees and are sold at the market.
column4: The tree growing in the market bears persimmons.

story: Unlike the younger sister (妹), who is not yet old enough to date... the elder sister is on the market!
column3: She's old enough to be allowed to go to the market.
column4: My ELDER SISTER is a WOMAN who works at the MARKET.

story: The PART OF THE BODY most important if you work at a MARKET is your LUNGS so that you can shout out at the top of your voice "IRASSHAIMASEEE" to attract customers.
column3: LUNGS are a PART of the BODY that can be found at any meat MARKET or black MARKET.
column4: So that I could breathe when I got there, I visited the moon market to buy a new set of LUNGS for my trip to the moon.

story: Heisig fails to go into detail about the top kanji, but, It's not a mountain like everyone is saying. It actually means Thirty 丗 the stroke order starts with a One, then draw in the three vertical lines from left to right. Then the last stroke at the bottom closing it up. Then comes the Apron which makes up a Sash. (-Story: I made a Sash out of Thirty cut up Aprons.
column3: WARNING: Try to avoid thinking of the upper element as a combination of one and mountain, because in this case you will get used to the incorrect stroke order.
column4: The buckle is on the sash of the apron. (Note that according to the dictionary, breaking down this Kanji includes only the radicals for "walking stick", "one", "crown" and "towel". Hence, "mountain" is not part of the radicals.)

story: History of the first karate blackbelts: In those days, it was often difficult to find fresh, clean water, so samurai usually had to wash their sashes in stagnant puddles. The longer one had been studying martial arts, the older the sash on one's karate uniform and, therefore, the darker the color. So why weren't their karate uniforms black too? Never seen a ninja????
column3: A moat is a stagnate ring of water like an obi (sash) of water tied around the castle.
column4: The water became stagnate because the drain was clogged with a sash.

story: A TREE with a BELT wrapped around the middle. If you tighten the BELT, hundreds of tiny SABERS pop out of the tree in all directions, looking like THORNS.
column3: The BELT TREE has THORNS like SABERS.
column4: The tree was covered with a belt of thorns. They cut like a sabre!

story: The system for making leather belts involves slicing up a cow with a sword.
column3: Why all the gore and violence? How about a samurai cow? He doesn't have to be a violent samurai, either. He only wears the sword because he's part of the bushi SYSTEM. Actually, he studies ikebana, shodo, and zen. Imagine him sitting cross-legged in a Zen temple (a very Special Zen temple). The master asks him if a dog has buddha nature and, shifting the swords in his belt, he calmly replies, "Moo!"
column4: Gary Larson cartoon of the feudal Japanese system: cows walking around with belts, complete with katana sabers. The Sa-MOO-rai class system.

story: Made in... is a system of labels you can find on every garments.
column3: A SYSTEMATICALLY made GARMENT will no doubt have MADE IN on the label.
column4: We have a system in the US where all garments have labels saying what country they are made in.

story: The REVOLVING wheels of the car (with REVOLVER blaring on the stereo) kicked up RISING CLOUDS of dust.
column3: Just a note to remember the cloud primative: The name of Goku's pet cloud that he used to help him rise (fly) in the Dragonball anime series (and also the scientific name for a certain type of cloud) is Nimbus [ http://www.rpgclassics.com/shrines/gba/dbztlog/screen2.jpg ]. The katakana-ization of this is ニムバス, so the rising cloud primative is just an abbreviation of that name written from top to bottom in the old Japanese style.
column4: Burnout! As the car's wheels revolve the rubber burns making a rising cloud of smoke!

story: Imagine an old Kung-fu movie: "Try my rising cloud flower technique!!!" smash pow crack!! .
column3: Illusionists have a technique, they make flowers disappear, leaving only a rising cloud of smoke.
column4: If you watch BLEACH, you know one of the most powerful TECHNIQUES is Byakuya's Bankai: senbonzakura kageyoshi. It looks exactly like a RISING CLOUD of FLOWERS.

story: From the ceiling hangs a towel dripping four drops like RAIN.
column3: The rain falls from the sky, landing like teardrops on my windows.
column4: It rained so hard that we had to put a towel under the ceiling to contain the drops that came through.

story: Every rising cloud is a potential rain cloud. (Thanks astridtops).
column3: Every cloud is a potential rain cloud.
column4: A cloud represents the stage of the earth's water cycle between when rising clouds of water vapor head for the sky and when rain falls.

story: Cloudy weather is when a cloud blocks the sun (up above).
column3: I have difficulty remembering that the rain is ABOVE the clouds, which is not its logical spot. This is cloudy weather, not rainy weather. So I imagine the sun raining down on the clouds instead.
column4: The sun is above the clouds, the definition of cloudy weather.

story: If it's raining and you're standing in the middle of a rice field, you're sure to soon become acquainted with the thunder up close and personal.
column3: Thunder is a sure sign of rain coming. When you hear the thunder, you've got time to get out of the field before it starts raining.
column4: I've been told by Japanese people that this word, 雷（かみなり）　means BOTH thunder and lightning together. Though there is no individual word for thunder, there is for lightning (いなずま）, so I understand where Heisig is coming from. Just remember a powerful storm over an empty field and you're sure to remember this kanji.

story: FROST is kind of an inter-weather, phenomenon, something between rain, snow and freezing temp’s.
column3: The inter-action between rain and cold makes frost.
column4: The freezing RAIN formed FROST on the TREE right before your EYES. If you want, frost-y then think Frost Tree to get to the mnemonic. SECOND STORY: FROSTY the snowman? It's RAIN that FROSTS that can then INTER-act with the kids, till he melts of course.

story: Don't slip off your legs in winter, strap two skis to your feet.
column3: In winter my walking legs feel like blocks of ice.
column4: In Winter, there's ice beneath your walking legs! Be careful, even just two icelets could slip you up!

story: If you think of the sky as a ceiling above our heads, here you have the heavens as the largest ceiling you could ever imagine. As Heisig pointed out, nothing comes above the ceiling primitive thus the order of primitives is taken care of.
column3: The ceiling that all large dogs aspire to go to is known as heaven. After all, All Dogs Go to Heaven.
column4: Tip: 天 and 夭 (heavens and sapling) are different, but RTK confuses them sometimes. The latter appears in numbers 634, 938, 2078, 2079, 2080, and all characters containing angel 喬 (429, 430, 1221, 2104, 2120, 2369).

story: If you don't want to get bewitched (and who would?), then avoid any woman you see carrying what might appear to be a sapling. It's really a wand in disguise, and if you're not aware you might get bewitched.
column3: sigh. For some reason, Heisig never seems to understand the difference between 夭 and 天. This uses the former, which means young/sapling. Surely it's not hard to imagine a young witch messing up a spell and accidentally bewitching everyone around her?
column4: I was bewitched by the woman fairy (like an angel, but not as tall).

story: You use water to irrigate your saplings.
column3: Water from the heavens is nature's way of irrigating.
column4: If you need your plants IRRIGATED call the WATER WITCH. Dial 1-800-H20-WITCH Today!

story: A small 5 year old child has lost her mother in a tragic death. Her family tells her, "Don't worry, your mom is an angel now, in heaven, watching over you." The small girl takes this very literally and is found one day, gathering pieces of wood. Her dad asks her, "What are you doing with that wood?" "I'm trying to build a bridge to heaven to visit the angels."
column3: The wooden bridge is guarded by an impressively tall angel.
column4: ANGEL primitive: On the bottom there is a HOODED MOUTH, which you can think of as a NUN; and shes praying to an ANGEL, which is the HEAVENLY MOUTH above.

story: The most attractive of women are said to resemble angels. Similarly, angelic women tend to be attractive.
column3: Be careful not to confuse this with exquisite (women + few - frame [123]). I try to keep them distinct by remembering that all women angels are attractive, but few women are truly exquisite.
column4: Just because a woman is attractive doesn't mean she's an angel.

story: A vase that can't stand up won't be a vase for long.
column3: This is a real stand up vase. It even wears a top hat!
column4: Stand up a vase on a table and put a top hat on it and then represent it pictographically and there you have this kanji!

story: Guys have two ways of watering when they are standing, the less common one is crying.
column3: She stood up to leave the room when her eyes started to water...
column4: If you cry really hard you can fill up a vase with the water from your tears.

story: In the military, badges are given out early in the day, with everyone standing at attention.
column3: Ash Ketchum stood up early in the morning, and said, "Pikachu, let's go get us another badge!"
column4: Those who STAND UP EARLY receive a BADGE.　ショウ　文章　ぶんしょう(a sentence).

story: TWO twin BROTHERS are competing (VYING) for the title of who is the older BROTHER. The game is that they must balance a VASE on their head and the one who drops his looses and becomes the younger BROTHER!
column3: Two crazy brothers vying for the guiness records books of stupidity by trying to stand on their heads the longest.
column4: Two teenagers vying to see who stands tallest.

story: The crazy sovereign stands up from his throne, wearing nothing but a crown and a towel. That's why they try to keep him locked up in the castle away from the public.
column3: This one is so tricky for me. The key is to remember that the bottom stroke on the standing element takes those little crown "winglets" on the right and left. The most effective image might be of QEII (who is quite short) using her crown as a kind of stool. She's standing on her crown rummaging through a high cupboard looking for her apron. I guess the sovereign's servants have the day off.
column4: This are the kanjis where stand looses it's final stroke: No group: 商 商 (#471), 傍 傍 (#1090) Antique group: 嫡 嫡 (#472), 適 適 (#473), 滴 滴 (#474), 敵 敵 (#475), 摘 摘 (#709) and 鏑 鏑 Kazoo group: 識 識 (#521), 職 職 (#887) and 織 織 (#1432) Sovereign group: 帝 帝 (#466), 締 締 (#1440), 諦 諦 (#467) and 蹄 蹄 (#2770) Lad group: 彦彦 (#1852), 顔 顔 (#1853) and 諺 諺 (#2754) Products group: 産 産 (#1681), 薩 薩 (#2962). Story: Think of Rome. Now picture a sovereign standing with a crown and a hanging cloth. Careful! 傍 傍 (#1090).

story: The words of the sovereign king inspire the people: never give up! Never surrender! Okay...maybe it wasn't a king.
column3: Anytime I think to give up Japanese, I remember giving my word that I would become sovereign of Japanese! And I watch あきら to get pumped about it. Note: to give up - 諦める is read あきらめる).
column4: You can go to Wikipedia and hear the words of Japan's sovereign Emperor Hirohito announcing that Japan would be giving up World War Two. (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gyokuon-h%C5%8Ds%C5%8D under External Links).

story: The juvenile stood on top of his computer and broke it. Noob.
column3: This one is really easy if you gave 里 (#185) the meaning "House of the Fathers". Most juvenile people stand on the house of their fathers, because they can't yet afford their own house.
column4: The movie Zoolander is a little JUVENILE and silly, but I love it nonetheless. Just remember Owen Wilson standing on the desk, hitting the computer like a monkey. (The files are IN the computer - IN the computer...).

story: In Japanese comics, the eye's of juvenilles all have enormouse pupils.
column3: WARNING: This kanji only means the pupil of the eye. It can be confusing to use a story that has pupil meaning student in it.
column4: In Japanese comics, the eye's of juveniles all have enormous pupils. WARNING: This kanji only means the pupil of the eye. It can be confusing to use a story that has pupil meaning student in it. (greenapple + codexus).

story: The METAL bell rings to call the JUVENILES to class.
column3: The golden moment for juveniles is when the bell rings at school.
column4: Remember that show, Saved by the Bell? It had a bunch of juveniles in it, and in one episode they actually tried stealing the bell because it was made of gold!

story: Four loudmouths trying to make a deal on a vase.
column3: Slick Willy standing on the motorcycle helmet he's trying to sell you to demonstrate how rugged it is. His legs crash through the top of it and after a moment of awkward silence his mouth opens and says, "hey, we can still make a deal."
column4: Why is everyone talking about prostitutes when this is clearly about the Little Mermaid? Ariel made a deal with Ursula because she wanted to stand (remember the lyrics "Bright young women, sick of swimmin', ready to stand"). She traded her voice (represented by a mouth) for a pair of legs. The hood is the head-scarf that Ursula briefly wears while singing right before the boob jiggling scene (i.e. one of the most traumatic moments of my childhood).

story: Legitmate wifes tend to be women who are antiques in contrast to the young bit of illigitmate fluff on the side.
column3: The woman you'll want to be with even when you're both antique should be your LEGITIMATE WIFE.
column4: When the legitimate wife finds her husband flirting with another woman, she'll take the valuable antique Ming-vase and whacks him with it over the head. That should teach him a lesson!

story: Think of the term from televison "suitable for all audiences" to get the sense of the word. What program could be more suitable for the whole family than the "antiques road(show)".
column3: It's an antique, but it's still suitable for the road.
column4: Even today, some antique Roman roads are suitable for travel.

story: DRIPS of WATER were collected in ANTIQUE VASES since the museum had a leaky roof.
column3: You must never let water drip onto antiques.
column4: The antique faucet DRIPS water.

story: The taskmaster became my enemy for life when he smashed the antique vase holding my wife's ashes.
column3: In Indy Jones movies the enemy is always a taskmaster who is after antiques.
column4: Link must destroy ANTIQUE vases to replenish items when fighting the TASKMASTER, his main ENEMY.

story: To remember the primitive meaning, picture someone sitting on the ground performing Seppuku...with a spoon. http://tinyurl.com/co48k.
column3: Not only is stroke order important, but also be sure to note the direction of a stroke. In both 'spoon' and 'seven', the first stroke is the horizontal one - but here it is written right to left in a downward flick, while in 'seven' it is a strong line from left to right.
column4: I sat on the ground, feeding myself jelly with a spoon.

story: A kid gets scolded if they don't put the spoon properly into their mouth when eating.
column3: Kids get scolded if they don't open their MOUTH to take their SPOONFUL of medicine.
column4: Well, how do you picture getting SCOLDED? You listen to that MOUTH while you have to SIT DOWN there and take it.

story: The aroma of any delicacy is bound up in a spoon.
column3: The BOUND UP SITTING MAN is going crazy because he can smell the aroma of fresh cinnamon buns, but can't get out of the ropes.
column4: Note that 匂（ におい） means good smell and 臭（におい） 臭 (#128) means bad smell. Story: Cheech/the muchacha (#451) smells the aroma of tacos but he spent all his money on dope.

story: An alarm clock with a unique design: You set it for, say, 7:00 am, and at about that time the clock reaches out with a spoon and hits you on the head.
column3: It's about time to sit down and read another page of Remembering the Kanji.
column4: "About that time" is a typical expression for a recipe: "add a pinch of salt after about two minutes." And since recipes are generally written down on pages and are about preparing something that can be put on a spoon...

story: In the north, the weather is so cold that people are often seen sitting back to back to preserve warmth.
column3: Warning: The left part is NOT the primitive turtle! The stroke order is different. Sometimes it will look exactly the same but not always depending on the font / style used to draw this character. Be sure to study the difference!
column4: Codexus wrote: Warning: The left part is NOT the primitive turtle! The stroke order is different. Sometimes it will look exactly the same but not always depending on the font / style used to draw this character. Be sure to study the difference! My 'story': There are NO turtles at the North Pole. What looks like turtle-backs are actually Igloos, so small you can barely sit inside them.

story: While japanese people are generally small, people in the northern contryes have taller stature because of all the flesh they eat!
column3: Stature/height has to do with how far "NORTH"(upward?XD) your FLESH/BODY goes.
column4: Your STATURE is measured from the northern most part of your body.

story: Compare the two spoons... the one on the left is funny-looking.
column3: STROKE ORDER NOTE: Beware, the horizontal stroke comes first. Actually, the left character is the katakana character ヒ(hi). Story: If you carefully compare hi (ヒ) and spoon (匕) you'll notice their subtle differences.
column4: In the kitchen, compare the taste of the two dishes you're stirring with a spoon in each. Mmm!

story: Grandparent spends all DAY COMPARING photos of their DESCENDANTS.
column3: Japanese people have compared themselves as being descendants of the sun. (Amaterasu, the sun godesss). Sun, comparing = descendants.
column4: Ask a Japanese person what this kanji means, and they will surely spout 昆布 (konbu, seaweed)　and 昆虫 (konchu, insect) - but beyond that they will likely be mystified. Here's my best crack at it: imagine a grandfather watching his DESCENDENTS (grandkids) playing outside under the sun, silently comparing them, considering which of them will grow up and make him proud. Suddenly, grandma calls them in for a snack of 昆布 and for a re-application of repellent to keep the 昆虫 away.

story: If you compare colors, you will find that white is produced from the mix of all the others.
column3: All detergents claim that, when comparing to other brands, they produce the whitest laundry. But you can save lots of cash when you realize that they're all ok.
column4: Unfortunately, EVERYONE in Japan compares how WHITE they are (hence, ALL these whitening creams, etc).

story: Block letters (as opposed to cursive) are rigid and lifeless like wood; they're all the same size so that all can read them.
column3: Print-style writing (as opposed to cursive): All print-style writing looks rather wooden to me. I prefer the fancy curves of cursive. (Note: Heisig gives this character the official keyword "block letters," but based on what I've read about the meaning of the character in the Yahoo! Japan Dictionary, I prefer "print-style writing").
column4: Literally the block letters on children's blocks, carved into wood so clearly that all can read them.

story: harmonious: If a choir is to be harmonious, all the voices need to combine to hit the right notes, and say the right words.
column3: To have orderliness, your words must be in all the right places.
column4: When you say 言 something and everyone 皆 does it, that's orderliness.

story: People have to mix their fluids (have sex), in order to create descendants.
column3: It was a MIX of elements, happened millions of years ago, that created the first bacterias in the WATER. From them we are DESCENDANTS.
column4: Our WATER DESCENDANTS (i.e., mermaids), are a mix of man and fish.

story: You awaken from your siesta because you feel extremely thirsty so you go looking for some water.
column3: If anyone is having difficulty creating stories with the primitive siesta, try changing it to beggar - a beggar sits in his box begging for food/money under a hot sun. I have used beggar as a primitive in several frames and it works like a charm. Here a beggar develops a deep thirst for water as he crouches in his box under the hot sun.
column4: Have some water before you take a siesta, or you will wake up thirsty!

story: The talk was so boring the audience took a siesta.
column3: Note: The keyword meaning is "Have an audience with . . . (Pope, King, etc)". Story: When you arrive for your audience with the Pope, he appears to be dozing. His assistant says, "Sorry about your audience, but you won't get a word out of him while he's having his siesta".
column4: If you break up SIESTA into tongue wagging in mouth, bound up, sitting man, you have somewhat the image of a prisoner begging. This gives you the general sense of BEGGAR. Using BEGGAR as a primitive is better I think. A 渇 (#488) beggar begs for water. A BEGGAR SPEAKS requesting an audience(to beg for money), a beggar's garments are usually 褐 (#490)(dirty), and beggars sleep so much when they open their mouth, their voice is 喝 (#491). (btw, chinese etymology: the bottom part of siesta means to beg).

story: Mexicans use a cloak (pancho) for their siestas. Their color is usually brown.
column3: Why is my package late? Imagine a UPS driver dressed in BROWN garments taking a siesta. What can BROWN do for you?
column4: The hobbits from "The Lord of the Rings" just had to crawl under their brown cloaks and they could take a siesta.

story: If you have a siesta with your mouthopen, you will wake up with a hoarse voice.
column3: After taking a siesta, you find that your mouth is hoarse (after all you ARE thirsty remember).
column4: When you are hoarse, it's time for your mouth to have a siesta. (I don't like relating this to thirst, mixed them up a few times).

story: Flower, siesta: The muchacho was not careful. He passed the warning signs and decided to hold a siesta in the kudzu field. The kudzu grew so fast, he was completely covered by it in a few hours and not able to escape. Now, the kudzu flowers mark his grave.
column3: The muchacho takes a siesta under the flowers of the kudzu.
column4: Kudzu is a flowering plant that never takes a siesta...it grows constantly and has already overtaken most of the southeastern United States. Beware the kudzu!

story: Use a spoon to eat a DELICIOUS hot fudge sundae. Duh..
column3: It's sooo delicious I could spoon it in all day.
column4: Instructions for delicious: 1. Find said delicious 2. Get spoon 3. Spend all day eating.

story: Every chef will tell you, fat is what make the meat taste delicious.
column3: Fat is the most delicious part of the flesh. (Note this refers to physical fat, not the concept of obesity 肪 (#533)).
column4: Well, after months with nothing else but delicious food - of course you get fat!

story: You visit a shrine to say your wishes and offer delicious offering to the gods.
column3: On New Year's Day, Japanese people usually read the words written on their New Year's cards (nengajou - 年賀状), eat delicious special New Year's foods and visit a shrine to pray for good luck in the coming year (thx mantixen).
column4: As a man of reason, Socrates knows the only reason to visit a shrine is for the delicious food.

story: The samurai who has been crowned number one is so good he uses a spoon to fight with rather than a sword.
column3: Imagine Neo (a futuristic samurai aka The One) wearing a Burger King crown, in the famous scene from the Matrix where he's told "There is no spoon."
column4: Unlike roman numerals there's nothing archaic about the usage of this kanji. This is how you'd write 'one' on a cheque so the person you paying it to can't change it into a 'two' or a 'three'. So with that in mind, the hard up samurai (士) has been selling (売) his crown (冠) is now sitting down (匕), you give him a cheque for 1 yen, but are sure to customize it for him. You write it 壱yen, so he can't change it to a 3 (三) before he cashes it in!

story: Freud believed every man wants to lie down with his mother.
column3: Every mother looks forward to the end of the day when she can finally lie down.
column4: Every ( 亻) person has a (毋) mother.

story: Every master(or taskmaster) must have some degree of cleverness.
column3: Cleverness is something every taskmaster must have. Every taskmaster has cleverness.
column4: Every master(or taskmaster) must have some degree of cleverness. Note the "ever" in cleverness -> every.

story: Plums actually grow on every single tree. What, you didn't know that? They do. Orange trees, apple trees, cantaloupe trees. Plums are simply mutant fruits that have been installed in the root software of every single tree. I hear that some plum-loving scientists are working on a way to hack every tree's genetic code so that every tree will bear nothing _but_ plums.
column3: EVERY Japanese person asks you if you like UMEBOSHI. No I say, I prefer to eat my PLUMS fresh from the TREE.
column4: Plum trees have fruit on every branch.

story: Every drop of water will eventually return to the sea.
column3: There is water in every sea.
column4: As depicted in the classic SF film Fantastic Voyage, every drop of water is a sea, if you look close enough. Imagine peering through a microscope at a vast sea teeming with microbial life (and perhaps a minaturized submarine). Note: Take care not to confuse with 洋 (#549).

story: Lying down, Captain Hook is begging to be spared from the ticking crocodile.
column3: People that beg have a hard time in Japan. They have to lay down, and for most of the time they only get fishguts.
column4: The homeless man lying on the street with a hook for an arm begged us for anything we could spare.

story: During a drought, everything begs for even a mist for relief.
column3: During a drought, even mist is begged for.
column4: Beggar has to drink mist because there is no water in the drought. I get this one confused with thirst 451 but try to remember that there is no water element beacuse it is a drought.

story: The only body part that doubles over.
column3: Imagine getting punched in the abdomen, a fairly tender part of flesh, and instead of doubling forward, you double back. That would be pretty painful.
column4: The part of the body (flesh) that is exercised when we lie down and bring our walking legs toward the sun (aka: leglifts) is the abdomen.

story: My girlfiend saw someone wearing the exact same (duplicate) outfit at a party, so she doubled back to change!
column3: In Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, Hermione uses a device called a "time-turner" to double back in time, but this creates duplicates. The smart thing to do would be to combine Hermione's time-turner with Harry's invisibility cloak. That way, one could double back in time without creating any visible duplicates.
column4: The magician took his CLOAK, FOLDED IT (DOUBLE BACKED IT) and DUPLICATED it!! Amaaaazing.

story: To me, this kanji looks like a person with two arms and two legs, but who lacks a head.
column3: When your body lacks oxygen you yawn.
column4: A PERSON BOUND UP due to work is tired and LACKS sleep, hence YAWNS.

story: How am I supposed to BLOW if I lack a mouth? (Imagine a kid at his own birthday party, and - like Neo in the Matrix - had no oriface where his mouth was to be. And yet, the people cruelly cheer him on to blow out his candles...).
column3: After your mouth opens and you yawn, you BLOW out a lot of air.
column4: Blowing makes your mouth lack air.

story: Japanese cooking sometimes lacks fire, e.g., sashimi.
column3: This character shows the difference between a cook and a chef: a chef prepares food with passion and love; a cook only stands there with a pan over a fire, with no passion and just yawning.
column4: How can you cook something when you lack fire?

story: Can-Can-ers lack the ability to sing a song, so they just dance.
column3: Do you know the "Obama song"? It goes like: "Yes we can, yes we can!" The problem is, the lyrics repeat so often that everybody starts yawning sooner or later. - This is no political comment ;-).
column4: The Idol contestants think "I CAN I CAN SING THIS SONG" but most of them LACK talent.

story: Cars are rough steel things, lacking softness.
column3: If your car has really soft seats, you may start yawning and eventually fall asleep at the wheel (imagine that this seat is a huge soft beanbag that nearly swallows the driver, and it will be easier to remember).
column4: Someday, they will invent SOFT cars. The cars will be so safe that accidents will become no big deal. (Imagine drivers yawning as their cars crash into each other and bounce harmlessly away).

story: Is this store lacking ice? Let's try the next one, then.
column3: A rapper called "Ice" went for auditions but was told he lacked talent. Next...
column4: A lack of ice is the next phase of global warming.

story: To prevent animals from eating the beautiful flowers in your garden, the best thing to do is to plant briar bushes immediately next to them.
column3: The briar patch may look unremarkable now before it blooms, but there will be flowers next, and it will be beautiful.
column4: An important life lesson: Briars are always NEXT to FLOWERS.

story: Assets are the next best thing to money.
column3: The first SHELLS you get you obviously spend, but the NEXT SHELLS are your ASSETS, you should bury them in a low safe place (placement!)
column4: I invest my assets in NEXTEL and SHELL.

story: The next woman always has a better figure! Thinking like that, you'll end up alone in an old folks home longing for the good old days!
column3: Whenever I am next to a woman, I can't help but take notice of her figure.
column4: The next woman always has a better figure ! Thinking like this is a burden weighing down many women. - (Thanks to alantin, but the last statement helps me get the placement right - it always used to be a problem with this kanji).

story: Having a word with the next mouth over, like a neighbor, is usually a good way to consult with somebody for cheap. Because, you know, actual consultants charge huge sums.
column3: "Consulting with" is having words with the next mouth.
column4: Don't like the words of the first one? Consult with the next mouth available.

story: Compensation is money you give to someone to shut them up (i.e. muzzle their mouth).
column3: Compensation is a kind of euphemism for hush money here. Money that muzzles.
column4: I expect compensation for the bite I recieved when you didn't muzzle your dog.

story: To cultivate the land is to tame it, control it. In short, you muzzle it's unruly, chaotic nature. 培う つちかう to cultivate, to foster; 栽培 (さいばい) : cultivation.
column3: The illegal immigrants cultivate the land but are socially and politically muzzled (wear muzzles while they work too).
column4: In olden times the land (soil) was cultivated by farmers who were muzzled by the land owners: they were prevented from expressing their opinions.

story: When you DIVIDE someone, there is sure to be a lot of screaming. That's why you should use a MUZZLE before using the SABER.
column3: Divide and Conquer: Shut 'em Up and Cut 'em Up.
column4: The two women keep arguing about whose baby it is. So Solomon muzzles the both of them, pulls out a sword, and prepares to divide the child between the two.

story: If you were standing on the sun, believe me, you'd be making sound.
column3: The tongue wagging in a mouth produces a very high-pitched sound, breaking a nearby vase.
column4: Note that sound is very close to the muzzle primitive (it has the sun instead of the mouth at the bottom) - but in meaning they are precisely opposite!

story: Picture the sun exploding - there would be a gigantic noise and then...nothing. Everything would plunge into darkness.
column3: Total darkness lacks sun and sound.
column4: In places of complete darkness, such as caves where the sun can't reach, creatures such as bats have learned to navigate by sound rather than sight. The poor guys must have to fly around screaming "Marco!" and "Polo!" all the time.

story: What is a RHYME but some SOUND that EMPLOYEES say to get them through work.
column3: Dr Seuss's employee finally rebels against him: "I'm tired of odd sounds all the time, I will not, cannot, speak in RHYME!"
column4: A rhyme is the sound of an employee going off to work. Everyone knows that ever since 'Snow White' in 1937 all employees sing 'hi ho, hi ho, it's off to work I go' (because it's so catchy! And it's so catchy because 'ho' rhymes with 'go'!).

story: Words are difficult to discriminate/discern from sounds in the middle of a fiesta.
column3: I wonder why Heisig didn't use discernment for this kanji. It fits the meaning equally and it is not as loaded as discrimination. // It is quite hard to discern words in the middle of a noisy fiesta.
column4: I have discriminating taste. I'd rather listen to the words of a lecture than attend a kazoo concert. (Picture some snobby guy in a tweed jacket turning up his nose at entering a loud raucous kazoo recital).

story: Mirror should suggest vanity. Imagine a spoiled girl who gets her parents to buy her a Golden mirror so she can stand in front of it all day vainly admiring her lovely human legs.
column3: The metal mirror makes a sound - it's answering the question "who has the fairest human legs of all?"
column4: TIP: 竟 = ENDPOINT (Sound 音 travels with its legs 儿 until it hits an ENDPOINT, like a wall or mirror, and can be then reflected) STORY: Alice stepped into the other side of the golden 金 mirror, the endpoint 竟 of reality, and arrived to Wonderland. [thanks Kayin].

story: In the dense cities of Japan even a small garden is a luxury. In this house, the owner has put mirrors on the boundary of his land so it feels much bigger.
column3: Be aware the right-hand character 竟 really means "endpoint" or "finally"; it's commonly read "つい" (as in "ついに") and usually written in kana alone. A boundary represents a country's land's endpoint (awkward phrasing for order) .
column4: 竟 = tsui (final, end). So 境 = SOIL + END, or the end of the land. End of the land = its perimeter, the boundary!

story: The top hat hanging on a hook belonged to the now deceased Charlie Chaplin.
column3: The recently DECEASED are said to hang their hats on a hook by the door to the afterlife.
column4: A deceased man's hat will forever rest on the hook.

story: Deceased eyes! Easy ;).
column3: A person with deceased eyes is blind.
column4: Rather than "dead eyes," break down DECEASED into TOPHAT and FISHHOOK, and picture each blind person's EYES as being unable to see because their eyes are covered with a TOP HAT, that's attached to a FISHHOOK stabbed in their eyeballs.

story: I had a problem with remembering that "deceased" went over the "woman". So, here's my story: The delusional woman was carrying her deceased husband on her back.
column3: If you think you should perish for that woman, you have a major delusion.
column4: Remember "The Corpse Bride"? Well, she is under the DELUSION that someday someone will marry her. Too bad that nobody wants to marry a dead woman .

story: After Godzilla laid waste to the city, the survivors put some flowers on the bodies of the deceased and floated their bodies down the stream.
column3: Laying waste is just a euphamism for flushing poop down the toilet. It smells nothing like flowers, more like deceased flowers, and it's flushed down into a stream of sewage. Use "waste" to avoid 滅 (#390) 壊 (#427).
column4: Hurricane Katrina laid waste to New Orleans....as a result, a stream of dead flowers floated into the sea.

story: You're dead meat, buddy, my ambition is to be king.
column3: The ambitions of kings often result in dead bodies.
column4: The king's one ambition, before he perishes, is to go to the moon.

story: Note: The primitives are top hat and bound up. Compare 万 (#68). Story: A rich man wearing a top hat and bound up from head to toe hobbles up to you and asks for directions to the nearest police station because he just escaped from his kidnappers.
column3: I always keep my directions bound to the bottom of my top hat so I won't lose them.
column4: To find the direction, the magician waved his top hat over his dagger to make it function as a makeshift magical compass.

story: If an attractive woman passes by, it can disturb your moral compass.
column3: In college, whenever I had a woman in my room, I'd hang a compass on the doorknob as a do not disturb sign. The compass let my roomie know that he needed to "take a hike".
column4: A woman 女 often disturbs a man's sense of direction 方 in life. "What? You want me to lose the top hat 亠 and dagger 刀? But honey, that's who I am!" (She wants him to be more of a "beau guy.") 妨害、ぼうがい, interference, obstruction: 交通を妨害しないでね, "Don't block traffic, okay?" 妨げる、さまたげる, disturbance, obstruction (sounds like "some-a-da-girl-u"): 叔母ちゃんのいびきがみんなの睡眠を妨げた, "Auntie's snoring disturbed everybody's sleep." 違法駐車が交通の妨げになっています, "Illegal parking has become an obstruction to traffic."

story: Little boys always head in the direction of mud and dirt.
column3: Boys thoughts often head in dirty directions.
column4: It's a dirty BOYscout, lost in the woods by himself with only his compass for directions. Can't you just see the lost little boy, all alone?

story: She used a perfume so strong, that you can track her by following the direction of the smell of flowers.
column3: A flowery scent spreading in all directions is perfume.
column4: People always seem to overdo it with their perfume. It seems that whenever I am at school, somebody walks by with their cheap flowery perfume. If I close my eyes, I can actually use that floweriness as a compass - it tells me which direction they're in.

story: "Flesh in all directions" = obese.
column3: Yo momma so obese, she changed the direction of the moon.
column4: Yo momma so obese, she made the moon change direction. (I like DrWarrior12's story, but switched the words to match the kanji.)

story: When you call on someone, you point your words in their direction.
column3: Japanese streets usually don't have names, so finding places can be difficult. So if you plan to call on someone you need two things; 1) words (for asking the way) and 2) a compass (in case you get really lost).
column4: When calling on a girl, you'd better what what sweet words will turn her fancy in your direction. (Image: last century teenagers on a frilly couch in the sitting room, she with her back to him, and he fumbling for the right words to turn her around).

story: Go in any direction away from your taskmaster when you are set free.
column3: The 'Saw' movies: If you follow the directions of the taskmaster, you'll be set free.
column4: Remember what the Genie from Aladdin wanted, to "to be free: be my own master, choose my own direction".

story: Overnight the slave got Violent and was Set Free. Overnight....Set Free.
column3: In the last frame we saw the slaves set free (放); yet emancipation didn't end segregation and conflict... remember the VIOLENT clashes on the street, whereby white taskmasters turned fire hoses in the direction of the black protesters, spraying them with water. (Thanks to KANJI for the (true) story about Bull Connor and the protests).
column4: Water is white in every direction, even the tasmaster is afraid of the violent sea.

story: HORNY TEENAGERS love to UNDRESS FLESH.
column3: Before you undress I should warn you -- the sight of flesh brings out the devil in me.
column4: Undressing, she exposed her flesh, which brought out the devil in him (don't confuse with 裸 (#1205)).

story: The words of a horny teenager typically fall into one of two categories: either rumors or explanations.
column3: The words of the devil incite rumours and false explanations.
column4: HORNY TEENAGERS always come up with wild EXPLANATIONS and THEORIES to SAY to their parents when they come home late after curfew.

story: Pointed is the metal devil's pitchfork.
column3: The metal of the devil, his pitchfork, is pointed.
column4: Pointed metal objects are used by horny teens for devil's play.

story: Formerly, horned animals were used to plough the ricefield, and it took all day. Nowadays it's done by machine.
column3: I can't help but see this as the former president of the United Sates, George W. Bush. The horns growing out of his brain with an evil thought, his tongue wagging in his mouth, saying something stupid. (It helps later on. Increase = him increasing the national deficit until we have nothing but dirt left, Hate = Bush's mind). Fun stuff.
column4: The horns found in the ricefields were formerly used in rituals celebrating the sun goddess, amaterasu.

story: Prices always INCREASE for LAND that was FORMERLY cheaper.
column3: Farmers work the land so they can INCREASE their formerly puny crop supply.
column4: To increase the size of your kingdom, you must take land (earth, soil) that was formerly that of your foes.

story: SEA SHELLS were FORMALLY great PRESENTS. Nowadays kids wants playstation and DS!
column3: FORMERLY at Christmas I got PRESENTS, but now I just get MONEY.
column4: The artist formerly known as Prince gave presents to all his fans. Picture him throwing live oysters into the audience as he performs. People are horrified and start gagging from the smell.

story: Traditionally seen as a pictograph of the sun rising behind a tree.
column3: Through the trees, I watch the sun rising from the east.
column4: Imagine that hugely symbolic Japanese SUN piercing through a TREE as it sets on Tokyo (東京), the EASTern capital . (with thanks to AndamanIslander, just found it easier to remember this version).

story: Feng Shui states that the ridgepole of a house should be made of wood and face east.
column3: Ok just a note to the 'ridgepole facing east story' im making up a story to JUSTIFY why that is the case. Assuming that 99% of you guys use the age old story of a 'sun rising through a tree tells you were the east is', back in those days when people used ridgepoles they wanted to align their houses in such a way that they face the rising sun, so they wake up with a bright day, and wake up early with the sun seeping through in a perpendicular manner( as the ridge pole faces the sun in the morning).
column4: Way back when, all Japanese houses were made of wood and built with the ridgepole facing east. The reason for this is that since there were no alarm clocks yet, everyone needed the rising sun to wake them up every morning.

story: Eastern Siberia is often frozen by ice. According to wikipedia, Yakutia (in Eastern Siberia) holds the record as the coldest town on Earth. Check it out yourself...it made it stick for me!
column3: The ice will stay frozen until the sun is visible through the trees.
column4: It is always the east side of anything, mountain, yard, forest, that stays frozen with ice.

story: A pregnant woman is a porter of her child.
column3: A woman becomes pregnant when a drop of gentleman gets inside her.
column4: TIP: 壬 actually means "9th CALENDAR SIGN (Chinese calendar)". However you would easily confuse it with 九 (#9). So think of it as a PORTER like Heisig suggests: a PORTER drops 丿 by to help you carry luggage. What a gentleman 士! This kanji can combine everything though in its story - see: STORY: A woman 女 becomes pregnant with a drop 丿 of the gentleman's 士 semen. She must then port 壬 the baby in her womb until the 9th 壬 month. [thx Raichu & cameron_en].

story: A porter has run away from his master. His punishment is to be stretched out on the rack. So say the courts in this barbaric time.
column3: Stretching the truth in court caused a drop of sweat on the gentleman's brow.
column4: In court they STRETCHED the PORTER on the rack until he confessed. Torture!!!

story: To make this dye, I used water and the barks of nine different trees.
column3: The baseball team hangs their freshly dyed dripping jerseys at the top of a tree to dry.
column4: [dye; color; paint; stain; print] The most common dyes are liquids that come in nine colors (the 7 of the rainbow, plus white and black), and are extracted from trees.

story: Any sort of thing can burn in the fire.
column3: The Japanese are very particular about what SORT OF THINGs are considered BURNable trash and what's not.
column4: Fire burns any sort of thing.

story: This house is reserved to V.I.P. only. If you are not one of the few with enough money to call you that way, keep out!
column3: The V.I.P. visits your house, but your ceiling is too low for his inflated head, which he bumps and hurts. You have to give him your few shells as compensation.
column4: HONEY! We've got a V.I.P visiting tonight!! Let's decorate the house a little why don't we? That ceiling is boring, let's hang a few fancy shells up there, that'll impress them!

story: Santa had to put his foot down to stop a march of little guys, namely elves. They were protesting the harsh treatment they get every year-end when Santa asks them to step up toy production for the holiday season.
column3: At year-end, we stop for a small celebration before marching ahead into the new year.
column4: At the year-end, everything seems to come to a stop. However, there's still enough prime time for one little party to celebrate.

story: After sticking a fishhook in your eye, the yakuza boss probably has little more to do to convince you to move to a different prefecture.
column3: Smaller administrative units, hooked together by a (Sauron's) central eye.
column4: Each prefecture is eye-catching (has its own little "hook") in its own way, even if the attraction is just a small one. 県 (けん) : prefecture.

story: There are a bunch of HORSE CHESTNUT TREES on top of this CLIFF above the beach. Chestnuts keep rolling off the cliff and falling on people's heads. So far TEN THOUSAND people have been killed by falling chestnuts, and the Japanese government still ain't did shit about it.
column3: There is a horse chestnut tree that has grown by a cliff for so long, it has deposited 10,000 horse chesnuts that lie at the bottom. Don't worry over this one too much, you'll spend so much time trying to figure out the right story for it, you probably won't forget it.
column4: Strokes 5 and 6 are in reverse order, so it's not an ordinary cliff, but a drag (primitive at the beginning of lesson 50!) Story: When we were kids, we loved collecting the fruits of the horse chestnut tree. But because there were so many to collect, we sometimes dragged more than ten thousand of them behind us!

story: Picture the ground as an extent of soil where scorpions are buried like land mines. Imagine a sign post saying 'no trespassing, scorpion mines' if that helps, and how it is dangerous to walk there.
column3: The soil is littered with scorpions everywhere and no ones dares put their foot on the ground.
column4: The DIRT SCORPION is a ground-type pokémon.

story: Remember the story of the scorpion that begged the turtle for a ride across the pond? Halfway across the water, the scorpion stung the turtle on the neck and they both sank to the bottom.
column3: Water scorpions loves to live in the pond.
column4: The POND was infested with WATER SCORPIONS.

story: I see the bottom of this kanji as an arm, and the top is an insect biting into the arm, sucking some blood.
column3: Insect in one drop of amber. Think Jurassic Park.
column4: An insect stuck its sharp, needle-like mouth in my arm and sucked out one drop of blood.

story: Bugs have to go to school to learn how to become lightning bugs. Only the brightest bugs graduate to become lightning bugs.
column3: Q: Who's the smartest insect in school? A: The lightning-bug. Because he's so bright! (Image: lightning bug in school with glasses, pocket protector, etc. Maybe even have some cool kids teasing him).
column4: In the schoolhouse for insects, the brightest are obviously the lightning-bugs.

story: A snake eats insects and he does that outside, while we eat in the house and preferably with a spoon.
column3: I use a spoon to feed my pet-snake insects in the house.
column4: The Far Side cartoon: Picture a snake with glasses and a tie inside of his house in the morning. He's staring at the spoon next to his bowl full of insects. "Dang!" he mutters. (thanks to Cheesemaster64).

story: Little is it known that a rainbow is actually created by insects of different colours flying in formation, a craft they have perfected to create the rainbows we see today.
column3: Rainbow is of course created by billions of colored insects (what? you really thought it was an optical illusion?). However I had problems remembering that the insect primitive goes on the left. If you have similar difficulties, try this: rainbow is an Insect-Craft. Mnemonic: I.C. Rainbow (I see rainbow).
column4: For my arts and CRAFTs project at school, I made a rainbow out of dead BUGs spray painted different colors and glued to some paper. The teacher was not amused.

story: A butterfly is an insect that appears after spending a generation on a tree as a cocoon.
column3: Tip: New primitive: Let Tarzan = generation + tree -- because Tarzan lives with several generations of his family at the top of a tree. (This combination appears five times: 葉 (#243), butterfly, (FRAME 521), 喋 (#2280), 諜 (#2757), 牒 (#2934)). Story: You see Tarzan swinging from tree to tree chasing an insect. Later he shows it to you neatly pinned into his butterfly collection.
column4: Butterflies are insects that like to eat just the flowers but leave the leaves behind. (helps me to think of the kanji for leaves, minus the flower bit).

story: The bachelor's apartment looked like it had been attacked by a pack of wild dogs. There were even insects in the kitchen. No wonder he's single!
column3: A SINGLE guy is a WILD DOG who BUGS many women.
column4: If you smell like a PACK OF WILD DOGS and attract INSECTS, it's pretty likely that you're gonna stay single.

story: In China it was believed that the silkworms were insects sent from heaven because of the beautiful material they produced.
column3: There are no insects in heaven - well, that is, except for silkworms. What, do you expect Jesus to import his fancy robes from China?
column4: Imagine an insect, the silkworm descending from a heavenly, golden, cloud- filled sky on a single string of silk.

story: They say that when an INSECT flaps its wings even the single DROP of WIND that it creates is sometimes enough to create a hurricane on the other side of the Earth.
column3: The WIND usually carries things around in it - drops of rain or snow, and lots of insects.
column4: Mediocre insects get caught in the wind.

story: This kanji looks like the "s" of "self", looking at its own reflection in a mirror (reversed sideways), as if pondering about his "self".
column3: When Superman looks at himself in the mirror, this is what he sees on his chest.
column4: I is self educated! I drawed this "S" all by myself!

story: Be careful when you're RUNNING through the jungle, because you might step on and ROUSE a sleeping SNAKE. Then you'll have to RUN like hell before it bites you!
column3: Nothing will rouse you quite as much as finding a snake in your bed. You will run away like you've never run before!
column4: Yelling "Run!!! Snake!!!" is more than enough to rouse anyone nearby.

story: Cleopatra.
column3: Queen Cleopatra ends her reign (and life) with the help of a snake.
column4: Medusa, the snake queen. She's the penultimate "snake woman".

story: The taskmaster of Slytherin ( wizardry house symbolized by a snake ) plans a reformation of Hogwarts, disallowing the study of magic to all muggle-born. こわいですね！.
column3: If you want to achieve the reformation of your inner self you have to control your desires and correct your flaws; in sum, be your own self taskmaster.
column4: This is a Meiji reformation taskmaster, trying to force usage of the Roman alphabet in Japan in place of Kanji. He holds a snake in the shape of the letter S and tries to explain how much simpler this is (j/k).

story: A scribe writes down the words spoken by a snake (i.e. a lawyer).
column3: Snakes have no hands. So, when a snake needs to write down something, it has to call in a SCRIBE, who will write down all the sayings of the snake.
column4: This scribe was truely badass - to jot down words, he would grab the nearest snake and squeeze it's venom out of it's fangs and use it as ink.. no pen for this guy.

story: The snake bound up its prey by wrapping his body around it.
column3: Imagine Jessie sending in her Ekans (snake pokemon), and telling it to use bind attack to wrap up pikachu.
column4: His kids were always peeling back the paper to sneak looks of their wrapped gifts, so this year instead of a bow, he bound them with a snake.

story: Placenta is flesh/part of the body wrapped around the foetus.
column3: Placenta is the flesh that wrapped around us when we were in the womb.
column4: 胞子, 共産党細胞, 細胞核, 同胞,胞 (#531)ホウ(包) ... Parts:月, 包 ... Note: Not Placenta; that's 胎盤胎 (#748). 胞 is any body sac, of any living thing, including cells (細胞). ... Story: A Part of the body that completely wraps something up: a cell, a placenta, a spore. Include the umbilical cord as part of the placenta wrapped around the fetus like a snake After the Fetus is born he swings the snake around like a lasso. YeeeHa!

story: Primitive cannons fired stones wrapped with poisonous snakes.
column3: Cannon = stone projectile wrapped by a barrel.
column4: Rather than a cannon, think of a catapult or trebuchet. Both these siege engines fire a large stone that is initially wrapped up or cradled in some fashion. 鉄砲 (てっぽう) : gun.

story: When water forms a bubble, it wraps a pocket of air.
column3: To prevent people from popping bubble wrap for fun, the post office has started filling the bubbles with water.
column4: Bubbles are just air wrapped up in a layer of water.

story: It seems bizarre, but tortoises are a genetic cross with the head of a fish and the tail of an eel. Where the shell comes from, no one knows.
column3: A tortoise is prosperity bound up with a tail. They are very lucky creatures.
column4: Tortoise. DBZ. This is goku's symbol in his back. How can I forget it!

story: Think of a two natural sources of electricity: electrical storms (a form of weather) and electrical eels. 電話 でんわ phone, call; 電気 (でんき) : electricity, (electric) light.
column3: If it rains on an electric eel, expect electricity.
column4: When it RAINS , if you put an electric EEL in the swimming pool , you can generate ELECTRICITY.

story: Have you ever seen an asian DRAGON? it looks like an eel, but can stand up because it has legs.
column3: A dragon is like a standing eel.
column4: If the poor villagers don't provide him with a vase full of eels each day, the dragon will lay waste to the village.

story: Ever went under a waterfall, vase in hand, trying to catch eels from the water as it pours down?
column3: A WATERFALL makes the WATER roar like a DRAGON.
column4: I imagine an incredibly high waterfall spilling into a small vase. Several eel are swimming over the edge and having a diving competition to see whether they can make it into the vase. Just imagine a few missing and you're set.

story: Pork comes from the flesh of a sow.
column3: One possible pictograph for "sow" primitive: the top line is a feeding trough, the stroke touching it is the head, the long curved stroke is the body (with a little hook at the end for the curly tail), and the four remaining strokes are the sow's legs.
column4: When a mother pig nurses its piglets, we call it a SOW. When that same mother pig's body parts are on our plates, we call them PORK.

story: In association with 遂 (#579), our sow is on the road pursuing a mate.
column3: Miss Piggy, everybody's favorite sow, is hitting the road to pursue her long lost Kermit the frog.
column4: The pig is on the road in the pursue of the turtle who is trying to 逃 (#301). (See story on 逃 (#301) & 遂 (#579)).

story: This is still Miss Piggy only she's gotten horny (as she often does) and now she's pursuing Kermit to help her consummate her desires.
column3: I don't often complain about Heisig's keywords - but 'consummate' is a little misleading. Think about this kanji in terms of ACCOMPLISH or "realize" rather than a sexual encounter. Or, combine the two: the policemen thought they had accomplished the task of driving out (see pursue, last frame) all the sows, but they received a phone call reporting two horny pigs CONSUMMATING on a road. When they got there, they found a male and female police officer, not pigs!
column4: In association with 逐 (#578), our sow has tracked down a suitable mate, they've consummated their relationship, and now the little sow is all grown up into a boar with horns.

story: Think of "The Three Little Pigs". There was a house made of straw, another made of sticks, and a third made of bricks, each occupied by a pig. So, naturally, housetop over pig means house, the central element of that story.
column3: Man, ever hear of cleaning? This house is a pig sty.
column4: Miss piggy in the hooooooooooooooooouse.

story: Since the Nihonjin man is hardly ever home, the woman feels more like she's married into the house than into a relationship.
column3: Traditionally, it was the women who would marry into the households of their husband's families.
column4: 婿嫁婚姻: Four kanji related to marriage, all with the woman primitive. Bridegroom: for the honeymoon, he takes her to the zoo for a month. Marry into: since the J-husband is never home, she feels more like she's married into the house than into a relationship. Marriage: is when she gets a new family name on one particular day. Matrimony: is the state after the marriage, where she has the husband pent in like a dog... 嫁[よめ].

story: In Orwell's 'Animal Farm' the pigs overpowered every other animals. They crownded themselves as ruler of the farm and walked tall on their rear legs, a crime strictly forbidden in the animal republic.
column3: Ganon, the tall crowned pig, has been overpowering ther land of Hyrule for decades.
column4: This kanji is also used for Australia. Think about it from Japan's point of view. On average Australians are taller than the Japanese. Australia is nominally a monarchy, indicated by the crown. As far as manners go, compared to the Japanese, typical ockers are pigs.

story: Intestines are the part of the body that is taken out of piglets to make piggy banks. Just imagine factory workers scraping out the intestines of real piglets and packaging them up for little children.
column3: Imagine a child's horror if upon smashing open his piggy bank, instead of coins, instestines(flesh) pours out.
column4: The intestines are like the piggy bank of your flesh, everyday you deposit a little more into them...

story: You're looking for a good location to bury your piggy bank savings. It has to be in some soft soil that's easy to dig up, well hidden, and easy to rememger like this kanji.
column3: Don't confuse with 所 (#1208). Think of location not as a single fixed spot, but as the act of locating. You've buried your piggy bank in the dirt in your backyard, but you can't remember where. You frantically dig everywhere in a process of location to find your piggy bank.
column4: A pile of soil marks the location of where I burried my piggy-bank.

story: Imagine a hot water kettle for your tea, except this one is a pink piggy bank that pours the water from its snout (and squeals when the water is piping hot). Make sure to use a potholder!
column3: My HOT WATER cut off because I forgot to pay the bill. So I break open my piggy bank and run to the local 銭湯 (sentou; public bath).
column4: Hot water is a phrase that can mean "getting into trouble." This kanji pictures just one of the many meanings of that phrase: it's water that you get into (with creditors and the like) when your piggy bank is empty!

story: Picture of a sheep run over by a steam roller. Must have been a ram, note the horns.
column3: Our Lord and King put on ears and a tail to become a lowly sheep for the slaughter.
column4: (you might consider using something with a religious connotation when used as a primitive, like "lamb of god" or something, because sheep seems to appear in a lot of religious kanji).

story: I guess this kanji proves it's not just the Welsh whose idea of beauty is a large sheep.
column3: Who is more beautiful, a sheep or a st. Bernhard dog? Imagine a big contest with many judges, then let the sheep win, since it is on top in the kanji (perhaps even let the sheep ride on the st. Bernhard dog because it won).
column4: That sheep's a beauty! Look how large she is!

story: This kanji refers to the waters of the Pasheephic ocean.
column3: Remember the story of Jason and the Argonauts from Greek myth? Jason travelled across oceans of water in order to recover the fleece of a certain sheep.
column4: If you drop a sheep into an ocean, it will soak up all the water with its thick coat of wool.

story: Trembling from head to hoof from such a traumatic experience, the sheep gives a very detailed worded account to the detective about his wolf attack. "We need more details Mr. Sheep. Tell us exactly where the baaad man touched you".
column3: The next time you can't sleep, instead of counting sheep, think of wordy sheep, boring you with details of their mundane lives (baa, baa, baa, .........zzzzz). 詳しい (くわしい): knowledgeable, detailed 詳細 (しょうさい): details, particulars.
column4: Say! detailed sheep, not like that! DE-TAILED sheep. Got it?

story: This one's easy to remember. The kanji gives 2 examples of foods that should be purchased fresh. To remember which foods, take the first letter of fresh, "F", to stand for fish and the final sound of fresh, "SH", to stand for sheep: FreSH. It even puts the primitives in the right order.
column3: The freshest fish is caught in the middle of the night while most people are "counting sheep." (If you've ever been to Tsukiji fish market, you know what I mean).
column4: I like my FISH 'n' SHEEPS (chips) FRESH.

story: Dolly (the first cloned sheep ever) grow tired of being a celebrity and escaped from the labs by digging a tunnel. She turned out to be an ACCOMPLISHED escapist, as she managed to dig a road under the soil. /Imagine Dolly performing a escape, like those movies where the main character has to escape from jail.
column3: The dirty sheep had come far down this road and had accomplished many things.
column4: I see this character used most often as the "-dachi" in tomodachi. And so, as we travel the roads of the earth, we gather a flock of sheep (friends). And only then we can say we have accomplished much.

story: A very thirsty sheep, who always lacked water, spends his days watching his fellow sheep (in the farm next door or in another pen) and being very envious of their water.
column3: Envious of the greener grass on the other side of the fence, the sheep looks down in disgust at his own dry grass lacking water.
column4: A sheep that lacks water is envious of those who have it.

story: The distinction between fine and common wool, is the craftsmanship of the wool.
column3: This New-Zealand pro-gamer has won many distinctions playing WoolCraft (a massively multi-user game in which the goal is to shear sheep).
column4: Noob players make no distinction between what games they play, whether it's the geniune thing or a bootleg fake copy. The biggest example of course, would be the legit World of Warcraft and the biggest ripoff there is: World of Wool-craft!

story: A pullover is donned by pulling wool over your eyes.
column3: Someone who is donning a disguise does that in order to pull the wool over your eyes.
column4: The wolf donned his disguise by pulling the wool over his eyes.

story: The mouth of a turkey is used solely for saying, "Gobble." Likewise, your mouth, full of turkey, is solely used to gobble it up.
column3: Sadly my mouth gets to taste turkey solely on Christmas Day.
column4: "We can't prosecutre the murderer based solely on what comes from the mouth of this turkey!" Imagine a turkey who witnessed a murder of his fellow kind (to be eaten) and trying to report it to the cops.

story: After our pre-Thanksgiving massacre, we piled high all the turkey corpses atop the soil of the farmyard.
column3: During the Turkey Holocaust (this is what the animal kingdom calls Thanksgiving - they have really short memories and thus don't recall that it actually happens every single year), turkeys are killed en masse, and their bodies are piled high. To keep them from tumbling down, a pile of dirt is piled high right next to them to keep them standing upright so that they will be fresh when it is time to eat them.
column4: The farmer awakes Thanksgiving morning to find huge mounds of dirt piled high in front all of his doors and windows. He can't get out. Clever turkeys.

story: This is the kanji for the shii tree, on which shiitake (椎茸) mushrooms grow. It's easy to picture a turkey dropping by the shii tree to gobble down some of those sweet oaky (shiitake) mushrooms.
column3: Why is the sweet oak so sweet? Not sure, but to me it tastes just like turkey (with gravy and cranberry sauce!) Now that is sweet.
column4: I always use SWEET OAK WOOD to add flavor to roasted TURKEY.

story: Do you remember that song where they say "Who let the turkeys out!? Gobble.. gobble.. gobble"?
column3: [who; someone; somebody] You're alone when, suddenly, you think you hear someone speaking. "Who's there?", you say, but there is no answer. Then you find out it was only a turkey gobbling. You feel relieved (and ashamed to tell this story). (Based on raulir).
column4: "Who's there?" he says, but it was only a turkey.

story: When I put the turkey over the oven fire, it always ends up being charred beyond recognition. I'm not a very good cook.
column3: Char could be any meat over oven fire. So why is it a turkey in this kanji? Because charred turkey is what sticks out most in your mind as the thing that ruined Thanksgiving dinner.
column4: Turkey is not very common in Japan. (found only in Subway sandwiches!) So when Japanese try to barbecue turkey on the grill, they always char the meat. masaka!

story: Reefs are often formed from volcanic rock, or "rock that has been charred".
column3: Coral reefs are now dying off due to our abuse of the environment and now look like charred stone. For a picture illustrating this, see http://www.nacri.org/images/Hof-dredgingfig8.jpg.
column4: You may be familiar with this unfortunate natural phenomenon. The Coral Reefs are some of the most beautiful habitats in the world, full of color and life. However, recently due to overfishing, the reefs have been undergoing something called Coral Bleaching. The algae dies off, and the sun chars the coral, leaving nothing but a barren wasteland that looks like charred rock. The color is gone and all you have left is bone-dry, white rocky charred stuff.

story: Hunter-gathers, searching all along the ground for food. They never look up and see the Turkeys that have gathered on top of the trees to hide. Those were some smart turkeys!
column3: Gather the turkeys for Thanksgiving. Gather the trees for Christmas. In that order...
column4: The TURKEYS GATHERED in the top of the TREE........who knew they could fly up there??

story: Quasi-modo, the famous hunchback of Notre-Dame wasn't actually a hunchback at all!! He used a frozen turkey to make a hunch!
column3: An iced turkey is only quasi-as-good-as fresh turkey.
column4: You're having a frozen turkey for dinner? Come on, that's not a real meal...that's a quasi-meal at best!

story: Why did the turkey cross the road? To advance to the other side, of course.
column3: [re: raulir] Animals on the road: Turtles 逃 (#301) and Pigs 逐 (#578), while the Turkeys advance (looking very formidable indeed).
column4: The turkey leader led his brave troops across the plumage-covered road: "ADVANCE, turkeys! I know none of you are chicken!"

story: Newscast: "Among today's miscellaneous stories, we have a report on a baseball team that was chased up a tree by a turkey. Stay tuned for this and more!"
column3: "Nine wooden turkeys?" asked the official directing people at the antiques roadshow, "I suppose you should head over to the miscellaneous department to get them appraised."
column4: Among the miscellaneous birds sitting on a tree (nine in total), the biggest one is a turkey.

story: Stop | spooning | turkeys. Spoon females.
column3: To become feminine you must stop using a spoon to eat turkey and use a knife and fork like a proper lady.
column4: Tip: stop/footprint + spoon : This combination of primitives appears seven times in Heisig, including as a separate character, which he names 此 (#2201). REF: feminine/female (FRAME 563), 紫 (#1475), 柴 (#2202), 砦 (#2204), 些 (#2203), 髭 (#2205).

story: At the turkey fighting semi-final, turkeys are injected with drugs via needles and splashed with water to help them last the match.
column3: The anhinga, or water turkey, has a needle-like nose, so really it's only a semi-turkey http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anhinga.
column4: The Turkeys made it to the water polo semi-finals against the Ducks before the refs discovered the needles in their lockers.

story: The St. Bernard dog pounces on a turkey in a rice field and stirs up all the other birds around. See them all gobble gobbling in fear?
column3: Gruesome, but it makes it easy to remember. Here goes: The St. Bernard stirred up a crowd of turkeys and caught one. It bit the head, brains spilling onto the rice field.
column4: Calling my brother/sister "big turkey brains" gets her real stirred up.

story: Don't let the neighbor's St.Bernard rob tonight's turkey....glue it to the table if you must.
column3: Remember the scene in A Christmas Story where the big dogs robbed the family of their Christmas turkey? Well, the following year Ralphie's mom glued the holiday bird to the kitchen table, just as a precaution.
column4: The turkey and a St.Bernard dog are going to rob a bank. The turkey first, the dog behind him. When they approach the bank the turkey pulls out a tube of glue and says, "Remember Dawg, it's a robbery, whatever happens we gotta stick together.

story: To assure that no one will get into the Turkey coop, put a huge rock in the entrance!
column3: You've heard the expression "killing two birds with one stone." (一石二鳥 is-seki-ni-chou). We'll, there's another one that roughly translates as "killing an entire coop with a giant boulder. " That's the method that hunters use when they want absolute assurance of taking home a bird.
column4: I assure you, the rock is big enough to keep the turkey inside the house. And if that's not enuff, I'll tie the tail of the turkey to the chimney 確認 , かくにん 確か , たしか(for sure,certain).

story: Noon is a good time for a ten minute nap (using lie down as nap).
column3: Noon is a good time to lie down for ten minutes or so.
column4: Noon is the hour of the horse.

story: If horses could speak, you might have to ask their permission before mounting them.
column3: Mr Ed ( a famous talking horse ) was finally at a loss for words when told he would need a permit for public speaking.
column4: To speak to me at noon you need a permit because I'm eating lunch.

story: Imagine a spoiled little girl. Her delight when she gets a Pegasus for her birthday... and then like all spoilt little girls she gets bored of it quickly... hence the yawn.
column3: I would be delighted if Japanese lacked the Pegasus kanji.
column4: A lack of flying horses is a delight to those on the ground who get hit with the flying horse poop.

story: I have Eric Cartman of the “South Park” animated series, wearing a cop uniform, riding a wooden Pegasus (such as on a funfair), and yelling “RESPECT MY AUTHORITAH!!!”.
column3: No one has the authority to tie up a pegasus to a tree!
column4: The park authorities are here, making sure everyone's dog is on a leash and everyone's pegasus is tied to a tree.

story: Microsoft Outlook works about as well as a pegasus that can't see: they both crash all the time.
column3: This kanji actually means view. While on a pegasus you will see a great view.
column4: I used to hate birds.They're loud, stupid and worst of all they shit on your head. Used to think birds were the most vile creatures on earth. Then I encountered a pegasus. I was just walking down the road, minding my own business when I happened to look up. I saw it there, braying noisily, ivory wings outstretched like an angel, back leg raised ever so slightly. It dropped a steaming brown load right on my face. It changed my outlook completely. Birds are the second most vile creatures on earth.

story: These days the biggest concern in airline safety is ICE on the WINGS of the plane. Birds that fly long distances also have to worry about getting ICE on their FEATHERS.
column3: Two wings full of feathers.
column4: Just noting how I use this as a primitive. When it's in this full form, containing the "ice" element, I try to think of it as penguins or flightless wings. When it's the variant with straight lines, then it's feathers or flying wings.

story: Imagine a white bird loosing a couple feathers as it is learning to fly. You learn a lesson as you watch it doing so, maybe you learn that “nothing comes for free” or that “one has to be prepared to loose in order to gain”...
column3: By the time you're old and all your feathers have turned white, you should have learned a thing or two.
