column4: Learning is all about adding more feathers to your cap and the most prestigious of all is the beautiful pure white feather you'll receive when you have learned the kanji!

story: Your feathers would also stand up if you were a hen in a slaughter house and you heard: "The following!"
column3: "The following segment is sponsored by...Swiffer - who make excellent feather dusters for cleaning your vases".
column4: The first thing a bird must do is learn how to stand. The following thing it must learn is how to use it's wings to fly.

story: Tip: feathers + turkey : This combination of primitives appears six times in Heisig, so it's worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest "futon" (your futon is made from turkey feathers). REF: weekday (FRAME 576) , 濯 (#619), 躍 (#1379), 擢 (#2370), 燿 (#2594), 耀 (#2892). Story: On weekdays you hang your futon out in the sun.
column3: The poor farmer spends every weekday while the sun shines, plucking turkey feathers.
column4: Excuse me? This kanji includes Saturday and Sunday, but the concept of weekday (which would actually be 平日) does not! Why does it have to be so misleading? I'll use day of the week as a keyword instead. Every day of the week begins when the sun 日 comes out and ends when you lay down on your futon 翟. If you do insist on weekday (not recommended), an alternative STORY: On weekdays 日 I sleep on my futon 翟, but on the weekend I go to my parents' place and sleep in a comfy bed.

story: At the laundry you stuff your large futon (made from turkey feathers) in the machine, thereby causing it to break -- as shown by the water spurting out the side.
column3: When turkeys do the laundry, they put their feathers in water (they don't have clothes).
column4: Wednesday is laundry day. Or in kanji arithmetics: 水 + 曜 = 濯 + 日.

story: "Sayeth"?! Who the hell says "sayeth"? Doesn't seem quite right...just like this kanji, which is just like "day" but doesn't seem "quite right."
column3: When pent up alone, one sayeth little.
column4: So I don't mix with 申 (#1198). Sayeth rhymes with dayeth.

story: I'm supposed to make an enclosure for my tree, but if I use its wood for the enclosure, there won't be anything left to be pent-in. What a quandary!
column3: Trees need space to grow. If you pent in a tree, it will be in quite a quandary!
column4: You are pent in the garden of eden with one tree, but outside is the whole world to explore! What a quandary -- should you stay in paradise with the tree of knowledge or should you go out into the world?

story: Fossils are old things pent in that have hardened.
column3: Remember Metapod from Pokemon? All it used was harden, which kept it pent in until it grew old enough to evolve into Butterfree..
column4: If you keep it pent in the breadbox, old bread will surely harden.

story: RTK supplement: weld (metal, harden) - welding the metal bars of a cage together, to harden the cage even more... nothing shall escape now!
column3: You weld metal in the knowledge that it will harden again.
column4: imprison: Metal hardening describes the method of imprisoning people in Star Wars by freezing them in carbonite. (The carbonite as used in Star Wars is a fictional substance and may or may not be metal, but I'll imagine it is.)

story: In my country (England) the crown jewels are kept pent-in in the Tower of London. Which happens to be where enemies of the state were once also pent-in (probably for trying to steal those jewels).
column3: Just think of Japan, a country which is like a jewel but historically very enclosed.
column4: Think of a country that has “pent in” all of its jewels so they wouldn't go away. Maybe it was China and its great wall.

story: When you are admitted into a group like the Yakuza, you're well and truly done (だん) for. You must stick to the group like glue, and you will be pent-in for life, never being able to leave.
column3: A pent-in group will naturally be more cohesive, or "glued together."
column4: Living in Japan, this image is too true for comfort. Every group I've ever encoutered sticks together like glue, but it seems thats not enough so they create little barriers to keep outsiders out and insiders in, once someone finds their group they are pretty much pent in for life. (that felt good).

story: We once had a dog with big paws // and oh what great trouble he'd cause // we built a huge pen // to keep him pent in // and stop him from breaking more laws //.
column3: Why is there poop on the kitchen floor? Oh, the cause is that you kept the dog pent in the house all day. Next time remember to walk him.
column4: The cause of the big bang (the ultimate cause) was a very large amount of matter pent in to a point in space.

story: 婿嫁婚姻: Four kanji related to marriage, all with the woman primitive. Bridegroom: for the honeymoon, he takes her to the zoo for a month. Marry into: since the J-husband is never home, she feels more like she's married into the house than into a relationship. Marriage: is when she gets a new family name on one particular day. Matrimony: is the state after the marriage, where she has the husband pent in like a big St. Bernard.
column3: Women cause matrimony.
column4: Women are the cause of matrimonies.

story: You can't breathe very well, so the doc looks inside your mouth to find the cause. "Oh, I see the cause of your windpipe blockage. There's a St Bernard penned up in there!"
column3: The windpipe in your mouth is what causes you to breath.
column4: Imagine a group of windpipes chatting: “That mouth is the cause of all my problems, you know, always breathing in germs, etc.”.

story: A nice picnic pent up in the park, with your crock pot and scarf (picnic blanket).
column3: In the park, I discovered a lidded crock wrapped with a scarf. The police promptly pent it up. (lidded crock wrapped in scarf = fake bomb, look at first story in 遠 (#402)).
column4: Imagine a beautiful park, pent in of course, with women in long kimonos walking between the blossoming cherry trees. Beautiful! (Notice how the long kimono changes when there is a line under it, compare 遠 (#402), contrast 猿 (#403)).

story: Write mouth two -times.
column3: Pretty much a pictograph, see book. Keyword meanings : to turn round, counter for number of times, counter for rounds. Some simple compounds using previously learned kanji : 次回 (next time), 毎回 (every time/each round), 回る (to wander around).
column4: A pent in mouth will curse many times.

story: A man on the podium announce the rules for the contest: You must fill a top hat with dirt as many times as you can by nightbreak.
column3: Abraham Lincoln used a simple mound of soil for a podium, when he wore his top hat and gave the speech he had practiced many times until nightbreak. But it was so magnificent that no one noticed.
column4: A podium is a bit of raised ground where top-hatted "important people" go around and around making speeches until nightbreak.

story: Try to remember all those stores from Zelda that were inside caves and had fortune-teller like vendors.
column3: The fortuneteller has a store in a cave.
column4: I kept mixing this up with shop until I found the phrase "in store" like "what is in store for you in the future." Only the store ran by the fortune teller can tell you what is "in store" for you,.

story: I think of the Batcave. It's a big cave that Batman uses as a warehouse to store his car, the Batmobile, and all his cool big-boy toys.
column3: Have you ever worked in a warehouse? It's like a giant metal cave. Watch out for that forklift!
column4: With rents high and auto businesses failing, GM chose to use a cave as a warehouse for their unsold cars.

story: When the courthouse caved in, trials had to be held in the courtyard.
column3: Back in caveman days, courts were held in caves. When too many people showed up to watch, they spilled out into the courtyard (the yard outside the cave court ) . 庭 (にわ): garden, yard, compound 庭園 (ていえん): garden, park 校庭 (こうてい): schoolyard.
column4: A courtyard (as the name suggests) is a yard where court is held. However, due to frequent inclement weather, the courts were moved to a cave. Old habits die hard, however, and the name "court cave" never caught on; people still refer to it as a courtyard.

story: Some bureaucrats at a government office decided that the tunnels of caves need to get street signs, which are then nailed to the walls of the cave.
column3: In some of the scarier countries, when someone is invited to visit a "government office", it's actually a dungeon where they're dragged into a cave and nailed to the wall.
column4: The government office is on cave street.

story: The two safe places to sleep in the wilderness are in a tree and in a cave. So these can be considered as beds.
column3: (based on mspertus:) The two safe places to sleep in the wilderness are in a tree and in a cave. So to be on the safe side it is best to put a tree in a cave and use it as a bed.
column4: Draculas bed is a wooden coffin in a cave.

story: Where is the best place to hid your grove of hemp trees? In a cave, you dope!
column3: (Image: while Batman is out, Robin is smokin' a huge doob in a secret corner of the Batcave where he nurtures his hemp grove).
column4: The world's most prolific drug dealer maintains a massive grove of hemp in a cave to avoid law enforcement.

story: If you grind the hemp you are bound to get stoned quicker.
column3: You must GRIND the HEMP collected in the grove by your cave on solid STONE to make the best ropes.
column4: "Grind, grind, grind the hemp, slowly with the stone".

story: (mature content: violence) I hung the heart of my victim with a hook and three drops of blood spattered me.
column3: Heart needs three drops of blood to work.
column4: The big L that is surrounded by three falling water droplets symbolizes that Love occurs in the heart from beginning(left dot), middle (top dot) to end (right dot).

story: You only truly forget her when she has perished in your heart.
column3: To forget means that something perishes from your heart.
column4: We keep the deceased in our hearts so as not to forget.

story: Selfish lover breaks your heart and moves on to the next lover. (And yawns with a heart of ice at your suffering).
column3: A selfish person doesn't care about the next person's heart, only their own.
column4: I'm born with two hearts? How lucky! Well I could donate one and save the life of someone else, but I'm one selfish bastard.... If my first one fails, I'll just move on to my next heart!

story: A ninja must be able to endure the pain of clinging to a ceiling, motionless, for hours at a time, waiting for just the right moment to drop down and thrust the blade of his sword into the hearts of his enemies. By the way, this character is used in the compound 忍者 (ninja) which is why I choose to use ninja as its primitive meaning.
column3: To endure unrequited love is like living with a blade in your heart.
column4: 忍び（しのび）Shinobi the 忍者（にんじゃ）Ninja was able to endure the massacre of his family & horrors of his training by placing the way of the blade above the way of the heart.

story: You are given a speech about some serious mistakes of yours, and you have to endure the whole thing, because all you can do is acknowledge.
column3: I never read the "acknowledgements" section of books or theses, because they are mostly just boring words that i must endure reading, before i can get to the interesting part. :).
column4: You would think that most ninjas (see previous frame) would acknowledge each other's presence with something like a silent nod. Imagine the consequences if, while raiding an enemy castle, one stupid ninja chose to acknowledge another by saying, "HELLO!!"

story: Remember the tale of Cleopatra? She was MOURNING the loss of her Marc Antony, so she placed the asp SNAKE to her HEART.
column3: You are mourning the death of a relative, and it feels as if a snake had bitten into your heart. -- "mourning feels like snake-bitten heart".
column4: Mourning is really self-pity. When someone mourns, it seems on the surface that they are feeling sadness for a lost loved one. In reality, they are feeling heavy-hearted because they themselves have permanently lost something very precious.

story: A samurai's intentions always come from the heart.
column3: Gentleman always have hearts full of good intentions.
column4: Father: "What are your intentions to my daughter?". Samurai: "I intend to give her my heart! (slices out his own heart and hands it over).

story: This is quite simple: a document is a set of words describing your intentions.
column3: A will is an important document that contains your final word on how you intend to distribute your assets.
column4: A policeman stops you (in Japan) saying, "Documents, please". You: "Er, I intended to bring them, but . . .". Policeman: "Words of intention are not good enough, I need to see your documents!"

story: Giving a girl flowers is like lighting the wick to her heart.
column3: My favorite are heart shaped candles that smell like sweet flowers. The trick is to find one with a thick wick, they give off the most flower scent (but burn the quickest).
column4: A wick is like a flower stem running through the heart of a candle.

story: Their true loyalty exists in the middle of their hearts.
column3: Your loyalty is to what's in your heart.
column4: Hachiko, the most loyal dog of all, has a statue in his honor in the middle of the heart of Shibuya.

story: This is a pictograph if ever I saw one. Two chunks of meat on a skewer.
column3: The actual definition of this kanji is "a skewer," which I believe is much more helpful as a primitive. Just think, two mouths skewered on same stick.
column4: The skewer that runs through the two junks of shish kebab.

story: A person who is afflicted with the vampire disease can only be killed with a sheesh-kebab through the heart.
column3: If you eat too many shish kebabs, your heart will be afflicted with cholesterol.
column4: A skewered heart is afflicted with pain.

story: Think with your brain NOT your heart.
column3: To think is to use your brain over your heart.
column4: Thinking too much with our brains, and not enough with our hearts, leads to many of our life's pains and sorrows. This kanji reminds us that thinking, while an activity of the brain, should always have the support of the heart.

story: Grace here is a favor freely bestowed, like a good deed. So to remember this kanji, go to the local shelter, find a big dog pent up in a small cage and adopt him. That will cause a warm feeling in your heart!
column3: Grace is when you give from your heart to serve a higher cause.
column4: A grace is a gift whose only cause for being given comes from the heart. WARNING: Do not confuse with 淑 (#778) - this kanji and it's meaning have nothing to do with being graceful.

story: [bravo, scottamus!] To apply for the job as a (replacement) Batman, you have to make it to the heart of the cave past all the traps he set up to test you. There, you see a table with the application form on it. Now that you think about it, the ad in the paper did say "Those who don't make it to the heart of the cave need not apply."
column3: In the videogame Zelda, Link enters a CAVE to visit a fairy that will APPLY magic to fill his HEART containers.
column4: Heisig's keyword doesn't apply this kanji directly. 応用する （おうようする）means "to apply" as in 彼らは新しい科学技術をその産業に応用した。"They applied new technology to the industry." The most common translation of 応 (on it's own without 用) might be "respond". As in responding to a question or responding to a situation. Story: Men are CAVEmen at HEART. When confronted by emergency situations they RESPOND by APPLYING their primitive power.

story: When you get a good IDEA you get excited and you can hear the SOUND of your HEART, it's pounding so hard.
column3: Picture someone who's just had a great idea, but in place of a blinking light bulb over their head, you see a heart thumping with great noise. Imagine the greater the idea, the louder the sound of the beating heart.
column4: The best ideas are sound ideas that come right from the heart!

story: Cowardice is the situation where you get the thought that maybe running away and saving your flesh is a good idea.
column3: Cowardice is when you are not willing to sacrifice your flesh for your ideas.
column4: If you are too concerned about your flesh 月 -- your safety -- this idea 意 leads to cowardice. Then you will hear the sound 音 of your heart 心 beating very loudly. A coward has 100 million 億 (オク) ideas about how to save his own flesh 月. 臆病、おくびょう, cowardice: 彼は臆病だと非難された, "He was accused of cowardice." その臆病な男は恐怖に震えた, "The cowardly man shook with fear." 臆病者、〜もの, coward: 彼らは彼を臆病者だと呼んだ, "They called him a coward." 彼は臆病者呼ばわりされて立腹した, "He resented being called a coward."

story: The concept of love is basically two hearts inter-acting as one.
column3: ''Inter-heart'' is a new therapy CONCEPT that helps macho guys share their feelings with each other.
column4: When you finally manage to explain a difficult concept to someone, it feels as if your hearts are inter-connected.

story: Your breath brings oxygen in through your nose which is then pumped around your body by your heart.
column3: I think I've met my dream girl, but there's a problem. her breath is horrible! So, do I listen to my nose or my heart?
column4: BREATH brings oxygen from your nose to your heart.

story: Recess to me is a school break. At recess some kiddies are comparing their latest body piercings. Tongues and noses are nothing special. The new cool is to have your heart done!
column3: At recess, little boys stick their tongues out and pick their noses while little girls draw hearts on the ground with chalk. It's winter now, so any tongues --left-- out for too long will freeze.
column4: Ah recess; tongues slandering, noses being turned up, and beneath it all, young hearts being broken. Dominant in playgrounds is the noise of tongues, which helps me remember that in this kanji tongue comes first.

story: Too easy. Imagine the Wizard of OZ. There, the three heroes asked the Wizard for three FAVORS: the lion wanted courage of TEN men, the scarecrow wanted a BRAIN, and the tin man wanted a HEART. Ok, the lion bit is stretching but you have it memorized now, so who cares?
column3: If you would give someone 10 fields as a favor then you truly have a big heart. Or, people who do lots of favors for others have a heart as big as 10 fields, a "10-field-heart".
column4: "Igor, do me a favor: go down to the morgue and pick me up ten brains -- oh, and a heart, if they have any fresh!"

story: If your heart surgeon is mediocre in his craft, you have plenty of reason to fear. ("Oops, I think I left my scissors in there").
column3: My deep dark fear at the bottom of my heart is that I am mediocre at my craft.
column4: Fear will craft a mediocre heart.

story: She was beguiled/mislead by his charm: at the party he kissed her on the mouth, they did it on the floor and thus he stole her heart. Poor girl!
column3: The same cowboy from frame # 356 (elements mouth, floor and fiesta), kisses the floor with his mouth, once again, before going to the fiesta. There, he uses his good looks to beguile women (gets them to buy him drinks or such), by playing with their hearts.
column4: At the fiesta I decided to beguile the crowd by performing a trick where I pull out my heart and throw it on the ground. It worked, their mouths hit the floor!

story: Emotion is a march of mouths inside your heart telling you what to feel.
column3: Strong EMOTIONS don't stay hidden. They march right out of one's heart (below) and out one's mouth (shouted, snarled, or gently whispered - depending on exactly what kind of emotion it is!).
column4: When you get emotional, words come marching out of your mouth from your heart, and it's impossible to stop them.

story: Melancholy makes me think of Hamlet cause he was so 'emo'. In order to play up his feelings he bares his head and holds his crown over his heart then walks (on walking legs) around the palace making everyone see how melancholy he is. What a wuss.
column3: This is an image of the crucifixion. Jesus is on the cross. His crown of thorns has slipped down and is around his neck, right between his head and his heart. His walking legs can be seen dangling from the cross as well. How MELANCHOLY!
column4: In the middle of summer you lose both your crown and your heart. No wonder you feel melancholy.

story: The new widow sits in the house, her head in her lap (the extended stroke), her dagger in her husband.
column3: The widow is head of the house now that she's been parted from her husband. 分 (#844).
column4: The house's head, her husband, was murdered with a dagger. You can still see the drops of blood above the dagger. She is now a widow.

story: Busy (as in "occupied") means a state of mind where all other thoughts are perished.
column3: Some people who are workaholics say, "I can rest when I'm dead." That is the sort of state of mind a busy person has!
column4: Poor Japanese people are so busy. They work like 80 hour weeks! Slowly, you see them turn into automatons...their bodies still alive, but their state of mind like they've long ago perished... (Mental image: most stressed out salaryman you know.)

story: ECSTASY alters our STATE OF MIND and makes us DEVILS.
column3: The state of mind that horny teenagers are looking for.
column4: The devil sells Data some ecstasy saying it will make him, like, human, man.

story: Constancy is holding the same state of mind over a long span of time. (tweaking PepeSeco and mspertus).
column3: Data is the epitome of constancy. As a robot, his consistency spans the entire day.
column4: A term used by Kant. Kant says that humans are preconditioned to experience the world in space and time, but God's mind has Constancy. That is, God's is a state of mind that spans all time and is not inhibited by it.

story: When Dumbledore died, everyone lamented it greatly. He was buried with his sunflower wand in his hand as he was so eminent. Even the death-eaters were imperiused to make them look like they were lamenting his death.
column3: Closely related to grief, mourning and regret, it was difficult for me to isolate this kanji. A lament is a song or poem that deals with loss or regret. This brings to mind the works of the world's most eminent artists, their brilliance and powerful works owed to their emotional states of mind.
column4: Lament is the state of mind most eminent people live in, because so many expectations lay on their shoulders.

story: Enlightenment is a state of mind that goes beyond the five senses.
column3: Data finds enlightenment when he discovers the answer to the question, "Who am I?". (Image: Data meditating in a sitting lotus position).
column4: Enlightment, a state of mind that I must find. Only I can find this state of mind.

story: Someone in a dreadful state of mind has crawled into his bed and is hiding under the sheets (linens).
column3: From the Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy: Dreadful: (n) The state of mind of a frood who doesn't have a towel at his side.
column4: What would be your state of mind after seeing some linen animate and fly down a hallway (a ghost) ? Surely, full of dread. Hence, dreadful. Picture someone experiencing dread, trying to reach for the big switch on top of their head, to turn off their mind because they are so scared.

story: When I am disconcerted my state of mind is "laid to waste".
column3: (re: wazzab) The state of mind of the people of New Orleans as they examined their city's concert hall laid waste can best described as disconcerted.
column4: In this kanji we see a disconcerted as a mind which has been laid waste by a flood of contradicting information. Try to picture someone's head being flooded, looking left and right in disconcert, and the switch on top of their head turning on and off uncontrollably.

story: "For all have sinned..." so everyone's state of mind should be to repent.
column3: When you repent, you heal your state of mind by going over every thing you regret doing.
column4: Repent: the state of mind that everyone here will share when they get their 2000 star trek stories mixed up.

story: Your state of mind would turn to hate when someone would take away a loved one that was formerly yours.
column3: Hate is the state of mind that turned the man who was formerly Anakin Skywalker into Darth Vader.
column4: This kanji is very graphic and suggestive. All you need is just to visualize. STORY: Hate is the state of mind when you feel how horns of rage are growing right from your brains and your tongue wagging in the mouth sends curses to the person you hate.

story: Some hardcore monks have a state of mind that has become accustomed to their self-torture through piercing themselves.
column3: At first I thought that seeing people getting so many piercings was gross, but as time goes by your state of mind gets accustomed to it.
column4: The previous generations had the state of mind that piercings were outlandish, but now the general public has become accustomed to this practice.

story: At the meeting of butchers, in their narrow state of mind, they throw lame jokes around like, 'Oh hello, it's a pleasure to meat you', and find this rather pleasing.
column3: Manson? Bundy? Jack the Ripper? Whichever killer or butcher brings to mind the most graphic image (maybe a meeting of all of them?) - you won't forget this kanji as you peer into their deranged state of mind: can't you just see their vacant stares and smiles on their faces, while they takes great PLEASURE in plying their trade? Creepy.
column4: A meeting of butchers has dissolved into an orgy of blood-squirting violence. But since the killing state of mind is the highest pleasure a butcher can experience, they are all smiles.

story: When in a lazy state of mind, the things you need to do are left for next month.
column3: This may only work for me, but I just think that the left side of my body is the lazy side. It sometimes takes over and puts my whole body in a lazy state of mind.
column4: (Building upon darg_sama and raulir) Anyone could be ambidextrous, and work with both hands... but the general state of mind of people ("right-handed") leaves the left side of the body lazy.

story: Humility is the state of mind of accepting the truth about yourself - both favorable and unfavorable. (tweaked version of Raichu's).
column3: Humility is a state of mind when you consider yourself in accordance with the truth (you neither boast nor demean yourself).
column4: Humility is the state of mind of accepting the truth no matter how much you don't like it.

story: Remorse is the state of mind where I feel bad for what I did while I was tired and emotional!
column3: Tip: If you are confusing this keyword, remorse, with 悔 (#672) and 恨 (#1570), then note that rEMOrse contains EMOtion.
column4: Remorse is how we feel about what we did while in an emotional state of mind.

story: Recollection is about bringing ideas back to your mind.
column3: I have no recollection of my state of mind from last night, dude... I must have been drunk or something. Do you have any idea what I did last night, man?
column4: Recollection is the state of mind where one brings ideas back in one's mind.

story: When sitting through laser eye surgery, the surgeon stretches open your eye with a tight-fitting tool. The thought of a laser cutting through the lens of your eye within moments, and possibly blinding you in the case of a mishap, makes for a very disquieting state of mind.
column3: Your state of mind is very disquieted when you see all the tools stretched out in front of you before an operation.
column4: Disquieting: my state of mind when I noticed that the tool primitive has changed...afraid I won't remember to extend the 1st and 2nd stroke of the eye.

story: A juvenile's state of mind tends to go apeshit when they see something they yearn for. Usually involving jumping up and down, tantrums, and other bullshit. (Imagine giving them a big backhand across the face.)
column3: The state of mind of a juvenile tends to yearn for things like fortune or fame.
column4: Many juveniles are in the state of mind in which they yearn to become adults. Even more adults are in the state of mind in which they yearn to once again become juveniles.

story: I'm in a state of mind where I desire to see the sun over the capital for some nice scenery for a change (no more rain!)
column3: Think of a commercial designed at making you hanker for the product they're advertising. See how they cleverly use that scenery to put you in the state of mind they desire.
column4: A prison cell can be nice for a while, but after some time your state of mind will change and you will hanker for more scenery.

story: Pining, yearn for... etc. Presumably for lost love. An easy one here, someone standing in the graveyard, placing an old valentine card amonst all the existing tributes.
column3: I am in the graveyard pining for my lost valentine.
column4: Morticia and Gomez (of the “Addams Family”) are spending their Valentine's Day at the graveyard, pining for each other's affection.

story: Hawaii is a little drop of heaven nestled in the waters of the Pacific, most often visited by honeymooners and valentines. It was annexed to the U.S.A. in 1959, and more recently to Japan as well-- albeit only unofficially, and through private commercial holdings.
column3: Tip 1: 天 and 夭 (heavens and sapling) are different, but RTK confuses them. Sapling appears in numbers 634, 938, 2078, 2079, 2080, and all characters containing angel 喬 (429, 430, 1221, 2104, 2120, 2369). Tip 2: The kanji 添 means "something added/attached", so think of it as a building annex. Story: While in the Annex watering saplings, you find a valentine card amongst them – addressed to you!
column4: First learn 忝 【ＧＲＡＴＥＦＵＬ】 (I was very GRATEFUL to have recieved a VALENTINE straight from HEAVEN.) It's a rare kanji used in かたじけない which means grateful. Then 添 【ＡＮＮＥＸＥＤ】 (You should be GRATEFUL the city just ANNEXED some land and is building a new WATER park.)

story: You swear you'll be in love forever, but invariably there comes a time when your heart is divided.
column3: For this kanji I invariably got the stroke order wrong. I nearly lost heart, but decided to stick (pun) to it. Then I noticed the order is 1) katakana ソ (altered slightly); 2) fishhook; 3) two drops. Now I invariably get it right.
column4: A stake through the heart invariably kills a vampire. (As a primitive this can take the meaning 'vampire').

story: Anything full of water will invariably begin to ooze.
column3: When you pierce a heart with a stake, it invariably oozes blood.
column4: The invariably divided heart is... oozing water? Is it crying because it is broken?

story: This pictograph actually really works if you look at it as a hand with fingers spread and middle finger pointing down. see the very top stroke as the edge of a shirt cuff, and it will all come together.
column3: A hand is useful for 千一(1001) things.
column4: Hello. My name is Inigo Montoya. You killed my father. Prepare to die. (the 6-fingered man).

story: It's a hot day of summer with a clear sky, you're sitting outside a cafe (or maybe on a reclining chair in the garden), and you watch over the kids with a hand covering your eyes from the sunlight (next time, don't forget the sunglasses).
column3: Think of the monster from Pan's Labrynth, that watched over the poor girl with eyes in the palm of his hands.
column4: I picture a lifeguard standing in his tower with his hand over his eyes, watching over the swimmers below (might work better for Australians- picturing that distinctive yellow and red cap).

story: If you grind the hemp without a stone but use your hand instead it will chafe. (Image: "Robin, why are your hands all chafed?" 'Uh... (I've been grinding hemp all day)').
column3: Imagine sliding down a hemp rope, without gloves, just bare hands. Chafes, doesn't it?
column4: When the feds came to bust your little hemp grove, you jumped out the back side of the cave and tried to repel down with a hemp rope. Unfortunately, the rope chafed your hands and you fell .. ouch!

story: Someone with a huge EGO is too good for any romantic partner and as such has nothing but personal "hand fiestas" with himself every night.
column3: Did you hear about the guy who had such a big EGO that he threw a fiesta for his left hand?
column4: That guy has such a huge ego. He had to have a hand in everything to do with planning the fiesta.

story: Follow the path of RIGHTEOUSNESS like sheep follow the shepherd , let go of your ego.
column3: Light Yagami had such a big ego that he expected people would accept his justice / righteousness like sheep. 正義　せいぎ 意義　いぎ.
column4: Christians believe one attains righteousness by elevating the Agnus Dei, or "Lamb of God", above the whims of one's ego (with thanks to axelb!)

story: Careful deliberation produces words of righteousness.
column3: WARNING: This does NOT mean deliberation as in careful consideration before decision. It is the other definition of deliberation: formal consultation or discussion, as in 議会, the Diet. In the deliberations of the diet, only Righteous words are allowed. If you don't speak in righteous words, they kick you out of the discussion.
column4: Picture Samuel L Jackson's character in Pulp Fiction carefully deliberating over what words to say to freak someone out before killing them. He even browses through a list of bible quotations for inspiration. Then he finds it!... "the path of the righteous man".

story: A cow that is righteous sacrifices her milk for the human race.
column3: Cows are truly righteous animals. They SACRIFICE their milk so that we can have some. And if they don't have any left, they give a sheep a hand fiesta (good lord this is going too far) and give us that instead. What righteous cows.
column4: There are two kanji that need to be kept separate: this one and 牲 (#1680). Think of it this way: here there is a cow and a righteous person (presumably a Hindu). One must be SACRIFICEd, so the righteous Hindu takes the place of the holy cow. But by the time frame 1559 rolls around, the Hindu is no longer alive to protect the cow, resulting in the cow's life ending in an animal sacrifice.

story: I like to RUB my FINGERS over my EXTREMITIES ....like my extremity-ly long, umm, hair.... This has been edited in response to being reported ...you can change "hair" to whatever extremity-ly long body part you like.
column3: When you're cold, your RUB your FINGERS over your EXTREMITIES vigorously to warm up a bit. I'd still rather go in for a warm fire and some hot cocoa, though.
column4: Picture Mr. Burn's rubbing the extremities of his fingers together and saying "excellent..."

story: Why carry a handkerchief? I wipe my nose finger-style.
column3: It is not my STYLE to use my FINGERS to WIPE my butt.
column4: Using your finger is just one style of wiping. I use toilet paper.

story: He quickly yanked his fingers out of the vase. Maybe no one noticed the attempt to steal the cookies...
column3: As well as the meaning of 'taking captive', this also means 'crush' or 'batter'. One also often sees it written in Chinese, with the meaning "pull". (I think this is where 拉麺 comes from - 'drawn' or perhaps 'flattened' noodles.) My keyword is crush (I crushed my fingers trying to lift a heavy vase) but Ramen or the other common use for this kanji in Japanese, Latin (it's the abbreviation for the Latin language) would also be appropriate, as they help you learn the reading (ラ).
column4: He quickly yanked his fingers out of the vase. Maybe no one noticed the attempt to steal the ramen noodles... (拉麺＝ラーメン) Adapted from Splatted.

story: Here, I'm picturing that scene from ET (the extra terrestrial), where ET hugs Elliot before leaving. You see that EMBRACE is ET's long FINGERS that WRAP around Elliot.
column3: King Kong's way to embrace Ann Darrow (the blond beauty) is to wrap his fingers around her. He is too huge to embrace her like everybody else.
column4: When you really embrace someone you wrap your arms around them tightly to the point where your fingers can meet behind their back :).

story: Ok, this is a little wierd, but i took this back to the kanji for 塔 (#254). I think it helps simplify the image, and also helps anchor the pagoda kanji in memory better as an added bonus. say this aloud once, and i think it will bring out a vivid image very quickly: "Now boarding the pagoda ride. Please keep your fingers inside at all times..."
column3: When you board the ship on the way out from Hawaii a beautiful crewmember takes her fingers and fits a lei around you ....a lei is flowers fitted together with your fingers.
column4: All aboard! Fingers waving goodbye, flowers tossed in the air, and the meeting of mouths as lovers say goodbye.

story: The mafia want to extract information from you. You don't say a word, so out comes the knife. They cut of your fingers until you only have a few left and then you speak.
column3: You are at a the university library preparing a summary of some litterature and with your thumb, index and little finger (a few fingers) you point at a few passages to extract. Note: this kanji is used in the sense of an “excerpt”, not of an extract of some substance.
column4: WARNING: This is NOT extract the verb. This is like AN extract. A shorter version of something. An extract is a small part of something that you have to get out with your fingers.

story: Gandalf confronts the evil beast, shouting "you shall not pass!". He holds up a single finger and sends forth a whirlwind.
column3: The confrontation between the two sign-language people looked like a whirlwind of fingers.
column4: Imagine a thumb war. A confrontation of fingers in a whirlwind.

story: My criticism earned me the FINGER when I COMPARED her cooking to my mother's.
column3: Criticism is pointing at your finger at someone and comparing them with someone perfect.
column4: Think of the two most famous critics, Ebert and Roeper. On their show, they compare thumbs (which are technically fingers) with each other before dispensing criticism.

story: A Geisha beckons you with her index finger, and as you approach she runs her fingers all over her body in an attempt to seduce you. Keyword meaning : “invite”.
column3: I bet you all know the Maneki Neko, or beckoning cat, who with its raised fingers tries to seduce all good things (success, happiness and harmony) to its owner.
column4: The siren gently beckons you with her finger and seduces you to to your death.

story: A huge index finger coming down from the sky is kicking boulders of rock, clearing the land. Maybe it's the finger of God preparing a place for his little people to live.
column3: I imagine clearing the land in order to set up your tent after a long day of backpacking. Using your fingers, you pick up all of the rocks and get them out of the way so that you can get a comfortable night sleep. If you don't clear the land you can just picture the rock sticking into your back as you toss and turn all night long.
column4: To clear the land, farmers use their fingers to get the stones out.

story: (Image: the most snooty prim and proper English Lord with white gloves clapping only with his fingers. "Oh bravo old chap. Bravo...").
column3: I clapped so hard, my fingers became white.
column4: Fingers making white noise -- clapping, of course!

story: You're using a hammer to drive a nail into a plank, but you miss and strike your fingers, ouch ! PS: the character does not mean "to go on strike", it will be very helpful in the long run to create images that convey the proper sense of the character!
column3: My teacher used to strike my fingers with a street sign.
column4: Your finger or the nail. Which will the hammer strike?

story: You approach the thief from behind, stick your finger at his back to fake a gun, and say the phrase "You're under arrest".
column3: Giving the police the finger and a colorful phrase is a surefire way to get arrested.
column4: You are being arrested by a rookie cop. He has only just learned the Miranda warning, so he counts off the phrases on his fingers one by one: 1. You are under arrest - 2. You have the right to remain silent - 3. You have the right to an attorney... etc.

story: Someone stuck their fingers in my cottage cheese! I'm going to have to discard the lot!
column3: The wicked witch from Hansel and Gretel only likes the meaty parts of kids. Outside her candy cottage, you can see a pile of discarded fingers.
column4: This verb (suteru) is the one used for the ancient custom of 'baachan o suteru' - abandoning Granny in the mountains when feeding or caring for her became too much. Sadly, I can visualise many a victim clinging with her fingers to the cottage door and yelling that she doesn't want to go...

story: Wrap your FINGERS around someone's MOUTH to keep them quiet, then put the KNIFE to their throat to ensure their cooperation. This is the best way to KIDNAP someone.
column3: You kidnap someone by putting a finger on your mouth ("ssh!") and a dagger under his.
column4: Kidnapping is related to, but opposite to 招 (#702). If you beckon someone, you ask them to come to you, rather then going to them (to steal them). The kanji is an illustration of that fact, because the 口 (#11) is above the 刀 (#87).

story: My grandma always pinched me with her fingers when i was playing with her antiques. Imagine her fingers, also quite antique, thin, bony and hard, pinching at your hand. "Keep your fingers away from my antiques!!"
column3: >_< Don't you hate when your aunt (who is an antique) PINCHES your cheeks with her antique fingers?
column4: While admiring the antiques in a museum an old woman pinched my bottom with her fingers.

story: The rabbit pointed his FINGER at the TURTLE and said, "I CHALLENGE you for a race!" The rest is history...
column3: You are sure to take a challenge because your victory was portended. So you stand self-confident before your foe, point a finger at him and say "I will prevail, as was long portended!".
column4: Survivor Challenge! : Using only your finger, break open the turtle shell.

story: Finger lickin' delicious.
column3: When I was a baby, I thought my fingers were delicious.
column4: Imagine you lick your fingers after dipping them into something delicious. Alternatively, you may think of human fingers are delicious snacks for our favorite ogre Shrek.

story: At the BUDDHIST TEMPLE you'll see wonderous things, such as the priest that can HOLD himself upside down with just a FINGER.
column3: At a Buddhist temple people hold their fingers together in prayer.
column4: In Kyaiktiyo, there is rocking stone which sits on the edge of a cliff, and there is a Buddhist temple built on the top of it. You can rock the stone by pushing it with your finger, but it still holds in place. It's true, see here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kyaiktiyo.

story: The old lady said that there was a flood imminent, because her fingers hurt in the evening.
column3: Your imminent introduction (挨拶）this EVENING has you nervous, biting your FINGERS, with a FLOOD of sweat raining down from your brow.
column4: I lick my finger and hold it up... a flood in the evening seems imminent.

story: Teacher was always telling us to fasten our lips by pulling a zipper shut with our fingers. It always frightened me because I imagined getting my tongue stuck in the zipper.
column3: On the plane, you refuse to FASTEN your seatbelt and even go so far as to give the stewardess the finger and stick out your tongue at her. The crew comes and pins you down and forces you to FASTEN it.
column4: A finger in front of your mouth means "fasten your lips" or "hold your tongue".

story: A military leader in his chariot is brandishing his finger at the enemy, crying "chaaaaaaaaarrrgggeeee!"
column3: Think of the movie Gladiator but instead Maximus is brandishing a giant foam brand name (nike, rebok, adidas, whatever) finger like you see at a baseball game. He's riding in a chariot using the foam finger to kill his enemy.
column4: キ　Before the Battle of Agincourt in 1415, the French threatened to cut off the middle finger of all captured Englishmen. Without the middle finger it would be impossible to draw the renowned English longbow. The longbow was made from the English Yew tree. Drawing the longbow was known as "plucking the yew". The English won, and have since taunted the French. Here is the English "ARMY" BRANDISHING the FINGER saying "pluck yew!" The reading is ふるうwhich seems not so far off from F.U.

story: In mathematics, a conjecture is a mathematical statement which has been proposed as a true statement, but which no one has yet been able to prove or disprove. Have you heard of the Finger-Turkey conjecture ? It states that if turkeys had fingers, they would be able to count. Be sure to imagine a turkey with fingers at the tip of its wings, counting from one to ten.
column3: In the midst of conjecture on whether it was done or not, mom stuck her fingers in the turkey to check.
column4: The correct conjecture is that fingers evolved INTO turkeys! I'll prove it to you with a simple piece of paper...http://www.blogadilla.com/wp-content/uploads/2007/11/hand-turkey.jpg.

story: My piggy bank is so heavy that I cannot HOIST it using just my fingers.
column3: Picture a major robbery where some dudes are breaking into a bank to steal their money. They get their man in the vault through the ceiling - now he's hanging from a rope a few feet from the ground (like in the movies, dodging laser beams). He reports back that he has found the loot, and its all in a large piggy bank in the center of the vault. The alarm sounds and he's got to think fast. He jams the four fingers of his right hand in the piggy bank slot and tells his team to hoist him up, he's got the loot!
column4: You will be hoist by the neck if I catch you with your fingers in my piggy bank again! 唐揚げ からあげ deep fried food; 揚代 あげだい fee paid for the services of a geisha or prostitute; 揚々 ようよう triumphant, exultant, in high and proud spirits; 揚陸 ようりく landing, unloading.

story: When a man PROPOSES to a lady, he takes her FINGER and places the ring on it JUST SO, and the moment sweeps her away.
column3: I tried to propose to my girlfriend, but the ring was too small to fit her finger. Instead of saying yes, she just uttered an annoyed sigh. So I rushed to the jeweler where he made it bigger. But now it was too big, so I rushed back to make it smaller. This spiel kept going on until the ring was finally just so. Her eyes lit up and she said yes.
column4: Business proposals in Japan have to be set out just so. If you fail to lay them out in the correct way, you have to give up a finger, just like the yakuza. NOTE This is not the same type of propose as to propose for marriage, so I opted for a different direction.

story: Boss yells, "Who damaged the Xerox machine?!" fingers of employees point at one another.
column3: An employee lost a finger in a workplace accident, and sued the company for damages. (Don't confuse with 害 (#1671). 損 (そん) : loss, disadvantage; 損なう (そこなう) : to harm, to hurt, to injure, to damage, to fail in doing; 損失 (そんしつ) : loss.
column4: Employees damage their fingers because of too much typing.

story: I tried to PICK UP the bowling ball...but my FINGERS didn't FIT in the holes.
column3: To Pick Up something, your FINGERS must FIT around the object. --- This is a basic rule for all primates.
column4: If your fingers don't fit /You can't pick up shit. 拾う、ひろう, to pick up, find: タクシーを拾うのに少々苦労した, "I had a hard time finding a taxi." 私達が拾ったおにぎりを返してください, "Please give back the rice ball that we found." 拾い物、ひろいもの, something found, a "find," windfall. 拾 is also a formal way to write 十, ten.

story: One of Hercules' labors was to hold the world in his fingers for Atlas and not move until nightbreak, shouldering the considerable burden.
column3: One of the classic stories of shouldering a heavy burden is that of the kid who had to stick his finger on a dam until nightbreak to prevent it from breaking down.
column4: A surgeon works 'til nightbreak, fingers working with precision, shouldering the responsibility of saving the life of the person on the operating table.

story: When rockclimbing, when your weight disposes of the valuble foothold, all that's left is your fingers keeping you from death. Meanwhile, your walking legs are left dangling in the wind.
column3: Once you have a good foothold, you can dispose of your fingerhold.
column4: If you lose your foothold you will have to hold on for dear life with your fingers as your legs are left dangling in the wind. (Inspired by aircawn.)

story: A sketch is a 苗 (#249) of things to come. Before the assault, the sergeant draws a sketch of the attack with his fingers in the sand.
column3: I'm bad at drawing, so when I try to sketch the kanji for cat, you can sort of recognize it, but I don't get the curve of the "wild dogs" just right.
column4: Isn't finger paint great? This kanji shows a kid finger painting a sketch of a flowery field.

story: Tip: goods + wood/tree : This combination of primitives appears four times in Heisig, so it's worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest "furniture" (a common type of wooden goods). REF: 燥 (#228) , maneuver (FRAME 671), 繰 (#1469), 藻 (#2191). Story: Using just a finger you are trying to maneuver your furniture round your room.
column3: Luke skywalker points his fingers and uses the force to maneuver the goods through the tree branches and up over the tree.
column4: The rare kanji 喿 means "chirping birds." Therefore, why not use it since it occurs 4 times in Heisig? (note that it looks like a bunch of mouths up in a tree) Story: Think of Thing from the Adam's family (just a hand walking around) crawling around in a tree. He carefully maneuver's (this way and that) in order to isolate and stalk his pray, the chirping birds. They are quite a nuisance and he maneuvers up close and snatches one in his fingers, thus silencing its chirping.

story: A pervert meets a woman. The pervert tries to touch the women with his lustful fingers. The woman takes a vase, lifts it over her head and smashes it on the pervert's head...
column3: CHIKAN!! These are the perverts who use their fingers to touch standing women on crowded trains.
column4: Heh, Can't believe i didn't think of this any earlier. http://www.transitionsabroad.com/publications/magazine/0611/women_in_niger_carrying_water.jpg This image is perfect, some woman need to touch, others don't. :) (Vase, bucket, same thinggg :P ).

story: A muchacho puts up a notice that says “NO FINGER SNAPPING ALLOWED. MUCHACHOS ON SIESTA”. The muchachos are sleeping soundly, completely oblivious to the sound of dogs barking, guitar playing and even gun shots. Now imagine one tourist passing by and snapping his fingers and waking up all the muchachos at once.
column3: Just as I was finished putting up a "no siestas" notice on my property, a muchacho gave me the finger, sat down, and promptly fell asleep.
column4: The Mexican piano tutor PUT UP A NOTICE that his FINGERS were tired and that he was going to take an extended SIESTA.

story: Think RPG. The wizard points his finger to the guard and the ivy he has just animated with his magic wand climbs down the wall to hang the poor guy, opening the way for the adventurers into the dungeon.
column3: 3 ways you could hang something: 1) the normal way, with your finger putting something on a hook or whatever, 2) hanging from a vine the natural way, or 3) by means of the magic of the wand.
column4: This kanji depicts 3 different ways to hang something: using your fingers, using hanging ivy/rope, or with the flick of a magic wand. (much thanks to Darg Sama!)

story: "Come on people, the only way to make headway in this business is to let your fingers do the walking!" bust out the yellow pages and dial as many numbers as possible, surely someone is a sucker for a cold call sell.
column3: You can't just point with a finger and make headway, you have to actually walk* there.
column4: Walking on your fingers it's really difficult to make headway - any progress at all is very slow.

story: You use two hands to polish a stone: one to hold it and the other to rub it.
column3: Scene from Karate Kid: Wax on (with one hand), wax off (with the other). But instead of using cloth he's using stones in his hand.
column4: Cinderella polishing the stone floor with both hands.

story: Two hands, fiesta.....when moses received the ten commandments with two hands, he went back down the mountain and threw a fiesta with the jews, celebrating the arrival of the commandments.
column3: When Moses returned with the commandments in his hands he saw that his people were throwing a fiesta. At first he was excited. Then he looked around and got pissed. "Awww, c'mon guys. Golden idols? Really?"
column4: The 11th commandment was party! but Moses only had two hands and had to leave that tablet behind.

story: The king used both hands to tinker with himself in his spare time.
column3: Tinker seems to imply mending or working at something, which is wrong. This is more like "to trifle with". (The meaning of "to trifle with" is sufficiently different from "trifle" that there should be no confusion). The king can trifle with anything using his two hands (be it objects, his subjects, or himself).
column4: When something new is invented, the king is always the first to be able to tinker with it. So picture yourself looking up at the king with both hands holding your new invention, only to have it tinkered with and broken by the king who would say nothing more than "oh dear".

story: The ten commandments were heavy. So to help carry them, Moses made a wooden contraption; the ark of the covenant.
column3: In the medieval days, all who broke the commandments were locked up in a wooden contraption. (AKA Wooden Stocks).
column4: If it wasn't for Noah's wooden contraption (the ark), nobody would have survived to get the commandments.

story: An Egyptian embalmer reaching both hands into the dead pharaoh's nose and yanking out handfuls of brain.
column3: I sneezed so hard that through my NOSE I blew out my BRAINS into BOTH HANDS.
column4: Oneself may experience hay fever from rice fields requiring two hands to cover the nose while sneezing.

story: This kanji is for severe punishment. A man has his shackled hands placed on a wood block and they're chopped off with a saber. No more stealing bread in the Middle East...
column3: In Arab countries they punish theives by cutting off BOTH HANDS with a SABRE.
column4: The ancient punishment for theft was to have the thief's two hands chopped off by a red-hot sabre. To distinguish from 罰 (#833), think in terms of 'to punish', the actual -application- of the punishment, which only comes after deciding what the penalty shall be.

story: A famous ninja once pressed his two hands and saber into the soil of his temple, before going onto a mission from which he never came back. Think of some sort of signature that he left behind him. The mould of his two hands and saber has since become a popular attraction in the area.
column3: As a PUNISHMENT they made me lay face down in the DIRT leaving a nice imprinted MOULD of my whole BODY.
column4: Did you know there's a street in Japan like Hollywood Blvd. where famous ninjas press their hands and sword (which are famously deadly) into the sidewalk(soil) to form a mould?

story: A TEN year old had a STROKE of GENIUS and wrote this joke: 何歳ですか？ 。。。天才です！.
column3: Spinal tap: "Every other band's amps go to ten. But you see my extra stroke of genius - these go to eleven."
column4: Ten is ten, but add a stroke of genius and...

story: If you're a money genius, you can afford a lot of property.
column3: The keyword refers to property in the sense of money or funds rather than of buildings or real estate. Keep this one distinct from frame 193 (“wealth”) and frame 473 (“assets”). Here we have a genie, gulping down oysters. Someone tries to grab an oyster and the genie puts his big arms around his oysters and states his “right of ownership” : “They're mines, my property!”.
column4: Property comes in several forms, shells (money) and intellectual property (genius).

story: A TREE GENIUS is a LUMBER jack. Duh.
column3: The genie turns the lumber back into a tree.
column4: Just when the were about to turn the last tree into lumber, the Lorax (the tree-genie) jumps out and puts a stop to the whole affair.

story: How do you suppose they manage to cram a genie inside a bottle? Well, I suppose they put him in there while he's still a little child...
column3: Villagers on a little remote island one day find a bottle washed out by the sea onto the beach. After wiping the bottle and taking a closer look, they are amazed to see a (very small) child in it. The villagers suppose that the child is a genie in a bottle.
column4: Only children suppose genies are for real.

story: Genie in the bottle does exist but you need to dig deep into the soil to find one.
column3: You wipe the soil from the bottle, only to have a genie float out above you, saying: 'I am the genie in a bottle, what is your wish?' So now you know that they do exist.
column4: Genies don't exist! If you open the "genie in a bottle" you'll find nothing but soil.

story: FROM a pictograph of a thumbs up. That's how it also gets the primitive meaning of fist.
column3: Pictograph, see book. This kanji, as a chinese character, is in fact the origin for the hiragana possessive particle “no”. Try drawing this kanji fast, in a single stroke and you will end up with の .
column4: Think Charlton Heston: "From my cold, dead fists". Speech given to the National Boxing Association, in response to stricter control on boxing gloves.

story: This character is the "kei" in "keitai" (cell phone), a word you will no doubt hear often in Japan, since everyone has one. Imagine you've just arrived in Japan, but don't have a cell phone yet, so instead you're carrying around a portable turkey you can hold in your fist. To dial a number, just poke it with your fingers.
column3: Because they have no fingers, turkeys must use their fists when dialing on a portable phone.
column4: This character is the "kei" in "keitai" (cell phone), a word you will no doubt hear often in Japan, since everyone has one. I use my keitai with my FINGERS, like everyone, but if some TURKEY try to steal it, I don't hesitate to use my FIST .

story: I like to think of this as a fist with with brass knuckles because of the extra line. An old school thug reaches out to help you up but then with his other hand ( with the brass knuckles) punches you.
column3: This is an image of the fist getting an arm (the new stroke). The FIST now reaches out farther than before.
column4: I like to think of the MATRIX. Now hear me out... Remember the scene when Neo and Mr. Smith fought in the subway? there was this one part where Mr. Smith threw his FIST at Neo, but Neo stopped it. Mr. Smith reached out his finger (the line coming from fist) and hit Neo in the throat.

story: An open mouth and reaching hands : a baby wants to suck at his mother's breast.
column3: Imagine a baby reaching out and holding mom's breast as if it were bottle, and sucking on it to get some milk.
column4: It's a terrible image, but I see a baby reaching out to her mother's breasts, wanting to suckle some milk with her mouth. Meanwhile, her mother is sucking back on a cig with total disregard to her child's health. / Thanks Proxx: This is also the kanji for すう (吸う), used for "to smoke [a cigarette]".

story: One of the first thing a baby can do with his hand is to reach out and grab your finger as if it was a little handle.
column3: Pay attention to this story because you'll learn how to recall the reading of this kanji as well: We've all heard the expression: "Too hot to handle" -- Well, just imagine you are reaching out your fingers to touch someone's face and it is too hot to handle. (Then you can combine the word for hot (atsui) with the word for face (kao) and always remember how this character is read: atsukau - あつかう.)
column4: Handle with care... carefully hold the Nitroglycerin within your fingers with outstretched hands for fear of it blowing up in your face...

story: Both a meter and a yard are about one arm-length.
column3: ONE ARM LENGTH.
column4: This kanji reminds me of the kanji for big (I think it looks the same kinda of except for the last stroke). Maybe this works for guys, but when you were growing up you would compare "length" with your friends trying to show how BIG you were. You wouldn't show "it" but you would spread your arms out as wide as possible to exaggerate your length. Maybe even so wide that you trip (I the 3rd stroke getting pushed over)! I just find it easier to relate this to the previous kanji.

story: I sleep in history class with my mouth tucked under my arm.
column3: History students usually going to school with a history book tucked under their arm. But now instead of a book, you have a small talking mouth that tell you about history. "When I was young, I used to walk 5 miles everyday....."
column4: History is told by one mouth; the winner's. The loser's opinion is not told and is tucked under the arm (silenced ) by the winner.

story: One officer can change the course of history.
column3: One officer, namely Napoleon, changed the course of history. (Thanks, ayoung24). Napoleon is also my primitive meaning.
column4: This is not 尉 (#1095), but more of a government officer, official or bureaucrat, such as Barack Obama, who started out as a lowly government officer (communitee organizer) and the broke through the glass ceiling to become president of the United States and make history (I know a glass ceiling generally refers to an obstacle for women, but I wanted to avoid key words such as 女 (#98), 婦 (#1151) or 雌 (#563)).

story: At 旦 (#30) the sun rises above the floor, so it is logical that when it is growing late, the sun would rise to the ceiling. Time to pack up your things and take your belongings under your arm.
column3: I keep one sun tucked under my arm for light when it grows late.
column4: When it is growing late, the sun sinks below the floor. Time to tuck your belongings under your arm and head home. 更ける (ふける) : get late, advance, wear on; 更に (さらに) : furthermore, again, after all, more and more, moreover; 変更 (へんこう) : change, modification, alteration; 夜更け (よふけ) : late at night.

story: A stiff drink on the ROCKs after it GROWS LATE is a way to unwind after a long day...
column3: Stones are so stiff that even if you spent all day straining trying to change their shape, it would grow late far before you ever accomplished your task.
column4: There's a city whose inhabitants stiffen and turn to stone every night when it grows late.

story: I learned this one from the movie Evil Dead, but when it grows late, trees change shape and become spiny creatures! Lesson: don't go out at night.
column3: Usually the tree you bump into when it grows late happens to be spiny.
column4: Spiny are the trees that grow late in the year, usually in colder climates.

story: This keyword should really be "again" not "or again" Here is some context: think of the phrase "Jya mata" "じゃ又" which is a farewell similar to "then again". Also "Mata ne" "又ね" and mata ashita (again tomorrow) "又明日"。 Note this kanji is rarely used, most of the time JP people spell it out "mata" except for in the last example: 又明日.
column3: Cross you legs, or again I'll see your crotch.
column4: As a primitive, instead of using "crotch", I also often use "sat cross-legged" as this also looks like the kanji.

story: The animals boarding Noah's Ark all came in pairs – but Noah had to carefully check the two crotches in each pair to ensure that the animals were of different sexes and thus able to further their species after the flood.
column3: Crotch to crotch is how many pairs spend their private time together. . .
column4: The left crotch looks more like the man's and the right a woman's, the ultimate pair.

story: Children going around the mulberry tree singing "This is the way we wash our crotch, wash our crotch, wash our crotch..."
column3: Imagine kids all over the top of a mulberry tree, sitting astride limbs so that their weight is on their crotches. (Mulberry trees have big sprawling limbs that run horizontally or at shallow angles making them easy to climb and sit in. I have an old mulberry in my yard, and my kids are in it constantly).
column4: According to Wikipedia, "unripe [MULBERRY] fruit and green parts of the plant have a white sap that is intoxicating and mildly hallucinogenic." When looking at the MULBERRY tree, some have hallucinated that they are seeing crotches, crotches everywhere!

story: Donald Duck is a big bird that does not wear pants. It's good to use him as a mnemonic because he is a sailor, and this kanji is used to count vessels.
column3: The turky's crotch is a vessel for the stuffing that you fill it with.
column4: The USS Turkeycrotch is a seaworthy vessel.

story: Think of the flower-vessels as a the Greenpeace vessel “Arctic Sunrise”, only instead of a rainbow there is a big flower painted on the hull (this will come back in 獲 (#757) and 穫 (#974)). Think of “flower-power” and of the “peace” in “Greenpeace” and it will make some sense hopefully. -- In this kanji, we see an inauguration speech being given before the Greenpeace vessel is set afloat and sent to safeguard our planet.
column3: Words and Flowers are exchanged between sailors and their wives before they board the vessel to safeguard the world.
column4: The flower vessel is of course the Mayflower in which the pilgrims came to America in their search for turkeys. During they trip, they prayed non-stop - using words as spells to safeguard Mayflower from danger.

story: A pack of genetically-modified wild dogs is seized by a group of Greenpeace activists and taken onboard the Greenpeace vessel (the flower vessel, see 護 (#700)).
column3: Customs just seized a crate of poppies (flowers) detected by trained wild dogs who inspected the vessel.
column4: A group of police dogs are used to sniff out some opium flowers on a cargo vessel. The drugs are then seized by the authorities.

story: That GUY stole my WOMAN so I kicked him in the CROTCH. (This story helps keep the word "GUY" as someone you hold in contempt).
column3: Guys only care about 2 things: women and their crotch (preferably at the same time).
column4: GUYS (derogatory) are always thinking about women's crotches. 1) 此奴 【こいつ】this guy. 2) 其奴 【そいつ】that guy. 3) 彼奴 【あいつ】that guy.

story: This woman is angry because of the guys in the previous frame who pay more attention to her crotch than her heart. I prefer to decompose the kanji in three elements here because it is easier to read like a mnemonic.
column3: WOMEN get very ANGRY over the thought that GUYS are more interested in her CROTCH than her HEART.
column4: When a guy steps on her heart, a woman can get quite angry.

story: A good friend is always at your side. ---- I teach at a Japanese High School, and I often see chummy male students grabbing each other's crotches in a joking manner. It's still weird to me, but apparently reaching to your side and grabbing you neighbor's crotch is a great way to express friendship.
column3: A friend is always on your side - again and again and again.
column4: Your best friend is your crotch. Its always by your side and never lets you down.

story: Don't let good friends slip out between your fingers.
column3: Imagine a cliché Hollywood situation: one person is lying on the edge of the abyss and another (presumably his friend) is hanging, only thing holding him is the grip of their hands. Then fingers slip out of the grip and he falls in said abyss.
column4: Her fingers slipped out of mine as she said, 'I think we should just be friends...'

story: Well, you usually use your fingers to throw objects used as missile weapons. Easy. By the way, for those of you looking for a less anachronistic image for the missile primitive as a modern rocket, try a slingshot. it's a crotch (originally a tree branch) that sends missile projectiles flying into/like the wind. And for this present kanji, it is something you naturally use with your fingers...
column3: RPG. A wizard throws magic missiles from the tip of his fingers.
column4: He's a great pitcher. He can throw a split finger fastball that's like a missile.

story: (Note: this kanji is more collapse/cave-in/沈 (#2033) than humans drowning) A water missile? A torpedo! And when it hits it's target? The ship collapses then sinks and everyone drowns!
column3: The submarine's hull was breached after being struck by a torpedo ("water missile"), causing the entire crew to drown.
column4: I give this Kanji the keyword go down (in the sense of something plummeting or going down badly, not in the sense of descending, which is already used) because it is used in sinking (沈没), dying (戦没), and sunset (日没). It seems to me 溺 is the character for drown, and in fact it is given the keyword "drowning" later, which is just confusing to me. Story: The ship is going down! We were hit by a water missile (a torpedo).

story: Where's my flesh missile? Between my thighs, naturally...
column3: Chun Li's thunder thighs -- the part of her body that lets her kick with the force and speed of a missile.
column4: My thigh is the part of the body that my missile smacks against.

story: Establishment can be attacked by words or by missiles. Writers will use words, whereas militars will use missiles.
column3: When you attack the establishment with words, it fights back with missiles.
column4: In the United States, we began by establishing justice with words (in our constitution), but somewhere along the line we began 'establishing justice' with missiles instead. :(.

story: Your car has missles?! That beats mine, hands down.
column3: Think 3 methods of attack all combined into 1 kanji: 1. Vehicle to transport troops 2. Once troops have disembarked they have their missiles 3. If they run out of missiles they resort to hand to hand combat to beat the enemy.
column4: In a random version of rock,paper, scissors. A car is beaten by a missile that hits it, the missile is beaten by the hand that can type in the deactivation code (which in turn is beaten by the car that runs over it).

story: husk or shell. Japan's recent history in a nutshell: first the samurai became superfluous and then the Americans started to throw missiles and bombs during WWII.
column3: The primitives tie so nicely into a story: upon the use of missiles in warfare, the traditional role of samurai became superfluous in battle. How to tie it to the keyword of "husk"? Easy! Afterwards, the samurai were demoted (like potato-peeling privates), and they sat around HUSKING corn and cracking eggs and peanut shells (kanji refers to both 'husk' and 'shell'). A strong image to lock in the kanji: imagine samurai using their mighty swords to de-husk corn and split peanuts! Also see 穀 (#984).
column4: The samurai, now superfluous since the advent of the missile, was but a husk of a man. (Sumarai/Superfluous):Missile = Husk.

story: Picture sliding down the branch of a tree (in this case a pine tree or any tree with needles) and getting a bunch of needles stuck in your crotch--ouch!!
column3: A special branch of the military called the Needle Crotch Unit. Their only weapon is the needle embedded in their crotches, and they're quite adept at using them.
column4: Sitting on the BRANCH of a coniferous tree, getting sharp needles in my crotch. (Remember there is no tree radical in this kanji, whereas 枝 (#713) (枝) does because a "bough" is a main part of the tree, whereas this kanji refers to a smaller branch. It can also be used to refer to the branch of a store (支店) which also has nothing to do with a tree).

story: (Adapted from darg_sama's) Balancing a branch on your finger is the prototypical example of a skill that is nothing more than a skill (i.e., it is completely useless).
column3: I think of a guy balancing a branch on his finger, which definitely takes some minimal amount of skill.
column4: A surgeon's skill with his fingers determines his branch of medicine.

story: The tree's primary branch is known as the bough.
column3: Differentiate between BOUGH and 支 (#768): 'branch' is smaller, and can also refer to the branch of a store (支店), which has nothing to do with a tree. But a BOUGH is a main part of a tree, perhaps where the trunk splits into several large boughs, and so it logically utilizes the 木 radical.
column4: I think of a bough as a branch that's big enough to be a tree itself.

story: The limbs that this kanji represents are parts of the body that are connected to the trunk, like the main branches to a tree (“arms and legs” is the second meaning of this kanji). In other words, limbs are "flesh branches".
column3: Limbs are body parts that branch off.
column4: No Timmy, we don't say "flesh branches", we say "limbs".

story: Suggestion: Replace "spool" with "toilet paper/roll". Reasons: (1) Toilet paper/roll usually comes on a spool. (2) Toilet paper is used to clean the soil off your crotch. Story: Just get a flower and carefully wrap some toilet paper around its stalk. Spool also appears in 怪 (#773), 軽 (#774), 径 (#947), 経 (#1460).
column3: PRIMITIVE: soiled crotch = soiled underwear. To precent anyone from picking the beautiful flower, the gardner hung soiled underwear on the stalk.
column4: A flower's stalk can be seen as connecting the flower to the soil, or again the soil to the flower. It depends on how you look at it.

story: When you're suspicious, your state of mind twists round and round like a spool of thread.
column3: Suggestion: Replace "spool" with "toilet paper/roll". Reason: See my note at 茎 (#772). Story: Sigmund Freud (= state of mind) has a mystery patient who has wrapped himself entirely in toilet paper. Freud is very suspicious that it's someone he knows (who wants to remain anonymous). Spool also appears in 茎 (#772), 軽 (#774), 径 (#947), 経 (#1460).
column4: The girl's state of mind certainly became suspicious when she found a lot of used toilet paper in the waste basket beside her boyfriend's computer...

story: Fact: this kanji is used to denote a certain class of vehicles in Japan whose engines are under a certain size (less than 750cc I think) and are called light vehicles here. Imagine a so-called light vehicle or a light-truck with a load of spools driving down a road ever so lightly, careful not to let any of the spools roll out onto the street.
column3: Suggestion: Replace "spool" with "toilet paper/roll". Reason: See my note at 茎 (#772). Story: You are fussy about your car and to clean it you will only dab it very lightly with toilet paper. Spool also appears in 茎 (#772), 怪 (#773), 径 (#947), 経 (#1460).
column4: I want to tread lightly on the environment.... That's why I CAR-SPOOL to work everyday.... I know, lame.

story: Four straight kanji here with 叔 in it, so let's make one story: Your UNCLE was full of 寂 (#777) (寂), and he lived by himself. He was naturally 淑 (#778) (淑) in the water, and you knew he was once on the Olympic synchronized swimming team). You knew that there was something different about him, but you joined his youth team and he watched over you carefully as 督 (#776) (督). It was uncomfortable, though, how your 叔 (#775) often touched you just a little above the crotch (叔) when coaching...
column3: Imagine one of those cliches of comedy: an uncle is above the little crotch of the new born nephew, when the baby pees in his face!
column4: This kanji becomes easy if you use its proper meaning as a keyword: younger sibling of parent. Now read the character as a set of instructions to locate the younger siblings of your parents in your family tree, starting from yourself: If you go up to the row (generation) above, to your parents, then the younger siblings of your parents are the littler ones as that sprang from the same crotch.

story: Creepy uncle volunteers as gymnastics coach so he can eye the team from below.
column3: Four straight kanji here with 叔 in it, so let's make one story: Your UNCLE was full of 寂 (#720) (寂), and he lived by himself. He was naturally 淑 (#721) (淑) in the water, and you knew he was once on the Olympic synchronized swimming team. You knew that there was something different about him, but you joined his youth team and he watched over you carefully as 督 (#719) (督). It was uncomfortable, though, how your 叔 (#718) often touched you just a little above the crotch (叔) when COACHing...
column4: My uncle is also my coach. He keeps an eye on me.

story: The unmarried uncle's house is the picture of lonlieness.
column3: Four straight kanji here with 叔 in it, so let's make one story: Your UNCLE was full of 寂 (#720) (寂), and he lived by himself. He was naturally 淑 (#721) (淑) in the water, and you knew he was once on the Olympic synchronized swimming team. You knew that there was something different about him, but you joined his youth team and he watched over you carefully as 督 (#719) (督). It was uncomfortable, though, how your 叔 (#718) often touched you just a little above the crotch (叔) when coaching...
column4: This obviously refers to uncle Scrooge. Remember before he started to hang out with his nephews, he lived all alone in a huge house, old and broken because of the loneliness.

story: Uncle (the one who is lonely and coaches kids in his spare time) is actually a graceful guy once he hits the water, as he used to be part of the swimming team in his youth.
column3: Four straight kanji here with 叔 in it, so let's make one story: Your UNCLE was full of 寂 (#720) (寂), and he lived by himself. He was naturally 淑 (#721) (淑) in the water, and you knew he was once on the Olympic synchronized swimming team. You knew that there was something different about him, but you joined his youth team and he watched over you carefully as 督 (#719) (督). It was uncomfortable, though, how your 叔 (#718) often touched you just a little above the crotch (叔) when coaching...
column4: Your uncle’s bellyflop into the water is far from graceful.

story: I think of an anti-hero (Dirty Harry etc.) for this primitive, whose trademark for disposing of villians is not an honorable fight, but a kick in the crotch and then a shove off a cliff (perhaps whilst the villain's back is turned).
column3: Many cultures are so anti-sex you'd think they just want people to throw their crotches over a cliff.
column4: Despite their stunning similarity, this is not a 友 (#760), but the opposite: An anti-friend! Instead of always being at your side he throws you off a cliff.

story: A slope is anti-flat soil.
column3: As the villain (pushed off by the anti-hero) is tumbling down the slope, he activates gadget skis to escape, spraying soil everywhere as he flies down the slope.
column4: This kanji depicts a classic enviornmental problem: erosion. Erosion occurs when all of the soil washes of the side of the cliff, eventually causing the cliff to disappear, leaving a slope (an anti- cliff if you will) in its place.

story: Of course, trees are anti-plank. Wouldn't you be if you were a tree?
column3: Trees are naturally opposed to, or anti, the making of planks.
column4: Trees are definitely anti-plank. They're even having a protest. Ironically the signs are still made of paper.

story: Return here means "return something" rather than "go back". So here it goes, for those of you who are also suffering of the Japanese summer ;-) I ordered an anti mosquito kit, but it was damaged on the way so I had to return it.
