column3: "Return our land! Return our land!" - the cries of ANTI-ROAD protestors whose houses have been claimed under eminent domain laws to build a new ROAD.
column4: I am not sure why, but I bought a road. Why did I do that? I hate roads. I'm anti road! I'd rather fly. I'd better see if I can return it.

story: The goal of marketing is to get people who are naturally anti-buying to spend their shells (money).
column3: 『MARKETING: MONEY, ANTI』 The wide presence of MARKETING in our society has led people to become ANTI-MONEY.
column4: Marketing is an anti-money of sorts. When it comes into contact with money, the money disappears.

story: A pictograph of Wolverine's adamantium claws.
column3: Pictograph, see book. * I prefer the primitive meaning of an eagle rather than vulture. Somehow vulture makes me think more about meat and dead corpses than claws. An eagle however immediately brings to my mind the image of an eagle plunging into a stream catching fish in his claws, or that of the great eagles rescuing Bilbo and his party in Jrr Tolkien's novel “Bilbo the Hobbit”.
column4: Pictograph of a vulture's CLAW. The CLAW DROPS and leaves a STREAM of blood. *Primitive = vulture.

story: Overly gentle women are vultures who want to marry you and steal your money - not true but an easy mnemonic!
column3: An eagle must be extra gentle to pick up a dainty woman in its sharp claws.
column4: Edward Scissorhands was very gentle, and adored by women in spite of his claws.

story: A fledgling is being nursed at a zoo, it is fed milk through a small tube that is bent in the shape of a hook (so that it fits inside its beak). The fledgling soon becomes addicted to milk, giving us this very catchy mnemonic: “fledgling hooked on milk”.
column3: Drinking milk not only reduces 孔 (#100)'s but also strengthens nails (claws) thanks astgtciv.
column4: This fledgling is hooked on MILK.. better than booze I suppose...

story: Floating rubber ducky!!!
column3: A nest of fledglings somehow fell into the water (maybe it was perched on a tree bending over the river), but they are safe for now as the nest is floating. The fledglings are enjoying the cruise but they are soon coming to a great waterfall... ( a little drama to help us remember the story).
column4: An ugly duckling (fledgling) FLOATING in the water. But this one doesn't grow up into a swan - he's a vulture.

story: The vulture is on top of the porter and appears to be commiting a lewd act, so I throw water over the pair of them.
column3: The PORTER is lewd like hell. If a female guest tries to enter the hotel, he throws himself on her like a VULTURE. Therefore it is highly recommended for the ladies to bring some cold WATER and pour it over him to cool him down.
column4: The porter is dripping wet and has claw marks down his back. He receives a big tip for the unspeakably lewd acts he committed with a wealthy heiress guest, after she showed she expected more of him than just carrying her bags up to her suite.

story: The leader in this race is the turtle! It appears he has covered the vulture’s feet in glue, so that the vulture cannot get off the starting block.
column3: Once upon a time a turtle managed to trick a vulture into gluing itself to the turtle's shell. This way the turtle could now fly anywhere and became the leader of the turtles.
column4: X-men and TMNT join forces: Their new leader is an awsome asshole. He is simply Wolverine and Raphael glued together back to back (the biggest assholes from both groups combined).

story: It's easy to picture a LEADER that uses a BIG dog to EXHORT his people to do more.
column3: Here we have a St.Bernard exhorting the vulture to become the leader in the race against the turtle, but he can't because of the glue. see 将 (#789).
column4: Never support the leader!! Always exhort the underdog !!!

story: You ever wondered why this appeared as a primitive in so many RTK1 kanji? Well, you should know that once a vulture grabs hold of a tree, he can never let go. Even Heisig couldn't shake him loose.
column3: A common meaning for this kanji is 'DICE'. --- Ever wonder what vultures do up in the trees? They play DICE. But of course, being vultures, they are always grabbing the dice away from each other.
column4: The gigantic VULTURE swoops down and grabs that huge TREE!! AAAAH!!

story: You pick cheries with your fingers, then along comes a giant vulture and picks up the whole tree with its claws.
column3: Tip: vulture + tree : Heisig later combines these into a single kanji 采 called 采 (#791). Story: As you go to pick your nose, your parent grabs your finger and pulls it away (& gives you a lecture on social etiquette). REF: "grab" also appears in 菜 (#793), 彩 (#1850).
column4: 采 is grab (FRAME 采 (#791)) Pick is grab but delicately with your fingers only (thanks katsuo).

story: A vegetarian vulture is munching on a flower, perched on a tree, patiently waiting for a patch of vegetables to grow.
column3: 采 (#791) beneath the flowers to get the vegetables. 野菜　やさい.
column4: Wolverine is turning into total hippie. He said he only eats vegetables now and last time I saw him sitting in a tree with flowers in his hair.

story: The bird house is the brothel (someone else said so) and of course everyone is welcome - thay accept any crotch.
column3: The birds accepted the birdhouse that I made for them. I can see them there again and again.
column4: The birds accepted the birdhouse we hung in the crotch of the tree branch.

story: "Please accept this finger," you say, imparting it to your yakuza boss.
column3: This character depicts a student and teacher. The teacher imparts his knowledge on the student, pointing the way and guiding with the finger. Meanwhile, the student sits there passively accepting the tutelage of his superior.
column4: Impart means to "grant a share of." so imagine yourself imparting a share of M&M's (with your fingers) and it being happily accepted by the recipient.

story: If you really love someone, you won't keep them in a cage-like bird house relationship, but rather open the door and let their heart walk around freely. Think less about "I" (あい) and more about "we".
column3: The man is about to enter the 'birdhouse' (brothel) when he remembers his true love at home, and, following his heart, uses his walking legs to go straight home.
column4: 愛は相手の心を受けることです。(I heard that one from a buddhist priest - dont forget the extra stroke).

story: The sun's love is equivocal: it warms yet burns us.
column3: In RTK1 Supplement as "unclear." His feelings about her were equivocal/unclear, so she spent all day playing "loves me, loves me not."
column4: Inspired by haabaato: You confess your love under the sun, but the girl runs away. Her response is unclear to you (Using the supplement's keyword).

story: You're at a restaurant and raise your finger to indicate to the waiter that you want to pay. Your friend elbows you in the ribs -- it's his shout, and he insists on taking care of the bill.
column3: You are walking out of the restaurant when the waiter uses his FINGERS to grab you at the ELBOW and says, "excuse me sir, didn't you forget to PAY?"
column4: Traditionally Japanese people kept vallet in their kimono sleeves, so they reach for elbow with their fingers when they want to pay.

story: The Batcave is very wide and has a lot of elbow room for Batman to do his yoga.
column3: A wide cave has a lot of "elbow room".
column4: A caveman widens his cave by pounding on the interior with his strong elbows.

story: In RTK1 Supplement as "hooked." A friend hooked someone literally, by binding them up with their hooked elbow.
column3: Your elbow is bound up so that your biceps will stay flexed.
column4: Peter Pan tried to escape, but Hook hooked him by the elbow and bound him up.

story: Spread your fingers wide to broaden your hand.
column3: Broaden= you can widening an image with fingers on the iphone!
column4: An orthodontist with his fingers in your mouth says "open wide" and helps you to broaden your smile.

story: Elbonium: a new mineral found in wide caves shaped like elbows and made of metal.
column3: There's a really wide cave in Africa which is used as a mineral sample house. It has all sorts of metals in it which is why it is used that way. Picture all the widened stretched out tables which have been set up to display the various metals and other minerals.
column4: Imagine some miners mining some minerals, with their metal picks, in a cave, as they mine out more and more minerals, the cave gets wider and wider….

story: Opening a stuck valve requires 2 hands and a lot of elbow grease.
column3: "She's stuck real good-like" the guy from the いなか (田舎; country) said to me with a strong rural dialect (弁; べん). "You best grab on ta'er with both hands and giv-er that VALVE some elba' greeze." (I couldn't resist: this is a favourite Japanese word of mine, which also means "regional dialect." Such as Osaka-ben 大阪弁; almost all prefectures in Japan will boast of their own 弁 and slang).
column4: You try to unblock an old rusty valve with a hit of the elbow, and then with your two hands, to no avail.

story: Men walk with their elbows out from their sides in a weird turkey trot when they try to appear very MASCULINE. Think of a 70's pimp walk.
column3: Masculine duties are to offer your elbow to the lady by your left side and to cut the turkey on special meals.
column4: Surely you remember 雌 (#605)? In that kanji, we said stop/spooning/turkeys, spoon females! Here, once again, my buddy is looking at a turkey. What the heck is his problem? I give him a sharp elbow in the side. "Dude, be a man!" I said. "Where's your MASCULINE side?"

story: When someone's elbow is above your mouth he/she is probably standing on a pedestal.
column3: After training your whole life, you manage to get a bronze medal in the Olympics. You're extremely proud of your accomplishment as you step up to receive your medal. The guy in first place is up on a pedestal, towering above you, his elbow level with your mouth. Being a smug bastard, he "accidentally" knocks his elbow into your mouth, causing you to bleed and lose a tooth. Just cause he won the gold doesn't mean he can place himself on such a high pedestal and do whatever he wants!
column4: Rodin's 'Thinker' sitting on a pedestal, the arm bent at the elbow cradling the mouth.

story: While standing on the pedestal at the award ceremony, the recipient heartlessly neglected to mention the people that got him there.
column3: Someone you put on a pedestal will NEGLECT your heart.
column4: People who neglect don't put your heart on a pedestal, they put it below it!

story: From his water pedestal Neptune reigns over his Sea Empire.
column3: Build a moat around your pedestal to protect your reign of power.
column4: Michael Phelps reigns supreme as he stands on his watery pedestal (he just got out of the pool).

story: The secrets of metallurgy and smithing: get your redhot metal and bang it against the pedestal as an anvil. Then cool it quickly with lots of ice.
column3: An ICE PEDESTAL is useless in METALLURGY since it will just melt.
column4: In metallurgy, you need ice to cool the item, and a pedestal to craft it on.

story: Many men, before they commence their relationship with the woman of their desires, place her on something of a pedestal, which often leads to disappointment later on.
column3: Just think of any art class. You put a WOMAN on a PEDESTAL then you COMMENCE to draw her.
column4: If you want to commence a relationship, just put a woman on a pedestal and she'll love ya forever.

story: If any body part deserves to be put on a pedestal, it is the womb from which new life springs forth.
column3: In this kanji pedestal carries a sense of base, or stand. The womb is part of the body that acts as a pedestal: a base or stand from which a new human being is brought into life.
column4: Imagine the womb as a part of the body which contains a little 台 (#744) for the baby to stand on. Picture the baby, like a little statue of a cherub, standing on its pedestal in the fleshy womb.

story: This is either a love scene or a murder scene that you are seeing through a window. The love scene: through the window of a house (from a distance), you see a pair of human legs, then elbows, and then some pink hearts floating up like in a cartoon. The murder scene: peering through the window of a house, you see a gruesome murder scene. Human legs dangling from a ceiling fan, an elbow sticking out of a wall, and a heart still beating on the carpet.
column3: A photographer is at home, recovering his broken human legs. With nothing better to do, he is looking through the rear window with his camera (he needs to use his elbow to support those heavy lenses) until his heart begins to race as he witnesses a murder!
column4: A voyeur peeks in the window of a house, but all he can see is legs. So he elbows up into the window for a better view which gets his heart racing.

story: "Going, going, GONE!", said the gravedigger as he shoveled soil onto the body's protruding elbow (the last bit left to cover).
column3: If you want the soil stains gone from your clothes, then you'll need to put some elbow grease into cleaning them.
column4: I brush soil off my elbow - now it's GONE.

story: This kanji shows up in a lot of words related to the legal process. Try this image: using a very outdated judicial method, the people of Salem dunked accused witches in the water until they were all gone.
column3: There already was a 制 (#447) for butchering cows, a 芸 (#450) for turning smoke into flowers - why can't there be a method of about the same relevance for making water gone? Evaporation anyone?
column4: Following from the last frame; when rubbing isn't good enough, WATER is the best METHOD for making sure the SOIL on your ELBOW is GONE.

story: At the local company they have a very gory way of getting rid of incompetent personnel : they arrange a business meeting in a very special room where the walls are ... meeting. Not surprisingly the boss is never present at these meetings, he's the one who pushes the button that sets the walls in motion.
column3: The only thing created in most meetings is a lot of hot air. Imagine a cloud of it rising to the roof.
column4: Easy: (secret) meetings are held between 4 walls.

story: Sexual climaxes don't always happen on the bed; they sometimes happen against a wall or on the ground!
column3: The climax of the Berlin Wall affair was the tearing of it to ground.
column4: This kanji is the companion to 乃 (#741). It carries the primary meaning of 'arrive' or 'reach', so the 乃至 compound means "from... to...". In this sense, it is logical how humanity has progressed from using soil to build shelter, etc., to making walls and more advanced structures. And yet, we have not reached the CLIMAX of our potential.

story: You book a room in a love hotel called "Climax House".
column3: A simple room is made up of a roof, some walls, and a dirt floor.
column4: This is the room of a “climax house”, that is, a Japanese love hotel.

story: Http://i.imgur.com/RwJA4bH.jpg Just look at this image...
column3: Just as we were about to climax her father arrived with a sword.
column4: Arrival of a hero always happens at the CLIMAX of the movie, and of course he carries a SABER to defeat the enemy.

story: This character is used in two very high-frequency words: "you are welcome" (どう致しまして) and the honorific form of onegaishimasu (お願い致します; おねがいいたします). Can't you just picture this ridiculously polite S&M picture? A businessman, who DOTH the bidding of his taskmistress, is climaxing and yelling out "お願い致します" while she whips and says "どう致しまして". (This kanji also means "to bring about" and "do humbly", which is perfect for this image).
column3: To reach climax I doth the bidding of my dominatrix taskmaster.
column4: After he had climaxed Shakespeare is reported to have said to his taskmistress, "The lady doth charge too much."

story: The 69 position allows both parties to mutually give themselves pleasure.
column3: Mutually means "You and You together"---two katakana ユ (yu)s interlocking top and bottom.
column4: If you can combined your walls with another house's walls, both houses would mutually benefit, by the increase in size....

story: Think of a really loud and annoying baby, you want to abandon it but it keeps coming back...so you take of your belt by the buckle, and buckle the baby to a tree!
column3: A terrible image of an abandoned infant. Here he is in his little car seat buckled to a tree.
column4: The abandonned infant was buckled to a tree.

story: Bringing up your offspring means raising them from infant until they are meat ready to be harvested. What, cannibalism is in poor taste? Forget I ever brought it up. But bring up will forver be infant meat to me. I want my baby back baby back baby back ribs!
column3: Bringing up an infant requires months of hard work.
column4: Bringing up an infant on the Moon is easier than it is on Earth. (month=lunar) Gravity is lower, so they're easier to carry and they don't get hurt if they fall down. Best of all, their little space suits keep all that poopy smell inside!

story: A terrible yakuza taskmaster is bringing up his infant. Every time the infant does something wrong... well, you know what happens to yakuzas when they do something wrong.
column3: A taskmaster brings up his infant by threatening to remove a finger as punishment.
column4: "Don't lay a finger on him," a concerned mother says as the state REMOVES her child away for upbringing by a taskmaster foster home. 撤回 【てっかい】 (n,vs) withdrawal, revocation, repeal, (P) 撤退 【てったい】 (n,vs) evacuation, withdrawal, revocation, repeal.

story: Scene at the baby factory: Manager: "Good news! Your infant has been allotted human legs". Parent to be: "Thanks a lot!"
column3: An infant at the maternity ward is alloted a new pair of human legs, because his are not grown properly or absent. Picture the “lot” as a parcel, placed near the infant, to be used later. The “lot” of human legs has been alloted by some doctor, to be used later. Mnemonic “infant alloted new pair of human legs”. Note: to allot means to apportion by lots, it has the same root as the word “lottery”.
column4: In China, you are only ALLOTed one INFANT per family. My friends disagreed with that policy and HUMAN LEGGED it out of there!

story: "Everyone is allotted a metal gun" (US constitution according to the NRA).
column3: What is a gun but a device for allotting pieces of metal? One for you - BANG!...One for you - BANG!...One for you - BANG!...One for you - BANG!...etc.
column4: During war, all metal is allotted to the effort to make more guns.

story: Sulphur is like a rock, but it can stink like a stream of infant doodie.
column3: Sulphur IS a rock, but it often stinks like a stream of infant urine. It is the same color too!!!
column4: Infants are baptised in streams inorder to prevent their descent into a place of sulphur and brimstone.

story: INFANT Moses placed in the WATER and sent down the current of the STREAM.
column3: An INFANT fell in the WATER and was lost down the CURRENT of the STREAM.
column4: A water-breathing infant (genetically modified?) is caught in a flood, and drifts with the current, apparently enjoying himself in the process.

story: In some Asian kung-fu version of James Bond, the main protagonist has a “License To Kill” with his deadly elbows and human legs. His suit is always stained of red blood at the elbows and lower legs (this to help create an image that distinguish the two elements).
column3: You need a license to show your elbows and legs in mid east countries.
column4: A midget driver trying to pass the road test to get their driver's license. Their elbows are too short to turn the wheel and their legs are too short to reach the gas and breaks.

story: I named the right part legal prostitute has it represents a walker [walking legs] with the license. It's easy to imagine a legal prostitute tempting a man with her mouth.
column3: Prostitutes in Amsterdam have a license to show off their walking legs and tempt customers with their mouths.
column4: Tip : the right side can be thought of as a profession where one works on the street, for which they require a "license to work on their walking legs". This could be a sandwich man, or a prostitute (see gorgon's story). In this case, it's easily remembered as a prostitute tempting passers-by with her mouth. The combination will appear again in frames 1014, and 1437, and another four times in RTK Volume 3, where it is known as streetwalker (which is very close).

story: Suddenly, a cactus comes out of the ground with a sign that reads: exit. Now you can leave the desert! (Note: giving this primitive the meaning 'cactus' can be useful later).
column3: The exit lays between these two mountains.
column4: A mountain chain blocked our exit from Mordor.

story: YOU CAN'T POSSIBLY NEED A MNEMONIC FOR THIS!!!!
column3: Pictograph, see book. * As a primitive this element appears equally as well at the top or bottom of the kanjis (besides appearing to the left). Since a mountain often brings to mind towering peaks, I will consider it implied that the element is placed at the top of the kanji. When this primitive appears at the bottom, I will arrange my story in a way that other elements are said to be at the very top of the mountain (see FRAME 775 for an example).
column4: Stroke order: Begin with the center vertical.

story: With fingers fumbling around trying to get the key in the door so he could exit, the bungling husband woke his wife as he tried to leave for a rendezvous with his mistress.
column3: Horror movie cliche 769: Bungling victim's fingers fumble & bungle trying to open the exit door.
column4: You were bungling in the darkness and touched the cactus with your fingers. OUCH!!

story: A mountain-sized stone is known as a boulder.
column3: Here we see mountain rocks rolling down the mountain, gathering into a single monstrous boulder crushing everything in its path. Think snowball effect, even if it wouldn't work with rocks.
column4: Boulders are rocks that fall from the mountains above, just like in zelda.

story: Burn enough charcoal and you'll have a mountain of ash.
column3: You get charcoal from volcano ("fire mountain", 火山) ashes.
column4: Imagine a that a mountain fell onto a pile of ashes, compressing it into charcoal.

story: On the left, there are three mountains. The road branches off to each of them. (Note: This kanji is mostly used for branches in the road).
column3: In a lot of Super Nintendo-era RPGs, there are mountain levels to get through. You view them from overhead, so you can see a mazelike path with many branches. Picture your sprite characters at one such fork in the mountain path, as it branches off in two directions.
column4: You want to avoid the mountain road, so you branch off to an easier path.

story: Heisig mentions at kanjiclinic.com that he wishes he'd chosen mountain pass for this keyword as it's closer to what the word means. If we do this, the kanji makes complete sense because a mountain pass is just below the mountain top.
column3: The MOUNTAIN PASS helps you go up and down the mountain.
column4: To the north of Lorien lies the Misty Mountains, and below their towering peaks are the Mines of Moria. The Fellowship of the Ring first tried for the MOUNTAIN PASS that goes above, but were halted by the wizardry of Saruman at Caradhras, and so are forced to take the MOUNTAIN PASS that goes below, through the mountain - a path long feared by Gandalf for the ancient evil that lurks there. Note : the kanji does in fact refer to a "mountain pass".

story: Sam and Frodo were steadfast companions even as Mount Doom crumbled above them.
column3: You and your companion are climbing to the top of the mountain when it suddenly begins to crumble. Only one of you can survive - who's it going to be? You or your companion?
column4: The reason to always bring a companion when you go climbing in mountains. It is unsteady and may crumble under you at any time. That's when you need that someone to pull you up again.

story: To maintain secrecy, secret societies invariably have to house themselves in the moutains.
column3: To maintain secrecy, secret societies invariably have to house themselves on top of the moutains. (Slight tweak of chamcham's story, using fuaburisa's idea for remembering where to put the mountain primitive.)
column4: This kanji tells you an original version of "Brokeback Mountain". Here, the couple of cowboys have fallen in love, and their only way to keep their love in SECRECY is by meeting invariably at the house on the top of the mountain.

story: When I think of honey, I think of a bee hive, which is a HOUSE that INVARIABLY has INSECTS.
column3: Honey left in a house will invariably attract insects.
column4: The “house” which is invariably divided in hexagons and is full of insects is where honey comes from (a bee hive).

story: Storm is a full-blown wind that rips the mountains off the ground (you see one flying here).
column3: What a storm! Even a mountain was carried off by the wind!
column4: Winds are gathering at the base of the mountain (note the hint to primitive placement), going up, and turning into a huge mountain storm.

story: This is “Cape Strange” from FRAME 153, only with mountain in place of soil. Interestingly, there is also 碕 which is made of the primitives stone and strange. The three kanjis 碕, 埼 and 崎 all have the same meanings and pronunciations. They have very little uses other than names, for which promontory is the clear winner with over 2300 uses in place and people names, while the other two kanjis account for less than 200 names.
column3: A promontory is a small, strange mountain that juts out into the sea.
column4: Promountory. A strange word, indeed.

story: Standing at the base of the bluffs I announce, "I'm going to climb those ivy-covered cliffs, and then the mountain on top of them." My friends don't believe me, "He bluffs!" they say.
column3: The ivy-covered cliff we saw on the 涯 (#169) ... the sheer beauty of the mountain that overlooks these bluffs is enough to make you want to swim for shore yourself!
column4: This is used in the title of the 2008 Studio Ghibli film "Ponyo on the Cliff by the Sea" 崖の上のポニョ。 "Ponyo on the Mountain-high Ivy-covered Bluffs by the Sea" is an alternative title. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ponyo_on_the_Cliff_by_the_Sea.

story: Pictograph, see book. * As a primitive, using the image of going through a door, even one that stands alone with the frame and no wall around, helps flesh out the primitive “enter”.
column3: The opening of a tent, where you enter.
column4: Gordon Freeman enters the Black Mesa corporation's headquarters on that fateful day, after starting up a game of Half-Life (this kanji looks exactly like the lambda from the logo when written).

story: Everybody tries to enter the road during rush hour. That's why it's so crowded.
column3: During a traffic jam it is impossible to get your car to enter the roadway as it is crowded with cars. Think of a grid lock so bad cars are litterally scraping up against each other like people on a Japanese train during rush hour.
column4: There is a Japanese comedy skit where they play a trick on an unaware person who is walking down a quiet empty street. The trick is that a huge crowd suddenly enters the road and stampedes towards the person. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qb7zwr3vQKo (thanks, decals).

story: When something is entered by a dagger, it ends up being cut in several parts.
column3: (This kanji also has the meanings of "understand" and "minute"). It's important to understand that were you to enter an hour with a dagger and cut it into parts, those parts would be minutes.
column4: Perhaps one of the most read kanji in Japanese. It means to understand, to part, fraction, to break up, rate, minute, etc. To understand something completly one must enter a dagger into it to break it up into its parts. Imagine understanding a body by doing an autopsy(enter, dagger) and studying the parts. 分かりますか？.

story: In the case of true poverty, not having money is only part of the problem. There are other components as well, like lack of education, class structuring, etc., but that doesn't really matter. Just remember that the money is only part of it, not the whole.
column3: Parting with your money will lead to poverty.
column4: Poverty is having only a PART of the MONEY you need to get by.

story: The PART of my HEAD where I remember the KANJI is in the kanji PARTITION.
column3: The last time I tried to partition a hard drive under Linux, I got a severe migraine that parted my head.
column4: There are different parts of the head and they each have their own partitions: the corpus callosum, the different hemispheres, etc.

story: I always open the doors to the public restrooms with my elbows because I don't want to touch the door with my hands.
column3: I always enter the doors to the public restrooms with my elbows because I don't want to touch the door with my hands.
column4: The public trains in Japan are so crowded, to enter you have to elbow your way in.

story: Following up with the "entering public restrooms" story for the right-hand primitive: public restrooms always reek of pine tree scented disinfectant.
column3: A pine tree is a public tree: they are frequently planted in public squares, in commemoration of the respect Conficius held for them.
column4: The TREES in PUBLIC parks are usually pine trees.

story: The venerable old man is the public figure head of the Native American Village, answering all questions and solving all problems. The higher in rank you get in this tribe, the more feathers decorate you. Imagine this old man covered in beautiful feathers.
column3: The venerable old man is using the public restroom in the park where he feeds the pigeons. But, alas, there is no toilet paper! So, he's caught a pigeon and is using it to wipe his bottom. (note the feathers on the bottom of the kanji, this helps remember placement). Can you see the feathers flying everywhere?
column4: The venerable old man is in the public park feeding the pigeons.

story: Take care what words you say in public lest you be sued.
column3: [+radical_tyro] Socrates was giving a speech in public. Things were going rather well, until his robe opened a bit and people saw his, well, not-public area. He was promptly sued for public indecency. Certain things shouldn't be made public in public, you know?
column4: If you publicy speak negatively about someone, you can get sued for slander.

story: Think of the classic anime 風の谷のナウシカ (Nausicaa of the Valley of the Wind). We see Nausicaa entering the valley mouth gliding on an umbrella.
column3: Yea, though I enter the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil, for I have brought my umbrella and if anything scares me, I will open my mouth and scream for help!
column4: Pictograph - a little house with mountains behind.

story: This story is quite lascivious, sorry... Now, imagine you are at a 混浴　（こんよく） [two kanjis we now know] Onsen (温泉), and you are watching a woman bathe. Just picture the water dripping down her cleavage (that valley in between her breasts). Note: cleavage in Japanese is 谷間.
column3: The mountain man uses the water from the valley to bathe.
column4: Cleavage in Japanese is called the valley of the chest, and bathing sends water drops into that valley. Memorable image, I think you'll agree.

story: Imagine a house big enough to contain an entire valley. might want to live there. And now imagine cleaning it. . . . Maybe not . . .
column3: To CONTAIN the virus, everyone in the VALLEY had to stay in their HOUSES.
column4: Biodome.

story: Think of what happens when the snow on top of the mountains melts: it turns into water and flows down onto the rooftops of all the houses in the valley below.
column3: [melt; dissolve; thaw] An ice cube is melting, loosing the water it contained.
column4: An inconvenient truth: when the polar ice caps melt, there's going to be no way to contain the rising water level...

story: Guess what? Japanese has dirty words too! (In fact, a lot of them) A sexual story is NOT inappropriate here, as this kanji is very sexual, such as in 性欲; lust. As for a story: the lack of contact with a woman's valley will leave a man LONGING for love.
column3: The valley has something my life is lacking.... something I've been longing for.. peace and quiet.
column4: Imagine a young girl who has lived in this valley her whole life. She's looking out yawning. When confronted about it, she simply replies "This is such a valley of lack! There's nothing to do here but yawn! I'm longing to get out of here. I'm longing for something more than just this valley of lack, this valley of yawns".

story: Again using the fact that cleavage in Japanese is called "valley of the chest": a woman with abundant cleavage tightly wraps up her bosom in a form-fitting cloak, but leaving her valley exposed. Another unforgettable image (thank you, thank you, I'll be here all week).
column3: Welcome to cloak-valley, the valley where everyone wears cloaks and every shop sells cloaks. Mnemonic : “cloaks are abundant in the valley”.
column4: Elven cloaks are abundant in the valley of Rivendell.

story: Picture the molten lead (the heavy metal) being discreetly drained out of the factory into a gully behind.
column3: Lead is a very poisonous metal, and should not enter your mouth.
column4: This is an odd story. IF you have ever broken a pencil right in two the long way you can see the pencil lead lying in the little gully formed by the wood. Helps me remember that lead is used in the word 鉛筆 えんぴつ for pencil.

story: Water in a gully runs alongside the path.
column3: Picture one of those idiots that run alongside the bicyclists in the Tour de France trying to give them water. Watch as the cyclist shoves the person into a gully that runs alongside the road.
column4: Kurisu wrote: Anyone who has been to Japan has seen all the water in the gullies running alongside the roads and rice paddies. // Haha, in my parts we call them "gaijin traps" because almost every foreigner has run their car/bicycle/drunken ass into one at one point. In fact, if you see a gaijin running alongside the water gullies that run alongside the road, you may want to see if they need a hand.

story: You won first PRIZE in a shell-fish eating contest. Unfortunately you spent the whole night in the outhouse after.
column3: As a prize for being the 1,000,000th person to use the restaurant's outhouse, I got all the clams I could eat.
column4: This is a bit silly.. or maybe not only a bit, but.. You know some foodstuffs (cereals come to mind) sometimes have prizes mixed in them? Well, in this case, the prize was a shell (money, remember) and you only notice in the outhouse... (see also 秘 (#970)).

story: Every major political party, if personified, would look like a giant outhouse walking around with human legs spewing out a constant stream of bullshit.
column3: Every political party is full of shit. But nobody ever says how they get that way. Well, here's your answer - a political party memer is in the outhouse, greedily chowing down on the contents inside. He's grown so accustomed to the taste that he's in all the way, and all you can see are his legs through the window. He'll come inside later to the auditorium to make a speech and spew everything out.
column4: Here's an easy one from current events. Recently a certain senator, member of a family-values political party, was caught in an outhouse touching the human legs of the guy in the stall next to him - who happened to be a police officer. True story, folks - search for "wide stance senator" for details.

story: In most communities you will be hauled into city hall if you use the ground as an outhouse.
column3: There is a secret hall buried in the soil underneath the outhouse.
column4: Used in school's dining hall 食堂. Story: The food is so bad that you throw it to the ground and run to the outhouse.

story: It's usual to take your towel with your when you go to the outhouse at the onsen (hot springs bath in Japan) so everybody doesn't see your stuff.
column3: In the outhouse toilet you'd usually hope to find toilet paper to wipe your ass. If it's already gone, which is usually the case, simply use the towel.
column4: It's usual to carry along your own towel when you are in Japan, because at the outhouses (public toilets) there are no frickin' towels (or something else) to dry your hands. (usually gaijins use there trousers... ).

story: Compared to pants, a SKIRT is the GARMENT to be wearing when you want to use one of those Japanese toilets. It makes it so much easier: you just walk in the OUTHOUSE hike it up, and do your business.
column3: A skirt is the most convenient outhouse garment!
column4: Haven't you ever noticed that the men / women signs on the front of outhouses are sometimes very similar? The silhouettes are usually the same, but one will decidedly be wearing a garment in the shape of a SKIRT. Also, we've already learned the kanji for "woman", so if the signs are only in kanji you have no right to wander in and claim ignorance, perv!

story: If you're going to manipulate your body with your hand, then go do it in an outhouse, at least!
column3: Instead of magazines, we keep a Rubiks Cube in the outhouse to manipulate with your hands while you do your business.
column4: This also means a palm. So you're in the outhouse, manipulating something with your hand(palm).

story: A pelt is hooked on a branch. A small tent is made with a pelt and a branch planted in the ground. The mnemonic hints at the first stroke (the hanging pelt) and the hook at the end of the second stroke. This is chinese radical #107 meaning “skin”.
column3: To be honest, this is one of those cases where I have found it easier to "just remember it" as a radical, as it occurs so frequently: 彼（かれ him）波（なみ wave）and so on.
column4: Davy Crocket used to hang his coon-skin PELT on a branch that had grown out over the edge of a cliff.

story: Waves are the ocean's pelt (skin).
column3: The Inuit used water-proof seal pelts for their kayaks, to travel the waves.
column4: Waves blanket the ocean like a WATERY PELT.

story: An old woman is seen here as a woman with waves (i.e. wrinkles, creases).
column3: Picture an old woman on her balcony, watching the waves, wondering if her husband will ever return from the sea.
column4: You know "The Old Man and the Sea." Well, this is the sequel, "The Old Woman and the Sea Waves."

story: You expose holes in a pelt by passing your fingers through them and wiggling them on the other side. The sense of the kanji here is to reveal something that was hidden, to make known, to open your heart (thus revealing it, exposing it to others), express your opinion, etc.
column3: Fred Flintstone gets arrested for exposing himself to young cave-ladies. He does this by lifting his pelt with his fingers.
column4: Eskimos don't want to expose their fingers from their pelted mitts.

story: Before the invention of scissors or knives, sharp STONES were used to REND PELTs, so that caveman designers could complete new styles for the upcoming year.
column3: Rend is a violent, primitive kind of word. (Image: cavemen rending pelts right off live animals with stone tools).
column4: Me Ugg. Me have rock. Me rend pelt with rock.

story: If you wear a coat of fur (pelt) you are sure to incur the wrath of animal rights extremists.
column3: A cloak of fur (pelt) will incur the wrath of animal lovers.
column4: A fashionable lady decided to put on her cloak of pelt, and thus incurred the wrath of animal rights extremists. But don't worry, they weren't brutal or violent: they just shouted "ink her!" as they stained her valuable cloak.

story: The remainder of the bones have been thrown from the float (for the dogs maybe, at the end of the parade).
column3: Throwing all those coins (see 銭 (#394)) was a really bad idea; people got mad with greed. The only remainders left were the bones of those that was on the float.
column4: After the cannibal float had passed the crowd, all that remained were bones.

story: Think of the early Christian martyrs who suffered martyrdom because of their faith. See them held in cells for 10 days (a decameron) before being fed to the lions. They appear before the chanting Roman crowds as bones to be devoured. Think of what was leftover after the lions finished them off....nothing, not even a pile of bones to bury.
column3: The boney man martyred himself during his 10 day hunger-strike.
column4: To commerate the saint's martyrdom his BONES will be displayed for a 10-DAY-PERIOD (decameron).

story: A t-bone steak is vermilion - particularly if served rare.
column3: Castlevania -- The vermillion skeletons (bones) are particularly hard because they just keep regenerating.
column4: "Not PARTICULARLY," I said when asked if I was interested in buying a vermillion bone.

story: Advertisement for Breast Implants -- Tired of nights all alone? Want to get boned straightaway? AUGMENT your breasts and all your troubles will be solved!
column3: He wanted to augment his height so had some bone added to his legs straightaway.
column4: In the movie “Gattaca”, Vincent Freeman (played by Ethan Hawke) augments his size by straightening his bones (his legs), in order to match up with the genetically “perfect” population, and reach his goal of travelling in space. The stretching of his lower leg bones involved multiplying the bone cells, another sense of this key word.

story: A line of skeletal warriors, all armed with sabers.
column3: Skeleton army rank and file. Dudes made of bones carrying sabres.
column4: Common scene in (old) computer rpgs. Skeletons with sabers coming at you neatly in a file. (see 骨 (#1383)).

story: They tried issuing the skeleton warriors with proper garments to wear, but they kept getting split by the sharp bones or by their sabres. In the end, it was decided they look scarier naked anyway.
column3: Someone takes a sword made of bone to split the garment right down the middle. Very effective.
column4: We should walk in single file so no one sees I split my undergarments! (Undergarments should help with position).

story: The undead, marching single file, prove how ardent they are be walking across a field of flame. Fun fact, ardent used to mean to burn.
column3: Ardent followers (skeleton army), 列 (#812), would file over hot coals for their master.
column4: My Japanese students have such an ardent desire to speak native English that you will never find any of them confusing file with fire.

story: Ok, this is where knowing some Eastern culture comes in handy! In Japanese society, when someone dies they creamate the body and pick out the remaining bones with special chopsticks. In this case, they're out of chopsticks so they decide to use (gasp!) a spoon instead.
column3: Imagine the grim reaper (the bringer of death), carrying a spoon made of human bones instead of a scythe.
column4: The Grim Reaper eats bones for breakfast (with a spoon).

story: I imagine an interment as a funeral. At this funeral it's an open casket, and the dead body (death) is holding flowers with both of its hands.
column3: During the interment ceremony, the grandchildren placed flowers over the dead body while the widow sat praying with two hands.
column4: During interment, flowers are placed above death, while two hands from the netherworld are pulling from below.

story: What a dilemna, you wore SUNGLASSES over your EYES when you went to the BIRDHOUSE so you wouldn't be recognized - but now you can't WINK at the girl you want!
column3: Imagine Snoopy winking with his big eyes (and a happy smile) standing next to Woodstocks Birdhouse, woodstock being so cool that he wears little sunglasses.
column4: I prefer to use the 舛 to mean "dancing legs". Makes a lot more sense to me that way. Just think of it as in the evening, you want to watch dancing legs, (you can see the two legs wrapped around a pole... right? ;) ) You go to a certain kind of "BIRD" HOUSE, to watch the DANCING LEGS. Your EYE is drawn to one particular set of dancing legs in the birdhouse, she has a twinkle in her eye and you blink as she WINKS at you. (This kanji also means blink and twinkle).

story: Your ear is like the eye on the side of your head for seeing things, but there is hair around it that creates jagged lines.
column3: Deaf people use their ears as eyes. An ear is just a modified eye.
column4: Pictograph, see book. * The primitive meaning can easily be extended to ear plugs.

story: Fuaburisu's with a twist: You know that classic trick where someone pretends to take something out of an someone else's ear (such as a coin). Instead of a cigarette or a pen he pulls the person’s crotch out of their ear. Very painful!
column3: Someone does the classic magic trick of pretending to take something out of their ear (such as a coin). Or maybe it is a cigarette or a pen that you take from behind the ear (the crotch of the ear).
column4: "Its too dangerous to go alone take these." and so Link takes earplugs and crotch protection and goes to face the furious Zelda. Ganondorf was not the final boss..

story: The gist of it is this: We take the money and run!
column3: Pickpocket advice: It's simple, FIRST run, then take. Yeah, that's the gist of it!
column4: I gotta RUN soon so I will just TAKE the GIST of your otherwise long-winded story.

story: TAKE the UTMOST care when you SUN bath all DAY, or you'll get burned from your EARS to your CROTCH.
column3: Do your utmost - seize(take) the day.
column4: The renewable energy that man can take from the sun is of utmost importance to the world's future.

story: Take the utmost care that you don't have your finger in the way when you take a snapshot.
column3: As a Japanese girl, when having your snapshot taken it is of the utmost importance to make the peace sign with your fingers.
column4: When I learned photography from my dad as a little girl, he explained the basics to me: "when you take a snapshot, be careful not to put your fingers before the lens, and don't look towards the sun (this was in the days that photographs would be spoiled by direct sunlight).

story: Vincent Van Gogh's greatest shame was cutting off his ear to win the heart of a woman. 恥じる 【はじる】 to feel ashamed 恥ずかしい 【はずかしい】 shy, ashamed, embarrassed 恥辱 【ちじょく】 disgrace, shame, insult.
column3: Amelia Ear-Heart (sic) brought shame to those who said women couldn't fly.
column4: This chinese character explains how shame stands between social expectations (the ear listening to the outside world) and one's own expectations (one's heart).

story: Worst post in history: quality checker at the kazoo factory. Imagine the toll on your ears!
column3: Buckingham Palace guards are famous for staying at their post no matter what, even if you blow a kazoo in their ear!
column4: You want to leave your post when you hear the sound of the fiesta.

story: A holy man hears with his ears before he speaks with his mouth, which places him higher than a king in people's esteem.
column3: The trick for me is to remember that the 耳 is to the left of the 口. However, this is easy because a true holy man uses his ear to listen (i.e., to God or his supplicant) before he opens his mouth to speak, unlike a charlatan who just makes something up. Of course, kings are often true holy men and prophets (e.g., King David in the bible).
column4: Holy Hand Grenade: Monty Python: Quest for the Holy Grail. The rabbit just tore the ear off of a knight with it's fierce mouth. The knight is running back, screaming, and the King is watching. He decides to call out for the Holy Hand Grenade to fix the situation.

story: Only a truly daring Japanese student would wear a spike in his ear under the gaze of the Japanese teacher taskmasters!
column3: See that ear nailed over there ? It's the ear of the last person who was too daring with the taskmistress.
column4: English (punk) teenagers in the 70s were daring when they pierced nails through their ears. Many of them got in a lot of trouble with their taskmasters (parents, teachers, etc.)

story: I promise to use my ear to do nothing but listen ... stick a needle in my eye, cross my heart and hope to die! (Intentionally said backwards to get the order of the primitives correct).
column3: Listening to others is different from hearing [1626] with the ear. One must allow the words to pierce through the eyes (the window of the soul) and reach deep into the heart...a symbol of thinking about and contemplating on what was said, not just the sounds of words spoken. A married man while reading his newspaper, his wife going on about something suddenly, says, "You're not listening to me, are you?" He replies, "I heard every word you said. You said..." “Yes, but you're not listening."
column4: When you really listen to another person and not just hear them, you use your ears like ten eyes and see their heartfelt meaning.

story: (re: taijuando) When you are in New York City you have to be alert, i.e. in the "New York State of Mind": you need ten eyes to make sure no one will go through your garments and pick your pockets.
column3: She had me in her pocket. It was a state of mind that would eventually demolish me... ---I use this story with a kind of unrequited love theme not only because it jives with my romantic soul, but also because this kanji also has connotations of attachment and sentiments/feelings.
column4: The tailor's state of mind when he eyed the needle and the simple garment: Pockets! We must add pockets!

story: I'll focus on the mandala primitive here. I guess Heisig chose this keyword for phonetic reasons and as a character it's the "man" in mandara/mandala (曼荼羅). A mandala is a graphic representation of the universe, here split in 3 planes of existance, the sun representing the cosmos, the eye represents the human observer, the crotch represents the animal instincts.
column3: He' s often ridiculed for having his eye on crotches all day.
column4: Heisig really dropped the ball on this one, introducing the obscure primitive mandala without a word of explanation. I choose to read it as Nelson Mandela instead. Picture him under the hot sun, being tormented by cyclopes who constantly kick him in the crotch in his South African prison. Therefore, this kanji: The state of mind of Nelson Mandela was to constantly ridicule the Apartheid system.

story: One obscure Tibetan sect-- the Otaku cult-- has an unusually loose interpretation of mandala drawing practice. Instead of traditional mandalas they draw mangas (漫画). They then pour water on the image to wash it away, and begin anew.
column3: Staring at mandalas is a tool in meditation to loosen-up the mind and body, allowing the energy to flow like water.
column4: Key word is off. This is 漫画/manga のまん, cartoon or comic. Attempt to reconcile key words: in the romanticized manga version of the life of Nelson Mandela, a full-page drawing is devoted to the day he's set loose, depicting him kneeling by cool water, loose from the chains of bondage at last, drinking it in. Whether the story is a help or not, let loose of the key word.

story: When something catches my eye, I take out a few clams and buy before anybody else does.
column3: Rules to Buying: 1. You've had your eye on it for a while. 2. You have enough shells to afford it.
column4: Keep an eye on your money. Watch what you buy!

story: Working in retail you learn the placement of any item should be at eye level so it's seen straightaway.
column3: On the JET Programme, many people have their eye on a placement in Tokyo, Osaka or another big city, and write it on their application form. They are usually sent to the countryside straightaway.
column4: Good product Placement catches the 'eye' 'straightway'.

story: For Japanese, when the mind's eye (the sideways eye) feels guilty for something bad that the body has done, there are two penaltys to choose from. One, you can say I'm sorry. Two, you can commit suicide by sabre. Why, oh why, do so many Japanese executives commit suicide at the first sign of scandal when all the have to do is say I'm sorry to get off the hook. (on yomi: バチ, バツ).
column3: (Seppuku) The greatest PENALTY in Japan: You close your EYEs, say your last WORDS, put the SABER in...
column4: There is a 3-way masterplan for every goalkeeper to prevent a goal at penalty shootout: 1. Look directly into the eyes of the player --- 2. Confuse him by screaming senseless words --- 3. Pull out you your saber and ... (that's up to you).

story: A pretty tough kanji. Think of elegant old housewives with English accents dining together at a HOUSE party. The hostess brings out a dish of hors d'oeuvres: a SPIKE of metal with an EYEBALL and a HEART skewered on it. Upon being offered this treat, one of the housewives says in her English accent, "I'd RATHER not."
column3: Rather a house with a heart than an eye with a spike.
column4: I'd rather die peacefully in my house from a heart attack than from a spike in my eye.

story: The fly is wrapped in a spiderweb voicing "Help me, Help Me" under the watchful eye of the spider who's venom is dripping like water from her fangs.
column3: Pour water over the eyes of a bound up insect if you want to hear a pitiful buzz that is very similar to a VOICED consanant.
column4: Voiced here refers to the "muddying" effect on a soft consonant brought about by vibrating the vocal chords. For the image of muddy, we have an insect that is bound up and lowered into the water as bait. As it struggles for its life, it stirs up the sediment at the bottom, muddying the water such that your eyes cannot see through it.

story: Together with the next kanji, the keywords spell “send back the ring”. First we have a jewel. Next we have the great eye of Sauron searching for the fellowship hiding under the many ceilings during their journey. The fourth and fifth primitives are the mouth of Gollum always mumbling “My preciousss”; and Pippin's scarf! Placement: the eye appears at the top similarly to how the Great Eye of Sauron is perched atop the Dark Tower.
column3: In conjunction with 還 (#900)....... When I tried to give her the jewel ring, she eyed me, threw it to the floor, opened her mouth and tried to speak, she said nothing. She grabbed her scarf and left.
column4: In the Lord of the Rings: Return of the King, the king, Aragorn, finally claims the throne of Gondor and attempts to defeat the Eye of Sauron. But the only way the king can beat the Eye of Sauron is by having the One Ring thrown into the mouth of Mordor...wrapped delicately in a silk scarf, of course.

story: You've probably guessed it by now, this is the road that Sam and Frodo take to send back the ring to Mount Doom! (see previous frame, the jewel is replaced by the road).
column3: Continued from 環 (#899)....... So I'm on the road going to send back the ring minus the jewel, the hit to the floor knocked it out.
column4: The Saudi woman was tired of looking at the floor and covering her mouth with a scarf, so she asked her husband to send her back on the road to home, though she didn't send back the ring.

story: Even though it is argued size is not important, I'm sure most women would like their husband to have a big one.
column3: Homer Simpson, as a primitive.
column4: After marriage, most men let themselves go a bit, and the result is predictable: one large husband.

story: Band-Aids were invented by a husband for his wife, who would regularly injure her fingers while cooking. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Band-Aid.
column3: In Homer Simpsons' house, the first aid kit is usually used for when he smashes his fingers trying to build something (there are countless Simpsons episodes you can draw from for this).
column4: When a woman can't open a jar, her husband comes to her aid with his strong fingers. 扶養　ふよう　support dependants.

story: The Simpsons are on vacation. Homer stops to take a leak in a mountain stream but gets snatched by an eagle. Hear his scream?
column3: A husband who went fishing at the mountain stream to feed his family, fell in the rapids (we'll assume this is a large mountain stream). He is saved from the waters by a great eagle. He comes back home with nothing to feed the family, his clothes still dripping wet as he tells his wife of how he was saved by a great eagle, and of course she does not believe him. The story continues in 鶏 (#2097).
column4: The water from the mountain stream saved my husband from thirst, dehydration and the vultures.

story: In the male-dominated world of yesterday, the husband's way of seeing things was considered the standard point of view. Women who dared to disagree were frowned upon.
column3: Unfortunately, Homer Simpson is the standard model of a husband in American society. (Placement: You have to look in the RIGHT places to find one that doesn't fit that mold.)
column4: Ugh. You can tell what her standards are just by seeing her husband.

story: A show like "Trading Spouses" called "exchanging husbands" where 2 husbands are exchanged for a day (thanks dingomick).
column3: Marge's dream: to exchange Homer for another husband for just one day.
column4: This kanji depicts the reality TV show where two families exchange the two husbands for a day to see how they manage in another family.

story: Out of two potential husbands, which would you approve of? Well, the one with shells (money) of course!!!
column3: Out of two potential husbands, which would mom and dad approve of? Well, the one with shells (money) of course!!! (big thanks to zazen here but I keep getting this one confused with 択 (#1155) later.. So I figure mom and dad would be the ones whose approval we'd like).
column4: A pair of husbands who are married to the same rich woman, approve of each other's spendings of the wife's money (shells). Husband nr.1 - “That DVD player and wide-screen HDTV you bought last week, they're awesome!”. Husband nr.2 - “My pleasure. By the way I totally approve of that BMW you bought the other day!”.

story: When a submarine or similar vessel SUBMERGES an EXCHANGE of air for WATER takes place in special compartments.
column3: The two husbands exchange for a day on the reality TV show (see 替 (#905)) finally goes underway. One of the two husband's first job is to fix the water faucet in his new family's apartment. Unfortunately, he isn't very good at fixing things and after a few failed attempts the entire apartment is submerged in water.
column4: When you exchange places with water you become submerged.

story: The drop falling here is the husband's toupee... he's already lost his hair once, now he's losing it again. Such is life, I suppose.
column3: My husband is going to lose his hair, one drop at a time.
column4: Note: Heisig's stroke order is wrong. It's the same as vermilion, drop first. Homer loses/drops his wedding ring.

story: Iron is a metal that gradually becomes lost due to oxidation and rust.
column3: Compare with 銑 (#288). In moving from pig-iron to iron, some of the metal's maleability is LOST. (The only difference between the two kanji is that IRON has knee-less, unbending legs, while PIG-IRON (270) has very supple, bendable legs.)
column4: Iron, compared to 銑 (#288), has lost most of its carbon in the refining process. This makes it less brittle and a lot easier to use.

story: When you get lost, you just take an alternate road to get back on track.
column3: When you lose your way, you can always try to tell the wife that you merely took an alternate road. To save time you know. I'm not LOST, I'm just taking an alternate road. Ahem.
column4: If you take the alternate road, trust me you'll get lost.

story: Retainer: a servant, especially one who has worked for a person or familly for a long time. Now, if you imagine looking at a retainer (e.g. Igor) from top, you see how he is bending his head (middle rectange) between his two shoulders as he offers something with his two hands (upper and lower lines) to his master.
column3: Retainer = A slave (for the purposes of this kanji.) This is a pictograph of a slave collar with two handcuffs dangling from it.
column4: It may be useful to know that 大臣（だいじん） means Minister.

story: Princess Leia becomes Jabba's slave (“princess Leia is a woman slave”).
column3: Cinderella: A woman who was a slave who became a princess.
column4: Ancient princesses were simply women with loyal slaves standing by them.

story: The storehouse is overgrown with slaves. The slaves are to be sold in the store, to differentiate from a warehouse, which doesn't have the word "store" in it.
column3: Slaves moved flowers from the storehouse in preparation for the parade.
column4: For this story, I have chosen to use overgrown as an enclosure. The slaves, who are treated as objects rather than human beings, are denied the luxury of living in a proper house. Rather, they are stuffed in the overgrown storehouse with their owner's other possessions.

story: You signed your organ donor card, right? So, when you die, your entrails and other body parts will be placed in a storehouse.
column3: Your body is like a storehouse for your entrails.
column4: Again with the Pyramids, each Pharaoh had their entrails taken out and put into little jars that were shaped in the forms of their Gods and entombed along with the preserved body. So, the entrails are the parts of the body that are placed in the storehouse along with the Pharaoh! Damnit, why can't they always be this easy? :(.

story: An intelligent man is neither slave to his crotch nor to money. But an intelligent slave will know how to use his/her crotch to make money.
column3: Tip: The slave + crotch combination appears five times in Heisig. It may be worth making a new primitive. I suggest loincloth, which the slaves wear to cover their crotch. Ref: 賢 (#852), 堅 (#853), 緊 (#1374), 腎 (#2453), 竪 (#2618).
column4: "Slave" plus "crotch" is the character 臤, which apparently means "hard" or "wise". I like Katsuo's idea of calling it "loincloth" (something a slave might wear to cover his crotch). The intelligent slave used his loincloth to hide some of the master's shells.

story: If you have a weak KIDNEY, you'll become a SLAVE to your CROTCH's need to pee. Oh well, it's just a weakness of the FLESH.
column3: When the sex slave misbehaves, threaten to sell his body parts starting with his kidney.
column4: The kidneys are a filtering system for blood that removes waste and diverts it to the urinary system. In other words, kidneys are a part of the body that acts like a retainer for your crotch.

story: The strict parent thinks adolescent kids are "slaves to their crotch" (= can't control their hormones), so he grounds them. Permanently!
column3: Strict masters treat even 賢 (#915) slaves like dirt, and they get no shells.
column4: It's a strict place...any slave caught violating rules will be buried up to his crotch in the soil.

story: The slave is look to the future, "One day" he thinks "I will be able to recline with all my goods, a tv, stereo and washing machine, and when that day comes I shall be truly happy" he sighs.
column3: Roman master to slave - "I want you to look to the goods while I recline on this couch."
column4: You better look to your slave, he was last seen reclining on the goods he's supposed to be loading.

story: The slave reclines on the floor at night to watch the stars. Since that's the only thing the slave is allowed to “read”, he does so very thoroughly and diligently, hence perusal.
column3: "Please come in and make a perusal of all my finest slaves laying on the floor. Tell me if you see anyone you like. For you, I make the best deal."
column4: In Japan while out shopping, you will often hear the shop assistant use the phrase 'ご覧ください' (goran kudasai) which are words to the effect of 'please feel free to browse/take a look'. It is a politer way of asking someone to look than '見て' (mite). In the kanji for perusal, we have see, but also the addition of the Japanese sales assistant who acts as your personal slave with their body always inclined to the floor in a bow, marking the more respectful nuance of this kanji..

story: The letter E, with a GIGANTIC middle stroke.
column3: Gigantic... nay, 巨normous!
column4: The slave without his bonds (the missing two strokes) feels gigantic.

story: Having gigantic fingers is useful to repel insects. You can swat them away a lot easier!
column3: Want to REPEL someone? Give em the gigantic finger - your biggest finger, which is your middle one of course! (It's even more memorable if you imagine someone with a grotesquely large middle finger).
column4: Watching those giant fingers at work cracking lobster, Jerry Seinfeld was repelled by his new girlfriend at dinner.

story: I always refer to the power of the KATAKANA "KA".
column3: The power of Goku: KA-mehamehaaaaaaa! (Katakana KA).
column4: I have a very powerful muscle カ in my driveway!

story: Male is seen here as muscles working in the field, in other words working in the rice fields is the work of the male who are usually stronger. This is more or less the meaning of the original Chinese character.
column3: When it comes to choosing a MAN, I prefer brains over muscles.
column4: A man should value his brains over his muscles.

story: Those jocks who always tried to show their muscles in the schoolhouse are now the ones out there doing manual labor jobs while we sit here and learn Japanese. Ha!
column3: At the schoolhouse, the administration develops the children's muscles by making them do manual labour.
column4: Hard labor is like a schoolhouse for your muscles.

story: The necromancer hangs out at the local graveyard and uses his dark powers to recruit an army of undead. Emphasize the verb form to keep distinct from the noun 曹 (#1257).
column3: WANTED: Hardworking GRAVEYARD diggers. Must have 6 months experience with POWERFUL muscles as will be working in South Africa burying deceased elephants.
column4: The graveyard does have the power to recruit us all.

story: I have an inferiority complex because I have fewer muscles than everyone else at the gym. They all look like Macho Man Randy Savage (power) to me.
column3: I had trouble remembering the relative position of the components, so now I use this story: Even muscular men have inferiority if they have few things above their muscles (i.e., brain cells).
column4: I have an inferiority complex because I have few muscles! (Image: Arnold laughing at a weakling on the beach with few muscles).

story: The great achievements of humankind, were crafts completed by muscle power: the pyramids, the Eiffel tower, etc.
column3: All of Arnold Schwarzenegger's achievements started with him crafting his muscles.
column4: Try adding the phrase: "What an エカcellent achievement!" to whatever story you come up with.

story: Mnemonic "pegasus persuasion power". I think of the hippogriff from Harry Potter as being like a pegasus. To befriend a hippogriff, you have to persuade it you mean no harm, you can do this if you have "pegasus persuasion power".
column3: Only the powerful can persuade Pegasus to let them ride her.
column4: A little girl is trying to persuade a little boy to play dolls with her. She offers him her plastic pegasus figure and says, "See? Pegasus has muscles. He's got Pegasus power." And the little boy says "You cannot persuade me to play with your flying unicorn. I'm not of that persuasion."

story: Guy + Power: To reach a position of power in the company, the average guy has to toil very hard for many years.
column3: For the average guy to get muscles he must really toil in the gym.
column4: Guys with large muscles usually find themselves toiling in dirty, disgusting trenches doing the work more delicately constructed individuals cannot (or will not).

story: (Using the "newer" key word of "Uprising" and the 6th edition explanation that the needle/crown combo = "chapel") Joan of Arc was just a child under the influence of the chapel when she was inspired with the power to lead the French uprising.
column3: During an uprising, hide your child in the chapel from the power of the people.
column4: (Using both keywords). The child had the power of 10 crowns - it was he who led the peasant uprising. He didn't even have his first erection and yet he was more powerful than all the adults. 勃然 【ぼつぜん】 (adj-t,adv-to) sudden; fit of anger 勃起 【ぼっき】 (n,vs) erection (usu. penis); standing erect; stiffening.

story: 10,000 Persians are at the base of the cliff, but the leader of the 300 Spartans just flexes his huge muscles and encourages his men by shouting that they have the power to fight them all.
column3: People encourage you, giving you the power so you can dive off the 10,000m high cliff into the sea.
column4: See the most-starred story in 栃 (#553) for an easy way to remember this one. --> That same famous cliffside in Japan at which 10,000 people died ... together, we have the power to do something about it ... let's encourage the government to take action!

story: If you eat anymore, you will be adding more カロries. (katakana karo).
column3: This is Power Mouth, the most annoying neighbour in the world who always has something to add.
column4: To add muscle mass it's important to put protein in your mouth after working out.

story: When someone at work gets married, you pass around an envelope to which you add some money and a card which you sign with your congratulations.
column3: Congratulations are so much better when you add money to them.
column4: I was a bit shocked when I learnt that it's tradition in Japan to add around 30,000 yen (shells) or more to a wedding congratulations card.

story: Instant wood. Just add Viagra.
column3: I'm not sure I know about erector sets or tinker toys but I do know about jenga. You play by taking wooden pieces from the middle of a wooden tower and adding them to the top. In this way you erect a very unstable structure.
column4: Add wood to erect a structure.

story: What part of the body has a very, very, very powerful smell? The armpit, of course!
column3: Armpit is the flesh near your triceps.
column4: (no important on yomi) The part of Conan's body that is three times more effective at defeating foes than his muscles are his stinky ARMPITs. [Note: Typically, when the flesh primitive is on the left side it refers to a body part - this helps distinguish in from 脅 (#936)].

story: Compare the primitive positions of 脇 (#870) and 脅 (#871). When your triceps rest alongside your body, they fit snugly against your armpit. When you hold them above your body, however, your posture becomes quite threatening.
column3: Zelda (NES): Link THREATENS Ganon by lifting the "TRIforce of POWER" over his BODY. Then the final battle begins.
column4: Arnold S. (triceps) threatens to kill the waiter if he does not put a steak (meat) infront of him immediately.

story: The nurse says : “If you co-operate, that needle (syringe) in your triceps won't hurt”. Note: both co- and cooperate are meanings for this kanji.
column3: Co-operation: 3 persons can have the power of ten if they co-operate.
column4: The nurse says: "If you don't co-operate with us and let us stick this needle into your triceps, sir, we'll have to stick it somewhere else! (Thnx Fabrice!)

story: To me, this looks like a bridge going over a body of water, being supported by columns underneath it. Being that I live near the ocean, I see tourists and vacationers coming and going constantly on the bridge. Because the bridge is so long, it forms an arc to support the structural integrity. You can see that arc here.
column3: For those who need a mnemonic in order not to forget how to write this kanji, think of katakana イテ ite (here the イeven gets a dot): ite in Latin means go! +++ As for the primitive: I'll use i as in iTunes or itinerary.
column4: I use The Flash for for this primitive; a superhero who is always going very fast.

story: The calligrapher's brush is moving down a column of a script, in rhythm with his meditation.
column3: Picture a school of studious calligraphers. All their brushes are moving up and down the columns at the same time, in beautiful rhythm.
column4: The army COLUMN walked to the RHYTHM made by the drummer using a cool BRUSH like drum stick. Picturing the brush as a drum stick is not difficult if you've seen such a thing in jazz videos.

story: Before going all the way to the Boss in a Final Fantasy game, you should probably double back to save at a restore point.
column3: The column of soldiers has to double back to restore the peace in the village they just left.
column4: You are writing a complex technical document on your computer when suddenly your computer crashes and your document is lost. You have to restore your computer from backups. Your backups are kept in a tall column (spindle) of DVD's. After you finish restoring your computer, you double-back on your train of thought, reconstructing your lost work.

story: To gain more knowledge of what's goin on in the world I'm reading column after column of articles in the newspapers, and it takes so much time I'm glued to it till nightbreak.
column3: Just to GAIN a level in WOW, I will keep GOING until NIGHTBREAK GLUED to my PC.
column4: To gain more knowledge of japanese I'm reading column after column of RTK, and it takes so much time that I'm glued to my SRS until nightbreak (I love you Spidercat).

story: The line of viking soldiers is always accompanied by a horn mending specialist.
column3: As you're going along someplace, you pause to mend a wounded animal's horns, and it decides to go with you, to accompany you as a pet/sidekick, out of gratitude.
column4: Japanese Folklore:----------- Mend the Horns of an Oni, and he will accompany you on your travels, Going anywhere you choose.

story: The junior employee is always RUNNING around GOING here and there for his superiors.
column3: I'm not sure where Heisig gets the junior keyword, but this kanji is more often used in the sense of either futile (e.g. 徒労 - fruitless efforts) or group(gang) member (e.g. 聖徒 - disciple, キリスト教徒 - Christian). I'll use gang member for this one. The junior gang member is going to represent at the running competition.
column4: Your junior or Jr. in the succession line is the one who runs after you.

story: A line queued up outside the Buddhist temple, waiting to see the shrine on New Year's Day.
column3: According to my japanese teacher the etymology of this kanji is that in ancient japan, when people were going on trips they would wait at temples for other people, or to get rest.
column4: The COLUMNS of this TEMPLE are a well-know meeting spot. You can always see someone WAITING there.

story: Parties should stay in a single-file line and carry a candlestick while journeying through an unknown dungeon in an RPG.
column3: Famous journey, the three kings, sheperds, and all, going to see their new lord.
column4: During the Edo Period (江戸時代), you were required to go 彳 on a journey to Edo every other year if you were a Japanese lord 主. 往復、おうふく round trip (+ restore): 湖まで歩いて往復すると、４５分かかるよ, "If you walk to the lake and back, it will take 45 minutes." 往復ですか、片道ですか, "Round trip or one way?" 往復切符、〜きっぷ, round-trip ticket.

story: America seeks to GO and CORRECT other nations. But really what they do is subjugate them...
column3: To subjugate is to have somebody stand still and stiff as a column and behave one hundred percent correctly.
column4: Subjugated Samson. Here's the Bible story of Samson after Delilah deceived him into telling her the secret of his strength, his long hair, now shaved and subjugated into submission by the Philistines, chained to the temple columns where he choose to do the correct thing; called upon the God of the Israelites to give him one last burst of power and brought down the entire temple of the Philistines and slew more enemies of Israel in his death than in his life.

story: Scientists recently measured the diameter of Earth by drilling a deep hole and dropping a line of thread off a humongous spool until it got to the other side.
column3: Suggestion: Replace "spool" with "toilet paper/roll". Reasons: (1) Toilet paper/roll usually comes on a spool. (2) Toilet paper is used to clean the soil off your crotch. Story: Measure the diameter of a column (maybe Nelson's Column in London?) using a roll of toilet paper. Spool also appears in 茎 (#772), 怪 (#773), 軽 (#774), 経 (#1460).
column4: I'm going to measure the diameter of your crotch, sorry I know it sounds dirty but its for the good of science!

story: What's the main difference between a he and a she? The he has a column covered in a pelt... a penis. Badum-ching.
column3: The ultimate he-man is the Neanderthal cave man. His club is as big as a pillar (column), and he wears a ragged pelt as his only clothing. To remember the column, imagine the cave man resting the club vertically like a column when not in use.
column4: Wherever he goes // he wears pelt clothes.

story: Japanese kamikaze pilots (and the American from Dr. Strangelove) are so devoted to their duty that they go with their missiles.
column3: Imagine those poor saps in charge of nuclear silos, responsible for ICBMS, those towering column missiles. When the order comes they must decide whether to obey their concience or do their duty and damn the world to atomic annihilation.
column4: It is a soldier's duty to maintain a perfectly formed battle column, even when missiles are exploding all around them.

story: Hearkening back to the kanji for LISTEN... Benevolence is a good listener who is willing to go the distance to help.
column3: Benevolence: going to help those who are unable to listen (i.e. have no ears).
column4: In a rare act of benevolence, the Sparten column removes the needle from the cyclops's eye, and he repays them by eating their hearts.

story: Your mission, should you choose to accept it, is to penetrate enemy lines (or the columns of soliders). It won't be easy: the soldiers have been brought up since birth, by the taskmaster, to be on guard. To remember brought up, imagine horrible Orcs being created and brought up through black magic and pledging their allegiance to the evil taskmaster. These aren't Orc recruits; these are Orcs that have been created through black magic and brought up to destroy the enemy.
column3: Penetrate = "goes into." As in the lessons of the taskmaster penetrating the minds of those he his bringing up.
column4: Note similarity to 撤 (#822). They seem kind of like opposites. Penetrate just goes all-in, but to remove something you need your fingers.

story: If you see a column of kings being marched up the mountain under a taskmaster's whip... indications are, there has been a coup.
column3: The combination of column + mountain + taskmaster appear in quite a few kanji (徴,微,薇,黴), so let's give it the meaning of 'trek'. Story: If you see kings trekking like peasants, indications are they've been outcast.
column4: The King Under the Mountain is none other than Thorin Oakenshield. Based on Gandalf's indications, the thirteen dwarves (and one hobbit) marched in a line to reclaim the title of King Under the Mountain from the taskmaster, Smaug.

story: Penal servitude is served until indications show that one has had a change of heart (learned one's lesson). Easily confused with 刑 (#734) and 罰 (#896). Concentrate on the reasons behind the penal system ("changing people's hearts" here), instead of the penalty itself or the punishment (revenge) aspect. It may help to note that there's no sword, but a heart :-) (Note: 懲りる = learn from one's bad experiences).
column3: Judge: You will serve a penal sentence until indications show you have a heart.
