column4: Penal servitude is served until indications show that one has had a change of heart. In other words, when your iIndications changes from "I"M A BADASS MOUNTAIN KING TASKMASTER" to "I heart the world".

story: We're going up the mountain announces the taskmaster. Anyone with legs too delicate must stay behind.
column3: The Column of 300 spartans were in a delicate situation. They had travelled in one line (using only their legs) to the mountain pass to face the fierce Persian task master.
column4: (See my story for 徴 (#952)) Her legs were too delicate for trekking.

story: The boulevard of boulevards, the Champs Elysées, with the Arc de Triomphe covered in ivy to give the champions a heroes' welcome.
column3: A boulevard is one street where they use columns of ivy for decorations.
column4: Specifically... ivy boulevard... think hollywood & vine.

story: When the wooden girders start to snap, the workmen shout "Run! Let's go!".
column3: 「けた」。This kanji is used to denote a number of digits or decimal places, e.g. 三桁のパスワード (a 3-digit password).
column4: Those wooden girders have to go. Use steel I-beams instead.

story: To maintain the social equilibrium in a future dystopian society, the brains of citizens are bound up (hypnotized). The government is using mental wave emitting statues shaped like St. Bernard's dogs put alongside the boulevards.
column3: I think BALANCE is an easier keyword. I was walking down a busy French boulevard when between the rushing traffic I saw the wierdest thing. BALANCING on the central crash barrier was a St. Bernard dog, BALANCING a fish on its nose. As I looked closer, I realised it was a trick; it was holding the fish's tail in its teeth, and only pretending to BALANCE it. (keeps the position of the elements!)
column4: The poor St. Bernard walking down the middle of the boulevard cannot see to mantain his equilibrium. It seems his brain is all bound up with alcohol.

story: Aliens often draft their plans for invasion by cutting designs among the tall wheat.
column3: The first DRAFT of catcher in the rye was actually called "catcher in the TALL WHEAT"...good thing they changed it. I read it in 高校.
column4: Draft wheat beer (Hefeweizen) is served in the typical tall German glass.

story: Your earnings allow you to bring home your daily bread (made of wheat, naturally).
column3: Hmm, EARNINGS. Think of the popular saying "Bringing HOME the bacon". Here, EARNINGS is the picture "Bringing HOME the bread(WHEAT) and the bacon (PIG).
column4: A farmer's earnings can be viewed as the amount of wheat he has in his grain silo (house).

story: The extent to which some people will go to create 'wheat displays', or as some call them 'crop circles', is truly amazing.
column3: The wheat crop has come in, and the mouth of the king is gobbling it all up. Everyone is waiting to see... to what extent will the king manage to eat it this year?
column4: The extent to which the king can open his mouth to fit in wheat is really astounding.

story: Nobody likes the tax man, so here it is only fitting that the person who comes over to take some of your wheat is depicted here as a devil. Keep in mind that in feudal societies there was no kind of money to speak of, so taxes were paid by serfs in wheat to the devils who came over to keep them poor.
column3: This is an easy one. Taxes is like the devil taking away your hard earned wheat.
column4: I don't know if it makes sense, but it works for me: If the Warrior cannot levy the shells [frame 378], then the Devil will come and colllect your Wheat as Tax.

story: Immature turkeys are stuffed with wheat to make it look bigger.
column3: I can't believe I brought you to the fanciest restaurant in town and you asked for turkey on wheat...how immature is that?!
column4: It's immature to whip turkeys with wheat.

story: The first step to harmony is having enough wheat to feed every mouth in the world. Once we are all fed it is easier to get a long in harmony.
column3: What better image of harmony and peace than relaxing amidst the wheat, with one long stalk in your mouth.
column4: People who live in harmony with nature live in the country. they are yokels or hillbillys. See Billy-bob sitting on the porch in their denhim dungarees a sheaf of wheat, sticking from their mouth.

story: Picture the WHEAT field, filled with MANY, MANY stalks of WHEAT. Notice how they SHIFT like waves in the slightest breeze. When you hear SHIFT, just picture that scene.
column3: Many people are making the shift from white to whole wheat bread.
column4: To hide the wheat from the devilish 税 (#961) collector, the villagers shift the wheat between them many, many times. "We don't have much, sir, but we'll do anything for the crown".

story: An hourglass filled with wheat counts time. A few wheat seeds drop every second.
column3: I first came across this kanji on my microwave, so; if you want to microwave wheat, it's important to remember only to set it for a few seconds. If it helps you can picture those wheat/bran bag things that you heat in the microwave and apply to muscle aches.
column4: Wheat can be cooked in a few seconds.

story: In AUTUMN, the WHEAT looks the color of FIRE, meaning it's time to harvest it.
column3: Every autumn the wheat is set on fire to clear the way for next year's crop...
column4: After the wheat harvest, the farmers have a bonfire to celebrate the autumn season.

story: In AUTUMN, the farmer's HEART is in DISTRESS as to if he has enough crops. Even better, the farmer will experience great DISTRESS in his HEART if his WHEAT catches FIRE!
column3: Here we have distressed (think "gloomy") people with "seasonal mood disorder" during the autumn season. Hence "autumn heart" is distressed (gloomy).
column4: The HEART becomes distressed in the AUTUMN when summer loves end.

story: Warning sign: "Private wheat, trespassers will be elbowed".
column3: A joke so bad as "wheatashi wa" deserves an elbow in the private parts.
column4: I already know this as watashi, or "I". In order to associate the keyword of private, I'll think of this one as "Private I", like a detective.

story: Think of REGULARITY in terms of bowel movements. Enough WHEAT in your diet will help your DROPS with improved REGULARITY.
column3: Eating plenty of wheat will improve regularity and help you lose weight.
column4: I got it. Regularity, order, system, systematic. Now, Imagine the husband (the 'head' of the household, the farmer and what not). Walking across his farm, then in a regular, ordered, and systemised fashion he DROPS (the drop) a little piece of wheat. I love this image not only because it answers the keyword, but it is really close to the meaning of the actual kanji.

story: The prize at the bottom of a cereal box is invariably a secret decoder ring.
column3: A young couple meets in secret in the wheat field because their families are enemies. They cross their hearts and swear eternal - even if secret - love. Do not confuse with 密 (#775).
column4: The farmers invariably keep the actual amount of wheat produced a secret from the tax assessor.

story: Taking appellation to mean the act of naming, we have the little baby superman reclining in the space craft that landed in a wheat field. Mr. and Mrs. Kent look down and decide to call him Clark. (I also thought of Jesus but he was born in a barn full of hay not wheat).
column3: WHEAT that is RECLINING and LITTLE (small) can't get the APPELLATION "quality wheat".
column4: An Indian chief explains the art of appellation by introducing his three children: Swaying Wheat, Reclining Buffalo and Little Bear.

story: 1. Steal a bunch of wheat from a wheat field by cutting it down with your saber. 2. ????? 3. Profit!
column3: In the middle ages there where only 2 ways for peasantry to make a profit. one by being a farmer, 2 to be a mercenary and live by the way of the sword.
column4: Use the saber to cut the wheat and get your profit.

story: The Japanese pear tree is the most profitable in the world, because it produces its fruit in pairs [sorry for the awful pun].
column3: Japanese pears (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pyrus_pyrifolia) are very tasty fruits and frequently used as a gift in Japan. They are quite expensive, so you can assume that a farmer can make a good profit from these fruits after getting them from the tree.
column4: And a profit in a pear tree...12 days of christmas.

story: The harvest of genetically modified crops is taken onboard the Greenpeace vessel (see the flower vessel in 護 (#756)).
column3: Wheat is harvested; the grain (flower) is put into vessels for shipping.
column4: Aha! It's the wheat harvest that's being 護 (#756) on the ship! That's why the pack of wild dogs 獲 (#757) the ship!

story: The pilgrims only had wheat, so they asked the Indians to do them a favor and trade them for some ears of corn.
column3: The "ear of a plant" is the seed-bearing spike of a cereal plant, such as corn. In other words, it is the part which feeds us. Hence -- "the ear (of a plant) is the favor of the wheat".
column4: Botanist (lecturing to class): ". . . and this is the ear of the plant." Wheat plant: "Will you do me a favor and stop shouting in my ear!"

story: The rice plant is common in Japan because all the wheat was eaten by vultures in the olden times.
column3: It used to be that wheat was grown in Japan. However, this was often stolen by vultures, so in olden times, the gods gave the Japanese the rice plant.
column4: The rice plant evolved from wheat in olden times to defend itself against vultures eating it - rice causes vultures to explode.

story: If you focus the suns though a magnifying glass on to the bottom of a stalk of wheat it will start to smoulder and burn like a stick of incense. The weird thing is that it burns from the bottom upwards, hanging in the air as if my magic. Try it and see!
column3: When the sun burns the wheat a smell of incense remains in the air.
column4: If we would throw a huge amount of wheat on top of the sun, would it become a galactic incense? Maybe then aliens wouls come more often, enjoying the incense.

story: There's a season for planting wheat and there's mating season for having children.
column3: As the seasons pass, the wheat and the children grow, but the wheat grows faster, right over the children.
column4: When the wheat has grown so high that the farmer can't see his child playing in the field anymore (child under wheat) he knows that the season has come to harvest his crops.

story: Female WHEAT farmers decide to create a COMMITTEE, which they fittingly name “The WHEAT WOMEN COMMITTEE.”.
column3: While the men had to harvest the field, the women formed committee where they decided what to do with the wheat. Here you see one of them carrying some of it away.
column4: The 'straw woman' (woman figure stuffed with wheat) is put on the committee to make it look as if there is equal representation, but really it's just a bunch of men ("keeping the women down" for placement).

story: You spend three hours putting all of your wheat sale transaction records into Microsoft Excel, when suddenly it crashes, so you put your fist through the monitor.
column3: A soviet-era poster for the 5-year plan shouts "Excel" and shows a fist clenching a sheaf of wheat. Wheat/Fist.
column4: A photo depicting that this year's harvest excelled all others: fists full of wheat.

story: If you excel in the Mario Kart road, your movements are saved and you can race against yourself as a transparent racer. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xe8CkcrL-k4.
column3: If you want to excel at driving in the roadway, it's better if your windows and windshield are transparent. Picture the drivers with opaque windshields all wrecked on the side of the road.
column4: Because it is transparent, fiber optic cable excels as a roadway for the information superhighway.

story: Word and Excel somehow manage to entice people to use them, despite their plethora of bugs.
column3: Think of the smooth talker who EXCELS at using WORDS to entice women (including married women if it makes it easier to remember).
column4: This kanji actually means "invite" so think of it as enticing someone to attend something. This is a PR person, enticing everyone to attend an event. To be a good PR person, you would definitely need to excel with words. (Also, if you don't excel enough, you could get people drunk on beer(wheat) or hire the mob(fist) to get them to come to the event).

story: The hardest part of my training as a cook was when they gave me some wheat and a chihuahua with a human leg and said, "Now make something delicious".
column3: After a hard day of training, wheat is understandably delicious.
column4: The CHIHUAHUA with a human leg is now in training to be a baker, learning to turn WHEAT into DELICIOUS loaves of bread. Notice the Chihuahua is standing on a delicious loaf of bread in order to reach the counter.

story: There are different cereals in different parts of the world. Japan has samurai cereal. Great Britain has Crowned Wheat ... the United States and Russia have Missile cereals.
column3: The samurai crowns wheat as the best cereal, and blows all others up with missiles (he's a cereal killer).
column4: Hint: I think cereals should be studied with 殻 (#710) because the difference between the husk and cereal is what's inside, would it be wheat or air (wind)! Story: cereals are similar to 殻 (#710) only that the husks can be carried by the wind because they don't have a wheat grain!

story: Can also mean bacteria.....imagine the wheat pent in your fridge growing to the point where they resemble flowers.......I actually had something similar happen to onions...they grew footlong legs after about 2 or 3 years......OR just think of that Cowboy Bebop episode with the lobster in the fridge... :-).
column3: Actually it means germs as in microorganisms. So for example, you have to keep wheat enclosed so it isn't exposed to other plants. That way it can't catch any germs (like fungi) from them.
column4: Keep your wheat pent in an airtight container or it may catch germs and sprout flowers.

story: The keyword numb makes no sense. I choose 萎む（しぼむ）"to fade away". A girl lies in a wheat field at the same time every day. A photo is taken every day showing this scene and a time lapse video shows the wheat growing through the year until the wheat is tall and the top sprouts to look like its flowers. At this point, the girl can no longer be seen in the photos and she fades away.
column3: As the flower committee meeting went on and on, my mind went numb and everything faded away.
column4: Any FLOWER that will make you go NUMB is likely to be banned by the olympic COMMITTEE. No pain killers.

story: Stroke order: I like to think of the first two strokes as “chop sticks” with which one eats the rice. The rest then is the “tree” meaning “plant” in this contexct. also: USA.
column3: Two drops of rice in a tree, simple.
column4: 88! Japanese people think of this Kanji as 88. Each grain of rice holds 88 gods inside. Anyway, that is the origins of this kanji. It's easy to remember: Each grain of rice holds 88 gods. 八十八　written as one character. just remember one 八　is upside down.

story: Parts of parts of parts of parts of rice... is flour. (Image: geishas patting their face with RICE flour to make it white. Not wheat flour...)
column3: In Japan, rice flour is part of a balanced diet. Mmmm, mochi...
column4: In the United States, part of every meal is made from flour.

story: This is another way of fortune telling -- throw sticky rice against the wall, and look for the message in whatever sticks.
column3: STICKY RICE can be used for FORTUNE TELLING - throw sticky rice against the wall, and look for the message in whatever sticks. (props Matticus. reworded for correct order).
column4: Mochi, Japanese sticky rice 米, is prepared by pounding rice in a bucket with a mallet 占. Eating mochi at New Year's is supposed to bring good fortune. (占 also means "hold," which is another possibility.) 粘土、ねんど, clay, lit sticky earth; 粘膜、ねんまく, mucous membrane.

story: A sage is using rice to fill up a vase, but as an exercise in patience, he's doing it grain by grain.
column3: There's a contest...whoever guesses the number of grains of rice in a vase wins.
column4: We store the grains of rice in a vase.

story: Modern cosmetics are just the descendants of the old RICE flour and CAVE DIRT ('cause it's darker) used in the past.
column3: Cave soil is bat guano (feces). A derivative of guano called guanine is sometimes used in the production of mascara. Rice extracts like starch and oil are used in a range of cosmetic and hygiene products for their moisturising and nourishing effects on the hair and skin. http://www.gardenmandy.com/bat-guano-in-mascara/ http://www.plantcultures.org/plants/rice_cosmetics.html.
column4: Note: Right side 庄 later appears as a separate kanji 庄 (#2345). Story: The rice grown in this shire is used for cosmetics.

story: If you go astray, just follow the rice you dropped along the road to find your way back.
column3: The road that the USA is heading down is, well... let's just say that they're astray...
column4: Hansel and Grettel follow their rice back home, but they find it's been all messed up on the road. Hansel and Grettel are astray because the rice is all over the road. The rice is on the road.

story: In extremely chic restaurants, you have to pay 90 bucks for a bowl of rice.
column3: Americans think that tattoos with Chinese characters are chic, but nine out of ten times they end up with something trivial tattooed on their arm, like rice.
column4: TIP: This kanji is actually iki (いき), which is one of those Japanese words that cannot be translated. If you can use it correctly, Japanese people will do backflips. See "Iki (aesthetics)" on Wikipedia... STORY: Chic was an American disco band that was truly great -- better than 9/10ths of all disco bands... 純粋[じゅんすい] pure.

story: Words meant to lead you astray are those of a riddle.
column3: A riddle is words designed to lead us astray.
column4: Any good riddle contains a few loaded words that are deliberately inserted to lead your thinking astray. For example: "A man is afraid to go home because of the other man in the mask, but once he got there he knew he was safe. Exactly what is going on in this situation?" In this riddle, the word that leads you astray is "home".

story: Imagine Japanese army provisions like obentou boxes, always containing the same quantity of rice. (thanks darg_sama, emphasizing quantity and the nuance of food "rations", "food supply": the kanji also appears in "military provisions" and "army rice").
column3: All Japanese provisions contain a certain quantity of rice... they eat it with just about every meal!
column4: Army provisions are all identically produced, each with an identical quantity of rice.

story: Chrysanthemum flower consists of many tiny petals, just like many rice grains bound up together.
column3: History: “Around the 8th century A.D., the chrysanthemum appeared in Japan. So taken were the Japanese with this flower that they adopted a single flowered chrysanthemum as the crest and official seal of the Emperor. Japan also has a National Chrysanthemum Day, which is called the Festival of Happiness.” Mnemonic: flower that looks like a lot of grains bound together.
column4: Chrysanthemum is a flower that is as intimately bound up with Japan as gohan.

story: In the core of a nuclear reactor, scientists have discovered a way to get power from rice, by penting it in under high pressure. It's very dangerous, so they've trained a st. bernard dog to run things, he's adding more drops of rice as necessary.
column3: The Core CPU is just a small drop of silicone the size of a grain of rice that has more power pent in it than the very big machines of the past.
column4: In the innermost core of the house the wife keeps the rice, well penned in and guarded by a st bernards dog.

story: Young taskmaster is learning numbers by watching women haul sacks of rice past him. "One... two... four! No, wrong! Go back, go back!"
column3: Women toil in the rice fields carrying heavy sacks of rice to be numbered and counted by the taskmaster.
column4: Rice above woman is the character 娄, which can refer to a constellation. (Mnemonic: The stars of the constellation are like grains of rice, forming the shape of a woman in the sky.) We'll also see 娄 in 楼 (#930) and 屡 (#2221). Number: The taskmaster makes you count the number of stars in the constellation.

story: The young taskmaster (see 数 (#998)) uses a tree as a watchtower to get a better view of his rice-carrying women. "I can seeeee you! One! Two! Three!"
column3: On the top of the woodmade watchtower we look for our enemies, who will come to steal our rice and our women.
column4: Rice above woman is the character 娄, which can refer to a constellation. (Mnemonic: The stars of the constellation are like grains of rice, forming the shape of a woman in the sky.) 娄 also appears in 数 (#998) and 屡 (#2331). Watchtower: A wooden watchtower lets you get a better view of the constellation.

story: Note this character means sort in the sense of what kind, I believe a better keyword would be "variety" and this character does appear in some dictionaries with the primary meaning as variety, my story: I'm in a Chinese restaurant and the waiter says "What sort of rice would you like with your dog head?"
column3: There are many sorts of rice in Japan. Some are as big as your head!
column4: (Compilation of raulir's and Raichu's stories). Various types of food are enumerated on the page (maybe a menu): in the upper half you see vegetarian sorts of food (such as rice), and in the lower half you see sorts of meat dishes (such as St. Bernard dog's meat).

story: LACQUER is a type of WATERY type of liquid used to protect items made from TREES, sort of an UMBRELLA of protection. So protective, you can carry around RICE in the LACQUERED, WOODEN product.
column3: Water is falling from a tree onto the umbrella underneath which is protecting the rice underneath it. But it's completely dry since the umbrella is lacquered.
column4: Lacquer is a liquid 氵substance that you apply to wood 木 which provides umbrella人-like protection against water 氺. (氺 is a form of "water," not rice. It's called したみず, lit. "water underneath.").

story: Before 漆 (#1001) was made with water, it was made by draining this body part of fluid: the knee!
column3: Back in ancient Japan, people didn't have knee pads for things like rollerblading and such (what, come on. Ninjas on rollerblades. Ultimate 90s flashback). Instead, they would simply dip their knees in laquer, and wait until it dried (hence the flesh, and the abscence of any drops of water). Unfortunately, this meant that you would have to wait about 30 minutes after deciding to go rollerblade until you could actually do it (took some time to dry) - and removing it was a serious pain.
column4: The knees are the part of the body that I protect with lacquered kneepads.

story: Here we have the requirements to be counted among the ranks of the noble Esq. You must posses a forested estate, herds of sheep, and granary full of grains of rice.
column3: This is -Sama, a generic high term of respect for someone in an unusual profession. If you met a person that created a wooden sheep that was squeezing a single grain of rice out of its ass, you'd definitely call that person -sama. Because that is impressive.
column4: This kanji actually means -sama. You are the creator of TREES, SHEEP, and RICE?! Ooooh great creator-SAMA!! (kneels).

story: Enemy: "Any final requests?" // MacGyver: "Just an arrowhead and some grains of rice." (MacGyver then throws the grains of rice at the enemy and uses the arrowhead to cut his hands free from the rope.)
column3: Robin Hood holds his rich victim at arrowpoint and kindly requests that he hands over his grains of rice.
column4: A beggar asks for you if you can spare a few grains of rice, after you refuse you find him pointing an arrowhead at your throat. "That wasn't a request."

story: Someone files a request to see the family jewels and, to their surprise, you show them your balls!
column3: The KING REQUESTS your presence at the ball ... game.
column4: You cannot disobey the king, so when he requests to see your balls you have no choice.

story: Like in the biblical sense, someone looks skyward and makes a request for salvation from this horrible taskmaster...
column3: For salvation you have to request forgiveness from God (the ultimate taskmaster).
column4: A cruel taskmaster makes a request to god for salvation from the sins commited during his life. Yeaaaah... right.

story: Two reclining victims impaled by bamboo spikes.
column3: Since this is a really common kanji and so easy to remember on its own, I just remembered it by it's reading, which is たけ.
column4: I see this pictographically. Stroke 1: leaf. Stroke 2: joint of stalk. Stroke 3: section of stalk. And it's doubled because it comes in groves (just as you double "tree" to make "grove").

story: When the people tried to build a tower of bamboo to reach the heavens, the gods just laughed and laughed.
column3: Tip: 天 and 夭 (heavens and sapling) are different, but RTK confuses them sometimes. The latter appears in numbers 634, 938, 2078, 2079, 2080, and all characters containing angel 喬 (429, 430, 1221, 2104, 2120, 2369). Story: The fully-grown bamboo trees are laughing at the little sapling.
column4: That Panda is in bamboo heaven! Just look at him laugh!

story: The bamboo vase was beautifully crafted, but the tourist didn't know what it was and wore it as a little bamboo hat.
column3: The bamboo part is easy. Just remember that this kanji refers to those particular bamboo hats that are worn primarily by Buddhist monks, who always seem to stand outside of train stations, collecting alms.
column4: Hey, where'd you buy that bamboo hat? Over at that bamboo stand!

story: The bamboo generation smokes bamboo grass.
column3: “One of the most attractive aspects of bamboo is that it is a renewable resource; it takes less than a year for a stalk to reach maturity, compared to the decades for most trees, whether needle or broadleaf.” -- Mnemonic : "bamboo grass is the next bamboo generation".
column4: Bamboo grass lasts generations. very strong & durable.

story: The two fiestas communicated to each other on their respective floats by using bamboo stationery.
column3: Note: the spelling should be stationery (= paper, office supplies), not stationary (= not moving). The error is in the original book.
column4: Because this character was added to the Joyo list in 2010, it now uses a simplified version of the writing. It's now the "float" primitive instead of "two fiestas".

story: Muscle is part of the body that gives strength, and can be both supple and tense like the bamboo.
column3: Lifting BAMBOO STICKS is an old way for your BODY to put on lots of MUSCLE.
column4: If you have enough MUSCLE POWER, you can throw BAMBOO to the MOON.

story: The best kind of BOX is made from BAMBOO sticks that are INTER-laced to make it air tight. Just picture such a box and you've mastered this kanji.
column3: I think of a box made of inter-locking of bamboo strips.
column4: BAMBOO that INTER- locks makes a BOX. (thanks to Fuaburisu).

story: Bamboo is the best material from which to make a brush if you want it to be a writing brush.
column3: Traditionally, the ふで, or writing brush, was made with a bamboo handle and the hair of an animal (usually horse, rabbit, or wolf). Before the advent of paper (which the Chinese invented), writing was also done on segments of bamboo.
column4: When the panda held the magical writing brush, he was able to draw every Heisig kanji without having even studied the book. Picture yourself studying for months and the panda picks up the writing brush and does better than you.

story: Seriously, all BAMBOO sticks look the SAME, just long CYLINDERS. Should the story be more complicated?
column3: Fully-grown bamboo consists of a number of cylinder-like sections, all exactly the same.
column4: A monk is put into a cylinder prison made of bamboo bars.

story: The Bamboo Buddhist Temple has bamboo buddhas, bamboo buildings, bamboo benches, bamboo beds, bamboo bowls, etc. etc. etc.
column3: "So what'd you see in Japan?" - "Bamboo, temples...etc.".
column4: One monk at a buddhist temple says to another: "You only have to look at a bamboo grove to understand the meaning of et cetera". "How so?" "There is no single bamboo plant which catches your attention, no main attraction; they are ALL et cetera."

story: Before the time of digital calculators, people used old school calculators made of bamboo (abacus). It's not as easy as a calculator, but you don't need any batteries either. All you need are your eyes and your two hands.
column3: Tip : you may see this as an Abacus, which is used to calculate. This particular ancient chinese Abacus has eyeballs in place of beads, and its frame is made of bamboo. You'd be amazed at how fast people can calculate with this, especially if they can use both hands at once to move the ... eyeballs.
column4: Gah! I just can't calculate this differential equation! So I take a sharp bamboo pen in each hand and jam them into my eyes out of frustration.

story: The solution to this puzzle is, like the match stick game, to make the bamboo pieces fit together.
column3: Be careful not to confuse this with the inter-locking bamboo pieces of 箱 (#1013). Imagine a child's building-block puzzle. There are three holes: triangle, square, circle. Also there is a cylindrical piece of bamboo. Which of the holes does the bamboo fit into? The fitting hole is the solution.
column4: The solution to every problem? Bamboofit! Our new product is useful in many situations: when your friends talk too much? BAMBOOFIT! (shove it in their mouth) When your dog barks all night? BAMBOOFIT! Leaky faucet? BAMBOOFIT!

story: The temples in kyoto belt bamboo around trees in a scheme to protect them from the huge number of tourists. (true story)-----------対策 たいさく measure, countermeasure.
column3: (Elaboration of jameserb's story:) A clever scheme from Wile E Coyote -- he ties one of those rubber belts to some trees and uses it to launch a bamboo spear at the roadrunner...
column4: In Japan gardeners use a scheme to protect trees by putting a bamboo belt around them.

story: Note : the keyword is not a verb, think of a record book. This acupuncturist who uses bamboo in place of flowers to dilute water into his patients (see frame 227), managed somehow to appear on the register of acupuncturists. Chances are, he won't stay on the register for long. My image is close to that of gorgon's story.
column3: This doctor dilutes (see 227) his patients with bamboo stalks rather than the flowers of a standard diluting acupuncturist hence he needs to be on the Bamboo Accumpunturist Diltuers (BAD) register. Pumping that much water into a body can be dangerous; see the huge bamboo stems with gallons of water sloshing in and out of the patient.
column4: The acupuncturist was not very good. His bamboo needles made his patients cry copious amounts of water. He was put on a register of doctors to avoid.

story: Bamboo crafting is a mediocre substitute for wood when you are building or fabricating a house. While it may look good and might attract a chick (ちく) or two, the kids'll (きず) just tear it to pieces as its not sturdy enough.
column3: If you fabricate a boat from bamboo you get a pretty mediocre craft. Use wood instead.
column4: Just as you wouldn't want heart surgeons who were mediocre at their craft operating on you (see raulir's story for 恐 (#613)), you also wouldn't want house builders who were mediocre at their craft fabricating your house for you--they might fabricate a flimsy one of bamboo instead of sturdy one of wood. 建築 (けんちく): construction, architecture 建築家 (けんちくか): architect 築き上げる (きずきあげる): to build up/establish (one's reputation) Careful: 架 (#869).

story: The only cage that can keep a dragon is made of bamboo.
column3: Mulan carried the dragon Mushoo around in a bamboo basket.
column4: A bamboo cage won't hold a dragon!

story: Behold Mister T (of "A-Team" fame)! I chose Mr.T because he's sure to make amusing stories. He is a very versatile character since he's both the big, tough guy and the “moralistic” person, telling kids not “to do drugs or alcohol”. He is easy to imagine, the heavy gold chains are probably the most prominent feature of the character. And last but not least you can always pepper your story with the famous line “I pity da foo!” * Fittingly, on the left side of the kanji, it looks like a “T”.
column3: [I appreciate some people's occasional habit of using P for person in shared stories. That makes it easier to substitute Mr. T, Captain Picard, or whomever else a student is using as person.].
column4: For this character, I'm going to use Chuck Norris. He is a world class martial artist, winning several karate championships in a row. He also achieved ultimate power according to his Chuck Norris Facts, and works as a Texas Ranger (sheriff). He is however a very kind and religious person. Here we have a view of his powerful legs, while the contracted form shows him performing a roundhouse kick.

story: Mr T's assistant is on his left. Why? Because Mr T has this bad habit of suddenly extending his right arm (what with all the boxing that he did), and his assistant got inadvertently punched in the face more than once (ouch). So now his assistant is always to his left side, much safer - "Stay on my left, foo!"
column3: On your right is your "right-hand man" that you credit for all your success....on the left...... is your assistant who does all the grunt work and gets no credit for anything...
column4: Your left-hand man. (NB this kanji suggests a lower-ranking assistant. Their is a similar but rarer kanji 佑 with "right" that indicates receiving help from a superior.)

story: Mr. T don't take a partner, especially one with no spine. "I pity da foo got no spine", he says.
column3: As a PARTNER, I want a PERSON with a strong SPINE.
column4: Mr. T needs a partner with a strong spine as he's a beast in the bedroom.

story: However drunk Mr T is when he comes back to his place, he always get up at nightbreak. “I pity da foo who gets up after nightbreak !”, says Mr. T.
column3: MR.T leads a busy life, however he always makes sure to be in bed by NIGHTBREAK, however much he might want to stay up watching A-Team re-runs.
column4: However many times i try to look at this kanji in review i realize how abstract the term "however is". But i remember this story i made up just now which is a poor person until night break trying to remember this kanji.

story: When Mr T shows people round his dwelling he takes a big candlestick (with a candle in it!) so that the light shows off his collection of bling bling jewellery.
column3: Mr. T DWELLS in a house fit for a lord. As with all the bling, he has to keep up appearances, you know. Now all the people on his street are just 'trying to keep up with the T's' (as opposed to 'keeping up with the Jones').
column4: A person dwells in the place where he puts his candlesticks.

story: Mr T ranks first position in the stand-up competition (doing knee flexions). Just picture him doing hundreds of these while the rest of the participants are already completely exhausted after a mere hundred.
column3: Rank A person's standing.
column4: Mr. T ranked number one in the "last man standing" boxing tournament. You can imagine Mr. T standing atop all his fallen rivals to exemplify his top ranking.

story: When negotiating a hostage situation, Mr. T acted as the go-between, or person in the middle, for law enforcement and the terrorist.
column3: Go-between The person in the middle.
column4: They say only Nixon could go to China; but actually he sent Mr. T as a go-between. Nixon understands the Manchu dynasty, but only Mr. T pities the Fu.

story: Mister T works out his body (body-building), using two piles of books (i.e. an exercise that can be done at home with two chairs, similar to push-ups but working mostly the shoulders, trapezius and triceps).
column3: MR. T's fitness BOOK: How to Get a Body Like Mine.
column4: Mr. T works out his body then rips a book apart to test is body. His favorite to destroy is Dianetics.

story: Mr. T ventured out into a remote area to visit with his wise, old taskmaster who must use a walking stick to get around and originally gave Mr. T the heart to fight crime for the good of the community.
column3: Yoda, the Jedi with the walking stick who was a hard taskmaster for Luke but who had a big heart, was permanently exiled on the remote planet Dagobah.
column4: Even a person being hit with a walking-stick by the taskmaster, can remain calm if their heart is remote. (i.e. "emotionally remote", kanji also means calm/composed).

story: Note: this kanji refers to event or case. Current Affair headline: Mr. T has affair with cow. "It's only animal 'man' enough for me".
column3: How could you have an affair with that person?? She's a cow!
column4: I'm having a hard time keep straight just which animal Mr. T is having an affair with. chamcham's story made me realize that Mr. T is not having an "affair", he's having an "heifair." Get it?

story: Back in the day, a person who stands beside a samurai is usually attending to them or working for them.
column3: [+fuaburisu] Mr T attends to Tom Cruise in the Last Samurai, who is doing hara-kiri. Imagine Tom Cruise outside in the final scene, stabbing his knife into his stomach, while Mr T looks patiently on. "I pity da foo....no, really."
column4: Mr. T has become a samurai. Now he has to attend his feudal lord. "I pity da foo don't attend to his lord", says Mr. T.

story: It's one or the other: fight Mr. T, or be thrown into the scorpion pit.
column3: Old latin saying: homo hominis scorpio (people are scorpions to other people).
column4: Mr. T picks a live scorpion up off the ground and starts munching on it. "Mmmmm.... scorpion. The other white meat".

story: Don't need a silly story for this one: prostration is when a person puts themselves in a low position like a dog, as an extreme gesture of humility.
column3: Mr T has beaten up the chihuahua, who lies prostrated in front of him. "Now," Mr T says, "I quiero some Taco Bell!"
column4: “Get up foo, you ain't no chihuahua!" says Mr. T to the obsessive fan prostrated on the ground in front of him. "I pity da foo who gets hiself prostrated before anyone like a little dumb ass chihuahua!" says Mr. T. (don't confuse with 儀 (#1059)).

story: Mister T transmits a message with rising clouds (smoke) signals, to a nearby American Indian tribe. The smoke signals spell : "I p-i-t-y y-o-u f-o-o !".
column3: person transmitting smoke signals in coded rising clouds.
column4: Hanging one-handed under Cloud City, the Jedi-in-training Luke, uses the force to transmit his distress to Leia.

story: Mr. T says, "I ain't afraid o' no foo! I'll give anyone an elbow to the face, I don't care if it's Buddha himself!"
column3: Buddha is a person who always seems to have his elbows bent.
column4: Out of respect for Buddha, Chuck Norris simply elbows him rather than roundhouse-kicking him in the face. However, the sheer force of Chuck Norris's elbow is still powerful enough to bring Buddha to enlightenment in one blow.

story: Mr T resting by a tree.
column3: Chuck norris rests againsts the tree, but wait, no... the tree rests and stands against him.
column4: A person rests by leaning on a tree.

story: Mr. T is anti anything provisional. "I pity da foo' who's so indecisive that he can't make nothin' permanent".
column3: If provisional governments are left in power for too long, the people will begin to turn anti-establishment.
column4: A person's nature is always anti anything provisional - he wants permanent thing .

story: Mr T is dancing and singing and all that, but he's doing it on a branch. All that talent and can still still keep his balance? That's a real performing artist.
column3: (note: this is the 'ki' from kabuki).//The performing artist is a person doing Kabuki theater and dancing around with a branch in his hand.
column4: As PERFORMING ARTIST, MR T's career is all about BRANCHing out. You name it, he's done it: From bouncer to gold-chain-wearing local night-scene celeb, to action hero, to rap artist, to his new smashing breakout role as Radikal-9 aka "Da Man" aka亻, his experiments with can-can (何 何 (#1087)), and now classical kabuki (歌舞伎), for which he is a natural. (Yes, you got it: MR T pities da foo's who don't BRANCH out.)

story: Mr T was originally supposed to be the chief of the A-Team, but then the producers realized that America didn't want to see a Black guy as the chief of a prime-time TV show. So here, we see Mr T doing a bunch of cocaine, and then spreading it all over his face to look white, and trying out for the part of Hannibal. The directors were so impressed that they let him stunt double for Hannibal in a few episodes. OR, Mr T chiefin' on some crack cocaine. You make the call.
column3: The person with the white hair is the chief.
column4: This also means Count... Count Dracula, the chief vampire, is easily recognized by his pale white skin, gleaming white fangs, white shirt, white gloves, et cetera.

story: Mr. T says, "Don't be like them valley girls, always speaking vulgar language and acting all vulgar! They ain't nothing but foos!"
column3: Mr T meets the vulgar (common) people of the valley and participates in the vulgar customs (folkways). Looking at the vulgar (common) people, Mr T says - “I pity you foo!”.
column4: Most of the personages in the valley are vulgar types -- miners, farmers, day laborers.

story: Mr. T has faith in the Word of God. (Image: Mr. T kneeling and prayering in front of a bible. "Pity me, fool.").
column3: Faith is believing that a person will be true to his word.
column4: Have faith in the words of Mr T, “Don't do alcohol” “Don't do drugs” “I pity the foo what does not have faith !” “have faith (believe) in Mr T's words”.

story: Mr T wants to go to an excellent school, so he enrolls in Harvard, an ivy-league school.
column3: Bill and Ted are walking through medieval Europe when they see a humongous square jewel. "Excellent!" they both yell. But only after grabbing it do they realize it is chained to the neck of Mr. T, who grimaces angrily at them. "Bogus!" they cry, and totally run away.
column4: In Holland, when a person gives you an excellent mark for a test or an exam, he'll give you 10 out of 10 (10/10) and he underlines the numbers to emphasize your excellence!

story: Mr T is reliant (depends on) on his garment (the gold chains).
column3: Proverb: the clothes make the man (person). that is, we are reliant on what we wear to be who we are.
column4: People are reliant on garments to survive cold winters.

story: Mr T shows the example to the kids, and stays in the file (at supermarket, ...). “I pity da foo who does not follow my example !”.
column3: When Mr. T. wants to make an example out of a group of people, he lines them up all single file and knocks them all out with one punch!
column4: Mr. T teaching a fighting class, "For example, watch me beat the hell out of this file of skeleton warriors".

story: This keyword gave me trouble, I could write the kanji from memory but could not remember the keyword the other way around. In such case the dictionary definition can be helpful : "Middle English, single, indivisible". Here we have Mr. T. who is so hardened (all the body workout he's had) that he became in-dividual, that is, in-divisible. "I pity da foo who can be divided into smaller units."
column3: Mr. T insists that people be individual. He appears on television, saying, "Being an individual is hard! But you gotta do it! Harden yourself, and be individual!"
column4: Mr. T is a hardened individual.

story: Mr. T in a public service announcement yells, "I'm healthy because every day I build a food pyramid, foo!"
column3: "Mr.T, sir, how do you stay so healthy?" I asked. "Simple, foo," he answered, "you gotta build the body up by bodybuilding!"
column4: Many people strive to achieve a healthy build.

story: Mr. T rulezzz! I am on his side!
column3: A PERSON that follow your RULES is at your side.
column4: "Mr. T got one rule!" says Mr. T. "I'm on the side of those picked on by the bullies. I pity da foo who tries to bully those smaller than he is!"

story: Mr. T infiltrates the secret samurai Buddhist temple as a waiter with a tray of green tea. (Careful: 仕 (#1033)).
column3: Remember the kanji for wait, 待. Well, now we have a waiter, and he's dropped a dish. See: 侍! 待 crash 侍.
column4: Mister T can do no meditation! So he is a waiter at the Buddhist temple, attending upon the zen monks, serving green tea, etc. (but mostly, he is annoying all the monks with the noise of his big gold chains).

story: "Halt fool" - Mr T acting as a bouncer at the pavillion.
column3: Used in バス停　【バスてい】 (bus stop, or bus halt literally). Story: The pavilion where people wait for buses to halt.
column4: Mister T makes a halt at the African pavilion at the World's Fair. He eats all the snacks on offer, and chats up the ladies - "“I pity da foo who does not halt by your pavilion, it's the best !".

story: Mr. T (person) tells the used car salesman to tell him the real price straight away, and when he doesn't he throws him through the windshield.
column3: The price is what people want to know straightaway.
column4: Mr. T is shopping for new chains. He knows what he wants and money isn't an issue. "Cut the jibba-jabba, tell me the price, straightaway!"

story: Mr T downloads an emulator so that he can play his favorite game, Pokemon. He plays for a different reason, though - he hates to see them poor little foos in the ball so he spends his entire time setting them free.
column3: Just emulate Mr T, and set yourself free.
column4: The black slave who was 放 (#535) decides to emulate Mr. T, his role model. He uses his compass to head to Cali to start anew.

story: arrogant: Mr.T, the arrogant taskmaster he is, assures the group he’s leading them in the right direction. Until he realises his compass is filled with dirt.
column3: He showed his arrogance as he poured dirt on those who tried to emulate him.
column4: Mr T may appear arrogant because he addresses everyone as foo'. But, he's willing to get dirty in order to set free the youth in inner cities from drugs and poverty. Truly someone to be emulated. 傲慢 (ごうまん): pride; haughtiness; arrogance; insolence; hubris 傲岸 (ごうがん): haughtiness; pride; irreverence 倨傲 (きょごう): pride, arrogance 傲る (おごる): give (someone) a treat; be extravagant, live luxuriously; be proud, haughty.

story: The A-Team are planning to overthrow the government. However, they can't do a damn thing until Mr T arrives.
column3: In Return of the Jedi, after a climactic light sabre battle, Luke and Vader overthrow the emporer (literally throwing him over the balcony).
column4: The arrival of the person (e.g., Castro) marked the overthrow of the government.

story: Mr. T is a terrible spy. He walks around upright. "Why should I hide?! I've got nothing to be ashamed of!"
column3: NOTE: The second primitive is upright, not eminent. There is an error in the book.
column4: A perfect spy is a person who is deemed upright in the community.

story: Mr. T and the artist formerly known as Prince, who by the way is a buddhist, want to form a new heavy metal band. Instead of "Judas Priest" they will be called "Buddhist Priest".
column3: While a waiter at the Buddhist temple (see FRAME 976), Mr T increases in wisdom and becomes a Buddhist priest.
column4: Mr T was formerly a Buddhist priest but he beat up some young alcolytes so got defrocked or whatever.

story: Mr. T has an clear idea of what he would do if he ever got hundred million dollar. (I guess it would be a enormous gold chain !)
column3: A PERSON with a good IDEA will make a hundred million dollars.
column4: Mr. T's bright idea is to get a hundred million kids to vow not to use drugs. "C'mon, foo! Sign the paper!"

story: Mr. T is the master of ceremonies because he is a righteous dude.
column3: Mr. T was briefly a rapper, that is an M.C., that is a master of CEREMONIES (the origin of the phrase). But he sang only RIGHTEOUS songs, no cursing or anything like that. (all true: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7_rBidCkJxo ).
column4: A person that goes to religious ceremonies is not necessarily righteous.

story: Mr. T says, "This ain't no prize, foo! This is reparations for slavery!"
column3: NOTE: do not confuse with 賠 (#515)賠. However, 賠 is always used in conjunction 賠償... But 償 is used in various other compounds. Mr. T sold all his jewelry to give as reparations to slave families. The governent tried to honor his charity by giving him a prize, but it was a shitty outhouse filled with clams.
column4: A good PERSON would use his PRIZE money to pay REPARATIONS to those he harmed.

story: A HERMIT is a PERSON who lives in the MOUNTAINS.
column3: After living as an hermit (recluse) for a while in the mountains, Mister T becomes an immortal mountain fairy ("fairy" is another meaning of this kanji).
column4: Mr. T isn't on TV anymore because he is now a hermit living in the mountains. (Playing World of Warcraft).

story: And now a word from our sponsor. We see Mr. T, doing a sort of George Foreman thing, grilling Mountain Turkeys. "I pity da foo who don't have a Mr. T grill!"
column3: In a supermarket, there is a game sponsored by Mr.T. If you can beat him, you win a mountain of turkey.
column4: This show has been brought to you by our sponsor: Hermit's Turkeys.

story: Mr. T shows his humanity by giving two bucks to every homeless person he sees.
column3: Warning: This is not humanity as in all the people. But rather the qualities that make us human such as compassion and benevolence.
column4: This character, as Heisig points out, is strongly Confucian. Some scholars say that it references the importance of humane relationships between two people (parent/child, sibling/sibling, ruler/subject, etc). It's easy enough, though, to look at it as a person in a dialogue with another - the give and take, yin and yang - the two-way street in which humanity relates to each other.

story: Mr. T has scorn for every fool.
column3: People full of scorn tend to hate every person (including themselves).
column4: Mr. T spews a lot of scorn at people. He scorns everyone! Even reclining mamas during birth! "Damn woman! Stop the jibba-jabba and push!"

story: Mr. T uses the officer as a punching bag.
column3: Of course Mr. T will tell a police officer if he catches someone using drugs, foo!
column4: officers arrest a person who uses.

story: Mr. T loves the convenience of the new konbini. Not only does it stay open even if it grows late, they have brand new toilets, and a Post Office!
column3: Mr. T takes a dump on the floor of a convenience store. Well, it was growing late and he couldn't wait. He pities the fool who will have to clean it up!
column4: When it grows late only convenience stores serve people.

story: Mr. T keeps his double muzzled ... he wants all the glory.
column3: If you MUZZLE MR.T, prepare for DOUBLE trouble!
column4: Mr T, like many holywood stars, has a butt double who is used only for scenes where T's buttocks are exposed (he has issues with bearing his behind). The butt double has no speaking parts - he is muzzled. Of course T himself isn't he's rambling on about pity and foo.

story: The A-Team is on a mission to help Hamlet. With uncharacteristic tenderness, Mr. T consoles the melancholy Hamlet. "No, I really DO pity the poor foo. There, there little guy...take my hanky". (Careful: 徳 (#950).
column3: Someone can't be melancholy for long if just one person treats them with a little tenderness.
column4: All you need is tenderness to get a person out of melancholy.

story: At a fiesta, Mr. T tries to knock down a large pinata, but in his overly enthusiastic swings to get "the sucka," he actually FELLS the tree the piñata is hanging from, crushing some party goers. “I pity da fools who got crushed by my FELLED tree!”.
column3: This kanji means to cut down. All PERSONs at a FIESTA want to be the ones who CUT DOWN the piñata (with their strong swings).
column4: Means to cut down, as in "to fell a tree." Mr. Hito 亻was felled by a spear 戈. Note this differs from substitute 代 (代わり, 時代) by just one stroke! 征伐、せいばつ, conquest, subjugation (subjugate +); 伐採、ばっさい, timber felling, lumbering (+ pick); 乱伐、らんばつ, overcutting, deforestation (riot +).

story: The Toyoko Inn can house 100 people or 1 Mr. T.
column3: A hundred people under one roof, its gota be a inn!
column4: The inn is like a big house that can addomodate a hundred persons. Only this time, there's just Mister T and he's booked all the rooms!

story: Mr. T cannot believe the reclining piggy bank won't give up. He has cut off its legs one by one until it cannot stand, yet, despite being rendered almost completely useless it won't surrender. “It's just a flesh wound!” the reclining piggy bank yells.
column3: Mr. T gets wounded by reclining on his piggy bank.
column4: Some guy was robbed and beaten......he's the person with the gaping wound reclining on the floor with his piggy bank smashed to pieces.

story: Tip: Heisig later combines mouth and tree into 呆 呆 (#2297). Story: Your person (Mr. T. or whoever) is dumbfounded when told to protect the bad guys rather than fight them.
column3: Mr. T opens his mouth from the top of the tree saying "I pitty da foo who don't protect the trees!"
column4: To protect the environment people speak on the behalf of trees...

story: Mr. T is praised for his protecting of the trees by being given a top hat and scarf which he wears over his mohawk and chains, respectively.
column3: I have to praise this tophat and scarf, it sure did do a great job protecting me from the cold!
column4: The garment with a layer of bulletproof protection inside received praise at the technology fair.

story: My wise person says greatness does not come from wearing shades (sunglasses) but from planting trees to shade everyone.
column3: Mr T stands in front of you, his greatness radiating out from him so brightly. You need to put on your sunglasses and hide behind a tree to even talk to the guy. "Recognise, foo!"
column4: Wise Mr. T says greatness does not come from giving out shades (sunglasses) but from planting trees to shade everyone. (thanks to scottamus).

story: If a PERSON ADHERES to something, they stick to it like GLUE.
column3: He's low on cash, so Mr. T wants to sell ad space on his body. When you ask him where it goes he says, "glue it here, fool! Ad here! ad here!"
column4: Mr. T says, "Foo, of course I don't sniff glue! I adhere to my own advice to not use drugs!"

story: I dropped my token down the drain, so I used a piece of bamboo with chewing gum on the end to retrieve it.
column3: At the arcade, Mr. T adheres a bamboo rod to his token so that he can put it in the machine and pull it out repeatedly.
column4: Before entering the temple, one must adhere to the rules and buy bamboo tokens. Mandatory offerings.

story: A municipality, like any type of government, adheres to having caves for offices (see 庁 (#591)).
column3: Even if a municipality is in a cave, you have to adhere to its policies.
column4: Adhere. Cave. Fu from Osaka-fu. In the municipality (fu) of Osaka you find advertisements adhered all over the subway tunnel caves.

story: It is always Mr. T's responsibility to be the porter and carry around everyone's luggage because he's so strong.
column3: In 妊 (#507), the woman was the porter for the first nine months. Now, as a new father, Mr.T is assuming all the RESPONSIBILITIES that comes with it. Can't you just see him here as the new porter, wearing a harness with a his little dude (who already has a little matching mohawk)?
column4: The porter of people (rather than of baggage -- i.e., bus driver, airline pilot, ...) is the person with the greatest responsibilty.

story: It's your own responsibility to pay the bus fare with the correct number of shells/money.
column3: In Japan they have automatic ticket gates so you cant easily cheat on your train fare. In England however the ticket gates are fairly open. It is a different kind of system. In England you are given the RESPONSIBILITY to put in the right amount of MONEY, but if you are caught cheating, the fines are stiff and you feel like a real CHINCHIN. "un.CHIN".
column4: Belligerent passenger to bus driver: "Look buddy, I'll pay the fare if you just give me some change for my $20 bill!" Bus driver: "Hey it's your responsibility to bring the right amount of cash. Now get off the bus if you can't pay the fare." Don't confuse with 符 (#1076) - fairness goes with responsibility.

story: "Mister T substitutes an arrow for a toothpick" -- The keyword meaning is to replace something with something else, to act for another, to represent. It's best to stick to the first meaning, because the last two are very close to "mediator" which will come in frame 1761. The idea here is that the arrow is not a toothpick, neither it is changed into one, but it can substitute for one.
column3: Mr. T shot the substitute teacher with an arrow.
column4: The gym teacher asks Mr. T to substitute for him on the day the kids will be shooting arrows for archery class. Imagine going home and telling your friends "dude! Mr T was my sub today! I hope my teacher gets hit with an arrowhead and never comes back!". (thanks dihutenosa).

story: A sack is an easy substitute for a garment.
column3: A worker who was recently sacked from his job, is wearing a sack of potatoes as a substitute garment (naked otherwise), in some kind of protest. The kanji is close to frame 1547 "bag", and although the later really refers to a "straw sack", I use the image of a sack of potatoes here, and that of a "plastic bag" for frame 1547. The keywords would have been better swapped in my opinion, but the relevancy is not so important at this point (see notes of Lesson 31 in the book).
column4: If you're super poor, you can substitute a potato sack for normal garments.

story: In order for the bank to lend you money, you need to put up some sort of collateral as a substitute for the money.
column3: The poor substitute teacher asks the class to lend him some money for the bus fare home.
column4: When you lend money to someone, you are in essence substituting their money (or lack there of) with yours.

story: I just see this one as a pictograph of a person changing position and sitting down.
column3: Referring to a scene in the movie "The Matrix" where a girl bends a spoon with the power of her mind alone, I imagine Mister T who changes a spoon into something else (maybe the waiter forgot to bring knives or forks). Note: as a primitive, it can help to use the image of "spare change", this can help you keep it distinct from other similar kanji such as "shape" or "turn into".
column4: Mr. T reaches into his wallet for some spare change but it has all changed into spoons.

story: The flowers change with the seasons.
column3: The flower is the essence of transience. So, the conceptual flower involves both the concept of flower plus change.
column4: "Hana" turned me down so I gave her a flower to change her mind.

story: Freight is the shells (money) paid to change the location of something big. Don't confuse with the similar 賃 賃 (#1079).
column3: This is a freight train that runs on spare change. Imagine getting on the freight train with a bunch of spare change. You put in some change and it starts up...goes for a few minutes, then starts to slow down. You look at the slot..there's actually a slot for spare change and one for regular shells. Your call, but it seems to prefer spare change over shells.
column4: This is also commonly used to mean currency, which is easier to remember given the kanji I think. When you travel abroad you change your clams into the local currency. Easy breezy.

story: I didn't study for the test at all! So what else could I do? When the guy beside me wasn't looking, I leaned over, and changed his page with mine!
column3: Referring to the movie "The Elephant Man" by director David Lynch, here we see Elephant Man leaning on his bed, wishing he could change his head. He knew very well he could not lie down, for he would die unable to breathe, and thus he always slept leaning on a few cushions.
column4: When you change 化 your head 頁, you lean or incline a different way. 傾向、けいこう, trend, tendency: 郷愁にふける時、私達は子供時代をこの上なく時期を考える傾向があるかもしれない, "When we indulge in nostalgia, there may be a tendency to consider childhood a supremely happy period." 傾ける、かたむける, to lean, slant: 愛子さんは首を右に傾けました, "Aiko-san tilted her head to the right."

story: What can Mr T do? 'You mean: what can't MR T do, you fool'.
column3: If Mr. T can't do it, what person can?
column4: Personman. Personman. Doing what only person can.

story: TSA guard: What's in the baggage?! It's just flowers, I swear!
column3: Your girlfriend arrives at the airport. You give her flowers, but she brushes you off and says "here, carry my BAGGAGE." Dumbfounded at her rudeness, you say, "what?"
column4: Customs agent: "What kind of flowers are these in your baggage, sir? Poppies, huh? Please come with us, sir..."

story: The entire town wants to get rid of legal prostitutes, but the sagacious Mr T realizes that they are a benefit to the economy and society. So he lets the sa-geishas stay.
column3: (re: sweetneet) Since he is not very sagacious, Mr. T failed his driver's license and now needs to resort to his walking legs to get around.
column4: This is the first time I heard of the word sagacious, so I looked it up at dictionary.com and found http://dictionary.reference.com/search?db=dictionary&q=sagacious. For the definition they give the example of "a sagacious lawyer". And let a lawyer be a person that has a license to practice law and who walks frantically through the courtroom as he tries to sway the jury. To add some drama: he's defending Osama bin Laden (can be used as the person element).

story: In Japan, the emperor is a bystander - he stands on his crown but can't really affect the direction of the country. (thx shimouma).
column3: Mr. T is tired of being a bystander, he stands up and takes the king's crown for himself to change the direction of the country.
column4: Mr. T is in the street, standing up, wearing an golden crown and a compass in his hand... he's asking the bystander if they know how to get to Buckingham palace (!)

story: Myself as used by men – a person who prides himself on how big his “eel” is.
column3: "I did it all by myself!" Mr T stands there proud as holding a moray eel in his hand. He's brought down terrorist organisations, drug syndicates, but gets all worked up when catching a fish... what a guy.
column4: Myself as used by men – I myself, am a person who prides himself on how big my “eel” is. "my eel" = "myself" --- kanji for おれ. similar : I 吾 (#17), oneself 自 (#36), ego 我 (#690), private 私 (#968), myself 俺 (#1091).

story: Note: this is the ひさ in ひさしぶり . Long time no see mummy! (A bound up person).
column3: That bound up person is a mummy, he's been that way for a long time.
column4: This is a picture of a person bowing "long time no see!"

story: Using a TOP HAT to make FURROWS in the RICE FIELD takes a LONG TIME!
column3: A mummy tries to furrow his brow but realizes that he's got no head - just a brain with a top-hat on it. So he furrows his brain. [trigger: furrow your brain].
column4: A man from the city, thus wearing a top hat, working in a field, takes a very long time to dig a simple furrow.

story: A person pent in is obviously captured. Imagine a man put inside a wooden box, his evil capturers waiting for ransom money.
column3: Mr. T can't be captured. This kanji is lying.
column4: This is a very easy kanji. A PERSON who is PENT IN is obviously captured. DO NOT USE MR. T! Why people are using this as a primitive element is beyond me. MR. T is the variant of person when it appears on the left side of a kanji. Do not confuse your PERSON and MR. T or you'll never know which one to use when you have a MR. T story. Keep each version of a primitive distinct in your naming. (Think of the difference between using "heart" and "valentine").

story: A seatbelt keeps a person inside the vehicle.
column3: Mr. T's new belt is huge! When he's inside it, his feet no longer touch the ground!
column4: A person who fell through the roof of their house, now their legs are inside.

story: In this third class flight, the seatbelts are so bad that with the slightest turbulence all the persons hit the ceiling. (it's almost pictographic here!)
column3: Travelling by ship third class the cabins are all inside (no windows) and the ceilings are so low you hit your head.
column4: The ceiling inside third class is exceptionally low.

story: This is a "design" as in a "pattern", not a verb as in "to design". The tree grain design was too expensive for the third class airline to use for the panelling. They just painted it.
column3: Makes me think of Ikea. Everything is wooden and the design is really nice but the quality really is third rate.
column4: The third class seats on the train are very simply designed. In fact, they're not designed at all. They're just wooden stumps of trees.

story: Here we are looking at an x-ray of a cannibal whose insides are full on people-meat.
column3: A person's inside - fleshy, raw, pink, meat.
column4: Inside a person is meat.

story: The rotting meat adheres to the cave walls.
column3: Smaller municipalities are well known for filling their budgets with pork (meat). Thats why they are also well known for being rotten.
column4: The municipality workers in their cave are too busy with bueraucracy and adhering to rules so they cannot regulate and measure the huge delivery of meat that was made days ago. So it just lies in the back of the cave to rot as more work piles up.

story: Coal mine (cave); tea break time; the assembly line stops and everyone sit or squat on the dirt floor, in a long line, to rest.
column3: Nice one Gorgon. I thought I would mention that the stroke order is non-standard here. With soil the vertical stroke comes first.
column4: While working on an assembly line in a cave, there no benches on which to sit, so everyone just sits on the ground.

story: I sprained my fingers when I sat in meditation (by sitting in a strange position).
column3: (Using the primitives in the RTK1 addendum) The workers at the assembly line in the coal cave (座 (#1100)) frequently claim to "sprain" their fingers because working within all the dirt around them is hard and they'd much rather stay at home.
column4: With your fingers you try to repair an assembly line that got broken after some soil/dirt got into it. But then the assembly line suddenly starts working. It spurts soil everywhere, and its movement also sprains your poor fingers.

story: Ph.D graduation for assembly line of doctors(needles) with the cap and tassel(top hat). It took them 10 years (Bachelor's, Masters, PhD) to get there.... :-p.
column3: When you graduate, you wear a hat and graduate in an assembly line while your parents sit on pins and needles because it will take ten years to pay off those loans.
column4: In the distant future, universities will produce graduates on assembly lines. As the kids move along on a conveyor belt they are injected with knowledge via a needle from below while overhead robotic arms place square caps with tassels on their heads. This way it only takes a few minutes to graduate.

story: There are two assembly lines at the umbrella factory. One is responsible for making the top of the umbrella, and the other for making the handle. The two lines cross at the end, where one man tries frantically to jam the sets of parts together.
column3: FOUR PERSONS can fit under this UMBRELLA if they are thin as a NEEDLE.
column4: A pictograph: 4 people sheltering under one big umbrella.

story: "Dude! What happened to your arm! It's all bound up!" "Yeah man, it's a bummer... with my arm like this I can only lift one monme!"
column3: In Jamaica: Hey mon, may I have some (3.75 grams to be exact) uh dat leaf? I need it fo medical reasons. Look at my bound up arm!
column4: "Dude! What happened to your arm! It's all bound up!" "Yeah man, it's a bummer... with my arm like this I can only lift one monme!" "You'll never be able to use your dagger now!" (adapted from ergerg).

story: A man earns his living by means of the plow. I imagine a sweating man dragging a bronze-age "ard" behind him as he plows his field himself, too poor to afford an ox.
column3: By means of a plow and a sweat drop on his brow, a person earns his living.
column4: By means of the plow, with sweat on his brow, a man earns his chow.

story: A PERSON can become quite SIMILAR to someone else BY MEANS OF plastic surgery.
column3: A Mr T impersonator is becoming similarer (more like) by means of plastic surgery. The process is painful and his face is all bound up in bandages as the surgery heals.
column4: You can become similar to Mr. T by means of a sweaty plough (your skin will get darker and your body will get more muscular).

story: Mr. T furiously works a puzzle in an attempt to join Mensa, the high-IQ society.
column3: "Why do I gotta join these two puzzle pieces? I ain't got time for joining no jigsaw-jabba!" Mr. T apparently gets a severe case of crankypants when doing puzzles.
column4: Mr. T is doing a puzzle. "Just join the pieces , foo!"

story: Horror scene: Hanging from the ceiling, a plough and fishhook dripping with blood down onto the tiled bathroom floor.
column3: [true stroke order] First draw T for Tile, which then becomes I. Then draw an 'L' fish hook with a dash in the middle to make a mediocre 'e' that few can see.//ガ wa3 와 (wa).
column4: Note: This tile means roof-tile (e.g. 屋根瓦 ), not the ones you put on the floor. Hanging from the ceiling of an old shed are a rusty plow and some tangled up fishhooks. Since the tiles on the roof are old and broken some rainwater is leeking through and you can see drops glistening between the plow and the fishhooks.

story: A flower pot that has been dropped on the floor is like a puzzle of ceramic tiles to glue together.
column3: To solve this puzzle all you need is to put the flower pot on top of the proper tile. (cue secrets tune from Zelda).
column4: Imagine a mosaic like flower pot made from puzzle-like pieces of tile.

story: A friend of mine made up a rhyme for this one: "house with a spine, Shinto shrine"!
column3: The house that serves as the backbone of Japanese religion is the Shinto shrine.
column4: This Shinto shrine is built with human spines. Have you ever seen the ossuary in Sedlec, near Kutna Hora in Czech Republic ? It is a small church entirely decorated with human bones. Do a web search for "sedlec ossuary", it's quite a sight.

story: The schoolhouse is the backbone of a foundation that will allow you to find a good occupation.
column3: During the German occupation, this Nazi officer's occupation was to manage schools that were requisitioned for training the children of the Aryan race to stand proud with an erect spine (mnemonic : "the occupation's spine schools"). Kanji meanings : to manage, to conduct (business), and also "barracks; camp; encapment". This story should help avoid confusion with 職 (#887) and 雇 (#1164). The military occupation theme hints to the secondary meaning, e.g. 営倉 "detention barracks".
column4: Stay in school so you can get an occupation that doesnt require breaking your backbone all day.

story: Imagine a priest's teaching: "To achieve virtue one must first submit himself as a sheep to God's flock, rejecting the horns of Satan and resisting the mouth of Hell.
column3: To be virtuous, a good rule to follow is to put your sheepishness (discretion) over your horns (anger) before using your mouth. In other words, "discretion is the better part of virtue".
column4: Sheep proves to be virtuous by bringing food to its hungry baby, the two little horns and open mouth that are waiting under it for food.

story: The virtuous vegan will not touch this dining tray because it has had a piece of meat on it.
column3: Some people insist that the serving maids who bring in the dining trays are especially virtuous and never let any man touch their flesh.
column4: As VIRTUOUS cannibals, we serve FLESH on DINING TRAYS.

story: A horse wears a pair of sunglasses with one lens popped out after a particularly raucous celebration to ring in the New Year.
column3: A horse wears a monocle for New Years to appear dignified for the year of the horse. ――one lens = monocle, you will encounter this again in kanji like 降 (#1405).
column4: NOTE: 舛 is actually a radical meaning dancing legs. Can't you see the legs twisted about a pole perhaps? I am uncertain why Heisig chose sunglasses. Consider the last dance that a horse performs in a year for some festival. What do you mean, "horses don't dance"? http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zKQgTiqhPbw.

story: Actually, the lower-right primitive isn't quite "walking legs." It's a little more like "evening" with an extra stroke across it (look up the stroke order). So, it helps me to see this kanji for night as: evening plus an extra stroke representing the tuxedo tails to match the top hat which my special person is wearing out on the town...
column3: Here we have Mister T sleepwalking, wearing a top hat as if he was the ambassador of the night, walking, and walking and walking on his tired walking legs, until he drops (back into his bed).
column4: An elegant vampire. Going out in his night suit with a top hat, the creature looks like a person with long walking legs. The drop is the blood that the vampire seeks.

story: A wet dream........water fluid that comes out at night....
column3: I imagined some kind of liquid (water) that was discovered on another planet. It solidifes during the day, and becomes fluid only at night, in the absence of light. The question is, could any lifeforms thrive in there ?
column4: Try not to drink too many FLUIDS like WATER at NIGHT or you'll have to get up to pee.

story: There's already King of the Hill. This is Queen of the Hillock. It's Ms. Piggy sitting on top of a mound of soil in her crown.
column3: The crowned sow (we met her in overpowering) is standing atop her little mound of earth - hillock - the undisputed champeen of all the pigsty.
column4: Napoleon the Pig (from Orwell's Animal Farm) crowns himself king of the farm standing on a little mound (hillock) of earth.

story: A counterfeiter is using a shredder to shred a towel in order to print up some cash (he needs some rag paper) .
column3: In order to create some cash, first you feed a towel through a shredder to get the raw materials. ("Paper" money isn't plain paper; it's mostly linen.)
column4: (The shredder isn't a mechanical shredder but a little animal kept in servitude by the taskmaster. The little critter has a little belt around its neck which the taskmaster yanks when he has a document to shred).

story: You cover over the shredder with flowers when the FBI comes a-knockin'.
column3: Shredder is writing a anonymous ransom note to the police. "Bring me one billion dollars or I'll destroy your city with my Foot Soldiers! Signed, Shredder." ...oops! This was supposed to be anonymous, but he signed his own name! He can't re-write it now, he spent all that time doing the letter in beautiful calligraphy. What to do? ...Thinking fast, Shredder grabs a large daisy and some tape, and covers over his name, leaving only the "-er." Good thinking, Shredder!
column4: See why the FLOWERS keep on falling into the SHREDDER? You keep on forgetting to put the COVER OVER it. After you finished with it dont forget to put the COVER over it so that the FLOWERS wont fall into it again.

story: Shoving someone's hands into a shredder surely counts as abuse.
column3: You’ve heard of Edward Scissor hands? Well this is Medward Shredder Hands. Instead of nicely trimming your shrubs, he uses his TWO SHREDDER equipped HANDS to ABUSE your plants by shredding them into wood chips.
column4: Mafioso abusing someone to get information. They use a shredder on both of his hands.

story: Think yelp when you hear yell to help dinstinguish this from shout (1508). I think of the sounds that would come from the mouths of the 4 dogs if they were bound up together. I'm imagining lots of yelping.
column3: The musher yells at the 4 dogs bound up to the dog sled to get them to run faster and cross the finish line first. (4 St Bernards bound up together makes a dog sled).
column4: Note: 奐 means "clear; bright." The keyword 明 (#20) is already used. However, among all the 3000 Kanjis presented by Heisig, the keyword clear alone is not used, so you might want to use it to refer to this radical. Story: Although I could not hear them, seeing their mouthes, it was clear to me that they are yelling.

story: After months of practice, you finally managed to teach a nice trick to your sled-pulling four bound up St. Bernard dogs: one snap of your fingers and they interchange their positions.
column3: On the snap of your fingers, the four St. Bernard dogs bound up interchange places.
column4: Note: 奐 means "clear; bright." The keyword 明 (#20) is already used. However, among all the 3000 Kanjis presented by Heisig, the keyword clear alone is not used, so you might want to use it to refer to this radical. Story: With their fast finger movement, it was not clear that any interchange was taking place.

story: I have created the element "old camera" out of the left side of the kanji: from the subject's point of view, the light is captured by one mouth (the lens). The photographer is under a big hood, we only see his legs, and he is holding a spike in his right hand, which is the shutter release. Now, at the time the photographer takes the photo, a little insect is flying near the flash. The flash is so powerful that the insect is burnt and dissolves in the air.
column3: I've seen this crazy thing with only one mouth that can dissolve up to 4 nails and an insect at the same time. Sweet! (It's a venus flytrap, btw).
column4: Just one single mouthful of cola has enough acidic power to dissolve 4 nails and one large live insect! Gross! (Not actually true, but meh...)

story: Under their banner, volunteers are requesting alms for scorpion sting victims.
column3: "ALMS for the poor" cries the beggar under his tattered BANNER. An evil bastard instead drops a SCORPION into his begging bowl.
column4: (Note: This kanji also has the meanings "apply bandages/administer first-aid"). With that sense, you see some poor man who has been stung by a scorpion, so you extract the blood and make bandages out of your banner to administer first-aid to him. The you take the man to an hospital and give him alms to pay for the cure.

story: A merry-go-round with a big banner on top and below a veritable zoo of bakelite animals on poles in perpertual rotation accompanied by silly music. Giraffes, elephants, zebras, rhinos...
column3: Don't confuse with revolve or axis! Think of rotation as a rotation of animals in the zoo - some are on display (in rotation), some are in cages in the back (out of rotation). The ones currently in rotation (on display) are advertised with a large banner.
