column4: I had trouble remember this with previous zoo-banner-rotation stories, so here is something a bit more vivid: The future of ZOO technology: There is a giant Ferris Wheel-type contraption with individual plastic cages, each with an animal that ROTATES every 10 minutes. It's built half-way into the ground, can you envision it? The lazy people who watch wouldn't know what animal was what without the colorful BANNERS that accompany each cage.

story: The BANNER warns that CHILDREN PLAY on the ROAD.
column3: There is always a stupid banner talking about children at play near the road. They mean "drive slowly", but it sounds like its slow(stupid) children that are at play.
column4: No matter how many times we told them these CHILDREN keep PLAYing in the middle of the road, so we put up a new BANNER: "RUN EM DOWN", that scared the hell out of them... what? why are you looking at me like that?

story: The boat starts to leave on it's trip across the Atlantic. Underneath a huge banner that spans the width of the ship and says "Bon Voyage", the people wave their rags signalling a safe journey for all on board the Titanic.
column3: After a long long trip, what once was a proud beautiful banner, we had nothing more than a simple rag remaining.
column4: When taking a trip, people wave goodbye with banners and rags.

story: This kanji is NOT a piglett.
column3: The butcher is standing over the piglet. "This is a piglet...(cuts of head)...NOT!"
column4: Three strings walk into a bar. The bartender throws them out, yelling "Can't you read the sign?! I don't serve strings." The strings try again, and again the bartender kicks them out. Finally, one of the strings gets the idea to mess himself up a little. He walks into the bar. The bartender scowls, "What's wrong with you? Can't you read? I don't serve strings!" The string replies, "I'm a frayed knot!"

story: A cow is not a thing. Its an animal. If you study japanese you know that living beings and things are discerned from each other with the verbs iru and aru.
column3: The cow's "thing" is tied in a knot! ouch.
column4: A cow does not have a "thing"! (Cows are female).

story: The sun is not an easy place to get to.
column3: Under the sun, it is easy to untie a knot. Under a pitch-dark sky, it is knot so easy.
column4: If you take the ceiling off your piggy bank, you'll have easy money!

story: A grant is easy money.
column3: Do you want free shells from the government? It's easy with my new book, "How to Get a Free Grant from the Government!" Call today!
column4: This grant is shells (money) that were awarded to you, or that someone "deigned to give" to you (another kanji meaning). Regardless, they are "easy shells" because you won't have to return them, and you didn't have to work for them! -- "grant is easy shells".

story: Animals use their urine to mark their territory. So for them, their body water works as a flag denoting their "country" (why bother? we all know which story you are going to pick).
column3: The flag primitive looks like a big "P". And, let's face it, urine is just pee water. So, "Urine = P Water". Yes, it's stupid, but I don't think I'm gonna forget it now, haha. (I renamed the flag primitive "pee", it makes for unforgettable stories).
column4: Urine is water that flags your territory.

story: Red cross nuns sit in a tent under the red cross flag, spooning out food to the hungry.
column3: A nun sits in protests under an American flag.
column4: Nun in protest under the US flag. she has a megaphone and a big spoon. 'stop shooting, start feeding'. an anti war protest.

story: The baseball team stick flags in their buttocks and wave them at the opposing team to put them off.
column3: Simple image: a streaker running across a baseball field, bare-ass naked, holding a flag with two hands above his head. See him get tackled by the security guards...
column4: In the locker room, the BASEBALL PLAYERS snap each other in the buttocks with FLAGS.

story: TV gets weirder and weirder... Now they're doing mud wrestling shows with nuns splashing around in the water. What will they think of next?
column3: My catholic church was suffering from serious attendance problems and was in danger of closing down. Then they replaced the homily with nuns mud wrestling in mud made from holy water. Now mass costs $20 admission and it's sold out every night. Praise the lord!!!
column4: Water monks live in a den, but water nuns live in the MUD.

story: [fence; wall; (kokuji)] A fence separates one soil from the other. On a large scale, large pieces of soils in the world have a virtual fence called nation. Picture a world map where all countries have their soil with one color, their national flag as the legend and a fence on the borders... don't you think it looks like a giant puzzle?
column3: The Earth is fenced off with flags indicating different countries, forming a complex puzzle of lands. (thanks samuize).
column4: An Ikea fence: you want to seperate your soil from your neighbor's, so you go buy an Ikea fence. You start putting it together and it's like a puzzle, with little flags on top of each post.

story: NOTE: The most common use is in はく, meaning to put on footgear, rather than actual footgear itself. STORY: You are asleep in camp when you are woken up with news that the FLAG has fallen to the enemy. You quickly PUT ON YOUR FOOTGEAR and run off to RESTORE the FLAG.
column3: You should never use a flag as a shoeshine cloth to restore your footgear.
column4: The flag has fallen! To win the flag must be restored. Whomever has to run up on the hill to restore the flag needs good footgear.

story: Flag at the climax (highest point) of a castle roof.
column3: A couple climaxing on the roof, draped in the American flag. The neighbors are mortified and call the landlady...
column4: See 室 (#816). Room is roof + walls + soil (floor). Here roof is marked by flag to indicate what is being singled out in this kanji.

story: Fingers gripping the roof as your about to fall to your death. Think of an action scene in some movie.
column3: During a game of 'Capture the Flag': at the climax of the game the red team moves forward, gripping the flag tighly in their fingers.
column4: Want to improve your grip? Try hanging from the roof by your fingers. Guaranteed to work.

story: When yielding, soldiers raise the white flag before exiting from the trenches.
column3: If you live in Japan, you are only too familiar with the helpful little man who assists you in getting out of every parking lot or parking garage, standing at the exit, waving his flag to make traffic yield to you.
column4: When you YIELD in a battle, you raise the FLAG of surrender then EXIT the battlefield.

story: If you dig with your fingers hard enough, soil eventually yields.
column3: When you dig, you'd better hope that whatever you're digging into yields to your fingers. If not, you're bound to lose some nails.
column4: When you yield in battle, the enemy will often take you prisoner to execute you. While you are waiting, try to use your fingers to dig a tunnel out of their prison!

story: (See 掘 (#1141)). When soil finally yielded thanks to your digging efforts, what you have is a ditch.
column3: Ditch / trench. The yielding army abandons it's patch of soil, leaving behind a landscape of ditchs and trenches. Trench warfare.
column4: Trench warfare in WWI: both sides dug ditches in the soil, and refused to yield to the other side. This went on for so long, everyone ran out of ammo. The only option left was to lob soil at the enemy, demanding they yield.

story: A humongous American flag in Florida marks the place where all the old people reside.
column3: It is an old tradition that people plant a flag on places where decide to reside; this tradition still goes on: Antarctica, the moon: flags all over the place! cf. 据 (#1144).
column4: The old war veteran resides here. You can tell because hes always proudly flying the flag which he fought for.

story: The man set his finger firmly on the map and said "Here is where they reside, I am certain of it".
column3: Cf. 居 (#1063): you set the flag with your fingers on the place where you reside: an old tradition.
column4: (mod. to include "lay foundation" meaning of kanji) The man set his finger firmly on the map and said "This is were we shall reside. Let's lay the foundation of our new life here and leave our old lives behind."

story: Something is residing in the hem of your cloak. Maybe you should consider cleaning it? キョ コ すそ cuff; hem; foot of mountain.
column3: "AHEM! Young lady, you'll have to let down the HEMlines of those CLOAKs if you want to RESIDE in this dormitory. We are prudes here!"
column4: The hem of a cloak is the best place for your secret items to reside.

story: Formerly, in Japan, each social stratum had to wear specific types of clothes to flag their social class and caste. Of course, these days Japanese society isn't so regimented anymore.
column3: The study the different layers of the stratum, marking each layer with a little flag, to learn more about how the earth formerly was.
column4: The flag of a formerly mighty empire, now lies buried beneath the stratum.

story: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has email scanners that flag certain phrases.
column3: They do nothing at the bureau other than repeating the stupid catchphrase they have on their flag.
column4: This is a Tourist Information Bureau. It has lots of national flags signs to indicate which languages are spoken/available and it stocks many phrasebooks.

story: A sheep crossing guard waves a SLOW flag for his fellow sheep crossing the road.
column3: Road sign (flag): "Sheep on highway! Drive slowly."
column4: The traffic controller raises a flag that says SLOW while the sheep cross the road. (don't confuse with 屈 (#1060)).

story: WATER always LEAKED in the spot left by the FLAG planted in the roof everytime it RAINED. Not too hard to picture a hole left in the ceiling from a flag, now leaking water.
column3: Mark the holes where rain water can leak through with little flags.
column4: water leaked through the flag hole every time it rained.

story: We printed a japanese flag on his white towel by stabbing him with a saber while he was wearing it.
column3: The image that keeps coming to me is of the giant mechanical printing presses. The cloth-based material is coming off the roll like a flag and then, after printing, gets cut into sheets by saber-like cutting tools.
column4: Modern laser printers can print on flags and towels with saber-like precision.

story: Slang for blowjob and that's priceless for stories...but also the character looks like the letter R which I think of as standing for RULER (12 inches) other meanings include: rule, measure, length.
column3: Shaku is a unit of length equal to about 12 inches (just like a Ruler), used in ancient Japan. See also 寸 (#45). The shakuhachi is a flute about 20 inches long, which is supposed to be one shaku and eight suns, suns being about one inch long. The primitive meaning for this character will be playing the shakuhachi, meaning blowjob. (thanks all).
column4: This character by itself is NOT a slang term for blowjob. The term people are thinking of is 尺八を吹く and the like - so the flute itself becomes a metaphor. Just FYI. That being said..... BROWJOB!!!!! (props crystalcastlecreature).

story: A women is so exhausted by her "shakuhachi" that she needs to ice her jaw.
column3: This old Japanese man totally exhausted himself giving a winter-time performance of shakuhachi. That winter was so cold, the shakuhachi was getting clogged with ice as the man was playing. Mnemonic: "exhausted after playing ice-clogged shakuhachi". Meanings: to exhaust; to be exhausted; to use up completely; to use (exhaust) all one's strength (in the performance of one's duties).
column4: You can imagine how exhausting it would be to play a shakuhachi filled with ice. It would exhaust your supply of breath (and probably patience).

story: You're hiding from the enemy underwater in a swamp. To breathe, you have your shakuhachi flute poking up through the surface of the water.
column3: Sirens in the swamp play eerie music on their shakuhachi flutes to lure you in - you follow the enchanting music then its too late as you get trapped in the swamp!
column4: Different from 沼 (#145) in that swamp has trees. The trees are represented by shakuhachi flutes here, mystically calling the water in like Pied Piper did to rats.

story: You cannot pretend to translate into words the melody of the shakuhachi!
column3: Imagine some weird guy who only communicates via shakuhachi, so he always brings along a translator to translate his shakuhachi sounds into words. "Excuse me, do you know where the library is?" "♫♪♫♫♪♫♪." "It's just down the street on the left."
column4: Words R us- translating company.

story: Depending on where you choose to put your fingers, the shakuhachi will produce a different note.
column3: The fingers on the Shakuhachi "choose" the notes.
column4: Lisa is playing a shakuhachi. Ralph points at her saying "I choo-choo-choose you!" and accidentally gets his finger stuck in one of its holes.

story: Roosters in Japan are very civilised, they play the shakuhachi at nightbreak to signify the beginning of daytime.
column3: In a Zelda game, you can warp to the daytime if you play your shakuhachi to bring about nightbreak... or your ocarina if you don't have a shakuhachi.
column4: You have to pratice your shakuhachi during the daytime because after nightbreak the neighbours will complain about the noise.

story: Traditional Japanese storefront doors have several flags, known as "noren," hanging down from a curtain rod in front of them. I see this as a pseudo-pictograph, and use the horizontal line across the top to represent the curtain rod, since noren don't usually hang from the ceiling.
column3: A Japanese door has a noren, a flag hanging from a rod. (I give this primitive the meaning of a noren-covered door).
column4: Their is only ONE FLAG on DOORs in Japan. The Japanese FLAG of course!

story: The shoulder is the best part of the body to bash a door open with (Don't ever try this. Use your foot).
column3: The shoulder is part of the body you use to push through the noren in a doorway. I was having trouble with positioning of the primitives until I tweaked shaydwyrm's story slightly. If you think of pushing through a noren, this makes sense as a pictograph. The noren hangs from above, and you push through it from below.
column4: A part of the body I always seem to bump against the door.

story: Explanation: https://web.archive.org/web/20170613125616/https://forum.koohii.com/post-14540.html#pid14540 A TASSEL (房 (#1078) ) is placed at each corner of a sort of "shinto temple" style of roof placed over every sumo ring, pointing at a fixed direction (方 (#490)). 白房 (しろぶさ:white TASSEL) southwest 黒房 (くろぶさ:black TASSEL) northwest 赤房 (あかぶさ:red TASSEL) southeast 青房 (あおぶさ:green TASSEL) northeast You enter a sumo stadium through the door (戸 (#1076)) and see the 4 房 over the ring.
column3: A tassel hangs from my door showing the breeze's direction.
column4: When you walk in the DOOR to the sumo stadium you will see the 4 TASSELS pointing in 4 DIRECTIONS These TASSELS are always placed in the same order: 白房 (しろぶさ) : southwest corner 黒房 (くろぶさ) : northwest corner 赤房 (あかぶさ) : southeast corner 青房 (あおぶさ) : northeast corner (Thanks transtic).

story: It's insanely hot today! I'm standing in the doorway, fanning myself with feathers.
column3: Home Alone, when the bad guy opens the door, it triggers the fan to blow feathers into his face.
column4: Bird flies through door, hits the fan, feathers.

story: This hearth is equipped with a fire-proof door. On the kanji you can see somewhat pictographically the fire-proof door keeping the fire behind, and nothing comes under the door primitive, where you would have expected to see another primitive.
column3: -"Honey? Do we have any wood left for the hearth?" -"Aagh, just use the frickin' door!"
column4: Hearth is a fireplace, meaning a fire-door in the wall.

story: The St. Bernard dog whining at the door of his master’s house in order to re-enter / re-turn inside.
column3: This is common with cats, but also happens with dogs. They go out the door. 5 minutes later they change their minds and come back in. They re-go out the door. They re-come back in. They re-go out the door. They re-come back in. They re-go out the door. They re-come back in. They re-go out the door. They re-come back in. They re-go out the door. They re-come back in. They re-go out the door. They re-come back in. They re-go out the door. AAAAAARRRRRGGGHHHH!!!
column4: Think about hachiko, the dog waiting at the door of the station, waiting for his master to re-turn.

story: I see the story of Hachiko: the faithfull dog who still waited for his master to return long after he had died. Brings a tear to the eye.
column3: Tears are watery (water + re).
column4: The master shed tears of joy when his lost dog returned to his doorstep. (See 戻 (#1162)).

story: Our company has no standards. We'll employ any turkey who walks in the door.
column3: "Sorry," says a store manager, "We don't employ Turkeys here." He then points to the door. The disappointed turkey hangs his head low and walks out.
column4: Comedy. An executive is having an argument with a cocky, but skilled, employee: "Damn it, you might be good. But that don't account for your behavior. You keep this up and I'll fire your ass." "No, you won't." "What damn it, I'll fire you your ass so fast you won't...know..."-. "And what will you do after you fire me, employ the next turkey that walks through that door?" A turkey then walks through the door and hands the Exec his resume. --"The Exec employs the turkey that walked through the door".

story: I was EMPLOYED to give HEAD...when I look back, maybe that was not a wise career move.
column3: The people we employ are always turning their heads to look back. They don't want to be caught playing solitare on company time.
column4: It's sad to see the turkeys look back one last time before entering the door of the slaughterhouse and losing their heads.

story: Behind closed DOORS, the TASKMASTER tortures to get prisoners to open their MOUTHS and DISCLOSE information.
column3: You signed a non-disclosure agreement with the taskmaster but you opened your mouth as soon as you got out the door!
column4: It's best not to disclose what you were forced to do with your mouth behind closed doors for your taskmaster.

story: A boy made an altar, but he's afraid to show it to God because he thinks it's two little.
column3: Unrelated: Frankly, I found Chapter 30 BORING. (I guess I was spoiled with Mr. T.) To jazz up the excitement, this ENTIRE chapter is all about one very crazy religion that exists today (in your imagination). What are the specifics? That's for you to find out. The clues? The next 39 kanji. Just look at some of the keywords: Altar, oil, sleeve, collar, speakth, naked!!! Be sure to give altar it's own meaning inside the cult you're creating.
column4: I give this form a primitive of EVIL ALTAR. Imagine a black stone altar used for satanic rituals. I give the left radical form a primitive of CHURCH ALTAR. Imagine a beautiful cathedral altar.

story: "Indy, my friend, you must be very careful! If you approach the altar and do not give the proper salutation a large fishhook will rip you away".
column3: You should fish hook (bend/bow) your body before an altar as a form of salutation to God/gods.
column4: SALUTATION (a hand salute in this case) was given to the ALTAR by a veteran with a HOOK for his hand. Just keep that mental picture and you own this kanji.

story: Bringing a sheep to sacrifice on the altar was a sign of an auspicious life. The poor could only afford a pigeon, the more auspicious an expensive sheep for an offering.
column3: On this ewe-spicious occasion, you sacrifice a sheep at the altar. —— Sorry, but I really need more than generic altar sacrifices to connect keywords to stories. Sometimes an egregious pun is the only way.
column4: Once a year, the people pray for a sign from the gods. If the gods are pleased, they send down a sheep to the altar. The people see this as an auspicious gift; the wool and milk from this sheep is considered holy. But the gods think of it as a witty joke, since it's just a metaphor for the people following ancient rituals like blind sheep. Continued in 禍 (#1386).

story: When Japanese people turn 20 they usually visit the altar at their local shrine and celebrate no longer being a teenager.
column3: It's a Bar Mitzvah. At the altar, the teenager is singing in his awful, mid-puberty voice. We'll all celebrate when that part is over!
column4: Coming of Age Day (成人の日, seijin no hi) is a Japanese holiday held annually on the second Monday of January to celebrate those who have turned 20 years old. In this kanji we see someone going to the altar to celebrate no longer being a teenager.

story: This recalls the selling of indulgences in the history of the Church (As an aside, Protestantism began as a protest of this practice). Basically, one gave wealth to the altar (i.e. priest) and received a blessing. If you prefer a Jewish version, think of the donation (wealth) that is expected when you're called to the ark (altar in the kanji) to give a blessing over the torah.
column3: Put all your wealth on the church altar and receive one blessing. (You stand up out of your wheelchair or something.)
column4: Wow, this is Scientology put into a kanji. In the Scientology faith the wealthiest members have the highest status in the Church. So basically, the wealthiest person that puts the most money on the alter receives the most blessings....(not really, from what I've heard, the more money you give the better parking spot you get....)

story: And in front of every altar, she stopped to pray for the welfare of the others.
column3: Religious Republicans regularly go to the altar to pray for a stop to welfare.
column4: I pray at the altar everyday that they don't stop my welfare checks. (A quick mnemonic is better for this one).

story: When you enter a Japanese company it's like you join a cult... your workdesk becomes your altar and you worship the very soil the office is built on.
column3: The Japanese treat their company like a shrine and the company treat them like dirt.
column4: If a company is built on land near the altar, it is believed that it will become successful.

story: The beaurocracy in Japan is such that even altars need to be inspection approved. A little man with glasses comes once a year to give the altar a "visual once over" as he calls it (perhaps checking for unauthorised symbology?)
column3: [inspection; regard as; see; look at] Inspection: you 示 示 (#1167) and someone else 見 見 (#61).
column4: (Thanks to Ricardo) There's an inspection in the church. You show the altar, and the inspector sees if it's okay or not.

story: It's beautiful place, but the dark side of Nara is that they sacrifice St. Bernards on evil altars every night after the tourists leave!
column3: Nara is just a big show for tourists.
column4: There is a BIG ALTAR in NARA. (really! :-) ).

story: Of course it had to be the military officer's idea to glue a national flag to the altar he's stationed at.
column3: Perhaps you have heard about Koizumis controversial visits at the Yasukuni war memorial shrine. It is the japanese flag waving above a small stone altar. A military officer keeps watch here night and day, to honor the dead war heroes, as if he is glued to the ground.
column4: Only way I remember this is think of a MILITARY OFFICER standing next to a FLAG draped ALTAR (well, the coffin is by the altar) as if GLUED to it. Might hurt if you think that GLUED primitive looks like the MILITARY OFFICER is saluting the FLAG draped ALTAR, with a slight tear coming from the eye.

story: A military officer must offer consolation to the hearts of the families of his fallen men.
column3: This Kanji appears in the word 慰安婦 いあんふ, which was what the infamous WW II "comfort women" were called in Japanese. The story goes something like this: As a way of providing consolation to battle-weary, heartsick military officers and soldiers, the Japanese set up comfort stations (brothels) for their servicemen. (Just to be clear: this is not an endorsement of the practice, just a way to remember the Kanji.)
column4: The MILITARY OFFICER is given a Purple HEART by the army as consolation for the wounds he received in the line of duty.

story: Samuari, altar, yawn The samurai is on the altar, preaching about goodwill. The audience just yawns however, they want to see the man fight!
column3: A samurai's show of goodwill is never lacking.
column4: For better remembering the placement of the eleements: The samurai kneels before the altar at his wedding ceremony, when some of the attendants lets out a big yawn. He is a kind man and for the day his goodwill benefits everyone. No beheadings.

story: Similar to radical tyro's story. If you live in Japan, your main exposure to this kanji is probably "no smoking" signs. So I imagine the government enacting a prohibition of tobacco, and burning whole groves of tobacco plants on an altar (the altar of public health, or self-righteousness, if you will).
column3: Placing trees on this alter is prohibited.
column4: Hidden in a grove was a church with a secret altar that was stocked full of prohibited alcohol during the American prohibition period of 1920-1933. A local registered himself as a mininster of this altar so he could stock prohibited alcohol "for sacremental purposes" and share it with his kin (きん).

story: A collar is the part of your cloak that, if tightened too tight, will prohibit breathing.
column3: Collars are prohibited from wizarding cloaks. Blood purists say they're too muggle.
column4: Dress code: all cloaks without collars are prohibited.

story: I never really did figure out what religion my host family was - all I knew was that they kept an altar in their home.
column3: All the RELIGIONS have their own temples, which are houses where they place their altars.
column4: You can discover a japanese family religion by observing their house altar.

story: In ancient Greece, it was the religion of the time to adore the gods who live on Mount Olympus.
column3: Several kanji become their 'greater' version when you add 山 on top (風 becomes 嵐, 石 becomes 岩). Thus, religion becomes adoration.
column4: The annoying woman from Los Angeles says "oh I absolutely adore those cute little mountain religions, like tibetan buddhism, they shave their cute little heads and wear those bright pretty robes, so adorable."

story: A ritual such as a circumcision: a small piece of flesh from the crotch is left on the altar.
column3: There are many famous penis matsuris(festivals) in Japan. The rituals of these festivals involve placing the flesh of the crotch on an altar.
column4: まつり（祭り）Ritual nude dances (nothing but flesh) involving lots of pelvic thrusts before the altars of ancient Japan. Now they're nothing but festivals, but back in the day they were rituals. Most Japanese festivals have a circle dance, just imagine all the old people doing the except same dance but in the buff, wrinkly flesh flapping in the wind and all. Remembered. Unfortunately, perhaps forever.

story: I have an informed guess about whose house the dark rituals are performet at.
column3: Police (警察）drive around a street at night trying to guess whose house is having a matsuri indoors after complaints from the neighbours.
column4: The POLICE had enough evidence, so they were able to make an informed GUESS as to which HOUSE the dark RITUALS were being performed in.

story: If you mis-guess the cheese you'll grate your fingers on the cheese-grater (happens to me all the time).
column3: Ouch! Guess how many fingers I just grated in the grater? (Edit: OR: Ouch! Guess what I just grated in the grater? -- my finger!)
column4: When you grate something you have to guess where your fingers are so you don't hurt yourself.

story: "Wherefore art thou, Sprouteo?" (Juliet has fallen in love with a brussel sprout) (OR: A brussel sprout has fallen from Juliet's dinner plate and rolled off).
column3: "Cogito ergo sum." Wherefore is a bad choice here for two reasons. For one, it's often mistranslated as "where" when in fact it's an urge to know a cause or reason; and two, because this kanji represents the reason, not the urge. [A thought sprouts from my brain. I think, therefore I am.]
column4: Wherefore do we plant rice seeds in the rice field? For it to sprout and grow-up into rice. Pictograph of the wherefore of rice.

story: If you pluck your fingers, new ones will sprout in their place. (try it ;).
column3: If you pluck hair from your eyebrows with your fingers, more hair will sprout in it's place.
column4: fingers pluck a single sprout.

story: The liquid oil that sprouts from an oil field.
column3: oil is the most valuable liquid to sprout from the earth.
column4: In a rather surprising scientific breakthrough, genetically modified Brussel sprouts (which have become extremely absorbative), are thrown in the water to suck up oil spills.

story: The bad magician says, "As you can see, there's nothing up my sleeves!" Then he trips over his cloak and brussel sprouts fall everywhere.
column3: Sleeves are just what sprouts out of the sides of garments. Duh.
column4: Imagine some magic cloak, that when worn, has little green sprouts appearing on the sides that grow into sleeves.

story: Jack's beanstalk sprouted up, pushed at the roof and lifted the house so that it hangs in mid-air suspended on the SPROUT.
column3: Hahaha, the image of walking into a house and finding a sea of brussel sprouts floating mid-air is enough for me to remember. Maybe there's a magician in the kitchen shouting a reassuring "Don't mind the sprouts!"
column4: This one doesn't help me very much but some of my mates found it helpful: Jack's beanstalk sprouted up, he climbed up it and found a house floating in mid-air.

story: In the US, when the mail is delivered, a flag sprouts up on your mailbox. (We don't have that in Australia.)
column3: *** Warning: Don't use a mailbox in this story, there's a primitive for that coming soon... ***.
column4: A Japanese man ordered some Brussel sprouts from Belgium. They are delivered with a little Belgian flag (as seen sometimes in shops, little flags indicating the provenance and authenticity of the food like cheese and meat).

story: Flute is made of bamboo sprout.
column3: You pick up your bamboo flute, and recoil in shock as out comes not the dulcet melody you had hoped to play, but rather a Brussels sprout! You play again, and again a Brussels sprout. A bamboo flute that plays sprouts! Fabulous! Puts that golden egg laying goose in its place.
column4: Bamboo shoots... make good flutes.

story: An absurd image, but what the heck - worked for me. Imagine a car going across a plain at a fast speed. Suddenly a single sprout (the only one to be seen) gets stuck to the car's wheels, causing the car to fly around its axis.
column3: The Germans manufactured so many cars during World War II that it was almost as if they were sprouting from the factories of the Axis.
column4: Left side is the car, right side is a zoomed in picture of the car showing the detail of the axle/axis.

story: Funny.. this appeared to me as a pictograph of a samurai's armor. Then I looked up images of the samurai armor and it is not even remotely similar. Then I realised it looks in fact like the belly of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, which I somehow associated with the samurai armor because of the "turtle samurai" that appeared earlier. Fits me. The bit that pokes down is to protect the genitals, I guess.
column3: It looks like a bird's eye view of a tank (modern armor).
column4: Pictograph. Kendo visor with chin guard.

story: Push the roots down, instead of plucking the seedling.
column3: Use your fingers to make sure the roots of your plant are deep underground by pushing them down, down, down.
column4: Push the button with your finger and get root beer!

story: A headland is a mountain that is firmly rooted despite being surrounded on 3 sides by water. (Just like your head is a mountain surrounded by air on 3 sides, a headland!)
column3: Headlands are natural forts; in fact, once men build castles on them, they become armoured mountains. (Gibralter, for example, is basically an armoured mountain).
column4: Forget confusing the meanings (headland, 崎 (#840), 埼 (#164)) they are synonyms, no way around that. Luckily, all three seem to be used in names most. I used: The headland or head of the land is obviously the part of the land that is placed highest, in the same way our head is highest on the body. Mountains are the heads of the lands they have planted their roots into.

story: A rice farmer's delicate fingers have inserted 1,000 rooted seedlings into his field.
column3: Before you push the button for the ginseng root tea, you must insert 1000 yen.
column4: Fingers, the thief, is trying to get money using my ATM card. After inserting it in the ATM, he tried 1000 times to push the right buttons. And got my pin number right on the last try! Notice the long vertical stroke done last!

story: I imagine thomeone who can not pronounth the "s" and speaketh like thith becauth they have a cane in their mouth.
column3: I had persistent trouble confusing this one with 曰 曰 (#620). The way I keep it sorted out is that this one is used in "moshi moshi" when answering the phone, similar to the way an American would say "hello, this is X speaking."
column4: The cross in the mouth of the Monkey ensured it speaketh no evil.

story: Here we see Mr. T. expanding his gang with some trained fighter monkeys.
column3: Mr. T wants to show you the incredible expanding monkey trick. He grabs a monkey by the tail and neck, stretches him out a few times, then blows him up like a balloon. The monkey EXPANDs until it pops. Haha, sucka monkey, I pity you foo.
column4: A person speaketh and expands my knowledge.

story: Hinduism has many gods, not just one God. One of the most famous of these gods is Hanuman the monkey. Many altars are dedicated to him.
column3: At the alter, you speaketh to the gods.
column4: The Gods are gathered around debating Zeus' latest purchase for Mount Olympus. A huge and extremely kitsch gilded altar in the shape of giant "speak no evil" monkey. Hera decides she will never let him go shopping alone again .

story: The monkey searches around with his fingers for his crotch.
column3: With its fingers, a monkey searches its crotch for bugs to eat.
column4: Heard about the fourth wise monkey? Often overlooked after Hear, See and Speak no Evil, he's Seek no Evil. Picture the four famous monkeys at Nikko, the fourth covering his crotch with his fingers, showing he won't be searching for any evil deeds in that evil place.

story: If only Eve had used her brains and not taken the forbidden fruit from the tree.
column3: There really are brain fruit trees. See http://www.dpchallenge.com/image.php?IMAGE_ID=108312. Enough said.
column4: Just a pictogram of a cluster of fruit on a tree.

story: This candy is made in the shape of a flower, each petal with the taste of a different fruit.
column3: Candy is coloured like flowers and flavoured like fruit.
column4: I think of Willy Wonka's factory where the flowers all bear candy fruits.

story: After I finish each chapter of RTK, I eat a piece of fruit to celebrate all the new words I've learned. (Thanks Misha!)
column3: Words signify the written words in a book. The fruit represents something whole, complete. A chapter in a book often offers a complete idea, setting, or account. It's good to disambiguate the keyword from 項 (#86). To reinforce the kanji, imagine eating a fruit at the end of each chapter of Tolstoy's "War and Peace" to reward yourself. (If you ate a fruit at the end of each paragraph, you'd very quickly run out of fruit).
column4: The first chapter of the Bible are words telling the story of Adam and Eve and how they ate the forbidden fruit.

story: Here we have Adam and Eve eating of the forbidden fruit and realizing they were naked, and so clothing themselves in a cloak.
column3: Hey honey, I'm naked underneath this cloak. I've got some nice melons and a fresh peach waiting for you. Don't you want to taste my forbidden fruits...?
column4: Look at this. (it's perfect) http://www.ewallpapers.eu/view_wallpaper/funny-banana-1024-600-5265.html.

story: The axe-wielding maniac nails a poor victim, right under a cliff. Blood everywhere! (thanks scottamus!)
column3: Errata: stroke order in 4th edition is wrong. Top stroke is first.
column4: Warning: unlike the nail primitive, notice that the axe does not have a hook on the last stroke.

story: We chop down trees with axes to analyze their rings.
column3: Wood + axe = chop? how much more simple can it get?
column4: This more accurately means "take apart" or "analyse", so I guess, once you chop down the tree with an axe, you can analyse its structure.

story: You outsiders better learn your place! An axe stuck in the door when you get home is a pretty good indicator that this might not be the best place for you.
column3: A place for everything and everything in its place. To the right of the door is the standard place for the axe.
column4: When you come over to my place, you leave your axe at the door!

story: A warrior prays for victory before the battle. He kneels at the altar, his battle axe at the ready.
column3: Religious freedom has not always been respected throughout history, and nobody knew how to force religion on an indigenous people like the Spanish missionaries. They posted conquistadors at either side of the altars at the local missions, and if anybody refused to pray, they would get the axe.
column4: When you come to the altar to pray, you need to leave your axe to one side. Biblical quote, settle your differences with someone before coming before your god.

story: The end is near. The axe-murderer is waiting for you on the road...
column3: An absurd image, but working for me: two points A and B are separated by a long road. To make A and B near, take an ax, cut a big chunk of road, and the work is done.
column4: Hint: Short- cut.

story: It's the latest Japanese game show: Forudo! Contestants are given a sheet of paper and are told to fold it into a complex origami shape. If they're not done in 60 seconds, a huge axe descends from the ceiling and chops their work in half. Contestants know to recoil their hands from the falling axe, but some have been so absorbed in folding, they ignore the buzzer and get their fingers chopped off.
column3: Fold some origami into the shape of an axe with your fingers. It's even as sharp, so watch out for paper cuts!
column4: To hold an axe, you need to fold your fingers around the handle.

story: A two-hour lesson of philosophy in high school. All the students, bored to death, are folding sheets of paper into planes, love notes or whatever, while the mouth of the teacher is talking about Platon, Kierkegaard and many other notorious philosophers.
column3: I fold my mouth, therefore I am.
column4: All the philosophy that comes out of my mouth I learned from those Chinese fortune cookies with the folded paper inside. 'Confucius say...', et cetera. Come to think of it, the cookie itself looks like a weirdly folded mouth.

story: One of the dearest of Japan's dearly departed is Sasaki Sadako, who developed Leukemia after the bombing of Hiroshima, and became famous for folding more than a thousand paper cranes, never giving up hope. To this day, people in Hiroshima still fold origami cranes in her memory. For this character, let us imagine a parade in her honor, the entire road lined with folded cranes.
column3: The BIG ONE hits Tokyo. You see a news report of the recently departed victims who died when the roads folded (from the earthquake).
column4: The departed are those who have crossed that fold you cannot see past in the road we all walk.

story: This Japanese couple wrote the vows that they had made to each other onto a piece of paper and then folded it into an origami, and put it somewhere in their appartment. To everybody else it is an origami, but to them it is also a symbol of their vows. -- "the folded words are vows". Note : in this story and a few others I use the image of an origami for the primitive "fold".
column3: A Japanese wedding tradition is to present each other with origami cranes with their vows written on the BOTTOM.
column4: Sadako Sasaki vowed to fold 1000 paper cranes and kept her word. (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sadako_Sasaki).

story: I wanted a convertible so I chopped off the top of my car with an axe.
column3: A "chop shop" is a place where stolen cars are taken, and parts chopped off with an axe, to be sold.
column4: Picture a death-mobile car with rotating axes on the hood that drives by and chops off people's heads. [beheading is another common meaning].

story: Your car has been savagely (see steadily) attacked by an ax. It will be some days before your car is fixed. So you are temporarily without car.
column3: Today is Car Axe Day. The day where you can temporarily (today only) attack cars using an axe without punishment.
column4: [斬 (#1215) ... day] During daylight saving time, we temporarily chop off the day by taking an hour out of it, which we will return back in six months.

story: I imagine firemen working steadily to rescue a man from a crashed car. First, they spray it with water; then, they use an axe to break through the window.
column3: Water + Car + Axe: The steadily rising water was filling the car, but the firefighters took their axe and broke the window, getting me out.
column4: STEADILY, bit by bit, the WATER CHOPs OFF chunks of the hardest stone. (See 斬 (#1215)).

story: [Based on fuaburisu's] A man puts some rice on a fishhook as bait, but catches a fish so strong, he needs to take out his axe and sever the line lest he be dragged into the depths.
column3: When you get the ax at work, use your severance pay to buy fishhooks and rice. At least that way you can eat sushi.
column4: Your manager brings you into his office and offers you three severance packages. You can take the hook (become a fisherman), take the rice (become a farmer), or take the axe (become a lumberjack). Picture the items laid out on his desk like the shopkeepers in Zelda.

story: What is this substance on this clam? I've already broken 2 axes on it! (Good question...質問).
column3: Another keyword that I do not like by Heisig. 質【しつ】 (n,n-suf) quality. Story: Your at a local ax dealer and you have TWO AXES which you are testing for QUALITY by trying to split CLAMS right down the opening. Picture yourself succeeding with one AX and then some weird SUBSTANCE comes out of the shell...eww (I don't like clams).
column4: [seems to mean "substance" in the sense of essential nature or core quality, most common usage might be 質問, shitsumon (inquiry)] a pair of scientists are smashing away at a mysterious shell with axes, pounding it into powder so they can feed it into their analysis machine and discover exactly what substance it's made up of.

story: The kids at school used to reject me.. Made me feel really bad till I brought my axe to school. See the drop of blood on it?
column3: The quality expectations are very high in our axe manufacturing facility. If there's one drop of rust on any axe, it gets rejected.
column4: This axe is a reject from the axe factory : a drop of red paint got onto the handle, which looks like a drop of blood. It freaks out customers, so it doesn't make it to the shops.

story: I strongly reject the accusation implicit in your words.
column3: Words that make you feel rejected.
column4: After murdering those who rejected me with my blood-stained axe, I received a letter containing words of accusation from their families and the police.

story: One can use a simple word play to remember this character - the day that I saw before today was yesterday.
column3: Today I see. Yesterday I saw.
column4: Yester-DAY, all my troubles seemed SAW far away...

story: Pinnochio gets frustrated that every time he utters a word of a lie, his nose grows and he has to get the saw out again.
column3: Her lies are words that cut not like a knife, no not cleanly, but savagely like a saw.
column4: Hint: I think of lies as serrated words for some reason.

story: Mr T.'s favorite magazine is Make. He loves to make things. But he's a purist: he only uses saws, no power tools.
column3: Mr. T can make anything with his trusty saw.
column4: When the A-Team crash lands on a deserted island, Mr. T salvages a saw from the wreckage and says, "I don't know about y'all foos, but I'm gonna make a raft."

story: SNOW isn't all that different from RAIN, except it can be removed with a BROOM because it only forms in freezing temperatures.
column3: Unlike rain, snow can be swept away with a broom.
column4: PRIMITIVE: I like to relate the particle for BROOM also as HARRY POTTER on his BROOM. (stories become really easy for the next 11 kanji especially)... . STORY: During the summer Harry Potter on his broom shows off by turning the rain to snow. RTK2:　セツ　積雪　せきせつ(pilled up snow). ＃＊雪崩　なだれ　Avalanche.

story: This character is about a recording for a music box. The tines of the mechanism are like a metal broom and the little pins on the cylinder are like metal grains of rice.
column3: Historians have discovered an ancient record about Buddhist monastic life recorded in gold plates. Sadly, the only thing the monks did was use their brooms to sweep up rice.
column4: The right part should be a new primitive since it will appear several times (see 緑 (#1471), 剥 (#1227) and 禄 (#2648)) and can easily confused with similar stroke combinations. I suggest videotape, deduced from its Chinese meaning (thx shinclef).

story: Peel off the outside of the broom that sweeps up rice grains to reveal a saber.
column3: A multi-purpose broom! It cleans, it sweeps (rice!), it hits! In fact, peel off the mahogany exterior to uncover a sabre! It slices, it dices, it kills!
column4: Horror movie (on a videotape, see my comment for 録 (#1226), thx shinycled): A murderer peels off his victims with his sabre.

story: The policed inquired into the erotica scandal. They tried to sweep away the evidence, but some of it stuck. (Note: katakana エロ ero in the middle of this kanji is the Japanese word for erotica.)
column3: As a verb this means, this means "to ask; to enquire; to search; to look for; to look into; to investigate;". Imagine the police inquiring in an in-depth investigation. They are interrogating a suspect. But the suspect has a crafty mouth and is very sly. He/she also knows when to keep their mouth shut(glued) at the right moments to avoid self-incrimination. As a final measure, the police torture the suspect by tickling him/her with a broom while they inquire.
column4: You are new in Japan and you inquire about a new job. Lucky for you, there is one. You're now the guy with the broom who sweeps the エロ (ero) "studio" after they're done. "Eww, what's this gluing the broom to the ground...". Time to inquire about a new job :).

story: She was always bound to a broom, her heart pounding in a hurry to finish before she was punished for being slow.
column3: In a hurry to tidy up before guests arrive, you're feverishly sweeping with a bunch of brooms bound together, your heart pounding.
column4: Fantasia: Bound up brooms out of control send Mickey's heart racing--he has to hurry and figure out how to stop them before the magician returns!

story: This whole kanji is a picture of calmness. The wheat has been harvested and even the vultures sit calmly watching the humans sweep and clean-up after the harvest is over. Hearts are peaceful and calm at this time of the year. Even the days are calm without storm.
column3: A Calm day: the vulture is flying above the wheat fields, where there's a a scarecrow made with a broom with an heart painted on the shirt (like oz scarecrow).
column4: The farmer lying in the middle of the wheat field is so calm the vultures think he is dead and keep trying to get at his heart. He just lightly brushes them away with a broom, barely noticing their presence.

story: The parson ENCROACHES on the French maid; driven wild by her little broom, dainty tiara and sinfully short skirt showing her knickers (crotch)!
column3: "I pity da fool who encroaches on me". Mr T. is dressed as a French maid (= broom + crown + crotch), working undercover at a hotel that has a problem with guests misbehaving towards female staff.
column4: Mr T. hits a condom salesman (broom + crown + crotch) over the head with a broom because the dude ENCROACHed Mr. T's privates area during the sale.

story: The French maid draws a bath for her amorous master, but slips and falls in - getting immersed. (thanks to Nukemarine for the French maid image!)
column3: French maid at the hotel is demonstrating how to use the bath: “ ...then fill with water until you are completely immersed, like this...” (immerses herself).
column4: After being hit in the head with the broom, the condom salesman IMMERSED his head in some water.

story: After work, the French maid goes home and lies down with a turtle. Turtle? Well, he's sloooow and always hard... (thanks to Nukemarine and Wakela!)
column3: The French maid I hired cleans my house as slowly as a turtle, but I keep her on, because I love to 'lie down' with her...
column4: After being hit on the head 侵 (#1231), the condom salesman goes back to his house to lie down. He hasn't made a single sale today, so he doesn't have enough money to buy a pillow. He lies down on his pet turtle and cries himself to sleep.

story: In high society, a lady is a woman who never touches a broom or an apron.
column3: The LADY of the house is nothing more than a WOMAN who's a HOUSEWIFE (BROOM and APRON anyone?)
column4: The old fashioned image for the lady of the house: A woman in an apron wielding a broom.

story: Whether I SWEEP something away with my FINGERS or my BROOM, I should always wear my APRON.
column3: Sweep - Learn to sweep properly! Grip the broom with your fingers and be sure to wear your apron.
column4: FINGERS of the HOUSEWIFE (in itself, holding a BROOM, with an APRON) busily SWEEP the floor.

story: Some mothers use a small broom to hit their children when they misbehave.
column3: [hit; right; appropriate; himself] If you're old enough, this is a pictograph of an Atari joystick (which, BTW, got its name from this word/kanji). You can also think of how an Atari joystick is like a small broom with which you can hit and sweep off the enemies from the screen...
column4: Here is a weird carnival game where you hold a broom like a javelin and throw it, trying to hit the center of a very small target. The target is so small, in fact, that if someone does manage to hit it, the operator turns in surprise and says, "Whoa, really?! (本当?!)".

story: I was having mutual difficulties in my relationship. She was always the one wearing the crown and I was the one picking the fruit. In order to fix the problem I checked the glossary for "mutual difficulties" but found nothing. I guess we're going to have to mutually end our relationship.
column3: We had no idea what a crowned fruit was so we mutually checked the glossary. Well, I say mutually, but really I did all the work.
column4: When I went to Headless Mutual, the bank for tough London gangsters, I was given a pamphlet that said "If you try'a rip us off, we'll give you the rough end of a pineapple." I didn't quite understand this phrase, but it was important that I knew my legal obligations, so I consulted my Glossary of British Thieves' Argot. The result: "'give one the rough end of a pineapple': lit. insert the crown of the fruit into the recipient's anus. Metaphorically used to mean 'to exact vengeance'. Oh, I see now.

story: This can be seen as a Retarius, a roman gladiator. The Retiarius always fought with a net to bound up his opponents, and with a trident, which was able to pierce enemies after tying them. They were terrific contenders, so they were only paired with gladiators specially equipped to fight them.
column3: A boxing ring is bound up by the ropes. The contender is cheating and using a rake.
column4: In an episode of the Simpsons, Sideshow Bob is trying to kill Bart, but on the way has to contend with a pile of rakes which keep him bound up for some time.

story: Bottled water marketers contend to make their version of tap water sound the cleanest.
column3: The water contends against the dirt in the ultimate battle for cleaninless.
column4: Separate the primitives. Cleaning the garden involves watering the lawn and binding up all the leaves with a rake.

story: Just one word about this matter from your mouth and you will find this rake across it.
column3: I had to take one day off from work due to 'personal matters' after stepping on a rake and having the handle snap up and smack me across the mouth. I certainly wasn't going to tell anyone about it.
column4: This is a pictograph of someone stepping on a rake, and the handle coming up to hit them in the face...no laughing matter.

story: Two archeologists are in a cave looking at Chinese artifacts from various eras. One picks up a rake and says, "What about this – T'ang, do you think?" The second puts the rake in his mouth and answers, "Yes, it does tang a bit".
column3: Screw it, this character refers to the drink. The powdery orange substance is actually found on the floor of tropical caves, where trained aboriginal peoples use wooden rakes to rake the Tang into a pile before putting a bit of it in their mouths to see if it's tasty or not.
column4: (Based on matticus) The Tang juice was created in China in the T'ANG dinasty. The T'ANG emperor discovered that certain caves walls had a very sweet smell, so he raked the walls of one of them and put the rake into his mouth. This way he discovered that tasty powder that nowadays is known as TANG juice.

story: Sugar made from rice has a tangy flavour.
column3: The T'ang are the ones who began using sugar in China--of course, the first thing they tried it on was rice.
column4: The ultimate sugary breakfast is a rice krispy treat and a big glass of Tang.

story: A psychiatric hospital is located in a CAVE. To determine, which patients are sane and can be released, they are given a SIEVE and asked to empty a bathtub (the sane ones take out the plug and get the water out with ease).
column3: People on the cave age became more sane after they started using sieves to avoid eating harmful things with their grains. (This kanji is almost exclusively used to write 健康, health).
column4: Ever since I meditated in the cave and realised that wearing a sieve on my head would stop the C.I.A controlling my thoughts, I've been completely SANE.

story: Think police roadblocks. They act like road sieves, letting good people through but apprehending criminals.
column3: The police have a new way of apprehending criminals; a big sieve in the road. Innocent people pass over, but people with a guilty conscience fall through.
column4: In Space Balls, they were combing the desert in order to apprehend Lone Star. Picture Dark Helmet saying "Combing the desert failed, we must now sieve the road!"

story: The "boot" of Italy has gotten Europe all muddy. Who else could mop it up but Mr T?
column3: Here I have Mister T cleaning up with a mop, a real mess of spaghetti, in front of the Piza (in Italy).
column4: The radical on the right looks to me like a fork holding a spaghetti. In Italia is pretty common to see people eating spaghetti.

story: There's a tendency in Japan to make the younger members (kouhai) clean up after the older members (senpai) of a group, which results in a lot of grumbling and whining. "Well old boy," a senpai might say, "If you did as much work with the mop as you do with your mouth, you would have been done an hour ago".
column3: The Beatles, english old boys, had hairs like mop and a good singing mouth.
column4: 君[kimi] is said by the old boy to the younger boy, never the other way around as it would be an insult.

story: Good ol' boys are like sheep; they tend to flock together.
column3: A little girl herder calls out, "羊君、きて！" to the sheeps and they flock to her at once.
column4: (Thanks Stefanot) Fans flocked like sheep at Beatles - old boys concerts.

story: [akrodha] My comb is rust-proof, water-proof, and fire-proof. But unfortunately it is not idiot-proof--and I glued it to myself.
column3: I spent $100 recently on this excellent rust-proof, water-proof, fire-proof comb. But two days after having bought it, I left it in my back pocket and sat down, snapping this expensive comb in half! I glued it back together, but now every time I try to comb through my thick hair, it just breaks apart again. I guess my comb is also glue-proof.
column4: Glue your hair together and it will be comb-proof.

story: Supply and demand is a simple concept: when it rains, the demand for combs goes up to deal with wet hair.
column3: If it rains, the demand for combs will rise. However, if it rains combs, the demand for combs will fall. It's all about supply and demand. (A combination of radical tyro's and FuduMyo's stories).
column4: If it's raining combs, then the demand for them sure does drop.

story: No more Confucian jibba-jabba! I demand you tell me why it's raining combs!"
column3: One day, Mr. T started reading the little proverbs he found in fortune cookies, and with this newfound wisdom he became a Confucian scholar. He was suddenly in high demand as people came from all over to ask for his sage advice, immensely satisfied with suggestions such as, "You will find happiness with a new love".
column4: Mr. T demands to know what Confucian means!

story: Have you ever seen those shots in movies where the hero is standing at the edge of a sheer mountain face, hair blowing in the wind? It probably wouldn't seem so heroic if you saw him ten minutes earlier, when a crew of stylists was carefully combing his hair so it would fall perfectly.
column3: When you stand a comb on its edge, it looks like the 山 (#830) kanji.
column4: Jimi Hendrix: Well I stand up next to a mountain, chop it down with the edge of my ......... comb?

story: Primatives celing; belt; mountain as per Cumulative Errata. See volfy post for link. Both effective ways to commit suicide, hang your self from the celing with your belt or jump off a mountain.
column3: Under one ceiling both took off their belts in Brokeback Mountain.
column4: Be careful with this one. The correct primitive order is ceiling . . . belt . . . mountain. That said, in the Mario video games, there are some levels where spikes hang from the ceiling and there are large conveyor belts. One example is Koopa Mountain. Imagine both Mario and Luigi trying to get through the level unscathed.

story: Add water THEN the flowers. With both the vase will be full.
column3: I was thirsty so I gulped down the water. Then I realized I was also hungry. So I ate the flowers. Yes, I am responsible for both the missing water and the missing flowers. Yes, I'm afraid both. Am I still hungry or thirsty? Thank you for asking! How kind! But no, I feel quite full now.
column4: I hate going on dates where a girl says "I'll have a salad and a water" and then insists that they both make her full!

story: You decide one day to paint a kanji on your ceiling. Unfortunately, you don’t have a brush, so, being innovative, you use a sprout. Knowing it could be messy, you search for a drop-cloth, but can’t find one. Instead, you put a shovel down on the floor to catch any drips resulting from the BRUSH-STROKEs.
column3: To paint a kanji in your ceiling with only natural materials, you use a sprout as a brush and shovel some dirt to use as paint for your strokes. [modified from johnskb's].
column4: Start with just one stroke. Soon more will sprout, and then you end up with a whole shovelfull!

story: Stop shoveling rice into your mouth, you'll hurt a tooth! Use chopsticks instead.
column3: My dentist used his foot and a shovel to dislodge the rice stuck between my teeth.
column4: I cant believe i didnt see this before .............................................................. ITS A PICTOGRAPH OF A TOOTH!!! ...a front tooth thats white as rice, wedged into the upper gum to stop it moving and the shovel primitive is the shape of the tooth. ...you dont need much imagination to picture this!!........UPDATE: the stop primitive can even mean foot of the tooth (like opposite to head) thus root of the tooth.

story: It looks like the mouth of Bender the robot, from Matt Groening's animated series "Futurama". Thus, I use the character Bender the robot as a primitive.
column3: Also means "melody". Think of it as a pictogram of a guitar where you have to bend the strings to make a melody.
column4: When two sprouts sprout at the same place they don't have enough space and have to bend in different directions to grow...

story: A space cadet eager to make one bend around the sun. (a dangerous maneuver).
column3: Bender lasted just one day in the space cadets.
column4: Japanese cadets have to constantly do one thing--bend OVER all day, bowing to their superiors.

story: Close encounters of the third kind. The space cadet encounters aliens on the road.
column3: Bender the cadet (see frame 1172) has an "encounter of the third kind" on the road. Reference to Steven Spielberg's 1977 movie "Close Encounters of the Third Kind". Also a reference to popular stories of people reportedly chased by UFO's while driving on the road.
column4: Close encounters of the third kind. You encounter a space cadet on the road. (tweaked version of radical tyro's story. Having "alien" in the story made me want to use 玄 in place of 曹).

story: Bender the cadet (see frame 1172) is rowing, during some army exercise, and he's very afraid of water (Bender is a robot).
column3: The space cadet is in training, rowing in the water (see it splash).
column4: A space cadet has crashed on an unknown planet. Fortunately he crashed in water so he's unharmed, but now he has to do some rowing to get out of the water.

story: Also as part of some army survival exercise, the cadets (including Bender see frame 1172) are sent into the woods to build a vat (for collecting water for example).
column3: Bender the Cadet (kudos to Fuaburisu) is found on an army training exercise, hiding behind a tree, getting drunk on the famous scotch whiskey Vat 69.
column4: A true (?) story about Captain Cook and sauerkraut. Cook was convinced that sauerkraut would prevent the disease scurvy among his sailors, but his problem was getting his sailors to eat the stuff. He tricked the low-ranking cadets into eating sauerkraut by storing it in wood vats labeled "for officers' use only". The cadets thus believed that they were being unfairly denied access to the officers-only vats, so they secretly stole and ate the sauerkraut - which was exactly what Cook wanted them to do.

story: Since the meaning of "big dipper" is rather specific and the sense of measurement seems to be a more common usage, I concentrate on the primative meaning of measuring cup. This is a pictograph, with the first two strokes representing the measuring ticks on the side of the cup.
column3: The Big Dipper is a celestial measuring cup.
column4: I looked out my window frame and saw two shooting stars slashing through the big dipper. Primitive: Big Gulp cup from 7-11.

story: When buying rice, the fee is calculated by the cup. Naturally we don't just use any cup; it has to be a proper measuring cup.
column3: Ancient Japan mobile promises no monthly fees for long distance but I hate the fact that they don't take credit cards. I'm tired of mailing them a measuring cup full of rice every month.
column4: This kanji is used in 料理 (cooking). Imagine a cooking recipe: Telling you how many cups of rice (measuring cups, of course) you need, and what the fee at the supermarket is.

story: University departments study things like wheat (agriculture) and the big dipper (physics/astronomy), and exact measuring cups (engineering).
column3: The national DEPARTMENT of WHEATS and MEASURES. Get it? This one was hard until I came up with this.
column4: An alphabetical list of the university's departments reads "Agriculture (wheat), Astronomy (Big Dipper)...." and so on.

story: Can't see direct relation to 斗 (#1261) since its writing order is completely different. As raulir noted, it's written as overlapping at the last stroke of ツ and the first of メ. I take it as a pictograph or treasure map. Two dots represent big trees and the cross (marking the treasure) is placed relative to them.
column3: A pictograph of a treasure map. Two steps east then X marks the spot. 図る はかる attempt, deceive; 地図 ちず map; 意図する いとする make a goal, intend to do; 図々しい ずうずうしい impudent, shameless; 図書館 としょかん library.
column4: Ahem, it looks like a Trea-tsu mep, er a treasure map...

story: To tenderize meat in an emergency wilderness situation, just utilize your walking stick!
column3: I'll confuse this with 使 (#1065), so build a distinction right from the start. For me, "utilize" has an artificial, business-speak connotation; you only utilize "utilize" when you're trying to puff up what you're saying and sound important. So: "BioTools Inc introduces the FG2000 screwdriver, utilizing the our latest FleshGrip(tm) technology!" I'm seeing this as a picture of a stubby screwdriver with a handle made of flesh, a short shaft, and prongs to hold a screw in place until you drive it.
column4: When your flesh is weak you must utilize a walking stick.

story: To live a comfortable life, single men need only a cave for living, a rake for cleaning and a screwdriver for fixing.
column3: When I first moved in to my new cave, all I had was a bed (see 床 (#636)). But now I've settled in, got myself a few handy things like a rake and a screwdriver, and made myself more comfortable.
column4: To make your cave more comfortable, you'll need to do some work with a rake and screwdriver. Clean it up. Fix a few things.

story: Mr. T wants to climb up and pick the flowers at the top of the cliff. He equips himself with screwdrivers to use as climbing spikes to reach the top of the cliff. Imagine a large AMMO belt full of philips screwdrivers instead of bullets.
column3: A person equipping themselves with flowers they will utilize to beautify the barren cliff.
column4: An RPG where you're using Mr T as a character. Before you enter a battle, you equip the flower cliff screwdriver. This is a small screwdriver obtained at the bottom of a cliff that, when used in battle, shoots out pink flowers. When they touch the ground in front of the enemy, they create a massive cliff, and the ground under the enemy falls away into the sea. Picture being at the item select menu and EQUIPping this item just before facing a tough boss.

story: Once upon a time, the children were forced to eat their salad every day.
column3: For those who don't know the expression, "salad days" means the time of one's youth. (originally from Shakespeare's Antony and Cleopatra - see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salad_days). I suspect Heisig chose "salad" as the name for the radical just for this phrase...
column4: Once upon a time there was a McDonald's salad and it was left out in the sun for a whole day. But ... nothing happened because it was a McDonald's salad, chock full of preservatives and other garbage. The salad lived happily ever after (and so did the person who didn't eat it). The end. [I didn't write this... the original author deleted it... but it's my favourite story on the whole site.]

story: Once upon a time, it was thought that the ancient "art" of alchemy could transform anything into gold. At that time, people were obviously confused about the difference between reality and myth. (Arguably people are still as confused as ever, just about different things now.)
column3: Once upon a time there were some very confused alchemists. They couldn't understand why they couldn't turn other metals (i.e. lead) into gold. (adapted from Raichu).
column4: Ahhh senility, when you are confused by the everything in the world . . . your golden years are not at all like your salad days.

story: Once upon a time I let Mr T borrow my salad bowl, but he won't give it back. "This be mine now, foo!"
column3: Back in the day, you'd borrow from a person. These days you go to a bank.
column4: Mr. T borrowed a copy of Cinderella and won't give it back. He keeps watching it over and over again, trying to figure out how the Fairy Godmother does her magic.

story: What a pity! My state of mind when i think of the opportunities I missed from once upon a time.
column3: Data says "What a pity" when he hears that once upon a time there were no robots.
column4: "Pity? It was pity that stayed Bilbo's hand! Once upon a time he would not have felt it, but his state of mind changed, and he spared Gollum's life".

story: Long ago our ancestors set aside the use of fingers and began to use cutlery. (Raichu,11-7-2006) The way I remember it's 昔 昔 (#1268) rather than 旧 旧 (#35) is that they began to use cutlery to eat salad. (I also think about how when you visit the Medieval Times theme park, which is set in Once upon a time, their gimmick is that you eat with your fingers.)
column3: "Once upon a time..." Oh hell, you're just too old for this. You close your fairy tale book and set it aside, pushing it away with your fingers.
column4: To set aside in the sense of giving it up. We set aside childish things, namely, those ONCE UPON A TIME stories we grew up with-- though those stories' faeries and Disney tinkerbells come up to us, we brush them away with our FINGERS, once after another, but they keep coming, not wanting to be set aside-- so we flick them away!

story: The taskmaster is dissatisfied with the meal she's served, and scatters the salad & meat across the floor for the servants to clean up.
column3: When his salad had meat in it, the vegetarian taskmaster blew his top and scattered it all over the restaurant floor.
column4: Perhaps you've heard of Nyotaimori or Nantaimori (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nyotaimori) in which sushi is ate from the flesh of a naked person, the story comes easily. Scatter salad over the flesh of the taskmaster in preperation for some nantaimori :).

story: A generation is 30, one stroke less is twenty.
column3: Ten plus ten is twenty (see 世 (#28)).
column4: 十、廿、丗... Ten, Twenty, Thirty... Japanese is logical as usual.

story: Commoners have to huddle in caverns around a campfire, while higher class people get heating and central air conditioning in a hotel.
column3: PRIMITIVE: Cave + twenty = Finnish sauna (instead of Heisig's "caverns", which I'd confuse with "cave"). This primitive meaning works well for all kanji it occurs in; I've posted stories for all of them. STORY: Wealthy people have a sauna in their house, but commoners have to use their oven fire to warm themselves.
column4: If you are so poor that you are a commoner, you will have to live twenty commoners to a cavern, with only one fire for everyone to share.

story: The commoners are revolting! We must intercept them on the road before they reach the castle!
column3: If don't want your secret message to be intercepted, make sure your deliveryman is dressed as a commoner while traveling on the road.
column4: This keyword is dangerously similar to 逮 (#1244). The idea of a "road-block intercepting" people can't be used twice, so here's an alternative: The children from the local village (merely commoners) walked up to the overpass of the nearby highway and intercepted the communications of passing truckers using their little CB radio.

story: Remember those poor commoners huddled in groups of 20 in a cave? The only thing they had for a seat was some old toweling (while their lords could recline on luxurious couches).
column3: PRIMITIVE: Cave + twenty = Finnish sauna (instead of Heisig's "caverns", which I'd confuse with "cave"). STORY: You don't directly sit on the wooden seat in the sauna -- rather, you put a towel underneath.
column4: You're tired from walking the tour at this cavern and there's no benches to sit down on, so you take a towel and sling it up into a hammock-like seat using the stalagmites. (Big no-no).

story: The cavern refugees are so poor that they can't afford thermometers. So, the menfolk expose their crotches inside the cavern, and approximate the temperature in degrees from how shrivelled everything looks downstairs...
column3: PRIMITIVE: Cave + twenty = Finnish sauna (instead of Heisig's "caverns", which I'd confuse with "cave"). STORY: When it gets 95 degrees Celsius (or 200 degrees Fahrenheit) in the sauna, you start feeling the heat in your crotch.
column4: The cave is twenty degrees cooler than the outdoors. Twenty male crotches experience shrinkage.

story: This particular form of transit is a ferry (one of the actual meanings of this character). Naturally it can only cross the water if it's not frozen, so the temperature must be above 0 degrees.
column3: Hint: This is most commonly used in わたる, meaning to cross (a river etc) - most of the other readings are fairly obscure. I guess Heisig didn't use that because of the earlier 'crossing' kanji, but there we go. Story: the Dwarves who live in the Arctic caverns develop a transit system (perhaps of husky drawn carts) on the frozen water when its -20 degrees so they can cross to the other caverns.
column4: This kanji becomes a snap when you think of a surveyor's instrument called a transit! The transit has a small, curved liquid tube (with an air bubble) and a scale marked in degrees so you can tell if something is level or not.

story: Hustle and bustle = a big St. Bernard dog frisking about in a haystack, knocking it down and spreading the hay about, after the field hands just stacked it up.
column3: (note: easier way to remember haystack - it's just as difficult to find a needle in a haystack, even if you use two hands) Farmers hustling and bustling to move big haystacks.
column4: A bustle is also the name for the big wire-framed skirts that women used to wear. Here's a St. Bernard dog jammed ass-first into the top of a haystack, looking like some kind of proper Victorian-era lady as he struggles to get out.

story: History of Pompei: An unexpect eruption and from the mouths of the volcano come lava that threatens the farmers collecting haystacks in the fields and the fisherman catching shells on the coast.
column3: Well, the local farmers stuffed the mouth of the dangerous volcano with haystacks, thinking that would prevent eruptions. Even more stupid was one tourist who threw some sea food (shellfish) into the mouth of the volcano. This caused an instant eruption of unprecedented magnitude!
column4: Hint: the "haystack-shells" combination is itself a rare kanji, 賁. It means "decorate", but since that keyword is taken (飾 (#1477)) , I'll call it "ornament" (easy enough to get from flower arrangement + shells). Now, a volcano erupts from its mouth to ornament itself with shiny lava (forget geological pressures, the thing's just vain).

story: After the eruption all is a tomb. The soil has covered the remains of the farmers gathering haystacks and of the fisherman collecting shells.
column3: Using soil and hay to make bricks, the Egyptians built the pyramids to entomb the Pharaohs along with all of their money.
column4: Depending on how much money you have, you can be buried in the hay, in the dirt, or in a tomb.

story: Note: this word in Japanese has the idea of "indignant". So aroused here refers to being aroused because of anger over some unjust or wrong act, unfairness etc. It doesn't seem to carry a meaning associated with arousal in the sense of sex or pleasure. So, my story: think of the angry state of mind aroused at finding all your clams buried under your haystack stolen, gone!
column3: Data was aroused/indignant when he saw what the volcano had done to the farmers building their haystacks and the fishermen collecting their shells . The tragedy of it all aroused him so much he didn't even notice he was feeling emotion.
column4: An anime/manga character is clearly in an aroused (angered) state of mind when their head is ornamented with anger marks. ( #ﾟДﾟ) .

story: To the fire goes the straw man, thinking to bake a cake on it, but...
column3: This is the story of the cute little strawman who was helping to bake cookies. Thinking he was being ever so helpful he climbed into the oven to check if they were nearly done. "Hmm I think I can smell burning," he said "I hope it's not the cookies..." A moment later he realised his mistake. You can hear his screams as he staggers around helplessly on his little human legs, but he can't see for all the fire!!!! Oh the horror!!! Poor strawman :( .........[thanks akrodha].
column4: The best yakisoba / yakiimo / yakizakana / yakitori / yakiniku / takoyaki / taiyaki / shogayaki / sukiyaki / okonomiyaki / dorayaki / teriyaki / teppanyaki is made by burning a strawman.

story: The sun rising beside a straw man in a corn field is a classic cartoon depiction of daybreak.
column3: The first person to see the sun at daybreak is of course the straw man who stands outside all day.
column4: 旦 (#30) was yoake 夜明け = or when the night brights up - daybreak is a akatsuki (the kun reading of this character), coming from akatoki =明時 which is the exact moment at which the SUN can give life to the STRAWMAN (it used to mean the period of time when it's still dark - before dawn) 曙 (#2524) is usually reserved for the figurative sense of beginning of a new era. to keep them separated i'm sorting them chronologically as : 暁(4 a.m)/曙(5:12:04)/旦(6 a.m).

story: Imagine karate chopping the number three in half with a WALKING STICK and pausing the picture just as the first "board" breaks.
column3: I think of this as a pictograph, there are three boards to cut, the first one is already in half and there are still two more to go.
column4: If this were a comic drawing, and someone was cutting vegetables in a half with a knife real quick, this would be the view from the above of the scene. The ' ´ are just the impact / action marks. And the knife is the | dividing the two halves.

story: The person who is your consort is most commonly "your other half".
column3: Mr. T wants to splits himself in half so he can be his own CONSORT.
column4: MR T's CONSORT is only HALF the size that he is (she's Japanese after all).

story: A PADDY-RIDGE divides the RICE FIELD in HALF.
column3: Better keyword: waterside (as in lakeside, etc.) words: 河畔 (riverside) 湖畔(lakeside), 池畔(by a pond), etc. New keyword captures most common meaning, and avoids confusion with 畦, which means ONLY paddy-ridge. story: A rice field is divided in half, half is field half is water. If you stand at the halfway mark, you are at the waterside.
column4: Think about a large rice field as a big square. Then you draw a line down the middle, halving it into two. Then you draw a line across the middle, halving it again into four... These halvings are paddy-ridges that separate the rice field into separate sections. I dunno the reason why, but that's how it's done.

story: In the bible, King Solomon's JUDGMENT was admired not by saying to cut the baby in HALF with the SWORD, but that it revealed who the true mother was.
column3: It takes good judgement to cut things in exactly half with a saber.
