column4: King solomon was famous for his JUDGMENT. two mothers who came before him to resolve a quarrel about which was the true mother of a baby. when Solomon suggests dividing the living child in two HALVES with a SABER, the true mother is revealed to him because she is willing to give up her child to the lying woman rather than have the child killed.

story: 1) I hold a roll of quarters in my hand when I make a fist. 2) I hold a quarter in my hand as I prepare to play the Iron Fist Tournament: 鉄拳 （てっけん） at the arcade.
column3: Quarter, hand: If you have a roll of quarters in your hand, your fist will deliver a much more effective punch.
column4: 及 fist* His fist is a QUARTER the size of his open HAND.

story: Entering the movie, the dude asks for your ticket, so he can tear it in half. He looks at you funny when you hand him a ticket already torn in half. He quietly tears the stub into quarters after you show him your dagger with a smile.
column3: Typically, about one quarter of a ticket with be separated by a perforated edge which the ticket guy will tear off when you are at the gate. However, this kanji was made waaay before perforated edges were invented. It used to be that the guy would cut off a quarter of your ticket with a dagger.
column4: While a quarter may not buy you a ticket, a dagger will; if you know what I mean.

story: At a mysterious bazaar, you happen to come across something interesting: a rolled-up scroll for only 25¢. You buy it up impulsively until you realize that the powerful spell contained within is cursed by a poisonous snake. If you try to cast this spell, the snake will pop out of nowhere and bite you! Hrmph. No wonder it was so cheap...
column3: How to make snake maki: Take a snake. Roll it up in rice and nori (seaweed paper) like a scroll. Cut into quarters and serve on a wooden geta with ginger and wasabi.
column4: This scroll isn't long enough to show more than a quarter of a snake.

story: I assosiate scrolls with spell casting, the efect of this spell is pent in a certain sphere of influence, outside it no damage is done.
column3: [RPG] You're fighting a powerful enemy. Your mage uses a scroll/quartersnake of protection, and he's pent in a sphere of protection.
column4: The entire sphere of human knowledge used to be pent into the library of alexandria on scrolls. (oops, but then it all burned).

story: After your VICTORY cut your enemy's FLESH into QUARTERs to show your POWER.
column3: After England's victory over Scottish rebel William Wallace, they had his flesh drawn and quartered and then sent around Britain to demonstrate their power.
column4: On the moon it only takes a quarter of your power to accomplish the same victory (because of the low gravity).

story: According to legend, the great Ogaki wisteria tree grew and flowered from magical rice grains that were planted under the quarter moon.
column3: The wisteria is a type of hanging vine covered with flowers. By the light of the quarter moon, the flowers look like clusters of rice grains.
column4: This is easy if you've seen Desperate Housewives. Here on Wisteria Lane, under the immaculate flowers, you wouldn't believe the things going on at night under the light of the quarter moon, and we're not talking about fancy recipes for cooking grains of rice.

story: Sending a facsimile to the moon can be problematic only a quarter of the words actually get there.
column3: As a prank, a guy sits with his butt flesh on the facsimile machine, inserts a quarter, and tries to fax it to his boss. However the facsimile machine has pattern recognition technology and instead of an image of his flesh, it just transmits the word "asshole". Don't forget it's flesh, not words, on the left side; the flesh image gets transformed into words.
column4: When you send a facsimile to the moon it costs a quarter per word.

story: Fuaburisu's pictograph of a man kneeling and presenting the ring to his future wife is a one-sided version of the story. Others say he was giving her the finger.
column3: Taking the keyword in the sense of only one part of a whole, I see this as a pictograph of a man kneeling and presenting the ring to his future wife (I couldn't see any trees or branches in there).
column4: A one-sided romance--he proposes and she says no. (Thanks to fuaburisu).

story: Before the advent of printers in Japan, typewriters couldn't be built as they were in the west due to how many kanji there are. Lots of small printing blocks had to be used instead. One side of the printing block would have a mirrored (anti) image of the kanji. This is true.
column3: Printing block has a one-sided anti-image of what's being printed.
column4: Nazi propaganda. Picture the printing blocks producing very one-sided (Aryan), anti-Jewish propaganda spreading posters to hang around town.

story: Of all the kanji, this is the only one 之orro can write.
column3: The Z of Zorro (and yes he has a hat).
column4: "Hey Zorro, would you sign my chest?" "Why of course!" Long story short: he didn't use a pen...

story: Just one drop (of alcohol) and he starts walking in zig-zags – no wonder Zorro's living in destitution. (Note: As a primitive let 之 be Zorro or Zig-Zag: it's pictographic).
column3: Children in complete destitution have no hope of ever getting toys to play with, so when they find even a tiny drop of a building block they are overjoyed.
column4: The people living in destitution POOR. Zorro gives them every drop he has: drops of sweat while fighting, drops of blood when he is cut down,... even the senorita gets some drops.

story: Zorro, with a flower between his teeth for the ladies, defends his turf against evildoers. "This is my turf! And this...is for the lady."
column3: Artificial turf made easy: flowers stuck on top of building blocks that you can place anywhere.
column4: You know that when you see a flower bed in the shape of a Z that you're on Zorro's turf.

story: [Smithsonian] Scene: Mr. T hanging from the ceiling being tortured. He is asked if he is going to talk. Spitting (a drop of saliva) in the torturer's face, he says "Negative".
column3: One below zero is a negative number.
column4: A minus sign with an arrow pointing up at it, indicating that this is the symbol that means negative.

story: To distinguish between 否 negate, and 不 不 (#1217): Note that negate contains 口, which is a kind of gate.
column3: Negative mouths negate everything.
column4: I get this mixed up with 不 (#1217). The difference here is that someone ate the negative to negate it.

story: The maple tree is very negative about it, but the farmer still collects cupfuls of maple syrup from it.
column3: Ｗｈｅｎ　ｙｏｕ　ｓａｙ　［いっぱい」　Ｔｈｅ　ｋａｎｊｉ　ｉｓ　一杯． Just think of Wooden cups being used for drinking, but drinking CUPFULS is Negative as you might get sick.
column4: The kanji for いっぱい is 一杯． One cup is great, two cups still good, but if you have so many cupfuls that you pass out under a tree, the situation has turned negative.

story: Zeus ran out of lightning bolts and has to drop darts from the heavens.
column3: Do not mistake with LOSE 失.
column4: I lost 845 失 the tip to my dart 矢.

story: Angels have now been given a powerful tool to rectify human behavior instantly, without delay - they have been allowed to drop darts on those who misbehave... spare the dart and spoil the man...
column3: The Angel cupid uses darts to rectify people's love life.
column4: When you rectify something, it's straight as an arrow 矢. Right side 喬 is same as 嬌 "attractive" or 橋 "bridge." When you rectify (straighten) your teeth or get bridgework, you have a heavenly 天 mouth 口; you don't need to go around with a covered 冂 mouth 口. 矯正、きょうせい, correction: その頃はまだ父の悪い癖を矯正しようとしていた, "Around that time I was still trying to correct my father's bad habits." 歯列矯正、しれつ〜, orthodontia.

story: With a banner declaring "Keep Out!" and blow darts to back it up, the Amazon tribe is not that friendly.
column3: TRIBES in Japan either have BANNERS (samurai) or poisoned DARTS (ninja).
column4: Hint: This most commonly occurs in 家族 (かぞく, family), and family is not taken, so I'm renaming this kanji to family. Story (thanks Hawkeye123): When I'm playing darts at home, I put a banner on the door so my family doesn't enter my room and get stung by a dart.

story: I should know. After all, I did graduate from Dartmouth!
column3: [know; wisdom] [An arrow 矢 like mouth 口] If you know the answers, they will fly like darts from your mouth.
column4: A know-it-all can't help themselves, like Hermione, the answer to every question just darts from their mouth. [slight reframing from Ricardo's].

story: Wisdom is knowing everything OVER the sun (fools assume everything UNDER).
column3: Knowing more each day, brings wisdom.
column4: Wisdom is the knowledge gained by the passing of days.

story: In the busy pub, one of the dart players shoved his dart into my elbow by accident when it nearly slipped out of his fingers.
column3: Your fingers slip when someone's elbow shoves you, causing you to drop the dart you were about to throw. But as you can see, their elbow is very small, so you decide they're too weak to shove back.
column4: You're scared to do your introduction (挨拶）, so a giant FINGER appears to shove you in front of the class. You land on your ELBOW, and the class shoots DARTS at you for falling.

story: マオ Zedong always carried a halberd.
column3: Mao (マオ) gets his head chopped off by a halberd.
column4: Halberd: A weapon of the 15th and 16th centuries having an axlike blade and a steel spike mounted on the end of a long shaft. Pictograph: Take a moment to see its different parts. The upper マ is the blade, the horizontal line belongs to the shaft, and finally the lower vertical line is the spike.

story: [tender; weakness; gentleness; softness] Love me tender, Love me perfect, Never cheat on me. Or I'll impale you on my Halberd, And hang ya atop a tree...
column3: Use a halberd to tenderize a tree: halberds can chop, poke, and slash, so it's all good!
column4: I like my steak tender. That's why I impale it with a halberd and smash it against a tree to tenderize it.

story: It is with the halberd he holds that the taskmaster exerts his power over those actually performing the task.
column3: So many video games have a "boss" stage you must pass in order to advance to the next level. Here, your task is to use your halberd to beat the taskmaster with the huge, bulging muscles.
column4: A first RPG task--not even a full quest, just a task some random dude gives you (you always have to start off with some stupid weapon and go kill some other random dude, for no reason). Here, take this halberd I happen to have lying around. Now go kill the taskmaster and his hired-muscle UNDERling.

story: This fog is the perfect weather for us to perform our task undetected.
column3: FOG is easy to associate with the RAIN primitive. So think of FOG as a type of RAIN that is slow at the TASK of getting the place wet.
column4: Rain's task is to get rid of the fog.

story: Am I the only one who took this as penis and balls? In order to be in the man-squad, naturally you need to have two balls with your "spear" in the middle there.
column3: Here we have two kings trying out for the cheer-leading squad. A spear on the floor separates their dancing areas.
column4: King Leonidas from the movie 300 throws his spear at Xerxes (the Persian king) trying to kill him as his squad of spartins make their last stand.

story: A female warrior returns home from battle. Her husband takes away her spear to symbolize the end of fighting and gives her a broom and an apron. “Boy, this is some kind of HOMECOMING,” thinks the veteran. (Adapted from johnskb).
column3: Our high school theme was tradition. They gave the homecoming king a spear and the homecoming queen a broom and apron.
column4: At the homecoming, the man drops his spear, while the women drops her broom and removes her apron. Cherishing the moment that they are reunited.

story: My personification for this primative is Legolas from the Lord of the Rings: a master at the bow. I suppose robin hood etc would work too.
column3: I have a BOW made from a SNAKE that I BOUND UP. He sure wasn't happy!
column4: Picto: COMPOUND bow, because of the shape.

story: This is actually a bow and an arrow. (Real origin of this kanji). Pull and release to fire!
column3: Put a walking stick in the bow and pull it back, ready to fire at the geezer.
column4: If you pull at the ends of a bow long enough, you'll deform it to make a decent walking stick. This was a tactic used by injured archers to escape battle.

story: Perhaps a pictograph of a soldier's weapons--his sword and bow-placed ceremonially over his body before burial, while people offer their condolences.
column3: Send your condolences to the old geezer whom you shot the walking stick into with your bow. (see 引 (#1318)).
column4: Don't confuse with 償 (#1060), 賠 (#515). Condolences aren't monetary or physical; it's just a letter. "Dear wife, your bungling soldier husband tried to string his bow with his walking stick, which of course failed. He was promptly killed by enemy fire. Our condolences."

story: If you pull the bow back with your elbow, you can shoot a vast distance.
column3: The valley was so vast that if you yelled elbow! you could hear it echo bow, bow, bow.
column4: Legolas pulls back his elbow so he can fire a vast distance. I think of the part of 'The Two Towers' when they are chasing the orcs who have captured Merry and Pippen. They were covering a vast area.

story: An insect who can fly vast distances is strong.
column3: The vast majority of insects are pretty strong; ants can carry 10x their weight!
column4: There was once a legendary archer, who was known for being incredibly strong. In reality he was very weak but had a powerful insect friend who tugged on his elbow while pulling on his bow and arrow.

story: If I recline back, I can pull my bow open a little more and more.
column3: More and more archers shoot their bows while reclining a little. It's a very popular stance.
column4: More and more bows were made to kill people, until they were laid down for better smaller guns.

story: Two weak archers agree on a duel to the death. They constantly shoot at each other but never manage to hit their target. But what they lack in skill they make up in determination, and they keep shooting for hours, and days, and months, until it's wintertime and their bows are coated in ice.
column3: BOWS with ICE on them are brittle and WEAK.
column4: I'm missing this Kanji too much, so here's another take: Look at the two BOWS and you'll see it looks like FEATHERS at the base of the BOWS. So, imagine two indian children who are still too WEAK to pull a real bow, so their parents make two BOWS from two long FEATHERS. Now the WEAK children can pretend they have real BOWS. Two FEATHER BOWS.

story: Weak people placed in the water start drowning. Get some strength in those arms and learn how to swim!
column3: Darwin awards: The weakest of the weak will start drowning if put in several drops of water. (Do not confuse with 没 (#763)).
column4: In the water, it's the weak that end up drowning.

story: Re CharleyGarrett: This liquid looks like ordinary water, but it will instantly seethe when it comes in contact with counterfeit dollar bills. The inventor must be rich (and probably has dollar signs in his eyes).
column3: When his daughter used a lot of water for her shower, the father could practically see the dollar signs, so he was seething with anger.
column4: This kanji is more closely related to water and emotions boiling. Story: When his daughter used a lot of WATER for her shower, the unemployed father could practically see the DOLLAR SIGNS going down the drain. He began SEETHing with anger... (Thanks smithsonian).

story: An expense is an expense, whether you put it in dollars or in local money.
column3: A dollar sign next to an amount of money denotes an expense.
column4: There's always an extra expense involved when you try to convert DOLLARS into other MONEY (clams).

story: The No. 1 currency in the world is the dollar. But, the Asian nations are fast catching up and may in reality have already surpassed it. So, let the bamboo represent the No. 2 currencies (the yen, etc.). The reverse order (bamboo on top and the dollar on the bottom) is really a look at the future.
column3: The No.1 currency may at one time have been the dollar, but since the economic slowdown the weak dollar has been overtaken by currencies from bamboo growing countries. (Thanks to Johnnyltn for the idea.) Using the alternate writing of the dollar primitive as weak dollar.
column4: Bamboo bling is the newest Asian Rapper, No. 1 on the charts right now.

story: Younger brothers are always more prone to mischief. Mine, you can almost see the little horns on him and the dollar signs on his eyes when he comes up with a money-making scheme.
column3: The younger brother was a horny dollar -chasing bastard.
column4: This is a picture of my stupid younger brother's tattoo. I can't believe he thinks a red dollar sign with devil's horns is cool.

story: Adroit: dextrous, deft, skillful. Snare is a little generic so I'll use BEAR TRAP, with huge teeth cartoon style that snares you around the ankle. In the crafting of a bear trap, one must be particularly adroit. Otherwise they will become the victim of their down device.
column3: To be adroit one must have mastered the crafting of snares.
column4: To be adroit is to have mastered the craft of avoiding snares.

story: My nickname is "No Lips". Yep, I shouldn't have put my mouth on that bear trap...
column3: When certain nickname snares to people's mouths, they will call you that way forever.
column4: Also used in code, signal, password, etc. A password is the code you must mouthe to release the snare so you may enter safely. Most people just use their nickname (which is not recommended by security experts).

story: This snare isn't terribly effective, because it's swinging from a decaying tree. Imagine the tree as being so decayed that when an animal gets caught in the snare, its struggles cause the tree to collapse into a putrid mess.
column3: [+air,charley] Trigger: decaying remains. You walk by a tree and see the decaying remains of what looks like a dead human (? hard to tell, it's been years), still trapped in a bear trap. Turns out that the tree itself set them out. All of its comrades were getting chopped down, so it puts out bear traps to ensnare would-be choppers and lets them simply decay, and uses their remains as nutrients.
column4: Don't use wooden snares because, as the woodsman says, "They're prone to decay, and the catch gets away".

story: The hunter's boast: I say, it was a "big one", but the snare broke and it got away. (credit to many others before).
column3: A dog owner boasts about how obedient, not how smart, his Saint Bernard dog is. "Why, my dog will even walk right into a trap if I tell him to. Watch!" With a single word, "go!", his dog obediently runs into a snare trap hanging from the ceiling. In a flash, the dog is netted tightly and swinging from the ceiling. Don't forget the ceiling!
column4: When you boast too much, your words cause your head to become so big it gets snared on the ceiling.

story: Your chin is the part of your head under your nostrils that forms the double snare that is your jaw.
column3: Left side is crocodile primative. crocodile's head's most prominent feature is his jaw.
column4: Both my friend's and my mouths dropped open when we saw a person's head snared up to the ceiling by his chin.

story: A hunter Washes, with WATER, his TWO SNAREs, because they are dirty.
column3: Washing your dirty snare in water, the extra line represents the water level as you submerge the snare.
column4: きtanai. Backwards き with drops of dirt coming off it.

story: David went to battle with a slingshot and it only took him one shot to slay Goliath. Partly because of this, the prophet Nathan was later instructed to bestow upon David the throne of all Israel.
column3: In The Legend of Zelda Ocarina of Time, one of the first weapons bestowed on Link was the slingshot.
column4: High 5! And bestow me one low!

story: A crown was bestowed to the British royalty museum, but it was only a copy.
column3: True fact: in the UK the right to print a copy of the KJV Bible is bestowed by the crown -- there are only a few authorised bible printers. (see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_James_Bible#Copyright_status).
column4: A crown is bestowed upon each Burger King patron, why not? It's just a cardboard copy.

story: Somebody was just looking for you. He had a longnose that reaches down below his mouth, and a long jaw that sticks out past his nose, and a scar across his face. (greenapple,16-3-2006) The way to remember that this is somebody rather than 者 (#1345) is that the story is full of body descriptions.
column3: Somebody was just looking for you. He had a long nose that reaches down below his mouth, and a long jaw that sticks out past his nose, and a scar across his face.
column4: Gang members sometimes mark themselves to show belonging, like by cutting their nose with a large slash mark. Why do they do it? To show that they are somebody. As a primitive, this character will mean gang member.

story: You SHOOT SOMEBODY with a GLUE-gun.
column3: Like paintball, GLUEball is another hunting game. You walk around looking for SOMEBODY to SHOOT a big blob of GLUE at, you know you have got him, because he gets stuck to the spot unable to escape.
column4: Whenever they shoot somebody 身, police forensic experts show up and measure 寸 every aspect of the scene. 射殺、しゃさつ, shooting to death: 射殺された時、その警官は非番だった, "At the time he was shot to death, that policeman was off duty." 注射、ちゅうしゃ, injection, shot (pour +).

story: In the Wild West it's shoot first, apologize later, but in Japan the words come first - so polite!
column3: The famous speech by the man that Dick Cheney shot in the face: "I'm sorry for the trouble I have caused the Vice President".
column4: socrates says, "shoot first, apologize later".

story: An old man, wondering what it's like in a grave, sits in a freshly dug plot. When a gravekeeper mistakes him for dead and begins burying him with soil, the old man saves himself by flailing his walking stick in the air.
column3: The dirty old man had a stroke so now he must be spoon fed.
column4: And old man fell to the ground after having a stroke, and now he has to be spoon-fed.

story: Before shooting an old man with a slingshot, one shold carefully consider the possible consequences.
column3: Even though he had the old man Mr. Wilson within the sights of his slingshot, Dennis the Menace considered what he was doing and stopped.
column4: As a last resort, we actually might consider sending our old men into the battle, armed with slingshots only...

story: This child has taken filial piety to the next level. He is actually carrying the old man on his shoulders.
column3: +dilandau23: This child has taken filial piety to the next level. He is actually carrying the old man on his shoulders. There is a picture of a statue depicting this here http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filial_piety.
column4: In filial piety, the child looks up to the old man.

story: In early Japan, filial piety was the cornerstone of education, and harsh taskmasters were employed to teach it.
column3: You could say that the taskmistress is teaching you filial piety when she whips you and asks, "Who's your daddy?!"
column4: Can you please teach me what filial piety means, taskmaster?

story: In Torture 101 class they teach you to Consider the Fingers as the first part to inflict pain to. Then you can move on to other parts (like feet, groin, head, etc. etc. ; ) ).
column3: "Aaaargh, stop!" cries the victim of torture, his fingers being squeezed by the thumb screws. "I'll consider it," the torturer says coolly, "if you tell me the names of all the agents in your organization."
column4: Pulling finger nails is considered to be the most common kind of torture.

story: I find the best way of memorizing this kanji is in conjunction with the Japanese compound for ninja: 忍者 -- i.e. someone who endures (see FRAME 597 for the kanji 忍). A 忍者 is not just a 身 (somebody), it's 者 who can 忍 great 拷!
column3: An old man is someone who has seen many days.
column4: Back in the day, the old man used to be someone. His name was in the papers and all that. I use CHUCKY from the movie Child's Play as my major alternate meaning for this primitive.

story: I had a hard time with the next several frame numbers trying to use "puppet." So i thought of "voodoo doll" but then found "love doll" (which is just a special type of puppet) fit well with these 8 frames. Observe: Here I am boiling my love doll over the flames to warm her up a bit...
column3: There is a lesser known voodoo practice of boiling a puppet over an oven fire, to really make your victim feel the heat!
column4: Instead of puppet I like to think of "someone" as ninja (since it is the second kanji in ninja)- it made me think of some interesting stories. First up: A ninja must be able to walk over fire without his blood boiling. (see him walking across the stretch of fire in concentration).

story: Here I am, putting a wreath of flowers on my love doll's head and pretending she is someone of great renowned.
column3: This someone is so renowned they are covered with flowers every time they perform on stage.
column4: The most renowned ninja can use even flowers to kill someone.

story: I've always wanted to use bamboo chopsticks to eat sushi off a naked woman. Unfortunately, there is no woman in my life, so this love doll will have to do.
column3: This ninja uses bamboo chopsticks to fight enemies.
column4: Bamboo, lovedoll: At dinner, my lovedoll decided to eat her meal the Japanese way using chopsticks. But well, what a problems she had getting those bamboo shoots into her mouth (which should not be that difficult, I would say!).

story: Before giving your SIGNATURE to accept the LOVEDOLL, you should EYE over the LOVEDOLL for any damages, then give your SIGNATURE.
column3: The ninja's signature move was to paralyse people just by looking in their eyes.
column4: [signature; govt office; police station] Signature? Forget it! Retina scanners (using our eyes as signature) will empower governments to find someone in any soil, any day, rendering all of us like puppets!

story: Ahh, a fine sultry day with my love doll under the hot sun. I think she's getting a tan!
column3: [from decamer0n] This is the kanji for atsui (暑い) as in hot. If you've ever been in Japan in the summer no doubt you have heard hoards of people bellowing "Atsui! Atsui!" Here you are laying with your love doll under the hot sun. Luckily the manufacturers were smart and when the doll got to hot it would bellow "Atsui! It's so sultry!"
column4: Ever wonder why ninjas only operate at night? It's to avoid the sultry sun of course!

story: Because i get tired of saying the same old thing, I have lately been trying to use various terms of endearment to my love doll. I think she appreciates it too.
column3: A ninja must be able to cope with various situations- like reciting word for word what he overheard while spying. (see the ninja clinging to the roof and spying on a conversation, preparing to recite what he heard later).
column4: When you pull the string at the back of Chucky, he will say various things. "Hidey-ho! Ha ha ha!" "Hi, I'm Chucky. Wanna play?" "I'm going to eat your liver, bitch!"

story: My love doll is made of special pheremone impregnated vinyl. Unfortunately, a pack of wild dogs mistook her for a wild boar and tore her to pieces. Oh dear!
column3: The pack of wild dogs attacked the ninja, but he turned into a wild boar and gutted them all. (see the ninja snapping his fingers, cloud of smoke, and turning into a giant boar).
column4: (Image: a pack of wild dogs chasing Pinocchio who's trying to escape by riding on the back of a boar. See him bouncing around as they race along?).

story: I was stranded on a desert island surrounded by water for hundreds of miles on end. I wasn't upset though - I had my love doll! What a great strand of sand to be stranded on - just me and my love doll!
column3: A lovely romantic walk on the strand, splashing in the water with my love doll.
column4: There's a ninja here on this strand of beach. Can't see him hiding in the water? Can't see him hiding in the sand of the strand? Nope? He sees you, though...

story: When we gamble at the shell game, I always win against my love doll.
column3: People who gamble compulsively are like puppets controlled by money.
column4: If you're worried about the drop above the sun, don't be: http://forum.koohii.com/viewtopic.php?id=1576.

story: A gorge is where God has cut into a mountain with a pair of scissors. (synewave,6-10-2006) http://www.travelblog.org/Photos/197361.html.
column3: Etymology of right half = 夾 (Type 1 Phonetic) (be pressed between). Interesting? 峡 (#1355) 狭 (#1356) 挟 (#1357). Very directly related to the meaning of these three kanji.
column4: NOTE: Heisig chose SCISSORS for 夹 because of 鋏 (#2795). 夾 is the old form of 夹, and means to be PRESSED BETWEEN, as others have pointed out. PRIMITIVE STORY: A large 大 man is PRESSED BETWEEN two other people 从 = 夾. KANJI STORY: A gorge is pressed between 夾 mountains 山.

story: In a CRAMPED space, a brave man holds off PACK OF WILD DOGS with only a pair of SCISSORS.
column3: A pack of wild dogs, waiting in a very cramped waiting room, to get their hair cut by Edward Scissors Hands, who is very popular.
column4: It's far too cramped on the train. You see that there is a guy with a pack of wild dogs, held only by a ribbon. You saunter up to him, and as the train doors open, you casually snip the ribbon with your scissors. Sensing that they are free, the pack of wild dogs spring into action and chase everyone on the car out, including their owner. A few people may get mangled, but hey, at least you're not so cramped anymore - in fact, you've got the whole car to yourself.

story: 挟まる 【はさまる】 (v5r,vi) to get between; to be caught in; (P) Story: You know how in tokyo there are those really packed trains where train staff in gloves shove people in? Well imagine being sandwiched in so tight, that when the doors close, only your FINGERS are sticking out. The train staff have no choice... they must cut them off with SCISSORS =( snip snip..
column3: Fingers sandwiched between a pair of scissors. Don't move or else!
column4: In Tokyo trains, they've got a problem with chikan, or old men who "accidently" molest women while being sandwiched against them on crowded trains. So now, Japan has hired Edward scissorhands to cut off the fingers of the offenders. Being sandwiched together is no excuse for chikan!

story: Your cheeks contain your jawbones, which are known as the "scissors of the head."
column3: The Joker from Batman had his cheeks cut with scissors to give him that eternal smile. Now the Joker isn't right in the head.
column4: Pressed between 夾 your cheeks is the rest of your head 頁. Adults like to squeeze 夾 your cheeks when you're a little kid, often while saying "Ho, ho! Look at those rosy cheeks!" 頬、ほほ or ほお, cheek: 涙が彼女の頬を流れ落ちた, "Tears ran down her cheeks." 恥ずかしさで彼女の頬が赤くなり始めた, "Her cheeks began to turn red with shame."

story: Maestro, coattails flapping wildly, is being chased down the road by his fans.
column3: Maestro primative = James Bond. Here he gives chase down the road to the bad guys. I'm thinking of the car chase in 'The Man with the Golden Gun' - NOT 逐 (#539). I think about 'Race N Chase' (a scalextric type toy)...there were no pigs in 'Race N Chase', only cars.
column4: This Kanji reminds me of Nodame Cantabile. I just have to imagine Chiaki, our maestro in training, getting chased by Nodame down the road.

story: The maestro lives on top of a large hill so that he can play music at over ten decibels without anyone giving a damn.
column3: Note to those who have not got this far in the book: This is the full kanji for the Pinnacle primitive (i.e. only the left-hand version of the primitive). The full kanji for the City Walls primitive is 邑 (#2296). Beyonce went for an invigorating walk up a large hill on a summer's afternoon. Since the grass was so lush and cool, she took off her sandals and immediately stepped on a used hypodermic needle. 岐阜県　ぎふけん Gifu Prefecture.
column4: (Thanks to kapalama. Since this kanji is pretty much exclusive to Gifu 岐阜, that's what this story shall centre around) Gifu is dominated by a large hill upon which Oda Nobunaga, the maestro of unifying Japan, made his stronghold. Below him was the crossroads of Japan: control Gifu, control the country.

story: A maestro in a large auditorium with high ceilings is conducting his orchestra of expert musicians at a fever-pitch, sweat pouring out of him. When the piece is over he reaches for his towel to wipe his brow.
column3: Maestro is such as expert, he can conduct even with a towel hanging from the ceiling in front of him.
column4: The maestro hangs the towel from the ceiling. He's not only a brilliant conductor but an expert in acoustics.

story: The COMMANDER is a military MAESTRO who never throws in the TOWEL.
column3: I like to recall commander in conjuntion with expert. Both are maestros with towels -- however, there is no upper limit (no ceiling) to what a commander can achieve in comparison to a mere expert.
column4: The greatest of them all; Commander James Bond, 007. Here he is the maestro of undressing women, removing the towel from some bond girl. Of course the towel symbolises her last vestige of resistance.

story: No one likes classical music anymore. Our Maestro is here at home without his baton sighing sadly before he heads off for another day as his new job as a bureaucrat.
column3: Bureaucrat, def: The maestro without a baton, the one who orchestrates oppressive rules, regulations and taxes on every household.
column4: Bureaucrat = the letter "B" beneath the "roof" of the House of Representatives ... writing legislation.

story: An excellent use of wood is to make coffins for bureaucrats.
column3: The maestro at home was sick of being a bureaucrat, so he got some wood and built himself a coffin and got in.
column4: The coffin must be constructed only of the wood of certain trees. It's the sort of rule that only a bureaucrat would come up with.

story: Japanese bureaucrats send all their messages through an inter-office bamboo pipe system.
column3: "The Japanese internet is a series of bamboo pipes" said one ignorant bureaucrat trying to draft Internet legislation.
column4: In Japan, bureaucrats only smoke from bamboo pipes. They're "too good" for cigarettes.

story: Luke, I am your father. Darth Vader (really surprised nobody put this one up before: 2 laserswords).
column3: Not to confuse anyone, but I think if you put your mind to it, you can see the image of a father here. The first two strokes take on the form of his eye brows, and the third and fourth stroke make up the nose and mustache.
column4: It is a pictograph of your dad tying his tie!

story: Your father uses his legs to stop himself from being put in a metal cauldron.
column3: Whilst on holiday, my father was captured by cannibals and put in a metal cauldron.
column4: 釜飯, 茶釜, 釜茹で, 電気釜, お釜, 釜 (#1367) かま ... Parts: 父+金 ... Similars: 鬲鬲, 鼎鼎 (#2878), 鍋鍋 (#1388) ... Fun Fact: this is slang for butt; and because of that it has become the word for male homosexual/transvestites お釜 (Okama); Always hard to tell with these sorts of words, but it seems matter of fact, and not loaded with hate. So, when you are making stories about lowering fathers into metal cauldrons....

story: Even though your FATHER is an old man, he can't give up his party lifestyle. Once a week he still dons his cool TOP HAT (well, it was cool 40 years ago) and goes out on the town to MINGLE with the ladies. This is a pretty common thing in Japan, where old motherfuckers still think they can pick up 19 year old girls.
column3: My father puts on a top hat and tries to mingle.
column4: Darth Vader tries to mingle with his troops. He even weares one of the helmets of the stromtroopers. (one of them laughs: white helmet, black suit. Darth Vader thereby slashes him in 2).

story: Mingling with the powerful can bring you success, bypassing the need for any merit.
column3: There is great merit in mingling with the powerful.
column4: Once again Heisig makes a keyword that doesn't make much sense. The real meaning is effect/efficacy (take your pick). My dad tried out both wearing a top hat and doing some body-building for his muscles to see which was more efficacious .

story: The people I had invited to the party were mingling quite well with one another, until they all suddenly started talking about the cars they own. Pretty soon the crowd divided itself into distinct, contrasting crowds: rich snobs with fancy cars, soccer moms with minivans, and hippies with bicycles.
column3: Our world of today, cars mingling on busy streets, is in stark contrast to the one of yesteryear, where it was people who would mingle on the streets.
column4: People mingle at parties. In contrast, cars mingle in traffic jams.

story: The schools that accepted them were posted on a TREE, the students MINGLED around trying to find their names. (コオ）.
column3: Note: this Kanji does not mean exam. It means school. I find this keyword an choice odd as school by itself is not used elsewhere. Examples: 校長 is principal (lit. school chief); 中学校 is junior high school (lit. middle study/knowledge school).
column4: Ninja school exam: Mingle with the trees. If the teacher can spot you, you fail.

story: Captain Ahab lost his leg to the great white whale's mouth and had to mend it with a peg leg.
column3: I'll use my mouth to mend your leg, I'll kiss it all better :).
column4: (Hint: if you do yourself a favour and call 足 (#1372) "foot" (for which it is the prefered kanji) and distinguish the measurement 呎 (#2960) (e.g."foot [measurement]") you can call 脚 (#1498) legs or leg (which is what it means), freeing up “shin” for its actual kanji (脛 (#2991))) The MOUTH of the shark bit off the pirate's foot (and then some), so he had to MEND it with a wooden leg. Primitive in middle/right=FOOT. Primitive on left=WOODEN LEG/PIRATE.

story: You stimulate a person by giving him a kick.
column3: Mr T, ever the optimist, is trying to stimulate Capt Ahab's wooden leg by rubbing it down. Capt Ahab normally wouldn't let anyone do that, but he appreciates Mr T's stimulating conversation.
column4: Mr. T is such an incredible masseuse that he can even stimulate a wooden leg. "I pity the peg that don't feel like a leg!"

story: I felt a finger on my leg as someone tried to nab my wallet.
column3: We almost nabbed the pirate. I had my FINGER on his WOODEN LEG.
column4: Fingers nabs Davy Jone's wooden leg: Argh! Bring me back me leg, ya scurvy dog!

story: You can step a long-distance if you have a leg that's gigantic!
column3: You can step a long-distance if you have gigantic wooden legs (stilts).
column4: Anything we might consider long-distance would be a truly gigantic distance for someone with a wooden leg.

story: When pirates try to hide, it's always easy to find them. Their wooden legs leave distinctive prints, showing where each is hiding and the exact path he took.
column3: I have a wooden leg for each type of path. One with a rubber stopper at the end for absorbing shocks on paved paths, and one with a wide foot to distribute weight better on mud paths.
column4: On the path to becoming a pirate, each one must gain a wooden leg.

story: After the rain the path was covered with dew.
column3: The path is always so wet with dew in the early hours that everyone assumes that it had rained.
column4: A lame Mountain Dew commercial: Someone is hiking on a path, when the latest rock music begins to play and it starts raining--to the extreme!!!!!!

story: A turtle with a wooden leg needs to hop to get around.
column3: A girl with a wooden leg always wanted to play hopscotch with the other girls, but every time she tried to hop she'd lose her balance and injure another girl. That's why the other girls make fun of her and see her presence as a portent to injury.
column4: Captain Ahab's peg leg is so sensitive to Moby Dick's presence that when Ahab starts hopping around the deck, it portends trouble.

story: [Story for people following katsuo in making feathers+turkey a 'futon' primitive] If you're going to leap from a high place, better hope there's a futon below -- otherwise you're going to break your leg at the very least...
column3: Well, there are weekdays 曜 (#618) and there are laundry days 濯 (#619), and on February 29th leap day, the manufacturer recommends servicing or replacing your peg leg because they tend to wear out every 4 years.
column4: Tip: feathers + turkey : This combination of primitives appears six times in Heisig, so it's worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest "futon" (your futon is made from turkey feathers). REF: 曜 (#618) , 濯 (#619), leap (FRAME 1285), 擢 (#2370), 燿 (#2594), 耀 (#2892). Story: I leap out of bed so fast that my wooden leg gets left behind in the futon.

story: Pirates must tread carefully when walking on parade floats, so as not to break through the weak plaster with their wooden legs.
column3: The pirate with the wooden leg chased after the parade float and was run over by the next one, leaving tread marks all over him and his leg.
column4: "Tread lightly with that damned wooden leg 足 of yours," he whispered, "or they'll hear us coming and we'll have two spears 戔 through us before you know it." This also means practice or practical. Older form 踐 clearly shows the two spears. 実践、じっせん, practice: 理論と実践は常に両立するとは限らない, "Theory and practice do not always combine harmoniously." 実践的、じっせんてき, practical.

story: You have to watch your step when moving your leg on a watery day.
column3: So, we've walked on the moon, but it's going to take a pirate with a wooden leg, with a huge supply of cooling water to land on the sun and take that "one small step for a man".
column4: This is better remembered as "step on" or trample. I picture a puddle of water with the sun reflected in it (to get the water above sun positioning), then you step on the puddle with your foot to trample the image.

story: The trail of the wooden leg religion was very easy to follow, since all its followers have wooden legs.
column3: Footprint: In the pirate(=leg) religion, footprints are important because they lead to treasure.
column4: Footprint: You can actually tell a pirates religion by the shape of their footprint. Catholic pirates have crucifix shaped peg legs, jewish ones have david's star, and muslim ones have crescent moon and star peg legs. PS Is anyone else finding all of the supplement keywords to be really poorly chosen?

story: Your body meat is attached to the bone joints of your skeleton.
column3: The top box 口 is the skull and the brain 田 has shriveled to the size of marble (but following kanji convention it is depicted as a square) and rolled into the bottom right hand corner. With all the hair and flesh gone the crown has slipped down to the shoulders like a necklace. 月 represents the rest of the body of the skeleton. [Idea for position of crown thanks to n1williams].
column4: The most awesome pictograph ever: It's a guy going through an x-ray examination. The crown primitive depicts a glowing power field that goes from the top of this head down to the floor, progressively revealing his skeleton. Now, it's at the position of his shoulders, so everything below it is still flesh.

story: Don't give water to a skeleton. When he drinks it, it'll sluice right through his bones, forcing you to put one of those "Caution - Slippery Floor" signs up on the resultant puddle.
column3: Slippery surfaces are very dangerous for skeletons, since their bone feet slip easily... a few drops of water, and zweep! A large mess of bones to pick up and reassemble!
column4: WET SKELETONS are notoriously SLIPPERY.

story: A skeleton is shuffling along the shoulder of the road, so you pull up next to him and ask where he is going. He says he's going to donate his marrow to the hospital because he got into some financial trouble and lost everything; his marrow is the only thing he still possesses.
column3: Did you know there are road ways in skeleton? Yeah, they are cool, they possess marrow.
column4: Pictograph: A skeleton walking along the sidewalk trips over breaking his arm and spills his only possession over the road, his precious marrow.

story: Continued from 祥 (#1169). Once a year, the people pray for a sign from the gods. But if the gods are feeling particularly mischievous, they'll send down a jawbone to the altar. The people see this as a sign of calamity to come. The gods think of it as an amusing prank.
column3: Bit of a calamity at the wedding. The bride tripped and broke her jawbone on the altar. Funniest home vids here we come.
column4: Well, for Jawbone I think of Samson and his JAWBONE of an ass. So, Samson caused great CALAMITY at the Philistine ALTAR when he attack the priesthood with that JAWBONE of an ass.

story: Grampa's flushing the toilet, when his denture (Jawbone) pops out and gets sucked down the whirlpool!
column3: A whirlpool is water opening its jaws to swallow anything whole.
column4: Jaws, the shark, sitting at the bottom of the whirlpool waiting for victims.

story: A metall pot with non-thermoconductive jawbones as handholds.
column3: A gruesome kind of cauldron that Snape might have used is a metal pot in the shape of a skull.
column4: A jawbone is thrown in a metal pot to make bone soup.

story: Jaws XII~! Jaws strikes the highway! Man, they're really overdoing it now.
column3: In 'American History X' Edward Norton's character overdoes it when he makes the dude that tried to steal his car lie face down with his jawbone open over the pavement of the roadway and then stamps on the back of his head. My teeth still tingle when I think of that!
column4: Grampa is in the old age marathon, but after a half mile on the road he is wheezing so hard he coughs up his dentures (Jawbone). Geez Grampa, don't overdo it man!

story: If you're scared of Heights, you don't want to stay at The Pinnacle; you are anti- The Pinnacle. Primitive: The Pinnacle is a dream-like gated community at the top of a mount. This allows for innumerable stories for all the kanji with this primitive since you have a whole city to work with. Also prevents confusion with "mountain".
column3: People are being displaced in 大阪 to make room for a new development, Osaka Heights, the pinnacle of modern Japanese housing. An angry mob of protestors are outside with Anti-Osaka Heights signs.
column4: This kanji is only used in names and in "Osaka". By chance, last week my japanese friend told me that it used to be 大坂(as in "slope"), but Hideyoshi, the Taiko, didnt want to have anything to do with "land" (his ascendance were farmers...) so he replaced the "earth" for what we call "pinnacle".　Its true. RTK2:　ハン　阪神　はんしん(Osaka and Kobe)… MIXED GROUP:　反722　坂723　板724　販726　版1213　飯1473　(ﾍﾝ): 返725　(ｶ): 仮966.

story: Can you see Africa from The Pinnacle? I can! I can!
column3: A kinda pictogram: 'BoT', the first 3 letters in 'Botswana' an African country.
column4: At the pinnacle of the Mt. Kilmanjaro imagine Chaka Zulu (famous African war commander) yelling at his troops, "are you an Afri-"can" or an Afri"can't?!" To get the pumped up for the next battle.

story: On occasian, rituals are held at the very tip of The Pinnacle.
column3: Many rituals are practiced every day (blessing before meals, evening prayer, etc.) Only the peak rituals (wedding, Bar Mitzvah, etc.) qualify to be called an occasion.
column4: They usually do the A-ritual, but on a special occasion they do the B-ritual.

story: The officer at the gate to The Pinnacle with a giant badge sewn to his chest hinders all visitors. But not the handicapped. They're hindered enough already. They're given a badge and can pass right into The Pinnacle.
column3: At the pinnacle I was awarded a badge so big that it hinders my movement.
column4: A bouncer stands outside The Pinnacle, hindering those without a VIP badge.

story: They won't let me in The Pinnacle, but I can see a little bit of sun through this little chink in the wall. Hmm, maybe I could make this chink bigger...
column3: There was only one chink in his plan. Even standing atop the highest pinnacle, standing above even the sun, the little man was still just as little as when he was under the sun.
column4: From the pinnacle 阝of the hill, he could just see the sun 日 peeking through two 小 little 小 chinks in the clouds. 間隙、かんげき, gap; 隙間、すきま, crevice, crack, gap: 塀の隙間から猫が入ってきました, "A cat came in through the gap in the fence."

story: [Image: Follow the 'Yellow-Brick Road' to success] The pinnacle signifies your personal goal and destination. What you're seeking to possess lies at the end of the yellow-brick road. You must follow the road to get what you want.
column3: This story is about lemmings. when the first takes a road that falls off a pinnacle, the rest follow as if possessed.
column4: Those who possess a map of the road to the pinnacle are the best people to follow.

story: In case of emergency, The Pinnacle has auxiliary guard dogs, but they keep them muzzeled until they're needed.
column3: When you climb the pinnacle you'll need to take a muzzle of auxiliary oxygen.
column4: Hint: This is a very rarely used kanji and the only relatively common word that contain it is 陪審 「ばいしん」 (meaning jury, juryman). I recommend using one of these meanings as a keyword, since you are not going to see it anywhere else unless you intend to read historic novels. [Trivia: The other meaning of this kanji is something in the spirit of subordinate. Look it up on wwwjdic if you are curious.]

story: A kid is perched on a pinnacle with his piggy bank. He uses the coins to catch the sunshine, and redirect it into people's eyes, far below.
column3: The Pinnacle is environmentally friendly. They collect solar power through sunshine on their piggybank shaped solar arrays.
column4: At the Pinnacle, they use solar collectors, sun piggy banks, if you will, to capture the sunlight.

story: Every morning at The Pinnacle, the residents line upon the East side for morning stretches and leisure.
column3: Hikers line up to get to the top of that great pinnacle of the East... Mount Fuji. Seriously, they really do! ...probably the only mountain in the world with a queue at the top.
column4: This is not "people in a line". This is "a line up" like a line up of shows or performers. @gavmck At The Pinnacle they are having an exhibition of Oriental art where you can see all kinds of amazing artifacts lined up.

story: A giant compass is The Pinnacle's self-defense system. It points in the direction of any invaders so the city is prepared well ahead to ward off the intruders.
column3: On the pinnacle you can see in every direction and can ward off attacks or invasions.
column4: To ward off enemies, the ancient Greece kept watch from the Acropolis, where they had a clear view in all directions.

story: A sign was AFFIXED on the PINNACLE of the Acropolis so that tourists would ADHERE to the rules.
column3: Signs are affixed to walls in The Pinnacle to ensure tourists adhere to the rules.
column4: The Pinnacle is firmly affixed to the top of the mount with bubble gum. (付 (#1075)).

story: The Institution of The Pinnacle is perfect in every way. It is the new House of God, his chosen city.
column3: To reach the pinnacle of kanji perfect you need to attend the Heisig Inst.
column4: The Inst. of Kanji.Koohii. It's where we all try to get to the pinnacle of Japanese by perfecting our kanji writing skills.

story: Note: This kanji is most often used in a military context. Story: Here we see an encampment of military vehicles laying siege to The Pinnacle. With other countries being envious of the perfect life they lead there that makes sense. Fortunately, the pinnacle knows how to 防 (#1302) enemies.
column3: Paparazzi make camp outside of The Pinnacle in their cars, waiting for the celebs to come out.
column4: At the pinnacle of Mt. Everest, you can camp, but you cannot find a parking place for your car!

story: Every regiment of The Pinnacle's army is lead by a Miss Piggy with a viking helmet on.
column3: Every regiment of The Pinnacle's army has an animal name. This regiment is called "Horned Pig Regiment". They're wearing Wiking helms and are usually cowered in mud.
column4: The Pinnacle is guarded by a flying regiment of horny pigs.

story: One of the members of our air force regiment has been shot down; he managed to safely eject, but his plane crashed into the ground.
column3: The regiment led by horny Miss Piggy wearing a viking helmet accidently falls off The Pinnacle and crashes into the ground below. // old story with wrong meaning of regiment: Kermit is so frustrated with horny Miss Piggy's regimented sex schedule, he throws her off The Pinnacle and she crashes into the ground.
column4: Horn-helmeted Miss Piggy and her regiment of Valkyries really believed they could fly just like real Valkyries (yeah, and pigs might fly) so they launched themselves from the parapet of The Pinnacle. Of course they crashed to the ground (soil).

story: "Sunglasses-missing-one-lens" is obviously the monocle. The proper, high-class way to descend The Pinnacle is wearing a monocle with your walking legs splayed to a full gentlemanly stride.
column3: Used in 降りる 【おりる】（to alight or get off - e.g. from a bus). So here we have a tour bus arriving at the acropolis: Everyone descends from the bus, stretches their walking legs and puts on their monocles. (EDIT: fixed up primitives).
column4: After a cool, hip businessman angered the executives at The Pinnacle, they beat him up, popping out a lens from his sunglasses, and tossed out the window, head first, walking legs second. One executive later commented, "It was like he was descending into Hell from Heaven!"

story: All buildings of The Pinnacle are multi-storey. They don't have much room, so they have to build up. It sucks when someone presses all the buttons on the elevator! You have to stop at each storey!
column3: Some stupid kid has pushed all the buttons in the elevator. As it stops at all storeys you reach a pinnacle of impatience. Finally you reach your storey, the last one, at the pinnacle of the building.
column4: The pinnacle of a building is the sum of all the storeys.

story: Your highness is the pinnacle of finesse compared to all of us commoners who are but like dirt on the ground.
column3: His Highness, the main man at the Pinnacle, often compares those who live outside the city's walls to dirt.
column4: One of the many talents of the highness of The Pinnacle is his astounding knowledge of soils. He can compare any two soil samples brought to him.

story: America thinks it is the pinnacle of the world, looking down on all neighboring countries through its mirrored, aviator sunglasses.
column3: All the neighboring communities to the Pinnacle have a major problem. The kids at the Pinnacle have a habit of throwing down rice from the city walls in all directions, so people in neighboring communities are forced to wear sunglasses all the time in order to avoid getting rice in their eyes.
column4: Tip: rice + sunglasses : In RTK3 Heisig names this combination "shoeshine". It also appears in: 憐 (#2208), 燐 (#2209), 麟 (#2210), 鱗 (#2211). Story: You visit the Acropolis and are amazed to see the guy from your neighboring house back home working there as a shoeshiner.

story: The Pinnacle, to me, is a city that makes itself out to be perfect but is filled with dirty secrets that photographers are always trying to reveal (see 融 (#1123) The city's councilmen have isolated all professional photographers to make sure they don't photograph these "dirty secrets". (which are up to your imagination).
column3: Sadly, since the Pinnacle is isolated, they have no modern technology. Their only means of photography is an old camera. What's that? Forgot how old cameras work? Let me show you: Light is captured through the lens (one mouth), the photographer is in a giant hood, all you can see out of it are his human legs. He holds his flash controller(a spike) in hand.
column4: Do you remember the poor insect in 融 (#1123)? Actually, it was not dissolved - it was beamed right into the pinnacle prison for committing the crime of disturbing a photographer preparing for a snapshot and now lives isolated until the end of its three days long life... (note: 隔てる (へだてる) also means to disturb ones view).

story: The wheat farmer's heart is 穏 (#1230) about the eagle not stealing his crops because of the broom scarecrow. But he still conceals all his wheat at The Pinnacle in case anyone else trys to steal it.
column3: Move the broom with a vulture perched on top, and you'll find the concealed entrance to the heart of The Pinnacle.
column4: People of the pinnacle learned to conceal their nature with calm demeanors, though in their hearts they are vultures and witches (broom).

story: Any attempt to possess the pinnacle will degenerate into a land ("ground") war.
column3: The Pinnacle has degenerated into an group that just tries to possess as much soil as possible.
column4: The Pinnacle of the Roman Empire (as with many other empires since) degenerated as they just tried to possess more & more land. " like . . . . . . duh!('ダ') " // お.ちる / ダ duo4 타 (ta) 휴 (hyu).

story: The Pinnacle is actually bound up by supports from olden times. Eventually, they give out, and the whole thing starts to collapse.
column3: The Pinnacle is supported by pilings which were bound up in olden times. One day when the bindings rot away, the whole thing will collapse. (tweaking dihutensoa's story to work a little better for me).
column4: At the pinnacle of any society's development, being overly bound to rules from olden times leads to collapse (see Jared Diamond's Collapse).

story: A black hole is a "House of Infinity". Infinity is of course represented by a sideways "8", but here we have a Japanese "8" instead.
column3: Billiards anyone? House rules here state that the first person to pot the eight ball into the hole wins the game.
column4: What good is it to buy a house with 8 holes in the ceiling? (The kanji for 8 also looks like water flowing from the ceiling.)

story: The craft of creating a black hole is in creating an emptiness which can attract things.
column3: Hole-craft is the way of making empty spaces, like the sky.
column4: The craft of making donut holes.....the middle of the donut is empty.

story: With my fingers, I punch in my bank code and withdraw some money from my account. And now it's empty again, as usual!
column3: If you find yourself in a fight with a karate master with no weapons or martial art skills, just your empty fingers, you should withdraw because 空手 (karate="empty hand") is more powerful than 控 (="empty fingers").
column4: This is a bit of an odd keyword choice from Heisig. "Withhold" would work a lot better considering how this kanji is used. As in restrain/hold yourself back (控える) or withhold/deduct taxes (控除) or withholding a spare/reserve copy (控え).

story: When you stab something you often leave a big hole.
column3: The police have recruited a special breed of St. Bernard that can lick the wounds of a stabbing victim. The bleeding will stop instantly, saving the victim's life. One quirky side-effect, however, is that this treatment leaves behind a rather large hole...
column4: There's a hole in that Saint Bernard -- somebody stabbed it.

story: Most research scientists have 9 holes.....two nostrils, two ears, a mouth, and four eyes...... :-).
column3: Scientiest are researching , and have already found nine black holes !
column4: The manager is doing research to find the holes in the opposing baseball team's strategy.

story: Sticking a plug up your hole will lead to stronger climaxes.
column3: I'm pretty sure Heisig wrote the whole book just so he could make this joke.
column4: Yet another Freudian kanji - plug up a hole, and the result is climax. Do we really need to spell this out any more explicitly? Don't mix up with 栓 (#282). Plug up has a slightly more sexual connotation.

story: The word STEALTH makes me instantly think of Solid Snake, who CUTS a HOLE in a cardboard box so he can peer out of it. 窃盗　せっとう 窃視　せっし.
column3: I picture a stealthy thief cutting a round hole in the glass window to quietly unlock it.
column4: Stealth bombers cut holes through the enemy radar.

story: You are digging a HOLE; suddenly the ground begins to YIELD, and before you know it you've discovered a CAVERN.
column3: After Osama blew a hole in NY, the counterreaction forced him to yield and retreat into caverns.
column4: In "The Empire Strikes Back", the Milennium Falcon flies into a large hole, of what they think is a cavern, because they don't want to yield to the forces of the Empire. Turns out it's not a cavern at all, actually...

story: A depression is a hole in the ground. Water naturally collects there which provides moisture for vines to grow.
column3: The depression in the ground become a trap: the hole was filled with water and covered with ivy.
column4: The meaning of this character is an indentation in the ground, not emotional depression. It's best to avoid using the latter in your story because it will give you the wrong meaning (keep in mind the eventual goal is to read kanji and understand the actual meaning of them). This particular depression is a hole in the ground that collects water, and ivy is growing out of it.

story: Very simple visual image makes this an easy kanji to remember. Just picture that you SQUEEZE your FINGERS going through the HOLE in the handle of the SAW. You then SQUEEZE your FINGERS tight to use the SAW to cut a HOLE.
column3: To squeeze is to hold something 窄 (#2660) in your fingers.
column4: Oh no! You cut a hole in your finger with a saw! Squeeze your finger to stop the bleeding!!

story: Be sure to put a hole in that ceramic sheep before you put it over the fire. Otherwise, it'll just explode in the kiln. (If you've never done ceramics before, it's important that the object have a hole in it, or this really will happen.)
column3: You put the sheep in the hole of the kiln and turn on the flames.
column4: True story: when I was a kid if there were lambs born in the winter we'd put them in a cardboard box and put them in the oven (on low!) to keep them warm. I guess this only really helps me out hehehe...

story: Hard up = nothing but your body, living in a hole, with just a bow to hunt for your food.
column3: Somebody so hard up for cash, the volunteered to explore a black hole with nothing but a bow.
column4: Ok, picture a HOLE (well, more a pit trap) that SOMEBODY (well, a hunter with a BOW) just fell in. He's dangling over the HOLE holding onto his BOW across it. SOMEBODY finds it's HARD to get UP out of the HOLE. That great visual image should grant mastery of this kanji.

story: Note: "crown+human legs" appears 7 times in RTK. In 4 cases (nos. 323, 1327, 1328, 2920) crown is above human legs, and in the other 3 (1888, 2472, 2679) one leg passes through the crown. I call the 1st pattern "Miss World" (who is wearing a crown & has long human legs) and the 2nd "garter" (one human leg passes through the crown wearing it as a garter). Story: Miss World has climbed a tree to avoid the finger that was groping for her. (探 means "grope for", i.e. search).
column3: I don't know why, but this is a pictograph of someone groping about in the dark (with his fingers, obviously) for his beloved wooden paper punch.
column4: As esaulgd said, this kanji DOES NOT mean "touch" like 触る。Here is my story: Imagine a blind detective who must GROPE for answers in by reading old police reports. But because he is blind, he must use brail books, you know, the ones that have been PAPER PUNCHED on PAPER (wood). Naturally, he uses his FINGERS for this.

story: Thrown in deep water, the Japanese School girl tries to reach a floating tree to save herself.
column3: Made a hole with a paper punch in a tree, so deep that water started flowing out.
column4: Miss World (see Katsuo's note on 探 (#1425)) is now hiding on a tree because now she is afraid of the deep water below.

story: Excalibur is the sword planted in a rock. Lesser known AXCAHILLBUR is the axe planted on top of a hill.
column3: At Capitol Hill proposals get axed on the floor.
column4: I climbed to the top of a hill but didn't have a flag so I stuck my axe in the ground in order to mark my momentous ascent.

story: A point is a extra little hill at the top of a mountain. We'll call it 'Fireman's Point'.
column3: This actually means a high mountain. So, to cater to the keyword, it's surely obvious (ahem) that if something gets such a fine title as Point, it must be more magnificent than the average mountain. It's as if there was a hill on top of an average mountain, adding to its height.
column4: I chopped off the point of the mountain with my axe. Now it is just a hill.

story: Listen up soldiers! We're going to take that hill. You are no longer men with human legs. You are voracious animals, with animal legs! Got it? Animal legs! Now take that hill!
column3: The hill is so steep that you almost have to have animal legs to walk on it. However, the soldiers have no problem because they've been trained to march there.
column4: Soldiers specially designed for combat in the hills have got their lower body replaced by that of a mountain goat. Picture them hopping up the hills like silly little centaurs with their new animal legs!

story: Seacoast -> Coast Guard -> "water soldiers" lined up on the seacoast defending our shores.
column3: Imagine Normandy after the strikes on the beach. The water of the entire seacoast dyed red with the blood of thousands of soldiers.
column4: The seacoast is where the marines assault. Marines are water soldiers. 浜 (はま) : beach, seashore.

story: I also went with Spiderman. However, in the cases where this primitive appears under other primitives, as opposed to on the left (I think there are ~5 times in this chapter) I've opted to use a similar character: Venom. This helps keep the positioning clear, especially on such characters as 細 (#1463) and 累 (#1464).
column3: On left with nothing on top of it --> SPIDERMAN. everywhere else....SPIDERPIG.
column4: I didn't see a story explicitly pointing this out, but the top part of the character is "cocoon" and the bottom "little". Silkworms are needed to make silk. A silkworm is basically a caterpillar-like creature that makes a silk cocoon around itself so that it can turn into a moth. Hence, thread from a little cocoon.

story: Spiderman weaves his way through the skyline while listening to his theme song on his ipod. It is played, of course, by kazoos.
column3: Spiderman's housemate insists on playing the kazoo every night, despite Spiderman's protests. Eventually, Spiderman can't bear it anymore and weaves a tight web around his housemate's face to prevent him from playing the kazoo. 織布 (しょくふ): woven cloth, fabric 織物 (おりもの): fabric, textile.
column4: Play the kazoo magically and the thread will weave itself.

story: After a day being virtuouos and keeping the city safe, Spiderman's outfit is in need of some repair. Luckily, as he can shoot out threads darning is very easy for him to do.
column3: Darning is too obscure a word for me, I prefer to just think of it as repair. And obviously, repairing someones broken cloth things is a virtuous thing to do, and you need thread to do it.
column4: Spiderman is of course virtuous and spends a lot of time darning his costume after battles so that his privates don't show.

story: After spending the night at an inn, spider man discovered to his dismay that his costume had shrunk in the wash, and no longer fit!
column3: Don't let the Inn wash your threads, they will shrink them!
column4: Spiderman spends the night at a traditional Japanese 宿 (#1070), to spend time with his friend Mr T snorting cocaine under the ceiling. Alas, that's not cocaine, it's one of those magic mushrooms from Alice in Wonderland. Spiderman and Mr T start to shrink.

story: Important: Luxuriant does NOT mean luxurious, as the other stories indicate. Definition: abundant or lush in growth, as vegetation. When Venom realized he couldn't beat Spider-Man in a fair fight, he showed his cleverness by spraying venom all over Spider-Man's luxuriant garden.
column3: Key word is luxuriant (abundant or lush in growth, as vegetation; teeming). Venom uses his cleverness to create a luxuriant garden, teeming with luxuriant vegetation, in a bid to lure Mary Jane into his clutches. (Thanks esaulgd.)
column4: The clever use of threads can make your garden look more luxuriant. Just tie the threads around the plants and bend them into the optimal position to give the illusion there are more than there really are.

story: When Spider-man does his amazing vertical wall climbing, a throng of photographers accompanies him to get a good shot of the action.
column3: You may only accompany spiderman if you're able to climb buildings vertically.
column4: True vertical can be found by hanging a plumb line - a thread accompanied by a weight.

story: This kanji shows Spiderman giving a dress of the finest thread to his girlfriend. Of course, the real purpose of the gift is to get his girlfriend to doth him.
column3: fine: If the thread doth fit through the eye of the needle, it is fine thread indeed.
column4: Fine. The new Goth Spiderman doth wear a costume made from black spider silk of the finest weave. 緻密・ちみつ close, minute, elaborate, intricate.

story: This kanji is used for train lines. Spiderman does a hot spring tour of Japan using the train lines. You can see the Spidey costume hanging on the washing line as he enjoys the onsen.
column3: Japan's train lines are like threads that spring from Tokyo station.
column4: Spiderman usually just travels by web, but when he goes to visit the hot spring, he has to take several train lines instead, since there are no buildings to swing from. [He tried swinging from power lines once--big mistake].

story: Even though his costume is coming apart at the seams as he chases the bad guys, Spiderman is still determined to catch them.
column3: Spiderman is so determined to catch criminals that he doesn't notice his costume is coming apart at the seams. The Daily Bugle will love this! "Spider-pervert terrorizes city!"
column4: The quality of the thread will determine whether your clothing will come apart at the seams.

story: (astridtops) Spiderman managed to get behind the sovereign. (pick your favourite nowadays country ruler who isn't doing a good job). Spidey has tightend a web around the sovereing's throat. As long as the sovereign says what spidey whispers, he will be fine. Sovereign yelping : ' we will draw are troops back! and we will spend more money on healthcare, schools and less on wars!' Spidey whispering: ' If you continue at this pace, you might be doing good things AND the people will like you.'
column3: The sovereign appears to be ruling, but in reality someone behind him (for instance his wife) has a thread around his throat, and if he dares to make a decision she doesn't like, she starts pulling the thread and tightens it around his throat.
column4: The Sovereign (a crazy comic book villain) has been caught by Spiderman. He's trying to get free so Spiderman tightens the web around him.

story: Hey, Spidey! Eat that turkey if you want, but make sure you eat some fibers: you want spidey threads, don't ya?
column3: If you want to increase your fiber intake, just leave on those threads that are used to sew up the stuffed turkey and eat them too.
column4: Feeling mischievous while shopping, Spiderman throws his web into the cavity of a turkey. He chuckles, "That ought to raise the turkey's FIBER content."

story: Lots of girls in Japan wear gauze patches over one eye made of course white fibers. They think it is cute, and I must admit, I have come to think so too.
column3: Rocky won the match but left with a nasty eye injury, and needs some gauze for it. I use a modified version of the Rocky theme song to remember this one -- "the eye and the fiber".
column4: The eyes on Spiderman's mask are made of carbon fibre gauze. Light, strong and see-through.

story: Spidey stays on the east side of the city to practice. The West Side is too dangerous.
column3: [+ skinnyneo] Spiderman visits the East to practice his swinging skills. All those Asian cities with skyscrapers and low crime rates make it easy for him to practice.
column4: After being defeated one too many times, Spiderman heads East to the Orient in order to practice various martial arts.

story: Spiderman has a secret fetish, he likes nothing better than to dress his lovedoll in a thong. Wierd, eh!
column3: A thong is no more than a thread used by someone as underwear!
column4: Everybody here talking about underwear just to remember the key word... People check your English and Japanese dictionaries. This kanji has NOTHING to do with underwear. Heisig had a different "thong" in mind. Maybe rename it to strap or something if you only know the underwear-thong-thingy. Story: Imagine a tiny puppet (or 者 (#1345)) strapped to a tiny chair with a 糸 (#1431). For this tiny puppet/someone this thread is thick and robust as a thong/strap.

story: Even though Peter Parker has become Spiderman, he continues to sell pictures that he takes as a photographer.
column3: Here's how Spiderman comics sell: At the end of the comic they leave with with a cliffhanger and say "to be continued". In fact, the japanese verb 続く is used in comics and tv shows to mean "to be continued". They have adapted the model created by Spiderman to hook the readers so that they can sell more comics.
column4: Spiderman's comics continue to sell after several decades. (Even the goofy samurai with his log-crown toys is selling spiderman).

story: There's never a picture of Spiderman meeting Peter Parker... I wonder why?
column3: Peter Parker's editor tells him "Next time you have a meeting with spiderman take a goddamn picture, you're a photographer after all".
column4: A picture is just a matter of the harmonious meeting of lines. The many threads of a brush meet together on paper, finally forming a painting.

story: Spidey is alloted the biggest crime fighter jurisdiction in NYC because his OVERALL arrest record is the best.
column3: According to Greek mythology, there's a thread alloted to everyone, and its length is the overall determinant of your fate.
column4: SPIDERMAN was originally ALLOTTED some overalls by the Superheroes' Guild, but he rejected them in favor of his current outfit.

story: Spiderman hates going to parties and having to mingle. He wants to strangle someone after just a little small talk.
column3: Spidermancame out of nowhere and started to strangle me, when I was right in the middle of mingling with this cute girl named Mary Jane.
column4: Darth Vader, who was mingling among the crowd with his hat, is spotted by Spiderman. Spiderman jumps at him to teach the villain for coming to New York. Darth Vader catches him in mid air and strangles him with the force...

story: Spiderman wanted to be a salaryman, but the suit just didn't fit him.
column3: The quality of the threads one wears generally fits with one's salary.
column4: Spiderman has so little free time in his schedule that he is unable to fit in a job with a good salary.

story: When threads become entwined, each thread is tangled to another.
column3: Spiderman entwines each villain in a tangled mess of spidersilk.
column4: "Stop thief!" yells the greengrocer. The thief doesn't, so Spidey saves the day by entwining the crook in a web, and dangling him walking legs over mouth.

story: Ok, here, you have to think of the phrase "TIE the knot" , which means a wedding (this kanji is used in the marriage compound 結婚 けっこん ). Now, at US weddings, it ends with the couple driving away with cans being dragged behind the car. So here, think of SPIDERMAN, who will TIE the knot with Mary Jane. At his wedding, Spider THREAD attached (or TIED) to SPRAYCANS are being drug behind the limo as they drive off.
column3: Spidey ties up the villain in a web of threads. "Good luck getting out of that, heh heh!"
column4: Spiderman and a fan have a competition to see who can tie up the most enemies fastest. Spidey's using his webs and the fan is using an aerosol can of silly string. So far they are tied.

story: This winter is so cold that spiderman's web gets brittle! Could this be the end of spiderman?
column3: Spider-Man can't wait for winter to end. Going outside in spandex isn't exactly toasty.
column4: The thread of life begins with the spring and ends with the winter.

story: This Kanji is the same ones used in the Japanese Language proficiency tests; i.e. ikkyuu (一級) The Kanji doesnt describe class as in a "class of students" or "classroom," but rather a grade of quality or ability. ---------- Spiderman is taking the JLPT Level 1. In desperation he REACHES OUT to grab his friend's answer sheet next to him, who seems to be doing well. The other test takers are obviously a class above him. Looks like this test is above his class of knowledge.
column3: Spider-Man reaches out to every class, rich and poor.
column4: Class, grade, rank. Members of a particular class or rank are connected (as if by a thread) by their similarities and common circumstances; and often, by the extent to which they will reach out and exert themselves to new heights. 下級(low grade). 学級(school class). 勤労階級(working class). 最高級(top class). 審級(instance). 上級(advanced level, senior). 中級(intermediate level). 飛び級(skipping a grade). 上の級に進む(to move up to a higher grade).

story: Worst fan fiction ever....SPIDERMAN joins the CHRONICLES of narnia to battle a big SNAKE!!
column3: In a CHRONICLE the THREAD of the story can twist and turn like a SNAKE.
column4: Spider-Man reads his self-chronicle every week when the newest comic comes out.

story: Spiderman crafted a crimson costume to fight crime in.
column3: After Spider-Man is whacked in the head with a I-beam, crimson blood flows from the wound.
column4: As this kanji is used to describe black (or "crimson") English tea, think of the craftsmanship involved in the production of the tea, from the tea leaves, to the paper bag, right down to the thread you use to dangle it in the cup.

story: Have you heard about patients who have surgery and the doctor mistakenly leaves a medical instrument INSIDE the patient’s body and proceeds to stitch up the patient’s incisions with stitching THREAD? Can you say “malpractice SETTLEMENT”?　.
column3: Spider-Man was working as a surgeon's assistant. By accident, he threw his spider webs inside the patient, causing his death. Fortunately, the hospital reached an out-of-court settlement with the victim's family.
column4: Another twist on the same theme: malpractise settlement for leaving a plastic spiderman inside patient.

story: Spiderman can spin his webs in any direction.
column3: "You keep me spinning right round, baby right round, like a compass baby." Spidey is making a retro 80s music video, spinning right round on his giant compass, singing his favourite song.
column4: Spiderman is spinning around, shooting webs in every direction.

story: Spiderman got distracted when someone yelled, "Spiderman, wait a minute." He turned around and flew into a building. ("part" also means "minute").
