column3: Due to the distractions of being a super-hero, spiderman can only work part-time. (variation on ayoung24's story).
column4: Distract = to lose the thread of thought in part, i.e. not completely.

story: Spiderman seduces all the girls he's introduced to.
column3: Peter Parker did a terrible job of seducing MJ. Spiderman however, seduced her as soon as they were first introduced.
column4: The first thread of a seduction is an introduction.

story: The word ‘sutra’ literally means a rope or thread that holds things together. Here we see that it is a spool that is holding the threads together.
column3: Suggestion: Replace "spool" with "toilet paper/roll". Reasons: (1) Toilet paper/roll usually comes on a spool. (2) Toilet paper is used to clean the soil off your crotch. Story: Spiderman (= thread) has a roll of toilet paper with the words of a sutra printed on each sheet (picture Spiderman saying the sutra as he tears sheets off the toilet roll). Spool also appears in 茎 (#715), 怪 (#716), 軽 (#717), 径 (#882).
column4: Note: this kanji shows up a lot in economics-related words. In fact, 経済 (けいざい) is economics. I see it there a lot more than sutra-related words... Story: Spools of thread used to drive the economics of the day. Imagine an oxymoronic Buddhist sutra used to guide you through the world of thread finance.

story: Monkeys are very adept at swinging around trees. But when they met Spiderman, who could swing around even better than they could, they all quickly addressed him as sire.
column3: Spiderman married a monkey and sired a brood of spider-monkeys.
column4: When conversing with a sire (noble person) you should always use proper words like "speaketh" and allow them to set the thread of the conversation.

story: Anytime Spiderman breaks a promise, Aunt Mae hits him one over with her ladle.
column3: Spiderman promised to get Aunt Mae's ladle back. He started to do a blood oath by spilling drops of blood but Aunt Mae stopped him and bound up the wound. "It's only a ladle Peter".
column4: Thread + bound + drop of blood. Blood oath is a promise, where a drop of blood turns into a binding thread.

story: Dainty women would always rather work with thread than in a field.
column3: Spider-Man used to just be a dainty, brainy nerd.
column4: Spider-Man's ideal type is a dainty girl with brains.

story: (dingomick) Venom is upset because Spidey is just that much brainier than he is! He chooses to accumulate as many brains as he can, snatching them out of people's heads and storing them on top of his own, till there's just one massive brain on top of his head!
column3: When you accumulate knowledge in your brain, neural pathways are constructed. All those pathways end up like a huge ball of thread tangled together. The more knowledge you accumulate the more threads you throw into the mix!!
column4: Like a jellyfish, a floating BRAIN accumulates THREADS beneath it-- a weird collection.

story: (modified akrodha's great story) VENOM has been captured by scientists and is being experimented on: they forced a CROWN of NEEDLES on his head and attached it to multiple electrical cords, which are connected to a big machine.
column3: Spiderman has been captured and given the ultimate torture: they forced a crown of needles on his head and attached it to an electrical cord, which they are about to plug into an outlet...
column4: An electrical cord has two (or three) prongs - needles - sticking out of it, a housing for the prongs that can be thought of as a crown, and the long thread-like wire leading to the appliance.

story: Spiderman could not achieve general acceptance by the media even after winning the public's heart.
column3: NOTE: This kanji stands for [Total, All, whole, gross]. The Kanji commonly used for "In general" will appear later as 般 (#2016).
column4: To win GENERAL approval THREAD your way into the PUBLIC's HEART.

story: Spiderman's polyethylene suit starts to ride up after a while, so he always looks forward to the white cotton towels he wears while lounging around his apartment.
column3: Cotton is the preferred thread for making white towels.
column4: Spiderman has a dark secret - he has stolen all the white cotton towels from every hotel he has ever been in.

story: Spider-man loves to run his mouth all over Mary Jane's silky flesh.
column3: Spiderman has little squares in the flesh of his wrists that the silk webbing comes out of.
column4: [silk] Silk is a thread that a larvae produces from its mouth to involve its body.

story: After stopping a bank heist, Spiderman is seen winding his webbing around the stolen goods to trap them in a tree until the police arrive to take them back.
column3: Tip: goods + wood/tree : This combination appears 4 times. I suggest calling it "furniture" (a common type of wooden goods). REF: 燥 (#228) , 操 (#724), winding (FRAME 1369), 藻 (#2191). Story: You are winding up your new furniture using a thread to get it through the window of your high-rise apartment.
column4: Spiderman often accidentally breaks his furniture (thanks Katsuo!) with his spider strength, so he is often seen winding up his webbing to drag a new piece up through his window.

story: Spider-Man is hooked on rice--it's all he inherited from his Uncle Ben. (thanks Nukemarine).
column3: A poor chinese fisherman could expect to inherit: the thread for his pole, a hook for catching something to eat, and some rice to live off of. (not concentrating on stroke order, sorry if that throws anyone off). (Adapted from bigloui,12-4-2006).
column4: The INHERITANCE given to SPIDERMAN was only RICE, because it came from his "Uncle Ben", ha ha ha, get the HOOK? "Uncle Ben" RICE? To be fair, I couldn't work hook into that tale very well.

story: Spiderman's nemesis the Green Goblin is in a slump; He's replaced his glider with a broom and is throwing grains of rice instead of bombs.
column3: Tie green thread around the broom that you use for sweeping up grains of rice (ie the kitchen broom) to distinguish it from the other colour threaded brooms that you might use in say the toilet, or the garage etc...
column4: Hint : I think of the little broom used for preparing Japanese green tea.

story: There once was a lonely little pig that constantly followed Spiderman, always nuzzling his leg and oinking tenderly. Spiderman finally caved in and decided to keep the little pig under one condition: the pig was to take a broom and sweep up all of Spiderman's leftover threads after having fought crime. The pig felt such affinity for Spiderman, he happily accepted—and did a good job too.
column3: Spiderman has no affinity for a broom hence his house is a pig sty.
column4: I hate doing this, since the Simpson's Movie was recent. But think of the AFFINITY Homer had with the PIG that was to be killed. The AFFINITY first had SPIDER PIG (Spiderpig, spiderpig, does whatever a spiderpig does). Then Homer dressed the PIG up with a BROOM and glasses making him Harry PORKER. Homer had more AFFINITY for that PIG than his family, hence hilarity ensues.

story: Spiderman traps The Rhino under the hood of his famous netting, where even Rhino's horns can not break free, in fact if the netting did not dissappear after a few hours then Rhino might even perish in there.
column3: You use a 糸 to make a net shaped like a hood. A stray animal got caught in it by its horns and perished.
column4: Sadly, sometimes nettings have a thread so strong, the net gets caught like a hood on an animal's horns, and stays there until the poor thing perishes.

story: Whenever Venom is tense, he loses control of his sex drive and becomes a slave to his crotch.
column3: TIP: This is the first kanji in "kinbaku" (緊縛), the art of Japanese rope bondage. STORY: The slave's crotch is tied up with rope (thread) to heighten the sado-erotic tension... 緊張[きんちょう].
column4: You'd be tense too if you were a slave and your owner removed the threads covering your crotch.

story: Venom starts to choke on a spoon. He's about to get it out, when you manage to stop the spoon from getting out, so he turns purple, as he chokes, and dies.
column3: Why is your ass purple? Well, I stopped and sat for a bit on a pile of thread... (I guess it was freshly dyed).
column4: If you use Venom for the lower primitive, this kanji is a piece of cake. The upper primitive is the left part of 雌 (#605). So, PURPLE is the color of Agony, the female offspring of Venom http://2.bp.blogspot.com/_hmOfolKlLFI/SN1l3LqagTI/AAAAAAAAA1Q/7tEpxy-Bfu0/s1600-h/agony.jpg http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agony_%28comics%29.

story: Spidey received good word that the acupuncturist working down the road was actually the evil Doctor Octopus! Spidey headed over to the clinic, and trussed the acupuncturist Doc Oc up using the maniac's own metal limbs!
column3: Because people are so afraid of the procedure, string has to be used by the acunpunturist to truss up his victims, er, patients.
column4: Ok, I already finished RtK, I'm coming back to warn you about this one - the right primitive is acupuncturist, not specialty. Trust me, mixing these up will mess you up later.

story: The tortoise has escaped! We tied it up with a straw rope, but all that's left of the rope are some torn threads, and the unbound tortoise is nowhere to be found. (Note that the right half here is not "eels". This is (in my opinion) a mistake in the RTK book, as we already decided in 滝 (#537) to refer to the simplified form of dragon as "eels". It is much better to call the right half of this character an "unbound tortoise".)
column3: When Spiderman fights the giant tortoise, he grabs a straw rope from the edges of the sumo ring and swings it at his head. However, the tortoise quickly tucks his head back into his shell to avoid the blow (hence no head on the tortoise).
column4: Our friendly neighborhood Spider-Man takes off the straw rope that was binding the tortoise.

story: In its infancy, a butterfly is protected by a cocoon, as it doesn't yet have any power of its own.
column3: During their infancy, children are often wrapped up tight like a cocoon (i.e. in those Snugli carriers) and supported by the muscle of their parents.
column4: During INFANCY the moth in its COCOON gains its POWER.

story: Column of walking legs (caterpillar) getting into a cocoon, about to leave its past self behind.
column3: after a grub goes through the cocoon stage, it leaves its walking legs behind for a life of flight.
column4: Think of a column of ants moving to a new nest. The soldiers are in front. The workers are behind carrying the cocoons on their long walking legs.

story: The villagers haven't the faintest idea that giant coccoons resting in the mountain are soon to hatch.
column3: Hint: this is faint as in dim, weak or indistinct, not the verb.
column4: Two people wrapped in their sleeping bags like cocoons are secluded in the mountains and can't hear the faintest sound.

story: At the Mexican fiesta, there is a coccoon eating competition. How many coccoons can one person eat? No one has managed more than two before giving up...
column3: It is a little awkward when you are at a fiesta and the host serves some rare delicacy, like moth cocoons, the guests must decide how many it would be polite to eat. You do the math in your head and it comes out to two cocoons per person. This is why the horizontal line is a fraction bar with two cocoons on the top, and one person the bottom.
column4: How many went to the party? Two aliens and one person (I feel sorry for that person).

story: An abacus is a mechanism made of wood used to calculate how many 'anythings'.
column3: To avoid confusing with 械 (#732), focus on the "ism" of mechanism. For example, fetishism refers to having a fetish; mechanism here refers to having a mecha-like property, where mecha is a type of anime robot that can transform itself. Imagine a mecha that can transform itself between two forms: a huge immovable tree (as a form of defense) and a gigantic marching abacus that smashes enemies between its giant beads.
column4: [synewave]An abacus is a mechanism made of wood used to calculate how many 'anythings'. Important geek note: This is used as the counter for your remaining lives in video games, as it also means chance/opportunity.

story: People aside, I wonder how many rice fields there are in the capital suburbs.
column3: This keyword refers to Japan's Kinki Region, a historic name for present-day Kansai. 近畿 きんき Just how many rice fields are in the capital suburbs? (The kinky (Kinki) people are hidden in the fields so you can't see them).
column4: How many brains does it take to run the capital suburbs?

story: What could be more mysterious than a cocoon in a top hat trying to sneak in...? (Pimitive: GANDALF).
column3: The invisible man in his top hat and cocoon of white bandages is the most mysterious man in the world.
column4: As romanrozhok said, this kanji has little to do with mysterious. It has the meanings [dark, abstruse, calm] (in Spanish, [moreno and recóndito]). As for the story, the union of a hat and a coccoon is obviously a fakir turban. India was maybe an abstruse place far away from China. Visualize a mysterious, dark-skinned fakir with a turban (in calming meditation) and the kanji is yours!

story: This mysterious rice field grows not only rice, but livestock too! Picture little pigs and chickens growing right out of the ground, among the rice plants. How bizarre!
column3: The livestock are disappearing! I've placed Gandalf over the rice field to protect them.
column4: Livestock has been mysteriously disappearing from the field. Aliens?

story: One sneaky farmer wanted to amass a large collection of livestock. We all know that cows like to eat flowers, so he planted lines of flowers leading to his own fields. The livestock followed the lines, eating the flowers one by one, and amassed in his field.
column3: To keep the difference between amass and 集 (#601) and 累 (#1464), I emphasize the MASS. To amass MASSIVE livestock, always feed them flowers. They'll get nice and plump. 蓄え = たくわえ = store; reserve; stock; savings.
column4: It may seem illogical, but the fact is, you need to plant flowers if your aim is to amass livestock.

story: A magic bow that only Gandalf can yield: there is no bowstring on it, and he uses his magic to fire arrows.
column3: A bow with a mysterious invisible bowstring.
column4: Small addition to cjon256's story to give me a more tangible image: A bow with a mysterious invisible bowstring that makes beautiful sounds like a stringed instrument. [Be careful when building your image; the "sound" primitive does not appear in this kanji.] 弦楽器 (げんがっき): stringed instruments 弦 (げん、つる): bowstring, string (of stringed instrument), chord (of a circle) 管弦楽団 (かんげんがくだん): orchestra 調弦 (ちょうげん): tuning.

story: A mysterious turkey with human fingers wants to hug me... I will never go to Tokyo Disneyland again!
column3: Imagine Gandalf hugging a turkey....ouch! It bit off his finger!
column4: Ok sweetheart, I want you to point your finger at the mysterious turkey who hugged you inappropriately.

story: Water is doubly mysterious. It's in all our nourishment...and yet, it's really not nourishing at all.
column3: Going off the idea of the right side meaning rapid growth/increase of small objects, I've decided to make the right side be Gremlins, those little mysterious creatures that double rapidly. Gremlins find water a little too nourishing, as it makes them instantly multiply.
column4: It’s doubly mysterious how water can be so nourishing—it doesn’t seem to have any substance and yet we would die without it.

story: Mercy is a doubly mysterious turn of the heart. On the one hand, everybody wants it, but on the other hardly anybody gives it.
column3: Two gremlins are atop a victim, tearing out his heart while he begs for mercy.
column4: Here we see the DOUBLE-MYSTERIOUS Siamese twins again, at the MERCY of the machines that pump blood through their veins, since the single HEART they share won't do the job...

story: A magnet is a rock with two sides; one that mysteriously pushes and one that pulls; doubly mysterious. (see astridtops' story).
column3: In the old days, people didn't know what magnets were. They just thought of them as stones that were double mysterious.
column4: The gremlins have this mysterious rock the use to attract yet more gremlins.

story: (Primitive: DNA, a drop of looong spiraled thread that is the key to your lineage).
column3: Spiderman's lineage (who his family is etc...) can be found in his DNA in a drop of blood. The villain that gets blood of Spidey will be able to find out who is family and lineage is. be carfefull spidey...
column4: A single drop of your blood holds the proof of the unbroken thread of your lineage.

story: Mister T gets a DNA test, and discovers that he was meant to be the person in charge after all.
column3: The person in charge usually must come from a long standing lineage of persons in charge.
column4: Mr. T is the person in charge of the DNA research center.

story: Your grandchild is the child of your DNA.
column3: Your child continues the family lineage by passing on your DNA, giving you a grandchild.
column4: Grandchild is a kid of your directe lineage.

story: The prefecture has suspended all DNA research for heart disease because of corruption. All involved will be suspended by their wrists.
column3: In a very racist prefecture of Japan, they screen everyone's DNA. If they find out you are of a different lineage, they rip out your heart and suspend it in the Hall of Shame.
column4: Hint: suspend as in hang up.

story: My parents aren't at all modest about their grandchildren, at every opportunity they take them on the road showing them off to their friends!
column3: He wasn't at all modest when telling us about his grandchildren - "They're all on the road to success" he said.
column4: Swift wrote in "A Modest Proposal" that Ireland should solve its economic problems by collecting the nation's grandchildren from off the streets and eating them.

story: [instead; on the contrary; rather] Gone is the time for stamps - use e-mail instead.
column3: We use e-mail now instead of regular mail. My e-mail is gone before you can even put a stamp on your snail mail.
column4: If you tried to attach money to an envelope to pay for postage it would be GONE before it arrived at the post office. That's why we use STAMPS instead.

story: Shins are the part of the body that Japanese traditionally sit on instead of their asses.
column3: Shins are the part of the body that one uses instead of one's eyes, for finding furniture in the dark. (Ouch!)
column4: This is one of the key aspects of soccer. At the beginning of every game you start by trying to kick the opponent's shins; their flesh, instead of the ball (lets them know you mean business).

story: Selling WHOLESALE HORSES over the internet had to be STOPPED because the cost of STAMPS was too much.
column3: If you need horseshoes (shoes that fit your horse's footprint), buy them at the wholesale shop. They lick and paste stamps in your membership card so you can get free merchandise later.
column4: Wholesale refers to the sale of goods in quantity to retailers for resale. When this kanji was invented, large loads of goods needed to be transported by horses who left steep footprints because of the weight they carried. The wholesale goods needed a special stamp to indicate that they were legal for resale. See 御 (#1500).

story: An honorable man will not try to cut in front of the line at the wholesale stamp store. (Imagine just how much honor it takes facing those long lines at the post office!)
column3: In front of the COLUMNS of the Capitol, the HONORABLE congressmen can be bought WHOLESALE.
column4: When buying wholesale the honorable thing to do would be to wait in line like everyone else.

story: It's customary to cover the flesh with clothing, but some designs are so outrageous they're not bigger than a stamp that just covers your crotch.
column3: Modern clothing shows a lot of flesh -- some is practically no more than a postage stamp covering your crotch!
column4: The PART OF THE BODY that you must STAMP clothing on, no matter what, is your CROTCH!

story: When you're born, your fate is measured, fitted, and stamped onto your soul. Good luck defying it.
column3: It is your fate to meet with a mouth, young postage stamp.
column4: It is my fate/life to fit stamps together.

story: (re: dingomick) "These are your orders," declares the general while passing out documents at the meeting. As everyone started to leave, the general exclaims "Oh wait! I need to certify these orders!" and went around stamping each paper with his personal chop-seal.
column3: "These are your orders," declares the general at the meeting as he stamps them with his chop-seal. (Primitive: chop-seal imaged as a papal ring, the one's they would press into wax as their official seal. Also a cattle brand.)
column4: Take note that this is written differently from how it looks in the typed font. See: http://kakijun.main.jp/ for the next kanji or http://www.saiga-jp.com/cgi-bin/dic.cgi?m=search&sc=0&f=0&j=%E4%BB%A4&g=&e=&s=&rt=0&start=1&sid=1240981825_91321, for example.

story: The amount of people that can order the rain to rain.
column3: Despite the rain, the zero pilot flies on. He has kamikaze orders.
column4: Zero from Code Geas gives his orders, and as usual there's a rain of bullets and blood.

story: You know you are fast approaching a ripe old AGE when you get ORDERS from the dentist to get new TEETH.
column3: At a certain age the tooth fairy orders your teeth to fall out--and they do.
column4: At your age false TEETH are the ORDER of the day.

story: To keep your water cool, just order some ice.
column3: The Japanese boss gives an order at the meeting: eat ice to stay cool (since they won't be running the air conditioning anymore).
column4: President Bush's drink isn't cool enough, and the Whitehouse is out of ice. "Time to invade Alaska!", President Bush says. "But sir... we already own it!"

story: Two cowboys are crossing a state limit. One says to him “Did you know that in this Jurisdiction there are Orders to get your head?”, so he takes out his gun and shoots him. He claims the reward afterwards. (Thanks Fuaburisu).
column3: Orders are given by the head person in any jurisdiction.
column4: You're outside of your jurisdiction, Johnson! Show me your orders or I'll have your head.

story: Some restaurants have a small gold bell to call someone to take customers' orders.
column3: In high society, people ring a small golden bell to call their servants and give their orders.
column4: This kanji refers to the golden, small bells (鈴=すず) that people ring at Shinto Shrines to communicate with gods who give 令 (#1503) on how to acquire authority and repel evil spirits!

story: I imagined some kind of initiation rite in old China, where every young man has to show his courage. They then receive a chopseal which is a mark of their courage.
column3: A MA （マ） raises a man to have courage.
column4: Re: fuaburisu - The initiation rite in question is actually a reverse elbow chop to the brain, and you receive the chop seal if you have the power to withstand it. This initial imagery helps me with the altered chop seal and vertical placement.

story: The courageous man who went into the water to save a drowning victim couldn't be seen, except by the air that bubbled up.
column3: Bubble up the WATER and see who has the COURAGE to jump into it.
column4: [+astrid] A very courageous man dove to the bottom of the water to save someone who had fallen in (and couldn't swim). The whole crowd was watching..30 seconds...a minute...1:20...are they both dead? Suddenly, a huge bubble rose to the surface, with the nearly-drowned victim - he bubbled up to the surface, in a bubble blown by the courageous man! And then soon after, the hero him self bubbled up. What a great story!

story: I bounce down the road on my pogo stick, easily getting through the dense traffic. (Note: New primitive: chop-seal + utilize = pogo stick. Because a chop-seal is long and thin with a rubbery bit at the end. If it were big enough, you could utilize it as a pogo stick). [Edit: pogo stick also appears in 1409, 1690, 2530].
column3: Building on gorgon's story I now change mine to a much more silly and rememberable one. The Chinese police is using a helicopter to check and regulate the traffic. Hanging from the helicopter is a huge chopseal that they utilize to mark some of the cars that are causing trouble on the road.
column4: Lots of Ma (マ)s utilize the road to take their kids to school. Sure makes a lot of traffic.

story: Dancing with pogo sticks tied to your legs is more like jumping about.
column3: The high jumper has his wooden leg fitted with a pogo stick, and can now jump even higher. (See my note at 通 (#1511) for pogo stick). EDIT (2 years later): Keyword "jump" leads to confusion later on (see cjon256's post), "Dancing" would be better (but be sure to keep it distinct from 舞 (#1912)). New Story: I was no good at dancing due to my wooden leg... until I had it fitted with a pogo stick!
column4: This is totally wrong. It doesn't mean "jump", it means "dance"! 踊 踊 (#1512) and 曜 躍 (#1379) are homonyms, so it is easy to become permanently confused about which one DOES NOT mean "jump/leap". Caveat Lector! Note: 舞 舞 (#1912) is quite a bit rarer (and not a homonym).

story: (Katsuo) You come at the zoo entrance. 'Here sir, a spoon to feed the animals.' cool 'and a dart(gun) in case stuff go wrong' ....' please chop-seal (sign) here for in case of accidents the zoo is not responsible.' 'lion feeding time is. bla bla' You are having serious doubts about if you still want to go into this zoo.
column3: A very doubtful story: At the entrance to my local zoo they issue you with a special spoon (to feed the animals) and a dart gun (to defend yourself in case of animal attack). You must then hanko (seal) a document to say you’ve received both these items, only after which will they let you enter the zoo. (Oh, and if you forget your hanko, I doubt they’ll let you in).
column4: Unless they use spoons to feed and darts to subdue the animals, I doubt the new zoo will get the WWF seal of approval.

story: Ask a MIMIC to give an impression of DOUBT, and he will no DOUBT scratch his head with his FINGER.
column3: I doubt you can mimic all these animals with just your fingers: http://www.google.com/search?q=%22Raymond+Crowe%22+Letterman (shadow puppets -- you'll love it!)
column4: Think of a mimic in Dungeons and Dragons, or a doppleganger: If you have doubts as to whether one of your party is genuine or a mimic, examine his fingers -- they'll lack fingernails or finger prints, and in fact are a poor mimicry of real fingers.

story: I doubt that the jello would congeal sitting on the counter, so I placed it in the icebox.
column3: Is there any doubt that ice is congealed stuff?
column4: I doubt that congeal is the right word to use when ice freezes.

story: This pattern made of bamboo is for a new model of car designed to leave as small an ecological fingerprint as possible.
column3: There was a pattern to the murders. At the scene of the crime, there would always be a little BAMBOO left in the victim's CAR, but no human FINGERPRINTS... In other news, a vicious panda recently escaped the zoo.
column4: How about a serial killer who's pattern is to drive by the victim and club them with a bamboo stick. Finally he makes a mistake and drops the bamboo stick, which is dusted for fingerprints.

story: Crimes can often be solved using the tools of dogs and fingerprints.
column3: This crime gang has yet to be caught because their pack of wild dogs takes care of licking off the fingerprints from all the crime scenes.
column4: The hardened criminals wild dogs from 獄 (#361) ended up in prison after police found their fingerprints all over the crime scene.

story: It's a widespread belief that they cannot find fingerprints on a body that has been deposited in the water.
column3: It's a widespread belief that water takes away fingerprints.
column4: Warning: 氾濫 (flood) seems to be the only compound known to the WWWJDIC, so I propose this as an alternative keyword. The burglars flooded the mansion they broke into with water, thus leaving no fingerprints behind.

story: Seeing some finger prints at the edge of a cliff, I wondered who that unlucky person was.
column3: Sherlock Holmes is very unlucky: he just fell off a cliff while he was looking around for fingerprints.
column4: See a cliff with fingerprints on the edge? That means someone was unlucky.

story: You're bound up by ropes to an unlucky person. It's dangerous, because whatever happens to him will happen to you too.
column3: While rock climbing you are bound to the cliff by just your fingerprints, which is why it's so dangerous.
column4: Being unlucky is bound to be dangerous. 危ない　（あぶ）ない.

story: Your address should be displayed on your house and mailbox.
column3: For the primitive: This is a hi-tech Japanese mailbox, it automatically lights up in the evening, and has a biometric fingerprint scanner. --- Each house's address, even if it's hard to see in the evening, is like its own unique fingerprint.
column4: Mailbox - i never get my evening paper but the paperboy says he delivers it. so here i am dustin gfor fingerprints everyevening checking for his new prints . roof and mailbox. superman is the newpostamn so the local people write their addresses on their rooftops as well as their mailboxes.

story: Like in Memento, I tattoo my address on my forearm flesh so I don't forget it.
column3: In Iraq people are having their addresses tattooed on their bodies, usually their arms, so they can be identified if they are killed. (true story).
column4: The part of the body that is good for writing someone's address down on when you have no paper at hand.

story: Japanese "gardens" aren't anything more than a pot of flowers on top of the mailbox.
column3: My mailbox is actually right in the middle of my garden, which kind of sucks since the mailman has to trample all my flowers to get to it.
column4: You call flowers on top of your mailbox a garden!? Get me out of this 1LDK!

story: I couldn't drop my grudge against him. So I put a severed pig's heart in his mailbox. He got the message.
column3: I had a little grudge against my ex-girlfriend and her new boyfriend...so I ripped out his heart (like in indiana jones and the temple of doom) and then I left it in her mailbox.
column4: Remember The Grudge movie? Instead of coming out from the attic, the girl comes out from the mailbox to rip your heart out.

story: Having decided to use SIGN OF THE HARE rather than RECEIPT and STAMP my mnemonic goes as follows: The WILLOW is the TREE that droops likes a HARE's ears.
column3: A strange thing about the japanese willow tree is, it grows eggs... but the eggs have no yokes. weird eh?
column4: I ordered a willow tree off Amazon but when it arrived it was covered in postage stamps. I try to peel them off but it ends up leaving a papery mess and cheapifies the willow's appearance. Luckily I kept a receipt.

story: The Easter Bunny dropped an egg on my desk and got yolk all over my receipts and stamps.
column3: The Easter Bunny (hare) drops a few drops of egg yolk while hiding easter Eggs.
column4: The Easter Bunny is hiding an easter EGG in each of its ears.

story: Got a receipt for that dagger, son? If not, we're going to detain you and send you to work in the rice fields.
column3: The use of RANSOM NOTE (think of a receipt with a dagger through it on a door) works great with DETAIN. Here the RANSOM NOTE says that the girl has been DETAINED in an undisclosed location. To get her back take the RANSOM to a empty FIELD.
column4: "We're detaining you because we found a receipt on you for this dagger we found in the brain of the man your wife was having an affair with. Care to explain?"

story: “The king has been detained by some marines!” “How do you know they were marines?” “Because they were wearing marine blue.”.
column3: The king was detained, by men in marine blue; Must be the marines, planning a coup. (thx Katsuo/gavmck).
column4: Halt! The king has detained you for wearing MARINE BLUE underwear! (Don't expect this to make sense - that's the same king that requested to see your balls (球 (#1005)), after all...)

story: There's a buyback program where you can trade in your dagger for money. But it's quite ineffective, since only registered dagger-owners with the original receipts can participate, and not criminals with illegally-purchased daggers.
column3: Here is my receipt and here is my dagger. Now give me my money back! Isn't that a fair trade?
column4: The new RANSOM note (a receipt stuck to a door with a dagger) from DETAIN (1423) appears again (probably after you went to the field as instructed) now gives instruction to TRADE the victim for CURRENCY you were told to bring.

story: Before sticky backs, they had to staple stamps to letters.
column3: Aaaagh, this old stamp doesn't stick! Okay I'll just staple it.
column4: A stamp for the 印velope of course!

story: I removed all the back to back staples and grinded them in a mortar to create metal dust.
column3: 臼歯臼 (#1531)キュウ，うす ... Parts: Back to back Staples... Or Cracked 白 (cf. 興味興 (#1533), 輿入れ輿 (#2874), 新潟) ... Note: this is simplified to 旧 in the Joyo characters. Ex: 児=兒児 (#62), 稲=稻稲 (#976), but not in 潟潟 (#2195) because it is a traditional place name (Niigata). In non-Joyo, the characters are written both ways: 焔焔 (#2605) is often written 焰. ... Note2: Stroke order varies since it is not Joyo.
column4: I went pictograph with this one: a cracked white rice grain--one that has been bashed in a mortar.

story: Wow, that baker must really be mad! He's trying to BREAK his MORTAR by throwing it to the SOIL. Whoa! Now he's aiming a MISSILE at it!
column3: Drawing inspiration from 撃 (#766) by kinkypete, this kanji shows the rules for a bizarre form of janken (paper, stone, scissors). A mortar can break soil (grinding it to dust). Soil can break a missile (burying it - causing it to eventually rust away). And a missile can break a mortar.
column4: You'll break everything down to dirt if you use both mortars and missiles.

story: To me, this looks like a pictograph of a road leading to the big city (see the buildings?) where there are plenty of places to be entertained. Unfortunately in this city, every store is the same: staples. What tools! [ayoung24].
column3: Photographically, this kanji simply looks like a set of two speakers (the staples primitives) between the sub-woofer (primitive for same) -- all this as a tool to entertain a group of drunks at a club.
column4: Wacky Japanese TV entertain-ment show: a monk is stapled to the wall on both sides with huge staples, whilst contestants throw tools at his face.

story: The sign of the bird on this whiskey bottle is of course the Famous Grouse blended Scotch.
column3: Normally birds fly south, but one bird flew west. People were worried about it and kept asking "Is there any sign of the bird – you know, the one that flew west?"
column4: The Sign of the Bird on Greygoose Vodka. It's got such a fancy bottle, but I think Absolut tastes smoother.

story: Sake is just watered down whisky.
column3: Sake is the generic term for alcohol (not just japanese rice wine). And a very popular alcoholic drink in Japan is whiskey and water.
column4: Sake. Looks like water, tastes like whiskey. (thanks Bodhisamaya).

story: At the local pub, their bartending practises are unusual. They serve the whiskey by pouring it from a ladle, like one would from the punch bowl.
column3: Ever seen the anime Bartender? Bartending isn't just about bottles of whiskey, it's about ladling out advice.
column4: Old fashioned bartending had the server ladle out the alcohol from a giant whiskey bottle.

story: While the keyword is "hooch", this usually means 焼酎. It has similar effect as whiskey and sniffing glue has: you get intoxicated.
column3: Tastes like whiskey, smells like glue? Then it must be しょうちゅうの「ちゅう」 ( hooch ). - There you go, reading meaning and a catchy ad jingle, all in one. Possibly the best story I've written. ^^.
column4: I combined WHISKEY and GLUE to make HOOCH.

story: The secrets of fermentation are passed to the son who displays the most filial piety.
column3: Since filial piety is all about respecting ones elders, and the older a whiskey bottle is (i.e. the time it have spent undergoing fermentation) the more respect you should give it, the meaning of this kanji becomes clear. If it doesn't, sink back some whiskey and it will.
column4: Add a phrase to Raichu's story: The secrets of fermentation are written on a whiskey bottle and passed to the child who displays the most filial piety.

story: It's cruel to pour alcohol down a cow's mouth.
column3: Offering whiskey to people to encourage them to make revelations is cruel.
column4: There is a saying that a drunk man's words are a sober man's thoughts. Be careful about giving someone a bottle of whiskey, you may get some revelations about their cruelty. Of course, they'll just say that it's the whiskey speaking.

story: Imagine a different kind of tax refund - instead of money, the state repays you with whiskey.
column3: If you take your whiskey across a state line, you'll have to repay the liquor tax in the new state.
column4: True story, the former communist state of Russia was once so poor it repayed it's teachers with vodka http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/education/177421.stm.

story: To stay healthy, Dr. Phil told me to have some dairy products with each bottle of whiskey I drink...
column3: In an attempt to increase sales of dairy products, the grocery store is giving away a free miniature whiskey bottle with each dairy product you buy.
column4: The makers of Bailey's Irish Creme add dairy products to each of their bottles of whiskey, creating one of the most delicious alcoholic beverages known to mankind.

story: Drinking alcohol that's turned to vinegar feels like a saw going down your throat.
column3: I spent ages sawing that whiskey bottle open, but when I got in, it had all turned to vinegar!
column4: For those who like real kanji history: I went to a vinegar shop and the owner said that the kanji for vinegar is derived from 酒 and 作 where you simply take the right side of each, because to make vinegar you actually have to use sake. So here we have vinegar, which is 酒 we 作 into 酢.

story: God you're drunk! How many whiskeys did you have? 9? 10?
column3: Whiskey with 90 percent alcohol will get you drunk. I don't care who you are.
column4: As Ernest Hemingway said, it only takes one drink to get me drunk. But I'm not sure if it is the ninth or tenth drink that does it. [from dingomick].

story: To DISTRIBUTE WHISKY during Prohibition you had to be as sneaky as a SNAKE.
column3: In Japan, it's rude to distribute the sake to your self before anybody else.
column4: Those who have studied physics may find this useful. The two parts of the kanji represent the two statistical distributions for bosons and fermions. The Bose-Einstein distribution is represented by the sign of the bird because birds, like bosons, are social creatures who like to flock together. The Fermi-Dirac distribution is represented by a snake, since snakes, like fermions, are solitary creatures who like to keep to themselves.

story: The prostitute carries an old whiskey bottle filled with acid to throw at any difficult Johns.
column3: Dealing alcohol requires a license, dealing acid requires fast legs (to run from the police).
column4: I stopped doing acid, and am living the clean life. Well, aside from all the whiskey and prostitutes.

story: The waver for this kanji means to hesitate. I wavered before going into the bar with a bunch of horned wild dogs drinking whiskey straight out of the bottle.
column3: For the right primitive: Red Bull (the energy drink). Can be mixed with alcohol and gives you wi- uh, horns. Coincidentally, also the name of the Indian CHIEFTAN in frame 2906. (Thanks Katsuo).
column4: I wavered when the pack of wild dogs was blocking the way, but then I drank some Red Bull and charged through. (thanks shakkun).

story: I drank the Devil Whiskey and was revered by all. Too bad I had to have my anus glued shut from the damage it did to my digestive system...
column3: Red Bull, the 酋 (#2915) is so revered in his clan that everyone sticks to him like glue.
column4: Have you seen people who save their empty alcohol bottles? Some of them take the reverence too far, and glue the revered bottle of whisky to the wall, mounted like a rack of animal horns.

story: If I eat BEANS, after ONE MOUTHful I fart like some kind of HORNED ANIMAL.
column3: I hate using primitives that are completely unrelated. Let's call this one Mr. Bean! He's an easy character to build stories with.
column4: Looks like a pot of refried beans on top of a stove to me with a top over the pot.

story: The head of the family sits at the head of the table.
column3: Mr. Bean has a funny head.
column4: Mr Bean's head.

story: He's so short, he can't even throw over a table while playing darts.
column3: Mr. Bean somehow finds himself in an archery contest. He has no arrow's so he uses darts, (even though they are quite too short!). All of his shots land extremely short! (Picture Mr. Bean trying to shoot a dart and it landing short).
column4: Sort of like ping pong, this kanji represents a game where you throw darts over a table at your opponent. The serve is rarely returned, so the games tend to be short.------------ This character apparently refers to duration, not just to height.

story: The bountiful feast was so bountiful that it bent the table below it under its weight! いただきま〜す！.
column3: Bender stands on top of Mr. Bean to be able to reach the bountiful feast on the giant's table. (Mr. Bean didnt know how he even ended up there).
column4: Be careful when people bend over around here: the bean harvest was bountiful.

story: I really hate the primitive meaning of "table" for "bean." I just use "bean." Anyways, for the DRUM primitive, imagine a SAMURAI who beats on a DRUM with two chopsticks, and a BEAN skewered on each end of the chopstick to produce a better sound. And the obvious story is: "DRUMing on a DRUM with a huge BRANCH".
column3: Mr. Bean tries to play drums with 10 different branches he found on the ground.
column4: These SAMURAI, sitting at the TABLE and waiting for their food, grab some BRANCHES to begin DRUMMING a rhythm while they wait. (In fact, they stand on the table, removing the top stroke!)

story: The samurai sitting on the drum is on a stage, and the people below him are rejoicing with their mouths in unison. It helps me to imagine the placement this way.
column3: Rejoice with the sound of drums and voice!
column4: Ten beans in my mouth! I was starving so this small meal is enough for me to rejoice!

story: The hippies object to trees being cut down for timber. They have glued themselves to the timber-trees and are beating their drums.
column3: To the cutting down of timber-trees and the destruction of the forest, the hippies have staged a protest demonstration using a drum in the middle of the town (see 村 (#221)).
column4: Drums are made from timber-trees cut down and glued together. (they really are).

story: Three dishes stacked side-by-side in a dishwasher.
column3: Pictograph of a dish with a three-layer cake slice on it.
column4: 3 dishes in a dish rack. HINT: To avoid making 4 dishes, remember that '4' is an unlucky number in Japan so things are rarely in sets of 4.

story: Vampire orders blood in one of those posh restaurants. Imagine his shock when all he gets is a giant white bowl and just a single drop of blood in the centre and a drizzling of balsamic around the edge. Disgusted he calls the manager over tells him its overpriced tosh and bites into his neck with a huge gush of blood spraying everywhere.
column3: You cut yourself washing the dishes, drop of blood.
column4: BLOOD?! IS that a SPOT of BLOOD on my PLATE!?! asks the infuriated vegetarian when he ordered a salad at a restaurant.

story: The part of the kitchen sink in which you wash dishes in is the basin.
column3: Your mom yells at you to stop throwing dishes in the basin. She lifts up (to show primitive order) the broken parts to show you the damage you've done.
column4: I'm not an expert, but it seems that as a basin this refers more to an oceanic basin that a kitchen one, and in any case seems most common in reference to the famous O-Bon festival. So, a story: in the O-Bon festival, so many dishes are broken that all the parts have to be thrown into a deep oceanic basin.

story: (re: Raichu) An undercover alliance between Japan (the sun on its flag) and Turkey (the moon on its flag) detected by a surveillance satellite dish. http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20100126a3.html.
column3: A new alliance is proclaimed at the end of a meal between officials. As a symbol of their alliance they clean up together one dish, and present it to the photographers. The clean dish under the flash lights appears very bright, and it's pretty much all you can see on the photo that appears on the next morning's newspapers, with the title "New alliance, one bright dish!".
column4: In medieval Japan (during Sengoku Jidai) there was an interesting ritual to form an alliance between different samurai clans. The warlord, who wanted to propose to form an alliance to another warlord, would send him a big ceremonial dish with the sun drawn in the center. If the proposal were accepted, the second warlord would draw an image of the moon next to the sun on the same dish, and then return the dish to the first warlord. (not true story, but helped me to create vivid image).

story: You are so poor you dont know where your next dish will come from all you know is that you will have to steal it.
column3: The first thing to steal is the silverware; next, the dishes.
column4: This is pretty easy: While he's not looking, imagine stealing food from the dish next to you!

story: If you leave water out in the sun in a dish, naturally it will get warm.
column3: I'm mixing this up with 暖 (#1949) far too much. Trying to use mnemonic "Warm Water" - 温泉　（おんせん） obviously relates to water that is warm, from the sun and when you think about it, is kind of like a big dish.
column4: I ate the sun on a plate, and I now feel warm inside. I had to drink water to stop this burning.

story: The lid of this dish is gone! Now the whole room smells of the flowers that were used in the cooking.
column3: The magic lid trick: you put flowers in the dish and cover them up with the lid. Then you lift and the flowers are gone!
column4: The waiter of a fancy restaurant takes the lid away and what you see is - nothing! The food is gone - somebody has stolen it. All what has been left from the dish is the decoration, a single flower...

story: The slavetrader oversees the slaves washing dishes int he kitchen. No reclining on the floor!
column3: The slaves are reclining on the floor when the overseer comes in. They tell him "We're not goofing off, a dish fell and broke and we're cleaning it off the floor".
column4: While the slave-buyer is perusing (覧 (#919)) the stack of slaves reclining on the floor, the slaves' overseer supplies them with dishes of gruel -- don't want the slaves starving to death before they can be sold!

story: Who's job is it to oversee the water level on the dam? It'ts overflowing!
column3: The overseer isn't doing his job and he lets the slaves overflow the sink!
column4: When water overflows it is usually because someone was not properly overseeing the task. Image: A mother talking on the phone, overseeing the drawing her kid's bath, boiling something on the stove, and breaking up a fight between two of the kids. Something is bound to overflow.

story: The overseer tags his slaves with gold earrings, just like specimens.
column3: (Thanks bodhisamaya) The authorities are suspicious about the athlete that won GOLD at the olympics. They are now OVERSEEING a thorough drug test, taking all sorts of SPECIMENS.
column4: The overseer tags his favorite slave with gold earrings. "Ah, what a fine specimen!"

story: Indigo flowers have to be overseen because they are often picked for their beauty.
column3: Traditionally, 青 青 (#1654) could be used to describe blue OR green. However, two kanji that describe the hues specifically are 藍 and 緑. This kanji is the "blue" counterpart of 緑 (#1471). Story: The overseer, master of the slaves, wore a cloak dyed with indigo, and flowers in his hair.
column4: Http://gaijinsmashnet.wordpress.com/2007/06/28/1-kyuu/ Reading this rant by a non-RTKer mentioning this particular kanji made me remember it very well.

story: The fierce WILD DOG attacked the CHILD who came near his feeding DISH.
column3: I picture a fierce little fat kid, defending his dish of food from a pack of dogs.
column4: If you want to make your wild dogs fierce, put a child in their dish.

story: Japan's economic boom turned their empty plates into full ones.
column3: The boom of satellite TV has made antennas turn into dishes.
column4: The Japanese have a phrase, マイブーム (my boom), which refers to something that a person is currently obsessed with or fascinated by. This kanji depicts the boom as a certain dish that has just turned into a national trend.

story: In the old days, salt was a worth alot, so it is not surprising to find someone reclining on the ground, mouth to plate, getting every last grain of that delicious salt.
column3: It is bad luck to spill salt on the ground, so you better recline and lick it into your mouth or put it back on the dish.
column4: Remember the mock sushi documentary that circulated a while ago: "Because some feel that the shoyu was not salty enough, complementary salt dishes are provided on the ground outside the sushiya, you can recline and put as much as you desire in your mouth".

story: Like gold, silver is a metal.
column3: Silver is almost as 良 (#1578) as gold, but not quite (one stroke missing).
column4: Metal that is silver is silver!

story: The athlete's state of mind is nothing but resentment after getting the silver medal.
column3: Data's greatest resentment is getting a silver medal in Science Olympiad. (Image: Data fuming on the podium muttering about being half robot).
column4: What is your state of mind when you win silver? You resent that you didn't win gold!

story: Since trees eat through their roots, one could imagine roots as tree silverware.
column3: The roots of the magical tree are silver.
column4: In the kanji for root (not the primitive), I imagine a tree whose roots end up in silverware, which the tree uses somehow to eat whatever is underground.

story: He scratches off the silver stamp and discovers that he is an instant winner.
column3: For instant postal delivery, buy a silver stamp!
column4: Instant ramen always has silver foil stamped on the top of the cup, as a lid.

story: An eagle stole the baron's eye in the war, but now he has a silver coin glued in the socket instead.
column3: Here we see an evil baron - a vulture perched on his shoulder, and a siver eye-patch glued to his eye.
column4: A vulture took the baron's eye, so he glued a silver one in its place.

story: Counting the nodes on bamboo is an instant way to tell its age.
column3: A certain species of bamboo is considered the fastest growing plant in the world. A new node can be formed in an instant. 節 【せつ】 (n) node, section, occasion, time, (P) 節 【ふし】 (n) joint, knuckle, tune, melody, (P) 節句 【せっく】 (n) seasonal festival, (P) 節減 【せつげん】 (n,vs) retrenchment, curtailment, economy, (P).
column4: Is it just me, or do the nodes on a bamboo tree look like a stack of Cup Noodle instant soup cups?

story: You see a huge army of people in silver armour on the road so you retreat.
column3: In the land of Oz, you advance by following the golden road, but you reatreat by following the Silver Road.
column4: In Spanish there is a saying which is useful to remember this kanji. It says: "A enemigo que huye, puente de plata," which translates literally as "To enemy that retreats, silver bridge," meaning one should not stay in the way of a retreating enemy. In the kanji we just replace the silver bridge by a silver road.

story: The speed limit at The Pinnacle is posted on silver signs.
column3: At The Pinnacle, they limit how much silver you can have. Too much silver will lead to wrongfulness.
column4: Not just anyone can gain membership into The Pinnacle, it limits its membership to those with the appropriate amount of silver, both to be used as cash and weaponry in their war against the werewolves. (Mnemonic: Pinnacle limits membership to those with enough silver.)

story: Eyeballs made of silver. That's what they use to play pachinko with, isn't it?
column3: The baron's silver eye was not actually an eyeball.
column4: Picture an EYE all dressed up in SILVER, on its way to the EYEBALL. It's a joke you see.

story: With a drop of silver, the forces of good can vanquish the werewolves.
column3: A drop of silver is good, but a whole bar of it is better!
column4: I'm a good person. See my drop of silver HALO?

story: [Image: 'Moonlight sonata'] The moon has inspired many good composers (like Ludwig van Beethoven) to write something melodious.
column3: A glowing halo surrounds a magnificent full moon. A perfect image of the mythic and melodious music of the spheres.
column4: 'Au clair de la lune' (in the halo of the moon) is a melodious french lullaby ( http://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Au_clair_de_la_lune ).

story: Water is a good thing to have when you're out wandering.
column3: John the Baptist with a halo sprinkling water on people as he's wandering the wilderness.
column4: Jesus (the halo) wanders idly over the water.

story: Your daughter is a good girl......well, let's hope so... :-).
column3: Be careful not to think woman + angel here, which has already been seen for 嬌 (#461). Suggest using woman with a halo, as in an innocent girl, something that everyone sees their daughters as being.
column4: Parents wish that their daughter grows up to be a good woman.

story: That umbrella looks good enough to eat!
column3: Umbrella + Good: Let's go eat at that restaurant - the table with the umbrella looks good.
column4: Imagine the halo when you pray before the meal. The people queuing up outside the restaurant in the rain with an umbrella couldn't care less about your sanctimoniousness.

story: I'm anti-fastfood. Sit down and eat a real meal!
column3: I'm Anti-McDonald's. Anti-Happy Meal. Anti-hamburger.
column4: Part of every traditional Italian meal is when they eat the anti-pasto first. (Antipasto is not a food, it's the first course; see Wikipedia.)

story: When you lack food, just drink something to fill you up.
column3: In Japan, the one thing I always seem to be lacking with my food is a properer sized drink. Instead I have to drink that shot glass of water.
column4: Always the same in those restaurants. You've already received your drink and you're waiting so long for your food that you begin to yawn.

story: The smell of cooked food wafts past you in the wind, making your stomach rumble and feeling hungry.
column3: The wind blew away my food, so now I'm hungry.
column4: When you feel the wind (or even hear it) in your stomach, that means you're hungry and you need to eat. Imagine your stomach like an empty, barren desert, and the wind blowing through it.

story: All those starving models in Hollywood - they want to eat, but their ego (about their appearance and trim look) makes sure they grin and bear it!
column3: He starves for FOOD but his EGO won't let him beg.
column4: He was starving for food, but he had too much ego and was too proud to ask for food.

story: [decorate; ornament; adorn; embellish] We decorate a table before eating, reclining a towel over it.
column3: Naked sushi: a lady reclining on a towel as decoration for the food laid out on her.
column4: You decorate your house with pictures of you reclining in a towel surrounded by food.

story: Food made of ears is animal feed.
column3: When I bring out the can opener to open the food, my cat's ears prick right up. Feeding time!
column4: Do you know Mike Tayson favorite feed? Ears! He eats ears!

story: A building that eats bureaucrats!!!!!!!!
column3: This Bldg. is like all the other government buildings - they house bureaucrats who sit around sipping wine and eating expensive meals at the taxpayers expense.
column4: The bureaucrat never goes out for lunch, always choosing to eat in the Bldg.

story: Call your friend and he answers the phone "Mochi, mochi!" whatever he is eating sure is making it hard to understand. I will puzzle over the content of our conversation for some time to come.
column3: Mochi is like a puzzle you eat and solve in your mouth lest you choke.
column4: Mochi ice cream is a puzzling food, I still have no idea how they get that ice cream in there, but it sure tastes good.

story: A sheep became the foster parent for a wolf pup, feeding it with milk. This story cannot end well...
column3: You foster ("promote the growth of") your sheep well when they have food right at their feet.
column4: Judy Foster in "The Silence of the Lambs" is what Dr. Hannibal-the cannibal-Lecter would like to eat.

story: My gluttony was only sated after I ate the hamburger AND the wrapper!
column3: This guy is sated only after eating the hamburger AND its wrapping!
column4: I was sated, so I wrapped up the rest of my food in a doggy bag to take home.

story: Distinguish from 曽 (#540). Think of previously as "the previous customer" in a restaurant. At a cheap sleazy diner, the waitress gives you unwashed silverware that was previously used by the previous customer. Yuck.
column3: For the waitress primitive, I don't really see the receipt. So instead, I imagine a waitress holding a plate above her head, using those legs to weave through the tables.
column4: Previously -> previews at the movies. Almost all the actresses on the silver screen previously were waitresses. Story by mspertus.

story: A murder has been commited. A corpse was found under a tree. The police chalks the outline of the victim, an old silvered-haired waitress working at a restaurant nearby.
column3: If you attempted to outline the biography of most famous actresses, you'd find that they have roots working as waitresses before getting their big break.
column4: If you look at the outline (resume/CV) of any professional woman, you'll probably find that while a student she was a waitress part-time so that she could pay the bills, so you could say that most professional women have their "roots" in being a waitress.

story: If you don't leave some silver as a tip, you will rue the day you earned the resentment of your waitress.
column3: The resentment of a waitress who gave up going to college to help her boyfriend (with his tuition). She rues that decision ever since she got dumped by him (just after he graduated).
column4: State of mind + Previously: To rue something is to let your state of mind be ruled by whatever previously happened.

story: There's an even covering of water lilies on the pond at 金閣寺（きんかくじ） the Golden Pavilion in Kyoto.
column3: This is even as in flat, level, smooth, calm (not like "even if" or "even though").
column4: The graph of an even function [f(x)] will be symmetrical over the y-axis, as this kanji appears to be.

story: I'm a lazy fisher, so I genetically engineered a lily pad with a fishing hook at the stem and a mouth to call me whenever it catches something.
column3: The right portion of this character isn't a water lily at all; we will take it to be a broken hand (see how if you rotate the second and third strokes, you approach the appearance of the character for hand?). In this character, we see someone who is trapped with a broken hand opening their mouth to call for help.
column4: I just follow the calls from the frogs mouths on the lily pads to hook them.

story: A two-mat area is just about as much ground as you will need for a lily pond.
column3: A two-mat area is plenty of space for sleeping in a tent but you won't be comfortable unless the ground is even.
column4: A two-mat area is exactly how much ground a giant lilypad will cover.

story: Good evaluation should always be words of even fairness.
column3: You get an evaluation copy of MS Word because you want to evaluate whether it's worth buying the full version. At the end of the evaluation period the CD turns into a lilypad so you can't use it any more (an innovative new copy-protection trick).
column4: Gardeners have developed many words to evaluate the health of lilies.

story: Sheaf? No. This is the sign of the X-Men. I'm going with Wolverine on this one.. Wolverine reaps the bad guys with his saber-like claws.
column3: A SABRE is used to cut the stalks of plants being REAPED at harvest. They are then combined into a SHEAF.
column4: You reap what you sow, so sow plenty and reap a lot to have a メリ Christmas!

story: Wolverine waiting atop a tree to spring down on Sabretooth at any moment.
column3: The kendo artist takes a brief moment to practice his skills: he throws sheafs over the tree and tries to cut them with his saber when they come down again.
column4: Means temple not moment. I think Heisig was trying to think ahead to compounds. This means moment: 刹那（せつな）。.

story: Wolverine (sheaf, see 刈 (#1600)) hopes they invent linen sheets that he won't keep shredding in his sleep.
column3: "I hope this works," you say as you stuff a sheaf of stalks under your blanket but above your linens. Your real hope is that your parents don't find out that you left the house.
column4: Most people outside the first world hope only for food and clothing - a sheaf of wheat, a bolt of linen.

story: Wolverine (sheaf, see 刈 (#1600)) takes out a villain who can't be cut by smacking the crap out of him with a shovel.
column3: Here the villain digs a hole with a shovel and covers it with a sheaf, hoping someone will fall in.
column4: Note: the stroke order is actually: sheaf, shovel.

story: Bosom is a Flesh part that should be bound up lest it provoke villian thoughts.
column3: As you know, female comics villains are always binding the flesh of their bosom up in interesting ways. One has to wonder how these clothes stay on their body at all...
column4: Just think of the heroine's bosom in a movie. The villain ties up the heroine (to the traintracks or the conveyor belt etc) but her bosom is the body part that is always left sticking out.

story: I've finally met my arch-rival, the evilest of all villains. Finally, I'm about to fight him. But what's this? He's suspiciously quiet. I move to attack him, and his right arm falls off at the elbow. Strange. I walk up to him and detach his left arm. Very strange. I undo his belt, and take off his top hat... BLAST! It was just a decoy turkey!
column3: The most ridiculous character ever dreamt up for a film. DETACHO, a top-hat wearing villian who is able to detach his body parts for use as weapons. His most powerful weapons are his elbows, which he can detach, tie together with his belt and use as nunchucks. DETACHO has a sidekick turkey which he uses as an advanced scout as well.
column4: I'm surprised no one has worked Oddjob, the villain from the James Bond movie, Goldfinger into their stories. He's the big oriental guy that killed people by throwing his top hat at them. He practises his technique on turkeys, detaching their heads in the process. Being an assassin, he can also kill people by garroting them with his belt or smashing them with his elbows.

story: The King's crystal got detached from his royal throne, and is missing! Looks like the turkey got away with it. He's no where to be seen!
column3: In my story for detatch 離 (#1605), the left side primitive was junkie. The top-hatted villian of society with a belt around their elbow. Here, the junkie is getting a fix of crystal meth: the jewel in the crown of today's drugs.
column4: The super-villain DETACHO (see 離 (#1605)) looks into his crystal ball planning new evil.

story: Wolverine (sheaf, see 刈 (#1600)) leaps over a tree and with one swipe of his claws kills a bad guy aiming a missle launcher.
column3: I suppose when this kanji was made, it was most effective to kill your enemies with sheafs of wood used as missiles.
column4: This is the Monty Python "How not to be seen" sketch (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/How_Not_To_Be_Seen) where they use heat seeking missiles to kill people first behind sheafs of hay and then behind trees.

story: A large airship drops parachuting Wolverine clones into the bracing night air.
column3: Often used in shaving lotion and fragrance descriptions 爽やか　さわやか refreshing, bracing, sweet, clear. Story: Slap some alcohol-based さわやか aftershave lotion onto the 4 big x-shaped hockey stitches on your face. That's bracing!
column4: If the keyword is supposed to stand for invigorating, why not just make that the keyword? Heisig doesn't use invigorating, or any variation of invigorate as a keyword, and bracing is almost never used to mean invigorating.

story: Earthworm Jim's prized possession is a genuine copy of the #1 issue of Spiderman.
column3: You need to attach a genuine earthworm to the thread. With plastic bait you won't catch anything.
column4: The real Spiderman loves to eat earthworms—they provide essential nutrients that make his threads stronger. So next time someone goes around claiming to be the real, genuine Spiderman, give him a few earthworms to eat.

story: Ever chopped the head off an earthworm? Notice how it will grow back immediately! Beware the killer earthworms...
column3: When playing Earthworm Jim, remember that the weak point of the boss is his head. Don't bother attacking anywhere else, it will just waste time. Attack the head immediately! 道頓堀　どうとんぼり, the main nightlife street in Osaka.
column4: In the barracks you have to respond immediately when the head of your unit calls.

story: The metal hook is too dull to even pierce an earthworm....
column3: I was excited when they made a game that was a combination of Metal Gear and Earthworm Jim. But it turned out to be pretty dull.
column4: From the earthworm's perspective, it most be pretty dull when you are put in a metal bowl, just waiting for being put on the hook on the fishing trip the next day.

story: Eating spicy food makes you stand up ten times faster than usual, 'cause you just need to get something to drink!
column3: Eating spicy food makes you stand up as if you had sat on a needle.
column4: This caracter has 2 meaning : Spicy -> see book (からい） and heart-breaking painful （つらい） => stand up on barefooted on needles is painful.

story: This guy's job is tasting the spicy curry at the local Indian Food Factory. He has to resign from his job before his tongue is rendered completely useless after all the spicy food that he has to try all day long...
column3: After my tongue touched the most spicy pepper of all, I had to resign from the contest...too hot for me!
column4: A lecherous male worker is forced to resign because the female employees compained about his spicy tounge.

story: The CATALPA is the tree that bears the SPICY Indian bean (NOTE - The Catalpa is also known as the "Indian Bean" due to the bean pods that grow from it).
column3: This kanji is barely used. Just rename the keyword to PEPPER TREE (so you don't need a story) and move on. If you do a google image search for the kanji 梓, you'll find that this character almost exclusively refers to the female name あずさ (by the way, you will see some cute girls).
column4: The caterpillar's favorite tree is the catalpa because it tastes spicy.

story: Superintendant Chalmers is dining at Principal Skinner's house. He takes a bite of his meal which is unbelievably spicy. His wig pops off and he yells out: "SKINNERRR!"
column3: The superintendent of an old-age house has to make sure the food is never too spicy.
column4: This also means "manage," so just think of a manager of a "House of Curry" 宰領 さいりょう superintend/manage.

story: Did anyone else used to put ketchup packets on the ground and jump on them so they spattered on the wall?
column3: Primitive for Ketchup: When the taste is too spicy your mouth has basically given up trying to handle it ..or in other words raised the white flag of surrender. But unlike war , putting Ketchup on it will usually solve the problem. Wall(dingomick); Did anyone else used to put ketchup packets on the ground and jump on them so they spattered on the wall?
column4: NB: Heisig's "ketchup" for 辟 is totally arbitrary. I'm naming it DONALD TRUMP. It works really well in the kanji that have this primitive: 壁 (#1616), 璧 (#1617), 避 (#1618), 癖 (#1826)! Primitive: DONALD TRUMP 辟 always waves the national flag 尸 ("Make America Great Again!"), and he's best known for his spicy 辛 mouth 口. STORY: Donald Trump 辟 wants to build a yuuuge wall between the US and Mexico to control immigration. What he doesn't know is that Mexicans will dig UNDERground 土 tunnels if needed.

story: This kanji shows a policeman with a holed gem (which can be thought of as jewelry, I guess), but he thinks it's a doughnut. For some reason though, he liked his doughnuts with ketchup on them, so he added some, and tried to take a bite. He lost a few teeth on the process.
column3: 完璧璧 (#1617) Holed Gem RTK ＃1500.1 ヘキ ... Parts:壁-土, 玉 ... Note: This is a new official Kanji added 05/10 to the Japanese lists. Japanese people mix this and 壁 up all the time, so learn them together. Holed Gem is the official Heisig Keyword. (though it has nothing to do with IRL usage. IRL this is just the second half of 完璧. It's only used in that compound, but that compound is very very common, and means Perfect! as an exclamation. ...
column4: perfection: Only the tomatoes of perfection, comparable to jewels, were used for the expensive ketchup.

story: You can try and evade them, but they'll ketchup with you on the road... Sorry, couldn't resist it.
column3: In order to evade the bear, you lie down on the road, put ketchup on yourself, and play dead.
column4: A giant Heinz Tomato Ketchup truck crashed on the road, spilling giant globs of ketchup everywhere. They didn't close the road, but you have to evade the globs of ketchup as you drive.

story: (I don't like the 'red pepper plant' primative so I just go for standing atop a tree). Here we have the woodcutter standing atop a tree waving his brand new axe. "Look what I got for christmas, yippee!"
column3: Axe-man grows a patch of red pepper plants in his back garden. He rubs red peppers on the edge of his axes, and this seems to keep them sharp like brand new.
column4: The Red Hot Chilli Peppers and Axel Rose form a new band.

story: If your firewood is too new and still has flowers on it, it's unsuitable for burning. You need drier wood.
column3: Still giving flowers to that special woman in your life? That's so last year. Everyone knows now with the price of fuel that / "Firewood is the new flowers" / Go on, get some firewood today and make her Valentine's Day dreams come true.
column4: Sometimes, new firewood still has flowers on it.

story: I remember this one the way the Japanese do: a parent standing on top of a tree watching what his or her kid is doing.
column3: A wise parent lets their kids learn. A kid wants to try to eat the red pepper plant, the wise parent says "Try it and see for yourself".
column4: A PARENT STANDING at the top of their family TREE, LOOKING at their kids.

story: happiness is the ONE bite of SPICY curry.
column3: This is one of those rare occasions when I forgo Heisig for other methods. 「幸せから一本取ると辛い」 -- if you take but one stroke away from happiness, you get painfulness. (oh well, Heisig used similar one for 百).
column4: Happiness and pain(spicy) are just one stroke diffence. It's a fine balance.

story: To be tenacious, you need to have deep stores of happiness (so troubles don't discourage you) and you need to be big and round (so hunger doesn't drive you to give up). The most tenacious person of all time was happy round Buddha!
column3: The fat man Santa Claus is tenacious about carrying out his duty to bring happiness to all the children of the world on Christmas day.
column4: Tenacious D is a band of happy, round fellows.

story: Tenaciously clasping something with your hand.
column3: You could tell he was earnest from how tenaciously he shook your hand.
column4: At a Tenacious D concert, Jack Black reaches down and clasps the hands of all those on the front row of the audience.

story: Recall the fashion model wearing just a stamp over his crotch (服 (#1399)). When he got happy, of course, it ended up in the news report.
column3: On the news: "We are happy to report that stamp-sized bikini bottoms are back in style!" (Well, the men are happy about it, at least.)
column4: The REPORT from the doctor made me HAPPY because it said that he had STAMPED out my CROTCH infection.

story: There was a man in a village who had a special gift : whenever he shouted and screamed, his mouth became a cornucopia, overflowing with fruits and food of all sorts. Many of the locals thought he was a cruel man, always screaming at his wife, until they realised he was in fact very kind, and his gift brought prosperity to his family.
column3: You can hold a CORNUCOPIA up to your MOUTH (like a megaphone) to SHOUT lounder. Also notice that the shape of CORNUCOPIA implies the shouts are 4 letter words.
column4: Note: the cornucopia primitive is not described adequately in Heisig. It has 3 strokes as opposed to 2 as mentioned in the book, but on the left may have 2 or 3 depending on who you ask... Also, on the left, the long stroke is written first. See http://forum.koohii.com/viewtopic.php?id=921 and http://forum.koohii.com/viewtopic.php?id=185 for more.

story: A Pepsi promotion where you twist off the cap to find pictures of your favorite heroes like Spider-Man or members of the Fantastic Four.
column3: [twist; ask; investigate; verify] Stories full of twists are difficult to write, because of the cornucopia of threads the author has to manage.
column4: +++SPOILER ALERT+++ For the twist to the next spiderman movie we'll find out that Peter Parker's seemingly endless supply of web is actually produced by a cornucopia.

story: Prostitutes can make a veritable cornucopia of income by using their crotches -- they put the "come" in "income." (A bit lewd perhaps, but effective in keeping this character distinct from similar keywords like 利 (#972) or 稼 (#959)).
column3: Women love men with money. If you have a high income you can get a cornicopia of crotches.
column4: STROKE ORDER WARNING: The order in which the cornucopia primitive is written is altered here. First the long vertical bar, then the L part in either one or two strokes (this seems to vary in different reference materials).

story: A LOWLY single rice grain, DROPPED in an empty FIELD, can produce a CORNUCOPIA of food.
column3: Lowly people only have a drop of brains and use nothing but 4-letter words.
column4: The lowly people with a drop of brains are the ones who labor to produce the cornucopia.

story: There is a grave of a lowly man with a tombstone made of a simple, small stone. If you bow really low you can read the very small inscription engraved on the stone, it says - “Now that you bowed so low to read this, you are as lowly as I once was”.
column3: A STONE makes a LOWLY TOMBSTONE.
column4: A simple stone serves as the tombstone of a lowly peasant.

story: My rice-seedlings have become sentient and will go on a mission. I can only apologise for the next 6 frames. In the distance, there is a pinnacle, which the newly-awakened rice-seedlings who are still stuck in the ground can see. Could it be the Promised Land?
column3: (圥 is the rare kanji for a mushroom. Sticking out of the ground like little knubby legs, it's pretty easy to remember.) Story ~ The land around The Pinnacle has mushrooms covering the ground.
column4: When sailors see land in the distance, they first see the pinnacles of the new land, but when they come close enough they'll be able to make out the rice seedlings, and finally the ground!

story: I keep an intimate relationship with my rice seedlings -- I never take my eye from the soil.
column3: 陸 (#1631) Some of them begin to see eye to eye about the possibility of reaching the promised land. A group of awakened rice-seedlings stuck in the ground becomes intimate and starts to form a plan.
column4: Make eye contact with the sexy girl planting rice seedlings and you can get intimate with her on the ground.

story: 陸 (#1631) The rice-seedlings still stuck in the soil gather round in a circle. Their combined power forces them out of the ground at last.
column3: Mushroom...Fat man....= Mario. Mario jumps on top of Bowser's forces, crushing their evil power.
column4: The fat sumo-farmer forces rice seedlings into the ground with his huge muscles. With his combination of mass and strength, it's not suprising very few of the seedlings survive and he is forced to diet.

story: 陸 (#1631) The rice-seedlings (newly freed from the ground but with soil still clinging to their roots) gather in a circle around an oven fire. They need to heat up prior to their journey (presumably plants can't walk if they're too cold?)
column3: Heat up those RICE SEEDLINGS you pulled from the SOIL in a ROUND pan over a low FLAME. (Note: the hot pan image helps reinforce the idea that this kanji for "atsui" refers to something hot to the touch, as opposed to hot weather).
column4: This is Mario avoiding the fire's heat. http://retromedia.ign.com/retro/image/article/870/870378/super-mario-bros-20080429110134449_640w.jpg.

story: Some girls want diamonds, but others will be satisfied with just flowers. However if you think you can win her over with rice seedlings, expect her to get up on her walking legs and walk on out!
column3: 陸 (#1513) Deciding to use the diamond-shaped water caltrop flower as cover/protection, the rice-seedlings with their walking legs (now free from soil), can start their journey.
column4: Mitsubishi! In Japanese, 三菱 .. "Three Diamonds" .. Now look at their logo! THREE DIAMONDS. Not really a story for remembering this kanji, just wanted to share how I was just amazed by something obvious.

story: 陸 (#1631) However, the pinnacle that the rice-seedlings finally reach with the use of their walking legs turns out not to be the Promised Land after all, but simply a mausoleum (containing many dead rice-seedlings exhausted from previous quests?). Oh no!
column3: On top of The Pinnacle is a masoleum for rice seedling farmers. They make an annual walking pilgrimage there.
column4: Every year, thousands walk up The Pinnacle to see the Mushroom Mausoleum. It's shaped like a mushroom, surrounded by mushrooms, and supposedly Toad is enshrined inside (he died in a fiery Rainbow Road accident).

story: A greedy hog in a top hat who has eaten all of the acorns. He even elbows people out of the way to get them.
column3: Top Hat + Elbow + Person: The sign of the hog was a very recognizable tattoo - a hog with a big grin in a top hat, sticking his elbow into the person next to him.
column4: This is easy, if you know Mr. Peanut, the logo of Planters. Replace his face or body with an acorn and you have Mr. Acorn, the logo / sign of the hog. He wears the same top hat, has the same turned out elbow holding a diagonal walking stick, and poses like a human.

story: The nucleus of an oak TREE is an ACORN.
