column3: Ernest Rutherford discovered the Nucleus. Picture him sitting under a tree pondering atoms, after an ACORN falls on him he suddenly understands that each atom has a nucleus.
column4: [nucleus; core; kernel] Right in the nucleus of the acorn, you can find a future tree.

story: This famous ninja (I always use ninjas with sabres, distinct from samurai) used to engrave the kanji for his name onto acorns, and throw the acorns to distract his enemies. The legend goes that by the time his victims would pick up the acorn and read the engraved kanji, they were already dead.
column3: While it's traditional for lovers to engrave their names on a tree in many countries, in Japan, however, it was traditional for a samurai to signify his undying love for a woman by engraving the kanji of her name on an acorn with his sabre.
column4: TIP: This also means "time"... STORY: The Swiss watchmaker is a master engraver. He engraves the minutes and seconds on an acorn using a tiny saber to make a miniature cuckoo clock... 遅刻[ちこく].

story: I asked my teacher what this strange word meant, and she furiously replied that it was explained in the above-stated paragraph before throwing an acorn at me!
column3: The above-stated words are the acorn from which the following statement grows.
column4: I literally imagined atree with words stuck on acorns. And thus the words are above-stated (that is until they fall on your head I guess). (This one really needs a mental picture).

story: The remains consisted of a skeleton which had the remains of some acorns in its stomach area. Whether it died from eating the acorns remains to be seen.
column3: Hint: The remains of a chipmunk.
column4: Ultimately unsuccessful, all that REMAINS of Scrat (of Ice Age fame) is his SKELETON which is almost clutching the ever elusive ACORN.

story: Acorn Power is the people's way to CENSURE a congressman you don't agree with. Pelt your Senator with acorns today.
column3: Animal Farm works for me - where the hogs have the greatest power of censure.
column4: The liberal squirrel blogged that he would give all his ACORNS to congress if it would exercise its POWER to censure Bush and Cheney.

story: Why are the roads leading through the woods so sticky and dirty? Hmm... I think the forest ranger mentioned something about excess resin on the roads...
column3: No-body mentioned that there was resin on the road. Now I'm stuck!
column4: The resin factory worker sees the boiler about to explode and hesitantly says to his boss, "um, there's something I should mention to you..." At that moment the factory explodes and sends an overflowing batch of resin is cascading down the road bringing fiery death. (Semi-true story, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Boston_Molasses_Disaster).

story: Behold the "Boulev'Art" : a life-size section of a boulevard cast in a huge block of resin. Some call it ... art.
column3: The definition of art is getting more and more loose these days. Why even some resin spilled onto the boulevard is now counted as art! Hmmph!
column4: I get it, when the resin is on a boulevard instead of a road (see complaints in 述 (#1643)), it's art.

story: Some strange animal tried to steal a stalk of celery from my house. However, it was freezing and the floor was covered in ice, so the mysterious animal couldn't get any traction. Picture a stalk of celery and a pair of animal legs slipping and sliding clumsily around the ice, and never able to leave the house. Eventually it got so cold that the little animal froze to death.
column3: The story of gordon is really great except that there is a tremendous mistake : this kanji is used for the weather , the temperature (samui 寒い ) .... not for the feeling to the touch : for this one it's tsumetai 冷たい 冷 (#1404) the jap HOUSE are infamous for being insanely cold . How much cold ? you don't even need a freezer for keeping your CELERY . Worse it's this much cold that there is some ICE on the floor and that you must have arched ANIMAL LEGS like pingoo for moving without falling.
column4: Did you ever see that Tom and Jerry episode where they made it so cold that the inside of the house became a winter wonderland, and Jerry grabbed some celery and used his animal legs to skate and sled around on the ice? It was a real celery-bration, ha ha... ha..

story: The A/C wasn't making the house cold because the filters had been blocked up with dirt.
column3: It was so 寒 (#1645), the pipes blocked up with ice. After removing the ice, we insulated them with soil.
column4: Block up cold house with dirt.

story: On the troical island of JOU, they brew whiskey while wearing grass skirts (top hats and scarves too). (Image: the strangely dresses islanders stirring a pot of brew. Careful 酵 (#1538)).
column3: To me, the grass skirt is composed of six celery sticks and a scarf. Apparently you can brew whiskey out of grass skirts. No wonder it tastes horrible.
column4: Note : up to frame 1530, the kanji share the same chinese reading (JOU), so don't hesitate to group them into the same environment. Here we have the "brew"-man, who brews some kind of whiskey using palm tree leaves. Instead of collecting them himself, he just buys the grass skirts from the people on this tropical island where he lives (which you may name the JOU island, after the chinese reading).

story: The islanders defer to the words of their chief Jou in his grass skirt.
column3: I talked to my Japanese spouse, who confirmed that this kanji does not mean "defer" as in "put off, delay". It means "defer" in the sense of "submit" or "yield".
column4: OddAndersen is correct. 譲る 【ゆずる】 (v5r,vt) to turn over; to assign; to hand over; to transmit; to convey; to sell; to dispose of; to yield; to surrender; (P) 譲渡 【じょうと】 (n,vs) transfer; assignment; conveyance; (P) STORY: I heard of Japanese Boss who SUBMITTED a new notice saying all the female employees must wear GRASS SKIRTS to work. Naturally, the female employees YIELDED to the man's wishes, unable to say a single WORD.

story: My dream is to buy a small lot on a tropical island and spend the rest of my days relaxing in a grass skirt.
column3: On the island of JOU, in order to be considered a lot, a ground must be big enough to grow sufficient grass for a grass skirt.
column4: (RE: Stormchild) My dream is to buy a small lot on a tropical island and spend the rest of my days relaxing surrounded by women ingrass skirts.

story: Conversation at a party: A: "Who is that lass?" B: "Which one?" A: "The woman wearing the grass skirt." B: "Alas, I don't know".
column3: "There once was a lass, whose skirt was made of grass..." insert your own humorous ending.
column4: LASS is short for LAdy-in-a-skirt-made-of-graSS.

story: If you grow up with a mother that drinks and smokes, you can be sure it's poison in the stuff you get from her breasts.
column3: You can use silicone implants to to make your breasts "grow up" but if they leak, it's poison.
column4: For grow up I will be using the idea of Peter Pan the boy who did anything but grow up. Have you ever wondered what happened to Peter Pans mother? My guess is he poisoned her.

story: When he was growing up, Venom never had many friends in elementary school. Maybe it explains why he turned out how he did.
column3: This is a pictogram of string theory. Strings are the most elementary particles of matter, which then grow up to become matter itself.
column4: This kanji has nothing to do with elementary school - it means element, elemental, basic, bare. Imagine the thread as a thread connecting all life, starting from the basic elements and growing up into everything.

story: If you eat lots of barley, you'll grow up to have strong walking legs.
column3: Barley is a very cheap grain, and it's not really worth spending time to harvest. Therefore, scientists have genetically engineered it to grow walking legs once the grain is grown up and mature, so it can harvest itself.
column4: "Grown up" barley, i.e. beer, is what gets you tottering legs.

story: "Once in a blue moon" refers to a rare event. But originally "blue moon" refers to a full moon, in other words a fully grown-up moon. Whether once a month is rare or not depends on what we're talking about, but that happens to be the origin of the expression.
column3: The last time I saw a blue moon was in my youth when I was growing up.
column4: Blue = Smurfs, whose bodies never grow up.

story: Before rice is refined, it is actually blue...bet ya didn't know that!! (alternate....Condi Rice was blue when insurgents blew up the iraqi refinery where oil is refined).
column3: Very refined people in the upper classes have skin as pale as rice and blue blood.
column4: NB This means "spirit", "vitality", "essence", "semen". For vitality, you need to eat healthy food, symbolized by rice, and exercise under the blue sky.

story: That door-to-door salesman can stand outside ringing my doorbell until he's blue in the face. There's a big sign on my front door, and the words clearly say "No Soliciting".
column3: You can talk until you're blue in the face, but if you're trying to solicit me, you're just wasting your time...
column4: Going through smurf blue light district - heres a smurfette saying all sorts of dirty words trying to solicit herself.

story: Feeling blue is a state of mind where you're dominated by your feelings.
column3: Data is feeling blue about not having any feelings ... hey, wait a minute.
column4: Feeling blue is your state of mind when someone hurts your feelings.

story: Sun and blue sky! Yep, the weather's cleared up!
column3: When we speak of clearing up we easily think of both the sun and blue skies. But in another since to clear up is the absence of weather. And therefor the reason weather has no place in its writing.
column4: The sky cleared up and we have a sunny-blue-day.

story: Pure sea water is always a radiant blue.
column3: Bottles of water claim to be pure. They're generally in blue containers, because blue makes you feel like its that much more pure.
column4: Pure water is pure blue.

story: When someone you know who is normally talkative goes quiet, it's usually a sign that they are contending with the blues.
column3: When you feel blue, you want to go somewhere quiet to help you contend with your problems.
column4: "And the next contender is.... a Smurf!" As you can imagine, the crowd goes quiet with shock.

story: As one grows up, one typically starts to blame all of their problems on money.
column3: This is the story of a poor fisherman and his wife. A long time ago he caught an oyster with a small but precious pearl. The intelligent wife told him to sell the pearl immediately: the greedy husband figured if he kept the oyster and fed it, it would grow up and yield an even bigger pearl. One day the oyster grew so big, it crashed through the house and escaped back to sea. The angry wife left her husband, blaming his blind greed for their poverty.
column4: Alice (毒 (#1651)) blames her strange adventures on a batch of bad raw oysters.

story: Spidey's exploits are world famous but still The Daily Bugle's pages blame him for every problem out there.
column3: Spiderman's exploits have earned him fame and blame.
column4: The exploits of the RTK online community are such that every single poster has personified the thread radical into Spiderman. I blame it on the video games and TV that the kids are watching now-a-days.

story: On many wheat cereal boxes, there is a disclaimer stating that "This package is sold by weight, not by volume. Some settling of contents may have occurred." well they only say that because they don't want to be blamed by people getting really disappointed after they see what a small volume of cereal the box really contains.
column3: The volume of the wheat crop is way down this year! Blame the weather!
column4: Wheaties and other cereals are sold by weight, not volume, in order to avoid blame if the contents settle. (simplified version of sweetneet's).

story: [bond; loan; debt] Mr. T buys a lot of high risk bonds and then blames his broker when they all plummet in value.
column3: It also means Loan and Debt: A friend of mine (or if you prefer, Mr. T) bought Bonds worth 1000 dollars, which came from a Loan from his parents. As predicted by his coworkers, family and friends, he lost everything in 3 days. He is the only Person to Blame. Now he has big Debt (true story).
column4: Una fianza permite liberar a una persona de algo que le quieren inculpar.

story: When pickling you MUST use distilled water! When it doesn't come out right, generally it is the water that is to blame.
column3: Bad water is to blame for the process of pickling.
column4: When the pickling doesn't come out right, generally the water is to blame.

story: When I was GROWING UP, the SURFACE of my SCARF was always covered with snot from blowing my nose on it.
column3: Imagine a scarf growing up until it covers the entire SURFACE of the world.
column4: Alice got back to the surface by climbing up the rabbit hole on an extremely long scarf.

story: Mr. T's punching bag has one beat up surface.
column3: Superficial people (ie those who are only concerned about the surface) are obsessed with expensive bags.
column4: Do you know why every person in Japan has a Louis Vuitton bag? After the 1985 JAL air crash that killed 520 people (the world's worst). An image on tv of the crash showed Louis Vuitton bags (whose LV logo covered surface was somehow impervious) litering the crash site. From that point on they stuck in Japanese people's mind's as durable and high quality. (True story).

story: To ensure she remained undefiled, a young girl growing up in a rough area always kept a dagger concealed under her threads, even when she went into the water.
column3: (rgravina) To ensure she remained undefiled, a young girl growing up in a rough area always kept a dagger concealed under her Spiderman underwear (to remember the position of thread), even when she went into the water.
column4: Venom's suit is self-cleaning and remains undefiled, despite its forming weapons, growing up into daggers and killing people, sending drops of fluid (blood) flying everywhere. No water necessary, and his conscience is clean too.

story: Imagine a totalitarian regime where, while growing up, you have to pledge allegiance to the flag at dagger-point and with St. Bernard guard dogs watching you.
column3: With our new pills we pledge to grow your dagger bigger - typical junk mail.
column4: In medieval Japan often to form an alliance Warlords would give up their daughter as a pledge. She would grow up guarded by daggers and St. Bernard dogs. If the alliance was broken she would be killed (More or less true).

story: This means eat/drink/smoke. Maybe you make a pledge to stop gutsing/binging/puffing, but your own mouth is tempting you to put something in it.
column3: I make my mouth pledge to consume less.
column4: After pledging, Alice and the sorority consumed the St. Bernard with their mouths.

story: With kids growing up in your house, you have to keep them from harm of putting anything in their mouth, paint chips, bleach, knvies, etc.
column3: This is silly, but.. If a house suddenly grows up from your mouth, you will come to great harm.
column4: In the house, whenever Alice opens her mouth (to eat or drink) she causes harm (by growing too big for the house).

story: Control is very important! Especially when operating a car. Few people realize the harm they can cause just by losing control of their car for a second. Tremendous harm. Stay in control!
column3: If you lose control of your car, you may come to great harm.
column4: The roads are icy, and a whole bunch of cars have spun out of control! Luckily, it was just a couple of dents; nobody was harmed.

story: [proportion; comparatively; divide; cut; separate; split] Hey, don't take this out of proportion! I did you just a little harm, no need to come over here with a saber...
column3: As shown on this pie-chart, the proportion of people harmed by sabres is relatively a small slice compared to those harmed by guns.
column4: In Japanese anime and video games, the heroes often have sabers that seem way out of proportion to their weilders, especially with how scrawny these pointy-haired kids tend to be. I'm not sure if the proportions of those sabers will cause more harm to their enemies or their weilders... Or, I'm surprised they don't harm themselves with the proportions of their sabres.

story: The constitution is important. At least my parents thought so. In the house where I grew up, it was framed on the wall. Under the watchful (sideways) eye of my mother, we had to study it until we knew it by heart.
column3: The house of US Congress needs to grow up! Their twisted eyes have lost the heart of the constitution.
column4: The original Japanese constitution is locked up deep within the Imperial Palace, home of the Emperor. Since its creation, it's gotten bigger and bigger, and it's even grown a pair of eyes, as well as a beating heart. Naturally the Emperor tries to keep this hidden from the public, but what will they do once the constitution-monster becomes big enough to destroy the palace?

story: This is the first CELL of a human, the foundation of its entire LIFE, a small DROP that will GROW UP to form a complex organism.
column3: Growing Up is just a Drop of our LIFE.
column4: Life starts with a drop of sperm and then you grow up.

story: The sun is the nearest star to the only planet with life - Earth.
column3: Sun is a star that has given life. Can't say that of any other stars yet.
column4: Our star, the sun, gives life to all cells.

story: On awakening the first thing I notice is a (nearly empty) whiskey bottle by my bed. Then I see the stars are still shining. “I think I’ll go back to sleep and try awakening again later.”.
column3: You'll need an awakening after the whiskey bottle makes you see stars.
column4: After spending too much time with the whiskey bottle 酉, he often found himself awakening under the stars 星. 覚醒剤、かくせいざい, stimulant drug.

story: When women marry, they adopt the surname of their husband, signifiying the start of a new life together. (adapted from gorgon).
column3: Woman change their surname when they "start their new life".
column4: To help you keep this separate from 氏 (#1970) (as I have been doing lately...), picture a woman who just married a man, and of course, she adopts his surname and they start a new life together. Throughout their entire life together, he requires her to address him as "sir." Yes, like the sur in "surname".

story: When you're in the state of mind for creating new lives.
column3: this ideogram is used for sex in the sense of gender, such as 女性 or 男性. Therefore the story goes as: you need to be in the right STATE OF MIND to have SEX with a person of the opposite GENDER and create a new LIFE together.
column4: Means sex (gender), also nature or character. Our state of mind 忄 determines our life 生, our nature or character. 女性、じょせい, women; 男性、だんせい, men; 性格、せいかく, personality: 兄は明るい性格です, "My older brother has a cheerful personality." 性に合う、しょうにあう, to fit your nature: 収入は不安定だけど、翻訳って仕事、すごく性に合っているの, "It's not a steady income, but the translating job really suits me."

story: Animal sacrifice = taking the life of a cow.
column3: In the 21st century, animal sacrifice is no longer really necessary. We can take a single cell from a cow, with no harm to the cow. We create a viable cell line from this single cell, and feed the resulting biomatter into a furnace at the exact rate necessary to appease the gods.
column4: There are two kanji that should be kept separate: 犠 (#693) (義), and this one. Think of it this way: in 義 there is a cow and a righteous person (presumably a Hindu). One must be SACRIFICEd, so naturally the righteous Hindu took the place of the holy cow. But as the Hindu is no longer alive to protect the cow, so we will now take the cow's life in an animal sacrifice.

story: If you were to stand up all the products you have accumulated over the course of your entire life on top of one another, the result would probably be as tall as a cliff.
column3: The salesman is standing on the cliff's edge. "Buy my products!! Buy my products! Or else I'll take my own life"! Man, that's selling on pressure.
column4: People stand on a cliff and want to end their lifes. This is a product of todays society.

story: You are struggling to the top across the humps, but you suddenly see the pinnacle and you feel new life in your walking legs.
column3: The hump of a camel is actually a separate animal resting on top of the camel. It has its own walking legs and its own life. These animals are great as pets but are very expensive. A resident of The Pinnacle has bought one of the expensive pets - a hump with walking legs and a life of its own - and is walking it home from the pet store.
column4: In pregnancy when the hump is at its pinnacle, a new life will come out from between the walking legs.

story: "Walking legs" over "bushes" needs to have a primitive meaning of its own. It appears in several kanji, such as 縫 縫 (#1563), 逢 逢 (#2417), 蜂 蜂 (#2687), and 鋒 鋒 (#2768), and it is clumsy to work bushes and walking legs into every story. "Pointy" works fairly well: the walking legs are stuck on top of the pointy part of the bush; and for this character: a summit is the pointy end of a mountain.
column3: If you are using the "walking legs + bushes = pubic hair" primitive... The nudist colony was banished to the top of the mountain's summit, so that nobody would have to see their bushes again!
column4: Moses climbs to the summit of the mountain using his walking legs to talk to the burning bush.

story: A bee is an insect with a pointy (see 峰 (#1562)) stinger.
column3: I got stung by an insect walking through the bushes, I think it was a bee.
column4: Many people think bees are insects with fur. But that is not correct! The "fur" is actually the pubic hair (bush under walking legs).

story: Good thing I brought some thread, cause I need to sew my pants that I tore up walking through the bushes (see 峰 (#1683)) before we hit the road to go back down the mountain.
column3: Spiderman while walking through bushes chasing a villain, rips his suit and stops on the road to sew it up.
column4: Spider man has to sew a new costume. He slipped while web swinging and fell on a bunch of pointy stuff in the road. Ouch! (See Mcfate's 峰 (#1683) story for the "pointy" primitive).

story: I put my fingers together in worship of the bush that hangs from the ceiling -- that wonderful mistletoe which has gotten me kissed by many a girl.
column3: Imagine a weird cult where you hang a bush from the ceiling and then point at it with one finger saying "Bush, bush, bush, I worship the bush!"
column4: PRESIDENT BUSH thought that coming to power would cause people to WORSHIP him, but now that his approval rating is so low, people just give him the FINGER and hang BUSH-pinatas from the CEILING to hit with bats.

story: This old China man glued shrubs to his body. The added intake of oxygen from the shrubs was, according to him, the secret of his longevity. Sometimes he would sit all day in meditation without moving, and the locals believed the old man had actually turned into a shrub !
column3: In an attempt to increase a bush's longevity, an incompitent gardener glues all the leaves back on that have fallen off. Maybe he should have tried watering it instead.
column4: Increase the longevity of a bush by sticking the fallen leaves back on with glue.

story: They made a metal casting of the Chinese man who glued shrubs to himself to increase his longevity. It's now sold around the world as it's thought that having one will increase your own longevity.
column3: Casting things in metal improves their longevity.
column4: We take a casting because metal will have much greater longevity than the original.

story: Once upon a time, in order to enroll in a Christian school you had to answer a series of questions to ensure that you were really Christian. For example, the principal might show you a picture of a Christmas tree and a picture of some bamboo and ask you which one is most suitable for decoration at Christmas time.
column3: Japanese father enrolls his student in a well-rounded school: they teach eastern traditions (the way of the bamboo), western traditions (like Christmas trees), and also teach literature (once upon a time).
column4: Once upon a time, there was a little bamboo plant who tried to enroll as a Christmas tree.

story: In the springtime bonsai get plenty of sun.
column3: When it's springtime you can only leave the bonsai out when the sun has gone down. Their little leaves can't handle too much heat.
column4: Springtime is the best season for Bonsai, because you can leave it out in the sun all day.

story: The tree of spring. Fact: Camellia are highly valued in Japan and elsewhere for their very early flowering, often among the first flowers to appear in the late winter [early spring?].
column3: Anyone who's lived in Japan knows camellia are by far the first tree of spring to flower. And how can you miss those shockingly pink flowers!
column4: CAMELLIA is the TREE that signals with its flowers the arrival of SPRINGTIME.

story: If you look into Japanese gardens they seem so peaceful - with their small bonsais and the white stones looking like rice grains.
column3: A monk pleads with an invading warrior not to destroy his people. "We are a peaceful people," the monk pleads. "Our monks spend all of their time tending to their harmless bonsai trees. And as for food, we require only a few grains of rice."
column4: A bonsai with rice under it (to imitate a miniature white rock garden) is the epitome of a peaceful image.

story: When you play music to them, your bonsai will grow like they are in heaven.
column3: In heaven you are surrounded by bonsai trees (full-sized ones fall through the clouds) while you play music on your harp. I always have trouble remembering that the bonsai tree is on top, so think of them growing on top of the clouds.
column4: I play music to my bonsai to help it grow. Its favourite song is Stairway to Heaven.

story: Bonsais are grown in a house, away from the harsh reality of the real world where they wouldn't survive.
column3: On this rather boring 'big brother' type reality show, they have locked up bonsai inside a house and everyone is watching them on TV 24x7. The viewers have to vote on which bonsai shall remain in the house and which one has to leave.
column4: The reality is that most bonsai don't do well in the house.

story: To join the temple, you have to dedicate yourself to raising bonsai for enlightenment, and cornstalks for sustenance.
column3: A Japanese farmer who was growing corn tried to dedicate himself to the god of corn (in the hope it would bring better harvests). He had a little room with prayer beads, incense, etc. One day he brought an offerand that he thought would please the god of corn : a bonsai - corn (a corn plant turned into a bonsai). The god was infuriated and yelled at him "HOW DARE YOU TORTURE MY CORN IN SUCH WAYS!". The End.
column4: You have to be really dedicated to make a bonsai tree out of a cornstalk.

story: Mr. T gets a stipend every month if he stays dedicated to his temple training, a very hard thing for the impatient T.
column3: You must be kidding... yet another source of confusion, with 稼 (#959), 給 (#1449), 資 (#512), 貯 (#206) and 収 (#1628). A stipend, in English at least, has a connotation of only a small regular payment. Despite a life of dedication, P has to go back to a simple life of tending to bonsai and growing corn after he retires with only a small monthly stipend.
column4: The stipend is given to a person who is very dedicated to his bonsai art so he can study more.

story: Ha! If you know anything about Buddhist monks, during meditation, they're slapped with wooden rods to stay dedicated to their task.
column3: The wood from this tree is dedicated to making rods to flog naughty kids.
column4: After crafting his rod from the finest tree in the land, Moses broke into a battle rap. "I dedicate this rod/ To the all mighty God!"

story: Muttering words of gratitude for a wonderful meal, I discreetly slipped my cabbage under the table for the dog.
column3: Cabbage primitive: When a cabbage is growing up, you must put it in your mouth before it flowers, because that's when it becomes bitter. Seriously, it's called 'bolting' or something. When you're discreet, you try to make your words like a cabbage: well-layered, but in an unassuming way.
column4: HOW TO REMEMBER CABBAGE: it's the flower that is shoved in your mouth while you are growing up (parents force feed you cabbage), note how the "grow up" primitive is pushed into the mouth primitive overlapping. "Muttering words of gratitude for a wonderful meal, I discreetly slipped my cabbage under the table for the dog."

story: To MR.T swallowing a whole CABBAGE is no more than a TRIFLE.
column3: People may consider themselves important but in the cosmic scheme of things, they are merely a trifle of no more worth than a cabbage.
column4: Mr. T is a trifle annoyed when he finds cabbage in his trifle (pun -- trifle is a kind of dessert in UK).

story: Growing cabbages takes muscle and diligence.
column3: With enough diligence, Koreans can turn ordinary cabbage into powerful kimchi.
column4: Bodybuilder diligence: Eat cabbage. Build muscles. Eat cabbage. Build muscles. Eat cabbage. Build muscles...

story: In the water between Japan and China, the Sino- side has put scarecrows in the water to try and keep the Japanese away.
column3: Take the left to be "kanji" not scarecrow. Sino- (Chinese) people had to put a lot of sweat into learning the kanji. See the drops of sweat coming off.
column4: Kanji came from across the water, on the Sino- side of things.

story: A sigh escapes the mouth of the scarecrow, who laments: "...if I only had a brain, I could learn kanji".
column3: I will let out a huge sigh of relief from my mouth when I learn the last kanji.
column4: A sigh escapes the mouth everytime I come across yet ANOTHER kanji i have to learn...

story: It is difficult for a scarecrow to scare a turkey or else they would've been called scareturkeys.
column3: Learning Kanji is difficult for Turkeys.
column4: It is difficult to get back into the kanji learning groove again after going cold turkey for a month or so.

story: The Queen of England taking a walk round a village: 'Excuse me, I couldn't help noticing the splendour of the flowers in your garden. Simply splendid. Ten out of ten.' The villager gruffly replies: 'No it 'aint. It's all muck. An' I'm gonna cut it all down and sell it to the farmer for silage.'
column3: Hint: Splendor in the Grass. Compare with 草. This is just a more splendid version of that kanji.
column4: In all its splendor a delicate flower arose from the pile of silage on a single needle-think stem.

story: For an old man with a walking stick, even a drop of silage to carry on his back will make him droop low down to the floor.
column3: Even a drop of silage is enough to make an old man with a walking stick droop low down to the floor. (rgravina - fixed up order).
column4: Imagine looking through the sight of a hitman's crosshair. The bullet hits, a drop of blood appears on the target's shirt. The target drops his walking stick and starts to droop... finally hitting the floor. (I take 'silage' to mean 'crosshair').

story: When some people are sleeping, their mouths droop open, and saliva drips out.
column3: Easy to remember if you have read the manga -or watched the anime- 謎の彼女X「なぞのかのじょX」("Mysterious Girlfriend X"): a boy who falls in love with a classmate when he sees her dripping drool during a nap (BTW astridtops' story fits in perfectly). Note: The boy's name, 椿「つばき」椿 (#1691), is a wordplay: it's one of the ways you can pronounce this kanji (唾き).
column4: Obviously, the mouth is where saliva droops out.

story: Our eyes droop when we are drowsy.
column3: Hint : the eyes of Droopy Dog (see 垂 (#1705)). When you are drowsy you have "droopy eyes". That is, you have Droopy's eyes!
column4: When you are DROWSY your EYE-lids DROOP, but imagine your whole EYES drooping out of their sockets - Urgh!

story: Wasn't it a cursed spindle that Sleeping Beauty pricked her finger on? Therefore the spindle was the metal that caused her to droop and eventually sleep for 100 years.
column3: Spindle: the needle that drops on an LP record player. This is made of metal. It droops. Viola.
column4: Think of a plumb bob rather than spindle (which are the same shape, and this kanji means both). It's a perfectly literal kanji: drooping metal.

story: It's a hay ride! You sit on piles of silage and everyone likes to imitate old-time farmers with a piece of wheat sticking out of their mouths.
column3: [ride; power; multiplication; record; counter for vehicles; board; mount; join] In the near future, we hope to ride on biomass fueled vehicles. Good news for those who have wheat silage surplus.
column4: The hardest part about being a farmer is when it comes to the slaughter. "Come on boys, we're going for a ride!" "Oh boy, a ride!" say the little wheat sprigs, hopping onto the tractor. The farmer then takes them off to become silage, tears in his eyes.

story: If you go for a ride and find a saber beside you, perhaps you got into an Army surplus jeep.
column3: Recall the wheat sabers we made a 利 (#972) off. We made too many and now there's surplus, for sale on this hay ride.
column4: We got a surplus of people on the hayride. Chop 'em off.

story: My MEETING is at 7- but that's NOW!
column3: (re: ruuku35) The meeting is not at quarter to seven but now!
column4: Looks like a ラ　with a hat. Like a cowboy saying "Raaat now, pardner."

story: This clock includes a mouth that will tell you what the time is now. Hearing impaired people have this kind of watches... now imagine them as a big mouth under the clock.
column3: Batteries included with this clock. Open the mouth at the back and insert them after purchase.
column4: #include < time.h >, < stdio.h >//or clock.h , mouth.h

story: One begins one's life coveting money. One ends one's life coveting time -- those precious seconds ticking away on the clock. Remember to always put time over money (in this kanji and in life).
column3: "Gimme all your money now!" said the covetous criminal.
column4: Covet time over money, for money cannot buy time, as the clock keeps ticking.

story: To versify, words of rhythm needs to shoot out of your MOUTH with a CLOCK-like regularity.
column3: Just imagine a rapper using his mouth to versify with a big clock around his neck.
column4: Versify this kanji as follows: Hickery dickery dock, the mouth ran by the clock.

story: Someone wishing from the bottom of their heart that the clock would stop. A mid-life crisis perhaps.
column3: A wish is something that your heart desires right now.
column4: Remember in the Wizard of Oz when the tin man wished for a heart and the wizard gave him that dinky little clock instead? Well it turns out, somewhere nearby, some poor sap was wishing for a clock and got a heart!

story: Ever try WRENCHING a bolt with just your FINGERS? Trust me, you'll WISH you had a wrench for WRENCHING to save your FINGERS.
column3: "I wish you would accept our friendly offer", the mob guy said, as he started wrenching my fingers one by one.
column4: The keyword refers to twirling or spinning something. Use your fingers the spin the hands on the clock wishing it would turn 5 and you can go home.

story: Two kings were fighting over a beautiful koto (harp). So they had a clock built into it that would measure how long each one played it. That way they could be sure none played it more than othe other.
column3: The two kings want to hear a harp right now!!
column4: A pair 0f kings exchange gifts: a clock and a harp(koto).

story: The only shade at The Pinnacle is in the shadow of the giant clock tower, or from a rising cloud.
column3: The pinnacle is in the shade, because it has now become cloudy.
column4: Frosty the snowman is running around the pinnacle, staying in the shade. As he looks at his clock to see how much longer he can last, small clouds rise (steam) from his body. Nooo, Frosty!

story: Beforehand, this was a halberd but I cut it short so it could be for hand to hand combat.
column3: Your halberd doesn't have a handguard? You should have thought of that beforehand (i.e., before you were missing your hand).
column4: This is the halberd beforehand, i mean: before you draw the hand (the last stroke of halberd).

story: The preface to all human history was written beforehand in caves.
column3: Rename the "beforehand" part to be glove (because you have to wear gloves beforehand if you want to wield the halberd, which is why this primitive is an incomplete halberd). The story: a winter morning. A textbook author is holed up in his tiny office, a veritable cave. He wants to start his masterpiece textbook by first writing the preface. But he can't get started. He sits and stares at empty paper until evening. It gets cold and he puts on gloves, shivering, but still unable to start his preface.
column4: In the preface to his latest edition of RTK, Heisig tells us that until he invented his brilliant kanji-learning method, he was living in a cave beforehand. Luckily, the publishing of the book gave him enough money to move out of the cave into an apartment. He could also finally afford to put a handle on his halberd.

story: Depositing money into your savings account is something you do beforehand if you use your head. If you're in Japan your passbook says 預金機（よきんき）when you make a deposit.
column3: You bang your head on the ATM, wishing you'd deposited some money beforehand.
column4: 預血 means to deposit blood in a blood bank. Imagine bringing a severed head to the blood bank for a blood deposit. Of course, you are wearing gloves when handling the bloody head.

story: These days we all work in front of computers. Beforehand we all worked out in the fields, in the plains.
column3: The plains are a challenging place to get any work done. Be sure you recharge your computer's battery beforehand, or you won't get anything done.
column4: In windows XP, if you don't change the background beforehand, it's that STUPID pitcure of plains. You ALL know what I'm talking about. http://photos.codlib.com/wp-content/uploads/2007/07/bliss_xp.jpg Now that I look at it on Vista, I actually realized how pretty this place really is.

story: Our ninja hero, disguised as a gardener with a rake, is suddenly attacked from both left and right concurrently by bulls with animal horns. Our hero lets out a blood-curdling scream and tears his rake handle vertically in half, so he now has two wooden staffs (split rake handle) to fight with. He grips each staff (left side and right side) and rams it into the horns of the charging bulls. The force of each charging bull causes the tips of each staff to split again (split bottom of each rake handle).
column3: You decide to take the bull by the horns and do both chores concurrently, grabbing your double-handled rake before attempting to clean up both your's and your neighbours' garden. But unfortunately, it's not long until your rake splits in two.
column4: Special rake, used to hold a bull by both horns concurrently. Two handles have V-like ends to set your arms against.

story: Naturally, if you're dating more than one woman concurrently, they will certainly dislike each other!
column3: Attempting to court two women concurrently will make them both dislike you.
column4: WOMEN dislike CASANOVA because he dates more than one concurrently.

story: This is a special sickle with metal blades on both sides. It can cut many things concurrently!
column3: The gold sickle of the USSR flag represents both leaders and workers laboring concurrently.
column4: The sickle was one of the choice weapons of the stealthy ninja. Made of sturdy metal, it could function concurrently as an apparently harmless farming tool, as well as a lethal weapon in combat, as well as a grappling hook. (True story).

story: When you are self-effacing you use words to concurrently bring yourself down and make yourself look better.
column3: Try to compliment a Japanese person and they'll interrupt you by saying self-effacing words concurrently.
column4: Though the man's words were self-effacing, his actions concurrently made it clear that his modesty was false.

story: Stores don't want you to know it, but if you find the secret cave, they run bargains there concurrently to their regular prices. (Image: pulling a certain level in a store to find the "bargain cave).
column3: Think of the cave as a bargain basement, where shoppers rush in concurrently as soon as it opens.
column4: With multiple sales going on concurrently in the same cave, you’re sure to find a bargain.

story: The old west represented by a completely empty whiskey bottle (compare 酉 (#1534) whiskey bottle about one third full).
column3: Note: this kanji is also used to denote Spain.
column4: One of the four directions: The West.

story: Mr. T has a high value in the Old West because you see him in "Wanted" posters all over the place! (thanks fiminor).
column3: What might it mean for a person in the old west to be of value? Their face is on a "Wanted!" poster, of course. Imagine the reward...
column4: Mr T is highly valued in the West.

story: In the Old West, women were needed because nobody knew how to cook or clean.
column3: In some movie with the theme of the Old West, the population of a town finds themselve in dire need of women, after all of the town's womens became crazy and started gunshooting and participating in duels and such.
column4: In the old west the needs of a woman were always at the bottom.

story: If you want to get closer to the actual meaning, then I think that 腰(こし) is more like the hips or the small of the back. After being sat down in the office too long, people often say 腰がいたい！It's the part of the body that needs massaging.
column3: The body part that has more "needs" than any other is the loins.
column4: My loins ache! They need some flesh!

story: In the Old West there were no ballot boxes. Afraid of fraud and fighting among the gunslingers, the ballots were posted into a slot in the top of the local church altar instead. They may have been rough, but the cowboys wouldn't fight in the church.
column3: In the West we show our opinion through the ballot box.
column4: In western political elections (US), peoples ballots will often depend on religion and at which altar the prospective president prays.

story: The political fanatic stole all the ballots and dumped them in the stream. He calmly watched them drift away as the cops came to a screech behind him.
column3: Drifting on the water we held a ballot to decide who to kick off the raft.
column4: Picture a drifting lifeboat, water splashing over the side, and the occupants holding a ballot to decide who to eat next.

story: Trees were frequenly used as signposts in those days, indicating where one had to go to cast their ballots.
column3: Large wooden signposts are planted on peoples lawns, with the faces of their representatives all saying: "Vote [1] Me!" for the upcoming ballot.
column4: [Warning: Not a very nice story] There's a signpost up high in the tree that says where the blacks can cast their ballots. It's so high up, they cannot read it. (In the old West, blacks were able to vote, but prevented from doing so.)

story: Chestnut tree, west nut tree.
column3: Picture an old western cowboy on his front porch shooting chestnuts off his chestnut tree.
column4: The cowboy climbed the tree to see where they were in the woods. The poor guy chose a chestnut tree. ouch ouch.

story: shudder: You’re in the state of mind of shuddering with fear when the chestnut tree is falling over towards you.
column3: Shudder. If chestnut trees were sentient, shudder would be their state of mind as the tree shaker approaches. Note: Tree shakers are used commercially to harvest nuts and cider apples. A tree shaker makes a tree shudder causing all the ripe chestnuts to fall.
column4: shudder in fear: Data shudders in fear whenever he sees a chestnut because they look like tribbles.

story: Since the days of the Old West, traveling has transitioned from trying not to step on big snakes to driving on big roads.
column3: The west has gone through quite a transition, gone are the days when dogs and snakes roamed the desert, it's all roads and casinos now.
column4: I was driving through the desert, west into the sun, wearing my transition light-to-dark glasses. They were too dark, and I accidentally hit a dog. When I got out to see if it was still alive, a rattlesnake bit me. Before I died I saw the dog hobble over and drive off with my car. As I made the transition between life and death, I scratched this kanji into the sand.

story: The U.S.S. Old West has capsized, and all the cowboys on board are trying to restore her upright.
column3: Remember Oregon Trail? Remember how you had to float your wagon across rivers to get to the Old West? Well, sometimes that wagon capsizes. Once that happens you'd better quickly head to the nearest town to restore.
column4: On its journey WEST-ward, the cruise ship CAPSIZED and was damaged so bad that they couldn't RESTORE it.

story: In the Old West, they used to light fires in the ground to make smoke signals.
column3: Should be easy. SMOKE brings to mind "Where there's SMOKE, there's FIRE". So, the FIRE in the OLD WEST can tell people we're you're at, so put out the FIRE with SOIL to keep the SMOKE to a minimum.
column4: In the old west people not only fired up and smoked tobacco filling the air with its smoke but they chewed it too, spitting it on the ground.

story: South of my belt leads to happiness.
column3: In the south (Southern Alabama, Southern Africa, picture any south, but choose one and stick with it) "they measure happyness by the belt". If someone has a larger belly (and a longer belt), it is believed they are well fed and thus are happy.
column4: A BELT cost 10 YEN in the SOUTH.

story: We traveled to southern Japan just to see a camphor tree. It's what we came for.
column3: Trivia: Cinnamomum camphora is native to Taiwan, southern Japan, southeast China and Indochina,.
column4: Fact: the Japanese camphor tree grows in the southern regions of Japan. It must have been regarded as a very special tree in ancient times having a kanji dedicated to it depicting exactly the region from which it grows. It's also used as an insect repellent, in the manufacture of film, plastics, lacquers, and explosives, and in medicine chiefly in external preparations to relieve mild pain and itching.

story: A South Korean street vendor is offering chihuahu snacks.
column3: If you go to someones place and the food sucks, you lower it down south of the table as an offering to their dog.
column4: KFC is offering southern fried chiwawa for a limited time only.

story: Heisig's stroke order in the 4th edition (and earlier) is wrong, so be careful -- first is the left-most vertical stroke, then draw the rest of the "sun" attachment as you would normally. In fact, if you just wrote it out as two suns with elongated sides, you'll get the stroke order exactly correct.
column3: The gates to Hell. guarded by Cerebus or ... Bill Gates?
column4: Bill Gates is just about to walk into a saloon.

story: A mouth on the Gates of Hell says "Answer me these questions three, or thru the gates ye soon will be".
column3: The mouth is the gate from which questions are asked.
column4: There's a mouth on the gates that asks you a question before letting you in.

story: A little devil at the gates of hell reviews your record to see if you're evil enough to get in.
column3: Gates' IS the devil. He releases software that clearly hasn't gone through any kind of review process.
column4: As I was reviewing for my exam at a quiet saloon, the devil popped out of nowhere and offered to make sure I pass. But I told him no way, since that's cheating. Besides, I'm just reviewing things I already know. I won't fail. But he kept insisting, so I kicked him and sent him crashing through the entrance gates.

story: You set a guard at the gate to fell intruders not of your clique.
column3: The felled souls of the world, cut down like trees, pass through the gates of hell and join the clique.
column4: A clique is a small exclusive group of people usually gathering around a leader or for a common purpose. Here we see Mr. T's fan club meeting for a fiesta at a very select club called the 'Perly Gates'.

story: The interval between star systems (suns) was too large, so the stargates were created to travel between them.
column3: We open the gates at regular intervals to let a bit of sun in.
column4: At regular intervals the gates of Hell burn like the sun keeping all within nice and toasty. Interval paining.

story: Through the gates of hell there is no sound, no light, its all pitch dark.
column3: I like to think of a horror movie where the protagonists enter a graveyard when suddenly their flashlights go out and it becomes pitch dark, whereupon they hear the sound of the gate creaking shut behind them.
column4: When it is pitch dark, you must navigate by sound.

story: The simplicity of bamboo plant is in all its joints being at equal intervals.
column3: [simplicity; brevity] The ししおどし is a bamboo device for scaring birds from the gates of your garden by clacking against a stone at regular intervals. Its design is simplicity itself. (Inspired by PepeSeco).
column4: Wordplay: simplicity -> simcity. You are playing a game of SimCity, a city simulator. You can choose from one of several pre-defined city layouts. One of the city layouts is called "SimpliCity (a simple city for SimCity)". This layout has nothing but an empty field with bamboo trees planted at regular intervals.

story: To open the gate, use your both hands.
column3: Sure you can squeeze through these gates by kicking them or pushing them with your body, but if you want to get them wide open, you need to do that with both your hands.
column4: To open those big heavy Gates of Hell it takes both hands...

story: The gates are too big to be closed by man. Only a genie can. "Close sesame!"
column3: "オー no! I stayed out past curfew, and now the gate has been closed!"
column4: Bill GATES keeps his operating system CLOSED, does that make him a GENIUS? I think not.

story: To keep this distinct from other kanji such as "watchtower" and "pagoda", I use the mnemonic "towering tower". -- In some old 8-bit kung-fu videogame, with a plot similar as Bruce Lee's last, unfinished movie, the hero must break through a gate at each level of the towering tower, fighting with opponents using various styles of kung-fu until he meets the finale at the topmost level of the "towering tower".
column3: Remember the two towers from lord of the rings... each has it's own - very difficult to master - entrance gate.
column4: There is a tower on each side of the gate, they are posts for archers.

story: Imagine the gates the Garden of Eden, the ultimate land of leisure. You're not allowed in, but if you peek through you can see trees.
column3: Beyond the Gates of Hell, there is only one leisure spot for all the billions of souls within, a single tree beneath which people can sit for a few seconds. Ah, but that moment of leisure makes the rest of Hell that much worse...
column4: Imagine Leisure Suit Larry walking through the saloon doors with wood in his pants, hoping to get lucky.

story: Press your ear to the gates and see if you can hear what is going on inside.
column3: To distinguish from listen, you hear someone at the door (gate).
column4: At the GATES of Hell, along with the mouth that asks the impossible questions there is of course a giant EAR to HEAR the answers. The ear doesn't really listen as it knows they will always be wrong.

story: Forgetting about the moat, the king stepped out of his gate and landed in the water. Needless to say he got wet.
column3: (I had the same idea as Dingomick) I imagine some prankster who put a bucket full of water on top of the huge gates, so that it would fall on the king as he came through them. See the king now, between the gates, all wet, dripping drops of water.
column4: Some prankster threw water on the king as he came to the city gates. Now he's all wet.

story: A column of text scratched on a black tree beside the gates of Hell: To the East lies The Beast.
column3: Ancient morning newspaper column, posted daily on a tree at the east gate. Why the east gate? Well, it's a morning paper, and the sun rises in the east, so the morning rays shining through the gate illuminate it nicely. I picture all the ojisan who rise in the wee hours gathering around the tree each, waiting for the sun rise so they can read the paper. "Been coming here every day for 40 years! Can't start the day without my paper!"
column4: This is a column of text, as used in a newspaper. The trick for this kanji is that to mark the columns in the old printers, you place wooden blocks at certain intervals of the paper. Now, look at the right part; it looks as if you had put a wooden block in an interval primitive. That graphical reminder will help you to remember this kanji!!

story: During the saloon brawl, one guy got glued to a table and was tossed out through the saloon gates. But he really wanted to fight, so he ran back through those gates (with the table still glued to his back) only to be tossed out again. Imagine him repeatedly running in and being tossed back out.
column3: Food fight! Look, beans are stuck to the gates like glue.
column4: Bill Gates and Mr. Bean having a glue fight.

story: Hint : the "godown" is like a warehouse, it's on the docks and mostly in Asia. To make an image distinct from that of "warehouse" or "storehouse", etc, I picture the goods stored there, piled up on pallets really high, and thus they have to "godown" before they can be taken outside. The front of this godown is a "meeting of small gates", i.e. a row of gates through which goods come in and out. The mouth can be an opening somewhere in the back, or the top, where cranes lift down the goods.
column3: Note: this is not gate but actually a variation of door and is written as such, with the vertical stroke last not first.
column4: Imagine a mafia godown at the docks where shifty mafia types meet and lots of dodgy deals godown. This is a very secret place, so there is only one gate, and to enter you have to say the password with your mouth.

story: Back in the day the people were so excited to get hold of the Sega genesis they looted the godown with sabers.
column3: The genesis of my hatred of kanji learning is when you get so mad that you have to look up what a godown is, and you end up cutting the book (or even Heisig himself) up with a saber.
column4: In the story of Genesis Adam and Even were kicked out of the Garden of Eden. They had to "go down" out of the garden and the entrace was guarded with sabers to prevent their return.

story: This looks like a pictogram of 3 fingers from each hand trying to open up a crack in a wall. That's an un-believable way to escape from prison OR the UN- have a prison in the Hague.
column3: People in the jail cell are un-friendly, un-comely, and un-cooperative.
column4: Un-zipped.

story: I pity the fool/ Who put me in this jail cell/ I pity the fool. (Credit taijuando).
column3: I pity the fool/ Who put me in this jail/ I pity the fool.
column4: Person is put in jail for writing a haiku with the wrong number of syllables.

story: When ordered to go to the jail cell, the defendant gave the judge the finger and said he repudiated all that the legal system stood for if they were going to send an innocent man like him to jail.
column3: He reached his fingers through the bars of his jail cell, trying to touch his beloved. But she repudiated him and left.
column4: Once he had his fingers around the jail cell bars he repudiated all ties with his former gang!

story: Saddness is like having your heart captured and jailed because of some sad or terrible event, etc. Here the sad heart waits for someone to come and un-lock their jail cell and set them free again.
column3: Stuck in a jail cell with his heart crying out to see his family again, the prisoner has never felt so sad.
column4: A jail cell will make any heart sad.

story: It is his guilt that is causing them. He is having these nightmares where the great (sideways) eye appears at the top of his jail cell, and is staring down intently at him. Guilt is a merciless tormentor.
column3: EYE-witnesses helped prove this person's GUILT and put them in a JAIL CELL... now constantly under the watchful EYES of the prison guards.
column4: He is guilty! you can see it in his eyes.. Throw that man into a jail cell!

story: Some man jailed in Russia, is freed by his comrade (from the Communist party perhaps), who crashes into the jail cell with a vehicle.
column3: (+fuaburisu) But it's the wrong jail cell! Your comrade is one floor above.
column4: When you're in JAIL, your COMRADE will come and DRIVE a car through the JAIL CELL, coming FROM BELOW to bust you out.

story: The only way out of a jail cell is to serve your time and walk out the front door. There are no other doors.
column3: An old man serving a very long jail sentence painted a life-like door at the back of his jail cell, hlafway open, with the blue sky, clouds, etc, as some kind of symbol of freedom. Every time the prison officers come to take him they ask him to come to the door. The old man with a grin always answers "Which door?", looking at his painted door with a grin. And the prison officer always answer, sighing - "The front door !".
column4: It's a sad reflection on modern times that our front doors need to be built like jail cells to keep us safe. 扉 (とびら) : door, opening.

story: Mr. T is made a marquis after he and the A-Team save the life of a duke. The duke also gives Mr. T the key to the gentleman's dart room where one can relax in luxury, smoke a cigar, and play a friendly game of darts. Mr. T eagerly accepts the key and places it on one of the gold chains that hang around his neck which acts as a key chain.
column3: (Going off various) Mr. T. is made a marquis and given the key to the city. But somebody disagrees with it and assassinates him with a dart.
column4: MR.T had one final challenge before he would be promoted to a MARQUIS. He must shoot a DART through the hole of a KEY.

story: "If the marquis opens his mouth one more time, I'll cut his throat", his rival the baron said.
column3: I think of "clearing your throat". Some stuffy guy opens his mouth to clear his throat so the marquis can speak.
column4: Every time the MOUTH of the MARQUIS opens, it's "ahem ahem" clearing his throat.

story: The marquis has absolutely no interest in issuses of climate change. He's old and near death. [Don't forget the walking stick to symbolize his old age.]
column3: The marquis moves to a warmer climate after he gets old enough to need a walking stick to get around.
column4: In his old age (walking stick) Marquis T becomes Al Gore's climate control nemisis.

story: "Decide!" "Decide?! Death by drowning in polluted water or death by guillotine. How can I decide?" I asked.
column3: To decide if someone is a witch or not first dunk them in water. If they don't drown they are a witch and can be sent to the guillotine.
column4: Waterboarding? Guillotine? The Decider has decided both these are legal and moral. I keep mixing this up with 択 (#1155). Try associating these negative options with our half-wit "decider" to build a distinction.

story: A large crowd in a cheerful state of mind applaude each criminal as they become victims of the guillotine.
column3: Data is cheerful as he goes to the guillotine. That's because he knows he can just solder his head back on afterwards.
column4: A cheerful crowd of insulted aliens applaude as Data's head is chopped off by guillotine.

story: Mr. T is certainly an ADMIRABLE PERSON, so much so that parents are buying lockets with his picture in it and having their children wear them like amulets.
column3: For locket: The locket (key dangling from something, the vertical stroke) opens like a mouth, but you need a jeweler's monocle to make out the pictures within. ----- Dracula survives a staking attempt when the locket with Mina's admirable picture deflects the blow. "It was an admirable attempt," he admits as he sucks his attacker's blood.
column4: She thought that Mr. T was a tough, heartless guy, but then she found out that he carries around a locket with a picture of his daughter. Suddenly, she found it admirable that he had such a soft side.

story: You lose your precious locket on the road to somewhere. You ask people if they've seen it, but no luck. "Just buy another one," someone says. "I mean, what's the difference?" Then of course you say "Well, it makes a huge difference!! Since it has sentimental value, I don't want a different one! " Then of course they understand.
column3: You loose your LOCKET on the ROAD and report it to the 交番. They find one, and show it to you. 「これですか？」 But it's the wrong one... You say, 「いいえ。。違います。。」.
column4: An odd version of The Road Less Traveled: "I found a locket in the road, and that has made all the difference."

story: Spiderman buys a locket for Mary Jane because he wants to get HORIZONTAL with her.
column3: Spiderman on a boat, marking the Earth's latitudes. He first attaches a personal locket to a small piece of thread for ballast and good luck, and shoots with his right hand. After a few minutes (and lots and lots of thread), the locket and thread have flown around the world. Spiderman catches the locket with his left hand, and ties the thread's ends together. Voilà.
column4: Hint : this kanji also means "latitude", which are the horizontal lines on a globe. Do you remember James Heisig's story for frame 175 "black ink" ? Here a cartographer on a ship, is using his "thread locket" to mark horizontal lines on a map. He pulls a chalked thread from the locket, and snaps it to mark horizontal lines. Imagine the "thread-locket" in the shape of a globe, filled with dark powder and a little bobbin of thread.

story: [defense; protection] For "defense against the dark arts" class, you go the magical boulevard and buy an enchanted locket.
column3: Since it was in the middle of the boulevard, everyone could see she hit the man only in self-defense, as he was trying to steal her valuable locket.
column4: I think of defense as an attribute in video games. Like Final Fantasy, for example. When you go to a new town, you walk up and down the boulevard for shops that will sell you better items. One of the best accessory items for defense is a locket that absorbs magical energy. Unfortunately, you can't buy it yet, as it costs over a hundred thousand gil.

story: There's a young Korean male actor, Yon-sama, famous amongst middle-aged Japanese women. Extremely famous. Read about his affect on Japan/Korean relations on Everything2.com. In any case, women just flipped over this guy, traveled to Korea to see his home, started taking Korean language classes, etc. So, imagine here the misty eyes of the Japanese women as they clutch their lockets with Yon-sama's picture inside watching his Korean romantic mini series called "Winter Sonata".
column3: This character represents the flag of South Korea: a locket (circular taegeuk) in the middle of the mist (white background). http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flag_of_South_Korea.
column4: The Korean army is wearing "mist lockets". When the lockets are opened, a mist spreads about a meter over the floor level, which allows the Koreans to advance without being seen.

story: Dry one item in ten minutes on the clothesline.
column3: Vampire: Upside down samurai. They suck humans dry.
column4: Note: the book shows the strokes for potato rather than dry...dry does not have the hook at the end.

story: Well you all know that the liver is the part of the body that would be quite grateful if you led a dry lifestyle (i.e. no alcohol).
column3: Imagine a beat up liver(too much alcohol). The doctor takes your liver out of your body, and puts it on a clothes line to dry off. Then puts it back in your body, sealing up the flesh. A dry liver is a healthy liver he chuckles as he puts it back.
column4: The slaughterhouse prefers to ship dried liver to the supermarkets (can you imagine boxes soaked in blood on the truck that delivers them?). Imagine them lifting the slabs of flesh and hanging them on the clothesline to dry.

story: The newspaper pages are hung on the clotheseline to dry and then cut down with a sabre to be published.
column3: The newspaper pages are hung on the clotheseline to dry. This gives the government a chance to censor the news: they cut up unwanted stories with a sabre. Therefore, only state-approved stories are published.
column4: The author's work was so dry that he had to threaten the publisher with a sabre in order to get them to publish it.

story: The way sweat is supposed to work: it gets your skin wet, and then as it evaporates/dries, it cools you off.
column3: When you sweat your clothes become soaked with water, prompting you to hang them to dry on a clothesline.
column4: Sweat a process to regulate body temperature : water comes out of the pores of the skin, and when it dries it cools you off.

story: Flats in the city are crowded. You get a space for your car in front, and a clothesline out back. Nothing else.
column3: Small flats (garages) for cars help keeping them dry.
column4: Did you hear about the guy obsessed with his car? He keeps it in his flat to keep dry.

story: At the base of mountain cliffs, there is usually a beach. You often can see people lying there, drying off after a swim.
column3: Three impossibilities for a beach: There cannot be a beach at the top of a mountain. There cannot be a beach on the top of a cliff. There cannot be a beach that is completely dry.
column4: I use a play on words here to help with the similar keywords such as "strand", and "coast". The Beach Boys just had a concert down at the beach, and they're all wet after the performance. It's not dry enough down at the beach so they climb the nearest cliff. Still, it's not dry enough there so they climb the nearest mountain. Finally, the air seems dry and they take a rest while their clothes dry.

story: A fine mist is falling, and so everyone gathers around near the tree-trunk, effectively using the rest of the tree as an umbrella in order to keep dry.
column3: By astridtops - In the rainy mist, Totoro is standing in front of a tree-trunk at the bus stop, under the umbrella he just received. Look at him smiling: even when the big drops fall, he remains dry! Great story...which I get to by thinking: tree-trunk->TT ->Tonari no Totoro. I also imagine Mickey Mouse is there too as the KUNyomi for this kanji is みき.
column4: Note: The literal meaning of "shinkansen" is not "bullet train" but "new trunk line" 新幹線 because it only runs on a few main trunk lines. Regular trains serve all the branch lines to smaller cities.

story: If your potatos are growing flowers and those little hooked roots, you should either buy less or eat them faster.
column3: If your potatoes are growing flowers, you need to store them in a more dry place, like hanging them on hooks so they don't accumulate moisture on the floor.
column4: Believe it or not, originally the potato was cultivated because of its beautiful flowers rather than for eating the actual "potato" below. (historical fact).

story: Under the eaves of the house the poor family has potate plants.
column3: Very good image Erik. To help those who struggleded with this, the eaves of a house is usually the bit where you hang the roof gutter along, usually made of zinc or plastic and shaped as a half-pipe. It catches rain water, so it flows to a drain pipe instead of down onto people and windows. And in this family the potato plants grow along the eaves so the water pours down on them. They are poor. so no gutter.
column4: This kanji means universe, seen here as a roof as that was how it was represented back then the vault of heaven. Today, we know that seen from the universe, our planet has the aspect of a potato, and not a perfect sphere.

story: You hang an umbrella upside-down on a hook of the scales and fill it with little potatoes. No luck: it weights too much.
column3: This is the kanji for 「あまり Amari」, which means too little in negative sentences and too much in the rest (always with a negative sense). I take the liberty of using the symbol ">" (more than, another meaning!!) as the umbrella component, and using 二 (#2) and 小 (#110) for the potato primitive. So, this kanji either means "two much" (more than 2) or "two little". (thanks, Virtua_leaf and Thunderball!)
column4: I was worried that my POTATOES were getting TOO MUCH direct sunlight so I stood over them with an UMBRELLA. Now they are getting too LITTLE rain! I clearly have TOO MUCH free time on my hands.

story: To become a member of The Pinnacle, they test you on a scale. If you weigh too much, they exclude you.
column3: You won't make it unless you exclude something. The climb to the pinacle cannot be completed if you are carrying too much. You just have to decide what you can afford to exclude.
column4: Before entering The Pinnacle, one must be weighed on a scale. The authorities have to exclude anyone who is over 300 pds since their weight might damage the floor.

story: You can't expect weight loss to happen overnight. You should limit going to the scale to weigh yourself to once a day or once a week, in order to observe the anticipated weight loss gradually.
column3: I set up a column chart next to my scales so I could record my weight gradually changing.
column4: Remember the urban legend of the ARMY COLUMN that weighed TOO MUCH with their rythmic marching that the bridge collapsed? Now ARMY COLUMNS will march GRADUALLY across so that they do not bear TOO MUCH on the bridge.

story: Amazed at the weight of his crotch, they conferred every honor upon him. (Image: guy with his junk on a scale getting a medal pinned to his chest/around his neck/being knighted, etc.)
column3: When you confer again 又, you confer too much 余!
column4: I bet there is some medal that is confered to the sumo wrestler weighting the most. Imagine him stepping on the scale and being declared the winner. Now where does the medal go, as he's only wearing a 'mawashi'? Right: directly on his crotch. Sorry for the image, but it'll stick.

story: On this route, all trucks have to check in at the scales before they can get on the road.
column3: There are too many roads, so you need to plan a route.
column4: Truck drivers in the US have to drive the truck onto some massive scales at state borders, for tax reasons. They have to plan their route accordingly; there aren't scales on every road.

story: The main bar of an old-fashioned scale(balance) will be very diagonal if you place a giant measuring cup on one side.
column3: The scale tilts diagonally when a measuring cup filled with too much is set on one end.
column4: The constellation of libra (meaning " scales" in latin) is diagonal to the handle of the big dipper.

story: If you add too much water to the paint it will drip onto the ground.
column3: A true artisan mixes his own paint from water and soils on a scale in careful proportions.
column4: People ask why the ground of our backyard is entirely white. Well, my cheapskate dad wanted to add a fresh coat of white paint to our house. He bought the biggest, cheapest tub, placed it on a scale in our yard, and started diluting it with water. It was working fine, and he was adding water drop by drop and carefully checking the weight each time. However, his hand slipped, and he added too much water and the scale broke down violently, spilling the paint all over the ground.

story: Mnemonic: Bundle of joy. Here I see the proverbial stork with a baby hanging from its mouth fly straight into a tree. Painful, but he doesn't drop the bundle.
column3: Unlike in 杏, this big mouth isn't content to wait for apricots to fall in his mouth, so he has climbed the tree and is taking them in bundles.
column4: A bundle of some kind has been stuffed into the opening of a tree.

story: We found a bundle of severed heads in your room, its difficult to trust you.
column3: Don't Trust the press just a bundle of lies on every page!
column4: [trust; request] Do you trust anything? Actually we do, as long as a bundle of heads say the same thing. If a bundle of scientist's heads say we live in a 12 dimensions universe, why should we not trust them?

story: You need complete trust in your water guide to attempt Class 5 rapids.
column3: The water in the rapids can't be trusted.
column4: You can never trust the water in the rapids, it will do everything it can to pull you under. Imagine a line of natives with bundles upon their heads all fighting the rapids to cross the river.

story: This is an imperial order for pizza. To deliver the huge bundle of pizzas to the emperor, the pizza boy needs huge muscles.
column3: Imperial order carries quite a bundle of executive power.
column4: "Did someone have an imperial order for pizza?" says the muscular delivery boy with a large "bundle" in the new adult film, "The Emperor's Nude Groove".

story: [True story] In Osaka the homeless (the alienated) live in large numbers around the city zoo. Picture them in winter all bundled up in rags trying to keep warm, alienated from the society, living literally worst than the animals in the zoo who at least are bundled in their natural furs and have pens to live in sheltered from the elements.
column3: This kanji is so strange that it was alienated at the kanji zoo. The bundle of joy stork bundles this kanji up and takes it to a kanji foster home.
column4: Think of a Kanji Zoo, where we bundle up all the bizarre and hard to remember kanji, to be ridiculed and alienated from the other more sensible kanji. This kanji definately belongs there!

story: bitter, spicy, bundle: In a desperate attempt of creating a new drink, they decided to mix a bitter drink with a spicy one -- now bundled together for the same price of one! However, bitterness didn't go well with the spicy, as seen in the misshape to the left.
column3: The bitter taste was so awful that I put whole bundle of spice in my mouth to get rid of it.
column4: A spicy bundle of herbs to counteract the bitterness.

story: If you find a bundle of money on the road, pick it up quick before anyone notices.
column3: Uh oh. The stork just dropped the bundle of joy in the middle of the road. Somebody save it, quick!
column4: A bundle of optic fibers running along the road makes for quick internet access.

story: Recycling in Japan, you have to make sure all your bundles are organized correctly otherwise the taskmasters won't accept them.
column3: Organize, def: when taskmasters bundle tasks correctly.
column4: When a bundle of taskmasters organize something chances are it won't be done correctly because they are constantly arguing.

story: If it helps, make the awl primitive ice pick instead. They're basically the same thing. This kanji is an easy David vs. Goliath story of the icepick vs. the saber...
column3: Every self-respecting ninja knows the story of "The Awl and the Sabre". According to the legend, a woman once defended herself by using an awl against a sabre! She used to work all day with that awl. However, the bandit using the sabre had no skill. And thus the awl beat the sabre. And from there the saying goes : "The sabre is powerless against the awl, if one can't use the sabre."
column4: ICE PICK primitive: How do you FIT a PERSON into a tight BOX (mouth primitive)? Poke holes in him with a ICE PICK, draining the blood and making the body smaller. STORY: If that does not work, take out your SABER and cut them up into neat pieces.

story: The edge of The Pinnacle is precipitous, so they have a guard posted with an ice pick to poke people and keep them from the edge.
column3: Getting to the Pinnacle is a very precipitous climb. You need to drive awls into the wall as you climb up.
column4: Well I have someone climbing an inflatable precipitous pinnacle. Once at the top it is so precipitous that the person is afraid to climb down and instead punctures the inflatable pinnacle with an awl to get safely and slowly back to the ground.

story: You're giving a TREE an EXAMINATION. You take a wood sample from the TREE with an AWL (cmp 校 (#1371)).
column3: After intense cross-examination from the prosecutor, the tree confessed to murdering the wood-pecker with an awl... "He just kept at it, he kept poking at me with that beak, so I thought I'd see how HE liked it!!" The autopsy examination revealed at least a dozen puncture wounds, what a brutal case.
column4: You're giving the tree an examination. You use an ice pick to chip a sample of the tree for examination.

story: Mr. T is as frugal as they come. He uses his one ice pick for everything: to eat, pick his teeth, clean his toilet, kill people, cook, etc.
column3: Mr. T is so frugal, he hires Frankenstein as a butler because he doesn't have to pay him.
column4: Mr T is a frugal person in spite of his brash appearance. He brings an awl with him to fight for the A team, not wasting needless ammo and dynamite, since no one ever gets killed anyway in A team series.

story: The first computer in the world was as heavy as thousand computers are now.
column3: To me it looks like a car with two extra wheels, like a truck. As it is a very heavy vehicle I suggest an image of a huge mining truck, like the yellow Liebherr T282B. Remember that the first "wheel" is a bit bent. http://www.primidi.com/2004/06/21.html.
column4: 1000（千）computers (里)　are so heavy.

story: Even though the furniture is heavy, it'll be easy to move with all the muscles that he has.
column3: His MUSCLES are so HEAVY, he barely can move...thats ironic.
column4: Heavy things can be moved with a bit of muscle.

story: A tumor is a useless body part that is nothing but heavy.
column3: The world's heaviest tumor ever removed from a human body was a 300-pound stomach tumor, removed in 1991 in Stanford Hospital. Now that's a heavy body part!
column4: When flesh clumps together and gets heavy, it forms a tumor.

story: A meritorious deed? Like moving a damsel in distress out of a fire, maybe.
column3: Prometheus did a meritous deed for humanity by MOVING FIRE from the gods to us humans.
column4: Oskar Schindler is best remembered for his meritorious deed: moving 1200 Jews to his factory so that they could be saved from the fires of Auschwitz.

story: Mr. T's real line of work is for a moving company.
column3: A person who moves something is doing work, physically speaking.
column4: Mr T, move. Mr Ts new exercise video called "Work it suckaz". Here is shouting "move it work it move work it!"

story: This kanji also means "Seed." STORY: Scientists have developed a new SPECIES of WHEAT that has large HEAVY seeds. Now we can feed the world.
column3: After the whole low-carb craze, scientists developed a new low-carb species of wheat, so that dieters could eat it without getting heavier.
column4: The heavy wheat is a special type or species of wheat used to fatten livestock.

story: Two heavy trucks in a game of chicken collide while racing toward each other on the boulevard.
column3: Something heavy rolling down the middle of the boulevard is definitely going to end up colliding with something.
