column4: 衝 【しょう】 (n) (1) important point (e.g. on a route); (2) important role (responsibility, etc.); (3) (astronomical) opposition. STORY:Two HEAVY trucks are playing a game of chicken on the BOULEVARD. However, they both missed the IMPORTANT POINT: that they have to turn in different directions. Naturally, they COLLIDE when they both turn in the same direction. (ty dingomick).

story: Do you know how they make those FRAGRANT air fresheners? Well you take some FLOWERS, compress them with a HEAVY weight, and put them on an OVEN FIRE for a while... (cmp 芳 (#532)).
column3: The heavier the flowers the stronger their fragrance when you burn them.
column4: These flowers emit very heavy fragrance when burned over the fire (e.g. the fragrant jasmine flowers).

story: Caveman got ill after flying third class. The cabin air and food got to him. (Primitive: these all got MUCH easier when using CAVEMAN instead. ).
column3: If you hang around a third class hospital, you'll get ill with the sickness everyone else has.
column4: Hint: The ill in ill almost looks like the roman numeral III. Use as a hint to 3rd class. The ill are more abundant in third class countries (third world).

story: Of course caveman is stupid. He doesn't know anything. He's a caveman!
column3: This kanji shows stupidity as a "knowledge-sickness". Everybody can be stupid at times, and it usually happens because of a lack of experience. Hence the stupidity is a "knowledge sickness".
column4: Ever since reading dingomick's story, I've had this dialogue stuck in my head when I come across the keyword: "Caveman not stupid, Caveman know things."

story: Caveman has horrible pox. They look like edamame beans oozing bight green paste.
column3: Pox is a sickness which symptoms include bean-shaped bumps on the skin.
column4: Mr. Bean tries to explain to the caveman that he is covered in chicken pox and not to come near him, but the caveman misunderstands and eats him. "THIS CHICKEN POX NOT TASTE GOOD."

story: Once you have all the symptoms right, you have correctly identified the sickness.
column3: A sickness can only be correctly diagnosed if the symptoms are identified correctly.
column4: One of the SYMPTOMS of being a CAVEMAN is you don't get much CORRECT in a test.

story: The witches piggy bank was cursed with a spell causing any thief who stole it's contents to fall ill. The illness would result in the victim being covered from head to toe in a mass of carbuncles. Crime doesn't pay!
column3: Caveman has to open up his piggy bank to receive treatment for his monstrous carbuncle.
column4: His sickness caused numerous carbuncles, which when emptied by the doctors also emptied his piggy bank.

story: The sickness that only allows you to eat monkey crotch will surely make you lose weight.
column3: Caveman want to lose weight... but not know how. He sees a lean monkey playing with its crotch. Ah! So that's how I lose weight, and he imitates the monkey.
column4: Simian Immunodeficiency Virus, the precursor to HIV, is a sickness that is transmitted by carnal knowledge of a monkey's crotch. Naturally, it causes one to lose weight. Cavemen used to catch it all the time.

story: I picture a sick caveman, and two people rapidly blowing darts at him. One is blowing poison darts, the other is blowing antidote darts. Will the sick caveman live or die? Depends on how rapidly they fire.
column3: If shot with a poison dart, sickness develops rapidly.
column4: Hm, it's getting tougher to differentiate similar kanji: 迅 (#280), 急 (#1146), 速 (#1669). Let's consider rapidly as a rapid-fire weapon: rat-tat-tat-tat-tat-tat. This weapon fires poison darts rapidly in an automatic rapid-fire fashion. The poison darts are not lethal; they merely induce sickness in the victims.

story: If you go through women rapidly you will be the object of envy.
column3: Ah, puberty ... the girl that starts her journey towards womanhood the most rapidly will become the subject of envy from all her classmates.
column4: Women get envious very rapidly. Picture one woman walking into a party in a gorgeous dress, and all other women there rapidly getting envious of her beautiful dress.

story: For a country full of pay-per-use public toilets, sudden diarrhea is certainly the most profitable sickness!
column3: Diarrhea is a sickness that makes wheat go through me like a saber.
column4: This poor caveman happens to have celiac disease (an allergy to wheat). Eating wheat gives him terrible diarrhea. It feels like a rack of sabers going through!

story: I suffer from silver-sickness, that is, if anything made of silver even touches my skin it leaves a scar.
column3: Caveman has a scar because he was shot with a silver bullet when he was mistaken for a werewolf.
column4: silver nitrate will burn away sick tissue, but it will leave a scar. (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silver_nitrate#Medicine).

story: I picture an exhausted sick caveman snuggling up in a comfy pelt blanket.
column3: Your body feels tired when you have a sickness. All you want to do is wrap yourself up in a nice warm pelt and get better.
column4: Caveman was tired after hauling mammoth pelts all day.

story: Sickness-missiles are being engineered by bio-terrorists to spread epidemics all over the world. Imagine seeing footage of a place where those sickness-missiles are built : rows after rows of missiles, and if you look closely on each is inscribed in tiny letters the name of different sickness such as "flu", "plague", etc.
column3: SICKNESS / MISSILE ** Hint: True fact about biochemical warfare: in the medieval and ancient world, SICKNESS in the form of the corpses of those who had died from some EPIDEMIC or plague were often hurled at the enemy via the crude MISSILE launchers of the time. [C].
column4: When CAVEMAN first fashions a primitive MISSILE and kills a mammoth with it, the technique spreads like an EPIDEMIC across the inhabited world.

story: The CAVEMAN felt such a pain after his POGO STICK got stuck in his butt.
column3: When I was feeling sick my mum said I shouldn't go out to play on my pogo stick until I felt better. Well I wasn't strong enough to stay up on it and so fell over and have the pain to prove my mum right.
column4: Think of the phrase pain in the xxx. Then think of a pogostick up your xxx. That's painful, right? The real question is why a pogostick is up your xxx. That's sick, dude.

story: Caveman has a bad mannerism of putting ketchup on everything he eats. I guess that's ok since raw mammoth can't be too good...
column3: This mannerism is a sickness of the modern generation. It was only recently that we started putting ketchup on everything.
column4: Building on inuki's idea: Monk, who suffers from OCD (a sickness involving mannerisms) sees a row of ketchup bottles at a restaurant crime scene and spends twenty minutes making the Heinz labels face exactly the same direction.

story: Young kids likes to hide in cardboard boxes. (Primitive: CARDBOARD BOX, especially kids playing with them.)
column3: This kanji doesn't really mean hide in the sense of hide and seek. It is more towards the meaning of hiding one's identity. --------------------------AKA anonymity----------- Schools are getting so strict now about personal identity, that they make young children keep anonymity by making them wear cardboard boxes over there heads.
column4: Note that stroke order with box primitive is as follows: first horizontal line, then enclosed element, and then a hook (it's incorrect in 4th edition).

story: Most people don't know that one of the most revered artisans in Japan preserves the ancient art of cutting cardboard boxes with an ax.
column3: The axe murderer considered himself an artisan for how his tastefully chopped up his victims and arranged their remains artfully in boxes.
column4: Hint: Artisan/Ax Def: An artisan is a skilled manual worker; a craftsperson. Here we see his tools represented by the artisan's ax stored in his toolbox.

story: The doctor puts the cardboard box on his head and throws a dart at a chart to determine his patients' illnesses.
column3: This DOCTOR prefers to use DARTS instead of syringes for injections. Here, he pulls out his BOX of DARTS, and the child on the examination table squirms.
column4: The doctor is tired of seeing one patient after another wanting vaccinations, so he steps into the waiting room with a big box full of darts loaded with the medicine. Bam, bam, bam, all done.

story: This kanji is used commonly as a counter for small animals. This is a pictograph of a SMALL ANIMAL'S view from inside a CARDBOARD BOX looking out at his masters HUMAN LEGS. He's probably hiding so the master does not COUNT him with the other animals which will probably be eaten (thus he avoids everyones EQUAL fate on the farm: the kitchen table).
column3: Put a box over everyone's heads, letting only the legs show, and we all look pretty much equal.
column4: 4 - 1 = this kanji.

story: That's the homeless ward of the city. Wolverine lives in a cardboard box there.
column3: In the Akihabara ward, it is mandated that every resident own an X-BOX (well more like a PS3 but you get the point).
column4: In the homeless ward of the city you see people sleeping in CARDBOARD BOXES using a SHEAF as a pillow.

story: The hinge on Wolverine's cardboard box is made of wood because he doesn't have enough budget to buy metal hinges.
column3: You notice a hinge on a tree and realize there's a secret door. You open it up to find an Xbox!!!
column4: The hinge in this hospital ward was made of wood because they didn't have enough budget to buy metal hinges.

story: The city decides to disperse the homeless ward with a precision missile assault. They didn't know Wolverine was living in a cardboard box there though...
column3: The biggest assault on Japan during WW2 is when the wards in Hiroshima and Nagasaki were wiped out by nuclear missiles.
column4: Kids these days are just assaulted by violent games. Just look at these X-Box games - they all have missiles in them! Even Barbie Horse Adventure!

story: "Europe? Yawn... I've been to every ward(country/area)," says Wolverine interviewed from his cardboard box.
column3: [Europe] X-Box was first released in America and Japan (the biggest videogame markets). Europe had an X-Box lack for a while...
column4: Do japanese consider Europe like just a ward, boring enough to make them yawn?? This kanji is offensive!

story: A true stamp collecting nerd won't be able to repress the urge to get his fingers on the latest box of collector stamps!
column3: They would repress dissents by cutting off their fingers and mailing them to relatives in small boxes (of course including stamps for proper postage).
column4: A chikan (bus-molester) tries to repress his finger-groping desire by refusing to travel by bus anymore. Instead, he seals himself in a box, makes sure there are enough postage stamps on the outside, and mails himself. He's a good man at heart , you see... just a bit of a slave to his libido. (I suggest using this same Chikan as the primitive for the "box and stamp" combo on the right side of this kanji, which come up more than once later on).

story: All stamps in Mr T's collection box are lied carefully face-up.
column3: Mr T with the post package at the post office: 'these stamps don't stick to the box, foo' Postguy:' Try it again but this time with the stamp, face-up.'
column4: A person who is a stamp collector has all of the stamps face-up in their box.

story: Stamp-collectors sit and wait on the road to welcome new mail arrivals.
column3: The stamp collector goes out to the road to welcome the arrival of his new stamp box.
column4: I welcome the box from Amazon (a box with stamps on it) that has come a long way.

story: When an American Indian warrior dies, his body is placed on a TABLE inside a TEEPEE, and a ritualistic ceremony is held to encourage his spirit to ASCEND to that big buffalo hunting ground in the sky.
column3: When I was a kid I went out camping in a teepee. I ate beans for dinner, and afterwards I produced so much gas that my teepee actually ascended in the air!
column4: Mr Bean ascends a teepee, which then collapses, flattening the American Indians trapped inside.

story: Scuba divers know that when you ascend in the water, your lucidity increases (For non-divers, the deeper you go, the more you become mentally impaired by nitrogen narcosis, every 50 feet is like drinking one martini). Scuba divers also know that as you ascend in the water, the lucidity of the water improves, too.
column3: Lucid dreams allow me to control what is happening. In a drowning nightmare, I forced lucidity and allowed myself ascend to the surface.
column4: The keyword refers to limpid water, but also to something that is clear (as in "crystal clear"). In Buddhism the thinking mind is often compared to a pond : if you stir the water, the mud from the bottom mixes with the water, and the mind is "muddy". To attain lucidity, one has to let the mud settle, or as in this kanji, take a shortcut and just ascend through the water.

story: Two pairs of human legs poking out of a teepee: you know there'll be a discharge soon, be it sexual, violent (husband returns home with a weapon), or dishonourable (soldier caught molesting a native), or perhaps all of the above.
column3: The indian chief went into his teepee and found his wife sleeping with a cowboy. He discharged his gun at the two people, and left with their legs discharging out the door.
column4: The soldier was dishonorably discharged when his commanding officer saw two pairs of legs sticking out of a teepee designed for just one soldier.

story: I think discharging nuclear weapons should be abolished. That includes underground tests in caves. You listening Kim Jong-il?
column3: Guns were abolished, so gun enthusiats left for the hills to discharge their guns in caves.
column4: Discharging guns in caves was abolished because the ricochets were causing too many injuries.

story: Trivia: The right primitive is kagaribi - 尞 - fuel used for sacrifices. I would use sacred bonfire as a primitive . (Mnemonic: Top is a merged image of big and fire - big sacred bonfire that looks like little sun). Story: Your colleague got fired literally... in a sacred bonfire by Mr.T.
column3: Some businesses allow pets in the office. Here, my colleague is Mr T and he set up a little pup tent for his minidog, then turns around and completes his TPS reports.
column4: A colleague implies someone that you share work with, such as in your company or profession, etc. Here your colleague helps you to erect your pup tent during a company outing. Note: Heisig's warning to keep this distinct from other similiar kanji such as 朋 (#19), 友 (#760), 伴 (#1287) and 輩 (#1765). That is why I chose to have the person element pictured as someone (the colleague in this case) helping with the work of building the pup tent.

story: I paint a huge eye on the side of my pup tent. Why? – It’s obvious: when I’m at the camping site it makes it obvious which tent is mine so I can quickly locate it.
column3: Users of Kanji Koohii, please open your eyes! What your eyes see here is OBVIOUSLY NOT a puptent, and has never been one. This is actually kagaribi (尞), fuel used for sacrifices. And as a primitive, you can call it sacred bonfire. I know this wasn't OBVIOUS at first... but I hope it's OBVIOUS to you now ☺.
column4: It is obvious that you shouldn't be staring into sacred bonfires with your eyes.

story: This guy would rather use his pup-tent as a house, than sleep in the dormitory. So he effectively turned that pup-tent into a house by getting a postal address for it etc. (just to emphasize house).
column3: To please gods and pass next exams you set a whole dormitory (house) afire. Wow! What a sacred bonfire!
column4: All-male dormitories in Japan are really weird, and tend to have a little too much 男気. Here is a trick they play where if they find that one dorm member has pitched a "pup tent" while sleeping, they make it into a house by putting a little roof on top of it -- complete with a lit cigarette for a chimney -- and wait for the "fun" to start (fun meaning...lighting their friend's genitals on fire).

story: In Final Fantasy 4, sleeping in a tent completely heals you and recovers all your HP and MP (and cures any sickness your characters may have).
column3: The sick caveman asks gods to heal him (from a hangover) and sets a sacred bonfire in his cave.
column4: Sick caveman has to sleep in his pup tent. Not the cave because to humid and cold but a nice small pup tent in the sun will heal him from his cold.

story: Start with a circumference and carve away until you get the shape you want.
column3: [My primitive for shape is Mystique, the shape-shifter from X-Men.] Mystique the shape-shifter carves obscure markings around the circumfrence of her blue body.
column4: (Primitive: shape - when you were three you played with Play-Doh.) 彫: Did anyone else use the circumference of the Play-Doh container to carve circular shapes?

story: Everyone in the kindergarten came up with fun and interesting shapes made out of Play-Doh, except for the kid with the amputated arm. Seems like you really need both hands.
column3: Of coure, a sculptor needs both hands to shape his works of art.
column4: Two hands can make many shapes.

story: The sun over the capital cast a shadow with the same shape.
column3: Mystique the shape-shifter blends into the scenery by transforming into a form that looks like little more than an animated shadow.
column4: You make some of the famous scenery of Kyoto out of play-doh, even going so far as to add some black play-doh to depict shadow.

story: Cedar is an evergreen tree that keeps its SHAPE all year long. That is, it doesn't loose its needles/leaves in the winter.
column3: Mystique leaning against a cedar tree for a photo shoot.
column4: Why do cedar trees keep their shape (don't lose their needles)? Because they're not real trees, they're made out of play-doh.

story: When coloring something in you grab the crayon of choice to fill in the shapes.
column3: In Sydney we occasionally get exotic birds. You first notice a colouring in a tree. You look more carefully and you make out the shape of a bird (here represented by its claws).
column4: Mystique the shape-shifter changes the coloring of her skin to camouflage tones and perches herself in a tree like a vulture waiting for her pray.

story: The shape of a sheriff's badge makes it patent who he is.
column3: Note: the keyword has nothing to do with trademarks and is to be understood in the sense of a "public recognition". However the kanji is not common, so getting the exact meaning is not a big deal.
column4: This is patent in the sense of being clear, not a patent for an invention. Mystique is wearing a badge to make it clear who she is no matter what she morphs into.

story: A young lad is standing atop a cliff, looking at the writhing shape of his fallen lass below.
column3: A lad standing on the top of a cliff, looking into the far, and thinking how to shape his future.
column4: A naughty young lad stands on the cliff and throws his Playdoh off the edge.

story: The lad jumps off the cliff, breaks his head, and smashes his face.
column3: When I was a lad, a pretty face was all it took for someone to get in my head, and I'd fill pages of lovelorn letters to them.
column4: Normally, lads have a pretty face, but an empty head….

story: Why, I OUGHT to RESHAPE your HEAD...
column3: Since this Kanji is exceptional, the shape ought to be on the left side. Got that into your head?
column4: You ought to like the shape of your head because you can't change it.

story: An injured body part may swell. It will begin to throb like a bass drum and will change shape.
column3: If a PART OF your BODY begins to SWELL and resembles the SHAPE of a bass DRUM, you’re either pregnant or in desperate need of a diet.
column4: This kanji does not mean swell as in a inflammation. There is a different kanji for that meaning (腫れる). This kanji means swell as in, a tire swelling/expanding, your income swelling/expanding, dough swelling/expanding, etc. Johnskb's story is best b/c it does not involve swelling in the sense of inflammation, just general expansion of the stomach. STORY: "If a PART OF your BODY begins to SWELL/EXPAND and resembles the SHAPE of a bass DRUM, you’re either pregnant or in desperate need of a diet."

story: I'm going to visit my grandpa in the hospital. He broke his elbow, and it became really big and contorted into a weird shape. I hope he will be all right!
column3: Hint: This is the humble/old kanji of the verb "to go/to come", and also is the kanji for "three" on legal documents. I suggest using the "three musketeers" for this primitive, raising their three blades with the elbow. (the elbow primitive could be viewed as a pictograph of the musketeer's hat, with a feather on the side, too).
column4: Whenever the postman has to pay a visit to this place, he brings an elbow-shaped thingy that he throws to the St. Bernard.

story: Whenever I have to visit the relatives... that puts me in one hell of a wretched state of mind.
column3: Data feels wretched because he has no family to visit.
column4: I don't know about you, but it seems to me that whenever I'm in a wretched state of mind and just want to be left alone, that's the time that other people always seem to decide to visit me!

story: Mr. T is a harsh taskmaster who will discipline you (beat you into shape) with his walking stick.
column3: Note : the meaning is in the positive sense, to cultivate one's character or interests. To work to make yourself or something better.
column4: A Jedi knight learns self-discipline from Yoda - a taskmaster with a walking stick - as well as to keep him or herself in shape. 研修 けんしゅう training, induction; 修理 しゅうり repair, mending, servicing; 修了 しゅうりょう completion (of a course).

story: The king has a really rare umbrella, it can change shape.
column3: Tip: umbrella + shape : This combination of primitives appears four times in Heisig, so it may be worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest "parasol" (because it is the same shape as an umbrella). REF: rare (FRAME 1723) , 診 (#1860), 疹 (#2624), 謬 (#2752).
column4: It's rare to see the king carrying his own parasol - typically he gets one of his attendants to do it for him (thanks to Katsuo for umbrella + shape = parasol and to Peppi for the story idea).

story: The doctor at my checkup was expressing words of concern about my umbrella shaped gut.
column3: At a check-up the proctologist views an X-Ray. I say, is that shape an umbrella?
column4: At my last check-up, the doctor said to me: "Start carrying a parasol, or you might get skin cancer. You've been tanning too much!" [Umbrella over shape = parasol].

story: A twist on greenapple: The teacher puts a tophat on all pupils with gramatically correct sentences, while the rest are left with a big red X on their homework.
column3: The teacher in the tophat puts an X on all the grammatically incorrect sentences.
column4: I celebrated finishing the Heisig books by buying myself a plaid top hat (top hat with criss cross pattern to symbolize the crisscrossing flashcards) and then I began the AJATT sentence method.

story: When sitting vis-a-vis, Scots will glue their kilt down to avoid embaressment.
column3: This is a character that is used in Japanese for "vs." (as in, "Alien vs. Predator").
column4: The word vis-a-vis is like sentence glue, it kind of joins sentences together.

story: Who knew that Spiderman was Scottish! He has sewn his family crest onto his uniform.
column3: A family crest sown on to a garment with thread sometimes has a Latin sentence as a motto.
column4: If you look closely, you can see that on SPIDERMAN'S CREST, there is sown in his favorite SENTENCE, "with great power, comes great responsibility."

story: The mosquito (an insect) knows only one sentence: Bzzzzz.
column3: Mosquitoes are the insect who love Scots in plaid kilts because it makes for easy access to the best parts.
column4: How to tell a scottish mosquito? Easy. They are the insects with the plaid kilts on. (imagine a far side comic strip with a bunch of mosquitos at a house party).

story: The sentences exchanged between the two kings got more and more heated, finally leading to a fight which left the whole area speckled with blood.
column3: Two kings, kilt: After an hour in the onsen, the two scottish kings, both heavily speckled like the scottish are wont to, decide to get out. However, in the mean time one of their kilts was stolen and only one was left.
column4: The Scotsman's balls (班 (#1315)) were speckled like quail eggs.

story: The Scotsman goalkeeper adjusted himself. He reached down and adjusted the two things between his skinny fencepost legs.
column3: HINT: this kanji as a primitive can mean goalkeeper. The "fence posts" are goalposts, and the two goalkeepers wear plaid uniforms (this kanji also means uniform as in even), making them uniform with each other and distinguishing them as goalkeepers from the rest of the team.
column4: The sentence was adjusted to fit in between the two fenceposts.

story: When my medicine dose is way too large, I adjust it by cutting it into smaller pieces with my saber.
column3: We had to adjust his dose slightly, after he went on a rampage with a sabre.
column4: The Scotsman goalkeeper took a dose of medicine injected by saber, like a real man.

story: When the goalkeeper finishes the game, he drinks a lot of water and adjusts himself.
column3: Finish him! Subzero adjusts the water in your body and crushes you into a few million pieces.
column4: After you finish exercising, be sure to drink some water and adjust your pace (cool down and stretch).

story: An exorcism, or "purification" of the soul. The possessed girl is tied to two posts next to the altar, her head spinning around and around. Then the priest says the required sentence: "The power of Christ compels you!"
column3: A scottish priest in a tartan kilt has put his altar between a couple of fence posts and is now playing the bagpipes in a very Scottish purification rite.
column4: Kind of vulgar, but here the SCOTSMAN got tired of adjusting himself so decided try PURIFICATION. Sadly, he did it by straddling the ALTAR with his skinny LEGS.

story: Even though it's a maddening task, the monks stay solemn as they rake rice between the fenceposts.
column3: Note: This is not sieve as it has a full rice and not rice grains and the hook is missing from rake. Also the given stroke order is incorrect (fenceposts should come last).
column4: This is a zen rice garden. It is different from rock garden in only one aspect. Here you see raked white rice between the fenceposts. In solemn silence the monks rake rice every morning.

story: Playing baseball in a rice field with sparklers stuck into the ground to act as bases.
column3: The traditional New Year's baseball game in Japan is held at midnight in a rice field. They stick sparklers in the ground for the bases so they can be seen, and to be more festive.
column4: Warning! warning! Base compromised initiating Computer on self destruct mode.

story: Zelda: Ocarina of Time - The white sparkly thing is Navi. She's hovering/dancing around a tree to the legendary Lost Woods music.
column3: The most amazing new bird has been found: it's white and produces the most beautiful music. It sits in trees all day and shoots out sparks as it sings.
column4: I learned this as enjoyable (which is 楽しい -　たのしい） Music is - 音楽 - おんがく as in sounds that are enjoyable.

story: New-age medicine involves using things like music and flowers (aromatherapy) as treatment.
column3: Flowers and music are the best medicine to make you happy.
column4: Oh man, this medicinal marijuana is making me hear MUSIC and see FLOWERS everywhere...

story: Keep separate from proportion. Gandalf is trying to adjust the aspect ratio of his monitor from 4:3 to 16:9 so that he can watch Lord of the Rings in widescreen format. He's poking around the inside of his monitor with a magnesium needle when he causes a short circuit which sets his needle on fire making the needle look just like a sparkler.
column3: It's quite mysterious how each sparkler gives of sparkles at a precise ratio of ten to one. Physicists have been studying this effect for decades, known as the Sparkler Effect, and using it to explain why stars look like sparklers in the night sky.
column4: A witches spell requires the proper RATIO of ingredients: "TEN SPARKLERS and TEN COCOONS into the HAT ye load, wait TEN minutes and watch it explooooode! hehehehehe".

story: If you eat something astringent water will stop the sparkly sensation in your mouth.
column3: I think that Heisig meant this as the "slightly bitter but fresh" meaning that it can have to describe foods like lemons (しぶい). So imagine a guy trying a cocktail (water), feeling like he's been kicked in the face (footprint) and sparks are flying from his tongue. 'How did it taste?'. 'Hmm, yes, slightly bitter, but fresh".
column4: An astringent is also a medical term for something that causes puckering of the flesh or can stop bleeding. An astringent is the liquid you'd need if you step on a sparkler.

story: Now that I'm a responsible adult, I have to get my vicarious thrills from watching stupid people put sparklers up to their ears and burn their fingers.
column3: I put my fingers in my ears to avoid going deaf while getting a vicarious thrill from watching kids light off sparklers and fireworks on Chinese New Year.
column4: [+mspertus] My friend is too afraid of loud noises, so while we go out to enjoy the sparklers and fireworks on New Years, he stays at home and watches everything on TV so he can have a vicarious experience. Just the sight of them freaks him out though, so he watches with the volume low and his fingers firmly planted in his ears.

story: A person with a big mouth wants to be the center of attention.
column3: Youve got the st bernard dead centre in your sights (the box).
column4: I see this as a modern-day pictogram for someone walking in carrying a big birthday cake, with one fat candle at its CENTRE (to remind me that the CENTRE vertical juts up from the "cake"), and to be placed at the CENTRE of a table, in honor of the person who's the day's CENTRE of attention. (I use the CENTRE instead of CENTER to promote the connection with 英 (#1878), 英.)

story: The original great seal of the king of England had a very ornate flower in the center.
column3: England was once the flowering center of civilization.
column4: Greenwich Park, the center of the World (0° longitude), covered with flowers. [thanks mistamark].

story: In the solar system, the Sun is the central source of all light, everything else just reflects it.
column3: A solar power plant consists of thousands of mirrors reflecting the sun's rays, concentrating the energy on a focal point at the centre. See here: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_Two.
column4: Imagine the sun, at the center of our solar system, like a huge disco-ball (a ball made with hundreds of tiny mirrors), reflecting the light from the planets and stars around (instead of emitting light on its own). The kanji refers to images which are reflected, mirrored and also projected, as in the kanji compound 映画 (eiga) : a movie, film. A projected image is like a reflection of the original material.

story: He was stabbed with a dagger, and little drops of red blood dropped onto the ground.
column3: There was red all over the soil after Little Red Riding Hood plunged a dagger into the wolf. Those two dots we see are wolfies animal legs we see, by the way (a la smithsonian).
column4: The soil was red after the hunter used his dagger to cut off the animal's legs.

story: The student blushed until his face was red, so the schoolmaster decided to pardon him.
column3: Blushing red while asking for a pardon from the taskmaster.
column4: Pardon the fart of the RED faced TASKMASTER.

story: It's quite unusual and abnormal to see an apple with walking legs running away from the person who wants to eat it!
column3: Imagine an apple on walking legs on stage singing "It's not unusual to be loved by anyone" (Tom Jones). Keyword can be confused with 異 (#1797).
column4: In Japan, it's very unusual for people to eat whilst walking down the street. When Japanese people visit western countries and see someone eating an apple or a banana on the street, they find it very strange. This is true.

story: Pirate pokes the tip of his wooden leg into an apple to disguise his tracks.
column3: To hide his distinctive wood-leg tracks, this pirate is throwing apples after his tracks in order for animals to come and confuse his tracks.
column4: Sir, these are definitely fake tracks. How do you know? One foot is a wooden leg, and the other is an apple.

story: The barbarian picks an apple from above and eats it even though there is a worm (insect) in it.
column3: Barbarians eat apples with worms still in them.
column4: Imagine a barbarian choosing between two apples - one full of insects, and one without. The barbarian of course decides to eat the one with insects - "I need my meat for the day!"

story: The romance between Snow White and Prince Charming started when Snow White took a bite of poison apple and her heart stopped.
column3: A childhood romance: a boy takes a red apple to school to try to win the heart of his beloved.
column4: You're the apple of my heart!

story: In his most daring feat, William tell used his bow to shoot an apple off the head of his son across the water of the gulf.
column3: An army of archers must cross a gulf of water. Fortunately there are millions of apple trees growing in the cliffs above the gulf. The archers use their bows to shoot down apple after apple, which all fall into the water and slowly fill up the the gulf until the archer soliders can cross on foot.
column4: This is one beauty of a kanji! Looks like a painting of a sunset. You can see the sea (water), the coast shaped like a bow and the red sun (or some red apples trees planted nearby).

story: The salad did not look very appetizing... The sprouts were yellow and there were animal legs sticking out of it.
column3: My face turned yellow when I watched my salad sprout animal legs and start scurrying across the table. Check please!
column4: The salad goes yellow sprouts legs and runs off.

story: A tree went all yellow. It died and fell down, ending up sideways.
column3: In a horrible accident, a yellow schoolbus gets wrapped sideways around a tree.
column4: Imagine a TREE that grows BANANAS that is so heavy that it made the TREE fall SIDEWAYS.

story: Japanese censorship laws require pornos to use a mosaic screen, so you can't see what the porno chick is grasping with her fingers (but you can assume, neetch).
column3: Your fingers grasp the Rubic's cube... if only your brain could too.
column4: To me, the 'mosaic' primitive looks just like a computer mouse. (Grasping your fingers around the computer mouse.)

story: Bound up in the Rubik's cube are the 6 different colours.
column3: Ever look closely at mosaics? They contain a bunch of images bound up into a larger one. It seems amazing until you realize that the only quality of the smaller images that really matters is their colour.
column4: This kanji has a secondary meaning relating to sex (so stop reading now if you have issues) and originally showed a bending person (bound up) over another bending person (mosaic). This might help as an alternative to the mosaic primitive. (Say, doggy-style? Works ok for 把 (#1889) "grasp the love handles with your fingers during doggy-style", but I'm not sure about 肥 (#1893)...Oh, wait, how about "be careful with your flesh during doggy-style of you might fertilize her"? No? Oh well...)

story: The Spider-man's multi-colored tie-dye costume comic book series was discontinued after only one issue because of poor sales and fan protests.
column3: Spiderman has decided to discontinue his red color suit in favor of the black one, it looks way cooler.
column4: As times move on and fashion tastes inevitably change, threads of certain colors often get discontinued.

story: To print something with bountiful colour, they use glossy paper.
column3: If you go to have photo’s printed, you may be asked if you would like a matted or GLOSSY finish. For nature shots, with BOUNTIFUL COLORS, I would recommend going with GLOSSY paper.
column4: Similar to the previous frame. The glossy pages of many magazines are bountiful in "color".

story: PART OF YOUR BODY excretes something that is commonly used for FERTILIZER. Sometimes this process is slow, so you solve a RUBIK'S CUBE while you sit and wait.
column3: If you're sick, a part of your body may produce fertilizer that makes a colorful mosaic.
column4: Natural fertilizer comes from a part of the body that cannot be shown on TV and therefore needs to be covered by mosaic.

story: Little red riding hood is carrying around a wicker basket filled with sweet baked cookies for granny.
column3: I let this be a honey pot. Wicker basket just doesn't do it for me.
column4: Sweet twenty-one. The next sweet number after sweet sixteen.

story: Much like Violet Beauregarde from Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, Spiderman failed to heed Willy Wonka's warnings, and upon chewing on the 3 course meal chewing gum turned a very navy shade of navy blue.
column3: The sailor in the navy blue uniform grabbed the lollipop from the little girl, but luckily Spiderman swung in and saved it for her.
column4: Spiderman bought his sweet a navy blue dress. Imagine Mary Jane walking down some stairs looking dazzling in it.

story: I had the same idea as fuabrisu. A generic person is described here as having body sort of like a tree trunk and head sort of like a wicker basket.
column3: Two girls with a lollipop in a tree gossiping' so-and so did this.' 'really? so-and what did she do' ' o she is sooo wrong..'
column4: Tip : you can make so-and-so a person, which will help with the following kanji. Mr so-and-so has no defining features, i.e. no mouth, no eyes, just a grey blob.

story: I imagine a clique of catty girls conspiring against a another girl...they are exchanging lots of words, chatting about how so-and-so girl is now up to such-and-such (gasp!), and how they will spread the word about it.
column3: Talking about so and so behind their back.
column4: When you conspire against someone, you use the word "so-and-so" in case they or one of their friends are listening.

story: In a divorce, the woman needs a mediator because she won't talk to that so-and-so. Imagine the woman on the ground and the so-and-so up in the tree, and the poor mediator climbing up and down, trying to mediate their fight.
column3: In a divorce, the woman needs a mediator because she won't talk to that so-and-so.
column4: The two little gossiping girls with their lollipops are having a fight. Now an adult woman (mom or teacher) has to come between them an serve as a mediator.

story: Kasparov practices deceit by grabbing your rook while pretending to yawn.
column3: Bushel-basket = pictograph of chess rook (running over the board). Trying to deceive the opponent with a yawn while positioning a rook on the board.
column4: Every day, a smuggler takes bushel baskets on donkeys across the border. But the border patrols can never arrest him for lack of evidence no matter how much they search the bushel baskets: they can't find whatever he is smuggling. What was his deceit? He was smuggling donkeys!

story: Chess piece = wooden rook.
column3: The machine at the chess piece factor takes in whole trees and spits out thousands of chess pieces into the barrel.
column4: Ever seen those huge chess games in parks? The large wooden chess pieces need to be carted in a shopping trolley.

story: The United Republic of Chess' national flag is actually a banner with a rook, that way they can hang it at every tournament.
column3: The national flag of Croatia. It's a banner with the Croatian coat of arms, commonly referred to as the Chessboard (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_Croatia).
column4: After 9-11, people sold national flags by the bushel-basket. And for every bushel-basket you buy, you get a free banner with some cheesy patriotic quote.

story: The slowest remote chess game ever: a one month period between every move.
column3: The slowest chess game ever: It took him a one month period to move the rook! (Edited from dingomick).
column4: One BUSHEL BASKET full of rice is enough to sustain a small family for a PERIOD of one MONTH.

story: Go is chess played with stones.
column3: The ignorant gaijin put a rook on top of his opponent's stone when playing Go, much to the consternation of the Japanese players.
column4: Go needs a bushel basket full of stones to play it.

story: Fundamentals of chess: use the rooks to protect your ground.
column3: Before playing chess, you must learn the fundamentals: begin by placing a rook on the ground.
column4: A Bushel-basket full of earth contains the fundementals of farming. i.e. earth.

story: It's a tremendous match between the two chess-players. They are clearly eachother's equal.
column3: Losing both your rooks is tremendous. It's almost equal to having your queen's legs chopped from under her.
column4: These two bushel baskets are tremendously huge. But not only they are huge, they are also perfectly equal in size.

story: Intuition is a tremendously powerful resource of the mind.
column3: Using Zareon's story for the previous frame "tremendously"... The two chessplayers who are eachother's equals are so good at chess that they don't have to even move a muscle. Their brain power does it for them. Furthermore, they don't even have to think, really. Their intuition takes control. This is: extreme chess.
column4: I had an intuition of who would win this fight by judging the size of my opponents tremendously large muscles.

story: Because I hid myself behind a huge dirt barrier I dug, I was able to withstand the tremendous nuclear blast.
column3: Plain old soil can withstand tremendous amounts of pressure.
column4: The two equal chessplayers from the last two frames are duking it out still. Part of this extreme chess match is when the judges dump a huge mound of soil onto them. Watch as they withstand the weight of the dirt and how their brainpower keeps all the chess pieces, rooks and all, on the board. Simply astounding.

story: Inside your purse is all of your money and your keys (き) etc. All of your precious valuables.
column3: Frodo kept the precious in the purse but did a switch with some worthless shells when he went to sleep. Heres gollum opening the purse "ahhh my preciousssssss.....why you m***** *****!!!!!.
column4: You put your precious shells (money) into your purse for safekeeping.

story: Bilbo bequeathes the "PRECIOUS" to Frodo, who will carry it on the long ROAD to Mordor.
column3: "Bequeath" is an odd old word, isn't it? Basically, it just deals with how I want my precious possessions dealt out, after I die, later down the road. "Being of sound, but antiquated, mind, I bequeath this to you!".
column4: When you're at the end of your ROAD, you BEQUEATH what is PRECIOUS to you.

story: Dispatch all cars and chase the maestro! He's gone crazy and stolen a ladies purse!
column3: Small additions to dingomick's story: Dispatch all cars and chase the maestro! He's gone crazy. He's thrown away his baton and stolen the purse of some lady on the road! 派遣 (はけん): dispatch, send 人材派遣会社 (じんざいはけんがいしゃ): temporary staff service (temp agency) 遣わす (つかわす): to send, dispatch 小遣い (こづかい): allowance, pocket money 気遣う (きづかう): be concerned about, care about, worry about.
column4: Apart from meaning DISPATCH, this kanji can mean "to give (to someone lower than you)," "to do," and to even "have intercourse." STORY: The MAESTRO is on the ROAD waiting for a pimp to DISPATCH some new ladies (lower than him) so that he can GIVE THEM money from his PURSE and then DO IT with them. Where is the MAESTRO'S baton? You don't wanna know...

story: Don't defile precious water.
column3: ...Faramir and Frodo watched the tiny creature far below. "Shall we shoot him?" Faramir asked. "This Gollum has defiled the waters of the Forbidden pond, looking for his Precious, and for that the penalty is death"...
column4: So much for 潔 (#1548). Not only did the poor girl get defiled, she also had her precious purse with money stolen from her. She ended up drowning herself in the water.

story: The yakuza boss reclines in the oaken bathtub wearing his shades while his personal harem dances nakes for him.
column3: I learned 無 (#1913) first because it is a very common kanji. Probably easier to think of this kanji in that context. Attractive dancers should dance wearing nothing but sunglasses.
column4: Heisig, let's get this straight: NEW keywords: 躍 JUMP ex-躍 (#1379); 踊 DANCE=ODORI ex-踊 (#1512); 舞 KABUKI ex-舞 (#1912) (used in concepts related to dance, like stages, fluttering, etc.). So, KABUKI 歌舞伎【かぶき】is the keyword here. STORY: We learn 無 (#1913) first because it is a very common kanji. Then we go to see KABUKI en the EVENING wearing SUNGLASSES.

story: When I enter the wooden tub heated by flames in the onsen, I can let all my worries slip away and be submerged into nothingness.
column3: In a hot tub you can relax and have your stress vanish into nothingness.
column4: Note: This is the actual kanji for -nai endings.

story: The leader of the Spiderman association has tons of Spiderman figurines lined up on his shelf.
column3: Watch this: http://i146.photobucket.com/albums/r249/sith_lord10/updated%20showroom%20july/s29.jpg The leader of the Spiderman association has tons of Spiderman figurines lined up on his shelf.(Zactacular).
column4: Association means linking things together. This can be made literal by using a thread to bind (associate) stuff which belong on your shelf.

story: Refined rice [1535] can only be found in exclusive grocery shops. Coarse rice by contrast fills the supermarket shelves - don't go looking for anything else there.
column3: Ugh, why does this shelf feel so coarse? Because it's made of rice, of coarse! Get it? Of coarse?? Hahahahahahahahahah god i hate my life.
column4: In America they sell coarse rice on the shelves. The Japanese are much more discriminating, as they eat rice all the time, so they want finer rice.

story: The EU and US impose such high tariffs on food imports that third world wheat (the most basic of staples) never reaches first world supermarket shelves.
column3: According to Henshall, this kanji originally represented the harvested rice (the wheat primitive) that farmers paid as a tithe. Its meaning today would seem to be very similar. Imagine the farmer putting aside some of his harvested wheat on a shelf in order to pay the tariff to his lord.
column4: All the wheat imports sit on a shelf until the tariff is paid and it can be distributed.

story: When her home was invaded by a pack of dogs, the little girl climbed on the shelf and aimed various items at the dogs below.
column3: There's this game at the carnival where you aim at prizes on a shelf. In this particular variant, you aim at pictures of wild dogs on a shelf. The more you knock down, the better the prize!
column4: I think the dogs purposely aim at your shelves to deal the most damage.

story: The ancestor worship is so common in Daoist and buddhist countries that you can buy tiny altars to put on the shelves, one for each deceased family member.
column3: The urns of ancestors are kept on shelves next to the altar.
column4: At the partents of my wife's house (she is Japanese) they have a shelf with pictures of their ancestors. Its like a little shrine and they often pray to it.

story: In a last ditch effort to thwart the invaders of The Pinnacle, they push glass shelves over the edge onto their heads below.
column3: The Pinnacle keeps its pantry shelves locked at nighttime, to thwart midnight snackers. No fatties allowed here!
column4: Keeping porn on the pinnacle of a bookshelf can thwart snooping kids (thanks bodhisamaya).

story: A whole team of cops is sent to investigate how a tree could grow on top of a shelf with no soil or water.
column3: The result of the inverstigation of the missing Trees? Why, most of them had become shelfs!
column4: Police suspected that some wooden shelves had come from illigaly lumbered timber in the Amazon. They launched an investigation in to the matter. "Trees are more important than shelves and therefore should be placed on top" A spokesman for the police said in an interview.

story: HELP! Someone's pinned under this bookshelf and it's gonna take a lot of muscle to lift it off!
column3: Can you help me move this shelf? I don't have the muscle to do it alone.
column4: To assemble an IKEA shelf, logic is sometimes not enough. You need help from someone with brute muscle strength!

story: It seems like every time my Japanese friends send me their best regards, they accompany them with a gift. Over time, I've gotten so many that I had to buy a second house which contains nothing but several fancy shelves. Each shelf is dedicated to a certain friend of mine and contains every last one of their presents.
column3: Noone in japan will admit to this but every house has a secret "best regards shelf" hidden away somewhere. Its a shelf full of the tat they are constantly giving each other on return from holidays etc. Heres the house wife looking over her shoulder for the all clear to put another useless present on the best regards shelf. Happy Circumcision and best regards. Shelved.
column4: The shelf your dad made for my house was fantastic. Give my best regards to him.

story: The king is peacefully sleeping on his new tatami mat when all of a sudden a shelf falls over and kills him. You can see his crown poking out and the brains splatter out the top of his head from all the pressure.
column3: Rice Field + Crown + Shelf: Tatami mats were used by everyone - from the workers in the Rice fields to the crown - and when they were not in used, they were put on the shelf.
column4: Making tatami mats from rice field waste was Japan's crowning achievement, but for some reason other countries just shelved the idea.

story: This is a simplification of 竝, a ideogram of two people standing in a row.
column3: Hint : as a primitive I use the image of a rowing boat. In a rowing boat people sit in rows, but also side-by-side (another meaning of the kanji), working together (yet another meaning of this kanji). Note : there will also be a kanji for "rowboat" coming at frame 1876. The rowing boat is associated with the sport, and is a primitive, while the kanji for "rowboat" has a generic meaning of "a small boat". In any case, the kanji for "rowboat" will not appear as a primitive in the book.
column4: Roman numeral II with 2 rows of animal horns.

story: People at Universal Studios wait in rows so long that the sun goes down.
column3: To me, row is way too close to 列 (#875), so I'm adopting Fab's meaning of rowboat from the previous frame. Universal Studios went through a number of logo animations before settling on the one they are most famous for: the letters UNIVERSAL orbiting the Earth. One of the most ridiculous of these involved a man rowing himself in a boat around the sun.
column4: It is a universal human desire to sit in rows to watch the sun go down.

story: Musical scores are in a universal language.
column3: A musical score can be read, but not like ordinary words. Music is a universal language.
column4: MUSICAL SCORES are not written in WORDS, but in a UNIVERSAL language called notes.

story: You first wash you clothes with water and wring them until they are just damp before hanging them in a row under the sun to dry. If you don't wring them damp first they will take days to dry!
column3: When your things are damp, you line them up in a row under the sun.
column4: An image: a shirt hangs on the oars of an old rowboat. Though it is slowly being dried by the sun high above, the occasional drops of water from it indicate that it is still damp.

story: One day a row of Suns appeared in the sky, turning everyone's heads upwards.
column3: Clouds were covering the sky for months now. Rows upon rows of people spent whole days with their heads turned upwards, waiting for sun to appear.
column4: When the sun comes up, a row of severed heads appears on the castle wall. Think medieval times, they put the heads of dead enemies on show at each sunrise to intimidate.

story: Spiderman has to stay slender, so during thanksgiving, he keeps away from the long row of food.
column3: At the time of Thanksgiving, there's a row of all sorts of food on the table, which you mustn't eat if you want to stay as slender as a thread.
column4: Spiderman has to stay slender, so during thanksgiving, he keeps away and rows a rowboat. (Zarxrax).

story: After raining for two days in a row, you plead with the SPIRITS for some relief. (Adapted from johnskb,21-5-2006).
column3: When it rains, two worlds come together and spirits can be seen in the forest, dancing in a row.
column4: When it rains, the spirits have to cross between the two worlds in a rowboat.

story: A truly gruesome profession: an abattoir worker. Where the carcasses are upside down in a row that have not yet been cut up into sausages and steaks.
column3: My profession is taking unfinished rowboats and waterproofing them. Customers come in all the time asking if I've finished, and I point to their upside-down rowboat, still wet with sealant, and say, "not yet".
column4: My life is ruined. All my businesses went upside down in a row. I'm not yet ready to change professions though.

story: After a row husbands take their wives upsides down over the knee and slap them with their fingers on the bottom (if that doesn't get me banned…).
column3: Here we have badly behaving HUSBANDs, whose wives have had them hung UPSIDE DOWN IN A ROW. Each wife approaches her HUSBAND, berates him, gives him a sharp SLAP in the face and, Three-Stooges style, pokes him in the eyes with her FINGERS.
column4: A couple in a rowboat. The wife slaps the husband so hard with her fingers that the entire boat flips upside-down.

story: Building on johnskb: Although it goes against the Heisig method, this story is a lot easier to remember when you know it's the kanji for "boku." Males usually use either "boku" or "ore" (instead of "watashi") to refer themselves. "Boku" is slightly boyish and soft; "ore" is rough & tough. Mr. T would definitely use "ore" -- but when he's one of the husbands hung upside down in a row about to be punished by his wife, he puts on a sweet act and switches to "boku" when he pleads "come on baby, it's ME!"
column3: Mr. T also finds himself as one of the HUSBANDs, whose wives have had them hung UPSIDE DOWN IN A ROW. But when his wife comes up to punish him, he pleads, “It’s ME, Baby. I wasn’t behaving badly like these other foo’s.”.
column4: Row of upside down husbands all begging Mr T to set them free..."ME! ME ME!"

story: The character for 洪 (#1939) gave me the idea to use together as a primitive for Noah's Ark. Noah kept plenty of salad on board to entice the animals with their animal legs to scurry on board together, two by two.
column3: The conjoined twins, who are always together, have trouble eating together because one is a vegetarian, eating salad and the other is a avid meat eater, eating chicken legs.[Thanks fuaburisu!]
column4: Salad and animal legs just go together. This primitive means chicken caesar salad. http://www.kfc.com/menu/salads.asp.

story: It took over 600 frames for Mr T to 作 (#1142), the Ark, but when he was finally done, he cast his saw aside and submitted the Ark to Noah for his approval. "I pity the foo who doesn't climb aboard this ark," said Noah to his friend.
column3: Mr. T submits a resume together with his application. "I pity da foo don't got no resume!" he says.
column4: When people are together and form a group, they suddenly submit their personal responsibility to the mob mentality.

story: Noah's Ark is so uncommonly large, he can even fit a rice field on top to feed the animals.
column3: Brains together with beauty is an uncommon combination.
column4: It's uncommon to find a pair of together twins who are connected at the brain! When such a set does turn up, they are inevitably showcased on TV.

story: The thing about feathers is that they usually cover the entire bird. A creature with feathers only on its wings would be very uncommon.
column3: WINGS without any FEATHERS would be an UNCOMMON site. Well, unless you like to eat chicken WINGS alot.
column4: This is つばさ. To make a distinct image you can think about aircraft wing for which this kanji is also used. Feathers would be extremely uncommon to use in design of an aircraft wings.

story: At Thanksgiving, it’s uncommon for people to accept humbly the food: most people just dig in.
column3: You're invited to a Thanksgiving party in Japan! Awesome! You're so happy that your Japanese friends are trying to make you feel at home (you've been homesick recently). You sit down to the table, and they bring out some..uh...uncommon food. Really uncommon. Like just imagine the most uncommon Thanksgiving food ever, and that's what you're given (i don't know, a frisbee or something?). Of course, you have to be Japanese and accept humbly their food.
column4: "ACCEPT HUMBLY" is a translation for 頂戴する (chōdai-suru), a Japanese expression of THANKS-GIVING that shows an UNCOMMON degree of respect and formality, and is reserved for the most UNCOMMONly solemn occasions. Ironically, 戴 also appears in 戴きます (いただきます), which is also a form of THANKS-GIVING, but is anything but UNCOMMON. In fact, it is so commonplace to that it borders on formulaic and meaningless. (NB: いただきます is also written 頂きます).

story: Water plus Noah's Ark equals deluge.
column3: Lots of water coming together is called a deluge.
column4: Even as the water was rising, somehow Noah got together all the right animals before the deluge began in earnest.

story: During a deluge, all the poor snakes get washed into the harbour.
column3: All throughout the deluge Noah had been kicking himself for forgetting to bring any snakes onto the Ark. It wasn't until the deluge had finished, and Noah had brought the Ark safely back to the harbour that he realised that the snakes had been under the Ark all along.
column4: After the deluge 洪, the harbor was full of snakes 己. (In places where there are lots of snakes, they are everywhere after a flood.) 港、みなと, harbor: 港の防波堤にある高さ１６mの灯台が壊れているのが見つかりました, "It was discovered that a 16 meter tall lighthouse on a breakwater in the harbor had been destroyed." 空港、くうこう, airport: 今成田空港にいます, "I'm at Narita Airport now." 港市、こうし, harbor city; 香港、ほんこん, Hong Kong.

story: Having spent all day stringing together grains of rice he suddenly had an outburst, "I can take it any longer!"
column3: Noah was having an outburst after being at sea for 40 days and 40 nights and running out of rice grains to eat. Then the sun suddenly burst out in an outburst over the Ark and there was an outburst of cheering.
column4: Sun together with rice grains => outburst of popcorn. バク.

story: Actually means explosion, like an outburst of fire.
column3: Bombs make fiery outbursts. It's almost too logical, this one.
column4: An outburst of fire explodes outside Noah's Ark. "What happen!?", Noah shouted. "Somebody set up us the bomb!", came the Lord's reply.

story: Noah feels like he gets no respect from the other passengers on the Ark, but they all make him Valentine's Day cards to show how much they respect what he's done for them.
column3: If you wanna stay together you have to show your valentine respect.
column4: As I like Aretha Franklin's song "R-E-S-P-E-C-T", I cut out each of the letters from pieces of card, then string them all together and send it to her as a valentine.

story: There were so many snakes on the road to Noah's ark so they had to elect which two would represent the snake species.
column3: You're driving on the road and you see two snakes together. You can't avoid both, so you have to elect which one gets run over.
column4: Isn't this how the US presedential election works? You are given a choice between two snakes. Their politics are actually strung together but you get to feel as though you chose which one you want to lead you down the political road for the next four years. So which snake are you going to elect?

story: Mr. President! We all stand here together under a national flag. One thing is certain: we'll never give in. We are launching nuclear missiles now to implement mutually assured destruction protocol.
column3: (+synewave) Noah looks on in disbelief as Mr. and Mrs. Smith board the Ark, start waving their flag everywhere and blasting everything in sight with a missile launcher.
column4: This is the Mr. (との) used when addressing someone at the start of a letter. How letters were delivered to the ark was intersting. Noah would wave a big flag and the post man would fire a flag-seeking missile full of letters for Mr Rhino and Mr Giraffe etc.

story: I nearly died by falling in a well. Actually, on two separate occasions. I'm glad to see they've added these fence posts. Now the well will be much safer.
column3: Have you ever seen an old fashioned japanese well? == http://cruises.about.com/od/southeastasiacruise1/ig/Osaka-Japan/Ancient-Well-at-Osaka-Castle.htm.
column4: This is a picto of the grate over top of the well at 大阪城, so no one falls in.

story: A little one is eating a domburi while standing over, looking down into, a WELL. He drops it, and it falls down & down until it looks like nothing more than a DROP, landing at the bottom of the well!
column3: I drop a domburi down into the well for the goblin living there.
column4: A donburi is rice bowl, with drops of food (other than rice) and garnish on top. The steep-sided shape of the typical donburi bowl is depicted in the kanji as a well, which is not a bad comparison. Picture: http://www.sushigallery.net/Arts/chicken%20donburi.jpg.

story: The village surrounded the well with a wall so kids wouldn't fall in.
column3: Tweaking dingomick's story: The village well is pent in by a surrounding wall so that kids don't fall in. 囲む (かこむ): to surround, encircle 範囲 (はんい): range, extent, scope 周囲 (しゅうい): surroundings, environs, periphery, perimeter, circumference 囲う (かこう): to enclose, fence in 囲い (かこい): enclosure, fenced in area (such as a corral or a pen) Careful: 郭 (#1985).
column4: You get good surround sound when your pent-up in well.

story: If you just grow your christmas tree in a well, there will be no need to till the soil.
column3: A man was tilling a new plot to plant xmas trees but his tractor hit an old covered-up well and fell halfway in, he's asking for a new tractor for xmas..
column4: Note: till in the sense of plow or cultivate, not until. (story: ergerg).

story: In Asian countries, people use II chopsticks to get things into their mouths. Just imagine someone shoving a piece of sushi into their mouths with chopsticks.
column3: China (中) taken two times should be about the total landmass of Asia.
column4: In the Roman Empire there were signs marking where you were about to enter Asia. This was a dangerous place for Romans, so the sign consisted of a picture of two Romans (= Roman two) being eaten by a mouth.

story: Because Asian people started to eat Western food, their hearts became bad and they started having heart attacks.
column3: Much of the Asian food in America is bad for your heart - just imagine some sodium & MSG laden Chinese takeout.
column4: This kanji really means "Evil" which is quite different from "bad." STORY: This kanji was really created by westerners, not ASIAN people. It's a form of propaganda, which says all ASIAN people have EVIL HEARTS. (made up story).

story: The shape of a Yen coin.
column3: A poor old man is almost killing himself trying to lift a huge glass hood with his cane (using it as a lever), to get to just one yen coin. Note : the kanji refers to a circular, round object, but also to the Japanese currency (pronounced "en").
column4: A pictograph of a bank teller's window. The circles are the coins which are passed back and forth for deposits and withdrawls.

story: A museum display of two walking sticks bound together under a glass canopy, showing the first device used to measure an angle.
column3: [+nuke] As a primitive, a boomerang. This boomerang is used to grab a bunch of meat, or flesh, lying around on the ground at a farm. First, you throw it straight at a walking stick, then it makes a right angle and goes to walking stick number two, and wraps around that. A quick tug, and you've got all the flesh flying toward you contained in that triangle. Hooray for free (stolen) food!
column4: [angle; corner; square; horn; antlers] I needed to measure an angle, so I improvised a rudimentary protractor by bounding up a walking stick to some body part of mine.

story: For insects to get in contact with each other, they need to place their antennae at just the right angle.
column3: Wow, he threw that BOOMERANG with such skill, it made CONTACT with that INSECT in mid flight.
column4: This is commonly read as 触る （さわる）, meaning to touch or feel something. An insect's version of horns are its antennae (see 触 (#1954)). They are it's prime source of contact with the world and it uses them to touch and feel its way around.

story: Did you know that you can unravel a cow? If you stick the dagger in at exactly the correct angle, the whole cow will just unravel.
column3: Unravel the mystery by determining at what ANGLE the SWORD went into the COW.
column4: I tossed the BOOMERANG, which stuck like a DAGGER into a COW that I targeted. Now I watched the COW's insides begin to UNRAVEL from the cut.

story: The king has eaten too much and has to get a new belt again. See his fat rolls hanging over?
column3: (I thought this was easier to remember as king with a belt) As the king gets fatter, his belt needs to be adjusted again and again.
column4: This is a belt with a non-adjustable jeweled buckle. Everytime you go back to the leathersmith telling him to move the buckle because you've packed on a few pounds (but that this is the last time!), he says "Again?!? Weren't you just here last month?"

story: I have a funnel attached to my laptop that takes my prof's lecture and puts the words into a text file. The bigger the funnel, the more accurate the conversion, so picture a bunch of laptops with large, unwieldy funnels attached to the USB port.
column3: Image: a professor walking around with a funnel and simply pouring his words into each students head instead of a lecture. (Primitive: FUNNEL, who got the celery stuck in the funnel again?! You know it's not supposed to be used for that!)
column4: FUNNEL primitive: "Celery--again?!" "You'll eat your celery or else I'll make you eat it with a FUNNEL!"

story: Subscription is like a money funnel, because the receiving end is small (just one company) and the other end is wide (the whole country).
column3: My subscription to Money magazine came with a free coin funnel.
column4: I had to cancel my subscription to that "special" magazine when my wife found out where i was funneling all our money.

story: Trees with good posture look like funnels. For example, http://static.flickr.com/53/118084202_8896e54a14_m.jpg.
column3: A farm girl uses a wooden funnel as a corset to improve her posture.
column4: I fell out of a tree and broke my neck. So they put one of those white funnels around my neck to correct my posture.

story: A gutter funnels water.
column3: A gutter takes the water that falls as rain and funnels it off to where it can be dealt with appropriately.
column4: Instead of a normal gutter, the city is cutting costs by just putting a huge celery funnel on the side of the road every few hundred yards. While this is actually a bit more efficient than standard gutters and quite cheap, it'sa bit dangerous (as there's a rather nasty juicing mechanism attached to the bottom of each one). Imagine telling some kids to stay out of the gutter on a rainy day, and one of them not heeding you (kids love splashing in them!) and falling to her doom.

story: Right part: academic conference (a meeting, some of the attendees making notes in scrapbooks during presentation). Argument at academic conferences is naturally carried out using words.
column3: It's very difficult to present a good argument if you don't bring along a scrapbook with some key words jotted down to the meeting.
column4: Words must he chosen methodically to make a good argument. Note: 侖 侖 is an extremely rare kanji meaning "methodical", I remember this with: "A meeting of scrapbookers who are very methodical."

story: Mr. T talks about ethics at the academic conference. "I pity the fool who gets caught plagarizing someone else's stuff!"
column3: Mr. T has no ethics at the scrapbooking convention. He'll do whatever it takes to beat all those ladies.
column4: 侖 = think or be methodical. A person who thinks or acts methodically has ethics. 五倫 【ごりん】 (n) the 5 Confucian filial-piety relationships; 社内不倫 【しゃないふりん】 (n) adulterous affair with someone at work; 人倫 【じんりん】 (n) human relations; humanity; 精力絶倫 【せいりょくぜつりん】being of unbounded energy or sexual stamina; 沈倫 【ちんりん】sinking into obscurity; 破倫 【はりん】 (n) immorality; incest; 比倫 【ひりん】.

story: During a talk at the academic conference, speaker shows an introductory slide depicting the structure of car, and then moves on to the more narrow topic of wheels.
column3: Someone stole all the wheels off the ladies' cars at the scrapbook convention.
column4: At an academic conference many thousands of years ago, the uses of the wheel were discussed--eventually leading to the invention of the car. I sort of imagine a TED conference with cavemen discussing the wheel with a 2001 Space Oddesy-esc transition to Henry Ford also at a TED conference. (www.ted.com A seriously good website).

story: Mr. T is very partial to hentai comic books. I know because he dropped a pile of them when I accidentally bumped into him at the door to kinokuniya!
column3: Mr. T is partial to konbini hentai. He reads them for hours every day after work at his local konbini. (Primitive: KONBINI HENTAI, all the magazines(scrapbooks) by every konbini door in Japan).
column4: Comic book is a nice idea. It's a sort of scrapbook that is like a door to a different kind of reality. Person is always partial (unfair) on the subject of comic books, because (s)he doesn't like them.

story: Go down the road in Japan and you will find comics EVERYWHERE, newpaper stands, 7-11, Tsutaya, even the supermarket. Comics are everywhere here along the road.
column3: Go down any road in Japan and you'll find konbini hentai everywhere.
column4: A scrapbook is a door that takes you down the road to everywhere you've ever been.

story: I took the compilation of covers of all my Spider-Man comics that I had saved in a scrapbook and glued them on my door.
column3: Whereas Mr.T was partial to KONBINI HENTAI, SPIDERMAN likes to wait for the COMPILATION. He finds it more convenient to have his hentai compiled in one volume to read on the loo.
column4: Mr. T may like hentai, but his collection pales in comparison the the compilation that Spiderman has! No wonder he keeps his face hidden...in shame!

story: Pictograph. I think of that Harry Potter spell book that had to be bound shut coz it wanted to eat you.
column3: Pictograph of three books tied up for transport.
column4: A pictograph of The Lord of the Rings Trilogy viewed end on: All 3 tomes held together with one ribbon - "one ribbon to bind them all".

story: A palisade is a "fence of stakes especially for defense," usually the stakes are very strong, set closely together, and pointed on top. Tome can be seen as a pictograph of several close-set wooden stakes, braced by one horizontal bar.
column3: Before I build him a wooden palisade, the mighty leader gives me a mighty tome on the subject.
column4: I'll let the tome primitive refer to a spell book, in order to keep it distinct. In that case, this kanji shows me a wooden palisade under siege by a few mages, trying to demolish it with their spells from the spell book.

story: This kanji means a code of law, not a secret language or symbolic language (such as programming code) ... Story: The code of law is a tool used to bend citizens to society's will. You can use the image of a totalitarian state, but be careful not to confuse it with the pinnacle primitive 阪 (#1294).
column3: Think "codex" (mnemonic help) or "code of laws", or even Leonardo Da Vinci's code. Here I see a codex as a tool used to bend the masses into submission. Picture a huge codex book lifted down on crowds to bend them down in submission. Another: if you bend to the code without asking questions, you are a tool!
column4: Code/rules can be bent with the correct tool... (usually money).

story: Looks a bit like Ft => Family title => Family name.
column3: The family name is important to me! Drop me from a building, torture me with a fishhook, I'm keeping my one family name. Hook me with a second fishhook, I refuse to change my family name.
column4: This box is full of arrows. Arrows are special: armorer's family name is engraved on each arrowhead (hence last dot is left out).

story: Spiderman doesn't have a single paper with his family name on it (because he doesn't want to reveal his identity).
column3: I imagine a ridiculously expensive, and rather pointless, Japanese type of paper for writing letters, with one's family name woven in fine thread somewhere in a corner.
column4: Spiderman regrets getting drunk last night. Peter Parker hands in his paper with the name Peter Spiderman--wrong family name. Oops!

story: Marriage is the day in this woman's life where she gets a new family name.
column3: Tip: Heisig later introduces the kanji 昏 昏 (#2526). Story: Never enter into marriage with a woman at dusk (wait until you see them in daylight). Note: This is an ancient proverb . . . (probably).
column4: 3 Kanji related with marriage, all the 3 with the primitive WOMAN. 嫁 嫁 (#581): Since the man is hardly ever home, the woman feels more like she's married into the HOUSE . 姻 姻 (#627): is the state you get after the marriage, in which the woman has got you PENT IN like a DOG, so that you cannot go after other bitches. 婚 婚 (#1972): is "THE" day in this woman's life where she gets a new FAMILY NAME. Remember that MARRIAGE begins one DAY, whereas MATRIMONY is the state you get after the MARRIAGE.

story: Mr. T travels to Japan and knows he must bow lower when presenting his business card.
column3: Primitive: The Japanese always underline their family name on their Calling (Business) Cards. (Easy to remember, Underlined Family Name = Business Card).
column4: A person bows low when presenting his business card.

story: Most japanese find it impossible to resist pushy businessmen in Japan when they push their damned business cards into your fingers.
column3: Japan business etiquette tip: When someone hands you a business card, resist the impulse to fiddle around with it with your fingers, and by all means resist the urge to use the card to pick gunk from under your fingernails. Just examine it carefully, ask politely about the (few by now) kanji that you don't know, and put it away carefully in a location that shows your counterparts how important they are to you.
column4: You have to resist using your fingers to present your business card the correct etiquette is to present it with both hands.

story: I put all those useless business cards at the bottom of a cave.
column3: At the bottom of the cave you find a meishi: "LOST? DIAL 1-800-..."
column4: In the deepest bottom of this cave complex, spelunkers leave their calling cards to prove they made it all the way.

story: All the people of the world with all their family names shouting with their big mouths.
column3: Once they'd learned to properly utilize their mouths to form a language, the people of the world all adopted family names, regardless of their race, culture etc..
column4: Note: Vox populi means "voice of the people" referring to people as nation. This is often used as an abbreviation of the phrase "Vox populi, vox dei" which means "voice of the people, voice of god", referring to the godlike power people have over their government. In this context, I think of this character as an angry mob that is rebelling against it's corrupt government (hence we have big mouths which call out the unwanted officials by their family name).

story: In an Orwellian sense, the eye watching the people never sleeps.
column3: People need to close their eyes and sleep.
column4: I sleep with one eye open, because the people are dangerous and may revolt at any time, you can't trust the unwashed masses.

story: I was retreating from the battlefield. In the chaos, my friend threw his dogtags at me to give to his family. I managed to catch them with my fingers as the chopper was lifting off.
column3: Dog tag: This is a wild animal track device. It has an arrowhead and screwdriver-shaped radio beacon. It's evidently fired in animals to track their movements. When animal has a dog tag, it's easy to catch it: just take a dog tag in your fingers.
column4: "Dog tag" appears later as a kanji on its own: 甫 Offspring are pretty slippery when they come out of the womb; be sure to catch the baby with your fingers so it doesn't slide and fall on the floor!

story: The extremely efficient (military veteran) wet-nurse keeps track of which infant has been SUCKLEd already by marking each MOUTH with a DOG-TAG. (Cf. 吸 (#744)).
column3: This mom of a dozen babies put dog tags on the ones whose mouthes she had already allowed to suckle her.
column4: The mouth of an offspring suckles. 哺乳・ほにゅうlactation, suckling.

story: The water of the bay washes all the dog tags up after the battle.
column3: Imagine the opening scenes of baywatch....beautiful water and the dog tags of the cast jumping up and down as they run along the beach.
column4: Otis Redding is sitting on the dock of the bay, looking over the water while clutching the dog tags of his fallen friend from Vietnam.

story: Bulrush was the flower that you could see near almost all bays in japan before the japanese started putting concrete everywhere. Just check how many percent of Japan's coastline that is concretised... you'll be surprised.
column3: Pharoah's daughter is walking along the bay picking flowers among the bulrushes. To her surprise, she sees a baby floating in the water on a primitive little boat made of bulrushes. After her servants swim out and retrieve the boat, they learn the baby's name by looking at his wrist bracelet dog tag. "Moses," huh. Sounds Hebrew. We'll just call him Bulrush Kid for now.
column4: Bulrush are flowers of the bay.

story: A shop in an impoverished country is just a cottage with a dog tag identifying it.
column3: Normal cottages (舎 actually means a building) don't have tags advertising their names, but shops do.
column4: Soldiers used to go the "lady-shop" at the edge of town. It was a little cottage stocked with women. All you had to do was show your dogtags to be admitted.

story: I usually hear supplement in "dietry supplement". So you're given a cloak for extra fibre and dogtags for extra iron. Keeps you regular and stops you feeling tired and run-down.
column3: The name and number printed on a soldier's cloak is a supplement to his main I.D. tag; his dog-tag, in helping identify the soldier.
column4: Ah yes, this dog tag perfectly supplements my cloak!
