story: So fed up am I, I've finally built city walls around my residence to keep these Japanese from soliciting me with their business cards.
column3: The business card says his residence is just to the left of the city walls. Can you find it? Yep, got it.
column4: Suggestion- since we have the pinnacle on the left(which had a great potential for imaginative stories as we explored the ultimate society), the right side will be the pinnacle's opposite - the slum. It's so dangerous that a steep menacing city wall has been erected to keep its denizens in(and protect those outside). story: If your calling card said your residence was the slum, you'd be too ashamed to show it to anyone.

story: The city finally received the enclosure that it desperately needed, city walls to protect it against attacks from the tall kids.
column3: Even the tall kids can't get out of the enclosure that is the city walls.
column4: As you can see, the tall kid peaks over the enclosure of the city walls to see the red light district (one of the meanings of the kanji).

story: County cricket. "I say old boy, you've hit that ball clear over the city walls. That's six and out!"
column3: You can take the good old boy out of county (and into the city walls), but you can't take the county out of the good old boy. Is that how the saying goes?
column4: The old boys don't venture out into the county. They stay cooped up within the safety of the city walls.

story: The country folk and and the city folk mingle at the outskirts of town, just past the city walls.
column3: The city folks don't like to mingle with people from the outskirts. That's why they built such big city walls.
column4: The city walls mark the outskirts of the inner city, where it begins to mingle with the suburbs.

story: Within the city walls, this section of town was so noisy that we had to muzzle them up.
column3: "Section 8 housing" is a way to muzzle the impoverished people who are unable to pay rent but want to live inside the city walls.
column4: (primitive city walls - slum. See residence 1841) A riot happens in one section of the slum. Rioting about the poor living conditions and treatment by the authorities. That section of the slum have muzzels fixed on them. Such demeaning treatment is typical in the slum.

story: A vision of a futuristic METROPOLIS: standing at the window of your 400th floor apartment, hand in hand with your LOVE DOLL, gazing out at the gigantic CITY WALLS that you can never escape.
column3: In a huge metropolis, it's hard not to feel like just someone within the city walls.
column4: [my primitive for someone is ninja]A ninja must be able to scale the city walls of the Metropolis without being seen.

story: The drooping citywalls was generating a lot of angry mail for the city officials.
column3: The city walls droop down in one spot so that the mailman can throw the mail over.
column4: The drooping citywalls was generating a lot of angry mail for the city officials. Hint: think "hate mail" and you will remember this one. [thx CharleyGarrett].

story: He reminisced about his home country: "Ah, back in my home country, the bushes grew so high that they covered the city walls!"
column3: In -my- home country, we'd like to put up walls to keep Bush -OUT-, thank you very much.
column4: In my home country, all we had for city walls was bushes!

story: If you arrive with two swords at the city walls, expect some interrogatives before they'll let you in.
column3: Phonetic ナ. If a trespasser attempts to cross the city walls, the guards will likely employ the interrogative approach of pointing a double-edged sword at them. Sort of shorthand for "Who goes there?". Note: "two" is written before final stroke of 刀.
column4: Mix of Katsuo and Gavmck: If you arrive at the city walls, get some interrogatives from the guards, and say that you have two swords, they will probably say: "ナ(Nah), you can't enter." Reading = ナ.

story: Your hometown is where you broke out of your cocoon (born), and where you left when your hair was silver (died), your whole life was spent inside the city walls.
column3: Your home town is where you earned enough silver to enable you to break out of your giant cocoon (leave home) and explore outside the city walls.
column4: He never left his hometown, from the day he crept out of the family cocoon till the day his hair turned silver-gray, he never once crossed the city walls.

story: People's voices are like echoes of sounds from their hometowns....you can always tell where they're from by how they talk.
column3: My hometown is a ghost town, any sounds echoes and echoes.
column4: Whenever I call long-distance back to my hometown, the sound on the line has a terrible echo!

story: The daughter is a good girl that grows up to be a woman. The son is a good boy that grows up to defend the city walls.
column3: Just like a daughter (娘) is good woman, son is good too, and stays safely inside city walls so as not to give his parents reason to worry.
column4: Sex difference: The 娘 娘 (#1581) is a good girl that grows up to be a woman. The son is a good boy that grows up to defend the city walls. Note: Be careful: The word for son is 息子 [むすこ] . It is however used in many son's names, most famously the baseball player Ichiro (一郎, literally 'First male child').

story: Your son plays in the corridor pretending he's exploring a cave.
column3: A corridor is a bastard son of a cave. Corridors dream too, hoping one day they'll be as great as their father, the cave.
column4: (ロウ) I think of the corridor found in the cave that Yoda made Luke Skywalker walk through as part of his Jedi training in Empire Strikes Back. It was in this corridor that Luke met Darth Vadar, cut off his head and found himself behind Darth Vadar's mask. An early little hint that Luke was Darth Vadar's son.

story: This is a magic shield with ten eyes which have the power to drag the victim towards it.
column3: You paint 10 huge eyes on your shield to scare the enemy, but consequently your shield is so big and heavy that you have to drag it.
column4: From Wikipedia: "If a Spartan hoplite were to return to Sparta alive and without his shield, it was assumed that he threw his shield at the enemy in an effort to flee; an act punishable by death or banishment." Picture the enemy of a Spartan soldier poking his eyes out with a sewing needle and trying to steal his shield. However, the Spartan desperately clutches on, and is dragged around for a while, preferring to die than to lose his shield.

story: This is mostly used in the word 循環, "circulation" (of buses through their routes, of blood, etc). So I think of a column of little Roman soldiers with their shields marching sequentially through the veins of a person, as an anthropomorphization of the immune system.
column3: A column of shielded soldiers advancing sequentially to avoid revealing the size of their army (Think "Sandpeople always ride single file to hide their numbers" from Star Wars).
column4: An army's column of marching sheilds, are lined up in sequential order.

story: Drag + rag gave me trouble until I came up with zombie for it. The zombie population became more diverse, separating into different factions. One of them being the water Zombies.
column3: The radical faction is almost eliminated, sir. They're living in the sewers dressed in rags and dragging their supplies.
column4: DRAG + RAG = ZOMBIE (walking around slowly, dragging feet, tattered rages...) In "Left 4 Dead" there are "normal" zombies and also some FACTIONS of specialized zombies: Smoker, Hunter, Boomer, oh, and the WATER-spraying "Soaker" ZOMBIES. Thanks to revenantkioku for the zombie idea.

story: The vein is the part of the body most lusted after by the flesh hungry zombies (drag & rag - see revenantkioku frame 1855).
column3: To get blood drawn from a vein you present the part of the body to the nurse, and they drag an alcohol swab (rag) across the vein.
column4: Japanese zombies have trouble pronouncing v/b and r's, so they sound like they're saying "Veeeeiiinns..... Veeeeiinnns...." instead of a completely different part of the body.

story: Masses of zombies, splattered with blood. (any zombie movie).
column3: When the masses are hurt, say in a natural disaster like an earthquake, they can be seen everywhere dragging their bloody rags.
column4: There was a lot of blood over the masses of squashed zombies I use 'squashed zombies' for the form of rag/drag with the two lines at the left.

story: (I prefer 2 towels over cornstalk and belt) - Have you ever wondered why your parcels always end up in such bad condition when you get them? Or why you never get them at all? That's because you've never looked at how they're actually delivered - each postman is given a load of parcel post and 2 towels to drag them down the road on.
column3: In the ancient parcel post, they just would drag the packages behind them tied to cornstalks woven into a long belt down the road. It was a wonder than anything arrived intact.
column4: People complained about the delivery methods of UPS after finding out that they loaded parcel post onto a towel and dragged it down the road. As a result, UPS have completely revamped their delivery system. Now they use two towels. (thanks Virtua Leaf).

story: This is a military-grade staple gun! It can be loaded with real missiles.
column3: In order to get your 1st grade, or first-dan (だん) black belt, you have to learn hand to hand combat with new weapons - first the grapple involving the staple gun, and then the missile deployment technique.
column4: Imagine a really mean teacher who grades papers with a staple-gun that shoots out staples (in a missile-like fashion) onto the paper to form the letter "F". She even uses such an opportunity as target practice. She gets way over to the other end of the class and shoots the little "staple missiles" onto the paper, cackling all the while.

story: As a discriminating metalsmith, I use the highest grade metals when forging such precision devices as staple guns and missiles.
column3: Metal has to be forged many times over in order to reach a high grade.
column4: Metal is graded depending on how it was forged.

story: The empress is cruel. Normally she'll violently pull her servants by the ear when they've failed to follow orders. But one time she dragged this one guy around the palace by the mouth. She must have been really angry—ever since that moment, he's never been seen again.
column3: The F word often comes out of the mouth of the empress.
column4: This is ax with the last stroke replaced by a mouth, thus forming a pictograph of someone about to have his mouth chopped off for spreading rumors about the empress. "Off with his mouth!" [Thanks raulir!]

story: After the play, The Phantasm of the Opera hangs up his cape on a clothes hanger and returns to his cocoon to sleep.
column3: You open your closet and find strange, glowing cocoons sitting on your clothes hangers... definitely a phantasm!
column4: After the opera, The Phantasm hangs up his tuxedo on a clothes hanger and returns to his sleeping bag (cocoon) to sleep. (Didn't want to start sticking cloak in there by mistake). 幻 まぼろし phantom, vision, illusion, dream; 幻影 げんえい phantom, vision, illusion; 幻怪な げんかいな strange or mysterious and troubling.

story: The porn director has one big mouth. "Don't bother putting your clothes on a hanger, just get started."
column3: The director sticks a clothes hanger in each actor's mouth and hangs them from the ceiling until he needs them.
column4: I think of this one as a pictograph of a guy talking on one of those headsets with a microphone attached - he's directing a police operation, so he has to be constantly in touch with everyone!

story: Mr. T is the director. You better pay respects to him!
column3: If Mr. T gets a role in a film, he doesnt pay respects to the director, the director pays respects to Mr. T.
column4: Mr. T pays repsects to the porn director for casting him in his first movie role in 15 years.

story: The big mouthed diretor is even picky about the parts of speech you use, shouting, "More verbs! Less adjectives!" and such all the time.
column3: A Grammar is basically a word director that tells us what part of speech each word is.
column4: This kanji is the ending of lots of parts of speech like noun, verb, adverb: 名詞, 動詞, 動詞. People are messing around with parts of speech all the time now. Company directors are the worst, making up new words by verbing nouns and nouning verbs. "please action that", "what is the take-home from that?"

story: After a pride of hungry lions ate the director, the producer decided to tone down his documentary and film domesticated cats instead.
column3: When you DOMESTICATE a animal, you are the DIRECTOR of it's life and what it EATS.
column4: We thought that the lion was domesticated but it ate the Director !!!

story: The director's mouth dropped open as he flipped through the scrapbook of properties he was about to become heir to.
column3: Careful with 継 (#1470). The egoistic director leaves instructions about what shall be handed down to his heir upon the director's death. First, the director's mouth should be surgically removed and preserved, to be handed down to his heir. Second, a scrapbook of the director's proudest scenes should also be handed down. The mouth reminds the heir that the director must be a loudmouth; the scrapbook reminds the heir of how to be a good director.
column4: This kanji must be referring to Harry Potter. Is he the heir to Slytherin? Who knows? His mouth speaks parseltongue though, and Voldemort is trying to kill him from a magical scrapbook.. (or was that a diary? haha). Oh, and the director of the potions department hates him. Poor harry!

story: I see this kanji as a pictograph of a two story boat seen from the front. The glass canopy is the body of the boat. The drop on top is the chimney. The horizontal line is the ceiling/floor between the the 1st/2nd floor. Finally, the two drops in the middle are the lights on the decks.
column3: Pictograph of a boat seen from above. The middle line is the oars. The drop on top is the rudder (at the back of the boat). The two drops inside represent the passengers: one is bent over with the effort of rowing and the other is sitting up straight, in the front of the boat, looking at the horizon for any signs of land.
column4: I dropped a boat on your mom.

story: The most famous LINER is the Titanic, which struck an iceberg and sunk. Just imagine that huge LINER strucking an even huger mass of white ice.
column3: A liner is to boat as an 皇 (#279) is to a 王 (#271), or a 伯 (#1041) is to a 人 (#1023): in each case we need only add white to the latter in order to get the former.
column4: Cruise Liners are huge boats that always seem to be white.

story: To navigate a "boat" through a "whirlwind" takes a skilled navigator.
column3: In Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker, you can navigate your boat by summoning whirlwinds.
column4: Forrest Gump, being the fool that he is, decides to navigate his shrimping boat into the whirlwind instead of around it. Though through his perpetual dumb luck, he manages to be the only boat that survives the whirlwind....

story: The gunwale is perhaps the most mysterious part of a boat for it is neither a gun nor a whale.
column3: Gunwale (rhymes with "tunnel") is the top edge of the side of a boat, for example the widened lip on the sides of a canoe. The mysterious origin of this part of a boat comes from the strengthened sides of warships that used artillery (it means "gun ridge").
column4: The meaning of GUNWALE is MYSTERIOUS for everyone, except BOAT enthusiasts.

story: Carrier?! This means "general" (as in the general public or generally). OK.. Carriers, i.e. boats with missiles, are not available to the general public.
column3: In general, carrier boats have missiles.
column4: For those who have the greasemonkey script, this kanji's keyword should be changed. I use run of the mill to avoid conflict with 総 (#1466). Story: Nowadays, even a run of the mill boat has missile launchers to protect themselves from pirates.

story: What do you call a "CARRIER" of DISHes? A TRAY.
column3: "This, my friend, is no run of the mill dish! Look at its finely crafted handles, its size great to hold dishes itself! No, my friend, THIS is a TRAY!" [See Cheesemaster64 for 般 (#2016)].
column4: Imagine a restaurant set in Disney's Fantasia or maybe in Harry Potter's university, where dishes are magically landing and taking off of a carrier tray.

story: When workers neglect workplace safety, their fingers get cut off and carried away by the conveyor belt, which looks like a 'finger carrier' in that case.
column3: During WWII, morse code was the primary means of communication from sea. The morse code specialist was the conveyor of messages to and from the crew of the carrier, using his fingers to tap out the secret messages. (This works especially well for 搬送周波数 carrier frequency and 搬送波 carrier wave, being the radio waves/frequencies used in morse code).
column4: Fingers take food from the sushi carrier, a conveyor belt.

story: A boy floats his toy boat in a gully and imagines it as an immense ship.
column3: A ship is a boat so big, it makes a river look like a gully.
column4: Aargh, hard to keep this separate from boat. How about this: the phrase "shape up or ship out!" This phrase originally meant that a soldier had better get his act together, or else face being shipped off into a combat zone. Here we see a poor WW-I soldier who has been shipped off to a combat zone. He's riding in the boat overseas to fight in the trenches (gulley).

story: The warship towers over the smaller benign boats, overseeing their safe path from port to port.
column3: A warship is a boat that oversees the seas. Think of it as the patroller of the ocean.
column4: On a normal boat, you do what you want: play shuffleboard, pig out at the buffet, sunbathe. On a warship though, there's an overseer making you swab this, batten that, and hoist the other thing.

story: In venice, the boat used by the courts to transport criminals is a rowboat.
column3: Courts in olden times would often punish convicts by sentencing them to a life of being the rower crew for large rowboat ships (there were no engines or boilers back then)... Yo ho, Yo ho....
column4: "Row, row, row your boat.....". Imagine someone who goes to court, claiming they wrote this song first.

story: 何これ???? ok, sorry to be crude... if you claw at a girls melons, she is gonna give you the elbow.
column3: M for melon. 瓜elon.
column4: Vegetarian vultures are fighting for a melon, each trying to elbow its way to it with claws.

story: Joan of Arc ("arc" also means "bow" in french) is practicing with a bow, shooting at melons in a distant field.
column3: When you use a bow to shoot a melon, the arc varies depending on how far away you are.
column4: Both a bow and a melon are arc-shaped.

story: Unlike the celebrated story of Momotaro the peach boy, no one knows the story of the melon boy who was left an orphan.
column3: This is the happier version of Oliver Twist. Here the orphaned children are served fresh melon with every meal. "Please, sir, may I have some more melon?" "Why, of course, help yourself!"
column4: The orphan child was found in a basket of melons.

story: This is a simple two-column manga showing the metamorphosis of a caterpillar into a cocoon. First, the caterpillar gets under a large flower (bees tend to hang around flowers, which scare away other predators). Then, in the first frame, we see the caterpillar (insect). Then, a bar separating this frame from the next frame (remember that Japanese manga run the other way!), in which we see the insect covered with thread, making a beautiful cocoon.
column3: The magic flower is the reason why Spider-Man ended up miniaturized and confined inside a hood-like cocoon together with an insect. Now, only a walking stick separates them both.
column4: Spider-Man bent over to pick up a pretty flower when a giant glass hood dropped over him- it's a trap! Now he's stuck inside, fending off a swarm insect with his walking stick as they try to wrap him in a cocoon. Could this be the end of Spider-Man?!

story: The benefit of having sharp horns and fast legs is that an animal can get to the food dish first.
column3: The benefit of being an animal with horns and fast legs is in keeping it from becoming a dish for the other animals! (shaydwyrm).
column4: The resturant I worked at had no real benefits (vaction time, sick leave, etc), except for one-free meals. However, the meals sucked. Basically, we were given left overs, consiting of animal horns, and animal legs, on a plain dish.

story: Some jackass-like people have way too much spare time. You can find video's of them all over the internet, if you like such things, you can watch it all day. You see them stapling their mouths shut, or throwing eachother upside down in boxes or kicking each other in the crotch.
column3: Tip: The complex right side of this kanji appears twice more in Heisig. He later names it "hobby". REF: 蝦 (#2728), 霞 (#2800).
column4: I avoid using "mouth" here because it makes me mess up the stroke order. Instead I use a flag/staple combo. Hopefully you've seen the Justin Timberlake "dick in a box" spoof. Someone has a lot of spare time, so he decides to spend the day making an especially elaborate dick in a box. There's a flag stapled to the box as decoration (like wrapping paper). He rigs it up so he can instantly flip the box inside-out to reveal his crotch. Well, it's a vivid image once you get it. He's my hero.

story: Arrowheads are spread all over the field. The taskmaster profiteerer forces you to find them all using a compass.
column3: Instead of being glued to one 専 (#46) 専, I decided to spread my attention in many directions 方, and be a taskmaster at none.
column4: I assasinated the taskmasker. When the arrowhead hit his brain, bits and pieces spread out in all directions.

story: You horny bastard, don't come, at least not yet!
column3: When I come home, there's nobody and no dinner waiting for me. Sigh...rice for one again.
column4: Here I see, of all things, Bambi. His animal horns have not yet come out. (As we can see in the kanji, the animal horns are not at the top, not "poking through". ) Remember: Bambi will soon come to have a great set of animal horns but they have not yet come out.

story: Captain Hook, his spirit crushed, is lying on the ground cursing Wolverine who has defeated him with his far superior claws.
column3: You're reclining on the floor trying to hook a sheaf with a small hook through the cracks. That you've been doing this for seven hours without success shows your burning spirit.
column4: Wolverine has a fighting spirit, and even while reclining on the floor sharpens the hooks on his claws.

story: Water vapor almost looks like a spirit but has no soul.
column3: Wolverine disappears into water vapor, seemingly his spirit dissipating into nothingness.
column4: In this scene, Captain Hook is RECLINING on the FLOOR with his HOOK in the air in the desert. He is drying up dying, you can even see the WATER VAPOR being sucked right out of him.

story: Hooks with small wings attached look like hummingbirds with a long beak. Two hummingbirds are trying to fly away with our little measuring box. What do they want it for?
column3: Two hummingbirds flying to feed at a measuring box filled with sugar water. This kanji is famous for having hard-to-remember stroke order. Try it this way: first a hummingbird flies over the measuring box walls backwards. But finally the other hummingbird manages to stick its beak right through them.
column4: (To keep the stroke order) Flying by, you see a hummingbird land on a walking stick. The bird looks around and sees a person nearby bending over, and gives the signal to attack. In swoops a second hummingbird, poking it's beak right into his back. Ouch!

story: (thx geezer) The maimed waitress (no head and arms just her legs and trunk) is dropped into the water with a cement crown to make sure she sinks. She shouldn't have been so nosy about her yakuza-boyfriend's schemes.
column3: This is the famous story of Archimedes and the Crown, where buoyancy was discovered. Watching the crown sink in the water, Archimedes detected the fraud and ran naked through the city (human legs distorted from running) yelling "Eureka! Eureka!" See http://math.nyu.edu/~crorres/Archimedes/Crown/CrownIntro.html and http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eureka_%28word%29.
column4: A mob of peasants throws a noble into the waters, his human legs stuck into the crown he was wearing proudly just a minute before (this later image for the special primitive combo on the right). The poor guy sinks to his death, unable to swim back up. Sunk by his crown!

story: The guy who was thrown into the river to sink was given one last request. "If I'm gonna be sleeping with the fishes," he said, "can I at least have a pillow? I'm real sensitive." The mafia bosses laughed. "Look, my doctor said I can only use wooden pillows, I have a real serious condition. Can I at least die comfortable-like?" The mafia dudes said fine, and let him have his pillow. They tossed him the river and drove off...and after a minute, he bobbed to the top, thanks to his floating wood pillow.
column3: WOODEN PILLOWS do not 沈 (#2033) in water.
column4: Some Japanese people sleep with a pillow made of wood, in case there's a flood in the middle of the night. Because pillows made of wood do not sink, they need never fear falling asleep without a flotation device nearby.

story: Ten rakes woman. your wife digs her fingernails into you and it feels like 10 rakes when she finds you ontop of another woman.
column3: (I'm really not sexist, this just helps me remember the kanji): I make my WIFE do all the yard work, and as a really mean joke, I bought her TEN RAKES for her birthday this year. "Do the yardwork, WOMAN! You have TEN perfectly good RAKES to choose from!"
column4: Your wife's fingernails are like ten rakes clawing into you. What a savage woman.

story: Sugoi! Sugoi! Ice Wife Sugoi!
column3: I prefer keyword "terrific" for this as the Japanese meaning can be either "great" or "dreadful". Story: freezing your wife is a terrific idea, she can still look pretty and you don't have to listen to all the nagging.
column4: His wife has a nifty way of making all types of ice cream in her home freezer.

story: If you thought that the dude in 哀 was pathetic, you haven't seen him after his decline. Here he is carrying a stick around in his mouth like a dog, begging people to throw it for him. Note that the mouth is closed only after the stick goes in, as is only logical.
column3: My kanji writing ability has declined so much even my one looks pathetic.
column4: If you thought that the dude in 哀 was pathetic, you haven't seen him after his decline. Here he is carrying a stick around in his mouth like a dog, allowing people to rent him and play catch with him for money!

story: The guy from 哀 (#428) shared his inmost feelings with a girl and she rammed a walking stick down his throat. It ruptured his inmost organs.
column3: Besides making money from acting like a dog (see decline), the pathetic man has risked his inmost internal organs by becoming a cane swallower!
column4: I'm going with 9 strokes: the magician pulled 10 scarves from the inmost part of his mouth.

story: When Jim Carrey puts on The Mask, he can make it seem like he has 100 eyes popping out of his head.
column3: If you're wearing a mask, a hundred eyes can look at you but none of them will know who you are.
column4: I see this as the comb primitive combined with the kanji for 3 giving the same stroke order :). So picture a person wearing 3 combs on their face as a mask. メン.

story: I always eat barley noodles with a mask on - it stops them splashing in your face.
column3: There is a certain restaurant in West-Shinjuku that serves its noodles made of BARLEY in a MASK instead of a plate. I love these theme-restaurants!
column4: Don't be fooled! That's just barley masquerading as noodles.

story: You can feed twenty mouths for a year for the price of ten leather coats.
column3: I asked the street vendor the price of the LEATHER jacket. He said TWENTY, but with my MOUTH, I talked him down to TEN. (correct stroke order).
column4: This kanji depicts a leather jacket wearing gang of 20 people. To make themselves look even tougher, they all have needles in their mouths (i.e. piercings, but here of a specific kind).

story: Leather shoes are nice because they change shape to fit your foot.
column3: Leather is often changed into shoes.
column4: If you buy leather shoes, you have to "break them in" - wear them so that they change shape to fit your foot.

story: In the Old West, cowboys had hegemony OVER the Indians despite their leathercraft and ability to navigate by the moon.
column3: In the old west, animal skins were made into leather and their flesh was eaten, thus using the whole animal, which viewed from the animal side could be taken as humans asserting complete hegemony over them. All your base are belong to us.
column4: Leather + flesh = scalping. It's commonly believed that the Indians invented scalping but in fact it was the American colonists that created the practice of cutting off a dead Indian's hair + skin as proof of the kill. In response the Indians started doing the same to them, but history is written by the winners so most people blame the Indians for this barbaric practice. (true story) In the Old West, colonists exercised their hegemony by scalping the Indians.

story: When an enemy's flag is raised, a true samurai can split it in half with just his voice.
column3: Having lost his voice, the samurai comunicated to his troops with a striped flag.
column4: The lower element is easier to remember as: venetian mask with stick. Story: During carnival time you try to guess who is that gentleman hiding his face under venetian mask with stick. You definetely heard his voice before.

story: The eyebrows hover over the eyes like a divided flag.
column3: (+astridtops) Eyebrows are like flags that are raised above your eyes. The flag is divided because otherwise that would be a monobrow.
column4: The venetian mask with stick covers the eyes but I can recognize his bushy eyebrows above it.

story: As a present, I gave my dentist a hand-crank tool for spreading mouths. He was so happy since it makes his job easier.
column3: This kanji does not mean "give" as in "give to someone." It means "give" in the sense that someone gave you something, or did something for your benefit when combined with a gerund (-te/-de form) of a verb. STORY: Your working in a factory and your hand gets stuck in one of the gears. You yell with a big MOUTH, "HELP!" and one of your co-workers runs over, GIVES YOU a HAND-CRANK TOOL, and goes back to work. =(.
column4: I see this as a pictograph of an old-style phonograph - a stand, record, crank and bell (the mouth). Even the primitives work out - a tool with a crank which plays music out of the bell mouth. Imaginge giving one of these old and beautiful phonographs to a classical or jazz music buff!

story: A man from a less enlightened society comes for a visit, and asks the host to give him a woman for some recreation.
column3: While at the dentist's office giving him his hand-crank tool, one of the assistant's asks me if I'd like to join her in the back for some recreation.
column4: A woman gives up her recreation time in order to raise a family.

story: It is a rookie mistake to believe the words when your sweetie says "You don't have to give me anything for my birthday." Trust me, your sweetie wants something, something shiny, and if you disappoint, you will suffer.
column3: You must give words of apology when you make a mistake.
column4: "I GIVE you my WORD that I won't make the same MISTAKE twice".

story: This kanji is used in compounds for the steaming of food and also for smoking/fumigation. Here we have the Japanese once again trying to replicate the French cuisine, only with a twist, steaming food with flowers (think of flower-smoked ham for example). Flowers must first be completely soaked in water, and then poured over a thin piece of flooring under which there is an oven fire.
column3: Note: complete + water + floor are later combined into 丞 丞 (#2927). Story: The driver of a steam train asks you for a helping hand and explains that your job is to throw flowers on the fire to make the steam.
column4: (EASY KANJI!) At the top we see hot steam forming FLOWERS. At the bottom we see the STOVE FIRE heating the bottom of a pan. So what's in the middle causing all this steam? Its all COMPLETELY WATER.

story: To get someone to completely acquiesce it takes 3 dunks in the water before they give.
column3: To get someone to acquiesce, duck them completely in aqua (=water) three times. (variation on dingomick's).
column4: Waterboarding: To completely acquiesce it usually takes just three sessions with water. (Thanks to dingomick for the idea.)

story: Damn racoons ill show them. I put a snare in the bin as well as a few phosphorous sparklers so as to scare the shit out of the buggers as they rummage through my bin.
column3: (thegeezer3) Damn racoons... I'll show them. I'll put a SNARE in the BIN as well as a few SPARKLERS so as to scare the shit out of the buggers, then hit them with a SHOVEL.
column4: A typical German apartment has five different kind of trash bins: paper, plastic, glass, biodegradable, and everything else. Don't you dare throw your trash in the wrong bin, or else you'll find yourself on the wrong side of a booby trap: hung by a snare, burned by sparklers, and knocked out cold by a shovel.

story: Can simplify this using 朽 (#1331). Then: The expedition to the poles is bad for your health, and the decay that started in your mouth spreads to your crotch – at which point you fall to the floor.
column3: (modified Katsuo) Can simplify this using 朽 (#1331). You travel to the poles, a frozen wasteland. In desperate need of food you try to set up a snare but the tree is decayed (see story for 朽 (#1331)) so you catch no prey. The brutal cold first attacks your mouth as your lips turn blue, then your crotch also gets cold as your body fails; finally you fall to the floor.
column4: Santa Claus (from the North Pole, of course), has a wooden sled led by reindeer snared at the mouth. One unfortunate night, he jumps down a chimney and burns his crotch on a piece of coal as he hits the floor.

story: The kanji looks like an elephant with tusks. the box is the elephant's eye. The final stroke is the tusk.
column3: He stored the tusks into a box, along with the broken halberds.
column4: You can save yourself a lot of trouble because Heisig is correct on 牙 (#2053) (4), 芽 (#2054) (8), 邪 (#2055) (8) but not 雅 (#2056) (5th edition says 12, but WWWJDIC says 13). So: In it's Kanji form, it has four (4) strokes, in it's primitive form (I suggest: ivory because that's what elephant tusks are made of) it has always five (5) strokes for all Kanji in RTK1.

story: Zoo keepers are baffled as to why the tips of the elephant's tusks keep budding into flowers.
column3: Buds while they're still small tend to be tusk-shaped.
column4: An elephant places a big flower on the other elephant's tusks, to show they're best buds.

story: The wicked queen builds her city walls out of menacing tusks.
column3: As everyone knows, rhinoceroses and elephants are often killed for the value of their TUSKS. Here we see a WICKED city mayor who has had countless elephants killed just to make his CITY WALLS out of TUSKS.
column4: You can see this is the city of the wicked just by the huge tusks adorning the city walls.

story: "Goodness gracious! Such an elegant turkey with a tusk." This mnemonic is meant to join RtK's keyword with a better proposition. Heisig could have used "elegant" here, which is not confounded so easily with 淑 (#778), and accurately represents the character's meaning (it is also the chosen keyword in Kodansha's Kanji Learner's Dictionary).
column3: To not confuse it with 恩 (#652) or 淑 (#778), think of the phrase "Goodness gracious." Like: "Goodness gracious! A turkey with tusks!"
column4: "Goodness gracious! A turkey with tusks!" screamed the elegant lady walking through the GM farm.

story: Animal track primitive: As expected, animal tracks were left in place of the trail of rice I'd purposely dropped the night before. EDIT - also try the footprint for a primitive meaning, the classic symbol of detective films. STORY: This shakuhachi player is so talented, he can do interpretations of animal noises too. They're so realistic he soon has animal tracks leading straight to wherever he's playing.
column3: The magical shakuhachi can easily give explanation for any animal tracks, just like it can be used to translate words (訳).
column4: Mrs. Badger follows the animal tracks to the den where she finds her husband getting shakuhachi from a fox. Now, I don't speak badger but judging from the screeching and the gestures, my interpretation of the situation is that Mrs. Badger is not pleased. (thanks dingomick! Just trying to use this new keyword).

story: The famers take it in turns to watch out for any animal tracks on their rice field.
column3: (modified thegeezer3) Animal tracks and animal droppings were found in the rice field, now the kids of the farmer take it in turns to keep watch and hinder the animals to make more animal tracks and leave animal droppings in their precious rice field. They roll the dice to decide in what order they have to keep watch and when everyones turn is.
column4: I find "turn" alone is too generic to remember, so I add an additional keyword, numerical order. This is perhaps the most common context in which this kanji is found, e.g. 1st, 2nd = 一番、二番. Story: I see animal tracks leading to the rice field and start to worry, but then see the numerical order in which the tracks are made: 一番mouse tracks, 二番　cat tracks, 三番　dog tracks, then 四番　lion tracks. Looks like the rice is safe.

story: At your divorce hearing the judge tells you to roll dice to see who keeps the house. ("I can't believe what I'm hearing!" you say).
column3: In the courthouse the judge decides your hearing with a roll of the dice.
column4: In the house of law, both sides take turns during the hearing.

story: Don't play dice with birds. When you're not looking, they'll flip the dice with their feathers.
column3: It's your turn to flip the chicken wings on grill.
column4: When the birds out the back are playing dice, they flip their feathers (not their finger) at their opponents.

story: This character refers to feudal clans that were abolished in 1871 (Meiji 4) in favor of prefectures (廃藩置県), and thus were predecessors of the modern prefectures. As we know from 落, flowers and water drops each have their own way of falling. This character says that clans' location was decided in the way flowers, water drops and dice fall: at random. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Han_%28country_subdivision%29.
column3: In the particular clan depicted by this character, each member has to take his or her turn watering the flowers.
column4: Each member of the clan has to take his turn at watering the flowers. The order they do it in is decided by a roll of the dice. (tweaked Matthew's story).

story: I've heard of people having hair on the back of their hands, but this is ridiculous! That's not hair, that's fur!
column3: Be careful not to pet a cat the wrong way - most cats don't like you rubbing your hand backwards over their fur.
column4: Reverse stroke of hand disturbs the fur.

story: The amount of "fur" (needles) on a Christmas tree decreases, until it doesn't look all that good.
column3: Real fur coats and real christmas trees are dereasing the last couple of years. Plasctic chrismas trees and fake fur it is nowadays.
column4: A marketing survey shows that there has been a decrease in Christmas trees sales. It turns out, many very stupid people confused a fir tree with a "fur" tree, and because "fur is murder" stopped buying the trees.

story: A dog waves its furry tail like a flag.
column3: A FLAG of FUR is a TAIL.
column4: Animals wave their furry tails like flags, indicating their mood.

story: This kanji is, of course, pronounced "taku", and it seems the owner of this home is a little bit otaku himself. He has hung up locks of hair suruptitiously obtained from various females all over his house. A veritable hair fetishist, and certainly someone whose home you wouldn't want to visit.
column3: "Home is where the hair is".
column4: At home, all the drains in my house are clogged up with locks of hair.

story: When you consign a matter to someone, you get their word and a lock of their hair (to be used in a voodoo ritual if they don't keep their word).
column3: In "The Lord of the Rings", Galadriel consigned a lock of her hair to Gimli the dwarf, along with some wise words.
column4: ENGLISH DEF.: give over to another for care or safekeeping; "consign your baggage" /// When you consign a matter to someone, you get their word and a lock of their hair (to be used in a voodoo ritual if they don't keep their word).

story: In this kanji, you can see 3 katakana characters: ソ, ユ, and then ユ again followed by TAIL FEATHERS. STORY: "So (ソ) you (ユ) wanna DO it?" "Only if you (ユ) do" says the female bird as she raises her TAIL FEATHERS.
column3: "ソ ユ think ユ can dance?" Dancer in a peacock costume: "Heck yeah, I do!" -shakes tail feathers-.
column4: Tell a story - a reluctant magician is asked to do a trick. The audience chant 'Do it, do it!', so eventually he does one. He takes a drop of water (stroke 1), drops it on the ground where it runs down and smears out (stroke 2). It drops down two steps (strokes 3 and 4) (imagine some nice setting with steps), growing and becoming multicoloured, like a petrol drop, as it goes. Then at the bottom the magician touches it with his wand and you see it has turned into a set of peacock's tail feathers.

story: Mr. T doesn’t "DO" FALSEHOOD. It goes against everything he stands for. “I pity da foos who revel in FALSEHOODs!”.
column3: "It depends on what your definition of do, uh, is," says Mr. T giving falsehood about his affair with a peacock.
column4: A person who claims he didn't do something while he actually did, is telling a falsehood.

story: The man being tortured was apprehensive as he saw his tormentor approaching with a hairpin poised to pierce his brain!
column3: I’m feeling apprehensive because I’m wading barefoot in a paddyfield and I've just dropped my hairpin.
column4: I was a little apprehensive before brain surgery, and when the surgeon took my brain out and stuck it atop a hairpin, my apprehensions were confirmed! Put my brain back right away, I bellowed. 畏まりました！ said the surgeon. (thanks Meconium).

story: The Geisha with long hair uses an ornate lacquered hairpin to bundle it all up.
column3: The top of this one reminds me of the staple primitive. So here's my story: The girl's hair was so long that she had to use staples instead of hairpins. It worked, but stapling her hair to her head was kinda painful.
column4: As a primitive I use the image of (very) long hair. Let this kanji represent a "Swiss Hairpin" (similar to a Swiss army knife) : the top part being a pictogram for half a comb, and the lower part being the hairpin. Just make sure not to confuse with the kanji for "comb". Think of this one as a "half a comb" that can be pulled from the "Swiss Hairpin".

story: The longbow is follows the design of a standard bow, only it has been lengthened.
column3: Wanna lengthen the distance you can shoot? Use a longbow!
column4: To make your bow into a longbow, just lengthen it.

story: In ancient China books were rolled-up scrolls of paper. So notebooks were nothing more than long towels.
column3: Students, for this class, your notebook will be a towel. Make sure it's extra long though, we'll have a lot of writing.
column4: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy is the notebook computer to bring when you're going on a (really!) long trip (Also, used by long haired hippy type galactic hitchhikers). Don't forget to bring your towel!

story: Taking Viagra let's your blood vessels dilate...resulting in a body part getting long.
column3: Staying out in the dark moonlit sky for a long time, your pupils dilate.
column4: Your girldfriend's pupils dilate. She's never seen a piece of flesh that long!

story: Japanese teenage girls consider the style of the hair of the head very important. If a particular style is trendy, soon they all want their own hair in the same shape as that of their friends.
column3: Friends influence the length and shape of each other's hair.
column4: My daughter has long hair which she shapes in various ways depending on which friend she's going out with.

story: You use an American flag to wrap up a salad for a picnic and bind it with a hairpin. Now imagine unfolding it to open up the bounty you've fixed up for yourself.
column3: Unfold flag, take out the salad, pin the flag down with hairpins and have a picnic.
column4: You unfold the Stars and Stripes flag in order to hoist it high, but there's a problem! One of the stars has fallen off! With some quick thinking, you pin a flower to the flag using a hairpin, and you're all set. Good thing you don't have to refold the flag once unfolded.

story: I miss my parents dearly. Here they lay, under a big cross, their mouths side by side. I stick hairpins in their graves. CAREFUL: the stroke order/primitive order is: ten, L mouth, R mouth, hairpin. "Soil" is not drawn in its stroke order.
column3: Ten days ago, our two mouths met for the last time... then she gave me her hairpin as a sayounara gift. How I miss my Geisha girl...
column4: This kanji means miss as in "miss a (dearly departed) person", not as in "miss a target". Here the dearly departed has been buried in the ground, with her favourite hairpin in place of a gravestone, and two mourners stand around crying with open mouths.

story: Owls only nest in fruit trees.
column3: The wise old OWL makes her nest out of FRUIT, carving out the middle for her chicks, because then it's less work: no running back & forth to get food!
column4: If only there had been a wise owl nesting in the tree of forbidden fruit to warn Eve about the snake.

story: Owls are smart...for this owl everything is simple coz his brain is ten times more powerful than mine.
column3: For owls, finding a needle in a rice field is simple (much better eyesight than us humans).
column4: It's simple for an owl to find a needle in a rice field 田, because an owl's eyesight is ten 十 times better than a human's. Older version is 單, with "owl" looking like 2 eyes 口口. 簡単、かんたん, easy, simple (simplicity +): 簡単な報告を出しました, "I turned in a simple report." 簡単に, easily: 宿題は簡単に出来た, "I was easily able to do the homework."

story: George W. Bush's plans for war were so SIMPLE. To him, its all just a big FIESTA.
column3: What started out as a simple fiesta, turned into a full-scale war after arguments about whose potato salad was the best.
column4: To start a war, simply throw a spear.

story: Knowing ZEN’s emphasis on “nothingness,” it’s not hard to envision a ZEN ALTAR being quite clean and SIMPLE.
column3: Because Zen is so simple, you don't need an alter, just a quiet place to sit.
column4: Simple-minded blond girl (see frame 1928) is very good at Zen, which isn't surprising since she doesn't think much. She has this bad habit of meditating perched on the main temple altar, which infuriates the Zen buddhists. When they get up to her and tell her rudely to step down the altar, she just smiles and teases them : "Not very zen are you ?". Who would have thought simple-minded blond girl would teach the Zen buddhists a lesson !

story: Hunting with a bow is too complicated. I'm switching to something simpler--using a bullet.
column3: The bow was a weapon for simple times, but nowadays it has been replaced by bullets.
column4: Give a bow to simple-minded blond girl (see frame 1928), and she'll try to shoot bullets with it ! When she joined this local archery club she was told she needed some equipment, and guess what she did ? She went to the grocery store and bought some bullets.

story: I was taking a picture of my girlfriend under the cherry tree during 花見, when an owl happened to poop on her at the exact moment the shutter snapped. It's really my favorite picture , just don't tell her that.
column3: The tree in Japan that represents both wisdom (the owl) and femininity (the woman). This is a sakura (さくら), or cherry tree.
column4: Athena seating against a cherry tree with her owl on her shoulder. She is picking cherries and feeding her owl.

story: The owl looks for its prey in the rice field. It sees so many potential animals to eat but since it only has one mouth, it decides that the tasty looking chihuahua will be its meal for tonight. (adapted from Copycatken,1-9-2006).
column3: I have a strange story for this one but it works. I imagine a owl getting into a rice field which serves as a boxing ring. His opponent is a little chihuahua. The fight starts, the owl takes one punch to the mouth and is out cold. In the chihuahua's corner is that coach from Rocky saying "Your an ANIMAL!!". A vivid image of this story works pretty well for me.
column4: This kanji is used for sort of monstrous beasts. Imagine a mythical animal with an owl's head and a dog's body. It is so large that it can devour an entire rice field with one mouth. 怪獣 【かいじゅう】 (n) monster; 獣 【けもの(P); けだもの(P); じゅう】 (n) beast; brute.

story: The brain is the part of the body that can give you the wisdom of the owl... or the wickedness of the villain.
column3: This villain is really messed up. He lets his pet owl eat various pieces of flesh from his body. Right now the owl is on his head, picking out pieces of the villain's brain.
column4: The brain is the part of the body that can make you wise like an owl or devious like a villain.

story: The owl villain is the one that troubles me most of all the super-villains. He's just so smart... you never know what he'll do! Definitely enough to put you in a troubled state of mind.
column3: You have troubles in the brain, not in the part of the body but in your state of mind. (see 脳 (#2084)).
column4: We're all in trouble if a wise owl has a change in it's state of mind and becomes a villian.

story: This represents a stern looking owl, perched up on a cliff. This cliff is quite famous for daring individuals to cliff dive off of, but is any of them daring enough to threaten the owl?
column3: (厳しい strict; stern ) You remember of course the daring fella who had his ear pierced and went standing in front of the taskmaster. The taskmasters punishment was very stern/strict. Fella thrown of the cliff, where the owls are ready to feast. No funny guy doing that anymore.
column4: The owl gives a stern warning to any animal that dare pass under the cliff.

story: The chain on this chainsaw is made of little metal shells.
column3: A gold chain with small seashells hanging on it is in fashion these days.
column4: The metal CHAIN holding an anchor is covered with small shellfish after being in dock for a while.

story: This is a special owl-luring tool. All you need is to raise it in your hand. Owl will come flying and perch on it right away.
column3: The owl was asked to raise his hand if he needed anything, but he had a wing, not a hand! So he made a tool that looked like a hand which he used when he needed to raise his hand. For raiseing, owl has a tool hand.
column4: When Harry Potter raises his hand, Hedwig brings him a magical tool.

story: This owl's reputation skyrocketed after he created a tool in order to speak human words.
column3: By word of mouth, owl-luring tool (挙 (#2088)) gained a reputation of amazingly effective and reliable device.
column4: Stephen Hawking has a reputation of being as smart as an owl but using a tool to speak.

story: [game-hunting; shooting; game; bag] According to unicode.org and wwwjdic, 鼡 and 鼠 (鼠 (#2856)) are variants. So, for 鼡 (which I'll call rat) I have: an owl, flying in the wind, can easily spot a rat even if it's hiding in the cornstalks. Now 猟 is easy: wild dogs are having fun by game-hunting rats.
column3: The WILD DOGS are GAME HUNTING the OWL who flies like the WIND through the CORN STORKS.
column4: The hunter, with his WILD DOGs to sniff out prey and his trained OWL to scout from the sky, is out game-hunting among the CORNSTALKS in a fierce WIND.

story: There is only one bird with such beautiful white tail feathers: the albino peakcock.
column3: The BIRD let loose a WHITE ONE from it's TAIL FEATHERS...right on my new car!
column4: A white bird with one massive tail feather.

story: A chirp is quite simply the sound that comes from the mouth of birds.
column3: This kanji is not limited to the chirp of a bird, but stands for the sound of any kind of animal. Picture a very weird bird that can imitate with its mouth (a bird with mouth, heh) the voice of many different animals: Meeow! Woof! Mooo! Cuack!!! (Maybe the bird has Kirby powers and obtains the abilities of the animals it eats).
column4: Addition to DrJones' story: the bird that can mimic other animals (and then some!) is a Lyrebird. Check http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VjE0Kdfos4Y to see one in action.

story: The original version of the "Ugly Duckling" was about a crane who grew up in a turkey coop. All the other birds made fun of it for not having a wattle or a snood or fanning its tail...
column3: I ordered a crane to move my turkey coop, but they sent me this damn bird instead.
column4: Do you know how cranes came to be? Well, they used to keep the poor bird cooped all the time. But the crane really wanted to be free, so it would always streatch its head and neck out of the coop trying to be free.

story: The book's story is just fine, but I found a kanji dictionary explanation also interesting: As crows are all black, it's hard to see where their eyes are (black on black), so a stroke is removed from the part in the pictograph where the eyes would be.
column3: A crow is a bird, but not a white one. MEANING: write bird, but skip writing one in white.
column4: When God made crows he took away their whiteness and gave them big mouths instead.

story: In the jungle there is a flowery vine called hedera rhombea that attracts humming birds by the dozens. They scoot around the flowers sucking up nectar off the vine.
column3: Note : if you'll remember we already have a primitive for "ivy", but it was completely made up from the "square jewel" kanji. The kanji here refers to ivy, or vine, and is used in a particular compound for "Hedera rhombea", which is a type of ivy native to Japan. This vine here produces a lot of flowers, and attracts many small birds, which is sure to cheer up even the most depressed Japanese gardener.
column4: It's strange that you don't often see flowers on vines, that's because those sneaky birds keep swooping in and stealing them!

story: Pigeons are the birds that come in hordes after baseball games to eat all the trash left by fans.
column3: A PIGEON defecates NINE times as often as other BIRDS. Or so it seems.
column4: Imagine some pigeons going to see a baseball game. They would surely be the only birds there!

story: The vulture's husband is a chicken...heck...who am I to judge their interspecies love? They're both birds so its cool.
column3: A continuation of 渓 (#903) (which happens to have the same chinese pronunciation) : the husband who was saved by the great eagle says to his wife that from now on, they will eat chicken ! No more fishing hardships and falling in the water.. just raising birds. Every now and then the great eagle comes to visit and the man offers one of his chicken to the great eagle who had saved his life.
column4: Ever since that eagle attacked my husband from above, he acts like a chicken whenever he sees a bird, fearing that it might be the eagle who has come back to finish the job.

story: This island is the home of the terrible mythical bird Roc. It sits mighty atop the mountain waiting for the next hapless ship to pass by.
column3: On the mountain of the island.. there were birds with no tail feathers.
column4: From the bird's point of view, an island is a mountain in the middle of water and it is very suitable for resting its tired tail feathers.

story: Ducks migrate south for the winter... they follow the warmth of the sun.
column3: Mnemonic for migrating ducks: ducks always migrate together in pairs to protect themselves from vultures--they become friends in the process.
column4: A massive group of migrating ducks is blocking the warmth of the sun as they pass over your house/barbecue/picnic. Their formation is so humongous they block the warmth for a good 10 minutes while they pass over. Mnemonic for the migrating ducks primitive : the migrating ducks stick together like the best of friends, flying together as one (fifth stroke), they are not easy prey for the great eagles / vultures.

story: You want to know about a beautiful woman? There's a woman that's so beautiful, the birds migrate to her instead of the sun!
column3: As I saw the most beautiful woman on Earth, a flock of migrating ducks passed by and let their poop fly. That just ruined the moment...
column4: Helen of Troy was known for her beauty -- as the "face that launched a thousand ships." In this slightly mangled version of the story, she's the woman who launched a thousand migrating ducks.

story: You abet the escape of migrating ducks by pointing them the way.
column3: This kanji is in the word 援助(えんじょ) which means to support or assist. The word abet suggests that you are helping or supporting something that is morally wrong. Support is a much better choice for this kanji. Story: The migrating ducks left a little early this year, leaving one duck behind. He gives them the finger and says thanks "Thanks for the support, assholes!"
column4: "Aiding and abetting:" You are accuse of abetting a drug dealer, by smuggling drugs in migrating ducks. Of course, this means you have to stick your fingers in their mouths.

story: Oh no Spiderman has some migrating ducks stuck in his web, he has to slacken it so they can get out.
column3: [slacken; loosen; relax; lessen; be moderate; ease] The thread in this story is a cable line, something like a power or phone line. The thread was tense with all the migrating ducks perched on it, but got back to being slackened when the entire flock flew away. (darg_sama-modified,2-11-2005).
column4: Spiderman is flying a flock of migrating ducks as one would fly a kite, using his web lines as the thread. But he notices the ducks are pulling away hard, threatening to break the line. Then he remembers the advice of dear Aunt May, a noted kite freak: you've gotta slacken it. Put some slack in it!

story: These bugs BELONG TO an extremist group promoting insect independence. They are parading the FLAG of their group, the Nationalist GNATS, and wearing explosives BELTS for their planned terrorist war.
column3: [WARNING: violent story] Two teams of insects are playing “capture the flag” (ala Unreal Tournament). All of them wear ammunition belts. Here you try to take the flag of the opponent team, when you are faced by an insect: “You’ll get our flag over my dead body!”. You reply: “All your base are BELONG to us!”, shoot him on the head, take the flag and run away. See the drop of blood flowing from his head?
column4: This kanji is often used like this: The frog BELONGS to the amphibian species. STORY: A scientist is trying to classify all the different INSECTS in the forest to find out which species they BELONG to. He does this by going from rock to rock, tree to tree, putting a FLAG where he already went, while taking INSECT sample DROPS (small insects/beetles look like DROPS) and DROPPING them into his BELT which is rigged with little jars.

story: The commando gnats entrusted their mouths to the translators and what came out was "All your base are belong to us!"
column3: If you entrust me with something, my mouth belongs to you.
column4: You should only open your mouth to entrust someone with a secret if they belong in your family.

story: Mr. T accidentially stepped on Jiminy Cricket (a brainy insect, with a belt sort of sash to hold his "conscience" badge).
column3: Mr. T accidentally steps on Jiminy Cricket. // Primitive: right side: Talking cricket = Jiminy Cricket, a brainy insect with a belt to whip little kids who misbehave.
column4: 禺 is actually a kanji itself, albeit a rarely used one. Despite its several meanings, the most common seems to be a red-eyed, long-tailed, big-headed monkey. Since we already have a primitive that means monkey, I'm going to call this one the long-tailed, talking monkey (borrowing from Heisig a little). STORY: After suffering a slow period of work, Ace Ventura accidentally discovered the rare long-tailed, talking monkey and life has been good to him ever since.

story: I was finally able to score an interview with the wisest being around: Jiminy Cricket. However, his schedule is really packed, so they had to squeeze me in while his tour bus rode between gigs. In fact, it was really short---after a few miles I was kicked out of the bus and stranded in the middle of the interstate. But man, it was worth it!
column3: On the road to my interview I accidentally bump into Jiminy Cricket who gives me some good advice.
column4: "Interview" is a bit of a stretch, as this means "to meet accidentally". The place where person accidentally met the crickety fellow was on the road somewhere. It was, in a way, like a sudden interview: in both cases person just wants to get away fast.

story: "Don't be foolish!" says Jiminy Cricket as he lashes you with his belt. Follow logic, like me, not your heart.
column3: It'd be foolish to follow Jiminy Cricket's advice in matters of the heart. After all, you never see him around any girl crickets, do you?
column4: I simply imagine Jiminy Cricket jumping all over the place, like a mad man, yelling "yeeeeehaaaaa!". Maybe he just fell in love? Mnemonic - "Jiminy Cricket has a foolish heart".

story: Jiminy Cricket has a favorite corner he likes to slip into at The Pinnacle for a long drink.
column3: If you behave badly at THE PINNACLE, JIMINY CRICKET will send you to sit in the corner.
column4: Oh how the pious fall from their lofty pinnacles! Jiminy Cricket now deals drugs on the street corner.

story: There's a road that's been inverted- it's gone from horizontal to directly vertical! The only beast that could possibly climb it is a mountain goat of course.
column3: This reminds me of a cartoon I saw once, perhaps it was with Donald Duck. he is startled and furious when he chases this mountain billygoat further and further up the mountain road, untill the angle is so steep that he finds himself inverted. And falls down, while the goat stands solidly placed inverted and laughs a goaty laughter as Donald plumments and makes that typical Donald shaped cartoon crater at the bottom.
column4: Mountain goat inverted. Horns stuck in road.

story: A legend says that if you model a mountain goat (with tail and everything) from dirt and leave to the light of the moon on the 朔 (#2862), the dirt will became flesh. (blackstockc).
column3: If you model a mountain goat from "soil" and leave it under the full "moon," it will come to life.
column4: Tip: mountain goat and moon are later combined into 朔 (#2862).

story: On the first day of the month, all the salmon go upstream, up the road, to the mating grounds.
column3: You accidentally ran over and killed the holy mountain goat on the road. Frightened by the view of the dead body and to save your own body from the angry villagers, you decide to run away from your bloodstained vehicle, jump into the river, and go upstream to hide your tracks.
column4: You decide to go salmon fishing, so you ride a mountain goat to the top of the road. Under the light of the moon, as it's illegal, you catch the salmon going upstream.

story: White mount , Fuji mount , olympus mount whatever ....The choice is yours but wherever you go they sell those snowglobe souvenir : under a GLASS HOOD you can see the mount with a MOUTAIN GOAT standing on top of it .... So kitsch you just can't forget it .
column3: Note: Stroke order is belt..horns..mountain, not the same as mountain goat.
column4: This has the same meaning as 丘, so my "Mount" is a hill with mountain goats on it under a glass canopy. It's obviously an effort by the locals to add some Mount atmosphere to their hill. As a primitive, it has the meaning "sturdy" (really), which Heisig has not used for some reason, but I will. The glass canopy must be pretty sturdy to keep the goats inside (bulletproof glass, I'm sure).

story: Mount Fuji is completely made up of a metal known as steel.
column3: Steel is the METAL forged in the fires of MOUNT DOOM.
column4: On the trail up Mount Fuji, the curators have put up metal railings for safety in some of the otherwise hazardous parts of the climb. The particular metal they used was stainless steel, so that it wouldn't rust in the rain and snow.

story: Spiderman saves Japan from floating away by tying Mt. Fuji to mainland Asia using a hawser made of web.
column3: Easy. In order to climb Mount Fuji you're going to need a strong type of thread, a hawser (heavy rope).
column4: A sturdy thread is equally obviously hawser (heavy rope). (see previous frame).

story: Mount everest is very sturdy, you can hit it all day with a saber and it wont even wobble.
column3: Anything sturdy in Japan is associated with Mount Fuji. Perhaps this is because it's symmetry is believed to make it rather sturdy itself, unlike all those crooked mountains that are around and tend to fall apart (think rock slides, avalanches, etc.). Here we see Sturdy-brand sabers with Mount Fuji engraved on the blade.
column4: Remember the sword in the stone. This is the saber in the top of Mt ---. It's so sturdy almost no one can pull it out.

story: Horses kept in the mountains have a unique savory taste. At least so the text on this tin can would have us believe, which contains 100% authentic mountain horse.
column3: The starving horse, stranded on the mountain, is forced to eat a tasty tin can.
column4: Hint: pictograph of a horse standing in a tin can. No need for mountain.

story: At The Pinnacle, traditional pottery is done by binding up a bunch of tin cans into whatever pot shape desired.
column3: In order the get clay up to the Acropolis for the pottery class, clay is packed into tin cans, bound in huge loads, and lugged up there by some unfortunate soul.
column4: Pottery is an obsolete art up in the super-modern Utopia of The Pinnacle ... instead, they bind up everything they need to preserve in high-tech tin cans.

story: For the condor primitive: A condor is like a vulture, but twice as big and it lives near mountains (a suitable place for such a majestic bird). For swing: I'm sitting on a swing when a condor comes by and picks up the whole swing set with its big finger-like claws and now I'm swinging in mid-air. Weeeeeeeee!!!!!
column3: I keep swinging gleefuly on the talons of the soaring condor until he slices off my fingers and sends me plummeting.
column4: I don't recommend using king as a primitive for condor, the stroke order is wrong. Vulture Dry Mountain or even Vulture Two Mountains should work better.

story: Noh chanting?!? I meant "NO CHANTING!" Now all you, just shut up! Not another word! Don't you know that chanting can provoke attacks from the local condor? So, no chanting, and especially no Noh chanting.
column3: Picture guy dressed in a condor mask up on stage during Noh performance chanting some words nobody understands.
column4: In the Andes flies the mythical Noh Chanting condor. You can barely spot this king of birds high up in the sky yet you hear its chanting words flow down to the ground.

story: [New story 2020] In the middle of the GLOOMY grove 林 you find a tin can 缶, containing a beautiful crown 冖, and a flask with very nice-smelling fragrant herbs 鬯! You feel so happy and lucky after finding these interesting items... but suddenly, they start changing shape 彡 in your hands... and turn into ashes! So, in similar fashion, your feelings, and the shape 彡 of your face, go from happy to really GLOOMY... and now you truly understand why this place is called the GLOOMY grove.
column3: A popular mnemonic device for this character is: リンカーンはアメリカンコーヒーを３杯飲んだ. Here's how it works: リンカーンは⇒林＋缶＋ワ アメリカンコーヒーを⇒米＋コ＋ヒ ３杯飲んだ⇒ノ＋ノ＋ノ.
column4: The depressed TIN-CAN sat between two TREEs with its CROWN on as the VILLAIN ate out of it with a SPOON and laughed at its funny SHAPE.

story: In the capital they have been having hearings concerning bioethics and bioengineering they call as their first witness a chihuahua with one human leg.
column3: Ahem...CONCERNING your recent science fair project, it was a CAPITAL idea, but the CHIHUAHUA with a HUMAN LEG is freaking out the other contestants!
column4: Note: 尤 (#2232) In the capital, there are hearings concerning bioengineering. Understandably, the piece of evidence that those in attendance found most shocking was the chihuahua with a human leg. Adapted from taijuando's version.

story: The soccer player was concerned that his peg leg would affect his ability to kick.
column3: We are here concerning your animal cruelty. Because you kicked all the chihuahuas in the capital, we are going to remove your foot as punishment.
column4: The pirate was reading the manual for his new wooden leg, and there was a whole section concerning how to use the wooden leg for kicking.

story: The skunk here is Pepe LePew of Looney Tunes fame. He's a very sociable skunk, as far as skunks go, but instead of having a "heart of gold" he has a heart of silver (since he always finishes second in the game of love).
column3: The skunk here is Pepe LePew of Looney Tunes fame. He's a very sociable skunk, as far as skunks go, but instead of having a "heart of gold" he has a heart of silver.
column4: (コン) Skunk and silver appear together in a few kanji so I combined them to make a silver skunk character. This skunk, due to a random fluke, is not black and white, but actually silver colored. Which means this skunk can pass, say for, a cat (aka Over the Hedge). When the skunk realized the odd coloring wasn't a curse but actually a blessing, it realized in it's heart that it could be sociable with all sorts of animals that normally would run away from smelly skunks.

story: It was the groundbreaking of the new farm, but there was an uninvited guest to the ceremony. It was a famous skunk, the one with the familiar silver stripe. The feet of the crowd rushing from the ceremony site churned up the soil very nicely. The ceremony was ruined but the groundbreaking was a great success.
column3: I got sprayed by a skunk, so no one is helping me with the groundbreaking of my farm. On a positive note, I found silver laying all over the soil. Mine all mine!
column4: (コン) The 懇 (#2123) silver skunk might not look like a skunk, but when it lets it smell fly, it's so bad it actually leaves craters. That's right - it's groundbreaking.

story: Skunk, white, human legs: You should have seen the shocked countenance on the girls' face when she saw the skunk nibbling away at the white human legs of the corpse she found in the woods. (Because of that, and the smell of course).
column3: The shocked countenance on girl's face when Pepe started to hump her white legs.
column4: Anyone who watched a looney tunes cartoon know those kind of scene : pepe embraces a poor kitty mistaken for a SKUNK and the smell of pepe make the unfortunate girl loose all countenance : she turns WHITE then runs as fast as her LEGS can carry her . So much for cat s dignity and countenance.

story: Obviously this is the rabbit from Alice, excusing himself and rushing away on his legs, as he has a binding day schedule. This is at the same time an image, with bound=ears, day=head and legs are just legs. The image is used in 兎 (#2235).
column3: What is the rabbit's excuse for being such a jerk? Well he was bound up for a whole day while being stepped on by peoples human legs in some make-up labratory. Yeah I think I can excuse him after knowing that.
column4: ''Excuse me.'' Jessica Rabbit walks past you, bound up in a red sequinned dress in which her voluptuous tatas are sublimely complemented by her long legs.

story: Bugs Bunny eludes Elmer Fudd by pretending to be roadkill.
column3: Word play to differentiate elude/evade: elude ~= e-lewd. Alice is following Mr. Rabbit on the road. Mr. Rabbit flashes her in a lewd way and disappears, completely eluding her.
column4: I like to maintain the primitive as excuse. Here a speedster is caught trying to elude the police. He stands outside his car bowing over and over saying ご免なさい、ご免なさい、ご免なさい。 | Note: I've actually witnessed this very event happening here in Japan. It is a common thing that people here will do when "caught" by the police...you'll see them sometimes bowing furiously apologizing over and over for their "bad" behavior.

story: At nightfall the sun excuses itself and goes to sleep.
column3: This is EASY!!! Japanese people see a RABBIT ON THE MOON (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moon_rabbit ) and so nightfall is when the sun leaves to make way for the rabbit.
column4: Imagine Bugs Bunny halfway sticking out of a rabbit hole, somewhere in Japan, taking in the sun, when all of a sudden, night falls. Our "sun-loving rabbit" burrows his way into the earth and pops out on the other side of the planet (say somewhere in America) and there it is, the sun high and bright in the sky! Thus, whenever it is nightfall you can be sure our "sun-loving rabbit" is taking in the sun somewhere else accross the globe.

story: Notice how BUGS BUNNY's legs (hint about stroke extension) are starting to get big MUSCLES? It must be because he's always EXERTING himself on the run from Elmer Fudd (or from kicking the shit out of Elmer Fudd when he catches up!!).
column3: Hint: Energizer bunny.
column4: The energizer bunny's exertion of power keeps going and going...

story: An elephant has huge ears, like a rabbit, and a big, fat body, like a sow.
column3: An animal with huge ears like a rabbit, and a body fat like a pig... ¡An ELEPHANT! For the "phenomenon" connotation you could use Dumbo, or Joseph Merrick (the "elephant man") ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Merrick ).
column4: With huge rabbit ears, and a body fat like a pig, the elephant has an image problem for sure (しょう)! NOTE: This kanji also means 'image'.

story: The statue of liberty is being replaced by a statue of Mr. T riding an elephant.
column3: In India, you see a lot of statues of the Hindu god Ganesha. Easy to recognize: he's the person with the elephant head.
column4: Mr. T is shocke of this bizarre statue of an elephant with rabbits floppy ears and the tails of a sow. I pity da fool who made this bullshit statue. What is it supposed to look like?

story: Turkey with the drops at the top removed and tail feathers added (this matches stroke order and there are the tail feathers already, why not have the whole bird). If you take the two drops of 隹 as wings, then horses are like turkeys, but have no wings and have more prominent tail "feathers". Both are actually supposed to be pictographs, though.
column3: True origin: Top three horizontal and two holding vertical strokes = the horse's mane flowing in the wind. The hook = the horse's tail and the four dots = the horse's legs.
column4: The top part is half a comb (see frame 1920) with an extra vertical stroke to account for a sturdier version used to comb a horse mane. As a primitive I used the theme of the Trojan Horse. Not the modern computer viruses, but the large wooden horse which led to the demise of Troy and of the Trojans. Either its size (much greater than a live horse), or the fact that it conceals things into its belly, will set it appart from the horse primitive that came in frame 568 ("noon").

story: The cute little innocent-looking plastic pony on the desk of a student is in fact a trojan horse, hiding phrases in its belly which are used for cheating during an exam. No pony will be permitted on desks during tests!
column3: A particular My Little Pony has a string that when you pull it, it repeats the same dumb phrase like "I love you".
column4: A phrase used to insult horses - is pony. They hate that.

story: We just verification that there are indeed no soldiers in the belly of this trojan horse. We're just gonna stab it in the belly with this awl to check.
column3: The verification proves the horse is real by poking it with an ice pick.
column4: Here we have a French trojan horse undergoing verification by the British police, or immigration, or other authority. The British police are punching into the trojan horse 's sides with anawl, to try and find if it is concealing people. Of course they aren't going to find much by using an awl for that purpose (the awl having such a short tip), but the sillyness of it should be enough to remember it.

story: If the equestrian team used trojan horses, it would be really strange.
column3: Equestrian events are where you get horses to do strange things.
column4: I always thought it was STRANGE that EQUESTRIAN was in the Olympics. Why don't we give the HORSES medals? They do all the work.

story: Parking in the dark may be difficult...specially if you're parking a trojan horse. To lend you a tiny bit of help, take this candlestick with you, and at least you'll have some light.
column3: In the olden days parking lots used to have reserved spaces for where the lord (of the set of houses, shops, whatever) could park his team of horses. nowadays it's pretty much the same...reserved parking in front for the big bosses' cars....
column4: A lord gets valet parking for his horse.

story: You have to be craaazzzzyy to drive a buggy led by a team of horses through a ward of Tokyo!
column3: Wolverine drives his box by having a horse drag him around. He seems to really be losing it after coming to the homeless ward...
column4: [drive; run; gallop; advance; inspire; impel] You thought you were downloading a driving game into your X-Box harddrive, but it was actually a trojan horse!

story: Anyone living in Japan knows that train stations play little melodies when the train is about to arrive. In Ye Olden Days, when horses and carriages were used for transport, the carriage driver would play a little melody on his shakuhachi to let the passengers know the carriage was arriving at the next station.
column3: In this train line the wagons are trojan horses and at each station the driver plays a little melody on his shakuhachi to let the passengers know they arrived at the next station. [thanks rtkrtk].
column4: A homeless horse playing the flute at the station to make a dime.

story: The hidden Greeks inside the Trojan Horse are getting boisterous as one of them is bitten in the crotch by a nasty insect. If they don't shut up, the Trojans will hear them...
column3: Or more precisely: the team of horses are getting boisterous because one of them got bitten in the crotch by a horse fly. The kanji also means to roar, make up noise, to kick up a fuss and to make merry. Perhaps it is exactly the etymology behind this kanji.
column4: My horse was boisterous because of nasty bugs in his crotch.
