story: The Greek warriors inside the Trojan Horse are complaining about this burdensome plump warrior who is not helping at all (say, just eating candies and watching). - "You know you're such a burden!". Note : be sure to keep "plump" distinct from the primitive meaning of "round" ("fat man").
column3: If a passenger is too plump and heavy, its too burdensome for the horse.
column4: HORSES find PLUMP riders BURDENSOME.

story: You stand in AWE at the 8th WONDER of the world, a huge TROJAN HORSE.
column3: This is another word for surprise. 驚く＝おどろく= surprise. The Trojans stood in awe of the magnificent Trojan Horse that they thought was a gift. But imagine their surprise (wonder) when a bunch of Greeks came rushing out of it! (To further cement the connection between the primitives, if needed: It's a wonder that the Trojans managed to speak keigo 敬語 even then, saying "わたくしたちを殺さないでください!!お願い致します!!").
column4: The horse wonders why it is being addressed in keigo 敬語 after all it is only a horse.

story: A fervent horse doesnt need to be whipped with a bamboo stick during a race, it will go fast by itself.
column3: A fervent history otaku rebuild the the Trojan Horse. But since he was Japanese, he used bamboo instead of normal wood.
column4: The fervent soldiers used bamboo for vents to breathe while crammed inside the Trojan horse. —— Using punnery to avoid confusing with 烈 (#814).

story: In ancient Japan, the most grievous insult was to poke a rival's horse in the eye (consider how rare an expensive a steed was in those days). It was the final step in preparation for a duel to the death.
column3: This time the Trojans take one look at the Trojan horse and say 'ha! the eyes are wonky.' They throw insult after insult at it until a voice from within is heard saying 'we tried our best!'
column4: In Japan, is is considered insulting to look at someone from atop your horse. You have to step down and face people properly.

story: Every quarter moon, the cost of a trojan horse rises one quarter by inflation.
column3: Inflation is rampant: a month ago, I could buy a horse with this money, but now, only a quarter of a horse.
column4: Flesh+quarter=McDonald's quarter pounder. Due to inflation, McDonald's has had to start making quarter pounders out of horse meat.

story: Magic wand + first two strokes of pelt (皮) + diced + human legs. A wizard who turns people he doesn't like into newts with his magic wand goes for variety - he has always wanted a tiger pelt - but things go awry when the tiger promptly dices and eats him, leaving only a pair of legs. (a fitting end for a wicked wizard).
column3: Tigger, the tiger, (from Pooh stories) is happy to have found a magic wand. Using it he can bounce up to a the top of a cliff, seven times as high as some human legs could bounce. Tigger thinks "Its great to be a tiger!
column4: The 7 very smart magicians were standing on top of a cliff. The 7 very smart magicians wanted to create a tiger. The smart tiger ate 6 and a half magicians, leaving a pair of human legs as a snack for later. The smart tiger hang the pair of human legs on a tiny hook, so that no other predator could reach it. Moral of the story: tiger wins.

story: Captive men are thrown to the tigers. I think you can imagine something else is done to captive women...
column3: Tip: To avoid confusing keyword captive with 囚 (#1094) note that captive contains "ti" for tiger.
column4: The CAPTIVE men in the movie "Gladiator" were forced to fight TIGERS in a Gladiator Arena.

story: Ending up in a tiger's stomach is not good for your skin, as it's full of stomach acids.
column3: TIGGER only has visible SKIN on his STOMACH. The rest of his body is covered in orange fur.
column4: They say, "there's more than one way to skin a cat", but if you try to skin a tiger you might end up in its stomach.

story: In Japanese folklore there is no hell, but there is the void. There, a row of tigers waits in the blackness to devour those souls who have failed in their spiritual life.
column3: If you stand in a row of tigers (tiger - you - tiger) there will soon be a void (tiger - void - tiger).
column4: Warning to Sigfreid and Roy: Your entertainment contract will be null and void unless you can make all the tigers stand in a row.

story: This is a story about the end of the universe. The universe is turning into a featureless void. There's nothing we can do about it except for throw a fiesta and frolic a little bit before it's all over.
column3: Sigfreid and Roy's contract having been voided, the tiger is free to frolic about at the fiesta.
column4: The fiesta was void. you go on a frolic of your own.

story: The dentist couldn't help but feel uneasiness as he used his hand crank mouth tool on the tiger in his chair.
column3: My dear friend, a Bengali merchant, gave me a tiger as a birthday present. I felt uneasiness, knowing that I'll have to reject it. Or was it horror?
column4: A tiger overhead would give anyone a feeling of uneasiness.

story: Real meaning: "to ponder". You have to think with prudence (ponder carefully) about approaching a tiger, as is evident from 虎.
column3: You have to think with prudence about approaching a tiger. If not, it will eat your brains and heart. Thanks raulir.
column4: Dear Prudence, think carefully before you come out to play with the tiger waiting for you ...I know it looks beautiful.

story: A great Indian drama acted out every year is how a poor Bengali boy fended off the tigers from his pigs using only a sabre.
column3: A very sad drama about a little boy and his pigs. You see, a tiger showed up and ate up all his sows (his only source of income), and so the boy had to find the inner courage to go after the tiger with his dad's old rusty saber. Of course the boy dies, very tragic and all. It is a drama after all.
column4: If you thought "The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe" was full of drama then you'll love "The Tiger the Sow and the Sword".

story: Here we see the evil tyrannizing tiger. What is on his chest? A giant E, for EVIL, of course.
column3: The "E" shape actually means claws here, and the real etymology is a tiger tyrannizing other animals with its claws (the etymologies actually make sense once in a blue moon!). I think of the claws here as two hooks, representing the front paws. (stroke order of that part: 二＋last of 直).
column4: The way to tyrannize a tiger is to stroke it's fur the wrong way with a broom (you don't want to use a comb because he'll eat you.)

story: Bambi wanders into a cave and sees a side order of salad and 2 spoons...but what's the main course?
column3: Santa's reindeer, Rudolf, opens a nightclub in a cave. It's popular with all the deer and reindeer in the world. The cave speciality is a salad w/ dressing on the side. There is no other deer club that can compare. How many other deer nightclubs are there?
column4: Hint: This kanji is easier if you remember it as 庇 庇 (#2343) (shelter) with a few extra strokes, and visualize the extra strokes as a deer head trophy hanging in the wall. The vertical strokes are the horns, and the rightmost corner is the nose.

story: Many deer can be found in the grove at the foot of a mountain.
column3: The cave with the deer painting was found at the foot of a mountain hidden behind a grove. That's why it took centuries to discover.
column4: Deer are well known for frolicking in groves of trees. However, they are not well known for actually watching where the heck they are bounding about. Here we have a bunch of dead deer bodies that you find at the foot of a mountain. You are trying to figure why there are so many dead deer in one spot, and then you trace a line up the mountain - leaves and such are scattered all the way up...to a grove. Looks like they hopped through some leaves to their doom.

story: It is recommended that deers stick to eating flowers. If they try to eat birds, they may end up choking on them, like this one here. Note that the head (白) is gone and the visible part of the body which is normally written with a stroke of the head must by necessity be drawn with a stroke of the tail.
column3: Picture an ad in which Uncle Jimbo (of "South Park" fame) recommends the latest craze in deer hunting : a high tech slingshot! The ad begins with Bambi prancing around, smelling the flowers. Then, all of a sudden, Bambi is brutally murdered with the slingshot, put on the cooking fire, and the camera pans to Uncle Jimbo happily munching on crispy cooked Bambi! Note: the slingshot is strokes 11-12.
column4: For tonight's dinner (says the waiter) I would recommend the Deer. It is very special because it has been fed with flowers all it's life, has been killed with a slingshot (so there is no gun powder in it) and right now it is in the cooking fire. The meaning: recommend; mat; advise; encourage; offer.

story: In this kanji, "deer" replaces the "head" primitive from the "melancholy" kanji. Poor Ned is feeling melancholy so Uncle Jimbo (of South Park animated series) suggests a good deer huntin' trip to fix that and turn that melancholy into jubilation.
column3: Bambi was melancholy at the death of his mother, but is now in jubilation as he's made friends with thumper.
column4: Hamlet's melancholy turns at once to jubilation when he discovers that his head has transformed into that of a deer's. No more will human tragedy be his source of suffering!

story: The anthropologist made an exact deer painting from the cave ceiling on the ceiling of his house. Too bad they're both mediocre. All his wife could say was, "How...lovely."
column3: Lovely bambi.... pictographe : just take a look at those innocent open eyes (part 1 it's not more far fetched than seeing mediocre in it) with thin eyebrows what a lovely deer ...(part 2).
column4: The deer painting is so lovely, when compared to the two mediocre paintings on two sections of ceiling above.

story: Most don't know it, but bears have the ability to walk on fire. They're invincible creatures!
column3: Note : I don't know why James Heisig put "bear" ahead of "ability" (next frame), but I sugget to skip this, learn the next kanji ("ability") then go back here and use ability as a primitive.
column4: Bears have the ability to smell food cooking on a campfire from over 30ks away (true).

story: The amputee has no hands but only stumps of flesh beneath his elbows. To give him the ability to eat he has two spoons implanted in his arm stumps, one in each side.
column3: Kid from the Oracle's place in the Matrix (whose head is shining like the moon) is holding a a spoon and making it bend using his special ability. When Neo asks to learn this ability the child replies, " Remember the truth Neo, there is no spoon." Neo Proceeds to the kitchen pondering these words of wisdom. The Child smiles mischeviously and pulls a second spoon hidden up his sleeve in the crook of his elbow. "That's right Neo," the child laughs, "there is no spoon...there are two spoons!"
column4: I have the ability to use my elbow flesh to juggle two spoons.

story: This guy has an attitude problem – lots of ability, but his heart's not in it.
column3: Having a good attitude means believing in your heart that you have the ability to do anything - like memorizing more than 2000 kanji, for example.
column4: "It's an attitude problem I'm afraid," says the teacher at parents' evening. "He has the ABILITY to be a great but his HEART is not in it." "What should we do?" says the concerned parent. "Let's try this HEART, shall we?" says the coach, handing over a HEART that will give their child a better attitude.

story: If you draw the sign of the tiger on the ceiling of your house, you will sprout tiger's legs (animal legs) and be able to run and pounce like the big cats yourself.
column3: The sign of the tiger is that he's eaten all of the 黄 (#1887) salad in the house.
column4: I don't know why but when I read sign of the tiger I get the "eye of the tiger song" stuck in my head. So I see rocky training in his house. Hes hitting the ceiling (no punching bag) eating brussel sprouts to keep in good health and running with only the animal legs his dog.

story: That was some great performance! He caused the water to shoot up into the air and form the sign of the tiger in airborne droplets. You sure missed a great performance!
column3: At the end of Rocky's performances, set to the Eye of the Tiger of course, he was quite exhausted and dumped water all over himself to cool down.
column4: You watch a tiger do a flip into a small pool of water at a circus. "What a great performance! I need to get my shirt signed by that tiger," you say to your friend.

story: Bruce Lee is such a badass he climbed a sheer vertical cliff using only 2 hairpins.
column3: The kid said "I don't believe you! Dragons don't exist!" so we made a little surprise for him: we pinned a huge dragon (it was just a sign really) on a nearby cliff. "Whoaaa! Dragon!" the kid said. "But why won't it move?" "I tell you why, cause it's pinned there with two hairpins" I thought to myself.
column4: In Sign of the Dragon, Bruce Lee climbs a sheer vertical cliff using only 2 hairpins.

story: During the shooting of one of his first movies in China, Bruce Lee fell through the cheaply built movie set, and into a barrel of glue. As you can imagine, to put Bruce Lee in that position must have caused great embarass to the chinese producer. Note the hints in the story for the position of the primitives.
column3: Bruce Lee is embarrassed when he does a high kick and splits his pants. He has to glue them back together.
column4: The sign of the dragon falls off the cliff, to our great embarassment (see 辰 (#2164)) We should have glued it there!

story: Bruce Lee has magical abilities in his newest movie. He can conjure rain and earthquakes.
column3: A la Kung Fu Hustle, Bruce Lee descends from the storm and causes an earthquake by smashing the ground.
column4: Instant mythology: When heavy rains disturb a dragon hiding under the earth, an earthquake may result.

story: Bruce Lee shakes the confidence of his opponents by simply waving his fingers in front of them, they know that each of them is a deadly weapon in their own right. Hwwaaaa...
column3: Your fingers will be crushed if you shake hands with Bruce Lee.
column4: Bruce Lee shakes his finger at an opponent who thinks they're a match for him.

story: Any woman spending a night with the virile Bruce Lee is bound to end up with child.
column3: BRUCE LEE'S WOMAN was WITH CHILD and it really upset her stomach because little Brandon Lee was kicking ass from the inside.
column4: A woman who is with child can't be sacrificed to the dragon; virgins only need apply.

story: I love Bruce Lee dubbing. His lips move, but sometimes words don't come out of his mouth.
column3: Bruce Lee says "Read my lips...", but when I try to, his mouth isn't moving with the dialogue.
column4: As I approached her lips, I began to sense the sign of the dragon breath coming from her mouth, and I almost fainted.

story: The most unlikely persons in the world to take up agriculture must be Bender and Bruce Lee. An awkwared moment as they stare on the various farming utensils, hoe, plow. Both with straw hats on and blue overalls, and drawn in Groenigs irrevent style.
column3: Bruce Lee is tough. But so is agricultural work. If Bruce took it up, even he would hurt his back from all the bending.
column4: (combine Immacolata & mattimus:) The most unlikely duo to take up agriculture must be Bender and Bruce Lee. An awkward moment ensues as they stand in straw hats and overalls, staring at the various farm implements. But soon Bruce Lee is spinning Bender above his head while Bender's arms and legs perform all sorts of agricultural tasks like pruning, watering, sowing... 農業[のうぎょう]、農場[のうじょう].

story: The agriculture of Florida is concentrated on making concentrated orange juice. Just add water! Imagine a can of FCOJ, dumping it into a pitcher and adding water.
column3: Concentrated water is going to revolutionize the agriculture! Just add water... oh wait...
column4: History has shown that agriculture usually is concentrated around bodies of water.

story: After worshipping the golden calf, God sent the Jews on a long road through the wilderness.
column3: The problem with the "gold calf" primitive is that the first vertical stroke of "heavenly" is shorter than the second stroke. But as we know, "heavenly" clearly has the FIRST stroke longer, not the second. The primitives we really have here are "animal horns (first 3 strokes)" and "big/dog (last 3 strokes)." What are the BIGGEST ANIMAL HORNS that you can think of? For me its a MASTODON. STORY: In caveman times, you SENT OFF packages with the MASTODON express.
column4: I couldn't stand the horny St. Bernard any longer, so I escorted it to the road and gave it a send off to go get neutered.

story: The golden calf is sent to the gates of Hell for it's connection to false idols.
column3: There's a weird connection between worshipping the golden calf and visiting the gates of Hell.
column4: See my story for 2016. The CONNECTION between the GATES OF HELL and MASTODONS is that the GATES were made out of MASTODON horns (b/c they so big and old).

story: Evil blossoms from the mouths of those who worship the golden calf. (Playing it safe and avoiding the image of a flower completely).
column3: It's the circle of life. The woolly mammoth died, but the mammoth's body was able to provide nutrition to the new plants, blossoming out of the mouth of the dead mammoth.
column4: The cult of the Golden Calf blossomed throughout the land of Canaan by word of mouth.

story: A ghost, or oni, wandering slowly on its human legs, searching for brains to eat. What looks like an elbow here is actually a pictoral representation of the forked tail protruding out of its rear.
column3: Ghosts aren't very intelligent - they have but a drop of brains - so can't tell the difference between an elbow and a pair of human legs.
column4: Building on Matthew's excellent image, the drop can be the single horn sticking out of the oni's forehead.

story: The ugly oni can't get a date so he drinks sake by himself at the bar.
column3: Drink enough whisky and not even an oni looks ugly any more...
column4: Drinking too much whisky can make you as ugly as an oni.

story: When we die, our soul rises up in a ghostlike rising cloud of mist up to heaven (we hope) (Adapted from darg_sama,28-10-2005).
column3: When you die, your SOUL either goes to the RISING CLOUDS (heaven) or to the ONI (hell, the devil).
column4: There exists a soul within us all. When we die, our ghost rises up like a rising cloud out of our bodies.

story: The witch sold me some hemp that made me see ghosts don't do drugs.
column3: This modern version of the witch lives in some hippie community. She smokes a lot of hemp, and spends the day talking to ghosts, which not surprisingly appears only to her.
column4: The witch inhales her special HEMP herb which sends her into a trance state in which she can commune with ONI (or ghosts or demons whatever your fancy).

story: Ghosts have not yet left the world, they must still have a deep fascination with their past life on Earth.
column3: The only people who have a fascination with oni are those that have not yet met one. 魅力 (みりょく) : charm, fascination, glamour.
column4: Even in these modern times our fascination with ghosts has not yet ended.

story: This word somehow reminds me of a golem... an oni made from soil.
column3: 塊＝かたまり, from Katamari Damacy (塊魂). Imagine playing Katamari Damacy; on this level you start with a clod of dirt, and roll up demons into it.
column4: A golemn is a clod of soil that has been inhabited by a ghost.

story: The top 16 strokes are the chinese radical for "dragon". Joining up both meanings of the radical we can name the top part of this kanji "imperial dragon". Two-headed snakes do exist as biological curiosities, and they look a bit like a slingshot (with the heads splitting at a junction). Our imperial dragon here, the pet of a Chinese emperor, is a rare "three-headed slingshot-snake" kept in a vase and fed with meat. When the emperor attacked neighbours, his army wore the imperial dragon garment.
column3: Fuaburisu's story is incredibly good, but I made it a bit simpler: The imperial dragon is a rare "three-headed slingshot-snake", kept in a vase and fed with meat. It's very aggressive, so at feeding time you need to wear the special garment or it will attack you.
column4: You attack an old dragon 龍 and take his clothes. REF: 龍 (#2985).

story: To upbraid someone, you criticize them in a menacing way. In other words, you jaw at them with your MOUTH until both sides of their face turn RED (hence the double-red).
column3: Tip: Heisig later names 赫 "red + red" as 赫 (#2917). Story: "So the boss upbraided you, huh?". "Yep, his mouth was incandescent.
column4: A father upbraids his daughter for the red lipstick and little red dress. "You're not going out like that!"

story: The king says "Only We are allowed to partake of the flesh of the golden calf."
column3: The queen is not happy. "We (majestic plural) are not amused that the hunger for the flesh of the wooly mammoth has caused it's extinction. Poor Charles is particularly upset.
column4: (朕はおもしろうない。 We are not amused.) A jester does an act with meat in front of royalty and their pet, the Golden Calf. After a short while, the Calf looks at the royalty and then back at the jester : ' WE are not amused'.

story: (This is atmosphere as in ambiance, mood). Rain is only part of the atmosphere for a romantic porch date. Food, music, and candles are the rest.
column3: The rain isn't a bad thing--it provides a part of the romantic atmosphere.
column4: Rain plays a big part in the atmosphere of an event.

story: You've entered in a chinese shop where apparently the only item in sale is old, dusty, hardened bamboo (for construction for example). It looks like these items have been there forever. Asking the clerk if anything else is available, he doesn't understand and instead asks - "Two items? Three items?" (the kanji is a counter for items) - thinking you want to buy something.
column3: Dragon Quest - You find a hardened bamboo stick, perfect for a weapon, but you can't pick it up because your items are full.
column4: When I checked the items on the shopping list my wife gave me, I did a double take when i saw hardened bamboo. What the hell kind of item is that and what could she want with it?

story: Tempering should be done with the metal facing east. (If not, the metal may pick up the earth's magnetic field).
column3: In the East, especially Japan ...there are masters of tempering metal to great strength....on the Spring of Trivia show in Japan I saw how a Japanese sword ...actually split flying bullets...all because of special Eastern tempering techniques.
column4: The old sword smiths of the East were rightly famous. The secret of course was in how they tempered the metal.

story: You must abide by the revered rules of the road! No devil's brew and stay glued to your lane in the road!
column3: Even the most revered person must still abide by the rules of the road -- no exceptions are granted to anyone.
column4: The revered chieftain says to abide by his rules or hit the road!

story: Hey, screw you! Don't you look down on me! I have the ability to quit anytime I want!
column3: I won't QUIT studying until my EYES have the ABILITY to read kanji!
column4: (no important on yomi) When I gamble, my mind's eye has the ability to "know when to hold 'em, know when to fold 'em, know when to walk away." That last bit is the most important part for any successful gambler - knowing when to quit.

story: The game characters from Worms sleep in their barracks at night.
column3: Earthworm jim sleeps in a barracks because he is a soldier... apparently.
column4: drop your shovels and put them neatly on the hooks...it's time to head back to the barracks ...now move it!!!!!!!!

story: Moreover is a literary term to shelve what you had just been talking about, to come back to it later.
column3: Same as darg_sama. Play on words. I imagine visiting someone who has an impressive collection of medals and trophies (chess champion, for example). After spending an hour showing you all the trophies in the glass shelf, you think "Whew! It's over." ... but the person says "... and wait, there's "moreover" !", pointing at more trophies lined atop the glass shelf.
column4: Shelves are useful for storing things, and moreover they are responsible for splattering the brains of monarchs on tatami mats.

story: Let wooden goods = furniture. Then: Walking along the sea shore you see some washed-up furniture with water (waves) splashing against it. From a distance it looks like flowers are growing out the top, but as you get closer you see it is in fact seaweed.
column3: Take seaweed (water + flower) and hang it to dry in a tree to produce nori goods.
column4: Seaweed is the flowers of the water. To sell as goods it must first be dried out in trees.

story: The samurai sits on the altar and watches the slave rake rice all day.
column3: The samurai from 款 (#1178) maintains his good mood on his wedding day. He tells his slave that he can keep all rice (used for confetti) that he rakes up after the ceremony. Generous Man!!
column4: The samurai sits on the altar and watches the slave sieve rice through a sieve all day.

story: At the butcher's meeting, all the butcher's who have a heart disease attend the faith healing workshop.
column3: Note: meeting of butchers + heart are later combined into 愈 愈 (#2511). Story: For healing to take place, you must catch the sickness in the nick of time.
column4: (Think rpg!) We were in dire need of healing. Our party was fighting the cavemen, but we didn't fare too well. It was more like a butcher's meeting than a fight... just as they were about to pierce my heart, luckily a priest came along and used his healing spell 愈 (#2511).

story: If you find a jewel with the imperial seal on it, just let it be. You wouldn't want to be accused of stealing the royal family jewels.
column3: This aquatic mammal belongs to the emperor, so it's an imperial seal. Nobody is allowed to mess with it. They have to let it be wherever it wants to go. You can spot it from the other seals by the jewel studded collar around the neck of the imperial seal, but above all, remember to let it be.
column4: The imperial seal is a tool to be used with official scrolls that can be rolled up like towels. To help the ink dry, powdered sheafs are strewn across the scroll before rolling it up. When the imperial seal has been used, the document in question becomes as valuable as a jewel.

story: Right part: mortar bound up over oven fire, comprising boiling cauldron. Lagoon is a shallow pond, thus easily warmed by sun, large-scale equivalent of a boiling cauldron.
column3: In an effort to appease the hideous monster from the black lagoon, nearby villagers grind up tail feathers of local birds in a mortar and sprinkle the powder in the water, in a primitive magic ritual that they hope will appease the monster. Note the first drop before the tail feathers, as the hook stroke of tail feathers always requires a vertical-like stroke to attach to (compare with do, bird).
column4: The top right primitive appears in Remembering the Kanji, Volume 3 : mortar = back-to-back staples [6] ("The mortar referred to here is a stone or wooden basin used for grinding with a pestle."). Thus we have water . . . mortar . . . bound up . . . cooking fire.

story: How about a rusty cinnabar colored dilapidated boat, found abandoned somewhere. The smoke-stack and the keel have fallen off...
column3: Rusty old boat with the bottom and top missing.
column4: I always remember Cinnabar Island from Pokemon. Ash finds himself stranded on Cinnabar Island. He comes across an abandoned, rust-colored 舟 (#2012) on the beach which is clearly falling apart: the smoke-stacka nd the keel have fallen off! (thanks ergerg).

story: 77 cows behind a fence.
column3: Pictograph of a stanchion, which includes two vertical posts to restrain cows so they can be milked, with a horizontal stroke showing the number of cows per stanchion: one. A stanchion is a great symbol for the SIGN OF THE COW, since modern, domesticated cows are often stanchioned in barns.
column4: There's no sign of the cow. She saw those daggers – two of them – and ran off.

story: The sheep is ashamed of it's sheepish nature, and dons the sign of the cow as a disguise.
column3: The sheep was humiliated by being branded with the sign of the cow (which is a major insult to anyone, even sheep) and tries to cover it up with it's wool.
column4: They said the woolen sweater I donned made me look like a cow - like I was the very 丑 (#2197). I've never been so humiliated in my life. 恥ずかしい(P); 羞ずかしい 【はずかしい】 含羞 【がんしゅう】 (n) shyness.

story: rabbit ears.
column3: You know how missing childrens' pictures often appear on milk cartons? Well here we have a missing hare. His concerned family is having his picture printed on the backs of receipts and even on stamps. So far, however, there has been no SIGN OF THE HARE.
column4: Identical to egg, without the "yolks." Both hares and eggs are used for Spring celebrations because they are symbols of fertility.

story: The 巳nd!!! =D.
column3: From now on THE SIGN OF THE SNAKE means YOUR SUCCESS on staying until the end, no matter difficulties or headaches, enjoyed more creative dreams, became a close fan of Mr. T and being accomplished. The journey of mastering the kanji begins here. Add a +star to everybody here ^^.
column4: I love you you fucks.

story: I'm not going to use 'this here' as a primitive because it's too vague. But 'stop and sit down', usually tied to a tour guide explaining scenery works for me.//Stop and sit down to have a look at this here.
column3: A wildlife explorer, let's call him Steve Irwin, the sadly passed away wildlife expert, is tracking down an animal in a forest. He finds a footprint, and gets out a spoon to taste it. He scrapes the spoon over the floor and tries it. "Now, this here is a crocodile footprint" he announces.
column4: I'll stop and sit down on this here, whatever it is.

story: (From mantixen's) I'll stop and sit down on this here tree, which happens to be brushwood. Now I have to brush wood off my butt.
column3: I'll stop and sit down on this here tree, which happens to be brushwood.
column4: The Shiba-inu (柴犬) is looking for a tree to stop and sit down to poop but all he can find is some brushwood. Well, better than nothing!

story: Those two tourists from my tour group don't have a whit of common sense. They never stop and sit down when the tour guide tells them to!
column3: Two-year-olds don't have a whit of interest to stop and sit down. They'd likely explode with all that energy.
column4: This here? I don't give a whit about it..No, I don't give two whits about it!

story: Stop and sit down to listen to the tour guide's story. "These stones down there used to be a fort, but the enemy came and tore the place down. It has never been rebuild".
column3: (Grammar and story adjustment from astridtops story) You STOP AND SIT DOWN to listen to the tour guides story. "These STONES are remnants of what used to be a fort long ago, but the enemy came and tore the place down. It has never been rebuilt".
column4: This here rock right below us is all that remains of the mighty fort.

story: "Please stop and sit down to look to the painting up there", the tour guide says. "We don't know exactly who is on the painting, but from the shape of the hair and the distinctive beard, we think they meant to depict President Lincoln."
column3: A beard is hair that, instead of wanting it SHAPED like your friends, you grow it LONG so that you can STOP, SIT DOWN and scratch it thoughtful while considering this here and that there.
column4: If you remember hair on the head is 髪. But when my mother sees the state of my beard, she says, "What is this!?"

story: The villain from 離 (#1492) and 璃 (#2048). Now, hidden under an umbrella (don't want to be recognised), he is after any fowl for dinner. (fowl = birds such as chicken, duck and turkey).
column3: Being a Terrorist on the FBI most wanted list, Bin Laden must constantly move from place to place and is never quite certain where is going to sleep. Sometimes he can count on a loyal supporter to let him stay in a spare room, but when traveling to more remote parts of Arabia, he is sometimes forced to sleep under an umbrella with the fowl. (which consequently, makes him smell rather foul).
column4: Disguised under an umbrella, Sheik carefully tries to approach and capture a fowl nearby.

story: A flying fowl smashes into a tree and all the apples drop off. "Eureka!" shouts Newton, who happens to be watching.
column3: A tree is struck by a flying fowl and all it's apples fall to the ground. "Eureka!" shouts Newton, who happens to be watching. (mod of Katsuo).
column4: Michael Jackson stands under an umbrella in case an apple falls way off the tree like he did.

story: Tom Cruise - American with sunglasses (thanks synewave). I can't sympathize with Tom Cruise's state of mind regarding scientology.
column3: Have you ever seen the really poor looking children on the corner block with a shoe shine stand? I can't help but to sympathize with them and give them some extra money. It eases my state of mind.
column4: Tom Cruise - American with sunglasses (thanks synewave). Data can't sympathize with Tom Cruise's regarding scientology because it's illogical.

story: Tom Cruise's shoes caught on fire, because he was using phosphorous to shine them.
column3: The shoeshiner always starts by cleaning the shoes first with phosphorus. This is a bit risky, though, and he sets himself on fire (picture him running around in flames).
column4: A phosphorus fire engulfs Tom Cruise during a bizarre scientology rite.

story: As a scientologist, A DEER to TOM CRUISE, is not just a deer. It is actually a descendent of a camelopard that was sent by extraterrestrials.
column3: You saw a camelopard!? Bullshit! Next your going to tell me that you saw a deer getting a shoeshine. (Actually I saw a camelopard getting a shoeshine, but now that you mention it, his body did look like a deer...)
column4: Soaking wet with rain, Tom cruise comes riding in on a giraffe/camelopard running along with a team of deer during the pivotal scene in the very serious film, "The last samurai".

story: Little known fact: Tom Cruise turns into a merman at night, scaled like a fish and everything. Weird.
column3: A scaled fish goes to a shoeshine place to get his scales shined up to impress the lady fish. (Shoeshines will shine up any type of scaled creature, including but not limited to fish and dragons).
column4: Tom Cruise scaled down his public display of affection after his appearance on Oprah looked a bit fishy.

story: Can't work with the Heisig primitive of Dachshund, as the all encompassing big eel is obviously the mythical Norse Midgard Snake.
column3: The DACHSHUND is so long he can stretch himself around the circumference of the earth, encompassing the whole globe. (It might help to think of the dachshund as the slinky dog from Toy Story.)
column4: According to Jim Breen (and cross-checked in Nelson's Modern Dict) the most "common" usage of this kanji is 奄々、エンエン, meaning breathing, covering or obstructing. Or this idiom: "気息奄奄 【きそくえんえん】 gasping for breath; on the brink of death; more dead than alive." I've chosen to call this "obstructed breath." (although I like astridtops big eel as a primitive) SO The big eel wrapped my neck and obstructed my breath - like that scene in the Princess Bride =).

story: The hermit's home, his hermitage, is a simple CAVE where he lives with his pet DACHSHUND.
column3: At the famous Hermitage museum in St. Petersburg, they have a cave below the museum with a big sculpture of the Midgard Snake.
column4: Are you looking for hermitage? Look no further! This encompassing, all-inclusive cave is all you need.

story: When your fingers completely cover something, it is shrouded from view.
column3: Apparently there is a cult worshipping the Midgard Snake, which is shrouded in mystery. Members have to cut off one of their fingers to join up.
column4: I put a huge pet sweater over my pet dachshund so that it was completely shrouded. I thought it was cute, but my dachshund wasn't so happy about it - he bit my finger!

story: In my sorry state of mind, I wanted to make amends for cheating on my wife with a legal prostitute.
column3: Data accidentally bumps into a legal prostitute, causing her to fall on her ass. To make amends, he invites her to a romantic dinner.
column4: I used to beat up random licenced walkers of the street, but I've had some nagging guilt at the back of my state of mind for months now. So I've decided to make amends by throwing small change at them while driving down the road.

story: This should be obvious, owners of prize race horse (STEEDS) are paid to have their STEED mate with another (hopefully to produce a prize winning foal). Yep, the STEEDS are glorified HORSE HOOKERS.
column3: Trojan horse, legal prostitute: The guy told the legal prostitute that he is like a steed in the bed and that she should do it for free. However, afterward - being severely disappointed- she considered him more like a Trojan horse.
column4: The Trojan horse approached a legal prostitute. "What a fine steed!", she exclaimed. "What I would not give to ride that animal!" The men inside were thinking about what they would not give to ride that lady. At the end of the evening, all were satisfied and the lady had made a year's wages in a day.

story: There are legal prostitutes waiting on top of a steep mountain. Not only is the mountain steep, but so are the cost of the legal prostitutes.
column3: Steep prices for streetwalkers up a mountain.
column4: On the mountain, the legal prostitutes are not cheap. In fact, one could say their prices are.. steep! Hahaha!!! haha.. ha..

story: I like mantixen's thinking. As long as its still standing up, the streetwalker still needs to complete her job!
column3: The streetwalker has to make something stand up in order to complete a job.
column4: The legal prostitute stands up and leaves when she's completed her job.

story: Mr. Rhinoceros doesn't see well, so to prevent an unwanted attack, I don't surprise him. I always approach waving a flag attached to my walking stick. I've drawn a picture of the I-ching and an attractive cow on the flag, so Mr. Rhinoceros will stay calm when he sees it.
column3: I hang a flag imprinted with the picture of a rhinoceros on the grill of my car to scare cows.
column4: The power of Eastern philosophy: A rhinoceros may seem like a dangerous, intimidating animal at first ... approach it with a flag on a stick painted with a calming yin-yang symbol, however, and it becomes as docile as a domestic cow.

story: What's a lunar month? The amount of time it takes a white to read just ten pages of the I Ching. Reviewing the Kanji notwithstanding.
column3: To keep track of time on a desert island Tom Hanks puts a needle into the white part of his yin yang symbol every time a lunar month passes.
column4: The I-Ching prophesy has spoken: "The next lunar month, white needles will bring you good luck."

story: PRIMITIVE: Four crotches = orgy. The rice-field footpaths were where we used to have orgies back in the day.
column3: In the rice-field footpath I found a condom (used to protect you from the one in four crotches that shouldn't be done ヌde) of someone who couldn't afford a hotel.
column4: The rice-field footpaths that run through the rice fields look like embroidery stitching from afar.

story: (Note: This kanji actually means compose/spell.) Spiderman, spell "crotch"! "Uhm.. ok.. krotch..." "Wrong!" "krotsch?" "No!" "crotsch?" "No!" "crotch?" "There you go, even though you needed 4 tries.."
column3: "Mend" is a terrible keyword for this one (mainly because it conflicts with "mending" and also because the majority of words that use this Kanji have to do with book binding, which I suggest as a replacement). Story: So much had already been written about the famous "Spiderman's orgy with the four crotches" that the publishing company had to use extra strong book binding to hold Volume I together!
column4: SPIDEY has to mend his own costume, so he used the CROSS-STITCHING his aunt showed him.

story: "Without the right metal, that there suit of armor won't mount to more than a hill 'o beans!" said the dwarven smith as I embarked on my quest - with my aluminum-foil hat and shield.
column3: A suit of armor crafted from metal so strong that it could withstand the weight of a mountain of beans.
column4: This metal suit of armor is making it hard to climb this hill of beans.

story: After eating a mountain of beans, I was able to triumph in the wind contest.
column3: With the wind blowing, it was a triumph for Jack to climb the giant beanstalk.
column4: TRIUMPH the insult comic dog eats a HILL OF BEANS at the Westminster Dog Show and then breaks WIND in front of all the other show dogs.

story: After planting the saplings, the villagers open their mouth and quaff large quantities of sake!
column3: The roots of a sapling are like a mouth, quaffing water and nutrients - so as to grow big and no longer be just a drop. Note that quaffing component 口 is positioned where it should be (in roots below sapling).
column4: The ugly old witch quaffs potions of beauty down her cackling mouth.

story: You can tell green onions from leeks because leeks are the ones that flower.
column3: For the green onion primitive, I use a pun: Green UN ONE. Leeks are milder than green onions, they're more like the flowers of the scallion family.
column4: Look up LEEK in Wikipedia, you can see the round FLOWER atop the GREEN ONION. (Thanks chibimizuno for the GREEN ONION pun: Green UN ONE).

story: I never play the lottery. I'd rather be whacked by bamboo staffs as I pass down an assembly line than do that. Of course, when a buddy wins, I'll go to the fiesta and enjoy the special salsa packed with green onions, but I will never play the lottery myself.
column3: (based on mantixen's) If I won the lottery, I wouldn't even need to go speed dating (a fiesta to form couples) to find a woman, even if I had onionbreath they'd be flocking in my direction. On second thoughts.. I'd better buy a bamboo cane to keep the ugly ones away.
column4: Better remembered as raffle. Picture a dating event (fiesta to form couples) where a raffle/lottery is held for a date with the most attractive person of each gender. Everybody pulls from a pot, if you get bamboo you lose, green onions you win!

story: Someone stole the bamboo from the previous lottery--but I'm sure their state of mind is very penitential.
column3: Indiana Jones: "The penitent man shall pass. The penitent man shall pass." Indy's state of mind is screaming at him that something is wrong. This assembly line of death is giving all kinds of hints that something is wrong. "Oh hey, green onions!" Indy ducks down to grab them and the trap misses him completely... fiestas ensue...
column4: (Accepting of Penitence, which is feeling or showing regret for something you have done because you feel it was wrong) A factory owner has a regret full STATE OF MIND for how he abused his ASSEMBLY LINE workers all those years ago. He goes to a priest cause he is now penitential. The priest says "You have to give a big Fiesta Party with free Green onion soup for everyone!"

story: The 2 mountain goats have to bind up all the hay then the farmer might give them their horns back.
column3: This one is easy if you know the old form of grass (艸); To make hay, get the old grass, bind up the clumps individually, and then stack them vertically.
column4: I know that 屮 is an old grass radical but here I can't help seeing two pitchforks 屮 hanging up the hay to dry (on hayracks or drying hurdles 勹).

story: The chick got lost in the hay. Now mama turkey is throwing the stuff all over looking for her chick.
column3: A young chick milling about in the hay looks up and sees a huge turkey looking down on it. Turkey leans down and says: "Boy, you got no hope of leavin this place alive..."
column4: HAY... TURKEY... leave us chicks alone! 雛豆　ひよこまめ　chick pea.

story: If you suddenly open the barn doors, the rats will scurry away, RUNNING quickly over the HAY scattered across the floor.
column3: Imagine a cartoon character hiding in a haystack, and then trying to run - the result is a haystack scurrying across the field.
column4: 帰趨 【きすう】 (n,vs) tendency; trend; drift 趨向 【すうこう】 (n,vs) tendency; trend; current 趨勢 【すうせい】 (n) tendency; trend.

story: A chihuahua with one human leg is understandably not as fast as other chihuahuas.
column3: That one-human-legged chihuahua that appeared before the capital in 就 (#1969) is understandably traumatized by the abuse he suffered at the hands of the scientists.
column4: Maybe it's better to imagine this primitive as a CHIHUAHUA that's humping a HUMAN LEG. It's an easier visual image. It's UNDERSTANDABLY that when a CHIHUAHUA is humping your HUMAN LEG, you'd want to shake the thing off.

story: Subject to even more cruel experiments in the name of biological science, the one-human-legged chihuahua is injected with chemicals that alters his shape grotesquely, and makes him as immense as a cliff (see how he's tall enough, standing right beneath it, to reach the top?)
column3: Ooh, what's that immense shape dancing of the face of that cliff? Oh, don't worry, it's just that little chihuahua with a human leg escaped from the lab, playing around in front of the flashlight.
column4: When I think of immense I think of something like the Grand Canyon, with its cliffs that, understandably, before science we could not understand how they were shaped.

story: A certain drunken mouth is on the floor at the fiesta moaning "Aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa".
column3: This is my spear. There are many like it, but this one, a certain one, is mine. It's the one I use for eating (mouth) and for slashing (slash). Used in range/area/level: 域 -- a certain earth is an area, range, or level.
column4: A is an indefinate article alright. At this fiesta, the band wern't the genuine article either. So the patrons threw them off the stage ("Aaaaaa!") and pressed their mouthes against the floor. "Sing no more you talentless hacks!!'

story: A real rabbit always leaves DROPs of poo pellets behind, and his ears are no longer bound up (compere 免 (#2126)), so they flap above like helicopter blades (pictograph), and his MOUTH still is wide-open with the STAFF-like tongue, and his powerful LEGS still look like a human's.
column3: Super Rabbit: This rabbit has helicopter ears and drops pellets on his enemies while flying. Because he's super rabbit, he gets his own kanji. Unlike that other loser who is always making excuses. 免 (#2126) He can settle for a primitive.
column4: Also written 兔, which differs from 免 by the combining of the fifth and seventh strokes (written bound, mouth, legs, dot). According to kakijun.main.jp, the center of 兎 is written open mouth+stick+closing stroke of mouth. The binding day schedule of the excuse-making Alice rabbit (晩) is gone, and only ears, mouth, (powerful, almost human-like) legs and drop-tail remain. In 兔 there's a foot in the mouth and in 兎 an ear tip. Strange rabbitses.

story: This is the kanji for the classical form of "is". I think Heisig's keyword "est" is the old english or latin word for "is". The Scorpion this est!
column3: "Est" is the latin third person singular of the verb "esse" (to be) in Latin. So, this word has been chosen to point out that this character is found chiefly in Classical Japanese (also names). I imagine an incredibly haughty Latin Scorpion, looking down at his vast estate and saying "Mihi est". This literally mean "It is to me" and means "It's mine" ... this is gramatically similar to how Japanese express possession too, incidentally.
column4: C'est un scorpion.

story: The "comma-design" referred to: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tomoe.
column3: This is a comma-design outlaid in mosaic on the floor.
column4: 巴紋, 卍巴と, 三つ巴, 巴, 巴瓦, 巴里, 巴旦杏, 巴人, 巴 (#2237) ハ, ともえ, (ともゑ) ... Parts: 色-勹 ... Story:Unbound Colors explode into a giant Comma-Design. The Japanese version of the Yin-Yang symbol, has three elements not two, to show that Shinto, Buddhism, and Confucianism have mixed to make Japan.

story: The zoo is full of critters.
column3: Yup, we counted lots of critters in the zoo.
column4: This evolved from "foot/leg" in Chinese, but this is a now a rare meaning in Japanese. It became confused with 匹 both in meaning and reading and now both kanji are used as counters for small animals. This is not a joyo kanji but it is a jinmeiyo kanji used for names. It is radical 103 with the meaning "bolt of cloth" and is a counter for rolls of cloth. If the first stroke is just a horizontal line, it is the primitive mended: it has to be mended or amended to become either 疋 (zoo) or 正 (correct).

story: This is a violet cabbage, hanging from a nail on the kitchen wall.
column3: Violets are blue, cabbages are green. Flowers on a spike are a sight rarely seen.
column4: If you put cabbage underneath the floor, violets are the flowers that will grow up through the cracks.

story: Spending the day with your eye on your crotch as you meditate on the mandala.
column3: The mandala is a graphic representation of the universe: the sun representing the cosmos, the eye represents the human observer, and the crotch represents animal instincts. (Thanks for original story by Codexus.)
column4: Citing my story for 慢 (#829): "It's clearly an Indian mandala, with the Buddha sitting cross-legged, eyes closed as in trance, beneath the sun, a symbol of the enlightenment which one can reach by practicing His teachings."

story: Think of manga where what a person says is quoted in a rising cloud.
column3: The messages of the Indian Chief were quoted in rising clouds.
column4: Quoteation marks are two elbow shaped markers found on either side of a sentence.

story: "Thou shalt not kill", 'cause the graveyard is full. There's no room left to dispose of the evidence!
column3: 莫大莫 (#2242)バク Graveyard Primitive RTK＃228.9 ... Parts:艹, 日, 大 ... Note: Heisig got this backwards. It is shalt not. But it is an unused Kanji anyway, so..It means the same thing as 勿勿 (#1128). ... Story: Thou Shalt not argue with RTK keywords, or angry mobs will put you in Graveyards ... 熟語:莫逆, 落莫, ... cf: 慕う, 幕府, 漢字.
column4: Thou shalt not plant any BIG-SUN-FLOWERS in the GRAVEYARD.

story: If you lose your comb, there is no point just hoping it will turn up. You must carefully comb the whole house looking for it, and then you will find it.
column3: This boring guy from the comb factory is telling me about combs. And then there are the plastic models, blah blah blah. And then there are the blah blah blah. And then and then and then. When's he gonna shut up?
column4: First it was a mask, and then it became a comb.

story: Mr. T was selected to head up the committee studying the Yamato period.
column3: This kanji was originally used as the Chinese word for Japan, and its etymological meaning is that of a "supplicating people". In the 8th century the use of this kanji to describe Japan (read as "Wa" or "Yamato") was changed to the kanji for 和 (#963), which was popular because the Japanese liked to believe that their society was based on harmony (not on being submissive and dominable as this kanji suggests). Story: Dad joined the Yamato committee to foster international cooperation.
column4: There's always a person named Yamato on every committee. And I always hate them.

story: Mr T approaches the knights and stabs his scissors into the table they're seated at. "I pity the fool who questions my chivalry!"
column3: Mr. T believes in chivalry - so whenever he plays a game of rock, paper, scissors, he always throws scissors to let the other person win. Note that this has nothing to do with women at all (hence the absence of women in this kanji) - just with everybody being weaker than Mr T.
column4: Chivalry demands equal weapons in a duel. So if a person challenges you with scissors, you'll have to duel him with your own pair.

story: Mr. T invented the book because he was fed up with scrolls.
column3: Mr T has been chasing some fools for a while, but they keep leaving riddle scrolls behind, making Mr T use his noggin to try and catch them. "Mr T is fed up with these fool games!"
column4: Mr T is fed up because the scroll he is trying to read keeps scrolling up just as he starts.

story: Mr. T is known to be particularly abrupt with anybody that has a big ego.
column3: Mr. T's big ego was shattered when his mom abruptly opened the door and caught him in the middle of a hand fiesta. "I pity da foo who don't lock the door!"
column4: A person with a big ego is not afraid to treat others abruptly.

story: Not so long ago, if Mr T was working in a field, he would have been a slave.
column3: The first television show that Mr T ever worked on was a slavery period drama. Operating on the assumption that all black people look alike, the director decided to save on his budget by just hiring one black person. In each scene requiring slaves in the background to work a field, he would put Mr T in the rice paddy in the background. Then when they changed the scene, he would simply put Mr T there too - no changing clothes, no CG - just the same dude in the background of EVERY scene.
column4: A person in a field is working a field.

story: Remember that sordid 件 (#959) when Mr. T was caught having relations with a cow? Well, some months later the heifer drops off the child at T's place. Does Mr. T share responsibility for his animal offspring?
column3: Quite frankly, more than any person's child, I have always found animal offsprings (like puppies (仔犬/こいぬ）, and kittens (仔猫/こねこ)） far, far, faaar cuter.
column4: Mr T, the vet, is helping the mare give birth. Except, animal offspring doesn't but out. A child does instead! Ewww, someone in the villiage has been behaving badly.

story: Mr. T uses a baseball bat for hitting foes. "I pity the foe! I mean fool!"
column3: Mr. T can handle nine foes all by himself!
column4: In this kanji we see Mr. T surrounded by nine foes. Of course he dispatches them quickly. Mr. T's foes need to come at him in greater numbers than nine if they expect to stand a chance against him. Fools.

story: Mr. T looks after the kids by making sure they get enough カロ ries.
column3: Mr T has been charged to look after the kids. He will use his muscle to protect them and make sure their mouths are fed.
column4: If you add another person to your family, you will have someone else to look after.

story: Faith, lovedoll: Mr T, having faith in the word of God, prayed really hard for the girlfriend he could never get in the regular way. God listened, but sent him a lovedoll instead. Being severely disappointed, mr T decided to prostitute her and make a profit instead.
column3: Mr. T is able to make a profit off of varoius things: merchandise, slogans, muscles, etc. "I pity the foo who can't make a profit", Mr. T says to his love doll.
column4: Money corrupts, and Mr T is no exception. In his search to make a profit, he has turned into a gangsta doing various dastardly deeds. Like running drugs, pimping hos and stealing cars. "Why you gotta hit me Big T?" "Coz I'm making a profit, fool!"

story: Mr T, angel: Believe it or not, but mr T is actually an angel. He emigrated from heavens to right the wrongs on planet earth.
column3: When people emigrate, they believe they are going to some better place, a place which to them, is heaven-high.
column4: Back in the day, any person who was an emigrant to the U.S. considered the Statue of Liberty an angel.

story: "Oy, mate", the carpenter calls out to Mr. T, "where did you leave my tools, mate?" Mr. T just hates it when people call him mate. It inspires him to misuse their tools.
column3: A mate is a person who lends you a tool when you need. (Just remember to return it if you want him to stay your mate.)
column4: Mates are a kind of condom that Mr T puts on his tool.

story: Mr. T is a man of integrity. Every time he opens his mouth, integrity just seems to stream out.
column3: Mr T's structural integrity has been compromised. Blood and guts is flowing from his mouth.
column4: 侃侃諤諤; 侃々諤々; 【かんかんがくがく】: arguing (heatedly) what one believes in; Mr. T defends his believes with a stream of arguments coming out of his mouth. He could use violence to get what he wants, but he shows integrity and just talks.

story: At a memorial service for Mr. T, everyone is thinking "I pity that foo".
column3: A memorial service is something that makes you think about a person who has died.
column4: At a memorial service, Mr. T tones down his usual "I pity da foo" by saying "I think I pity da foo". （人）を 偲ぶ (しのぶ): honor the memory of (人) (人）を 偲ぶ便 (よすが): memento to remember someone by 偲ぶ音楽 (しのぶおんがく): memorial concert, memorial music performance 故人を偲ぶ (こじんをしのぶ): to think of the dead 昔を偲ばせる品 (むかしをしのばせるしな): things reminiscent of bygone days.

story: Mr. T is exhausted! As is the woman who just gave him shakuhachi.
column3: You see person holding the exhaust pipe which has just dropped off their new car, and say, "You should return that and get your money back!". "Trouble is," they reply, "I bought it as is".
column4: Mr T buys a used car as is and gets a great deal. As soon as he gets it off the lot, though, the exhaust freezes and falls off. He stops the car and yells out the window - "Hey, fool, you better give me a refund!" "No, " says the salesman, "you bought that as is!". Mr T calmly steps out of the car, picks up the exhaust, walks over to the salesman, and wraps the exhaust pipe around his neck (causing his neck to freeze from the cold). I pity the fool that runs an as is scam.

story: Once again, Mr. T ventured out into the remote area to visit his old taskmaster (see 悠 (#958)). However, the old taskmaster has become very weak. His flesh looks like dried meat and his heart almost stopped (no heart). He stayed a whole month to take care about his former teacher.
column3: 束脩 脩 (#2130) シュウ, おさむ ... Parts: 修-彡, 月 (cf:悠悠 (#958), 修修 (#1722), 篠篠 (#2639) ... Note: Usually the male name おさむ ... Story: Historically the offering of dried meat (束脩) given by an apprentice to a master when coming for training. So to get 修修 (#1722), an apprentice must bring meat. Then over time that meat is Shaped into Discipline.
column4: Mr. T doesn't like dried meat. He's been known to take a walking stick to the taskmaster trying to hand him a piece of meat that had been dried out. No, Mr. T doesn't like dried meat a-t a-l-l!

story: "My son", sniffs Mr. T, "I'm so glad that you are now a college graduate" he said.
column3: Important note: Instead of the keyword "my son," the keyword "good for nothing son" may be more appropriate. This word is one of the examples of depreciating titles for family members. This word is used to refer to your son when you especially want to lower his status. So, keep that in mind when deciding on a story or when making your own. I suggest CountPacula's story, since it involves that "good for nothing son" meaning a little more.
column4: I won't consider that person to be my son until he actually manages to show he's capable of something and graduates!

story: Note that the meaning of this (rare) kanji is "make (something) / do (something)", not "get by with". Story: Mr. T doesn't rely on happenstance, he makes things do what he wants. Edit: In fact three Japanese kanji dictionaries I checked all list 做 as an alternative to 作 作 (#1224), so "make (alt)" might be the best keyword. Story: Mr. T by happenstance found an alternative way to make things. (See also bennyb & faneca's notes).
column3: (food for thought) I know this is RTK3 and all, but this kanji seems almost completely useless. The two most common phrases it's included in are 言い做す to speak as though something were actually the case and 見なす to regard (as equivalent). Both of which USUALLY just write なすin kana, and neither of which have anything to do with the meaning. In fact I can't find any trace of Katsuo's suggestion of this meaning. Anyone care to enlighten me? Perhaps this one's worth skipping.
column4: @bennyb: As much as I usually love katsuo's contributions, I agree with you this time. For the sense you mention, I guess "figuratively" would be a better keyword. See [1]: 「見做す」"to regard [figuratively] as", 「思い做しか」"imagination (to think [figuratively])", etc. On the other hand, look at the Chinese compounds at [2]: it clearly means "make"/"do" (做爱 to make love, 做梦 to dream). [1] [ http://tangorin.com/general/做 ] [2] [ http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/做 ].

story: (Note that per Heisig, this doesn't mean 'able to cut'; it means mentally sharp, adept, or 'on your toes'!) During the Ice Age, cavemen had to be especially careful around the woolly mammoth, because they were more mentally sharp than they looked. If the cavemen weren't careful, they could end up impaled on the mammoths' tusks!
column3: A sharp tusk pointing out of the ice. Probably belongs to a mammoth.
column4: The ice-age mammoth was very sharp and knew how to make use of its tusks.

story: You don't want the lettuce to wilt, do you? So, you put ice around the circumference of the serving tray, and then the lettuce on top of that, so it cannot wilt.
column3: Plants wilt, wither and die when ice envelopes the circumference of their roots.
column4: If ice forms around the circumference of a plant, how can it wilt?

story: On their walk to the Promised Land (陸 (#1513)), our brave rice-seedlings are faced with an unforeseen obstacle: An ice glacier the size of a rain puddle. Will they be able to pull through?
column3: In a very harsh turn of the weather, the water of the rice fields has turned to ice! The farmers are strutting around the little rice seedlings anxiously on their walking legs, hoping that the plants will pull through and survive!
column4: [dramatic music] The ice comes, and we wonder if the little rice seedlings will pull through, or their tiny little walking legs will freeze first...

story: Much more stately than that soil podium, this is made of ice. You can still see the dude standing behind it in his top hat, and he still spouts pretty much nonsense as many times as he can, but you have to admit his showy altar is quite stately.
column3: This stately home in Brittain has been used for winter weddings many times. A reverend in a top hat stands behind the altar in the home's chapel, which is adorned with ice sculptures. Very romantic.
column4: Abe Lincoln visited the state of Minnesota in January 1863, and decided to give his speech from an ice altar at an unheated but stately church instead of a soil podium. It was a stately speech in the coldest state of the Union.

story: I'm drying myself at the 露天風呂 (outdoor hot spring) when a sudden gust of wind catches my towel and blows it into the air. I chase after it and onlookers remark, "Look, he's flying a kite!"
column3: If the wind is strong enough, even a towel makes a good kite.
column4: The first kites were towels blowing in the wind.

story: A lull in a storm occurs when the wind stops.
column3: There is a lull when the wind stops.
column4: 夕凪 , 朝凪, 凪 (#2266) 国字, (なぐ), なぎ ... Parts:几, 止 ... Story:Nowadays, internet trolls do what Zen masters used to: ask meaningless question for the reaction it causes. For the Lulz, I posted that people could be free if they could make a footprint in the wind. ... 熟語: ... cf:.

story: The earlybirds always get all the best food at the buffets, and all the latecomers get are just leftover bones, you can almost see the wind and tumbleweeds rolling over it.
column3: You can either fly like the wind and be an earlybird at the buffet or come late and be left with only the bones.
column4: The earlybird is just about to catch the worm when it is caught by a gust of wind and slams into the ground and dies. The worm now eats the earlybird instead, just leaving a pile of bones. (At the end of this sequence, imagine the earlybird's bones being blown away by the wind.)

story: Souring in the winds there is only one bird left. The phoenix. It scorched the other birds, never to return...
column3: (The extra stroke combines with white in the bird component to make a hundred-year-old bird) The Phoenix -- the bird made famous in myth, that after it reaches hundreds of years of age, is reborn and rises again on the wind.
column4: The famed Ho-oh rides the wind above all other birds. 鳳 appears to refer to the male bird, while 凰 refers to the female, presumably one whose beauty is coveted by emperors. (The generic word Ho-oh is the compound 鳳凰. Note that technically this is not the Phoenix but shares some similarities.)

story: threat: To keep the ballot box safe from threats, the poll watchers were given swords.
column3: Try to show up at the BALLOT with a SABER. You'll be arrested as a MENACE you are!
column4: 剽窃【ひょうせつ】: Plagarism: Producing the ballots in saber-form was my idea for the annual renaissance faire meeting! Plagarism!

story: Because the police had confiscated the swords (though they got a receipt in return) from the group of men protecting the gold transport, bandits attacked them with sabers and slaughtered every last one of them.
column3: The ransom note explained that if the gold was not received by the following morning, the victim would be slaughtered with a saber.
column4: A guy brought a receipt and a sword to Wal-Mart customer service asking for a refund in gold, but when they didn't give it to him, he pulled out another saber and slaughtered all the employees.

story: The younger brother wants to look cool and shaves himself with a saber instead of a razor.
column3: My little brother kept asking me to teach him to shave. I got a little tired of his requests so I told him to try it himself using a sabre. Long story short, he won't be annoying me anymore.
column4: Your younger brother wants to shave too, so he takes his toy saber since you won't give him a razor.

story: The poor chihuahua who had fallen down a cliff was totally despondent about his position. He saw the sun and the moon pass by, but expected no rescue any more.
column3: While you may know the story of Hachikou, this is about a chihuahua that lost its master. They used to play a game - Sun and Moon - where the master would stand at the top of a cliff and wave his hands as if to resemble sunrays, and the dog would lie on the ground in a crescent shape - then they would switch. But one day the master fell! The dog, for years after, would go to the spot where he fell at sun and moon rise and look despondent. Imagine the despondent puppydog eyes.
column4: Under a cliff, the sun beating on its flesh, our chihuahua is despondent realizing there's no Taco Bell around here.

story: Mr T is sent on a mission to find a wild goose that swallowed some important, top-secret chemicals (they were in a baggie, so he has to find it before it dissolves!). After searching for clues and tracks, he finds it - and backs it up against a cliff. In a heroic move, Mr T jumps off the cliff, grabs the wild goose, and lands on the ground on his back, protecting the volatile wild goose. He then looks at it - wait - this isn't the wild goose, this is a mere turkey! Sent on a wild goose chase!
column3: I've been sent to chase the wild goose! I'm here at the top of the cliff, and I can hear Mr. T and that tricky turkey down there sniggering about sending me on a search for the wild goose.
column4: MR.T wanted to catch a wild goose for dinner but all he found was a TURKEY that fell off a CLIFF.

story: The police hoped to catch the crooks making counterfeit money, but it all turned out to be a wild goose chase.
column3: You catch a wild goose that lays money (shells) instead of eggs. Unfortunately the bank declares it counterfeit.
column4: Some criminal is trying t0o make counterfeit １０００円 notes but the dumb shit puts a goose picture on the back instead of a 鶴.

story: What happened to the kitchen? It was here a second ago... Well, it fell off the cliff. See the table down there below the edge of the cliff? Maybe we can glue it back together. Of course, first we've got to retrieve the kitchen from the base of the cliff.
column3: We started to 闘 (#1757) in the kitchen, but we kept on moving about and, before I knew it, she had me cornered atop the cliffface.
column4: I took the natto (bean glue) out of the kitchen and threw it off a cliff like any rational person would.

story: So, you found a dead person abandoned at the bottom of the cliff? You think I might be involved? What are you trying to insinuate?!
column3: That is it. I have had enough of your insinuations. Off the CLIFF you go. Bye Bye.
column4: Are you trying to insinuate that Mr. T pushed someone off a cliff?

story: Boy scouts nowadays blow sparks out of their mouth to start a fire. Sure beats rubbing two sticks together .
column3: Good scouts 消 (#144) candles with their mouth, not with water. Otherwise the smoke might tell the enemy where they are.
column4: The scout reports with his mouth what he saw by candle.

story: Each time I see this kanji I reprehend the person primitive for knocking the each primitive out of shape.
column3: You only reprehend him because he is reprehensible! He walks around kicking people, like he wants to dispose of them. And that's all on top of having a big mouth. Reprehensible! Of course you must be the one to reprehend him.
column4: You reprehend the person butting in and messing you up each time you try to write a kanji.

story: If someone's whispering you'd need three ears close to his mouth to be able to hear it.
column3: It's funny how if I just talk, no one listens, but if I whisper, many ears are eager to hear what's coming from my mouth.
column4: People are curious beasts. If you whisper something out of your mouth, there will be many ears listening. Or alternatively, think in terms of power levels: In kanjis, the same element can appear in groups of 1-3. Here we see mouth power level dropped to the minimum (whisper), which means that ear power level has to be raised to the maximum. (like mobile phones, which need more power when the bars indicating signal strength drop).

story: Two good friends looking at their childhood tree house and remembering how it seemed like generations ago since they were up in it chattering away all night.
column3: Mouths like to chatter about the new generation on the tree.
column4: The only thing that comes out of the MOUTHS of this GENERATION of young people, is chatter and chatter. I can't even escape the chatter on top of a TREE.

story: Mouths quarrel over who is more splendid.
column3: These very competitive neighbours open their mouths and quarrel every day about whose silage stack with flowers looks more splendid.
column4: In a quarrel, sometimes things come out of mouths which let's just say aren't too splendid.

story: If you open your mouth to gossip about people, it's usually the most fun if you have some juicy bits on people who are generally revered, for instance that they are secretly glued to their bottle of Horned Whiskey.
column3: "Did you know that the most 尊 (#1547) 酋 (#2915) is not only a horny guy, but an alcoholic, too? Ah, and I forgot, he also sniffs glue... Ups, did that come out of my mouth? No, no... I NEVER gossip!"
column4: Gossip is usually people opening their mouths to say things mean things about people that are secretly revered by them.

story: I looked up, opened my mouth and suddenly an acorn fell in! I had to cough it up quickly so that I wouldn't choke.
column3: A squirrel's mouth coughs up an acorn.
column4: You start coughing hard and suddenly an acorn pops out of your mouth o.O

story: To clamor means to open your mouth and proclaim loudly your opinions.
column3: I picture those guys on the street in Japan with a megaphone next to their mouth proclaiming something very loudly and creating a clamor being totally annoying.
column4: For this keyword, I am reminded of the Night Before Christmas, with the father awakening to see what was the clamor, and his mouth dropping open as he sees the fat bearded man spanning the rooftops (bounding from one house to the other).

story: These &^% stamps won't stay fixed to the envelop when I lick them with my mouth. No matter how hard I bash them, they come loose every time. Aargh!
column3: For me, the kanji looks like a picture of two eyes. Somebody bashed the right one until it burst open. Ugh... Put a stamp on it - I don't want to see it!
column4: The STAMP collector BASHED me in the MOUTH for using his STAMPS on my letters.

story: うそ = Something void of truth coming from your mouth.
column3: A statement void of truth uttered by a mouth is a fib.
column4: Instead of BS, a fib is TS: tiger shit coming out of your mouth.

story: Just like the ones on a rhinoceros, there are little birds who like to peck at the skin near the mouth of a sow and clean it.
column3: The typical story of anorexia nervosa: a pitiful emaciated girl who doesn't really eat, but rather just PECKs AT her food, keeping her MOUTH as tiny as a sparrow's beak, all the while thinking of herself as a gigantic SOW. [thx CharleyGarrett].
column4: A scavenger bird is pecking at the mouth of a dead pig in a field. The snout and tongue are the most delicious parts of the carrion.

story: The mouth of a chihuahua is good at barking.
column3: The smaller the MOUTH the bigger the barking hence the fact the chihuaha is damn annoying.....
column4: Just like 鳴 (#2092), I like to call this a "perfect kanji" :).

story: A towel dangles under his mouth to keep him clean at dinner.
column3: Dangle a bib or towel under my baby son's mouth.
column4: Instead of a napkin, he dangled a towel under his mouth when he sat down to dinner.

story: Use your teeth to chew what you put in your mouth.
column3: "To chew, you need a mouth with teeth" said the toothless granny.
column4: "When you open your mouth, don't take in more food than you can handle, and chew it properly with your teeth", mum told us.

story: "come true" is a better keyword IMO. If you speak your wish 10 times it will come true.
column3: With his big mouth he claims he can do ten things at once. "It's all within my ability", he boasts.
column4: 叶う(P); 適う; 敵う 【かなう】 (v5u) (1) (esp. 叶う) to come true (wish); (2) (See 道理に適う) (uk) to be suited; (3) (esp. 敵う) to match (implies competition); to rival; to bear (e.g. I can't bear the heat); (P) 叶える 【かなえる】 (v1,vt) to grant (request, wish); (P) STORY: Christians say that if you pray with your MOUTH to the CROSS all of your WISHES will COME TRUE. Yeah right...

story: Dimples. Those knots on the sides of the mouth. Too easy.
column3: Look at the sides of his mouth! His moustache is tied into great knots. They're not even symetrical. Look at the knots on the right side of the mouth! (though they're there on both sides of the mouth....
column4: (Kanji used in the word kissing 接吻 = せっぷん) In a kiss mouths become like a single knot. In a good one, you use even the sides of the mouth.

story: "S... Si... S... Sir!" the beggar's mouth stammers when appealing for some help from the business man. See the mouth open and close like a fish out of water would.
column3: Most beggars beg for money, but I see one begging for a new mouth. I ask him why . . . "'Cos this mouth st-st-stammers".
column4: A begging mouth stammers unintelligibly.

story: He really can spin a tale. Every time he opens his mouth, some new and creative tale comes out.
column3: Oh yeah, suuure - tell us a new one...
column4: Something new is always coming out of the mouth of someone who can spin a tale.

story: Miso is full of active microbial cultures, so when you put it in your MOUTH, those bacteria just INCREASE and INCREASE until your mouth is overflowing with miso!
column3: The みそ汁 in your MOUTH was FORMERLY soy beans.
column4: Note: if someone, like me, is confused by seeing the traditional variant in your browser (like the handwritten animation here: http://jisho.org/search/%E5%99%8C%20%23kanji). That seems(?) to be the new "standard" and is thus used in newer fonts, the “Heisig”(simplified ) one in older. Story: my MOUTH (口 (#11)) waters and I do EIGHT SQUEEZE-MY-EYES-SHUT (曾) when my WAGGING TONGUE (日 (#12)) gets a lick of miso. (Old) variant story: my MOUTH (口 (#11)) has an ever INCREASING (曽 (#540)) demand for miso.

story: The city walls are beautifully built. High above you, shows you the famous mouths of former city mayors, all smiling down at you, integrated into a total mosaic making the city walls a unified beautiful work of art.
column3: I stand outside the city walls, requesting permission to enter. The guard hands me a Rubik's cube and tells me ill only be allowed in after I fit the whole thing in my mouth...
column4: The city walls had a lovely mosaic design. However, they also had defensive features including openings above through which boiling oil could be poured or cannons fired.

story: His mouth fell open dumbfounded when he woke up and found himself on top of a tree.
column3: The first time I saw an Australian apricot tree (呆 vs. 杏) I was dumbfounded.
column4: You'd be dumbfounded too if you found a tree with a mouth! The damn thing can talk, and no it's not dumb, it's quite intelligent!

story: Ingest is a fancy word for what you do with your mouth as you eat.
column3: Note: This is a colloquial word for "eat", so the formal keyword "ingest" might better be replaced with something like "scoff" or "tuck in", etc. Suggested story: "Yeuk! I can see the food rolling around in your mouth when you scoff it like that!"
column4: Ingest implies something that goes in your mouth and you swallow it, not necessarily something you deliberately eat. If you stick your head out the window of a car and ingest a fly, it's not the same as deliberately eating a fly at the dinner table. [Note: what Katsuo says is true; this kanji means OM NOM NOM NOM. My elaboration of the keyword "ingest" stops me from confusing it with 餐 (#2814).]

story: This one rhymes: "If you fights wiz Cassius Clay, you'll hit the soil, boy, straightaway!"
column3: A special type of clay, this soil will cook into porcelain straightaway.
column4: Just as plants don't become trees straightaway (Ref: 植 (#217)), soil doesn't become clay straightaway.

story: While "autochthonous" can mean "indigenous" in ENGLISH, that is NOT one of the potential meanings of this character (thus, the majority of these stories will not help you with meaning). Rather, the kanji is "autochthonous" in the sense of being Earthly, mystic, and portentous (the ancient, primitive, sacred power of DIRT and SOIL). A vague, poorly-chosen keyword all around. Mantixen's story does the best job of conveying accurate meaning--> "A monkey likes the earthy/autochthonous feel of soil".
column3: A monkey likes the earthy feel of soil.
column4: When it saw the keyword for this kanji, the monkey soiled itself...

story: A DUGOUT is a dry moat found around Japanese castles. The SOIL is arranged so as to OVERPOWER (or give the advantage to OVERPOWER) an attacking army. If dug in a low lying area it fills with water and becomes a moat (濠 濠 (#2400)).
column3: We needed to create a dugout in the soil in order to avoid the overpowering attacks coming from the sky.
column4: As they constructed the visiting team dugout, they removed a quantity of soil when there was an overpowering stench. Nobody will want to use this dugout!
