story: Big consternation in the court! A little bit of soil in the garden touched the empress' face and left a blemish there. Courtiers fainted left and right...
column3: The empress gets a soil mask at the spa to treat a blemish.
column4: 垢嘗 [akaname] or 'grime licker' is a classical Japanese monster that comes out when your ofuro gets dirty and feeds on the filth. Its saliva is said to be poisonous. You can just picture it, hanging from the ceiling of your bathroom, dragging its enormous tongue wagging from its mouth, eating up all the dirt. If that doesn't help, try this: The empress is actually using the services of akaname to clean blemish off her face. As for the poison, well it works like botox..

story: I'm usually flat on the soil passed out at nightbreak.
column3: I have a nice big garden with one problem – moles! Anyway, when I get up at nightbreak (= dawn) there are always piles of soil (molehills) everywhere. My first task of the day is to jump on them to make them flat.
column4: The gardener got up early to trim the top off the 垣 (#165) so that it would be even and flat along the top surface.

story: You idiot! Why on earth did you build the wharf on a large hill? Are the ships supposed to sail through the dirt to get there? That is seriously the WORST place you could have built it.
column3: He came to finding himself down at the wharf with soil all over his tuxedo. The maestro can only guess that he'd been drugged by some needle sharp dart, since the last thing that he recalled was feeling a prick on the bottom, before waking up at the wharf.
column4: If you build a wharf on a 阜 (#1360), the vessels should be able to sail the soil.

story: Soil, box, sun, woman: In Peru, they were constructing a dam and to this end, soil was gathered from the surrounds. During the excavations, they found a box, containing little statue of the sun woman (godess). A nice archeological find, but detrimental for the dam building efforts, since the work was to be halted.
column3: To build the dam, soil was collected and carried in cardboard boxes. And when the sun got hot, they made the women do it.
column4: All the dams were built by the Army Corps of Engineers' Ladies' Auxiliary. So the WOMEN worked under the SUN all day, with a BOX full of DIRT on their shoulders, to & fro, building up the dirt wall that would become this mighty dam.

story: I was relieved to find my stolen lovedoll tied to some railing. She's a bit dirty but still good!
column3: The ninja sprinkled a thin powder of fine soil along the hand railing, so he would know if anyone had walked down the staircase - if the soil were disturbed, he would find another way out.
column4: A railing prevents museum patrons from getting soil on the voodoo dolls.

story: The woman removes the two shells covering her breasts (for modesty) and then attaches the suckling infant. How very Little Mermaid...
column3: I see this as two suckling infants clamped onto their mother (woman) like shellfish when breastfeeding.
column4: The old form of 桜 (#2082) uses this as the right hand side (i.e. two shellfish instead of owl). Compare 桜 to 櫻. It's not in RtK3 but it's still very common - I saw it on a building yesterday. Story: two clams latched onto the woman's breasts like two suckling infants.

story: Many women violate me at the same time. Then I woke up.
column3: To avoid being violated, three women cluster together in the women-only wagon of the train.
column4: 姦する means "to violate" but also "to commit adultery", so "illicit sex" would be a good keyword too; look at these compounds: 和姦 "(consensual) sexual intercourse" / 強姦 "violation" (strong->forced+illicit sex) / 輪姦 "gang rape" / 姦通 or 姦淫 "adultery" / 姦夫 "adulterer" / 姦婦 "adulteress" / 獣姦 "bestiality" / 近親相姦 "incest". Problem: none of the keywords carry the meaning of "wicked" or "evil" (usually 奸 could be used instead), like in 奸賊, 姦賊 "villain".

story: Handmaiden's are usually quite lowly women, but this one is a special (just look at the way lowly is drawn).
column3: A handmaiden is a woman in a lowly regarded profession.
column4: A handmaiden is a woman servant with the lowly job of burning pirated Chinese DVDs (rough copies of already lowly movies) http://technology.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/tech_and_web/article6730463.ece.

story: When asking a girl out on a date, you are only well finished when you have her address and phone number.
column3: Euphemism is this kanji's most common usage. Story: A woman whose address is in a red light district uses euphemisms to describe where she lives. 婉曲 [えんきょく] euphemistic; circumlocution; roundabout; indirect; 優婉 [ゆうえん] elegant; grand.
column4: To become well finished, young women often go to a finishing school at a posh address.

story: Harlots are women who make a lot of money, usually, so they or their pimps are quite prosperous. Look at all her bling bling, shining like more than two suns. Who says vice doesn't pay?
column3: Being a harlot can be quite PROSPEROUS. However, you have to work from SUN down to SUN up.
column4: Harlots are women who make a living selling themselves to prosperous men.

story: In the 平安時代（へいあんじだい）, the courtesans (women who lived in the royal courts) often stayed in the side portions of the palaces, the section that branched off the main building. Idea taken from illustrations in a copy of the Tale of Genji.
column3: The courtesan is in a branch of prostitution is way above that of the typical street whore.
column4: This woman is not a harlot; she is a courtesan. Her clientele are from a much higher branch.

story: The photographer took a picture of this fair woman framed by ivy.
column3: Come on, think of Rapunzel. That WOMAN was so FAIR, she was locked away. Only she used her IVY like FAIR hair to let her lover climb to her.
column4: The WOMAN is so fair I would climb IVY just to see her.

story: Little did you know, the woman who made you climax was your niece.
column3: My niece is a WOMAN now, and can make herself CLIMAX.
column4: Niece (woman associated keyword so the woman part is taken care of here) does a splendid job in the climax when she plays piano sonatas or any other piece. We can imagine a niece playing her piano recital. After traversing the climax of a piano piece from the Romantic period, we can see the women in the audience are bursting in tears. (so much that only the men applauded when the piece concluded).

story: As any servant knows, a mistress who runs things well must be nature be a very demanding woman.
column3: Mistresses are always making demands. "Leave your wife!" "Make it rain!" "Comb my hair!" Stuff like that.
column4: It is normally the woman who does the job around the home. A mistress is highly demanding. You can see her bossing her family around to do the chores while she does her leisure activities. Looks like she's doesn't have to be bossed to do anything.

story: The woman version of an old man is an aged woman.
column3: You know an aged woman?! I know an old man. We should set them up. (Note: Be careful not to confuse with 婆 (#867)).
column4: (+paasan) This is to avoid confusion with old woman. In this day and age, the woman in a couple will often out-age her old man and become an aged woman.

story: According to Japanese traditions, daughters-in-law have to pay respect to the woman who is their mother-in-law, because they are older.
column3: Mother-in-law is a woman who's not going to die young. No, she's gonna live to be very old, just to piss you off.
column4: My mother-in-law is the OLDER version of my WOMAN on the left.

story: A young miss in a rich Japanese household is often treated with such care that she is a like a woman who is put on a shelf like an ornament.
column3: The young miss won a long of baby beauty pageants. A whole shelf is devoted to the prices she won.
column4: A young miss is fiercely protected by her family, like a fragile figurine kept on a shelf.

story: Finally, I got a woman ... I have to just shriek and rejoice, I'm so overjoyed!
column3: [Thanks, AKremlin: 女が喜び、嬉しい. This reminds me of my husband's motto, "Happy wife. Happy life."] I'm OVERJOYED when my WOMAN REJOICES.
column4: Women rejoice when they have children, and are often overjoyed with them.

story: A woman says to me “I’m expecting – there’s a child in here (pointing to her stomach)” I put my ear to her stomach and suddenly the child punches me – I see the shape of its fist in the stomach wall. “Well, you might be expecting, but I certainly wasn’t expecting that” I reply.
column3: 乃 = picture of a woman with swollen breasts and stomach (true) i.e. a pregnant woman. Obvious story: pregnant woman is expecting child.
column4: Fist, child: The guy had only put his fist inside and now his girlfriend is expecting a child. "How long ago did I have that business trip?", he wonders.

story: Well, yeah, the kid's assiduous: he's got that taskmaster on his back all the time! What else would you expect?
column3: Assiduous children make assiduous taskmasters.
column4: I'm surprised at how many people seem to think that the key-word 'assiduous' has negative connotations. A quick glance at a decent dictionary will tell you that it is a synonym of diligence, though its emphasis lies more with the painstaking care with which one might go about a task. For this kanji, the assiduous child assiduously did as his taskmaster told him, all the while assiduously planning his escape.

story: It really soothes my mind that I possess a house. Now at least all my payments are going towards something solid, instead of just throwing it away as rent.
column3: My house is possessed by the ghost of Barry White, who often sings me songs to soothe me to sleep at night.
column4: The possessed house surprisingly played soothing music as I entered, I guess the friendly spirit likes music.

story: When you see Jiminy Cricket near a house, it will imply that Pinocchio isn't far off.
column3: The talking cricket says, "you've been spending a lot of time in the house lately," and you say, "What is that supposed to mean?", to which the cricket replies, "I'm implying you need to get a job!"
column4: The talking cricket has lived in Gepetto's house for a century, but in noting this I do not intend to imply anything irregular in their relations. Disambiguate imply & 仄 仄 (#2153) by remembering that it is a sin to push someone off a cliff or to insinuate that someone else might have, but that anything Jiminy Cricket does is simply impish.

story: During an extensive search of a murderer's house of horror, homocide detectives found an elbow body part by the side of another body. Surely there were even more victims than they imagined.
column3: Thanks to Katsuo: BY ONE'S SIDE and ELBOW can be SUPERMAN (think of the George Reeve's SUPERMAN pose for a mental image). Well, that fortress of solitude is very EXTENSIVE. Would you expect SUPERMAN's HOUSE to anything less?
column4: Tip: by one's side + elbow : This combination of primitives appears four times in Heisig. REF: 雄 (#804), extensive (FRAME 2212), 肱 (#2536), 紘 (#2704).

story: For a cow used to free-grazing, being stuck in a house is equivalent to being in jail.
column3: Looking at the kanji 家, keeping pigs in the house was normal. But, if you instead kept a cow in the house, you would be sent to jail.
column4: Stuck in jail, otherwise known as the big house or the hoosegow, er, "-cow" (the 'c'/'k' getting voiced into a 'g' in the compound word...) (^ahem^).

story: The Sung dynasty was so-called because people kept trees in their houses and as a consequence birds sung in them.
column3: The Sung dynasty needed to cut down a lot of TREES to make a lot of HOUSES. (the imperial dynasty of China from 960 to 1279; noted for art and literature and philosophy).
column4: During the Sung Dynasty, people built their HOUSES out of WOOD.

story: I was once served venison at home, but the only way I could eat it was to down a six pack first.
column3: I told my friend the deer I kept in my house for venison was called "roku" (six). He asked if naming it didn't make me attached to it. I said no, because "roku" is also a way to say the kanji for deer.
column4: The venison from one deer can feed about six houses.

story: Generals usually see their soldiers as mere puppets in their war game. These poor sods are given a flag and told to fight for their country. As if that would make good all the butchering.
column3: Flag, lovedoll: My first suspicion was mitigated since my lovedoll was still giving me good lovin'. But when I noticed that little flag which had suddenly appeared on her left breast, I knew something was wrong. Checking her diary, I find out that a lovedoll coup was underway, which would involve butchering all owners!
column4: Chucky from Child's Play was found butchering a poor victim with a flag pole.

story: You haven't smelled a fart like his! His were so bad, that when he cut one, they had to wave a flag to keep folks away. None compare to the farts that he farts.
column3: At a fart contest each contestant holds up a flag whenever they fart so the judges can come over and compare it to the others.
column4: The boys have a simple game: They fart into a FLAG and COMPARE how much they make it move.

story: You aren't supposed to throw an American flag out with the rubbish. The proper way to get rid of a flag is to burn it, shown here by holding a candle underneath it.
column3: Japanese society has always been quite environmentally conscious. Even back in the Edo period, they had an ingenious method for punishing people that didn't properly separate their rubbish. If, for example, you threw your ペットボトル into the paper can, a large Semaphore Flag would fly up out of nowhere and alert people, and a candle would fly out of the can and catch you on fire, so that people would know immediately who the perpetrator was.
column4: Burning a flag with a candle is a rubbish idea. Why would you want to do that?

story: Imagine the flag of Japan. I frequently go there for its tasty rice and to see its beautiful women.
column3: They frequently flag down the rice women who aren't working hard enough and punish them for their 'laziness'.
column4: On clear nights, people frequently look at the stars. Whenever they spot a constellation, they raise a flag and tell others about it. [rice+woman=constellation].

story: After meeting death, a flag covers the soldier's corpse.
column3: Imagine the character Death (the shroud-wearing skeleton) carrying an armful of flags. He goes round at night sticking a flag in each corpse. (i.e. to distinguish it from those who are merely sleeping).
column4: 屍, 屍体=死体, 屍蠟=屍蝋, 屍 (#2332) シ, しかばね, かばね ... Parts:尸, 死 (cf 死亡死 (#878), 葬式葬 (#879), 骨骨 (#1383), 躯躯, 骸骸 (#1641)) ... Note: This kanji is why the 尸 Flag Primitive is actually called the Corpse Radical (しかばね) ... Story: I Pee on your Dead Corpse.

story: This folding screen looks quite pretty, with all the national flags printed on it, but folding and unfolding it is rather complicated. It looks more like a puzzle than a utility item.
column3: Someone took an old 塀 (#1136), brushed the dirt off it and turned it into a folding screen.
column4: I'm throwing up the white flag of surrender after having to put together yet another Ikea folding screen. They fit together like a puzzle, and I've had quite enough of trying to put together these puzzles for one day.

story: High-reaching aspirations usually revolve around the mountain that is the tallest. For climbing, for descending, for just bring there - the thrill of it all.
column3: People like Sir Edmund Hillary set very high-reaching goals, like being the first to climb Everest, the tallest mountain in the world.
column4: A mountain that's tall is also high-reaching.

story: The next step on the sentient rice-seedlings; journey, after their miraculous 凌 (#2136) from being trapped: mountains in the distance, extremely rugged mountains, and nowhere to go next but through them.
column3: When trying to cross RUGGED MOUNTAINS you'll feel like you have RICE SEEDLINGS for WALKING LEGS.
column4: Rugged mountains are mountains which have "black diamond" (expert level) ski slopes, and no flowers can grow there. (The part on the right is 菱 菱 (#1517), minus flowers.)

story: This mountain lies exactly between two prefectures, so naturally there was a struggle about which prefecture had jurisdiction there. And would you believe it, one of them gained jurisdiction over the base, and the other over the mountaintop.
column3: In war whoever seizes the MOUNTAINTOP can use their firepower from the MOUNTAIN to control the surrounding JURISDICTIONs.
column4: At the top of the mountain, Bill Clinton found an intern and said "This mountaintop is my 領 (#1507). I order you to give me head." The intern replied, "Come on Bill, hasn't this type of behaviour caused enough problems already?"

story: No way that sweet girl can fit those mountains of hers into an A-cup. They'll be severely lacking space. Too many sweets I guess.
column3: (from mantixen's) I was going to take some sweets on my climb up the mountain, but it wouldn't fit into my bag, so I lack them.
column4: This means really "got into" something - "ゲームに嵌まっちゃった"　- I became hooked on Video games (Tae Kim). I really got into mountain climbing lately but I lack fitness due to eating too many sweets.

story: The fortune teller tells me that in the future I will have my own quire. "Is that choir as in 'group of singers', or quire as in 'sheets of paper'?" I ask. She can't tell because her crystal ball is too misty, so I rush to the bathroom, grab a towel, and use it to wipe the crystal ball. Turns out to be quire as in 'sheets of paper', of course.
column3: (25 sheets of paper) -- the fortune teller orders a quire of paper but receives a quire of towels. She calls to complain, but customer service tells her, "Why didn't you see it coming?"
column4: A quire in English means a set of 24 sheets of paper. In Japanese, it means 25 sheets. Well, rumor has it this is because on the 24 sheets needs to a towel (the 25th sheet), to ward off evil spirits, according to a famous fortuneteller.

story: When I go to gaming conventions, I always bring my banner: a simple towel with the dice logo on it. Let's roll!
column3: My favorite towel is one that says "Who wants a turn?" like its an advertising banner.
column4: Anti-gambling banner: 'There is no such thing as luck. Don't throw the dice, throw in the towel.' Picture a banner with the quote and a ⃠ sign on a pair of dice.

story: Yep, it's a party alright. The kazoo fiesta noise is audible from far away, and look, they fashioned pennants out of towels to use as a signal flag for beckoning visitors in.
column3: A pennant is a cloth flag that is blown so hard by the wind that it vibrates audibly, buzzing like a kazoo.
column4: Many towels were waved and kazoos blown when the Cardinals won the pennant.

story: The cleaver was found with the dismembered body wrapped up in a cave.
column3: The murder victim was killed by a a cleaver. Her body was found in a cave, wrapped up in plastic.
column4: The murder weapon was found in a cave. It turned out to be a cleaver, the police wrapped it up in plastic and took it off to a forensics lab for it to be analyzed.

story: The Fight Club had no licensed quarters, so they battled it out in the enclosure down inside a cave.
column3: 遊廓=遊郭, 廓 (#2342) カク(郭), くるわ(郭) ... Parts: 广, 郭 (cf: 醇朴, 淳朴) ... Note: Now replaced by 郭郭 (#1985) ... Story: As the old form of 郭, this is just Old Enclosure written as it was in the old days- on Cave walls. Licensed Quarters means whorehouse. Old days theses were all Enclosures in Caves.
column4: Modern prostitutes use motels, but in ancient Japan, their licensed quarters consisted of an enclosure in a cave. Classy.

story: This overhang has so much shade it's comparable to being in a cave.
column3: This overhang is really good against the warmth. Compared with other overhangs, this one makes you feel as cool as if you are in a cave.
column4: You go with a friend into a deep, dark cave for a really dangerous (and stupid) contest - the overhang contest. There is a dark, cramped tunnel that you crawl through, which leads to a (as far as you know) bottomless pit. You and your friends take turns overhanging off the overhang - and whoever can stand to overhang into the pitch dark the longest (did I mention that there are strange animal-like noises coming from the bottom?), wins - and you compare times on a score sheet.

story: CAREFUL: 雁 (#2273) contains "cliff", here we have "CAVE"!
column3: The turkey is hiding in the cave, because there is a hawk patrolling outside. However in the cave he encounters something far more dangerous than the hawk - hungry Mr. T. "Oh shi-" Mr. T. then proceeds to eat the hawk as well, "a bird is a bird".
column4: Those wild goose scurry into the caves that have been worn into the side of the cliffs, all trying to avoid a hawk. The bird storming down on them for an easy feed.

story: In the Shire, hobbits used to live in caves. Nowadays their holes in the soil still look a little like caves.
column3: In ancient times, a SHIRE (feudal village) began as a CAVE divided by walls of SOIL for each family's dwelling area (as in Clan of the Cave Bear).
column4: Remember at the end of the Lord of the Rings, when Saruman was found in the Shire trying to fill up all the hobbit's caves with soil? Or something like that.

story: With few visitors, the tomb sanctuary in the cave is only open in the morning.
column3: The tomb sanctuary of the Egyptian pharaohs is only open in the morning. At night they seal the cave to keep the spirits from escaping!
column4: Come morning, vampires must seek sanctuary. Of course, tomb sanctuary would be ideal, but any cave will do.

story: If you can't pull your bow all the way back, you need to strengthen yourself by eating a stack of pancakes and waffles.
column3: I strengthened my bow skills by eating a double decker rice sandwich.
column4: To STRENGTHEN the defenses against the impending onslaught, squadrons of expert BOWmen are lined up along the BORDER (畺 畺).

story: The scorpion nibbled on the string of my bow and loosened it. Now I have to string the bow again!
column3: My grip on the bow loosened, and I felt myself slowly slipping away. The last thing I remember seeing was the scorpion quietly scuttling away from my trouser leg, where it has delivered it's poisionous blow.
column4: Legolas loosened his bowels when seeing a scorpion.

story: Rice gruel gives you the strength to use two bows at once.
column3: The 50-kg bodybuilder-wannabe submits himself to a "grueling regime": RICE GRUEL for every meal. He's tired of being WEAK (弱). He wants to "scrape the ICE off his BOWS", so to speak, by injecting massive quantities of RICE calories into his diet, and there's no cheaper, simpler way to do this than by gorging himself with RICE GRUEL.
column4: Kill me now with 2 BOWS, I'm sick of eating RICE gruel.

story: To stop workers losing fingers on the lathes, the company has decided to issue lucky rabbit's feet to its workers.
column3: Get your fingers caught in the lathe, and you will have no time to say: "Excuse me, may I use your first aid kit?" but: "Aaaa..! Where the f..k is the d..n first aid kit!!!!"
column4: Bugs Bunny knocking out carrot fingers on a lathe.

story: If you bump into a juvenile he is bound to give you the finger.
column3: The finger of the juvenile bumps into you, but he actually tried to give you a kancho.
column4: Juveniles are often unsure of how long their extremities actually are, because they're growing all the time. They often bump into things because their fingers are a centimetre or two longer than the last time they looked!

story: "How do you like my disguise?" "Umm... the fingers are only part of a disguise. You should really disguise the other parts of your body, too.. o.o" (Imagine the guy is just wearing camouflage gloves or something along those lines.)
column3: If I cover part of my face with my fingers, is that a good enough disguise?
column4: "Now part your fingers, and witness my latest disguise" It might just work, your friend now appears completely invisible!

story: knead: After spending all day kneading dough, I realized there was dirt under my fingernails. Whoops, forgot to wash! I think I'll keep this to myself; it could be bad for business.
column3: A young girl playing Natural Bakeries. She kneads the soil 土 (#161) with her fingers and then lays it out in the sun 日 (#12) to bake!
column4: I got my fingers on a document that granted me my own piece of ground in the sunniest part of the world. Turns out it was just a fabrication.

story: Reminds me of a Star Wars quote, Leia: "The more you tighten your grip, Tarkin, the more star systems will slip through your fingers." (i.e., the tighter you clutch, the more countries you'll lose).
column3: Clutch tightly with your fingers your passport so you can get back in the country without any issues.
column4: WARNING! This kanji does not refer to the automotive component "Clutch" pedal, rather it means to grasp and hold tightly.(That many stories below have fallen victim to, Clutch is rendōki 連動機) Story: Their Country has invaded our territory, our leader fallen into their CLUTCHES while everyone is looting anything they can get their FINGERS on.

story: In Nara, they do not accept はんこ, in fact their seals are done by simply impressing fingers into hot melting wax (fingerprints are unique!).
column3: In Nara, you impress wax seals with just your finger.
column4: (+ikmys) Let me impress upon you that here at the Nara city office, we do not accept documents that have only been hankoed. We need a thumb impression or a finger (preferably forefinger) impression on all documents that you submit. 指紋押捺を拒否する (しもんおうなつをきょひする): refuse to be fingerprinted 署名捺印する (しょめいなついんする): sign and affix seal, execute (a contract or deed) 捺す (おす): to stamp (e.g., a passport), to apply a seal.

story: Insects on your crotch make your fingers want to scratch.
column3: Scratching with your fingers is a possible sign of a 蚤 蚤 (#2721) infestation. Even when they (the drops) are gone, the urge to scratch remains.
column4: A nasty insect bit me under my crotch, so I scratched it with my fingers.

story: You reach into a bag of assorted lollies with your fingers and pull out two snakes stuck together.
column3: This is an assortment of chocolate fingers all pointing south-east (巽 is 巽) i.e. all angled towards the lower-right corner of the box.
column4: Noah is about to 選 (#1944) snakes for his arc. It takes a while since there is a huge assortment. He points at two snakes. "You and you! The rest can go now, sorry...!

story: This Kanji means "be complete; uniform; all present"... when you want to build something or cook something, you use your FINGERS to muster together all of the parts/ingredients you will need IN FRONT of you.
column3: You finally mustered up enough courage to point your finger at the bully in front of you and tell him what an *** he is. Hope you can run fast.
column4: The angry captain orders all his men to muster in front of him, then points his finger at those he plans to punish and make an example of. ”お前ら。。。”. (Heisig: The sense of the keyword here is “to assemble in an orderly fashion.”).

story: If you deal with the Yakuza, you might get a finger separated.
column3: "I'll deal with you separately," said the teacher, pointing his finger.
column4: The mother grabs the two unruly children and separates them. Her son gives her the finger, so she glares at him and says "I'll deal with you later."

story: Think of shiatsu. You press down on someone with your fingers to help them relax.
column3: You help your girlfriend relax by pressing down on her back with your fingers.
column4: 按針, 按摩, 按ずる, 按排, 按配, 按分, 按 (#2360) アン(安), ... Parts:扌, 安 ... Note: Anjin is the word for someone who investigates/pilots by compass needle. The keyword comes from 按摩 massage, but press down is not really a good keyword. ... Story: think of 按摩 Anma Massage: You press down on someone with your fingers to help them relax. (Adj. to Katsuo story: 指圧 is its own Kanji.

story: Means "plant; sow" When sowing seeds or planting flowers, the results will turn out better if you disseminate the seeds/plants with your FINGERS in TURN . A red flower here, then a blue flower, a red flower, then a blue flower, etc...
column3: Imagine your fingers disseminating dice instead of seeds.
column4: I'm all used up for the day, so I disseminate turns to the remaining ladies with my fingers.

story: For deaf people, whose ears do not function properly, the interpretation of speech is often attained by using their fingers in sign language, and pay close attention to the mouths of others.
column3: (NB: I use COLLECT for 揖, per 2d edition of RTK3.) 揖 illustrates the steps to be followed to COLLECT survey responses door-to-door. First, use your FINGER to ring the doorbell. Second, use your MOUTH to give your shpeel. Third, use your EARs to listen to the responses.
column4: I bow with hands clasped, my fingers holding the microphone (with an opening that's like an ear for receiving sound) after giving my own interpretation of the karaoke song.

story: The keyword in the book is "receptacle" (which is an actual word unlike receptable). I picture a kidnapping demand where a finger and a lock of hair of the victim is placed into a receptacle and sent to the family.
column3: Why are you holding that lock of hair, man? Are your fingers even clean? Go put that thing into a trash receptacle. No! Not your fingers, the lock. Receptacle seems to work...especially since receptable isn't a word.
column4: This is probably supposed to be "receptacle" (e.g. 茶托 = saucer for teacup, which is sort of a "tea receptacle"), though it can also mean "entrust with" and even "hint" and "pretend" according to my dictionary.

story: DEVOTE (new rtk3 keyword). Think of the Yakuza. To show their DEVOTION to the clan, they must be DEDICATED enough to cut off their FINGERS if they fail a task.
column3: My fingers are devoted to writing kanji, because I dedicated myself to Japanese.
column4: Dedicated people who dedicate themselves to growing bonsai cornstalkes have to have very fine fingers to work the bonsai cornstalk.

story: Bad guys in movies always twirl their moustache with their fingers, and that sort of thing.
column3: I know you like cute girls who twirl their hair with their fingers, that sort of thing can really get any guy going.
column4: Use your fingers to twirl your hot-dog over a fire.

story: The courts use their fingers as a counter for tools used in murder cases.
column3: (+ikmys) In court, the serial killer was asked how many different tools he had used in the murders. A bit of dolt, he counted on his fingers "one, tooo, twee, foe " as the judge shook his head in disgust. Fingers are indeed used as a counter for tools in courts, especially by dolts. 挺身する (ていしんする): to volunteer 空挺降下地域 (くうていこうかちいき): drop zone 空挺部隊 (くうていぶたい): airborne troops 挺 (ちょう): counter for guns, jinrikishas.
column4: In a courtroom, there's a specific counter for tools which might have been used to commit a crime. The counter is located in front of the witness stand. The witness must use his or her fingers to identify which tools were used in the crime, and use this kanji to count how many were used in all.

story: A new dance, called the "commotion" where you move your fingers in a melancholy way. (Derived from "The Locomotion": Everybody's doin' a brand new dance now, Come on baby, do the Locomotion.)
column3: There was a huge commotion in the state of Denmark when Hamlet cut off his fingers. He must have been really melancholic...
column4: 擾乱擾 (#2367)ジョウ ... Parts:扌, 憂 (cf. 憂い憂 (#663), 優しい優 (#1068)) ... Katsuo Remix: (Derived from "The Locomotion": Everybody's doin' a brand new dance now, Come on baby, do the low comotion.) A new dance, called the Low (melancholy)"commotion" Because its the emo version, there's no dancing, just moving your fingers back and forth.

story: I was petting my pet, but when I looked at my fingers I saw . . . nothingness – my pet had bitten them off.
column3: You think of nothingness while your fingers are petting your cat.
column4: I pet my pet with my fingers so hard... he was reduced to nothingness.

story: Use your fingers to scatter sprinkles on top of your ice cream cone まく.
column3: Sprinkling is when the fingers scatter things.
column4: To sprinkle something is to SCATTER it delicately with your FINGERS. (Similar to the difference between “pick”(採 (#792)) and “grab”(采 (#791))).

story: Tip: feathers + turkey : This combination of primitives appears six times in Heisig, so it's worthwhile giving it a name. I suggest "futon" (your futon is made from turkey feathers). REF: 曜 (#618) , 濯 (#619), 躍 (#1379), outstanding (FRAME 2272), 燿 (#2594), 耀 (#2892).
column3: My turkey suit, complete with actual feathers, was so outstanding that farmers tried to hunt me down with hatchets: I promptly gave them the finger.
column4: I still haven't gotten the hang of folding up the futon, so I ask my host mother to demonstrate it to me. Watching her fingers move lightening fast and fold up that futon in mere seconds, I can only mutter "...outstanding!"

story: Think of Braille – rubbing things with your fingers in order to learn.
column3: I learned, quite by accident, that by rubbing my fingers somewhere special, I felt great. 20 lears later, I'm still rubbing.
column4: Rubbing out an image with your fingers seems easy, but you have to learn to do it well to get the best results.

story: Someone tries to lay their fingers on your spoils, and you run after them hitting them with a broom as they run from you.
column3: As my share of the spoils of war I grab a running-broom that has fingers (just like the one in Disney/Mickey Mouse/Fantasia). It runs round cleaning up with its broom and uses its fingers to press buttons etc and operate household appliances. But also like Mickey’s it gets out of control and spoils everything it touches. So much for the spoils of war.
column4: Nimble: In my fingers I equip my Broom of Running. It can't fly, but it gives me +5 nimbleness. Now to quickly do some housework. NB: I couldn't find 'spoils' for the meaning for this kanji, so the next best thing was nimble which covers the meanings of fast and smart.

story: The penalty for gouging out someone's eyes is to have your fingers guillotined.
column3: Before they guillotine him they gouge out his eyes with their fingers, which is why we can't see eyes in this Kanji.
column4: Itchy and Scratchy. The mouses uses his fingers to pull out one of the cats eyes and then sets up a tiny guillotine to cut the cord connecting it to his brain. A very elaborate way of gouging out an eye. Bart would love it.

story: The gambling addict's state of mind ... wincing as he realizes that everything he owns is gone.
column3: As they pull the batteries out of Data, we see him wince and then he's gone.
column4: Your state of mind becomes gone for a second when you wince.

story: The state of mind of a turkey is to ponder the meaning of life while waiting to be eaten come November.
column3: Brain: "I'm in a lucid state of mind. Pinky, are you pondering what I'm pondering?" Pinky: "Yes Brain, but how are we going to get the turkey up here?"
column4: The crew of the Enterprise all get turned into turkeys. Data spends the episode pondering what happened and how to fix it.

story: Infatuation is the state of mind that makes a knot form in your heart.
column3: Infatuation is the state of mind when you 忽 (#2509) fall in love.
column4: Infatuation is a state of mind where you should know that what you feel probably is not something that touches your heart for real.

story: The commando team under orders need to be quickwitted and are always in the right state of mind for action.
column3: Data, orders: Commander Data is as quickwitted as they come. While Picard is still in the process of uttering an order, Data is already executing it!
column4: The commander has to be quickwitted during war-time. If for example some of his men die, he must not be confused by his STATE OF MIND and still be able to give the right orders.

story: The state of mind of the tall child whom receives all of the attention is often surprisingly considerate. They have known nothing but kindness in their life, and thus act the same in return!
column3: A considerate state of mind is open to receive others' input.
column4: Data is only considerate of tall children, he's a real dick to short kids.

story: I was in a state of mind to ask my wife if some slinky outfit from the closet fit her. "As if!" she yelled, "that belonged to your previous girlfriend!"
column3: My husband and I often have the same state of mind. We believe that's why we fit together well, as if we are meant for each other.
column4: Data's dream is to fit in with the rest of the Enterprise crew as if he was human.

story: Imagine the state of mind of a person who takes some viagra, thinking it will enlarge his package, but somehow it reduces it to ashes instead.
column3: He was in a terrible state of mind when his home that he was enlarging was consumed by a fire and everything he had build up was turned to ashes.
column4: Data falls victim to a spam mail marketing strategy, which promised to enlarge his robotic member. When he tested the new attachment though, it turned out to be far too powerful and reduced his partner to a pile of ashes.

story: The state of mind of a younger brother has respect for elders, including you if you're the elder brother.
column3: Data, younger brother: Commander Data had a younger, amoral brother (Lore). When they visited an old computer museum, Lore remarked that he could compute much faster than the machines on exhibition. That's when Data found it to be his duty to teach his brother respect for elders.
column4: The one family member who doesn't have respect for elders is the younger brother. In his immature state of mind he makes farting noises while playing with his food.

story: The canals on Mars contain zero water.
column3: A canal is used to put water where there was zero.
column4: When the water temperature reached zero, the canal freezes over and you can ice skate on it.

story: Rays of sunlight on the water make for a glistening effect.
column3: The WATER is glistening in the RAYS of light.
column4: Compare with shimmering (frame 2880), where the rays of sunlight shimmer off the futon. Water is what's glistening in those rays. (helps to remember both kanji).

story: You know you are deep in the water of a bounding main (deep body of water), when you look up and can no longer see the rays of the sun above you.
column3: You know you are deep in the water of a bounding main (deep body of water), when you look up and realise it's not 晃 (#2522).
column4: The sun shines over the glistening bounding main that is the ocean.

story: To gargle, put a bundle of medicine in your mouth with water and throw your head back as if in a yawn.
column3: 含漱=含嗽=嗽=うがい,嗽薬＊, 夏目漱石 = Natsume Soseki ＝ Summer Eye, Gargle Rocks, 漱ぐ=雪ぐ=濯ぐ,漱 (#2385)ソウ, すすぐ ... Note: うがい(Gargle) is written in kana or 嗽. ... Parts:氵, 束, 欠 OR 瀬- 頁, 欠 (cf: 瀬戸内海瀬 (#1795), 濯ぐ濯 (#619), 雪ぐ雪 (#1225),頼む頼 (#1794), 嗽薬嗽) ... Story: Going rafting with Soseki, we hit the rapids, fell out the boat, and our heads fell off. Now we lack heads and gargle river water. Not a good day out with Soseki.
column4: Gargle by bundling water in your throat that lacks moisture.

story: Australia is the only continent that is surrounded by water on all sides, yet is still a single state.
column3: If the borders of a state are all water, then it is more properly called a 'continent' instead. (For 州 州 (#135), I think of the small-dash/big-dash alternating pattern that is used for state borders on some maps.)
column4: Continents have states with water around it.

story: You have got a really, really plugged up bathtub - so plugged up, as a matter of fact, that when you get out of the bath, it takes an entire decameron for the gently swirling waters to go all the way down. You are really annoyed at this (it's gross, besides), so you get a tiny little sun and bound it up with twine, and lower it into the drain. It clears the clog right up, and the swirling waters zip right on down!
column3: For ten days, we watched the swirling waters, but it didn't seem like the water would rise in another tsunami.
column4: Swirling waters are truly a wonderful thing to behold. I could watch them for a whole decameron and never get bored. (I haven't been able to find any other reference stating that this kanji means swirling waters, so I'm going with truly as the main meaning).

story: We have a prettily shaped umbrella, but when it started to rain, water seeped through and three of our elbows got wet. So much for design over functionality.
column3: 滲み易い, 滲む, 滲 (#2388)(シン),(しみる),にじむ ... Parts: 氵, 参/參 (cf. 参参 (#1856), 惨/慘 惨 (#1857)) (Note: Uses 參 (old for 参参 (#1856)) ... Similar Keywords :A stabbed heart will invariably 泌尿器泌 (#686); an antique Vase will 滴滴 (#474), a flag pole mount will 漏れる漏 (#1149) when it rains. Old people 滲む滲 (#2388) fluids on my couch. ... Story: When old people visit (Old Visit), they tend to Seep bodily fluids onto my damn couch. get some depends, motherfscker.
column4: Water seeps through my parasol & wets all three of my elbows. (Edward Albee, anyone?)

story: In the wild west everything was so dirty! With the limited water people could spare, a simple rinse was the best your clothes would get.
column3: In the west, we don't rinse ourselves before getting into the bath water.
column4: NOT CLEANSE In the wild west, they would rinse out your mouth with water any time you said a dirty joke 洒落 [しゃれ] adj-na,n joke,pun,witticism *.

story: In the forest fire, they doused the trees with water to prevent more damage.
column3: You use water to 沃 (#459) saplings. When it has become a tree, you need more. Then you have to douse it.
column4: We doused the trees with water to prevent a forest fire. To disambiguate douse & 渥 渥 (#2411) recall that had we doused the trees properly in the first place we might not have had to moisten the roof later.

story: Water drops from your eye are teardrops.
column3: I get water in my eye to form TEARDROPS wishing every kanji was this easy.
column4: 泪橋 泪 (#2294) ルイ, なみだ ... Parts: 氵, 目 ... Note: Tuttle 3a9.21 ... 涙涙 (#1082), vs. 泪泪 (#2294) (vs 淚 )? don't worry. They are the exact same word except when used in place names: On and Kun are the same . 涕 has the decency to have a different On-Yomi. But the Kun is the same. ...

story: As the Pharaoh's chariots tried to cross the Red Sea, gushing waters came and crushed them.
column3: Picture yourself driving a chariot wildly down the street and knocking over all the fire hydrants. Water is gushing everywhere.
column4: My chariot hath runneth into a fire hydrant, and now there art water gushing everywhere.

story: The church is selling holy water for the faithful, but if you dare to say its tap water, they'd tell you you were blaspheming.
column3: During the Wedding at Cana, the Son of God had some people come up to complain after he performed his miracle. "This wine is terrible! Are you trying to sell me watered-down wine?" He replied, "It's a wedding, for God's sake, the wine is free, so stop complaining." The dissatisfied guest retorted, "Hey, don't blaspheme!" Jesus Christ just rolled his eyes and, under his breath, uttered his own name in vain.
column4: "Jesus entered the temple area and drove out all who were buying and selling there..." Mathew 21:12. In the Japanese version of this event, Jesus drives out the blasphemers by throwing water at them. Cf. 売 売 (#345).

story: What seemed to be water dripping from the wooden roofbeam was actually drops of blood dripping from a sword lodged in it.
column3: A while back, I was goofing around with my sword when I accidentally lodged it in the roofbeam. Apparently, I also poked a couple of holes in the roof because whenever it rains, some water drips onto the floor - one drop from each side of the sword. So that's why there is a tree growing on the floor now. :/.
column4: He cut down the tree with a sword to make a new roofbeam, but when he saw two drops lying on the tree, he assumed there was too much water in the wood and he left it to dry first.

story: Mr. President is visiting the city of New Orleans, where the sediment is being cleared away that got there when the water rushed in during hurricane Katrina.
column3: After Mr. (and Mrs.) Smith blasted everything in sight with a missile launcher (see 殿 (#1805)), turning the whole world into sediment, nothing was left to shot at. The only thing left was WATER. So boring...
column4: MR. Noah noticed as the WATERS receeded from the flood, lots of SEDIMENT was left on the land. Good for growing grapes I guess.

story: Old Kyoto was once the capital, but if has fallen from grace and the flowers that used to decorate its houses have all disapeared.
column3: (+nolusu) Old Kyoto once had a beautiful sign decorated with flowers saying "Welcome to Kyoto!". But over time, the flowers have fallen off. (compare 落 (#299)).
column4: Each drop of water has been through old Kyoto at some point.

story: One of the modern commandments: "Thou shalt not imagine wet women, dripping in their bathing suits".
column3: "O Romeo, Romeo, wherefore art thou Romeo?" says Juliet, her eyes all watery.
column4: Thou shalt not drink the water that comes from a woman.

story: I filter my water using a deer. Sure I'm a naturalist, but you know what? The filtered yellow "water" tastes MUCH better!
column3: When you go out into the wilderness, you shouldn't drink fresh water no matter how clean and clear it looks. A deer could have just crapped in it a mile upstream. Lesson: Bring some kind of filter to filter your drinking water.
column4: Deer Park water is filtered.

story: Water dripping repeatedly on someone is enough to put them on the verge of insanity.
column3: He was on the verge of a nervous breakdown. He hasn't slept well at all due to water 頻 (#373) dripping from the faucet the all night long.
column4: I was on the verge of wetting myself when she repeatedly showed me her...

story: A moat is a water structure used against something potentially overpowering.
column3: Australia was designed as a moat, surrounded by water, to keep out the overpowering forces of foreign nations.
column4: A MOAT around a castle is filled with WATER and OVERPOWERS an attacking army. AUSTRALIA has an enormous "MOAT" around it whose WATERS OVERPOWER any that would attack it.

story: If you discharge a water gun, it sprays water of course!
column3: To spray is to have water discharged, from, for example, a hose.
column4: Spray some WATER between those LEGS and wash out that DISCHARGE.

story: They started playing music when the ship of the emperor came in sight over the water and was brought into port.
column3: Across the WATER we could hear the band PLAYing MUSIC, actually "Anchors Aweigh," as our ship left PORT.
column4: At the port they play music when you arrive over the water, but not if you arrive by land or air.

story: Picture yourself living in solitude on a tiny island. There are only two trees, and you keep getting splashed by water from sea waves.
column3: Tom Hanks in Castaway living in solitude on an island surrounded by water with just two trees (a grove) for a hammock. (thanks Katsuo).
column4: A water-filled grove is a place of solitude.

story: According to the book of revelations, abounding waters will be the first sign of the apocalypse!
column3: If WATER was able to give a REVELATION of all it's seen, it would be ABOUNDING in all kinds of stories.
column4: A little known fact about cows is that they are pretty much like lemmings. Imagine the waters being abounding with cows (perhaps they're jumping off a cliff), and open their mouth trying to catch their last breath before drowning and sinking down to the bottom (they are horrible swimmers). According to the book of revelations, abounding waters will be the first and last sign of the apocalypse for cows!

story: These spikes mark the water's edge in ancient times. Notice that the water level is actually much lower today.
column3: The water's edge is firmly nailed to the ground with robust spikes... through the water.
column4: If you follow Water Street, it'll take you right to Water's Edge. That's why it's called Water Street.

story: A bird often found near creeks is the large goose.
column3: This is a large goose that has flown into a craft area - aka a construction site. It flies in and sits in a small pond of water and makes itself at home. The construction workers are about to get rid of it when they notice that it makes some really, really terrible honking noises - as a matter of fact, those noises sound just like construction work. They realize that if they keep the large goose around, they can take breaks without their boss realizing!
column4: A lady I know has this character in her last name so I'm going to think of her as mother goose. When I'm up the creek I call this old bird to come and do a bit of translation for me.

story: When the pegasus attacked, we did what we could and soused it: everyone knows that a wet pegasus is a dead pegasus.
column3: Souse the pegasus with water, she likes it.
column4: This pegasus found in ancient times was soused in salty water to preserve it.

story: Water is to the benefit of all live forms, so when a place has a lot of water, you soon see it brimming with life forms.
column3: WATER is brimming with BENEFITS for all living things.
column4: (+brendanmacdonald) Water is brimming with health benefits!

story: Inundation (flooding) is due to a tremendous amount of water.
column3: After the success of Gatorade, Michael Jordan was inundated with requests to do water commercials.
column4: Even though a tremendous amount of water was inundating the place were the tremendous chess game was taking place, the two players sat down calmly and kept playing.

story: The immaculate conception resulted in the tall child who could walk on water.
column3: Water you receive as a gift should be immaculate.
column4: You receive an immaculate blessing with holy water.

story: Before raging wildfires approach the town, homeowners will spray hose water on their roof to moisten the house as a preventative measure.
column3: Obviously, water on a roof will moisten it.
column4: When it's very dry, I sometimes moisten the wooden beams on the roof with water so that they won't completely dry out and crack open.

story: Rough seas are a body of water that is most difficult to travel over.
column3: Rough seas = difficult waters.
column4: 漢 漢 (#1701) turkeys are bred to not get seasick -- so that they are easily shipped to Japan over rough seas.

story: When you draw water you reach out and take the water from the well.
column3: You went to draw water from the well, but the water reached out and grabbed you!
column4: Kanji showing an accident while drawing water from a well. The person is reaching out to the people outside, trying to help him get out of the water.

story: A river pool is a little spot of WATER over on the edge where the water can be QUIET for a while before going back out into the roaring river to flow.
column3: Stare into the quiet water of the river pool, and maybe you'll see the river mermaids.
column4: The water is quiet in the river pool.

story: Water, detain: At the airport, crazy EU customs regulations made that every person carrying water bottles was detained and the water bottles themselves impounded. As you may imagine, in the customs office, there was quite a cumulation of water bottles.
column3: I look up at a cumulonimbus cloud and say “There must be a lot of water detained in that cumulonimbus, quite a cumulation”.
column4: A cumulation of water is detained in a reservoir.

story: Moses threw the golden calf into a nearby abyss, chased the offenders that had worshipped it with a saber, and cleaned the whole spot it had been standing with water as to wash away the sins of these people.
column3: Cornered, the mastadon has two choices: On the left the waters of the abyss, on the right, the hunters' sabres. [*Mastadon primitive from 送 (#2172) by romanrozhok].
column4: The horny St. Bernard got some of its "water" on me, so I used my saber to send it back to the abyss.

story: Chaos theory holds that a single EARTHWORM wriggling can cause huge flows of WATER all over the planet.
column3: People speak of "muddying the waters" or "opening a can of worms" as idioms for creating chaos.
column4: Earthworms go into chaos when there's no water.

story: The strainer exercises prudence on the water, only letting the good water pass.
column3: Prudence always splashes water over the strainer before & after using it. "Just being prudent", she says.
column4: "Always exercise prudence when using a strainer, sometimes the water that's being strained away can be very hot!" Thinks the tiger as he makes some pasta.

story: Those who demand water will be drenched.
column3: When he demanded water from the waitress, she dumped the glass over his head, drenching his clothes.
column4: I DEMAND a COMB for my hair because the RAIN WATER DRENCHED me.

story: If you get caught in an eddy, the water seems determined to pull you in. (Edit: As Sam79's post says, "eddy" isn't a good keyword. This kanji refers to things that stop moving such as water, air, speech, etc. "Stagnate" has been used elsewhere, so maybe "go stale," "stall," or "stop moving" would be suitable keywords. Story: The water reaches a determined position and stops moving).
column3: An eddy is created when water determines it doesn't want to just "go with the flow".
column4: Watch out, I think the keyword gets it wrong - at least I picture something dynamic for eddy - but all the meanings in the dictionary suggest stagnation, dead water and the like. That makes sense ethymologically, we have water that is determined - not do do anything to you, but in the sense that it's situation and location is fixed.

story: This kanji should mean black soil. It is is used for Buddha's death and nirvana (涅槃 (ねはん)). Story: Fabrication of black soil. Use water to wash away other colours and and dry it in the sun (sun over soil).
column3: The soil will turn into black soil after you pour water on it and it sits all day under the sun. This kanji means black soil.
column4: Black soil is nirvana for plants. Just add some water and sun to the soil and you're all set.

story: Father is sitting on top of an axe, and when I ask why he says, “Axe? It’s a hatchet, and I’m trying to hatch it”.
column3: The hatchet is the father of all axes.
column4: There once was a Dwarf lord with a HUGE axe. "This is the father of all axes," he said. "Everything else is but a hatchet."

story: Father!!! My Father exclaimed when he saw my grandpa again. [耶 (#2720)].
column3: My grandpa, the father of my father, often puts his ear agains the city walls to hear what's going on. Well, Alzheimer...
column4: FATHER climbed to the top and made the 耶 (#2720) that he is now a grandpa.

story: The sly criminal gave a skeleton to the pack of wild dogs chasing him.
column3: Sly fox thought he could outsmart the wild dogs, but all they found of him was his skeleton.
column4: Sly & the Family Stone still play like a pack of wild dogs, but over the years the drugs have reduced Sly himself to little more than a skeleton.

story: The indecent man made even the pack of wild dogs 畏 (#2069).
column3: An indecent video featuring a helpless victim taking hairpins in his brain while a pack of wild dogs tears him from limb to limb, has generated calls for compulsory censorship of the internet.
column4: The indecent streaker started to feel a little apprehensive after security set a pack of wild dogs on him. Time to cover the family jewels!

story: You have to have cunning to mingle with a pack of wild dogs and get away unharmed.
column3: The pack of wild dogs put on cunning disguises (Black Adder) and mingled at a party. Their aim; to eat all the party food.
column4: A pack of wild dogs mingle together and perform cunning-lingus.

story: A raccoon dog joined the pack of wild dogs as their computer-literate otaku member with circles around his eyes.
column3: The raccoon dog sends a message to a pack of wild dogs from his computer -- wants to know if he's eligible to join.
column4: raccoon dog = tanuki, the famous flying suit from Super Mario 3! Story: when I'm playing super mario 3 and have the tanuki suit, even a pack of wild dogs couldn't tear me from my computer game console..

story: A pack of wild dogs has to be really good to catch a wolf.
column3: I don't know if "All (wild) dogs go to heaven," but I think this wolf will, because he has a halo.
column4: Pack of wild dogs, halo: In the pack of wild dogs, there is a prophesy. The wild dog that is born with a halo surrounding it will eventually turn into a wolf and lead the pack of wild dogs to victory over mankind.

story: The pack of dogs got all flustered when they tried to open the shellfish with their snouts.
column3: The shellfish flustered the fishermen by pretending to be a pack of wild dogs. "woof woof, grrrrrr".
column4: A pack of wild dogs barks at you startling you into dropping your shells all over the place. You feel flustered as you scramble to pick them all up.

story: Mother dog: “I don't like our pup hanging around with that pack of wild dogs because he picks up all sorts of bad phrases.” Father dog: “Don't worry, he's only a pup – it's just a phrase he's going through”.
column3: "He encountered a pack of dogs" sounds like a scary phrase, until you mention they were all puppies.
column4: The phrase spawning "My little 駒 (#2133)" must have been a big hit. Now there's also "My little puppy". Pack of horses replaced by pack of dogs. Too obvious?

story: A pack of dogs chases a fox who has stolen a melon! Must be a vegetarian fox...
column3: In Japanese folklore the FOX is known for changing shape. This one was being chased by a PACK OF WILD DOGS and passing a garden, changed into a MELON to hide.
column4: In Japanese mythology, foxes often disguise themselves as women. So that foxy lady who has enchanted all the men (which are slobbering over her like wild dogs) with her large melons might be an actual fox!

story: From the pack of wild dogs only white ones are chosen to be a-un (to guard the temple).
column3: Statues of a-un dogs always have pigeons hovering around, so they end up all covered in white stuff.
column4: (These are the lion-dog guards at the front of temples.) And they're always made of WHITE marble depicting the a-un eating a PACK OF WILD DOGS.

story: In "The Lion King," Scar was the expert who did all the scheming, and the three hyenas were his pack of wild dogs that did most of the dirty work.
column3: The pack of wild dogs admire the lion as an expert hunter.
column4: This particular pack of dogs is expert in lion hunting.

story: The hunter employs a pack of dogs to hunt baboons, which he sells to zoos for a lot of dollars.
column3: Baboons like to taunt wild dogs by dangling their dollar sign chains from trees just out of their reach (and occasionally mooning them with their red butts).
column4: Thinking back to the Lion King again, I am reminded of Rafiki, the baboon. In the director's cut, he was a real crazy young thug - he ran around wearing a huge bling $ sign necklace. He was constantly getting chased around by the pack of wild dogs (hyenas), who were as interested in catching him to eat him as they were in taking his stupid blinged-out $ sign necklace. Remember that "Asante Sana, Squash Banana"? That was actually a rap song originally but it got cut...

story: If you smoke these tobacco flowers, you can blow funky smoke halos (rings).
column3: When Sir Walter Raleigh first smoked the flower of the tobacco plant, he said: "Man, this stuff is gooooooood.
column4: If you smoke these tobacco flowers, you'll end up sporting a halo sooner rather than later.

story: If you know someone called Jasmine, then just imagine yourself sticking a flower in her extremity.
column3: The jasmine flowers are exceptionally strong scented, and you can smell it the whole day if you rub them on an extremity of your body, like a hand.
column4: Just giving her flowers wasn't enough. The suitors had to go to great extremities to court Jasmine - magic carpet rides, etc.

story: Thanks to Nathaniel Hawthorne, the hawthorn flower is now profitable.
column3: A hawthorn is a flower that stands in the way of profit as it has to be taken out of the wheat fiels by farmers.
column4: Yasmin flowers (Jasminum sambac or Arabian Jasmine) are sold at great profit, because is it cheap to grow and it makes a wonderful addition to tea.

story: The strawberry plant is one that mothers really like. Not particularly for its flowers, but for the fruit of course, so they can make fresh strawberry pies.
column3: Most people eat the fruit of the strawberry plant, but your mother eats the flowers.
column4: Flowers over breasts...look like strawberries!

story: Bush clover flowers in autumn.
column3: The bush clover is a special flower which was dedicated to bush when he won the presidency in Autumn.
column4: From the Japanese Wikipedia page for bush clover: ハギ（萩）とは、マメ科ハギ属の総称。落葉低木。秋の七草のひとつで、花期は7月から10月。 So the bush clover really does flower in autumn, as suggested by its kanji.

story: Its the oldest technique in the book. When surrounded by the evil rice seedling forces (they have gathered all around the ground around you), you dispense a cloud of rising smoke from your feet, and disappear, leaving only flowers behind.
column3: A technique that can produce 熱 (#1634) without using a fire? That's an old technique that anyone can do!
column4: MARIO uses the OLDEST TECHNIQUES in the book... fireball FLOWERS and running on CLOUDS is so 80's.

story: Get a 雉 (#2584) to trim your flowers for you.
column3: This lawn doesn't need just a trim. With flowers and weeds so thick I have pheasants nesting in it, it needs to be mowed down.
column4: Wtf trim? Using "mow down" as keyword. Picture a pheasant massacre where all the pheasants were mowed down and now flowers have been placed there to commemorate the event.

story: Flower, decline: After your flowers have declined (i.e., lost their bloom), you can always use the remains to weave a straw raincoat. It's all about recycling these days...
column3: Looking for a job at a florist during bad weather, I was forced to wear my pauper's straw raincoat. Predictably, I was declined at every flower shop I found.
column4: Flowery raincoats are on the decline, with straw raincoats now coming into fashion.

story: Flowers can be seen on the pedestal covered with moss.
column3: Moss is a flower that usually grows on "pedestals", like rocks, trees, and the like.
column4: Most people throw flowers on pedestals after a great performance, however a strange person in the audience started throwing moss instead.

story: When the prodigal son returned, he was greeted with flowers and hot water for tea by his mum.
column3: The prodigal son thought he was going to be in hot water when he went home after wasting his family's money, but instead they greeted him with flowers.
column4: It would be prodigal to water flowers with hot water: What a waste of energy!

story: The alien plant from outer space flowered and started drawing mandala's on the ground with its tendrils as a way of communication.
column3: In a tentacle rape hentai, Sailor Mars uses her Burning Mandala attack to fight away the tendrils attempting to deflower her.
column4: If you show a mandala to a flower it will cross its tendrils into the lotus position.

story: A lotus can either be a flower, or else something that takes you along (the car make).
column3: Lotus can be either a flower or a car on the road.
column4: Way too easy! Lotus, as in the really expensive, fast car. Whenever I want to take someone somewhere (連れる）, I make sure to rent a Lotus so that I can arrive to pick them up in style. I'm a great customer of the local car rental shop, so they always make sure to give me a flower when I pick up my Lotus.

story: There's a popular myth amongst flower girls that the face of their future husband is hidden inside a lotus flower.
column3: [+woelpad] In a certain culture, there is a ritual carried out when a girl is quite young (young enough, in fact, that they do it before they are considered a woman in that culture - for the same reason that some cultures do not name a baby until they are sure it will live) - she must go on a vision quest for a lotus flower and look inside it to see the face of her husband - then report back.. Imagine a poor flower girl's dismay when she looks into the lotus flower and sees the face of Homer Simpson!
column4: A romantic husband presents his wife with a single lotus flower.

story: Those little flower buds contain a whole lotus blossom when they grow bigger.
column3: Lotus blossom flowers are highly prized because they contain lots of nectar.
column4: (Continued) This little flower girl eagerly waits for her lotus to blossom and reveal its secret. Will it contain what she expects?

story: The orchid thief tries to steal exotic flowers from the east, only to be stopped customs at the departure gate * 蘭 【らん】orchid.
column3: Note: I changed the keyword to Dutch because this is also the kanji used in Japanese for the Netherlands. I needed a break from all the flower types. Story: Nagasaki was opened up to Dutch traders in Japan, making it the only gate to the East at that time. As a result of the additional trade, both the Dutch and Japanese economies flowered.
column4: When the people of the Netherlands brought orchids east to Tokyo, the citizens of Tokyo opened up their gates to let the Dutch in. Apparently they've always had a weakness for orchids in the east.

story: You must play a tune using a hollow reed, to open the secret door hidden beneath the flowers.
column3: Ancient superstition requirs you to adorn your door with hollow reed and flowers, but nobody knows the purpose anymore.
column4: I was sitting in my house when all of a sudden the SWAT team came through and teargassed my apartment! I couldn't breathe, but no way was I going to go outside and get shot! Thinking quickly, I grabbed one of the hollow reeds I'd bought at the garden shop and stuck it under the back door and breathed deeply. The SWAT team was at the front - they'd never suspect a thing. But I forgot I'd just finished planting flowers in the back and sucked one in, clogging the hollow reed...oh no...

story: A yam has a signature flower that differentiates it from a sweet potato.
column3: The signature flower of Ireland: the yam! Speaking of which, how are yams different from potatoes?
column4: 甘薯, 薯童謡, 薯童説話, 薯 (#2451) ショ(署), いも ... Parts:艹, 署署 (#1349) (cf 曙dawn (#2448), 夢夢 (#327)) ... note: Sweet Potato is written with any of these: 芋芋 (#1784), 薯薯 (#2451), 藷藷 (#2482), 蕷. No reason other than RTK testing to know one from another. ... Story:The Signature Plant of Southern Japan is the Sweet Potato, and this is the old Chinese way of writing it.

story: Only prosperous people (picture someone with a lot of bling) can afford to have iris flowers in the house regularly. They're too expensive for daily use.
column3: Most people don't realize this, but there is a very specific biological reason that the iris flower has flowers that split into two main petal groups that generally face two completely different directions. The reason is that the iris flower was brought over from another solar system many light years away that had two suns. Thus, one petal group would face one sun, while the other petal group would face the other sun.
column4: You become so prosperous selling flowers (irises) you buy Van Gogh's famous painting "Irises" and hang in in your flower shop.

story: Like the fruit itself, banana flowers look charred as they age.
column3: Charred bananas on a bed of flowers are a delicacy that stir up images of a tropic island.
column4: Perfect. This is a Hawaiian Luau. You cook meat by building a fire, putting food wrapped in banana leaves in, and then burying the whole thing with sand. The person here has their own original recipe. They use Turkey instead of the traditional pork and put banana flowers on top. The fire is underneath the turkey.

story: I gave the angel a flower. In return she gifted me with a year's supply of buckwheat to feed my family.
column3: "Buckwheat's been shot! Buckwheat's been shot!" At his funeral, attended by the rest of Our Gang, Buckwheat is placed in his coffin covered by flowers. An angel is also present, and says "Its O-tay Buckwheat, you have been invited up to heaven!"
column4: Grain from the buckwheat plant can be used for some angelically tasting cakes.

story: In Aikita, the butterbur grow so huge that they use them to line public walking paths. The large flowers at the top (don't get it confused - they may look like leaves, but they are really just broad, green flowers) provide shade and make for a very pleasant public path way. Check it: http://hojinashi.cocolog-nifty.com/photos/uncategorized/101.jpg.
column3: Butterbur flowers can be seen along the path.
column4: A Butterbur is a plant, but also, in LOTR, Butterbur is the name of the owner of the Prancing Pony. The hobbits met him on their path to Mount Doom.

story: Eggplant is a low カロrie flower (thanks Peppi).
column3: An eggplant is a flower with almost no 加ries...
column4: An eggplant is a flower with almost no 加ries... And because it doesn't have much flavor, it can be added to almost any dish! (thanks to peppi).

story: Behind the scenes, in the shady areas, they trade various flowers: oh, yeah, gather 'round the good stuff!
column3: Behind the scenes, in the shady areas, it is very difficult to grow flowers. But thanks to you (御蔭で) we were able to do it. Now we are smoking them behind the scenes (thx Megaqwerty and herman).
column4: Hint: This one is identical in meaning and pronunciation (as well as it's use in compounds) to shade itself, so calling it shade (old) seems reasonable.

story: You bring a wormwood flower to a 逢 (#2497) for the bitter parting at the end.
column3: Wormwood brings very, very vivid and hallucinogenic dreams. You eat some of the intoxicating flowers of the wormwood with your girlfriend...and in your high state of mind, decide that it would be a good idea to do it in the bushes on the side of Mario Kart Road. Suddenly, in the middle of it, she starts tripping out, and runs through the bushes into the middle of the track, while they are racing...and is killed. Imagine waking up from that dream...or was it a dream? Sticks for me anyway.
column4: I had a 逢 (#2497) with a party girl who gave me wormwood FLOWERS and we both tripped all night.

story: Mustard has a lot of flavor jammed in to its flowers.
column3: Mustard is a plant that jams in all its taste into its mustard seeds.
column4: In the whodunit board game "Cluedo" ("Clue"), Colonel Mustard is found with a flower jammed in him.

story: You need a lot of bright light to germinate flowers.
column3: Bud, Moe girls are cute as flowers with their bright smiles. ― Note:You'll see this often as 萌え[moe] which is something cute you have a crush on. The beginning word, bud (plant related), is actually one of the keyword meanings this kanji has.
column4: FLOWERS need BRIGHT light to germinate.

story: Grapes are totally a conspiracy, I'm telling you. They're pretty little plants with flowers that grow in clusters, and they are sweet, I know, but...Bound up in each little grape (the skin is like a wrapping) is a tiny RFID tag that the government uses to spy on you. That's why they sell them in such large quantities for so cheap - if you "pass" a few of them out, no matter - odds are that at least one will stay inside you. They especially push them on kids.
column3: My offspring ate all the grapes off the 萄 (#2462)!
column4: This wine isn't made from grapes, but from flowers! This means it's only fit for a dog to drink, so the bottle is bound up with a dog tag to make it clear.

story: "I heard it through the grape vine"' using a pair of tin cans bound together to form a 糸電話 hidden amongst the flowers.
column3: I WRAPPED a large 缶 (#2116) to a grape vine, under the FLOWERS of the grape vine, so that grapes fall directly into the 缶 (#2116) when they are ripe.
column4: Tin cans are bound up by the grape vine plants.

story: Famous resurrection: Jesus. There's the fish and loaves of wheat bread he's got under his arms and flowers in his hair.
column3: Fish are used (as fertilizer) to resurrect your wheat to a flowering state.
column4: When christ resurrected, they showered him with flowers, and he showered them with fishes and loaves (wheat). 蘇る【よみがえる】(v5r,vi) to be resurrected,to be revived,to be resuscitated,to be rehabilitated *.

story: First the flowers grow up, but if you aren't attentive, they have a tendency to grow wild, playing dice out in the garden to kill time. A bad seed, indeed. Flowers grown wild!
column3: Some kids playing the board game Jumanji throw the dice, and as a result, flowers suddenly begin to grow wild all around them.
column4: Robbin Williams rolls the JUMANJI dice, and man eating flowers start growing wild .

story: A truly invasive parasite, the cocklebur is a flower that attaches itself to its namesake and proceeds to order the host around, the poor guy.
column3: When cocklebur flowers get stuck in your socks and shoelaces while bushwalking, you have to order everyone to stop and wait while you pick them out.
column4: I order you not to giggle at this flower's name, "cocklebur"! You're being immature!

story: Orphans sleep on the flowers of a rush mat.
column3: Rush Limbaugh criticized orphans and flower children on his show. So one group of orphans began selling "Rush Mats"--doormats with Rush Limbaugh's picture on them so people could wipe their feet on Rush's face before they went into the house. "If our parents were still alive, they would be proud," the orphans said.
column4: On my elegant rush mat I laid down flowers and an orphan named Lolita ..wait. what?

story: Flower, crown, one, sow: Each year, just before Christmas, one sow is selected among many to wear a crown adorned with flowers. Unknowing of her fate, there is a party in her honor that evening. Near the end, the lights suddenly darken and a lot of noise can be heared. When the lights go on again, the sow has been slaughtered and is ready to be baked for Christmas dinner.
column3: Miss Piggy has entered the Miss Universe pageant. Only one sow will get the crown, when the lights darken, Miss Piggy accepts the flowers as she is announced the winner!
column4: 損害を蒙る, 蒙る=被る, 蒙古, 蒙昧, 啓蒙, 蒙 (#2384) モウ, こうむる (usu 被る被 (#807)) ... Parts: 艹, 冖, 一, 豕 ... Note: Kanji for Mongolia ... Oregum remix: Mongolians have Darkened skins because they wear no Crowns, are never under Ceilings, but spend their time outdoors tending their Roses and Pigs.

story: There are two methods for swimming up on your enemy unnoticed. A ninja using a grassy reed, making sure the flower is first removed, will approach stealthily. A warriors scabbard, once the halberd is removed, can also substitute for a breathing tube in a pinch.
column3: Grassy reeds are plants useful for thatching. Be careful though, the leaf tips can be as sharp as a halberd. Careful with 荻 (#257), 芦 (#2450) and 葦 (#2491).
column4: The knight can't stand the grassy reed plants that are constantly invading his garden. I mean, they look nice in nature and everything, but they do not belong in his flower bed! If you've ever tried to pull them, though, you know that it's pretty tough to grasp them - generally you only get the "hairy" flower part on top and leave the actual stem. No worries - he gets his huge halberd and just lays waste to his whole garden - flowers, grassy reeds, and all.

story: A plantain is a flowering fruit that looks kind of like a banana, and of course bananas look sort of like a comma, so you might even say that they have a sort of comma-design.
column3: Southern cities in Europe often have plantains for street decoration. The light filtering through these plants makes for a nice light mosaic on the streets.
column4: Little known fact is that the RUBIC'S CUBE was inspired by PLANTAIN FLOWERS. The flowers are very colorful and kids in third world countries routinely pick them and play puzzle games with them. The Rubic's Cube founder saw this and it sparked the idea that turned him into a billionaire...

story: You reap what flowers you mow. (thanks synewave).
column3: Before you mow the lawn, first quickly reap any flowers growing it, otherwise they'll just go to waste.
column4: Reap what you mow.

story: The onion is a plant that has such spicy fumes, that you have to cry as if your heart is in a double knot.
column3: The ONION is a type of FLOWER (bulb) that makes you INSTANTANEOUSLY cry a DROP of tear. Just remember the DROP goes on the KNOT.
column4: This is ねぎ (japanese bunching onion). Story: Formerly they thought the onion plant was not good for your heart. When they found out it wasn't true they stroke the "not" out (not true).

story: The hollyhock is a flower that can grow as large as a teepee. It almost reaches to heaven.
column3: In American Indian mythology there is a "Jack and the Beanstalk" counterpart. It's a long story but basically it involves a hollyhock which reached up to heaven where a boy built a teepee. It then flowered. The end.
column4: The hollyhock is the favourite flower of porn star 葵(あおい)ぶるま. I went to visit her at her latest film shoot. On Japanese porn sets stars don't have trailers but rather teepees and so I went to visit 葵ぶるまちゃん with some hollyhock flower for her. She was delighted, placed the flower above the entrance to her teepee and then invited me into her teepee, where she took me to heaven.

story: When shingling with flowers, they can often block up your mouth and ears unless you wear the proper safety gear.
column3: Flower, deaf: The deaf guy was shingling the roof of his house with flowers (ecohouse). Being deaf was an advantage since he didn't hear the comment of his neighbours.
column4: There I was, shingling my home with FLOWERS, when my next door neighboor opened his MOUTH. "What are you doing shingling you roof with FLOWERS?" "Listen!" I said, "Its my house and I will shingle it with what I want!!!"

story: A male flower attracts many hearts with its stamen.
column3: The flower with the biggest stamen (male reproductive organ) will break hearts everywhere. True for flowers, true for people.
column4: This flower's stamen is so manly that it has three hearts.

story: My mother used to joke that if I didn't wash my ears properly, mushroom plants would be growing out of them.
column3: I took mushrooms and saw flowers sprouting from my friend's ears.
column4: After eating too many MUSHROOMS I stuck FLOWERS in my EARS and ran around yelling that I am going to save the planet.

story: All it takes is time to get flowers after sowing seeds.
column3: After sowing seeds it will take TIME before FLOWERS grow.
column4: It's flower sowing time!

story: The axe murderer glares at his flower garden victims "First Parsley, Sage, Rosemary, and Thyme!"
column3: Cooking for Cannibals: Sprinkling a freshly chopped parsley flower onto your axe before cutting up those helpless victims is a great way to add a little zest to your dishes.
column4: ...Next all we need to do is finely chop some parsley plant using a sharp axe.
