story: The thatching of the old thatched roofs in rural Japan often has FLOWERS growing out of it when it's gotten weathered. So you can pluck them and use them like tea leaves to tell your FORTUNE.
column3: The fortuneteller wants the thatching of his roof done with flowers instead of reeds.
column4: Flowers form the thatching over the local fortune-teller.

story: The godown was filled with pale blue flowers, probably some drug...
column3: If you give her pale blue flowers, she'll godown on you every time.
column4: 蒼天, 蒼生, 暮色蒼然, 蒼白, 蒼い=青い, 蒼惶として= 倉皇として, 古色蒼然たる 蒼 (#2479) ソウ(倉), あおい ... Parts: 艹, 倉倉 (#1758) (cf. 創造創 (#1759)) ... Similars: 青い青 (#1654), 蒼い蒼 (#2479), 瑠璃瑠 (#1528) ... Story: If you have Pale Blue eyes in Japan, you can deFlower lots of girls, and lots of girls will Go Down on you.

story: When a giant drinks a cocktail, he needs a straw of large proportions. He hollows out a tall tree for the straw, and sticks a giant flower on the rim of his drink.
column3: Story of three little pigs. First one built a house out of straw but it got blown down. Second one built a house out of flowers but it got blown down. Third one built a tall house out of wood. It was so tall, when the wolf blew it it fell back on the wolf, killing him instantly. The end.
column4: A flower that is as tall as a tree. STRAW.

story: Turnip flowers? Gross, but at least it's better than nothing to eat.
column3: Turnips just taste like nothing to me.
column4: If you have ever played Super Mario Bros. 2, then you know that the flower you pull from the ground to reduce all your enemies to nothingness is the TURNIP!

story: The sweet potato is a plant that can be used in various dishes quite well.
column3: The sweet potato is a plant that has various names. (So don't get it confused with "yam").
column4: The sweet potato is a flower that comes in various forms: orange, purple, etc.

story: I don't even know where Heisig got this keyword from. Using "thicket" instead: Picture a thicket with a large number of flowers.
column3: Notes: Keyword "quack" was presumably chosen due to its use in the compound 薮医者, but the general meaning of this kanji is bush/thicket. Also note that it mostly appears in its alternate form: 藪.
column4: The idiot savant was thought to be a quack because he couldn't help but count the number of flowers he saw.

story: In the temple were two altars. One of them had the usual array of fl0wers, but the other was adorned with garlic, so that the locals could pray to keep the vampires out.
column3: Garlic flowers were placed on the two altars of the small village that had been ravaged by vampires in an attempt to drive them away.
column4: It really amuses me that garlic is called にんにく. So here we have two altars in the human-vampire war. One of them is the vampire hunters' altar, covered in garlic flowers (for obvious reasons) and the other one belongs to the vampires, where they drink blood and eat... well... 人肉...

story: After eating all the BRACKEN FLOWERS on the CLIFF, the MOUNTAIN GOAT belts out a huge YAWN and takes a nap. Unfortunately he never wakes up as the BRACKEN is highly carcinogenic to mountain goats....
column3: Bracken is a flower that grows on cliffs and resembles a fish spine lacking stability.
column4: This is the name of a city (わらび) in Saitama. The kanji is so difficult to write, the city government sells a t-shirt with the stroke order: http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/news/20090702p2a00m0na004000c.html.

story: Military officers make for good fertilizer. So after a war the flowers in the military officer's graveyard grow plentiful.
column3: This reminds me of the old Peter, Paul and Mary anti-war song, "Where have all the flowers gone?" The final verse talks about the graveyards of military officers being the place where flowers grow plentiful.
column4: The military officer ensures his flowers grow plentiful, because he will need a huge amount of them to offer 慰 (#1177) when his soldiers die.

story: Madder red is an extract from a flower which was used as fake blood in western films.
column3: Madder red is a colouring agent that is acquired out of the roots of plants that grow in the west.
column4: Madder is a flowering plant, the roots of which are used as a coloring agent. The dyeing technique of madder red was formed in Turkey and India, both of which are west of Japan. ^^ A good historical explanation of madder red is here: http://www.colorantshistory.org/MadderRed.html . Botanical information: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madder .

story: The candle rush doesn't bloom often, but when it does, the flowers must be perfect.
column3: There was a candle rush because these scented candles were perfect, smelling just like real flowers.
column4: I prefer using "smiling" as keyword. Imagine her smile when you give her the perfect flowers.

story: Debt collectors will even hustle ghosts for the flowers on their bodies' graves.
column3: This demon is a bit of an oddball, he's a collector of rare flowers, most of the time you can seem him trawling the graveyards looking for species that he doesn't yet have.
column4: A bad-ass demon slayer who collects demon heads... and flowers.

story: Sedge is a flower (plant) that looks like grass, much like bureaucrats look a lot like real humans.
column3: Sedge is a very "boring" flower. It just looks like grass. So who would have such a flower in his house but the bureaucrats?
column4: The bureaucrats wanted all the sedge plants in the district counted. Whatever will they think of next...

story: After breaking up with her boyfriend and ditching him, she threw the flowers and locket he gave her into the ditch reeds.
column3: THANK GOD THIS IS THE LAST OF THE FLOWER KANJI IN RTK3. There were 65 of them! Time to ditch all these reeds, and seal all of these flowers away in the locket of your mind.
column4: The lost locket was found between the flowers of the ditch reed.

story: Imagine a trail of brussel sprouts along a road. You follow it, picking up each sprout and eating it as you go along. Eventually, after the last sprout, you find your reward – a milky Way.
column3: A road magically sprouts up to show the chosen ones onto the Way.
column4: (Inspired by Katsuo) Imagine an old master teaching you the "Way of the sprout, by making you eat all the sprouts along the sprout road.

story: When you're following someone along a road high atop a mountain, it is easy to track them down, since all tracks lead down.
column3: Despite travelling all the mountain roads and paths, no one could track down the Yeti.
column4: It was easy to track down the criminal hiding in the mountains, because he built a road leading straight to his hideout.

story: There are words written on the road, but you have to crawl along to read them: 'If...you...can...read...this...you...look...silly...'
column3: Some of those amateur marathon runners at the end seem merely to crawl on the road instead of running. They truly need words of encouragement.
column4: Socrates, unused to running the marathon, crawls pathetically down the road.

story: Due to potatoes in the road, there was a detour.
column3: A truck had spilt its load of potatoes on the road, forcing us to make a detour.
column4: When you're on the road to Sydney, take a detour via Robertson, NSW, to see the Big Potato (affectionately known as the Big Turd). http://www.australiantraveller.com/component/content/article/2227.

story: It really eludes me why we have two kanji with the same keyword... this one and 逸 (#1973). But lets intertwine their stories: The rabbit, who eluded capture (逸 (#1973)) on the road, was finally caught when someone threw a shield over it.
column3: The Spartan had to block the road to stop the advancing enemy army, but he tried to shirk his duty and threw away his shield. That's suicide.
column4: With 逸 (#1973) already taken, Heisig changed the keyword for this one to shirk (= elude responsibility) in the 2nd edition. [from Corodon] STORY: Imagine a pre-battle speech, "Down that road lies the enemy, raise your shields and do not shirk (elude your responsibility)". You can imagine the rest... "If you find yourself alone... riding in green fields with the sun on your face. Do not be troubled... for you are in Elysium, and you're already dead!"

story: Going out on the road to use a pointy (see my comments in 峰 峰 (#1562)) part of my anatomy, is called a tryst.
column3: While I was having a tryst with my secret lover on the road, I had to quickly run towards the bushes with my walking legs, because my husband suddenly appeared.
column4: Seeing pubic hair on the road is a sure sign of a lovers' tryst! (巡り逢う).

story: On the long long road through the desert, far off you can see a condor flying...
column3: The condor might seem like its far off in the distance now, but if you don't start running down the road you could be dinner.
column4: After the condor picked me up from the swing, I rode through the sky, gripping his talons. Eventually, he dropped me on some far off road. Then I saw him flying into the far off distance. How the hell am I going to get home?

story: (From astridtops) Faraway (2nd edition keyword) from civilisation, there are no camping sites, so you can see people in a pup tent near the road doing some wild camping instead.
column3: When I was lost faraway from home, I put up a pup tent on the side of the road so that people driving by could see me.
column4: Here we have bonfire [see 尞] lit along the road in order to help to guide travellers to their as yet faraway/remote destination. Once the bonfire is in sight travellers can breath a sigh of relief, because, although their goal remains 前途遼遠(ぜんとりょうえん), that is to say quite faraway/remote, at least they can see the bonfire at at the end of the road, so to speak.

story: When the wealthy go on the road, they always pretend to be pursuing pressing matters, so they speed along in their big BMW's.
column3: Those with wealth speed down the road as if they have some pressing matter to attend.
column4: The wealthy drive with the utmost arrogance and aggression when they're on the road, because they act like their daily tasks are much more pressing than anyone else's.

story: Beg in the road until you get what you want.
column3: Hitchhiking: You stand by the road, stick out your thumb, and beg for a ride until someone picks you up.
column4: He won't learn his lesson until he's begging on the streets.

story: The negotiations had reached a complete standstill. To try and get things moving again the meeting table was placed in the middle of a busy road! That should do the trick!
column3: I ripped a huge bean fart, bringing our road trip to a standstill.
column4: The traffic on the ROAD is at a standstill because someone left a bunch of TABLES laying there.

story: A St. Bernard balances a bottle of horned whiskey on his nose to get it over the city walls as a courtesy to his exiled master.
column3: (Tip: Horns + whiskey bottle = Red Bull (see shakkun's story on 猶 (#1438)). Story: Please do not feed Red Bull to the St Bernard, as a courtesy to all of us who live within the city walls. Last time someone did that, he caused chaos everywhere and nearly destroyed the city walls.
column4: The 酋 酋 (#2906) and his St. Bernard practice common courtesy at the city walls: Every newcomer is kissed ardently. The women by the chieftain, the men by the dog.

story: Working at The Pinnacle in not easy. The only vacation the employees got was when a meteorite fell on The Pinnacle.
column3: The pinnacle's employees started a new business there - they grouped a few telescopes to let people visiting the site stare at the meteorites during meteorite showers. See how the employees are watching over the customers, making sure they don't break anything.
column4: plummet: The pinnacle is a dangerous place to work and every so often you see one of the employees plummet. (Notes: (1) The most common compound is 隕石（いんせき）, meteorite. (2) As of edition 3, 隕 appears in RTK3 with keyword "falling").

story: On the pinnacle of the secret government organisation, every nook and cranny of the pinnacle is under government control, even the ricefields. You can't even drop a hairpin there without being noticed.
column3: Those apprehensive when they reach the pinnacle often find a nook to hide in.
column4: (+astridtops) Every nook and cranny of The Pinnacle is under government surveillance. It gives people a good reason to feel apprehensive about visiting.

story: I entered the stable and felt an icy chill. Yes, that horse is possessed and the only way to deal with it is a stake in the heart!
column3: The frozen horse still had a heart beat, it must be possessed!
column4: "Is this thing possessed?" the Trojans wondered when they first encountered the Greek's trojan horse. "It feels ice cold but there's definitely a beating heart inside".

story: You have to be young at heart to attract the opposite sex.
column3: Take just one look at the junior idol video industry (or don't!) in Japan to understand how the young attract the hearts of the Japanese. ;-).
column4: Contrast with 嬌 (#461). Think of attract the verb as specific procedures or actions taken to attract the opposite sex. The young and foolish think that pouring out your heart is the way to attract the opposite sex, but more mature lovers realize that restraint, mystery and coyness do much more to attract a partner. Remember, attract the verb: things you do; behaviors that may change over time. (not the adjective 嬌 (#461)).

story: Without exception, the heart of every hunter starts beating like crazy as he comes upon the tracks of an animal.
column3: If you get addicted to playing dice (番）without exception you will end up losing your rice fields (田） so take my warning to heart.
column4: Furries, people whose hearts beat like crazy when they see animal tracks, are despised by all other factions/fandoms without exception.

story: His heart got tied in a knot and he died instantaneously.
column3: Instead of Blood Clot, think of Blood KNOT, where if you get a Blood KNOT that goes to your HEART, you will die INSTANTANEOUSLY.
column4: A HEART will NOT instantaneously heal, forget, or get better.

story: The caveman, introducing his firstborn son: "And this is thing with heart. Come yesterday from woman's stomach."
column3: Everyone wants their firstborn son to have a good heart and a big "thing".
column4: 惣菜=総菜, 惣嫁=総嫁, 惣社=総社, 惣 (#2510) ソウ, 名乗り: おさむ, のぶ, ふさ) ... Parts:物物 (#1129), 心 ... Note: This does not mean first born son, that is 長男. It is a name firstborn sons are often given. Other than name uses, this character is interchangeable with, and largely replaced by 総総 (#1466). ... Story: Firstborn Sons are in General, such important Things that Knot having one first is like a punch in the Solar Plexus 心.

story: Nick XXX needs a heart transplant quick. He goes to a meeting of butchers where one of them is about to chop up an ideal heart. Nick snatches away the heart from under the butcher’s knife – just in the nick of time. (note: replace XXX with a Nick you know).
column3: The guy who had a heart attack at the butcher's meeting was saved in the nick of time.
column4: To ensure healing 癒, you must banish the sickness 疒 in the nick of time.

story: "forgive" is a better keyword for this. A woman forgives with her mouth, but it has to come from the heart.
column3: He's very sensitive about that sculpture, as it captures the likeness of the woman of his heart.
column4: Be careful with a woman's heart, as well as her opening, because they're both very sensitive.

story: In this astrological tempel, a sun is depicted, overarching the Sign of the Hare.
column3: When the sun shines during the sign of the hare the hares go mad and have an overarching desire to jump over arches. Edit: More useful keyword: Main use of this kanji is for the star cluster "The Pleiades" (すばる in Japanese). Story: Which star cluster is The Pleiades? Well look closely and you can see a hare hopping from one sun to another.
column4: This is the kanji for the Pleiades star cluster, read in Japanese as すばる. It's also a male and female given name. The car manufacturer gets its name from this. Story: The sign of the hare in the Chinese zodiac refers, among other things, to the time of day corresponding to 5-7am. This is the time of day when the sun rises, overarching the world with its magnificence and power. (For an extra visual image, imagine the sun rising behind a giant pair of hare's ears.)

story: The churches teach that if we eliminate horniness as a universal trait, we can make progress as a society.
column3: Is read シン and refers to the Jin (or Tsin) Dynasty in China in the 3rd century. Then there was a Later Jin Dynasty and other Jins using the character 金. Appears in name of Shansi province. Appears in names like PM 安倍晋三. Otherwise, it's a useless kanji! Why is it here? Are we studying Chinese now?
column4: Thinking of “The Pilgrim’s Progress”, imagine the pilgrim is stuck outside the universe 普, trying to get in. But the universe is surrounded by horns which block his path. Once he removes the horns from the universe, then he can make progress.

story: When the sun comes up and sets the sky aglow, night turns into day.
column3: The SUN TURNS the sky aglow.
column4: If our SUN TURNS INTO a supernova, it and we will be all AGLOW.

story: My halo is as bright as the sun, and is actually made from a wheel I pulled off a chariot.
column3: The sun, high above us, was according to ancient Greeks the chariot of a god, and the halo of this chariot are the rays of the sun.
column4: Helios, the Greek god of the SUN, would drive his CHARIOT across the sky each day. It only makes sense that Helios would have a HALO on his head.

story: Every day, the chariot of the god glitters as it moves from from east to west.
column3: The sun GLITTERS off the side of the chariot.
column4: The army hires a fashion designer to update their image. The designer sprays the army's tanks with glitter so they'll be more trendy. Trouble is, the sides of the army's tanks catch the sun and make it look like the sun is driving through town.

story: Dry weather is of course good drying weather, so everyone puts their clotheslines out under the sun.
column3: Excessive SUN has caused DRY weather.
column4: Cloudy weather is to cloud as dry weather is to dry.

story: Under the sun and the clear skies, you can really relax.
column3: When there are clear skies above you, you can relax under the sun.
column4: The sun is up. The skies are clear. The guys are out of town. Relax. There'll be no 宴 (#203) today.

story: The ancient villain in the Bruce Lee movies said to Bruce: "In the morrow, when the sun is high in the sky, I will feed you to my pet crocodiles".
column3: Bruce Lee waits for the sun of the morrow to begin a showdown.
column4: According to the prophecy, on the MORROW, the sun will be over the sign of the dragon.

story: In the Old West, the sun was the only method for bleaching hair.
column3: Sun, west: The Japanese like to bleach their hairs until these shine in the sun. It has to do with their obsession for the West.
column4: In the old west everything got bleached naturally in the sun. There was no need to use chemicals. 晒す (さらす): to expose (to the air, to the public, to danger, etc.); to bleach; to refine 晒 (さらし): bleaching, bleached cotton 未晒パルプ (みさらしぱるぷ): unbleached pulp 店晒し (たなざらし): shopworn goods; dead stock; shelf warmer 晒し者 (さらしもの): exposed to public view; public scorn or public humiliation.

story: The sun's rays passed through to the very bottom of the limpid pond.
column3: If something is limpid (meaning clear, transparent, free of obscurity), then, by definition, the rays of the sun can shine down through it.
column4: The sun's rays can be seen in a limpid liquid.

story: An outburst of sun is a good time to air out your things.
column3: Being suddenly blinded by the sun, a crew member of the International Space Station (ISS) has an outburst after losing an important round in Counter-Strike, he accidentally hits the button for the vents and let the air out.
column4: Annoying child had a yellow balloon with a sunny face on it. I had a sharp object. Air out indeed, a complete outburst. I refuse to apologise.

story: At DAWN, the SUN starts it's DAY of work, yes? So doesn't it need to SIGN IN with with SIGNATURE? Just picture that silly image for this kanji.
column3: I go out at the crack of dawn to buy a newspaper (The Sun), and bump into ex-sumo wrestler Akebono (曙) who is doing the same. Of course I ask for his signature on my copy of The Sun, which he signs "Dawn (Akebono)".
column4: The sun puts its signature on the day at dawn.

story: Sending mail to the sun. It would take a whole box of stamps to elevate it that high.
column3: A sunny day to a depressed person is just like a box of stamps to a stamp otaku: both have the ability to elevate spirits!
column4: This is kind of odd, but it works for me. The sun has stopped working, so we put it in a box, put some postal stamps on it, and send it up an elevator to God in hopes that he will fix it soon.

story: At dusk every day I go out in one of those airplanes that leaves a vapour trail and write my family name just above the setting sun. (I have to wait until dusk so that the sun is low enough in the sky).
column3: The WOMAN abandoned her 婚 (#1830) as soon as dusk came.
column4: Once dusk hits, my family name is more fearsome then the sun itself. We are vampire hunters.

story: Every month, there is one day that is the last day of the month.
column3: If only every day could be the last day of the month, I'd be filing for paychecks all the time.
column4: The last DAY of EVERY month is the LAST DAY OF THE MONTH.

story: If your flesh gets stung by the thorns of certain plants while doing agriculture work, your wound may infect and show pus.
column3: Forget Manure, the best thing for agriculture is pus, freshly squeezed from some rancid flesh.
column4: PUS happens when there's an attempt to turn a PART OF THE BODY/FLESH into AGRICULTURE (or to turn part of the CORPUS into a CAMPUS).

story: That municipality is so unsafe, thugs will attack you and cut the viscera out of your flesh to sell them on the black organs market.
column3: Your viscera are like a municipality of body parts working together with different roles.
column4: Viscera are parts of the body that adhere to the cave-like walls of your abdomen.

story: It starts in the bladder, passes through a certain body part and then appears like a ray of golden light!
column3: The part of the body that golden rays of light seem to pour out from.
column4: 腎 kidney The bladder is FLESH that needs emptying at the first RAYS of the sun.

story: When she took the pregnancy test because she thought she was carrying the flesh of an embryo, the test was negative and she dropped it on the floor.
column3: When a baby is born, he or she is considered "age zero". After a year of life, he or she is only then considered one year old. Since an embryo is found within a woman, it is effectively part of the body of that person. However, it is not yet zero years old - in fact, its age is negative one (i.e. -1 years old)! 胚性幹細胞　－　はいせいかんさいぼう　＝　embryonic stem cell.
column4: Miscarriage: When the embryo didn't grow into flesh, its pulse was negative and it fell out onto the floor.

story: The anus is the part of the body where crafty smugglers often hide small valuables.
column3: Mooning is the craft of baring one's anus.
column4: The body part I was always told a new one would be crafted for me (albeit in the less friendly "I'll tear you a new one!") is the anus.

story: If you're a fragile person, lots of things are dangerous and will hurt your flesh.
column3: Doing dangerous things reminds us that our flesh is fragile.
column4: An image that will remind you why human life and the human body is so fragile - go back to the scene in frame 危 (#1520), and see the bottom of the cliff on which the victim fell littered with the victims body parts after the impact with the ground.

story: Without ribs, our flesh wouldn't have the power to stay upright.
column3: Flesh, power: According to the bible, the part of the body that gave power to womankind was the mans' rib. Without it, they wouldn't exist.
column4: 肋骨, 肋間, 肋膜炎, 豚バラ肉 肋 (#2534)ロク, あばら ... Parts:月, 力...OR 筋筋 (#1012)−竹 ... Note: This Kanji is where the Japanese word for spareribs 豚バラ肉 comes from. When it is in that shortened form in that phrase, it is written in kana. ... Story: If you want to build big ole Muscles, ingore the Bamboo Shoots and stick to the Ribs when eating asian food.

story: A body cavity is an empty space within your flesh.
column3: During a body cavity search, the police check certain parts of your body to make sure they're empty of things like cocaine, etc..
column4: Embty flesh , body cavity.

story: An armrest is something that lets you rest the flesh of your arm by keeping your elbow by your side.
column3: The primitive on the left I call the "SUPERMAN POSE" (he stand with his elbows to the side), well here you see he is actually using the part of his BODY, the hips, as an ARMREST when he does the SUPERMAN POSE.
column4: A twist on Nukemarine's story: Superman has realised that he's grown love handles. Now, when he does the superman pose (RHS), he has some extra flesh to use as an armrest.

story: Only uncivilized people eat old flesh.
column3: Tip: uncivilized appears as part of four other kanji in Heisig, but is not named as such in the text. REF: 湖 (#159), 瑚 (#2615), 糊 (#2692), 醐 (#2776). (P.S. As a primitive I call this "zombie", because when the moon shines on the gravestones the zombies arise. And, zombies do tend to be uncivilized.)
column4: Uncivilized societies eat the flesh of their old people in the belief it gives them wisdom.

story: How do you know if a tree is a maple tree? Easy: Just stand next to the tree on a windy day, and if you get covered in maple syrup, it's a maple tree.
column3: Hint: Do not confuse between the wind primitive and the 風 (#563) kanji. The latter I call wind with gnats. (+Katsuo). How do you know if a tree is a maple tree? Easy: Just stand next to the tree on a windy day, and if you get covered in of maple syrup and gnats, it's a maple tree.
column4: 楓=花楓＊(かえで), 楓 (#2538) 名:かえで, ... Parts: 木, 風風 (#563) ... Story:(Since this is 'always' a name kanji) Getting Wood like a Maple Tree just from the Wind blowing? Not at at all. Kaede is just that sexy. (note the odd reading for the river 楓川(もみじがわ) for the river in Chuo, tokyo.) .

story: Because it's easy to spot, a purple willow is the tree that marks where my piggy bank is.
column3: I hid my piggy bank under a willow tree. Then I thought 'how am I gonna find it later?' So I painted the willow purple. 'Wait a sec, now everyone's gonna be able to find it!" So I painted all the other willows purple as well. Now I'm in trouble...
column4: Normally, I can resist the cries of a weeping willow, but this one, she was a purple willow! I just couldn't let the poor tree sit there, so I gave her my piggy bank.

story: The Oriental elm is, of course, a tree fairly representative of the Orient and thus it is common in the capital in order to show ambassadors what the Orient is all about.
column3: In the Japanese remake "A Nightmare on Oriental Elm Street", an anthropomorphic tree wreaks havoc on Kyoto. They should never have sold the film rights.
column4: All the TREES in the CAPITAL are Oriental elms.

story: Tip: bonsai and wheat are later combined into 秦 (#2889). Story: I come across lots of trees all planted in the Manchu dynasty. Then I notice every single one is a hazel tree. I wonder why? In the Manchu dynasty people must have been hazel nuts.
column3: I love hazelnuts so much that I had a hazel tree installed in my backyard. Mostly it's just for decoration, like a bonsai plant, but I harvest it like wheat every so often: there's just nothing better than homemade Nutella.
column4: During the Qin dynasty, the hazel tree was by far the most popular plant around. Everyone was a hazel nut - they planted the trees everywhere, and went as far as naming all their daughters Hazel, and wearing hazel-coloured contact lenses so they could tell people their eye colour was hazel, and not brown.

story: This magic comb will comb the nodes out of wood/trees (and make the grain straight).
column3: Simply put: A comb is a wooden tool that removes nodes in the hair.
column4: A comb used to be a wooden tool with many nodes.

story: Sick of being chased, the maestro grabs a wooden hammer to fight back with.
column3: When the trees rebel, they will chase us with wooden hammers.
column4: I needed to cut down the tree to make a wooden hammer, but the tree started running from me! I had to chase it down before I could make my hammer.

story: Mallet seems to be a poor word choice for this A lumberjack won't cut down a charred tree as they're not useful for anything.
column3: A charred tree can be toppled with a mallet.
column4: This lumberjack uses a new method: he chars trees until they fall down. (Note: Lumberjack seems a better keyword).

story: The tree was a little too high, but, hey, no problem, I'll just use my younger brother as a ladder!
column3: The only one who really needs the LADDER to climb onto our TREE house is my LITTLE BROTHER. The rest of us can just scramble up.
column4: If you have a tree house, be sure to use a rope ladder. That way, you can pull it up into the tree house after you climb up so that your annoying little brother can't try to come up too.

story: Behold! The sweetrus tree!
column3: The fruits from the citrus tree taste sweet.
column4: Little Red Riding Hood is picking citrus fruits from the citrus tree and puts them from the tree into her wicker basket.

story: Use pickets to hold down the tree in times of whirlwind.
column3: After the whirlwind hit, the wooden pickets from his fence were scattered all over his yard.
column4: A whirlwind turned the tree into pickets.

story: The holly tree has leaves which are always green. This is very practical in winter, when so much isn't, so that's why it became very popular as christmas decoration.
column3: The holly is a tree that lasts through winter (aka the "holly days") (thanks herman).
column4: All the best holly-days are during the winters, x-mas, new years...emperor's birthday?

story: The citron is relatively unknown overseas, but citron trees are beginning to sprout up everwhere in Japan.
column3: In keeping with the move to greener autos Citroën has introduced its new line which instead of 油 油 (#1188) runs on an extract from citron trees.
column4: I can't believe no one has mentioned that this is ゆず(the stuff they use to make Ponzu sauce, a big thing in Japanese food). According to this kanji, a great way to eat ponzu is by picking the citron fresh, making the sauce right away, and pouring it on brussel sprouts. That actually sounds good... maybe I'll try it... with bacon. Bacon makes everything better.... mmmmm.....

story: Wooden bowls made of wood have the address of the maker on the on the side.
column3: This is a specially hand-crafted wooden bowl. If you turn is over, you can see the address of the craftsman on the bottom.
column4: 21st century conservationistic etiquette dictates that every wooden bowl be engraved with the address of the unlucky tree that died in its creation.

story: The tree your mother warned you about is the hemlock.
column3: This is not a poison hemlock! It is a tree from genus Tsuga (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tsuga, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tsuga_sieboldii). According to Wikipedia "The common name hemlock is derived from a perceived similarity in the smell of its crushed foliage to that of the unrelated plant poison hemlock. Unlike poison hemlock (conium), the species of Tsuga are not poisonous." Story: In ancient Japan mothers planted hemlock tree in their gardens when child was born.
column4: Mother called me out to the tree in order to partake of some delicious hemlock tea.

story: Give the spindle tree a spin, if you can guess where it lands correctly, you'll get a prize!
column3: Spindle tree or Euonymus japonicus (botanical name). Far from being "spindly", this tree is bushy and evergreen, thus making ideal hedging for those seeking privacy. So if you want to be anonymous, "Euonymus" is the correct tree to choose.
column4: There's actually no such thing as the spindle tree, but it sounds like an appropriate name for a plant. Whenever young students are curious as to the name of an unusual tree, they ask their teachers. If the teacher doesn't know the correct name, the default answer they give is "...um, yeah that's a spindle tree." They usually follow it up with some difficult-to-decipher technical language, like "Yeah, the spindle tree is a dioecious evergreen monocotyledon. Native to Japan."

story: The sacred Shinto tree is a tree of the gods.
column3: This kanji is a 国字 (こくじ) i.e. created in Japan. Logically it combines tree 木 + gods 神 giving us a "tree of the gods" (sacred Shinto tree). Note: 榊 (さかき) has 2 variants where middle element is either 礻or 示.
column4: The sacred Shinto tree is of course a tree that is dedicated to the gods.

story: The evergreen oak is a tree most strict with its leaves: they must be evergreen, or else!
column3: A very strict master dictates that the slaves must ensure that the evergreen oaks are ever green. One day a slave notices, to his terror, that one of them has turned brown! Not wanting to get buried up to his crotch in soil, he quickly pulls out a can of green spray paint and paints the entire tree. Even if that tree wasn't ever green before, it certainly is now!
column4: Evergreen oaks are TREES that are STRICTLY green.

story: The tree of white lies is the Chinese white pine. The tree of truth is the Chinese black pine.
column3: The Chinese make truth serum from the Chinese black pine tree.
column4: The old form, 槇 槇 is more common, and we should all use it.

story: The special brand Horned Whiskey is riped in special oak caskets made of the Japanese oak tree.
column3: Wood from the Japanese oak is very valuable. That's why the 酋 (#2915) demands that his house be made from the Japanese oak.
column4: Red Bull tastes different in Japan, because it's aged in wooden barrels made of Japanese oak. Costs a lot more than the normal stuff, but it tastes better.

story: The tachibana, or mandarin orange, is a type of tree which sometimes yields poor quality fruit. In such times, instead of simply standing up and inviting customers to make a deal, you must force the sale of your mandarin oranges by brandishing a halberd and forcing the customer to make a deal with you by purchasing your substandard fruit. [Note: along with 柚 柑 (#2482), this is used to describe all citrus plants - 柑橘類 かんきつるい means 'citrus fruit'.]
column3: The peddlar who likes to make a deal stepped off his motorcycle helmet and took his halberd to try and get some mandarin oranges off the tree.
column4: Let's make a deal -- your mandarin orange tree for my halberd. Sound fair?

story: According to the Wikipedia article, Japanese cypress (hinoki) is grown for its high-quality wood, which is used in the building of "temples, shrines, traditional noh theatres, baths" etc. So, this tree is vital to the construction of many of the major meeting places in Japanese society. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chamaecyparis_obtusa.
column3: Japanese science fiction company CyPress have the weekly staff meeting under the Japanese cypress tree (its symbolic).
column4: The Japanese cypress is a good tree to meet at: the Japanese covers the atmosphere and the cypress presses on any spies. Hey, I tried.

story: My wife wanted a special place to roost, so I built her one - on the top of that tree.
column3: Better meaning is "habitat" since this doesn't imply anything bird or nest related. Usual habitat for the wife is in a wood structure of some sort (avoiding using house to keep it out of the kanji).
column4: His wife wanted the chickens in the hen house to be housed properly, so she chopped up a tree and made wooden roosts for them to sit on.

story: For nestling, the west side of the tree is best – otherwise you get woken up by the sun in the morning. Remember: West is best for your nest.
column3: Its a secret that Nestlé chocolate syrup is drawn from chocolate trees that are found in the west.
column4: When Germany was still devided, even the birds preferred to nestle in the West-trees rather than in East-trees: Mainly because they did not support Communism.

story: When you see bellflowers next to a tree, ring them for good luck.
column3: When you see bellflowers growing under a tree, it means good luck.
column4: If you're climbing a tree, it's good luck to bring a bellflower with you, because then if you get stuck you can ring it to call for help.

story: A normal grove is 林, so in a temple grove half the trees have been removed and replaced by soil (presumably for graves).
column3: 杜氏, 杜撰, 鎮守の杜, 杜絶=途絶 杜 (#2500) ズ, トウ, ト, もり ... Parts:木, 土 (cf 社社 (#1092)) ... Note: Important unrelated usage: 杜氏 Master Brewer ... Story:A simple Zen temple grove: A single tree with soil. in the Zen tradition, things are said by what is said as well as what is not said, and things have an esoteric and exoteric meaning. Thus the single tree stands for a grove (exoteric) as well as reading as it it were a forest (esoteric)　.
column4: A temple grove is just some TREES on sacred SOIL.

story: All the grain that was spilled under the tree looked like a mosaic, but someone took a grain rake and disposed of it.
column3: Dad gave me a grain rake and told me to go and rake the grain, but since this is the most boring task in the whole world, I climbed a tree and played with my Rubik's cube instead.
column4: The grain rake is made of wood with tines bent in a comma-design.

story: An oar looks a little like a wooden tail.
column3: An otter's tail like an oar, which he uses to help move trees into his dam.
column4: 梶棒, 梶の木, 梶木 梶 (#2564)かじ ... Parts:木, 尾 ... Note: Odd keyword. ... Similar: 舵舵 (#2715), 梶梶 (#2564) ... Story: Old Style Japanese boats used the single rear Oar, making a ship look like it had a Tree for a Tail. (IRL that is a 櫓櫓 (#2568), but hey).

story: Tree, horse: At cooking school, I learned that there's always a relation between the item you will pestle and the size of the pestle itself. When I read in a cooking book that I had to mash up a horse with a wooden pestle, naturally a tried to obtain a tree to do the job.
column3: Ah, nothing like using a wooden pestle to mash up some horse meat on a Sunday afternoon.
column4: At noon she used a wooden pestle (made out of a tree) to prepare her lunch.

story: Wood of a certain length can be used as a cane.
column3: A length of wood will be suitable as a cane, a walking stick or even a weapon (a jo).This is じょう from the martial art Joudou 杖道. Ten 尺 make up a 杖. Also, walking stick, つえ.
column4: I made a WOODEN cane an ARM'S LENGTH in LENGTH.

story: The most revered tree is one that can be used as a wine barrel.
column3: The revered horned whiskey is riped in special barrels made out of Japanese Oak trees.
column4: [+astridtops] Horned Whiskey is ripened & mellowed in special oak barrels made of 楢 (#2556) 楢, but of course planks from the tree must be glued together before the revered whiskey goes into the barrels.

story: The village that made its living out of catching fish above all was prone to be raided by pirates. So they made a watch turret out of trees and would look every day if the pirates were coming.
column3: They were stuck in that wooden turret for ages, with nothing but sundried fish to eat.
column4: Fish + sun becomes Russia (魯). In Russia, turrets are made of wood.

story: How does an oak tree become sturdy? By eating pancake stacks for breakfast every morning. That's a sturdy oak.
column3: A sturdy oak was the tree I tried to build with my stack of pancakes and waffles, but it didn't turn out to be so sturdy.
column4: (NB: 橿 and 樫 [樫 (#2554)] are basically synonyms, both referring to the tree called かし, or Quercus myrsinifolia. Therefore, I call 橿 LIVE OAK, a term that is synonymous with EVERGREEN OAK.) LIVE OAKs are the ideal TREEs to use as BORDER (畺 畺) markers.

story: A wooden ladle is of course a ladle made out of wood.
column3: A wooden ladle is a wooden ladle is a wooden ladle.
column4: Just like 吠 (#2288), 泪 (#2391) and 鮨 (#2841), this is what I like to call a Perfect Kanji ☺.

story: A kid falls out a tree and the father exclaims, "Damn, son! Watch where you're going when you go plum-pickin'!"
column3: Children like to stand under the damson tree and hope the plum fruits will fall into their mouths.
column4: (I don't understand Heisig sometimes. Keyword: "japanese plum". reading :すもも. (プラム will cover western kinds I think). I changed 梅 (#499) to "japanese apricot" (=more correct anyway). also prevent confusion with (western) "apricot" (杏 (#215)) Note: also a very common name for Chinese; Li /Lee) The Japanese plum TREE is the favourite place for KIDS to sit under. (Here we see a young mr Li at ease, eating a plum).

story: Before 綿 (#1467) is made into thread for Spider-Man's white towels, it simply grows on a tree as raw cotton.
column3: The raw cotton that is ultimately made into white towels does not grow on trees, but on a kind of bush instead.
column4: Raw cotton differs from cotton in that it has wood chips which is why Spiderman isn't into it.

story: Escutcheons are noble shields that depict the coat of arms of a family. They are usually made out of wood.
column3: An escutcheon is an heraldic shield used for display of a coat of arms, rather than for defence. Therefore, it is usually made out of wood because it's easier to modify than steel.
column4: Note: This is not necessarily an escutcheon. It can be any wooden shield.

story: A Japanese hackberry tree is a type of tree that only has full foliage in the summer. It loses its foliage in the winter.
column3: If you hack into the hackberry tree with ur PC, you can program it to grow berries even in summer. What a cool hack!
column4: If you hack into the hackberry tree, you can program it to think it's always summer, so that it never stops producing berries! Awesome!

story: A birch tree can have a great aura of splendor with it's shiny white coated trunk.
column3: Tree, splendid: The Queen of England was visiting a park. The very nice birch trees got remarks such as: "Splendid! Such a splendid tree!" That was before she got birched with a stick made from one of the birches.
column4: The splendor of the birch tree makes it a popular choice for furniture and interiors.

story: When Sir Lancelot wants a new lance he goes down to the godown (they have a nice selection for sale) and tries some out by thrusting them into a nearby tree.
column3: Sir Lancelot gets wood when she godowns. -or- Lance Bass gets wood thinking about Sir Lancelot godowning on him.
column4: While fighting towards 創 (#1759), my sabre broke, so I grab the nearest tree and start using that as a lance.

story: The 桑 (#754) may be nice and let you dance around it, but if it were a wild mulberry tree it would try to protectiself by throwing rocks at you.
column3: If you smoke the leaves of the wild mulberry tree, you'll get stoned fo sho coz that tree is wild, brother.
column4: The wild mulberry bush is easily differentiated from its domesticated cousin the 桑 (#754) by its hardness, such as stone, such that not even the hardest of members is able to dance around this lonely tree, er, bush.

story: How do make a bale? Simple. You take a tree, like the one on the left, and you pent it up like the one on the right. Just like that.
column3: You would be in a quandary if you had to bale trees.
column4: 梱, 梱包, 同梱 梱 (#2578) コン(困), こり ... Parts:木, 困困 (#621) ... Note: Bad Keyword, fallout from mistakenly calling 俵俵 (#1667) instead of bale, and the fact that 束束 (#1793) is already taken. ... Story: You will find this almost always in 同梱, which is the way of saying something comes free with the purchase of. So when you buy your Tree you will be in a Quandary (or not) when you find it comes with a Bale of marijuana.

story: A loquat is a tropical fruit tree, that compared to other trees has an odd seasonal pattern: it's fruit is ripe in late winter or early spring.
column3: The loquat tree is very rare. To loquate it, you need to compare it to the trees next to it.
column4: If you compare the unusual spelling of this tree's name to that of another orange fruit, the kumquat, you'll notice the similarity. This is because the -quat ending comes from the Cantonese pronunciation of the kanji 橘 （橘 (#2557)）, which is read as gwat1. (This is true.)

story: A downspout is made by hollowing out a tree and placing it to carry water "traffic" from your rooftop down to the ground.
column3: My downspout empties into a 桶 (#2590) 桶 beside the road.
column4: The Romans developed a system of wooden downspouts to drain water away from areas of heavy traffic.

story: Santa needs to wear 3 fur coats when he rides his wooden sled.
column3: A dog sled is made of wood and has to be pulled by at least 3 ultra furry dogs whose fur can withstand the arctic cold.
column4: Ah, Chewbacca and his younger twin brothers (three of them in total) having fun riding downhill on a sled... and hits a tree. But they just roll around, and brushes snow of their fur and laughing. This is Chewbacca on vacation.

story: To the enjoyment of humans, many trees are carriers of delicious fruits.
column3: Just for some fun and enjoyment, the crew put their carrier on top of a tree as an April Fool's prank.
column4: 涅槃, 涅槃会, 大般涅槃経, 槃 (#2582) ハン(般) ... Parts: 般般 (#2016), 木 ... Note: Silly keyword used as the second Character for Buddhas nirvana. ... Story: It was just 一般の木, but when Buddha reached Nirvana there, it was renamed the enjoyment tree.

story: Two birds high up in a tree drying out after flying through a storm. "How will we get back on track? We lost our bearings!" number one cries. "Don't worry," the other one says, as he flips out his mobile. "I have it bookmarked."
column3: I love to use dried leaves as bookmarks. Every time I go by a tree, I pluck off a couple of leaves and then dry them to later use as bookmarks.
column4: 旅の栞, 栞紐, 栞 (#2583) しおり ... Parts: 干, 干, 木 ... Note: More common extended meaning is Guidebook ... Story: In my bird watching guide book, I BookMark the pages with Dried bits of Tree sometimes leaves, but also sometimes strips of bark.

story: (Note: ear + city walls = 耶 (#2720)). I see a tree with an exclamation mark painted on it. "Why is that?" I think, "An exclamation mark indicates danger, but it's only a tree". Then a coconut drops on my head. Ah, it's a coconut tree.
column3: A coconut tree drops a coconut on your head, causing you to make an obscene 耶 (#2720).
column4: I imagine a Super Mario-like side-scroller in which there is a bonus stage where a big tree throws coconuts with question marks on them. Hit them to get coins and goodies!().

story: Sandalwood is the ideal wood for a podium: it's easy on your sandals!
column3: SANDALWOOD is a TREE that is much preferred to dirt for making a PODIUM. It's aromatic and carves easily.
column4: The gunslinger raises the smooth sandalwood grip of his revolver just as the corrupt "Big Boss" politician ascends his podium for a victory speech.

story: ~~ Keyword should be sumac ~~ Sumacs are worthless trees. They don't protect from rain so you shouldn't use them for a ceiling - and they stink so you can't use them to make snares.
column3: We were seeking shelter for the rain under the plotosid tree, but someone had put a double snare there. As if that foul smelling tree wasn't enough trouble already.
column4: According to my dictionary, this is a sendan; a Japanese bead tree that is not useless at all; it is sometimes used in the making of instruments and Buddhist statues and such. I was cutting down a sendan tree to make myself a koto, when it started raining. I got closer to the tree to shelter myself from the rain, when I suddenly got snared by two branches, and it started strangling me! Guess the sendan wanted to send an obvious message: don't cut me down!

story: The zelkova is a sort of elm tree that is very good for making bonsais, setting a standard for other trees, so to speak.
column3: In the A to Z of trees, the zelkova sets the standard, because it begins with "Z" and ends in "A".
column4: AKA 欅. When the government decided that the zelkova would be the standard tree to plant in public parks in Japan, the populace obeyed, and today the zelkova is the only tree you will ever see in Japanese parks (at least, those well-kept enough to observe the national standard).

story: Due its tendency to encrypt all its messages, the cryptomeria has been a fairly prosperous tree whereas all the other trees have already fallen prey to espionage.
column3: The cryptomeria （すぎ） is a tree that enjoys prosperity in Japan because it's written kanji is like an encrypted form of the more infamous スギ（杉） which causes hay fever.
column4: Prosperous people can safely stash their money in the cryptomeria tree. It uses 128bit encryption so their money's well hidden.

story: Cedar trees are so copious they only come in groves.
column3: Cedar trees are so copious they only come in groves. (from Aerin). I use a pun to help cement this story in my mind. Cedar tree is スギ　in Japanese, so I just remember あり過ぎ（ありスギ）=there are too many of them!
column4: You'll find copious cedar trees all over Japan. They're the most common tree available.

story: One of my favourite pastimes is that I like to jump out of a tree on my pogo stick and try to land in a bucket. When successful it makes a very satisfying "clang". (Note: new primitive pogo stick = chop seal + utilize, for explanation see my entry at 通 (#1511).)
column3: As if in a cartoon, my pogo stick got stuck in a wooden bucket, causing me to fall over.
column4: I ran into a tree when I was riding my pogo stick while wearing a bucket over my head.

story: The 惰 惰 (#676) way to draw an ellipse requires two wooden pegs and some string (http://tinyurl.com/252zgx).
column3: When tasked with planting the trees to form a circle, the somewhat lazy gardener just winged it (instead of measuring) and the result was an ellipse of trees.
column4: (re: Johnzep's story for lazy) When I went under a tree to beat my meat with my left hand, my motions formed the shape of an ellipse.

story: The star-anise is an evergreen tree kept in secrecy for it's aromatic oil.
column3: This kanji 樒 (しきみ・しきび) refers to Japanese star-anise. Its evergreen branches are popular for placing at graves. It’s very poisonous. The edible spice of the same name 八角 (はっかく) is from the closely related Chinese star-anise 大茴香 (ダイウイキョウ). Both species produce almost identical fruits. STORY: A batch of Chinese star-anise was adulterated with its poisonous Japanese namesake. Great secrecy surrounds the incident. Was it an innocent tree mixup or coverup?
column4: Before Anise was a star she lived openly in town, but now that she is star-Anise she lives in secrecy in the woods.

story: I requested that the cat do something and he spit up a furball.
column3: For her birthday, your pampered girlfriend's request is, "Something made of fur". So you get the cat to cough her up a furball.
column4: 毛球= fur・ball 毬 【いが; かさ】burr; (chestnut) case; (pine) cone.

story: New primitive; let futon = feathers + turkey (i.e. my futon is made with turkey feathers). Then: Twinkle, twinkle little star, oops my futon is on fire.
column3: Tuesday is twinkle day. Or in kanji arithmetics: 火 + 曜 = 燿 + 日.
column4: With a twinkle in my eye, I set my turkey feather futon on fire for no apparent reason.

story: The fires outside the puptent of the sentinel are watchfires.
column3: Camping in the wilds can be fun but what about the big carnivores out there? So we have a watchfire and take turns at night, one asleep in the pup tent while the other keeps the fire burning brightly.
column4: Watchfire is what you must do if you light a fire outside your pup tent, in case it sets it alight.

story: A gigantic fire was started by the Olympic torch.
column3: The olympic torch is a fire carried on a gigantic journey from olympus to wherever the games are.
column4: 炬燵=火燵, 置き炬燵=置き火燵, 炬 (#2596) キョ(巨) ... Parts: 火, 巨巨 (#920) ... Note: Once you have lived a winter in Japan, you will know what a Kotatu (炬燵) is. ... Story: 懐中電灯灯 (#177) is a little bit of flame hung on a spike. A Torch is a Gigantic Flame.

story: I'm really bad at making fires, I needed kindling from a whole grove of trees before I managed to kindle the fire.
column3: A fire was kindled by the insane arsonist under a grove of trees. Unable to escape the ensuing inferno, he was burned alive.
column4: Imagine trying to kindle fire by rubbing 2 trees together (焚き火).

story: A mummy is running around the room on fire after his moxa treatment goes wrong.
column3: Moxa is a therapy involving burning a plant with fire together with acupuncture or shiatsu. It simply burns for a long time.
column4: Moxa is a therapy involving fire and acupuncture needles that has been around for a long time.

story: Fanning the flames with a fan.
column3: With a fan you can be fanning the fire into a bigger fire. Just make sure it doesn't get out of hand...
column4: 煽動 (扇動), 煽情的 (扇情的) 煽 (#2599) セン(扇), あおる, おだてる ... Parts:火, 扇 ... Story: This does in fact have the straightforward meaning of Fanning the Flames with a Fan. In compounds it has been replaced by 扇 by itself, leaving old references, and the verb forms to this Kanji ... 熟語: 煽る, 煽てる ... cf:.

story: Teacher: "How is soot formed?" Student: "Well, there is a fire, so-and-so, and then there is soot!"
column3: The so-and-so from Mary Poppins was covered in soot because he was a fire chimney sweep.
column4: Remember those sootballs in Spirited Away? They are just so-and-sos who keep the boiler room fire alive.

story: The East are the best at 錬 (#2186) because their fires are the best at firing.
column3: The process of firing, that is, glaze bricks or refine metals, is well known in the east, and of course fire is used for it.
column4: Firing bricks （煉瓦　れんが）became really important in Chicago after the Great Chicago Fire - in this kanji you can see the fire to the left and it stops to the east because of the lake.

story: After the evening rice, the guest set out to entertain the children of the house with a dazzling show. He pulled a wand seemingly from out of his crotch and suddenly it appeared to be on fire! Ohs and ahs ensued.
column3: [+mantixen] (wand+night+crotch=pole dancer) The American pole dancer gave a dazzling dance and set the audience on fire. Literally.
column4: Tip: The wand + evening + crotch combination appears again in 餐 (#2814).

story: The cook just got a new set of pots and pans from the master of the house. Putting them on the fire, they shined so much the refulgent shine blinded him until he blocked it from his view by holding up his ladel.
column3: He used a ladle to protect his eyes from the refulgent light of the fire.
column4: This miraculous ladle is so refulgent (resplendent and radiant) that it can start fires simply by reflecting and focusing the light waves.

story: With an iron that has been in the fire, each beast is subjected to branding.
column3: Branding with FIRE - EACH animal.
column4: Farmers use branding to protect the property of their flock. They use an iron fresh out of the fire to brand each and every animal with the same brand. Thinking more abstractly, branding (or advertising) burns like fire in the mind of each and every person exposed to it.

story: When The Pinnacle collapses, there'll be plenty of flames for sure.
column3: Fullmeyal alchemist: 焔の錬金術師 (ほのおのれんきんじゅつし).
column4: Got any old flames? I sure do, and though they are bound up in my memories of the olden days, any time I am near them, those flames start to fire up again.

story: If a fire goes smoothly you will have stew in no time.
column3: Tip: tall and complete can be combined into 亨.
column4: Cannibals make a stew with tall children over a cauldron fire. The stew is complete when the arms come off with a fork.

story: A mysterious crown appeared on the cow that wouldn't come off no matter how hard we'd tug.
column3: Mysterious, crown, cow: In Kazad-dum, Gandalf had found a mysterious crown. It really helped his magic, but when they came back to Rivendell, he had become unresistable to the cows (small side-effect). He tried to tug the crown off, but did not succeed...
column4: A cow is engaged in a tug-of-war with a tugboat. Mysteriously, the cow is crowned the winner.

story: The cow in this frame 牝 is filling a spoon with milk from its udders, so it must be a female animal. (The cow in the next frame 牡 is rolling around in the soil and is, not surprisingly, a male animal.)
column3: While the bull wants rough sex, the cow would rather spoon, I guess all female animals are the same.
column4: A cow is a female animal that fills your spoon with ice cream, milk, yogurt, etc.

story: Male animals are dirty pigs in English, but in Japanese they are dirty cows ボ ボウ おす お- おん-.
column3: That cow is staring at me and kicking up soil... hold on that's a male... animal... Oh shit! Run!
column4: The male animal cow is called a bull, and it likes to roll around across the soil.

story: The mechanism in my old grandfather clock suddenly broke with an almighty chime and one of the jewels was thrown out through the window into a nearby grove of trees. I'm now searching for the jewel in the grove while the clock continues to chime incessantly.
column3: The king knew playtime in the grove was over when he heard the clock tower chime.
column4: When the king got lost in the grove, he could easily find his way back to the castle by following the sounds of the chime.

story: The king was given two choices by the abductor: either the king gives him the lapis lazuli jewels, or he throws the king's infant son into the stream.
column3: The king as an infant was washed away by the current to a beautiful island of lapis lazuli waters, the Ryuukyuu Islands 琉球 (Okinawa before annexation).
column4: This kanji should be "Ryukyu Islands" or something similar and 瑠 should be Lapis Lazuli.

story: The king's servant got lazy and didn't thoroughly burnish some of the king's many jewels, thinking "he won't notice the difference." However, the king most certainly did notice the distinction between the burnished jewels and unburnished ones: "Off with his head!!"
column3: The king appreciated the distinction of burnished jewels.
column4: 切瑳=切磋, 切瑳琢磨=切磋琢磨, 瑳 瑳 (#2612) サ(左) ... Parts: 王, 差 (cf 差別差 (#593)) ... Note: Name Kanji pronounced SA. Compounds usually use the non-RTK 磋磋. .. Similars: 琢琢 (#2613), 瑳 瑳 (#2612) ... Story: I Burned the Left sleeve on my wife's Wool coat, and now I have to give her Jewelry to make up for it. Maybe that will Burnish my reputation with her.

story: The king realized he looked like a pig and sought to hone his body through exercise.
column3: King Henry VIII was keen on hunting wild boar. Here we see him first honing his skills on a sow.
column4: I hone my skills by skillfully separating real jewels from the fake junk worn by fat sows!

story: Neptune, king of the sea has a special tome containing all the different types of coral.
column3: The coral is not found in this tome of jewels since it's really not a mineral, but the remains of small animals.
column4: The greet coral reef (珊瑚礁) forms a 柵 (#1968) encrusted with the finest jewels the ocean ca offer.

story: The king had a coral reef installed in his lake.
column3: Under the light of the moon, the adventurers secretly dived for the old wreckage in the coral reef that would contain a fabled jewel.
column4: Be careful not to get mixed up with 礁 (#600).

story: The king wished he was as handsome as Fabio standing on the 端 (#1251) of a mountain combing his hair, but he realized he was fortunate in other ways.
column3: The king went mountain-climbing but dropped his comb and it tumbled miles below. However, he happened to find it on the way back. How fortunate!
column4: How most fortunate! After gambling his life on the 端 (#1251), Indiana Jones discovers that the comb is studded with countless jewels.

story: I spent a long time polishing the king's jewelry until it was all jet-black just like he ordered. Well, it felt like a long time, but it was actually just 9 minutes. (In addition to jet, this kanji is also used as 9 in legal documents.)
column3: Public airlines fly slow and take a long time to arrive so the king has a private jet.
column4: Mummies are adorned with jet jewels to connote death, or something. Oh, yeah, 'cause King Tut was a big fan of jet planes.

story: He who possesses the crystal stone is the rightful king of England.
column3: [+Aerin] Pretty much everything in England is fake. That includes the power of the king (it's a queen now, I know, but still) - everything is handled by the real government, and that post is just a symbol. Appropriately, then, the PM gets all the real diamonds, while the royalty gets the crystal stone decorated items. Crystal stone, of course, is just a nice way of saying rhinestones.
column4: As opposed to 璃 (#1606), a crystal stone is a crystal set in a stone carving, a jewel which Hyacinth Bucket is thrilled to find. That should up her status in the neighbourhood.

story: When the king barks out his orders, all the chandeliers and other ornaments in the palace start tinkling.
column3: The king (having no real power) likes to give orders to his family jewels - "Commence tinkling!". (Thanks to bodhisamaya).
column4: The king orders the tinkling of jewels to help him take a tinkle himself.

story: First, we sow the rice field, then we plant the flowers, and lastly we plant the corn. (Stroke order and story in one).
column3: This kanji is actually written in the following stroke order: rice field, flower, corn. Story: I was trying to teach an old farmer about crop rotation. He had been planting rice in his field for decades and the field was getting depleted in nutrients. So I told him he should try planting different flowers and then lastly some corn.
column4: Lastly, let me mention that my ricefield and silage stack are amongst the top ten in the country...

story: Ivy grows on the paddy-field ridge encircling the rice field as opposed to the intra-field paddy ridge that divides it in half.
column3: [+mantixen] The ordinary 畔 畔 (#1288) dissects the field by dividing it in half, but the paddy-field ridge runs around the outside & is covered in ivy. Disambiguate by noting that the hyphen in 'paddy-ridge' divides the word itself in half (five letters each side) but 'paddy-field ridge' has five extra letters on the right, the ridge itself, in fact, the part covered in ivy.
column4: This paddy-field ridge separates two paddy fields. The reason for it being made of ivy is a bit pathetic, but necessary - it turns out that the two neighboring paddy field owners got in a bit of a fight over whose paddy field irrigation system was the best. Then both of them started insulting the others' systems, saying that they didn't want the others' dirty water in their field. So they put ivy up between it, which sucks up all the water from the edges (which is why there is none).

story: If you think wearing a wool sweater is itchy, just think of how sheep must feel! They must be so sick of wearing that itchy wool all the time!
column3: Scrapie is a disease sheep sometimes catch. It causes them to itch so unbearably that they scrape themselves to death.
column4: When the caveman feels an itch, he grabs the nearest sheep and rubs himself with it.

story: When your sickness involves inflammation, you will produce phlegm (perhaps inphlegmation?)
column3: If I'm sick, and have an inflammation of my lungs, I cough up a lot of phlegm.
column4: Caveman, inflammation: Caveman had a very effective cure for inflammations. He just smeared a phlegm over the inflamed skin, bringing instant relieve.

story: He had a curious form of measles : the red marks on his skin were all in the shape of an umbrella. The doctors of course couldn't explain it...
column3: I'm sick with the measles. Whenever I go out, I carry my parasol to try and cover up the rash.
column4: Umbrella shape also appears in rare 珍 (#1859), checkup 診 (#1860), seep 滲 (#2388), fallible 謬 (#2752).

story: "Hemorrhoids 痔 are the sickness suffered by people who sit in meditative poses for long periods at Buddhist temples 寺." ( Joseph De Roo's "2001 Kanji").
column3: "Caveman try Buddhism. Caveman spend a long time meditating at temple with monks. Caveman get haemorrhoids. Looking for other religion now. Might try Kabbalah."
column4: Hemorrhoids is a sickness people at Buddhist temples get from sitting down meditating for too long. It's kinda true.

story: The SICKNESS called cancer works by self-replication, so that its bad GOODS grow more & more until a vertiable MOUNTAIN of them forms on you-- that's the tumor, the awful sign of cancer.
column3: People who are sick with cancer will buy mountains of goods (medicines, fake cures/placebos) in order to try and cure themselves.
column4: This is people sick with cancer seeking alternative treatment from goods of dubious repute at a remote mountain clinic.

story: This sickness seems to prey upon the lowly of society mostly, and causes paralysis in its final stages.
column3: Caveman, lowly: Caveman was just a lowly Neanderthaler, trying to survive. But he had healing hands and people were brought in from far to have him cure their paralysis.
column4: Tip: This contains the variation of lowly that is also in 婢 (#2309).

story: Here you have a picture of him with his apple of the eye: you see him keeping an eye upon his favourite cow, while leaning on it with his elbow.
column3: Barnyard romance: The big bull winked with his EYE and let out a MOO (牟 2961) toward the cow and said, "Your the APPLE OF my EYE baby!"
column4: An apple of the eye is something that makes your eye want to ム like a cow.

story: If you see mysterious things in front of your eyes you're definitely dizzy.
column3: When you see mysterious stars from your eyes, it's a sign that you're dizzy - 眩暈（めまい）。 Maybe becuase you're fighting off a face hugger who has its tail round your neck!
column4: Gandalf uses his eyes to make people feel dizzy ゲン カン げん.す くるめ.く まぶ.しい くら.む まど.う めま.い faint; dizzy.

story: I threw my dart at a pheasant during the hunt, but hit a turkey instead.
column3: A pheasant is like a small wild TURKEY except you can kill it with a DART.
column4: I tried to kill the turkey with a dart, but a pheasant, who was his good friend, jumped in between to save the turkey. Pheasant turned out to be just as good though.

story: That carpenter can never remember where his tools are, so there is a gigantic arrow pointing to his carpenter's square.
column3: I pin down my carpenter's square with a gigantic dart to keep it from moving when I make my measurements.
column4: My carpenter's square is hanging on that gigantic dart.

story: If you want to take all the stones out of this crag, you'll need a large carrier.
column3: Last time I was on crag's list, I found someone selling an aircraft carrier they carved out of stone! A crazy lawn ornament I suppose.
column4: The carrier got stuck on a large stone, also known as a crag.

story: A grapnel is a small anchor with several hooks, used for anchoring small boats, or to pull up sunken objects (it looks very much like a grappling hook). The position of stones underwater determines where the grapnel will catch.
column3: He was determined to climb this rock, so he used a grapnel.
column4: This reminds of Link's hookshot. The annoying thing about his grapnel was that it could only hook onto rocks pre-determined by the game's maker. Just think of how many frustrating puzzles you could skip over if it could grab onto anything!

story: Notes: 珀 (not in Heisig) means "amber". Story for both: A bus is stopped at some traffic lights in Japan. Inside, King Henry VIII and Barry White are arguing over whether the lights are yellow or amber. The lights change to "Go", and Mick Jagger (stone) then joins a new argument over whether the lights are blue or green. They compromise on blue-green.
column3: The rarest form of amber is a blue-green stone. (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue_amber).
column4: A 昔話 about why street lights in Japan are blue-green. In the old days, there was only one street light - and it was amber. When it was on, you had to stop - and when it was off, you could go (but slowly). So one day a salaryman was late for work and stuck at a long amber light. He got impatient and threw a rock at it. The light started to malfunction and flickered blue-green. People were confused - "what do we do? Stop? Go slowly?" "Uh..it means...go fast!!!" The end.

story: This is not an ordinary rock, if you look carefully you will see that it is an ancient inkstone.
column3: A magical inkstone was made in ancient China that was able to mix invisible ink. When the ink dried, the surface it adhered to became invisible. Unfortunately, someone used it once and forgot to wash the stone thoroughly afterwards, and when the ink dried the magical inkstone was never seen again.
column4: Inkstone rubbed on ROCK allows you to SEE an image.

story: In Bedrock, people had business cards made of rock and engraved using a grindstone. (Big ups to Katsuo).
column3: My calling card is made of rock, which is a bit inconvenient because it is so big & heavy. So I’m using a grindstone to grind it down in size.
column4: Grindstones, meet the Grindstones, they're the modern Stone Age family. . . . Fred handing you a business card.

story: Teacups at the Japanese restaurant are usually made of stone and have the name and address of the restaurant written on them.
column3: Similarly to the 椀 (#2550), the teacup made of stone has it's makers address carved into the bottom.
column4: Teacup = 茶碗（ちゃわん）. Pieces of stone(?) that everyone has at their address.

story: Those gremlins! At night break they insist on coming out and gluing stones all over the place. These obstacles make it nearly impossible for me to get to work!
column3: You 得 (#941) 得 when you make forward progress. If you encounter a rock, you cannot go forward. Perhaps you can go round. This is an obstacle.
column4: The column of soldiers who were gaining on the enemy at nightbreak ran into an obstacle: huge stone in their way.

story: Mount Rushmore is a place in the US where the heads of illustrious presidents are carved into the stone of a cliff.
column3: The illustrious stone heads of Easter Island.
column4: Illustrious people often have stone heads (busts) made in their honour.

story: To qualify as a rocky beach (as opposed to a sandy beach), how many stones does the beach need?
column3: "How many stones can you find at a rocky beach?" the Zen Master asked his baffled pupil.
column4: How many stones are at a rocky beach?

story: Whatstone would make the best whetstone? I wandered ten thousand cliffs in search of an answer.
column3: A whetstone so notorious that it had destroyed ten thousand cliffs.
column4: If you have an unusually long sword you may need a special WHETSTONE to sharpen it. Find a large ROCK on the side of a CLIFF and then rub the sword against it about TEN THOUSAND times to produce a keen edge.

story: Some mills use an animal, typically an ox or donkey, to rotate the stone. But in this mill the stone is being pulled round by a turkey.
column3: I can tell you, it was a big mess when a turkey accidentally came between the stones of the wind mill. We had to clean the blood and feathers away for ages.
column4: To create turkey stock, you'll need to grind the turkey down using a stone mill.

story: The beautiful woman has to fend off honorable admirers every day, who want to drag her to the altar and marry her.
column3: Tired of fending off your pregnant girlfriend's remarks, you do the honorable thing and take her to the altar.
column4: The Japanese believe that the HONORABLE ancestors enshrined at the family ALTAR will FEND OFF misfortune.

story: If you want longevity, go to an altar and beseech the gods.
column3: Altar, longevity: Having seen all his friends and family die so long ago, the ancient sage visited the altar and beseeched the gods to put an end to his longevity.
column4: I bessech thee oh alter of longevity!!! grant me longer life.

story: Picture a Japanese altar that contains ancestral tablets, placed on the right (on the left would be the incense).
column3: Divine intervention is what happens when things go right at the altar.
column4: During the Apple Special Event of January 2010, Apple devotees watched from their WiFi-enabled altars as the messiah Steve Jobs descended from the clouds, holding the long-awaited ancestral tablet, the iPad, in his right hand. [Anyone who clicks 'report' on this story is an Apple fanboi].

story: From http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shinto: Whenever a child is born in Japan, a local Shinto shrine adds the child's name to a list kept at the shrine and declares him or her a "family child" (氏子 ujiko?). After death an ujiko becomes a "family spirit", or "family kami" (氏神 ujigami?). Therefore, if your family name is inscribed in the altar, then you will become a local god.
column3: The altar dedicated to this local god has the family names of all the villagers inscribed in it, so that the god knows whom he should favour.
column4: The local god's altar lists the family names of all those under his purview.

story: The ancestral shrine has an altar that shows little reclining figurines of ancestors.
column3: Just a note: This is a rarely used kanji, the unsimplified version, 禰 , is far more common, and seeing as we're trying to be kanji masters, we'd all might as well use the traditional (correct) version.
column4: 禰禰 is the real version including let it be. STORY: Unless you want to piss off your ancestors, let the altar in your ancestral shrine be.

story: Ancient Japanese officials collected their salarium in the shrines. A priest would collect their rice grains with a broom, and sweep it unto the altar, where the officials could collect their rice.
column3: Rather than cold hard cash, the rice that the altar boys could sweep up became their salarium.
column4: This word is obsolete - It comes from the Roman era when soldiers were paid with salt, or rather, "salarium argentum", which means something like "salt money". Incoincidentally, it is where the term, "Worth your salt" comes from. Heisig's word choice for some of these is asinine. The Kanji means "salary" or "stipend".

story: When the wheelchair-bound Felicity was healed at the altar (by one of those healer priests), she was finally able to stand upright and was overcome by felicitation.
column3: On the special festival day, the altar of the local shrine contains the felicitations of local upright citizens, thanking their local gods for doing such a good job.
column4: When offering one's FELICITATION at the ALTAR, first bow, then stand UPRIGHT, then bow again, repeat again for good measure.

story: I use balancing scales to make sure everyone gets an even amount of Wheaties.
column3: Before the technology of balancing scales was widely available, farmers used to sell their wheat grain using the following method: customers would visit, and shovel as much wheat grain as they could onto a giant lilypad. They were allowed as much as they could pile on, and they were charged according to the number of lilypads they filled. This ensured that the greedy were punished, because if the lilypad sunk under the weight, they were still charged for the grain.
column4: Keep putting the weights on the balancing scales until the wheat on one side is even with the weights on the other.

story: Millet is a small grain whose importance was greater in prehistoric times. Nowadays, it has been supplanted in the West by wheat, and in the East ("under the bamboo umbrella"), by rice.
column3: 黍, 砂糖黍, 唐黍, 黍団子(吉備団子), 玉蜀黍, 黍 (#2651) キビ ... Parts: 禾, 人, 氺... OR ノ, 漆-氵 (cf: 漆漆 (#1001), 黎明黎 (#2942), 膝膝 (#1002), 鳥黐黐) ... Note:Historical Radical 部首＃202 ... Backwards Story:Lacquer漆 is actually made from millet: It's Millet with the husk removed (-ノ), then mixed with water (+氵).
column4: Millet is really, really a pain to grow. It's basically just a strain of rice that is really sensitive to light, so it has to be grown under umbrellas. For that reason, it was formerly only eaten by royalty, or by people in areas where the weather was particularly bad. With the invasion of Western influence, however, people have started to toss out millet and favor Cap 'n Crunch OVER millet.

story: The dude was so upset about going bald that he covered himself with a wheat sack so that only his legs were showing.
column3: A bald man uses some wheat as a toupee. The wheat is a bit long, so only his legs show underneath.
column4: You're at a pizzeria. Whenever a waiter goes in or out of the kitchen, you can briefly take a look inside. Flip! The door opens and you can see a bald guy who's throwing a wheat dough above his head. Shortly after, Flip! The door opens again and clearly he's failed miserably: he's completely covered with the wheat dough, only his human legs are visible. Your companion starts laughing soundly and says: "Im glad he's bald". "Why?", you reply with a smile. "Otherwise, we'd find some hairs on our pizza".

story: Every day, the farmer works in his wheat field, making a wish that his hard labor will bear fruit.
column3: I wish Wheaties would bear fruit... Then I wouldn't have to add any myself!
column4: wheat always wishes it can bear fruit instead of just being a grain product.

story: Crabgrass is lowly wild grass, quickly spreading with nasty roots, and difficult to remove out of your wheat field.
column3: Japanese barnyard millet (Echinochloa utilis). In Japan's past, this type of millet was grown where conditions were not suitable for rice paddies. It was far more common than wheat and helped to alleviate starvation when rice was damaged by cold weather. However since then it has become quite a lowly grain and is only grown in northern Iwate-ken.
column4: A lowly wheat field only grows crap grass.

story: A bumper crop is a very full crop. In this particular case, the bumper crop is a wheat crop, grown by this excentric guy in a grass skirt, who has gone completely native, but knows the secrets of how to get a good crop!
column3: The hula girl dances around the wheat, and this appeases the deities so they give them a bumper crop.
column4: On the tropical island of JOU, lots of crops are grown - coconuts, bananas, pineapples, etc - but these are really just for show to get lots of tourists. The real bumper crop that feeds the islanders is wheat.

story: Wheat, rice seedling, walking legs: The next hurdle for mission of the rice seedlings with walking legs was the imperial authority. They had to cross through a wheat field, but the imperial authority didn't give permission for rice seedlings and wheat to mix. How to solve this...?
column3: I changed the keyword to ridge because it seems to be more often used in mountain ridge and so many medical words for body parts involving a crest or ridge. (I use "tripping on shrooms" as the keyword for 夌 夌.) Story: After tripping on shrooms, the ridge seemed to be a good place to plant wheat.
