column4: The imperial authority is coming to inspect the wheat crop and the rice seedlings. No doubt they want to make sure they'll get very last bit of their dues. The poor farmers run around on their walking legs to assure they haven't kept anything hidden.

story: This region only has sparse agriculture. The few farmers hope their wheat crops will do well, but the soil isn't really good.
column3: Food is sparse, so the wheat crops are now their only hope.
column4: Scarce is a better keyword since this really means rare. Here, the farmer hopes he gets some wheat during the harvest since food is scarce.

story: I'm being obeisant to Doctor's orders -- trying to get into shape by eating only wheat and drinking only from that spring.
column3: The African slaves were obeisant to their white owners and had to work the wheat field. But inside their cottage at night, they played with small, white men made of play-doh, forcing them to be obeisant slaves..
column4: When Mystique starts to get a little chubby, she is obeisant to the Doctor's orders to get into shape by eating only whole wheat and drinking only from a spring (which she accidentally falls into when she leans over to get a drink).

story: Ladies, I apologize for peeping through the hole, but, you know, it's just standard protocol.
column3: The standard way to use a hole is to peep.
column4: 覗 peek Peep through the HOLE and your HUSBAND will SEE you.

story: That hole is still too tight. Bring the saw to enlarge it!
column3: I tried to 搾 (#1422) my fingers through a hole. It did not work! But I was clever and amputated my fingers with the saw. However, it was still tight. But I am not stupid! Why not enlarging the hole with the saw? Wait! I should have done that first! Oh no...
column4: Use a saw to enlarge a hole that's too tight.

story: There's a knock on my door, and it's the local dentist accompanied by an elephant. The latter is a patient, and the dentist explains that he wants to drill a hole in its tusk, but his normal dentist's drill is too small, so could he borrow my big DIY drill. Anyway, I drill the hole in the tusk for him.
column3: No drill? Pfft, just use this here tusk as a drill and make all the holes you can!
column4: The smugglers used live elephants to smuggle their drugs: they drilled holes into the tusks and hid the drugs there.

story: The original Japanese kitchen stoves were powered by electric eels (hey, Edison never made it to the far east!), so a small hole had to be placed in the dirt under the stove (for the eels to swim around in).
column3: We finally found the tortoise that escaped (縄 (#1477)), it has somehow crawled into a hole just above the kitchen stove and had become quite dirty.
column4: I'm going to make some turtle soup, so I take an unbound 亀 (#573) out of a hole in the soil, to place on the kitchen stove.

story: When you're a slave to your crotch like me, you're often afraid to stand because you don't want people to see your longness.
column3: In the slave's crotch there something standing with a vase-like longness. What could it be?
column4: 竪子=孺子, 竪琴, 竪=縦, 竪縞=縦縞, 竪 (#2663) ジュ, たて ... Parts: 臤, 立 (cf: 臤 = loincloth? 賢い賢 (#915), 堅い堅 (#917), 緊張緊 (#1474), 腎臓腎 (#916)) ... Note: This shares reading and meaning with 縦 縦 (#1436). Keyword chosen to differentiate, but it means Vertical ( Examples: ) ... Story: The best Loincloths have Vertical Longness, to cover up when you are Standing.

story: When I hear rustling in the night I stand up and go to check out what it is but it's always just wind.
column3: Vase, wind (with gnats): He heard a rustling outside and when he checked, saw a host of killer gnats riding the wind in the direction of his house. He quickly jumped into the large standing vase and put the stopper in, to ride it out...
column4: (thanks cameron_en) But I prefer the keyword "suddenly"! When I suddenly! hear rustling in the night I stand up and go to check out what it is but it's always just wind. さっと 【颯と · 颯っとirregular】quickly (esp. actions) —Usually written using kana alone.

story: A characteristic of an outpost is the lack of usual facilities. Here we see a fortune teller with no crystal ball having to make do with a vase.
column3: At a good outpost, there are guards standing and a fortune teller that can foresee any threat to stop it on time.
column4: Stand up, fortune telling: Something scary happened at the Mars outpost near the alien ruins. Suddenly, one of the soldiers stood up and started to tell fortunes. (Which weren't all that positive for mankind). Then he fell down and never spoke again.

story: Many repose peacefully in a blue vase after being cremated.
column3: You put a vase over that annoying Smurf. Ahhhh... Repose!
column4: I pose once by a red vase & then repose by a blue one.

story: It's a concubine: feel free to 接 (#725) her all you want.
column3: A concubine is a woman you can stand on and walk all over. She does not have the same status as a wife. The contrast can be seen in the compound: 妻妾 (one's wife and mistresses). Both are women; however, the wife gets a brush for her hair; whereas the concubine is stood upon and trampled.
column4: Concubines are women of low standing (which is also why the woman is at the bottom here).

story: Cloak, clock: The cloaks of Muslims have a tiny clock on their lapel, so that they can keep track on when to pray...
column3: "The boss wants to see you now," I said, grabbing him by the lapel of his cloak and dragging him into the room.
column4: The lapel of a cloak sometimes has a clock pinned on it for meditation sessions.

story: Cloak, fit: The lined kimono was lined in such a way that it made people appear to be slimmer than they really were. Even people who didn't fit in the accompanying cloak still bought the lined kimono...
column3: Girls all lined up in front of the cloakroom in the department store to be fitted with lined kimonos for their coming of age ceremony.
column4: A lined kimono is like a cloak but more expensive because they're custom fit.

story: You can 誇 誇 (#1332) with words, or you can instead show off your expensive cloak and hakama.
column3: 袴, 紋付羽織袴, (人名: 袴田) 袴 (#2670) はかま ... Parts:衤, 夸 (cf: 跨ぐ跨 (#2772), 誇る誇 (#1332) ... Note: The RHS 夸 (not a Kanji itself), actually appears in other Kanji (袴(桍)袴 (#2670), 跨跨 (#2772), 誇誇 (#1332), 胯). So a primitive of Dog Catcher (Dog on the floor caught in a snare)? ... Story: Dog Catcher wears a Cloak and a Hakama (Pleated Skirt), both imprinted with picture of fire hydrants, to catch his dogs.
column4: Many present wished they were wearing the hakama (pleated skirt) and cloak. Fortunately, we were spared any boastful words (誇 - 言 = 夸) from the lucky groom. Note: 夸 actually means "extravagant/handsome". So words + extravagant = 誇 (#1332).

story: Before you open the sliding door to the core of the nuclear reactor, you'd better put on your anti-radioactivity cloak.
column3: You move aside the sliding door into the inner (core) section of the house and catch a glimpse of the wife without her cloak on.
column4: The safety violations at Japanese nuclear power plants are egregious! Not only are they built inside ancient Japanese castles, there are no considerations for contamination. I was visiting last month when I opened a sliding door to reveal the cloak room. All the scientists had haphazardly piled their cloaks on the CORE itself!

story: The Chinese panpipe is an old musical instrument made of bamboo. People practiced the Chinese panpipe their whole life just so that they could play for the emperor, often a bad performance would have the emperor take their life away from them.
column3: Pan plays a Chinese panpipe, fashioned of bamboo, to instill life within the people.
column4: The Chinese panpipe is made by using different sized cells of bamboo.

story: The bamboo was felled to make a raft.
column3: Bamboo, fell: To escape the forestfire, the pandas felled some of the bamboo to make a raft and escape.
column4: Mr T is sick of this fiesta and needs something to do. Looking up, he sees that he's in the midst of a bamboo grove and so decides to fell some of the bamboo and make a raft while the fiesta goes on. There's no water in sight, but Mr T won't fly, so if he's to get out of here then by raft it must be. This, incidentally, is the beginning of a great love of building boats and such--after all, it wasn't long after this episode that Mr T was to submit [供 (#1935)] the Ark.

story: I see a load of bamboo for sale at a bargain price and decide it’s so cheap that I’ll buy it and make my own bamboo blinds.
column3: Bamboo blinds are pretty shitty so you can usually find them at bargain prices.
column4: Bamboo blinds are a hot seller at the bamboo bargain.

story: If you are making a rattan box, then the best advice I can give you is to use bamboo and keep it simple.
column3: The bamboo rice basket is a simple basket made of bamboo.
column4: Creating a regular 箱 (#942) requires all sort of special interlocking designs between the bamboo. Why not keep it simple and just create a rattan box?

story: In Japan they use bamboo poles to dry their clothes on.
column3: 竺 (#2684) + bamboo pole = bamboo clothlines.
column4: 釣り竿, 物干し竿, 旗竿, 検地竿, 竿 (#2676) さお ... Parts:竹, 干 ... Similars: 極極 (#2052), 竿竿 (#2676) ... Story: Pole for hanging out your Pandas out to dry on the Clothesline.

story: Compare the effectiveness of beating a person with bamboo, a belt, and a spatula.
column3: Compared to before when Japanese mothers used to throw a hood over their naughty kids and beat them bloody with bamboo, the modern "kitchen-discipline by spatula" seems much more civilized.
column4: Japanese spatula is made of bamboo and is the size of two spoons. In fact it's so big, it can be used as a hood or an umbrella when it rains. Picture wearing a spatula on your head to get that middle part memorized.

story: If I have any bamboo shoots left over from my stirfry I wrap them up in foil to keep them moist overnight. Then I can use them the next day.
column3: I always roll up my foil and hide it in sticks of bamboo overnight. This is to foil any attempt to steal it.
column4: Imagine staying in a bamboo forest overnight with only one of those thin, foil survival blankets to keep warm. http://www.lasoutdoors.com/images/CS02-Reflective-Survival-bl.JPG.

story: The film director is making a new low budget version of "The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe". As we watch him, he appears to be constructing something out of bamboo. Finally the director says, "Well, no lion or witch yet, but thanks to this bamboo at least the wardrobe is finished".
column3: The director is taking out the actors he stored in his wardrobe on his bamboo clothes hangers.
column4: 箪笥預金笥 (#2679) (タン)ス ... Parts: 竹, 司 ... This always appears as part of the compound 箪笥: 用箪笥, 茶箪笥, 整理箪笥, and usually appears in kana. ... Story: Quentin Tarantino has such as Asian fetish, that his furniture is made entirely of Bamboo. Even his Wardrobe. When he is on location in a rainy place, his clothes get all wet, but he don't care. It's bamboo, baby. ... cf:.

story: Bamboo, in front: Martial arts movie. The hero walks through a bamboo forest, and suddenly an arrow shaft stands quivering in the bamboo tree just in front of him. Time for some action scenes.
column3: If you suddenly see bamboo sticking out in front of you, it's most likely an arrow shaft.
column4: Bamboo forms the arrow shaft you shoot in front of you.

story: I can't play this ancient harp! It's craftsmanship is so mediocre! The bamboo is hard and stiff! Give me a new koto any day of the week.
column3: The ancient harp was fabricated without wood, a mediocre version crafted only of bamboo.
column4: I used bamboo to craft a mediocre ancient harp.

story: Mr T uses a stick of slender bamboo to beat his taskmaster that he chased up into the tree.
column3: The wise sensei instructs Mr. T while they perch atop a tree: Oh, you must be supple and thin like the slender bamboo!
column4: Slender bamboo used to be obese bamboo, but because of simple 修 修 (#1858) - whacks from a walking stick by the taskmaster and his assistant, the person primitive, was all it took - it has lost its earlier shape and become a fit and slender tree.

story: During post-production of a movie, redaction is required for "red action", or action that results in a bloody accident, like when they miscalculated how large an object Spider-Man could hold up with both hands.
column3: The editor of a family newspaper finds a story that’s a bit too graphic. It describes in detail how during kendo practice Spiderman's bamboo stick snapped and impaled the eye of a nearby St. Bernard. “Hmm, some redaction needed here,” thinks the editor.
column4: Calculate, st bernard, venom: Venom had made an insidious plan to strike at the redaction office of the Daily Bugle, to scare the free press. He plans to leave corpses of dead St.Bernards on every desk of the news office. Now, he still needs to calculate how many St. Bernards are required...

story: My bamboo cane is collapsible. It can fold into two separate bamboo sticks.
column3: The simplest thing you can make from bamboo is a bamboo cane. You only need two pieces: one for the shaft and one for the handle.
column4: 天竺, 唐天竺, 天竺鼠, 天竺牡丹, 天竺木綿, 竺, 竺 (#2684) チク(竹), 名乗り: あつし ... Parts:竹, 二 (cf 竿竿 (#2676), ... Similars: 側杖杖 (#2566), 天竺竺 (#2684) ... Note: Kanji slang for India (天竺), used for animal, plant names: 天竺鼠, 天竺牡丹, and as a general term for things from India and China (唐天竺). (cotton, Buddhism, etc.) ... Story: I stole the Rod "丨" from my Pole (竿) to use as my Bamboo Cane.

story: The chess player has a bamboo fan that he brings along to his matches for good luck. It has the power to make the user WIN NOW. Thus it is a winnowing fan.
column3: The hard working peasants get a little annoyed watching the aristocrats sitting around playing chess, so they start a revolt and whack the chess board and pieces away with their bamboo winnowing baskets.
column4: A winnowing fan made of bamboo is used to cool off the basketball player.

story: I see a panda wearing a backpack, and every so often something inside the backpack reaches out and grabs bamboo. (it’s acutally a baby panda reaching out to grab bamboo to eat).
column3: If you've ever seen the anime Mushishi, this is what Ginko uses to carry all his stuff in. It's like a box/backpack looking thing that he carries on his back. Here I see his reaching arms scrounging around in it looking for a shoot of special bamboo.
column4: With Kung Fu Panda being all the craze recently, I wasn't very surprised to see a schoolkid with a Kung Fu Panda backpack. But imagine my shock when he reached out into his backpack and pulled out some bamboo.

story: Each livraison (installment) of the scrapbook is delivered by post, and sits resting on your doorstep for when you get home. Of course, it might blow away so the postman has put heavy bamboo blocks on top of it.
column3: Bamboo, konbini hentai: The special issue of the popular konbini hentai is divided into different livraisons (installment). Each comes with a small piece of bamboo, which are - after obtaining all livraisons- combined in a bamboo nude statue the female main character!
column4: A limited livraison (edition) of manga made of bamboo.

story: Should you put bamboo through your tongue? If you don't already know the answer yourself, you shouldn't even ask.
column3: Note: Mantixen has the right idea with his story. This should is not a moral obligation (eg, something you "should" do), but rather something that is expected (eg, my keys "should" be around here somewhere...). If you know some intermediate Japanese grammar, you'll be familiar with it as はず. Story: 「私の舌は竹から作られているよ！」「そんなはずないでしょう！｣.
column4: A bamboo tongue piercing should feel good, but I'd rather she took it out first.

story: To winnow you need two things: a winnowing fan (no. 2643 箕) and a pelt (to use as a bag to collect the grain you winnowed).
column3: Now you may have seen the traditional winnowing technique whereby grain is placed on a sheet (or pelt) which is then held at the corners and flicked to send the grain into the air. The 箕 (#2685)箕 creates a draft to disperse the chaff. So the fan, by itself is not enough. To winnow we need to pair the winnowing fan with the pelt.
column4: Having no winnowing fan handy, the servant was forced to flap a large pelt about in an attempt to winnow (fan) his master.

story: Settlings at the bottom of sake are white and made of rice.
column3: (in drawing order): The settlings you see in sake are actually bits of rice. How do you know? Because they are white.
column4: Settlings are those tiny pieces of white crap that comes from rice that settles to the bottom of miso soup and sake.

story: New cadets aren't allowed to drink with the seniors, so they have to settle for the rice lees at the bottom of the empty sake bottles.
column3: The other cadets are really cruel: giving this cadet only the lees of the sake to drink….
column4: Bender as a cadet is really cruel to the rest of his batallion, he only lets them have the dregs of the rice. The rest he distills and drinks.

story: The uncivilized used rice as paste.
column3: Let the rice age for one month and it becomes an absolutely wonderful paste.
column4: The meaning is starch used as glue to paste things. While in Japan they used to extract that paste from 米 (#987), in the West old flesh served that purpose. The old flesh of horses and other waste from the slaughterhouse that was boiled to extract gelatin. Seems rather 胡 (#2537) to me, I like the rice-approach better...

story: Unhulled rice still needs a blade taken to it.
column3: What's all this unhulled rice still doing here? You were supposed to hull this yesterday! Pick up that blade and get to work immediately!
column4: Rice that has been through the blade is most thoroughly unhulled rice, as it lacks the hull.

story: Rice bran is for old people: its benefits to sanity in additional to being delicious rice make it an instant sell.
column3: "Good for the bowels and good for the brain, rice bran'll keep you sane."
column4: Rice bran keeps you sane. But only if it's made from real rice. None of that fake stuff.

story: Rice is easy to digest, so if you poke through your excrement, finding bits of rice is uncommon.
column3: It is uncommon to find rice in your excrement. Corn, on the other hand...
column4: くそ！Noah exclaimed when he found his annoying neighbors had left their excrements in his rice field yet again. With a helping hand of God, it was decided to flood the world, and let his neighbors drown in their own excrements. Just like flushing a toilet.

story: Maybe the Japanese ought to rethink their nickname for America. Seriously, the only "rice" I have seen in the wild west is foxtail millet.
column3: West, rice: In the old west there was a special type of plant (it's now extinct): the foxtail millet. It behaved like regular millet, but when somebody wanted to reap it, it ran away as quick as a fox, leaving a small trail of rice.
column4: Foxtail millet is a grain that tastes like 栗 (#1735), but looks like 米 (#987).

story: This should do the trick: http://tinyurl.com/dzhu4g.
column3: Little known fact about Venom is that he's a genius mechanic. He even rigged up a car for himself where he linked up missiles to the hood. Look out Spidey!
column4: In one of those ridiculous sentai TV programs, after the "car rangers" fire their missiles at the enemy monster, you can clearly see the thread that pulls them together when they link up to form CAR-RANGER-MON.

story: Spidey assists the older ladies at the twine convention by providing them with a continuous line of twine to knit with. They thank him for the twine with some wine.
column3: Spiderman + methodical: If you want to be like Spiderman, you'll have to be methodical and start from the beginning by learning how to make webs with twine. Note: 侖 is an extremely rare kanji meaning "methodical", I remember this with: "A meeting of scrapbookers who are very methodical".
column4: Spiderman, scientific meeting (meeting+scrapbook): Spiderman was attending a scientific meeting on twining. Not for handiwork, but to improve the strength of his webbing!

story: Spiderman, burgler - money (賊 (#381)): When the old lady returned from visiting the fiesta, she found a burglar in her home tied up with carpet yarn. A note said: Regards from you friendly neighborhood Spiderman. Well, she was not amused when she saw the remains of her carpet.
column3: Having failed to get the money, the 賊 (#381) escaped 'Spiderman'-style, by making a long 糸 (#1431) out of the carpet yarn.
column4: The burglar isn't getting Spider-Man's money, but he can get tied up with carpet yarn if he wants.

story: Spiderman, half: Since only half of his family was left (aunt May, uncle died), Spiderman kept strong ties with her.
column3: I must buy some more ties – half of mine are in threads. (Edit: All the kanji dictionaries I have checked classify this character as thread + half. Depending on the font, though, the right side often appears as a variant of 半 with the top two strokes sloping outwards).
column4: Spiderman is remarkable in that half his family ties are not human. This other half is a somewhat "small half" indicated by the 小-like element on top of 半.

story: Spiderman is put in a jail cell by the fashion police for wearing scarlet. (His fellow inmates include Scarlet O'Hara, Scarlett Johansson, Captain Scarlet, The Scarlet Pimpernel, etc).
column3: Without his SCARLET threads, peter parker is UN-SPIDERMAN...
column4: If you wear scarlet threads, the fashion police will put you in jail. [Thanks Katsuo].

story: Spider-Man's religion is a synthesis of spirituality and scientific proof.
column3: Spiderman, religion: Spiderman discovered that the Scientology religion (which just opened a chapterhouse in his city) was a synthesis of idiotic believes and a little mystery. Everything to obtain large sums of money from its 'believers'.
column4: Spiderman created his own religion, called The Church of Arachnology. Critics say it's nothing but a syncretic religion, a synthesis of fantasy and existing religions, with a dash of mind control thrown in. [The idea of a 'syncretic religion' helps me remember this keyword.]

story: A vegetarian replaces all his leather bootlaces with string, saying “There’s no sign of the cow in this thread!”.
column3: Spider-Man suspects there's a cow walking through his room while he's asleep, but when he wakes up he sees no sign of the cow. He decides to tie string around everything in the room, which will create a boobytrap for the cow.
column4: What's the only sign of the cow you'll find in Spider-Man's house? Why, string cheese, of course!

story: Spider-Man poses with his hands on his hips to convey being larger than life.
column3: Spiderman grows a chinstrap beard, and his friends elbow him in the side, guffawing and saying "hey, nice beard, Pete." http://www.ftmguide.org/images/chinstrap.gif 八紘一宇　はっこういちう.
column4: [1]: this kanji 'means' "string; vast, expansive". [2]:「八紘」: "a net that stretches over and connects in eight directions [cardinal points] (...) a reference to the land as a whole". See also [3]: 「八荒」: "(...) the eight corners of the land (...) the land as a whole". So my 変態 imagination gave me the keyword "worldwide" (web? ;-). References: [1] [ http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/紘 ] [2] [ http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/八紘 ] [3] [ http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/八荒 ].

story: Spiderman, cave, computer, human legs, soil: To summarize the newest Spiderman comic: Spidy needs to turn off a computer in a cave (countdown clock for nuclear bomb). However, his human legs get stuck in the soil (some kind of quicksand). The situation seems hopeless... but somehow at the end of the comic, Spiderman has saved the day.
column3: To summarize the story of Spiderman, he was a computer geek who lived in a cave. Then he got super powers and his human legs rarely touch the ground anymore.
column4: Spiderman>cave>computer>human legs>soil. Looks like a complicated plot but can be summarized as: Cyborg (computer on humanoid legs) runs amok in the 庄 (#2345) 庄. The hobbits call for Spiderman who saves day. The end.

story: Spider-Man is quite the womanizer. When he sees a hot babe, he whistles and calls, 'Hey, gorgeous, how'd you like to be bound up with Spidey for a decameron?' Unfortunately most of the women he whistles at don't know what a decameron is; some of them think it's a hot car.
column3: Spidey thinks de cameron_en is gorgeous. Why thank you, Spiderman :-).
column4: Spider-Man goes out with gorgeous girls a decameron at a time.

story: Spiderman solemnly swears that he hates embroidery, but everyone knows he loves it, he's always got the sewing machine out when nobody else is around.
column3: Embroidery is a much more serious affair than mere sowing. So if you see someone who is holding a thread and looking very solemn, then they are probably doing embroidery.
column4: Because of the special thread Spiderman uses for embroidery, and the special location from which it is produced, he is always solemn when he does embroidery, because it makes him hemorroidery.

story: Spiderman decides to try a new diet of sprouts to see how it affects the consistency of his web. To his surprise (150m above ground) a lovely line of pongee comes out instead. Time to think quickly.
column3: Spiderman, sprout: Pongee is a soft thin woven cloth. Spiderman - a textile buff in his own right- found out that the mold growing on rotting Brussel sprouts may also be used to make pongee. And it's much cheaper than silk!
column4: Pongee is the soft thin cloth made from the thread of mashed brussel sprouts.

story: Spiderman's a strange guy, wearing such ornate outfits to make himself look 綺麗【きれい】.
column3: Spider-Man looks strange in his ornate costume, but that's why you can't take your eyes off of him.
column4: SPIDERMAN wears such STRANGE outfits, that they seem almost ORNATE compared to the thugs he captures.

story: The rice seedlings notice that Spiderman's blocking their path to the promised land. So they put on da mask which was made of a figured cloth and managed to outsmart spidey.
column3: Those rice-seedlings on walking legs had to carry this thread all the way from the middle east to introduce the beautiful damask to the Japanese.
column4: Damask: a firm lustrous fabric made with flat patterns in a satin weave on a plain-woven ground on jacquard looms. Sounds fancy. Clearly not the kind of threads you should wear while planting rice seedlings and walking around in the field.

story: The thread with a mysterious origin... hint: its not from a plant!
column3: It turns out that catgut is the mystery thread of bowstrings (see 1386).
column4: Spiderman vs Gandalf - Gandalf uses his lighting magic to attack spidey but of course spideys too fast, he avoids it while it accidentally blows the cat up, catguts all strewn all over the place.

story: Spiderman, tall: Spiderman seemed taller than he really was, due to the stripes in his uniform. As is to be expected from our textile expert...
column3: If you wear clothes with vertical stripes, those threads will make you look taller.
column4: From afar you see Spiderman looking especially tall. as you get closer you realise he's actually riding a striped horse, or zebra if you want to be pedantic (縞馬).

story: Spiderman accepts the ribbon for most fashionable super hero.
column3: No one can accept the fact that Spiderman is a gimp.
column4: I used The Gimp to create such a real-looking photograph of Spiderman, it was immediately accepted by The Daily Bugle.

story: If there are very few threads, then the light will come through and the fabric be considered to be a gossamer.
column3: Because it has too few threads, Spider-Man decided not to use gossamer to make his skin-tight costume.
column4: Spiderman, few: Spiderman designed a new webbing, consisting of only a few threads. The webbing is like gossamer, but stronger than steel.

story: A household spoon is used for the rudder of your model boat.
column3: Tip: house + spoon : This combination of primitives appears four times in Heisig. REF: 蛇 (#558), rudder (FRAME 2674), 詑, 陀 (#2952).
column4: Let house + sitting on the ground = cold beer (because I like sitting on the porch under the shade of my roof drinking a cold beer. Also, I haven't used cold beer as a primitive yet, and surely that's blasphemy.) Story for rudder: The laconic fisherman heads upriver while relaxing in his boat, sitting back while the motor putts along, one hand on the rudder, the other on his cold beer.

story: My friend's new dangly earrings are interesting--cacti strung together with butterfly cocoons.
column3: Strung together, with no ears to hear for predators, the cocoons rest on the cacti for safety.
column4: 聯邦=連邦, 聯盟=連盟, 聯合=連合, 連合艦隊=聯合艦隊 聯 (#2716) レン(連) ... Parts: 耳, 幺, 幺, Cactus (cf 滋賀県滋 (#1489), 慈しむ慈 (#1490), 關東軍(Kwantung Army)關) ... Note: old alternate version of modern 連連 (#305) ... Story: When the Doubly mysterious man took off his hats, I could see his large Ears and his Cactus legs. He lost a bunch of weight recently so his 4X size pants are now 4Y and have to be Strung Together tightly to keep from fallling down.

story: Policymakers' ears have to be attentive to the heart of the public.
column3: You don't have to be Spiderman to receive 総 (#1466) public acceptance, you just need an attentive ear and a good heart.
column4: A wise person knows how to hear the public's heart ().

story: Ear, sprout, snare: When the summons reached his ears, he sprang up and started running. However, he suddenly noticed a delicious cooked meal of Brussel sprouts. He started to eat it, but it was snared! Appearantly, his loyalty had been tested and it was clear which was more important to him...
column3: When my parents asked me to eat my sprouts, I threw a snare at their ears. The next day I received a summons to appear in court.
column4: To summons a rabbit to dinner place a brussel sprout on a snare, then listen with your ear until you hear the snap of the trap.

story: The waitress's addiction to drugs got her caught up in a huge mess with the mafia. Before maiming her and throwing her into the river to 沈 (#1888), they cut off one of her ears.
column3: Fearful that I was addicted to ear piercings, my dad put a crown around one of my legs so that I couldn’t go to the piercing dude.
column4: There are many forms of addiction. This kanji represents the iPod addict. The ears are plugged into the headphones (crown) while the person on walking legs, oblivious to the approaching bus, steps off the curb.

story: Quiet!!!! The city walls have ears he exclaimed.
column3: The city walls have ears!? Did you say that with an exclamation or question mark?
column4: This really means "question mark" so I assume Heisig was referring to an exclamation mark rather than some sort of verbal outburst. The RTKIII keywords are truly atrocious...I sort of picture the primitive on the right as resembling a question mark, so the kanji looks to me like a cartoonish ear straining to listen with a question mark next to it.

story: Fleas jump onto your crotch, take two drops of blood, and then go on their merry way: what vile insects!
column3: Right side of 騒 (#1985) (but without the drops there). A flea is an insect that is depicted here as jumping from (or to) a crotch (the two drops). Note: this is indeed flea, not louse, which has its own character (虱). I'm not sure of the stroke order, but by the rule of drawing from top to bottom, the crotch drop should come first. The louse (虱) then is of course a drop-like insect that attaches itself to body hairs by little hooks.
column4: Flea! One bite in the middle of my crotch another just to the left & I can still feel the insect itself crawling around down there.

story: The crab isn’t truly an insect, but certainly looks like one. They’re real tasty, too, but you have to unravel it if you want to eat it.
column3: You unravel a crab leg, but insects fall out of it. It's probably too old to be edible.
column4: Fun fact about this kanji: In Ancient China, they used the parts 解 and 虫 because a Crab's legs were easy to take apart (分解しやすい).

story: At the zoo, most animals think of insects as just good sources of protein.
column3: Insects are fed to the critters at the zoo for protein.
column4: The zoo's had this huge bug problem lately! Actually the problem wasn't the bugs exactly. All of the animals were eating the bugs, and got so much protein that they all became super strong! (imagine ripped penguins!) They started strong-arming all the visitors for their wallets and eventually ripped the iron bars of their cages open!

story: Rather than die, tenacious insects go down into hibernation.
column3: Imagine Jack Black as an insect. "Whoa, that was some good nectar. Well, I'm happy, my belly's round, my band just played a sellout show for the ladybirds (and oh yeah, there were groupies, lemme tell ya)... now it's time for THIS insect to go into hibernation. Scientists call it diapause. Rock."
column4: After hanging out with his groupies and living it up for like a week straight, all Jack Black from Tenacious D wants to do is settle into hibernation and sleep it off in peace. Unfortunately for him, though, his bed is full of insects, and the tenacious little buggers won't leave him alone!

story: I unbind my tortoise to let him catch that pesky insect the housefly.
column3: Insect, unbound tortoise: Instead of using pesticides, you can also use natures' resources. For example, to get rid of houseflies (those pesky insects), you just unbind your pet tortoise, which will make short work of it.
column4: The housefly is the insect that buzzes as loudly as two eels (think electricity).

story: The ant is an insect of righteousness, putting the group before its individual concerns.
column3: The ant is an insect who lives by the principles of righteousness. You can see the ants working hard every day to ensure the well-being of the colony. But if someone tries to harm the colony, the ants will respond by inflicting righteous vengeance en masse!
column4: In Aesop's stories, the ant is often considered righteous.

story: While I’m game-hunting, I cover my dogs with wax so that they won’t be bother by insects.
column3: I like to go 猟 (#1940) for exotic insects and then store them in wax.
column4: When game hunting, I cover my face and hands with wax to keep away the insects. (+Megaqwerty, minus "dog").

story: Shrimp are the only “insects” that I can eat in my spare time: anything else requires way too much willpower.
column3: 蝦夷, 蝦夷地, 蝦 (#2728) えぞ, エビ ... Parts: 虫, Hobby (暇暇 (#2027) - 日) ... Tip: Many different Kanji for shrimp: 蝦,海老, 鰕､蛯. This Kanji is the old name for the Ainu: Ezo 蝦夷, and their land Ezochi 蝦夷地 (now Hokkaido). (It also has meant Frog as well.) ... Shrimp on menus and such is 海老. Tiger Prawns (車海老), Lobster (伊勢海老).
column4: Bubba's hobby was shrimp, and everything to do with shrimp - bioled shrimp, fried shrimp, rotten shrimp covered with insects... hold on a second.

story: The octopus holds up two of his legs so that they look like antennas and then walks on the other six. He bears a strong resemblance to an insect when he does that.
column3: The octupus seduces the INSECTS with a CANDLE to eat them later.
column4: The octopus enjoys a candlelit dinner of fine, imported insects with a loved one. It holds all the silverware as well as its glasses of wine and water, all at the same time.

story: 螺　(にし) is a fresh water mollusk with a shell like a screw. When the mollusk has died the shell is used by insects like a house. Thus, insects accumulate in the screw shell.
column3: Insects accumulate if a screw is missing.
column4: I’ve accumulated so many insects at this point, I could easily screw anyone over.

story: Cicadas are simple insects: they just pop out of the ground, mate, and die, albeit only every ten years or so.
column3: The cicada is a simple insect, making noise, mating, and dying.
column4: The cicada is an insect with a simple yet rich song.

story: There he sits, eating insects with his long tongue and blending in with the green ivy. It may no be easy being green, but it is easy being a frog.
column3: A frog hides in the ivy to catch insects.
column4: A frog lashes out with ivy instead of a tongue a gobbles up an insect on its left かえる.

story: The moth is an insect with an ego -- always looking for the (lime)light.
column3: The moth is an insect that affects your ego by eating holes in your clothes.
column4: “We moths are better than butterflies, you know!” Moths – the insect with an ego.

story: An insect fits right into the clam's mouth before it clamps shut.
column3: Certain species of insect live in clams, they just have to find one that fits.
column4: For contraband purposes, I tried to fit insects into a clam, but that didn’t work out too well.

story: The leech is an insect that sucks on you, but good luck reaching climax with all that blood being lost.
column3: The climax of this little insect's life is sucking your blood. Leeches suck.
column4: This is a special type of leech you can attach to your junk to make you climax -- say what you will but those leeches can suck.

story: An insect crosses ten thousand cliffs to make it to sea, only to be eaten by an oyster.
column3: 牡蛎=牡蠣=蠣=蛎=硴, 蛎 (#2736) レイ(励), かき ... Parts: 虫, Cliff/Drag, 万 (cf. 栃木県栃 (#553), 励ます励 (#931), 砺砺 (#2641)) ... Note: 旧字体-牡蠣=牡蛎, with 萬 for 万 ... similars: (cf 蝦蝦 (#2728), 蛎蛎 (#2736), 蛤蛤 (#2734)) ... Story: When you are all out of power to encourage(励-力) your friends, or maybe you are feeling all whet (砺-石), just remember, the world is your oyster. Aw shucks.
column4: We can only advance through dedication and teamwork. Here we see ten thousand oysters on top of each others, trying to overcome a cliff to form a new settlement somewhere else. Unfortunately, those at the bottom got a heavy burden, and now an insect is tickling one of them..

story: Keeping my eye fixed directly over the paper, I hold down the ivy and melt the strands with my magic wand. Viola, ruled lines are created! I bet most people think a machine does it.
column3: The cyclops couldn't make ruled lines with his wooden wand because it wasn't smooth, so he had to use a square jewel.
column4: When my eye crawls up Emily Ratajkowski's body like ivy in the blurred lines video, my magic wand stirs. (Close enough to ruled lines!)

story: In Japanese RPGs, you are well advised to add a stole to your clothing as a "freebie" way to add defensive points without swapping out some other garment. But since you can't find them in the shops, you have to "stole" that stole from a glamorous NPC who is ostensibly there to aid your quest.
column3: This stole really adds something to your garment, it's the final touch.
column4: The stole is a garment easy to add to your outfit: just drape it over your shoulders.

story: A monk's sash is a garment that has grains of sand in it from beachside meditations.
column3: The monk stashes grains of sand in his sash and hides it under his garment. Probably emptied the hourglass to hasten dinner time.
column4: 袈裟, 大袈裟な裟 (#2701)サ ... Parts:沙沙 (#2296), 衣 ... Note: 袈裟 only compound for 袈袈 (#2700)裟裟 (#2701) ... Story: Like Grains of Sand through the hourglass measures time, a Monk's Sashay through the abbey can mark the time for the initiates. Each time through he removes another Garment, till he is a sky-clad monk. Well except for the Monk's Sash. That he keeps on.

story: I’ll do the honors! So, I grabbed the knife and made an incision into the Thanksgiving turkey.
column3: On Soviet Thanksgiving, turkey make incision in YOU!
column4: The turkey thought the surgery was going to be for it's poor circulation, but once he was sedated and saw the surgeons making the first incision he noticed their hands were full of stuffing, it was almost Thanksgiving, what a fool he had been!

story: At Thanksgiving, there’s a pretty common bet: I wonder how much you can stuff into your mouth!
column3: If you want to exhibit your kanji mastery, then be sure to utilise this character every time you write ....かな, as in そう哉 - which is what the character traditionally represents.
column4: As you eat Thanksgiving dinner, you wonder: "口にどのぐらい入る哉。。。”.

story: In order to provide superior counsel, I spoke to him for ten days.
column3: I was counselled for ten days about my bad language. It was f**king horrible.
column4: If you're in a highly-visible position, you should wait a decameron and consult with your legal counsel before you say anything to the press.

story: When receiving a gift, you should say something polite.
column3: How about 'tedious' instead. Think of all those tedious things you have to say when you receive something.
column4: Jap to Eng dictionaries seem to define this as "wordy or long-winded" instead. New Keyword = long-winded STORY: The spoiled tall kid who is used to receiving so much attention is so long-winded! Words just keep coming out of his mouth!

story: In many Sicilian villages, when words are spoken which can never be taken back, a vendetta exists until this retribution - "a turkey for a turkey" - can be extracted.
column3: Two turkeys (one from Foster Farms and the other from Butterball) exchange words that cause a vendetta.
column4: This might be helpful: http://img251.imageshack.us/img251/3346/turkeysrevenge.jpg.

story: Words in the East remonstrate those who stand out.
column3: While talking to an eastern man: "I will remonstrate to you how to draw this kanji." "Don't you mean 'demonstrate'?" "No, I mean REMONSTRATE!" remonstrated the man.
column4: In the east, you have to be particularly careful with the words you use when remonstrating with someone. (The cultural differences make it easy to cause offense.) 諌める (いさめる): to remonstrate, to warn not to do something 諌止 (かんし): dissuasion 切諌 (せっかん): admonition, expostulation 直諌 (ちょっかん): personal admonition 諌早湾の干拓現場 (いさはやわんのかんたくげんば): site of the Isahaya Bay reclamation project.

story: When a Japanese person says they'll meet you at the capital, it's best to verify whether they mean Tokyo or Kyoto.
column3: Cameron_en's story is excellent. With emphasis added: When a Japanese person says they'll meet you at the capital, it's best to verify whether they mean Tokyo (東京) or Kyoto (京都).
column4: You sure that the capital said that? Sorry, but I'll have to go verify that.

story: Compliments are words of approval.
column3: The words spoken between the two husbands who approve of how each spends their wife's hard earned money are nothing but compliments. "Good job old chap!" "A fine car you purchased on her credit!" "What nice designer pants, won't she be miffed!"
column4: When someone approves of your work, they compliment you with words.

story: Word, needle, fishhook: The prisoner didn't speak a word in response to our query, so we got out our needles and fishhooks to get things going.
column3: I needed to query as to how much ten fishhooks costs so I said to the shopkeeper "How much for ten fishhooks?"
column4: If I want to know if the primitives ten and fish hook were used previously, I query my spreadsheet with the words given, and find 迅 (#298). Well, well, that was a swift answer.

story: When you split up from your partner, you say words that cut things off for good, like a guillotine.
column3: Words, guillotine: The prisoner was given the opportunity to speak a final word, before the guillotine would do its' work. He made a morbid joke, saying to his chest: "Here's head speaking. Let's split up."
column4: Words are the metaphorical guillotine used to split up relationships between people.

story: "I'm going out with an otaku" "I beg your pardon! What did you just say?!"
column3: "I won't tolerate such words in my home!" Beg your pardon?
column4: A strange person suddenly emerges from the shower in your house, naked and bald, saying how you need to help him because his only lock of hair got washed down the drain. "Beg your pardon?"

story: After someone moves into the house next door, and after you give them a best regards gift (something they can fill their shelves with) the words you can now speak are those of familiarity. No more "始めまして" ect.
column3: When you've achieved a certain familiarity with a Japanese person, you can do away with words such as "宜しくお願いします" （よろしく　おねがいします), roughly meaning "please accept my best regards".
column4: Giving words of best regards can establish familiarity.

story: Check-up (診 (#1860)), feathers: When, during the check-up, I noticed that the doctor had feathers sticking out of different bodyparts, I decided that his diagnosis would be fallible, since he obviously was a nut.
column3: At my check-up, the doctor tickled me with feathers and I laughed. Doc says it means I'm fallible.
column4: Thank god doctors are fallible. At my 診 診 (#1860) mine said I had a 珍 珍 (#1859) case of 疹 疹 (#2624) that would make me liable to fall all the damn time, make me change shape, and could only be cured by sprouting wings. Frightening words indeed but fortunately his fallibility was greater than his credibility.

story: doubtful: word, tusk: (During a safari). It may be me, but I am doubtful that the elephant understood any of my words. He's still coming at me, with his tusks ready.
column3: You might say elephants are gentle creatures, but I'm still wary of their tusks.
column4: There is this friend of mine who boast about the elephant TUSK he has decorated his living room with: he swore to me he got them after killing an elephant during a safari. I know too well the value of his WORD and I find it quite doubtful . It s way more likely he bought it somewhere just for the sake of this little charade.

story: Words, lad: The lad keeping watch at the cliff came running to town and began pouring out words. Leader: "What? I don't understand a word you're saying. Oh yeah, now I remember... you're the lad who speaks in proverbs."
column3: As a lad you're taught the words of many proverbs.
column4: Proverbs are profound words of wisdom condensed for a simple lad to remember.

story: If you slander someone with your words, you could end up in jail - Jeffrey Archer.
column3: SLANDER is WORDS that can UNdo one's good reputation.
column4: When I slander a person, I 言 (#335) things that I hope will get the other person in jail.

story: That so-called specialist's exact words were "don't worry, its just an upset stomach!" When it turned out to be cancer, his words dried up quick.
column3: The so called flattering WORDS made me sick to my STOMACH.
column4: It's very difficult for me to stomach my wife's so-called food, but I just don't know the words to tell her ...

story: Words, generation, tree: You see that guy over there having words with that tree? That's a secret agent. And you see that tree there? That's a secret agent too: the new generation of secret agents is not limited to the human race anymore.
column3: Secret agents are taught never to 喋 (#2158) 喋. When their 'mouths' open only carefully chosen words emerge.
column4: Tarzan makes a good secret agent because all his words come out like gibberish so everyone will think he is just an idiot.

story: A study Bible has many footnotes under the words of the Lord.
column3: The footnote's words were buried so far below the page that I had to pull out a candlestick in order to read it.
column4: The lord always has to have the last word, as if everything people say needs a footnote.

story: A parable is like putting ketchup on words to make them easier to swallow.
column3: Have you heard the parable of the ketchup? "Yea, as too much ketchup can ruin a good hot dog, so too can too many words ruin thy reputation. Be sparing, with the ketchup, my brethren, and also spare thy words.
column4: Ketchup, words: Do you know the parable of "The Ketchup and the Holy Word"? No? Well, it's about a boy who spilled ketchup on the Holy Word and then got punished by a priest. Lesson: don't use ketchup above the scripture.

story: Many cars rumble through the streets as the bousouzoku ride through.
column3: When you get three cars going at once at a monster truck rally, you can feel the ground rumble.
column4: In kanji code, 3 = a multitude. A multitude of cars rumble on the highway.

story: Car, dog tag: A car hung with hundreds of military dog tags passed by the police station. The officer on duty immediately called in for reinforcements: the notorious veteran soldier killer had just passed by.
column3: Two kinds of reinforcement the army needs: military cars (tanks) and, of course, 甫: more soldiers.
column4: A cheap way to reinforce your car - cover it in metal dog tags!

story: Wealthy people tend to have cars with solid gold spokes, sometimes they even spin with the car's not in motion, kinda cool.
column3: Wealthy people can afford vintage cars, which have wheels with spokes in them. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:1926_Bentley.jpg.
column4: Wealthy people pay as much for a spoke as I paid for my car.

story: When they offered a really cheap Porsche, my mouth dropped open and I bought that car immediately, but if I had had my ears open, I would have heard, "Some assembly may be required."
column3: When people assemble or gather, they first get in their vehicle and drive to the meeting point. Then, they open their mouths and their ears and share their thoughts and feelings.
column4: You must interpret the assembley instructions carefully in order to build your own car [or you could end up losing a finger]. 揖 (#2362).

story: Imagine that in the cartoon series the pink panther is in a dispute with a skunk. Picture the skunk filling a ladle with its stink liquid and then emptying it onto a snoozing pink panther.
column3: Someone drew a white line down the female black panther's back by pouring white paint from a ladle, and then Pepe mistook the panther for a skunk and started chasing her.
column4: "What's for supper?" Asked one PANTHER to another. "SKUNK stew," replied the other, who promptly got beat with a LADLE for making such nasty food.

story: Money, float: It's despicable. They throw down money off the carnaval float, while there are so many people in this world living in poverty. Just give it to them. Despicable!
column3: When they toss metal, that's all fine and dandy, but when those float people toss down shellfish, ugh!, that's just despicable!
column4: [+Megawerty & abaddon] When they throw money off the floats, that's admirable. But when they throw shellfish off the floats, well, that's downright despicable.

story: You get money from the generation above you.
column3: You get the generation above you to give you money. (note: I've modified the keyword a bit after having just read "Making Sense of Japanese" because it's important to me to integrate into もらう the idea that getting in this sense is to get someone else to give it to you.
column4: 貰う, 貰い手, 貰い物 , 貰い泣き(Cry in Sympathy), 貰い火(catch fire from next door)貰 (#2766) もらう ... Parts: 世, 貝 ... Story: The Kanji makes a point that the keyword does not. In Japanese, the distinction between coming into possesion and someone giving you something is strong. This Kanji uses Generation to indicate that this is not just Getting money, but Getting someone to give you some Money.

story: Bruce Lee made his clams in the bustling city of Hong Kong.
column3: Bruce Lee has money because he is always bustling about.
column4: The co-star of Bruce Lee's last film, Bust Ling, was known more for her ample breasts than her prowess as a martial artist, but she made a dear amount of money for the role, nonetheless.

story: To make atonement for taking one shell, the samurai must pay four shells.
column3: I visit the beach, but redeem part of the cost of the day-trip by collecting and then selling some sea-shells.
column4: As atonement for selling bad shells a samurai was froced to do an old sell. That means he has to sell them all to a samurai for only four shells. (old 売＝賣) Atonement (aganau SHOKUzai).

story: At the border crossing, a man was trying to smuggle a controlled substance in his wooden leg. He would have made it too had he not stumbled and spilled the contents.
column3: If the quality of your wooden leg is poor you will stumble when you walk チ つまず.く.
column4: A pirate's peg leg slips on some weird substance and he stumbles.

story: After He lost a leg in combat, our sovereign king got a wooden leg as a replacement. Since He thought it was a little boring, he added a hoof for kicks. (Wow, that was totally unintentional, I like).
column3: Our sovereign is horse-crazy and even had her own wooden leg fitted with a hoof.
column4: The sovereign customized his peg leg with a hoof because it seemed to have more horsepower.

story: The man who lost his leg in a accident now has to attach a wooden leg to the vestiges of his old leg. He only has himself to blame for drinking and driving.
column3: Upon finding the vestiges of your peg leg, you blame it on poor craftsmanship.
column4: The only vestiges of the town left were a few little bits of wood and peg leg tracks. Clearly, pirates were to blame for this plundering!

story: The amputee boasts about how the ladies just love to straddle his wooden leg.
column3: Same right side as 誇 (#1332). The big one that got away (so big you couldn't straddle it) took your leg with it. コ カ また.がる またが.る また.ぐ be; sit or stand astride; extend over; straddle.
column4: I straddle my LEGS, because I BOAST of what is between them.

story: It's dangerous to kneel with a wooden leg. It might fall off.
column3: "I missed the sign saying 'DANGER MINE FIELD'. It wasn't till I knelt down to tie my shoe laces... ", recounted the man with the wooden leg.
column4: Kneel on your LEGS and pray when there's DANGER.

story: The leader's whiskey bottle is filled with soy sauce since he doesn't drink alcohol but likes to pretend he's one of the boys by making a strained face when he takes a swig.
column3: Soy sauce is the sales leader in Japan but the whiskey bottle is not far below!
column4: The leaders of Japan use to trade soy sauce for whiskey when foreigners first entered Japan.

story: When filling a whiskey bottle with a whey mixture, you've got to get the proportions just so or it will just taste like curdled milk.
column3: If you hold the whiskey bottle just so, it scoops up the 'isk' out of the 'whiskey' and you're left with 'whey'. 'No way!' 'Whey!'
column4: 醍醐, 京都醍醐FSC, 醍醐味 醍 (#2747) ダイ(題） ... Parts: 酉, 是是 (#388) (cf 匙匙 (#2891), 話題題 (#389)) ... Unfortunate keyword: Whey is 乳清. 醍 is the first half of 醍醐 which is probably best thought of as the Buddhist equivalent of "Milk and Honey". It was once a food reference but is now metaphorical for the best. ... Story: Whey is way better with right amount of Whiskey added, just so. A 匙匙 (#2891) full is Just So.

story: Drinking ghee out of a whiskey bottle is rather 胡 (#2470).
column3: GHEE (clarified butter) if stored in a WHISKEY BOTTLE or some other air tight container will not get OLD and has a shelf life of many MONTHS at room temperature. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ghee.
column4: (I'll call this pair Nirvana flavour [1] and Nirvana flavour [2], since they are only used together in the word 醍醐 (だいご) meaning: "ghee (held to be the greatest of all flavours); the ultimate truth of Buddhism; nirvana") A WHISKEY which is aged JUST SO (醍 (#2747)) and a wonderful piece of OLD FLESH (parma ham f.i.) (醐 (#2749)): That's Nirvana flavour for you.

story: Whiskey bottle, receive: When you receive a bottle of whiskey from a Japanese person, large chance it is strong saké. It seems that giving 'sissy' saké is considered impolite.
column3: Now we know why the tall child is so 諄 諄 (#2743) & 惇 惇 (#2378): the effect of the the strong saké. He receives it at cost in the 廓 廓 (#2342) he set up in the cave, of course.
column4: I asked for whiskey, but I received strong sake. I guess it'll do.

story: Malt made from barley is often bound up with rice for brewing.
column3: This means kouji mould, so I think malt is a poor keyword. Sake, shochu and other East Asian spirits use this mould in place of yeast, which is used to make most other alcoholic spirits in the world. Mould and yeast are two different types of fungus. Yeast might have been a better keyword, as it is the organism doing the fermenting. Story: Kouji mould is grown on rice specially bound up to form a starter culture. To make mugishochu, the starter culture is added to a barley mash.
column4: I'm making my own special brew with Kouji Mold, barley, and some Chrysanthemum buds to add a floral aroma. Notice I'm not adding the actual flowers, just the buds. Otherwise things would taste too leafy.

story: A button is metal that requires an opening in order to function.
column3: A shirt in the clothes shop has buttons of solid gold, so you bite them off and try to smuggle them out hidden in your mouth. (Note: Main use of 釦 is for clothing, although katakana ボタン is more common.)
column4: Once you can get the metal button through the mouth, it's fastened.

story: A big metal keg portends a good party.
column3: The most expensive keg ever made: solid gold with tortoise-shell inlay.
column4: If a keg is made of gold it's a portent that the beer is going to be good.

story: Tilling a field by hand is very tough. A handy piece of metal to help get the job done, is the plow.
column3: 15 strokes, not 14!
column4: I need a big metal plow to help me move the snow.

story: A handsaw is a piece of metal that helps you fix up the place you reside in.
column3: Metal, reside: In that mansion resides a creepy man. In the last year, a few people have gone missing, so at one night we decided to sneak into his toolshed. There we found a metal handsaw and other equipment, all covered with bloodstains...
column4: A metal handsaw resides in every toolbox.

story: I used a metal awl to drill right through this here turkey: it was so much easier than using a knife to cut it open!
column3: To carve a metal turkey, an awl is the best tool for the job.
column4: The turkey was so tough we had to use a metal awl to get started carving it.

story: The hoe is a metal tool used in preparation for the autumn harvest.
column3: A metal object often used in autumn is the hoe.
column4: She's a pricey seasonal hoe: only accepts gold bullion & only works in autumn.

story: In medieval times, soldiers used metal rivets to build their suits of armor.
column3: Metal soldiers (toy ones) make good rivets.
column4: Many rivets could be seen on the metal soldier War Machine.

story: Tin is soft, bends easily, and melts at a low temperature. Hence tin is written as the metal that is easy to work with.
column3: Tin foil is a metal that makes it easy to wrap up food.
column4: Attention: Book says "Metal - Piggy bank" but it's really "Metal - easy". Story: Tin is easy to work with since its a very soft kind of metal.

story: An anchor is metal planted like a seedling.
column3: We were badly adrift & had no choice but to coat the cat with metal & use him as an anchor.
column4: "The golden city of Ankor Wat" was misunderstood as "The golden seedling of anchor 猫 (#259)".

story: A nail is a metal spike.
column3: A nail is a metal, well, nail.

story: A javelin is a piece of metal used for dispatching enemies – or athletics judges if they’re not careful.
column3: What was not reported in RtK1 is that it was with a javelin that finally they were able to 遣 遣 (#1910) the conductor who had dropped his baton as he ran down the road with that lady's purse. It was an amazing throw, from a remarkable distance, worthy of a gold medal if it had been the Olympics instead of a crime scene.
column4: A javelin is a metal object you dispatch.

story: A pointy (see my explanation in 峰 峰 (#1683)) bit of metal is a sword's point.
column3: A metal sword's point is pointed at the lovers having a tryst. Looks like someone got caught!
column4: Metal, walking through the bushes: An army camping in enemy territory: the sentry is walking through the bushes surrounding the camp. Then he sees the flickering of metal in the moonlight. Before he can raise the alarm, he's at sword's point and bid to remain quiet.

story: The hammer is the same as the 槌 (#2477), except it's made out of metal.
column3: The maestro grabs a metal hammer to get back at those chasing him down the road.
column4: The maestro decides the 槌 (#2477) is too weak and grabs a metal hammer to get back at those chasing him.

story: The church carillion was composed of metal bells that informed when it was the correct time to go to church.
column3: Wtf is a carillion? How about "gong" instead. Picture a game show where they bang on the gong every time you get the correct answer. Or, if you want to go with the book explanation, carillion is the "western" bell which is struck from the inside rather than outside. Story: just like everything else in the East (writing, utensils, etc) bells are harder to work than necessary, being hit from the outside and all. The correct way is to put the gong on the inside, makes it so much easier.
column4: The correct spelling is Carillon.

story: The easiest place to spot rust is when it grows on blue metal. All of my cars have been blue, and as soon as the first red rust appears, its off to the scrapheap.
column3: Metal gets the blues when it starts to rust.
column4: The blue oxidation that forms on metals like copper is a form of rust.

story: 1) Metal seems more heavy when it's balled up in a cluster.2) Fans cluster around the stage at the heavy metal concert.
column3: The heavy metal band explode cluster bombs as part of their act.
column4: 鍾愛, 鍾乳石, 鍾乳洞 鍾 (#2794) ショウ, あつむ ... Parts:金, 重重 (#1805) (cf 腫れる 腫 (#1807)) ... Similars: 塊塊 (#2180), 鍾鍾 (#2794) ... Note: Most Common use is Limestone caves, and Stalactites ... Story: The Cluster of cancer cases in the town was caused by Heavy Metals. But the cluster has luster because the heavy metal is gold.

story: On the St. Bernard assembly line, the dogs pass by and the workers clip their fur with metal scissors.
column3: At the grand opening, they had metal scissors so big that it required two people to cut the ribbon and let the first batch of customers in.
column4: 鋏, 鋏む, 鋏 (#2773)はさみ, はさむ, ヤットコ ... Parts: 金, 夾(夹*) (cf. 夾雑物夾) ... Note: はさみ is Scissors 鋏, and Claws: 蟹の螯螯 ... Story:Easiest to see this as the Metal that does the 挟む 挟 (#1267), but written with the old version of Scissors 挾=挟 Compare to 來, the old version of 来来 (#1884) (倖田來未) , Assembly line is replaced by a line and a ten-ten. This also gives you the reading of both.

story: The flasher hung out by the gates. Whenever someone emerged, the flasher opened his cloak, flashed the unsuspecting person, and ran off in a flash!
column3: The gates are closing quickly but you see a blur of a man zooming in at the last moment.... it's the flash!
column4: A person trying to climb over the gates... until the security lights flash on.

story: The gates suddenly slam shut, squashing your heart. Needless to say, this is agony.
column3: Because her child is out several hours past his curfew, the mother waits in agony at the gates, her heart pounding as she imagines the worst.
column4: Picture a man tied to the gates of hell with his chest ripped open so you can see his heart, which is constantly being poked by little demons. Just an example of the kind of agony awaiting you inside.

story: If you can't fit through the gates due to your size, try the side gate.
column3: 太閤　たいこう　This refers to Toyotomi Hideyoshi, an important Japanese historical figure who ruled Japan for awhile. His secret to surviving in the warring states period was to always have a side gate for a quick escape. He built this gate so only he would fit through, and anyone chasing him couldn't follow.
column4: Apart from the big gates of hell, there are many side gates leading out of hell. But they're designed to always be too little for the person trying to escape to fit through. Invented by the devil to drive the humans to despair.

story: Rain trickles downwards.
column3: Is it raining? Hmm...I can see some clouds up there, but I can't feel much down here: must be just a trickle.
column4: Trickle-down raegan-nomics: wealth rains on the rich and trickles down to the poor.

story: Jimi Hendrix works as a weather forcaster in his spare time. Today he predicts a (purple) haze.
column3: What a coincidence that work should give me time off only days that have rain or haze but no sun.
column4: My hobby is landscape photography so I don't like it when the weather is hazy. Note: 暇 (#2027) 暇 - 日 = 叚 so I suppose hobby is a diminutive of spare time. [叚 = 叚].

story: How to obtain quills for free: Wait for a misty day, then under cover of the mist creep up on an unsuspecting bird and quickly cover it with your umbrella. The bird will flap around wildly trying to escape and while doing so will shed a number of feathers. You can use these as quills.
column3: The latest quills are feathers with an umbrella-like point that sprays mist you can write with.
column4: Why quill? Letter is easier. On a misty day I like to sit down under my umbrella and use my writing feathers (quill) to write an old fashioned letter to my pen-pal.

story: Under the auspices of the local observatory, we looked at the Big Dipper on a misty night, huddled under an umbrella.
column3: Under the auspices of NASA, we explored the Big Dipper -- it was misty but NASA placed a giant umbrella over the Big Dipper to keep us dry.
column4: Looking around on the internet, the only word I can find with this kanji is 斡旋(あっせん) which means mediation. STORY: Mediation is what you do when two parties have a mist between them. You put up an umbrella between them, get them to come together, and measure out something for each of them to keep in a measuring cup.

story: A saddle is leather that helps you relax on horseback.
column3: Save a horse, ride your woman inside your house in a leather saddle instead. (Just to pick up competition with mantixen's story ^_^).
column4: The warm leather saddle felt so comfy that I relaxed too much and fell off my horse.

story: There's a leather section in the convenience store now – that's where I got this whip.
column3: A whip is leather that makes others do things at your convenience.
column4: Mr. Belmont's whip sure is a convenient piece of leather. (Oh, come on! None of you guys played Castlevania?)

story: A scabbard is a leather sheath that should to resemble the blade it's going to hold.
column3: Originally, the leather saddle straps were for holding candles, but now they're more commonly used for holding swords, like scabbards.
column4: It's all about the element of surprise. At the duel, I pull a candle out my leather scabbard and hurl it at my enemy to set him on fire. HA HA!

story: The first briefcase was a piece of leather used to wrap documents.
column3: The businessman likes to make out he's important but the only thing his leather briefcase keeps wrapped up his the lunch his wife made.
column4: LEATHER WRAPPED into a box (middle part of WRAP) is a BAG/BRIEFCASE.

story: A leather blade would make for a poor sword, because it's too pliable.
column3: A leather blade is liable to be too pliable to be viable in a fight.
column4: Barbers use a pliable leather strop to sharpen their razor blades.

story: Wtf terminate? This is "ball". Use "leather ball" for keyword, imagine a leather american football packed with bound up rice.
column3: Rice bound up with leather makes a good hacky sack. The game terminates when the ball touches the ground. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kemari.
column4: Soccer/football for blind people: The leather ball is filled (bound up) with rice. The rustling will tell the players where it is.

story: The DNA evidence reveals the truth about the crime but its too late to overturn the sentence now - they already chopped off the innocent prisoners head.
column3: If you come to learn the truth, you can overturn any unjust verdict on its head.
column4: Some of the heads on Easter Island have somehow been overturned. Your job is to find out the truth (and then set the heads true again).

story: A cheap brush tip is just wheat attached to the head of a spoon.
column3: When the tips of the HEADS OF GRAIN begin to appear, it's ABOUT THAT TIME that the RICE PLANTs begin to show their worth. (NB: In the dictionaries I consulted this character is given the meanings "heads of grain" and "cleverness", ahead of "point (of an instrument)". None of the few common words I could find that use this character have anything to do with brush tip. 穎脱する: to begin to gain recognition; 穎悟: smart, shrewd.) (Spanish: DESPUNTE.)
column4: We spoon up cereal that comes from heads of grain.

story: Donald Trump is exceedingly wealthy, but wears a really bad toupee -- he has an exceedingly large collection of pelts to place on his head.
column3: Pelt, head: The guy had an exceedingly quick hairgrowth. That's why it always seemed like he was carrying a pelt around his head.
column4: This kanji can also mean "prejudiced". Skinheads are exceedingly prejudiced.

story: Accolades are bestowed on your head in public.
column3: You gotta wear your public head when you receive accolades -- inside you're proud as can be but you gotta keep the cool with your public head.
column4: As a (kind of) accolade, your head is displayed in public after your death.

story: Homeless in Shinjuku, February: I keep my neck & throat warm by wrapping toilet paper around it, but my head is still cold.
column3: Women in certain African tribes put their heads through a spool into increase the length of their neck and throat.
column4: 頚頚 (#2813)ケイ, くび ... Parts: 圣(巠), 頁 (cf 頸部 鮼) ... Heisig got this wrong, it is not the simplified version Doctors use; it is the traditional version: 頸, with the old version of Spool: 巠. All of the 漢字that use Spool can be written with either version : cf: 頚-頸, 軽車-輕車, etc. But just like the other non 常用漢字 this tends to stick with the old version.

story: Remember that dazzling evening where you found the magic wand and used it on your crotch to make it bigger? Well this time you use the wand to disguise your little guy as food so that she thinks it's a repast. 燦 (#2543).
column3: What dazzling food! This shall be the most splendid repast yet!
column4: Formal dining at Hogwarts: Dumbledore flicks his WAND in the EVENING, the CROTCHES get warm and wonderful FOOD fills the tables. (See also Boy.pockets story for 燦 (#2543)).

story: After journeying the world wide, I returned to my hometown and was met with an incredible feast.
column3: Hometown food.
column4: If you've watched Asterix before, then this one shouldn't be an issue for you. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asterix.

story: To enjoy watching the eclipse, you go on a picnic with your friends. But due to the dim light, you accidentally pick up and eat an insect.
column3: You eat an insect by accident while watching the jaw-dropping eclipse.
column4: Eclipse is an IDE that allows you to eat away at the bugs efficiently.

story: Of all the foods, sweets are definitely the ones kids put on a pedestal.
column3: The only food at the pedestal is sweets to keep the lecturer's energy up.
column4: SWEETS are FOOD that are offered to the gods on an especially high PEDESTAL. Is that because they're more preferred or is it to keep them out of children's reach? Hmm...

story: This man is too heavy! We can't move the stretcher! Quick, add a team of horses to the ambulance!
column3: The final addition to the Trojan Horse was a stretcher (laid across the top). Hey, if the plan doesn't work, better be safe than sorry!
column4: Add, Trojan horse: The Trojan military are making a budget estimation for the next year. 'So that was the Trojan horse. We got everything covered now?' Assisant: 'No. We still need to add the stretcher for carrying away our wounded.' Reply: 'Aah. We don't need a stretcher. You win or you die, no wounded!'

story: Being just black and white, the piebald is a simple horse.
column3: Yep, old Piebald was the simplest horse in the book, just sitting there, eating bald pies.
column4: Although traditional Trojan horses usually had very simple designs, newer models come in piebald.

story: Use a scorpion to make a horse rush.
column3: The soldiers in the Trojan Horse were supposed to wait several hours before coming out, but when they spotted a scorpion in the horse with them, they all rushed out at once.
column4: A very hungry scorpion climbed up the hind leg of a horse, and took a big bite out of the horse's rump. The horse squealed in fright and took off in a rush, leaving the scorpion sitting there in a cloud of dust. The scorpion called out to the horse in the distance: "Thank you for the meal! (御馳走様でした！ ごちそうさまでした！）".

story: This character is だます, which means to trick or fool someone. The Greeks tricked (cheated) the Trojans by hiding in the Trojan Horse, which actually had a secret door from which the hidden soldiers would emerge. It was a brilliant tactic that would be recorded in the tomes of history.
column3: I got caught by my ex- with a pack of Trojans and a Hentai mag... of course she broke up with me, how the hell could I have convinced her I was not a cheat?!?
column4: An educational comic book that shows how the Greeks cheated by using a Trojan Horse.

story: The guy who said that you can take a horse to a river, but you can't make it drink obviously has never encountered a tame horse.
column3: The process to getting a tame horse is a bit like getting a tame Christian - baptizization! you take it into the river at a young age (just after it's born is best) and dunk it in until it is almost drowned. Then at the last possible moment, when its life is flashing before its eyes (good baptizers know when this is), you pull it back above water. The first thing it sees is its "rescuer" and "savior", and it will be tame and follow you for the rest of its life.
column4: A horse that's tame will not hesitate to cross a stream if asked.

story: Wolverine's had charges placed on him for murdering a horse, but he make's a rebuttal stating that he couldn't have been in two different places at the same time (i.e. There cannot exist two Wolverines). He was having dinner with his Aunt Margaret at the time, it's impossible.
column3: Wolverine gave a rebuttal that the slash marks on the horse didn't even look like his.
column4: Trojan horse, 2 sheafs: Proponents of taking the Trojan Horse into the city employed convincing arguments in their rebuttal. They put 2 sheafs next to the Trojan Horse and put them on fire. 'You see, if it were a trap, and enemies were inside, they would surely come out right now.' However, during the rebuttal, nobody noticed the caughing coming from inside the Trojan Horse....

story: The team of horses slowed to a gallop as they started up the hill.
column3: Trojan Horse, hill: The anchoring of the Trojan Horse had broken, and now it was accelerating down the hill. To save the men inside, riders were galloping down the hill to get them out in time.
column4: To leap over a hill, first accellerate your horse to a fast gallop. It helps to feed the horses COOkies (KU) to energize them.

story: The team of horses is nervously asking a tiger not to eat them. "Don't worry", says the tiger, "over in that paddyfield I can see my favourite dish – donkey!"
column3: The team of horses ran when they saw the tiger. But the stubborn donkey continued drinking from his dish in the open field. Talk about easy prey.
column4: Donkeys are small horses that can therefore fit into huts 盧.

story: A fish meditates on a mandala to gain the electric power of an eel.
column3: The only fish that Nelson Manadala got to eat in prison was うなぎ eel...sounds like punishment to me!
column4: Manga fish: picture a manga version of an eel and you're done.

story: The sea bream （たい） is a fish that often goes around the circumference of a 回転寿司（かいてんずし） a number of たいmes.
column3: Sea Bream (fish) found on the circumference of Australia and New Zealand waters.
column4: The "TAI" fish (sea bream) was such a prized fish that the fisherman traveled around the whole circumference of Thai/TAI-land just to catch one.

story: This is a weak fish -- you just open a can of sardines and there they are, weak and defenseless, ready to be eaten.
column3: Due to its small size, the sardine is a weak fish.
column4: Sardine fish are such weak little panzies that fisherman don't even have to hook them. They just say "Hey! Get your A$$ in this can!" Then the weak little guys just climb in and go to market.

story: Trout are a fish often revered for their beauty (especially rainbow trout).
column3: Fish, revered: The fish tribe revered a fat trout, living in an aquarium in the temple. One morning, they woke up, smelling a funny smell. It appeared as if a jungle explorer had found the trout's temple....
column4: This is the fish most belovéd by the revered Kilgore Trout & also by his less-revered son, Leon Trotsky Trout.

story: Salmon are fish that go over ivy trying to get back to their breeding grounds, killing bears along the way.
column3: SALMON swim upstream like they're climbing IVY.
column4: さけ, salmon are fish that go to higher ground (ground on ground) to spawn.

story: Tuna is the fish that posesses the most toxins (heavy metals, pesticides, mercury).
column3: Maguro tuna is a must-have (possess) fish.
column4: 「まぐろ」という魚。Tuna is the most-loved FISH in Japan. They talk about it constantly, eat it at every meal, spend millions of yen on its choicest cuts. It turns them into a nation of tuna-zombies! It's like they're all POSSESSED or something.

story: A fish arrives at the fortune-teller's who, without looking, says "Welcome, Sweet Smelt". "That's amazing", says the fish, "how did you know I was a sweet smelt?" "Well, most fish smell bad, but you smelt sweet."
column3: The fortune teller turned to me smiling, "Ah you (アユ) will do well. I can sense the sweet smell of success. And what better way to celebrate than with that sweetest of fish the sweet smelt!"
column4: These are the small fish that are commonly served on wooden skewers at matsuri. http://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E3%82%A2%E3%83%A6 Go to the matsuri, eat some barbequed ayu, then visit the fortune teller with greasy hands to get your palm read.

story: The horse mackerel is a fish that must visit both its horse and mackerel relatives.
column3: Fish, visit: Mother to daughter: "I bought you a hors...". The girls started a joyous screaming. "Let's visit it", the girl says. Daughter follows mother to.. the kitchen, showing her the fish she bought. Mother: "I wanted to tell you that I bought a horse mackerel for dinner!"
column4: The horse mackerel is the fish that is nonplussed – it isn't sure whether it's a horse or a mackerel.

story: Cod is a fish that is packed in snow to reach the inland parts of Japan.
column3: たら, cod is a beautiful fish whose flesh is the colour and texture of snow.
column4: Believe it or not, the COD is the only fish capable of swimming through snow! True story!... ok, slightly fabricated for RTK purposes :).

story: Holy mackarel! That fish just turned blue!
column3: Fish, blue: After the young girl found that disappointing mackerel fish (see story 鯵 (#2833)), she felt a bit blue.
column4: Http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue_mackerel.

story: Ever noticed how tiny fish will often mingle around a shark for protection?
column3: Most FISH don't MINGLE with SHARKS.
column4: A shark tries to mingle with other fish to get close enough to eat them.

story: The bonito is a fish with strict preparation procedures for making 出汁（だし） and 鰹節（かつおぶし）.
