column3: At the お好み焼き（おこのみやき）place I go to, they are so strict about putting かつお, bonito flakes on to your okonomiyaki that if you ever tried to ask for it without, they would tell you never to come back!
column4: Bono (lead vocals for U2) loves FISH, be he STRICTly avoids eating bonito, because he has interpreted the species' name as, 'little Bono.'

story: Fish, autumn: Old man to his son: "You are bullheaded if you think you can catch a bullhead fish in the middle of autumn. It's out of season!"
column3: Perhaps a bit of a misnomer. Bullhead is a river fish (カジカ). This kanji is most likely to refer to young Japanese yellowtail or amberjack. It is a fish of many names depending on age: fry (もじゃこ), young (鰍・いなだ or 魬・はまち), mature (鰤・ぶり). I suppose these kanji might crop up on a fish menu. STORY: Young Amberjack is not at its best in summer. Eat from autumn onwards (when it becomes more fatty). Also its tail is amber - the colour of autumn leaves.
column4: Both my dictionaries agree with Heisig and call this bullhead, not amberjack. From Abaddon: Fish, autumn: Old man to his son: "You are bullheaded if you think you can catch a bullhead fish in the middle of autumn. It's out of season!".

story: "Dude! What happened to your chin?" "Well, I was out fishing..."
column3: Saltwater crocs swim in the sea like fish. Right side = crocodile primative. Pictograph - 2 big eyes and one massive snare for a mouth.
column4: An alligator preys on fish and is often mistaken for a crocodile 咢.

story: The crucian fish adheres strongly to Crucianism principles.
column3: Crucian carp (ふな) is a freshwater fish most well known for its use in 鮒鮓 (ふなずし) which is an ancient forerunner to modern sushi.The fish is salted and allowed to ferment over a period of months. STORY: The crucian chefs prepare the fish for funazushi by adhering to the ancient ways. Note: This old way of preserving fish, known generally as なれずし (馴れ鮓 or 熟れ鮓), uses a rare kanji for すし - 鮓 鮓.
column4: Fish, adhere: It's crucial that you don't catch any crucian carp anymore. If we don't adhere to this rule, the fish will probably be extinct next year.

story: Japanese consider fish to be most delicious when eaten as sushi. (Note: In practice, sushi is more often written 寿司, but occasionally 鮨).
column3: They have a perfectly good kanji, yet they use the ateji 寿司 most of the time.
column4: SUSHI = Fish that is delicious. This kanji is amazingly perfect. I'm in love with it ☺.

story: Fish, old man, sun: An ominous fish fin approaches the old man, who went for a swim as the sun was going down. Soon, he'll sleep with the fishes.
column3: The old man thinks fish fin sushi is delicious.
column4: 1. Senile (耆) story: A senile old man doesn't know what day it is. 2. Fish fin story: You can estimate a fish's age when you scrutinize its fish fin. Senile fish have tattered fish fins. (thanks to Peppi).

story: A bird that goes to the inland wards for food is the seagull.
column3: There's a new Xbox game called Extreme Bird Chase, where you chase flocks of seagulls on the beach. Soon we truly will never need to leave the house.
column4: Wolverine had enough of this ward and hence went to the seaside with his cardboard box. Now he always kills a bird, a seagull, when he wakes up and eats it for breakfast, while listening to the sound of the sea.

story: Companion, bird: Roc, the mythical bird, was searching for a companion for as long as he existed. Little did he know that he was the only one of his kind.
column3: The roc is a large and intimidating bird. Because of this, the roc has a hard time finding a companion.
column4: The roc is a huge mythical bird that just wants a companion.

story: The parakeet is a bird that acts like a suckling infant when it drinks from the water dropper.
column3: A parakeet is a bird that like a suckling infant likes a parateets.
column4: Ariel, that little mermaid with the shells over her "ha-ha" 's is good friends with a parakeet voiced by Gilbert Godfried... or wait, is that some other Disney film?

story: A parrot is a bird of the warrior, for example pirates.
column3: A parrot makes a terrible bird for any warrior. As soon as the warrior tries to sneak up on its enemy, Polly wants a freaking cracker.
column4: 鸚鵡返し鵡 (#2846) (オウ)ム(武） ... Parts: 武, 鳥... ... Mantixen remix: The parrot is a bird of the warrior, for example pirates. Even better is the behavior of the parrot, just repeating without thinking what is is told. The best Warriors behave this same way: "Sir, yes, sir." ... 熟語:鸚鵡貝, 鸚鵡, ... cf:.

story: [+brose] The cormorant was historically used in Japan and China to catch fish. The fisher would use some rope or something to tie its throat so that it could only swallow small fish. If it caught something too big to swallow, it would take it back to the fisher's boat and the fisher would take it out. This particular cormorant is going after bigger and bigger prey - but one day it goes too far, and tries to swallow your little brother! Imagine trying to yank your brother out of its throat.
column3: The cormorant is a bird you use like your younger brother to fetch things for you.
column4: The YOUNGER BROTHER (弟 (#1240)) was too lazy to fish himself so he trained a cormorant BIRD (鳥 (#1941)) to do it for him.

story: The heron bird took the path to heroin, regrettably.
column3: As I was walking I noticed hair-on the path! When I bent to see what was up, I realized that they were in fact fine feathers poking through - someone had paved over a large bird!
column4: You have to watch out for the HERON! When walking on a lakeshore PATH this BIRD will dive bomb you from behind. (View 鷺 as if your looking at it from above and the story works).

story: Concerning, bird: The US senate had a meeting concerning the eagle. Although symbol of the US, this bird is close to extinction.
column3: There is much concern over the eagle for it is close to extinction.
column4: Timing fail: at precisely the moment the meeting began at the nation's capital concerning the fate of the national bird, the eagle, the only eagle in the national zoo broke free from its cage & made off with the only chihuahua with a human leg on display anywhere in the world.

story: Due to its waterproof armor, the wild duck is a bird that resurfaces even if you push it underwater.
column3: かも, or wild duck, is a Japanese term that means an easy mark or a sucker because wild ducks are considered to be easy to catch. This kanji shows a duck that is wearing some armor to avoid being an easy mark.
column4: As a defense against wildfowlers, wild ducks began sporting ballistic armour. The next innovation was カモflage. Time to reappraise the term "bird brained"!

story: The kite falcon is a majestic bird that flies in the sky as fast as an arrow. So much so that its feathers are often used to make arrows.
column3: Arrow, bird: The black kite is a bird of prey (like the raptor). You can see it approaching its target, like an arrow speeding through the air.
column4: A man from the medievil times goes hunting for falcons, he aims his arrow, shoots and runs to look at the bird he got. Sadly it was just a kite and he'd made some poor boy very upset.

story: The owl, being wise, is hiding its tail feathers in a tree so that its prey can't tell what kind of bird it is.
column3: The owl is a very snooty bird, one could say that it has a tree stuck up it's ass. キョウ.
column4: The owl is a bird that often perches atop a tree.

story: A deer stomps on the soil and dust rises from the ground. (big ups mantixen).
column3: This is actually the kanji for garbage, which for some reason is often written in katakana (ゴミ). If you find the whole body of a dead deer outside your apartment, with muddy soil clinging to its fur and its eyeballs covered in dust, make sure you put it in the municipally-supplied printed bag marked 燃やせるゴミ (incinerable waste).
column4: On the ground, we found the whole body of a deer covered in dust.

story: A giraffe is like a deer except that when it plays chess it has a better overview of the board.
column3: A deer with a rook-shaped neck probably is a giraffe.
column4: A deer standing on a bushel basket still isn't tall enough to be mistaken for a giraffe.

story: (from astridtops) "Real men don't use mortars", said my father-in-law, as he began to grind some stones down using only his fists.
column3: My father-in-law is more fun than my blood father. My father-in-law is a hillbilly with an arsenal of army gear. He gave me the mortar launcher and said: "Be a man! Blow up a chunk of Planet Earth!" And so I did...
column4: "Real men don't use mortars", my father-in-law says. "It's a girly thing to use".

story: You are chasing the famous three blind mice and try to catch them by slamming a mortar on top of them. Success! You can see their three tails sticking out from under the mortar. In fact the impact has broken the first two tails, as you can see from the sharp angle they bend at, and the two drops (blood) on each. The third tail still curves nicely though, and hence has no drops of blood on it.
column3: Mighty Mouse is so tough you can hit him with a mortar, double plows coated with 4 drops of rat poison, and you'll still never hook him.
column4: 鼠色, 栗鼠, 海鼠, 鼠 (#2065)(ソ), ねずみ ... Parts:臼, Pictograph. (cf:鎌鼬鼬, 鼡鼡) ... Note: Also comes in a simplified form: 鼡 (which appeared as a primitive in 猟る猟 (#1940)) ... Story: Mouse smashed with an 臼臼 (#2063). Two legs splayed out front, 4 drops of blood (4 for death) , plus tail sticking out.

story: This is pretty much only used in the word 鑿(のみ), chisel. Missile + metal is obviously a hammer being swung. The needle is the chisel and the mortar represents the impressions left (bored) by the chisel. For some reason the chisel is used to make a row of such impressions here, and the work is done in such a difficult place that it has to be done upside down. Perhaps this is some sort of sabotage, done in a place that is not readily visible to the outside.
column3: Hanging upside down in a row are ten mortars. You must shoot chisel tipped missiles into all of them and successfully bore holes through them in order to get the prize of gold. Talk about a messed up county fair game!
column4: At Staples someone used a needle to bore a hole through the bathroom wall, turning it into an adult movie theater where a Goldeneye can get his missile launched.

story: In military terms, a small craft is a boat that only has enough room for a mortar that fires walking sticks - which is pretty useless unless you hit the enemy in the crotch.
column3: In a small craft, the boat is so small that you hit yourself in the crotch when trying to use a mortar and walking stick (as a pestle).
column4: The small craft was a tiny boat made from a mortar and had a walking stick for a mast. It was so tiny that I couldn't even fit my crotch inside it.

story: When you wake up in Hades, you close the eyes and try to pretend it isn't happening.
column3: When you close the eyes of someone who just died...
column4: It's as dark as Hades when you close your eyes.

story: Hades is normally very dark, and even when the sun shines in it is still murky.
column3: The Sunshine looks Murky in Hades.
column4: (Not: Looks like this is only used as an alternative to 瞑 (#2859) in つぶ.る) Even if the SUN shines into the UNDERWORLD, it still is murky.

story: The cave was too dark for my tastes, so I went out to sit in mediation.
column3: 2 people sitting in mediation on the dirt.
column4: Two people (the master and his student) sit in meditation on the dirt. The keyword is mediTATION, not mediATION, as in 坐蒲 (ざふ) ; round cushion used for Zen meditation / 坐禅 (ざぜん) ; seated Zen meditation.

story: On the first day of the month a mountain goat lets out a "Baah" as it jumps over the moon.
column3: Ｗerewolves turn into wolves at the full moon, Weregoats turn into goats on the first day of the month.( primitave= Weregoat).
column4: The female mountain goat can only give milk on one day of the month: on the first day of the month. Her milk cycles are controlled by the moon.

story: The day seems to drag when it keeps you from having a fiesta.
column3: 曳光弾, 曳く,曳き船=引き船=曵船, 曳航曳 (#2863) エイ, ひく ... Parts: 日, 戈- 丶 (cf 洩らす洩 (#2864)) ... Note: this Kanji is confusing until you look at its older form 曵. It's not ’Under the arm’ but rather 戈Fiesta with one stroke doubled up with 日. Often replaced by 引く in modern times. Old version 曵 is used in the Hikifune (曵船) place name in Tokyo. ... Story:The Fiesta can certainly Drag if it goes all day Without a Drop to drink.
column4: Bored with the sun always going the same way (“it’s such a drag”), I tuck the sun under my arm and try to drag it in the opposite direction to usual. EDIT: Notes (1): tucked under the arm is reversed here, i.e. a mirror image of the usual primitive. Note (2): Tow might be a better keyword: see my note at 洩 (#2864).

story: (re: Katsuo) If you tow water in a wheelbarrow, some of it is sure to dribble out.
column3: Tip: Heisig has duplicated a primitive name here by calling the right side drag. We already have a two-stroke primitive called drag (see numbers 1853-1861 盾,派,脈,逓,后). I suggest calling 曳 "tow" instead.
column4: If you drag your water bottle along behind you, water will begin to dribble out.

story: A comet flew by and knocked down two bushes, so I went out there and swept up the mess, cursing astrological bodies along the way.
column3: Broom is ヨ. The lower primitive here resembles a rake 肀 without a handle (vertical stroke). STORY: Comets actually have 2 bushy tails (http://apod.nasa.gov/apod/image/9703/halebopp4_aac.jpg). Imagine a NASA probe with an attachment like a rake head designed to catch (rake up) the fine particles streaming from the tails for later analysis.
column4: Having 2 Bushes for president hurt like a comet hitting the planet and it'll take more than a broom to clean it up.

story: Comet, heart: Heisig: "The astute reader will notice that the second stroke in the broom element of comet doesn't pass through. The astute reader will take this observation to heart".
column3: The astute astral observer Edmond Halley put his heart into his work. And in return, we named a comet for him.
column4: The astute observer noticed that the 彗 (#2850) didn't have a tail, and his 心 (#595) started pounding at the thought of having discovered a new kind of comet.

story: Story by katsuo (but not yet posted) - At a small concert for the Beatles I was hanging eight towels from the celing. I asked Paul if he wanted me to stitch them together but he said "Let It Be".
column3: No matter what tool you use, this towel is beyond repair, even with stitching. Better let it be.
column4: There's a new cabaret show in town called "It's Raining X-Men" where eight Chippendales dress up in superhero costumes for the ladies. I would say something negative, but I just shake my head and let it be.

story: Add a drum when you really want to applaud.
column3: The drummer wasn't very good so he had a speaker built into the bottom of the drum which automatically added applause.
column4: The boisterous crowd began to applaud as the formerly "synth-only" group tossed out the broken electronics, and added a real drum to their stage show.

story: The evil villain's favorite hobby is breaking human legs.
column3: Think of Mike Myers' Dr. Evil standing in an identity parade of intergalactic criminals. Evil is the only villain with human legs.
column4: You should keep in mind that evil is not some abstract philosophical category-- it lurks incarnate, walking on human legs amongst us. Who are these evil beings, you ask? Villains, of course.

story: The overly-cautious white geek protects his entire upper body with a special helmet he constructed out of two cardboard boxes, unfortunately his human legs could still be easy targets for bullies.
column3: The perfect image for this kanji: http://bit.ly/stormtrooperhelmet How to make a lousy stormtrooper costume: take two cardboard boxes - one will be for your helmet and the other will cover your trunk. Paint them white. Find something to cover your human legs. Ta-da!
column4: I pull out from between my girlfriend's legs and shoot white stuff all over the helmet she's put on for the occasion.

story: The muchacho about to give a speech to his audience, only to be interrupted by a sudden rain, accompanied by very thick mist.
column3: Mist and RAIN 雨 (#451)? That's pretty bad weather for an OLD AUDIENCE 謁 (#489). Primitive: Old audience is using OLD SIESTA 曷 instead of regular one.
column4: An audience with a spirit is always accompanied by a veil of mist as drops of rain silently hang in the air. Don't confuse with fog 霧 (#1314) and haze 霞 (#2800).

story: kalpa is a Sanskrit word for a long period of time, sort of like "aeon." Once a kalpa has gone (passed), there will be no more fossil fuels for power.
column3: When a kalpa passes, all forms of power we see today will be gone.
column4: काल्पनिक (End of the age of the world).

story: (I use "kanji" for the scarecrow primitive.) I bemoan the huge number of kanji I must memorize, but I plod on despite my tired yawns.
column3: A scarecrow bemoans that it lacks legs.
column4: Audrey II yawns, bemoaning being stuck in the flower shop with nothing to eat.

story: I hop into my palanquin, my car of sorts, such that I may be transported to my next location of entertainment.
column3: A palanquin is a car used for the entertainment of royalty when they want to take a joyride.
column4: Before there were cars, the lesser nobility (who lived in small towns with only one long main street) used to be carried up and down the street in their palanquins for entertainment. Little has changed today, but this activity is available to all youths with cars and little better to do.

story: In the debate, your political opponent's has such a warped sense of perspective, that he believes the negative is actually correct.
column3: Warped is a combination of not and correct. If a piece of wood is described as warped, that means it is not the correct shape, according to a particular standard we have in mind. The correct Kanji points us to the standard; while the not or un- Kanji denotes that the standard is not met. Hence, whatever we are talking about is not standard - i.e. it is not correct or not regular. In other words, it is warped.
column4: A warped person will often believe that negative actions are the most correct for any given situation.

story: You're so jaded by the time you graduate that when you finally spread your wings, your feathers are all jade green.
column3: This what the valedictorian wears in Chinese high school graduations. It's a beautiful cap with jade green feathers covering it. No tassel, just those pretty feathers.
column4: As a commemoration of graduation we got these jade green colored medals in the shape of wings.

story: A good substitute for black is blue-black, like the color women try to substitute for their black eyebrows with a pencil.
column3: Substitute + black= blue-black or blackened-eyebrows. A close substitute for the color black is the color blue-black. Also, women in Japan sometimes have blackened-eyebrows, since their color is naturally a faint blue-black.
column4: Sigh... another Heisig fail. Blue-black is definitely 黝 (あおぐろい). Change the keyword to mascara or something.

story: Here we have two people sitting on chairs, trying to set up their camera on a tripod and periodically checking the viewfinder with their eyes.
column3: (NB: I use THREE-LEGGED KETTLE for 鼎, and reserve TRIPOD for 鬲 鬲.) This THREE-LEGGED KETTLE is used for sacrificial incense-burning. 鼎 shows a watchful EYE carefully putting the offering material in the opening of the KETTLE, which is shown as being squarely supported ON EACH SIDE.
column4: Your eye looks through the viewfinder as a three-legged tripod supports your camera.

story: The fortune-teller tells Wolverine that in a past life, she sees him covered in rocksalt from working in a salt mine.
column3: You see a block of rocksalt containing a pent-in ladybird (US = ladybug). Touch it with your magic wand and the ladybird is set free. (Note: Let ladybird = sheaf + four drops. It's pictographic: the sheaf showing the curved back and the four drops the spots on the ladybird).
column4: The fortune teller told wolverine that to cure his bad luck he should constantly sprinkle rocksalt all over his body, so now you can see him with little bits of salt all over himself.

story: Lye is white like rocksalt and can be broken up with an ice pick.
column3: (Agreed with Hissatsu, Soap it is!) STORY: This new "natural" hippy soap is ridiculous! It's hard as a rock, smells like salt, and I have to chips pieces of it off with an awl (or ice pick) just to use it!
column4: Soap is a far better keyword than lye (鹸 is only used in words referring to soap). "In the final step in making soap, I add rocksalt and stir with an awl." (Sort of true, in some soap production, salt is added to precipitate soap from the solution).

story: "That tiger at the zoo was so reserved. He didn't say so much as one sentence." "Um, you know tigers can't talk, right?"
column3: A tiger takes your reserved seat at the movie theatre which has "RESERVED" clearly printed on it, but you forgive him as tigers can't read sentences.
column4: (Note: mostly used in 敬虔 (けいけん), meaning “pious, devout, modest”. Keyword: pious) The TIGER was very pious, and would as always say a godly sentence before eating a godfearing SCOTSMAN. (Kanji with "tiger radical"(虍): 虎 (#2145), 虐 (#2153), 虔 (#2881), 虚 (#2148), 彪, 處, 琥, 虞 (#2150), 虜 (#2146), 號, 嘘 (#2286), 瘧, 劇 (#2152), 膚 (#2147), 戯 (#2149) (/戲), 慮 (#2151), 墟, 據, 盧, 歔, 謔, 虧, 遽, 罅, 濾 (#2418) (/瀘), 蘆, 鯱, 廬, 臚, 醵, 櫨, 饕, 艫, 轤, 鑢, 顱, 驢 (#2825), 鱸 (not used? 遞, 褫, 獻, 爐 (/鑪))).

story: Twenty birds (swallows) are perched at the north exit (北口) of the station. I light a fire underneath them, and as they wilt and fall in the heat, passing commuters swallow them whole. Well, they are swallows.
column3: Twenty swallows are perched atop the station's 北口 raining droppings all over everyone. Keep your mouth closed so you don't swallow any. (Thanks Katsuo).
column4: Hint: Now is a good chance to learn the verb "to swallow" as well, which is simply a mouth to the left of the bird: 嚥.

story: There are things in the outhouse that may appear delicious, and you may even want to lick them, but I assure you: they ain't delicious.
column3: Those big white "mints" in the outhouse urinals may look delicious, but it's best not to lick them.
column4: One word : gloryhole.

story: A pedestal in an Indiana Jones movie is littered with the bones of people who almost seized the treasure.
column3: I see a some bones near the pedestal of immortality: someone almost got there!
column4: This is the pedestal of the Master Sword (see the Legend of Zelda series). The area around it is littered with the bones of people who almost, almost, almost were able to pull out the sword and defeat Ganon.

story: Mahjong tiles, to the best of my understanding have only one side and are considered a lowly use of time.
column3: Mahjong tiles are printed on one side and are laid lowly on the playing board.
column4: MAHJONG TILES have only ONE SIDE, and the objective is to clear them all away, finishing with the LOWLY-lying ones.

story: Sneak preview - peek - director lets you see his new movie - 店を覗く（のぞく） - have a quick noze/look in a shop (nozoku).
column3: If a director lets anyone see his film before it's finished, it's only a sneak peek.
column4: 覗く(覘く)覗 (#2886) シ(司), のぞく ... Parts:司, 見 ... Similars: 覗く覗 (#2886), 瞥見 瞥 (#2935) ... Story: Director - See- Sneak Peak. This is the kanji for upskirt cams and peep movies. So a Peeking Tom Director makes his movies about Seeing through a hole in the bathroom stall.

story: [This kanji is included in RTK 3 third edition with the keyword 'disagree'] "Stop!" yelled the factory manager. The assembly line on the floor above was disagreeing with the assembly line below on whether to output shovels or shelves. The manager had them split the task.
column3: discrepancy: During the heated discrepancy, the man pushes his partner into a shelf, knocking out her tooth.
column4: I love his old teeth collection. Too bad there seems to be a discrepancy between the number of teeth on each shelf of the cupboard.().

story: [This kanji is included in RTK 3 third edition with the keyword 'discord'] [continuing the story from disagree (#40799)] The factory manager thought he'd resolved the disagreement between the two assembly lines, but there was still some discord among those on the floor below making the shovels. "Stop! If you don't cut it out, I will come down there and knock your teeth crooked!" the manager angrily yelled.
column3: crooked teeth: (during a crooked teeth anonymous meeting in England). Meeting leader/counselor: "Now repeat after me, everyone : "I have crooked teeth and I am proud of it!"().
column4: Because of some discord between a friend an I, I wound up with five holes in my mouth. Luckily, I had them filled with false teeth.

story: (thx Katsuo) The so-called 'mighty' Qin dynasty died a nasty death from starvation because they focused on growing bonsai instead of wheat.
column3: Please note: this is a mistake in Heisig. This kanji does not refer to the Manchu dynasty, also known as the Qing dynasty, 1644-1911CE, the last ruling dynasty of China. Instead, it is used for the similarly-named Qin dynasty, which was the first dynasty of imperial China. Story: The Qin Dynasty of 221-206BCE laid the foundations for the golden age of Chinese development. Two agricultural innovations they implemented were the art of topiary (exemplified by the bonsai) and crop cultivation (wheat).
column4: What did man chew in the Manchu dynasty? Well, first man chew bonsai, but he find that rather tough, so next man chew wheat. EDIT: I think the keyword should really be Qin dynasty. So how a about new story based on Bob Dylan's song "Mighty Quinn": "Bonsai without, wheat plants within, you'll not grow nothing like the mighty Qin. (dynasty)."

story: There are relatively few turkeys compared to the widely familiar sparrow.
column3: There are few turkeys available this Christmas/Thanksgiving, so we're having to make do with sparrow.
column4: So few turkeys remain after the carnage of RtK3 that we have had to prepare sparrow for dinner, M'Lord.

story: The peregrine falcon is the fastest animal in the world. It can reach speeds of over 322 km/h in a dive - over ten times as fast as a turkey!
column3: My peregrine falcon recently has been having confidence issues - recently it dives out of the sky and misses the target completely. To boost its confidence, I got a nice, fat turkey, killed it, and then set it up on a big needle so it looked like it was still alive - just loafing about. Then I went to my peregrine falcon - "hey buddy, look! A nice fat turkey. I bet you can get it!" It goes for it, but it spears itself on the needle!!
column4: The peregrine falcon is like a turkey on ten types of steroids. At 322 kph, it's the fastest animal in the world!

story: Rays of light hit the futon, making it shimmer. Think maybe somebody wet the futon last night..
column3: Shimmering rays of light awaken me as I lay on my turkey feather futon.
column4: Once it had been in a state of 燿 (#2534) for awhile, the turkey's feathers began to a-shimmering with some strange light.

story: When passing through Ebisu in Tokyo, (one stop south of Shibuya) you see an ebisu (= a barbarian/savage) whose pet St. Bernard has swallowed his bow; you can see the shape of the bow sticking through its skin. Notes: 1. I'm locating this in Ebisu to reinforce the sound; the place name Ebisu is actually written with different kanji. 2. As Meconium mentions, stroke order is 一、弓、人.
column3: I don't like the way Heisig doesn't list stroke order in RTK3, like it's not important or something. This is written one, bow, person, not large then person. It's annoying to have to check each time. Note the second leg of person comes from the bottom of bow, not from one.
column4: 征夷大将軍 (せいいたいしょうぐん) This is the 'i' part of the full name of the ancient shoguns. Sei i tai shougun (Great general who subdues the eastern barbarians). This Kanji is the "eastern barbarian" part. Being the shogun, the most powerful military leader in all of Japan, it is only fitting that he also have a very large bow to go along with his office. So large in fact, that it was given to him by the god of good luck, Ebisu.

story: Grass skirt, middle, crown: The girl wearing the grass skirt had a cyst growing in the middle of her head, seeming like a crown. A sign she will be the new village elder, I heard later.
column3: The hula girl got a cyst on her lips after she placed her mouth on my "crown" ten times.
column4: 嚢中の錐, 土嚢, 気嚢, 胆嚢, 氷嚢, 涙嚢, 陰嚢, 嚢=袋 嚢 (#2883) ノウ, ふくろ ... Parts:十+口+冖, 㐮-亠 ... SImilars: 腫れる腫 (#2467), 嚢中嚢 (#2883) ... Note: for Cyst usage likely to be 膿腫 as 嚢腫. Bag a better keyword, but Heisig misnamed 俵 as 俵 (#1547), so ... Story: The Angry Scotman 㐮 has exchanged his Top Hat for a Bishop's Hat. He is so proud of it that I hesitate to point out the bulging Cyst forming on it.

story: The monkey is carefree with his piggy bank, tossing it at whatever financial opportunity he stumbles upon.
column3: I am the most carefree person in the world! I'm even going to entrust my piggybank with my life savings in it to this monkey!
column4: As a carefree person, I'm always using my piggy bank to monkey around.

story: A dishonest taxi driver is circling to increase the fare -- trying to stretch out the ride, going around the block many times.
column3: A taxi driver stretches out the time it takes to get to Times Square by circling around it (thanks mcfate).
column4: "We seem to be circling! We've already seen this landmark fifteen times!" "Oi, that's quite a stretch! It's more like twelve or thirteen times."

story: I feel elation when I realize the axe murderer is lacking his axe.
column3: I was bored, yawning and such, so I picked up my axe and was suddenly filled with much elation.
column4: You're stuck in another boring meeting, falling asleep as they go blah, blah, blah. Suddenly the presenter gets this expression of elation on his face, picks up a nearby axe, and starts hacking up the table. Nobody's yawning any more...

story: A stalwart sow stands up against a missile.
column3: Stand up, sow, missile: See our stalwart hunter standing upon the sow he just shot, his missile launcher still smoking. (Nothing much left of the sow by the way).
column4: During the Bay of Pigs invasion, the Cuban stalwarts stood up to the CIA-trained mercenaries in spite of the bullets and missiles flying through the air.

story: Tip: Learn "this" 斯 and "that" 其 at the same time. ("that", 其 , is not in Heisig, but is probably more common than 斯). Stories: This bushel basket comes with an axe to open it, but that one doesn't.
column3: (Thx Kats) THIS AXE can beat any CHESS peice... except for maybe THAT ROOK.
column4: Tip: Learn "this" 斯 and "that" 其 at the same time. ("that", 其 , is not in Heisig, but is probably more common than 斯). Story: This rook comes with an axe to fight, but that one doesn't, so this rook will win, and that rook will lose.

story: After you get the wooden spoon in the "egg & spoon" race another competitor explains that you need to hold the spoon "just so".
column3: A spoon used to measure ingredients just so is a measuring spoon.
column4: Use a wooden spoon when cooking foods that need to taste just so.

story: After the revolution, the king was put into a box so that the government could be set straight.
column3: Walking through the park, I see many large boxes where homeless people live. But there's one guy dressed as a king, who seems to be arranging them all, i.e. he's setting the boxes straight. "Surely you're not a real king?" I ask. He replies, "Let me set you straight, I'm king of the boxes".
column4: A country needs to be set straight - if its borders are breached and its jewels missing.

story: Founding of a nation is usually done by the taskmasters in charge behind closed doors. They sign some papers with their writing brushes and voila..
column3: Everyone seems to think that the Founding Fathers of the United States (the ones who signed the Declaration of Independence) were doing it out of their own free will. Truth is, George Washington, that hard old taskmaster, wouldn't let people out the door of the Pennsylvania State House until they had signed their name, and passed on the writing brush to the next person.
column4: After the founding of Post Secret, people started to disclose things with a brush instead of their mouths.

story: Bending over constantly to cut all those woodblocks has given Utamaro a bad back. Now he smokes hemp while he works to ease the pain in in his spine.
column3: 歌麿 うた-まろ: The poor guy with leukaemia smokes hemp to ease the pain from all the bone マロ that has to be injected into his spine. [Note: probably not medically accurate.]
column4: Utamaro, smokes hemp to help his spine feel fine!

story: I have a huge conglomerate (collection) of old books I'm looking to get rid of. They're not in any particular order... some are upside down in a row, some are soiled... just look through them and take whatever you want.
column3: Could think of the primitives as upside-down-in-a-row + sheep + take (with some strokes shared). Story: "We conglomerate (bunch together) upside-down", said the sheep, "so that predators don't take us ".
column4: Stroke order: the sources I've checked show strokes 9 to 11 drawn in the order "vertical-horizontal-horizontal" instead of "horizontal-vertical-horizontal" (i.e. like ten or soil would be). It seems a little illogical to me (we all have made a long way to get here and are about to know more than 3000 kanji, we've already earned the right to express such opinions ;-), but if you want the correct stroke order, using sheep seems better (if you don't care just use ten and forget about shared strokes ;-).

story: Tip: "snack" or "appetizer" would be better keywords for this kanji.
column3: Wolverine possesses his own snacks when he goes out drinking.
column4: Wolverine posesses the most treats at the party because he's entreated for being famous.

story: The murderer who carved symmetrical patterns into all his victims was sentenced life in a jailcell. (thanks tomusan).
column3: In jail, everyone wears symetrically patterned clothes - usually stripes. In this, particularly fashionable Scottish jail, however, they have you wear plaid. It makes sense if you think about it - most jails have vertical bars, which translates into stripes - while this Scottish joint has squarish, symetrically patterned bars that go very well with plaid.
column4: Changed to worth 甲斐, since that's how you'll use it.　A dissident was jailed for composing haiku in 俳, but because of the worth/merit of their sentences the government will not execute them. One might say their worth as a poet is their armor 甲.

story: British magistrates wear wigs made of silver hair. But picture an eccentric magistrate who instead wears a silver hare on his head.
column3: For all his righteousness in court, the magistrate is really a horny guy. How do I know this? I accidentally found his stash of Playboy magazines, and there was some silver liquid on the sign of the hare.
column4: The magistrate should have a halo (the middle primitive is not silver, there is a drop on top) he is far from an angel, he is actually playboy, see his rabbit ears?

story: In the beginning you learn by fiddling with things.
column3: Emperor Nero fiddled with his fiddle while Rome burned. When he was later asked to explain himself he said, “Well, I was learning how to play this piece and had to keep going back to the beginning”.
column4: In the beginning, before education was mainstream, people learnt things by fiddling with them.

story: Image: An Arctic explorer frozen within ice, within his hands are an umbrella and a compass.
column3: "At" seems like a better keyword for this one. You're freezing under your umbrella and using a compass to figure out where you're at.
column4: You stand within the safe area under an umbrella and use a compass to figure out where you're at in the ice of the tundra.

story: The hackneyed hangover cure is to have "some hair of the dog that bit you."
column3: You may think you're being original by sporting an afro, but it's hackneyed to have big poofy long hair.
column4: 外套, 常套, 套 (#2910) トウ ... Parts:大, 長＊ (cf: 奮闘奮 (#607) ... Story: 外套 Overcoat is the most common use for this Kanji. So calling a guy in an Overcoat a detective is a 常套Hackneyed way of seeing things, but it works. We see a Dog in a Long coat and we thing McGruff the crime dog.

story: The half that was anti- started a rebellion.
column3: A rebellion is when the anti half starts pushing against the other half. (Like in this kanji).
column4: Once at least half the population gets into shape and everyone is strongly anti-government, a rebellion can take place.

story: A small tip on something large creates a sharp point.
column3: Little, St Bernard: In primary school, I had a pencil sharpener shaped as a little St. Bernard. I put in my blunt pencil, and it came out with a sharp point.
column4: A sharp point is, necessarily, small, but it can do a large amount of damage.

story: The samurai's crock was so old it was a crowned a heritage item of Asia, and he wouldn't sell it.
column3: Miss Asia uses her crock pot to cook her samurai husband a meal. (thanks herman).
column4: The E-mail read: "Hello, my name is Ubuntu Nonga, crowned samurai of a small Asian country. I have $5 million that I need to move to a safe place ..." But I knew that advance-fee scams are a crock.

story: Magic wand, crown, 1-eyed valley, crotch: The archeologist was searching for the birthplace of the homo sapience. Wearing his magic wand and his divining crown, he was able to located it in the 1-eyed valley, somewhere in Bolivia. His crotch got all excited, thinking on all the publicity of finding the birthplace of homo sapience.
column3: The magic wand in a guy's crotch is crowned with one eye, and contains a certain sapience... but they should try not to "think with the little head."
column4: The Moment when Homosapiens developed sapience was when people stopped merely doing what their crotches wanted and instead started thinking about more complex things: Religion and magic (the wand), politics (crowning one person), and managing nature (keeping your eye on the valley).

story: I have used Red Bull as a primitive since 猶 (#1438), so now it is easy to remember the chieftain's name: Chief Red Bull!
column3: Only the chieftain could drink horned whiskey since he was the one responsible for procreation.
column4: Tip to avoid confusing with 伯 伯 (#967): the other has "white" but a "chieftain" is a "tan chief," so this is the character without "white" in it.

story: The nightingale is a bird that goes to a schoolhouse at night to learn to sing.
column3: This character is actually a 俗字 (unofficial simplification) of the character 鶯. As such, it is actually far less common than the traditional character according to a google search. Story for the correct character: The nightingale is bird with a crown (mane) as bright as a deep fire (two fires).
column4: At the school house we all learnt about some bird named Florence Nightingale.

story: Incandescent red is naturally twice as bright as ordinary red (赤). Alternatively, this is a picture of spreading (already doubled), incandescent red fire. Note: This is used by far most commonly to write 赫(あか)い, although dictionaries do not recognize such a reading (except for kanji dictionaries).
column3: Incandescent light bulbs work by passing an electric current through a filament, heating it so it produces light by incandescence. When you think of something heating up so it glows, it usually turns red (toaster coils, embers, etc.). An incandescent bulb is much brighter, so it's DOUBLE RED.
column4: Rosy cheeks are incandescent, glowing red with heat.

story: If a person has retainers, then he can spend his life supinate (i.e. lying on his back doing nothing). (note: for the writing order think: SuPinate = Slave-Person).
column3: Slaves are made to supinate before common people.
column4: The person gave his starved slave some soup and he ate the soup in eight seconds.

story: A nephew is someone you can watch grow into a man over his lifetime.
column3: Life, male: During a visit to your family, you meet your nephew. You find out that in his short life, your nephew already has collected a great many male things in his room, such as 'dirty' magazines, etc.
column4: Your nephew's life began anew once he met a real man: YOU!

story: I enter a ballot to try to win a melon, but end up with a gourd.
column3: With its protective hard rind, a gourd is a melon used to deposit ballots in during elections.
column4: Melons didn't like being classed botanically as gourds so they had a ballot to change their status.

story: The two kings play their biwa, comparing each other's skill.
column3: The biwa is totally different compared to a 琴 (#1591).
column4: King, king! Sit, sit! Listen to me play the biwa!

story: When she's playing the lute between your two balls Japanese censors mosaic it out.
column3: Two kings, mosaic: The contest of the two kings continued, but now they were to play the lute. However, their lute playing was so bad, the precious mosaics fell down the walls.. and were looted by the crowd.
column4: The mosaic pictures two kings playing the lute.

story: Think of this as "tuning fork" (音叉). Then, touching a vibrating tuning fork against a crotch causes it to drip drops.
column3: You are looking for a bathroom, but the path in front is forked and you don't know which way to go. Suddenly a drop begins to appear on your crotch over your pants...
column4: 犬夜叉, 音叉, , 木の叉, 三叉, 三叉神経, 叉 (#2914) サ, シャ, また ... Parts:又, 丶 (cf: 又, 亦, 股, 胯, 俣） ... Story: Only certain women can get a Fourchette (蹄叉) piercing. It requires an extra Drop of skin in the Crotch. And it can make Forking very painful if it gets infected. And if it does get infected you are pretty much Forked.(Google it.)

story: oppose: The opposing army of one thousand went north up the mountain to strike Hamlet in his castle up the top.
column3: A thousand people decided to disobey the government and fight back against North Korea. And it worked! Here we see the thousand piercing the North!
column4: Chinese: well-behaved In the North, they are so well-behaved! They lick their spoons a thousand times before putting it back into the cupboard.

story: You see a white dove about to land in a paddyfield, and, believing that field to be under water, expect to hear a "plop". But the plop doesn't come, so you think to yourself, "Ah, that must be a dry field".
column3: The dry field is the rice field that has dried up into white dust.
column4: A rice field turns white as shit (literally) it is such a dry field.

story: My offspring is supposed to be weeding my vegetable patch, but he keeps running off to play. So I put an electric fence around the veggie patch to pent him in. Now he's hard at work in there!
column3: The crops in the vegetable patch are pent in and dogtagged by type of crop.
column4: Pent in underneath my vegetable patch.. (the dog tags are the last piece of evidence of my crime..)

story: If water completely covers the floor, you will need a helping hand to clean it up.
column3: Water is completely covering your floor, and no matter how fast you mop it up it makes no difference. In desperation you cry, "Can someone give me a helping hand?"
column4: I slipped the floor, which was completely covered by water, but someone lent me a helping hand........................................................................... http://gfcmonica29.files.wordpress.com/2009/09/helping-hand-21.jpg.

story: A tall girl in a translucent mini skirt... Hell yes.
column3: Let crown + human legs = Miss World. Then the very tall Miss World won the title due to her translucent dress.
column4: The spike that holds up the 亭 (#333) at the World Expo turns translucent at night, revealing, as if it were a gown, a pair of human legs. Quite the attraction.

story: The cocoon like piece of flesh between human legs can produce blood relatives.
column3: I think Halpern's keyword "progeny" is a better fit for this kanji. Then: Progeny – a cocoon-like piece of flesh that drops out between two human legs.
column4: The body part between Venom's legs can produce blood relatives.

story: The zoo needed a transcription of the accident report involving the infant caught in the flood.
column3: Imagine spending your whole summer learning two ancient arts - first, the art of speaking to animals at the zoo (this is a bunch of different languages - no small feat), and the art of writing your name in urine (you go see the Mannequin de Pis for this - just sitting there and observing for hours on end). Anyway, you decide to put these two together, and go to a zoo cage, and ask the animal to tell its story. You then open your fly and proceed to do a full transcription of what it is saying.
column4: Note: 疎 (#1797)(疎) and 疏 (#2930)(疏) are sometimes used interchangeably, according to Nelson. The "zoo" primitive appears on the left side in both of these kanji (a rare placement). The only other kanji I could find with this primitive on the left is 蔬 (蔬).

story: Your body parts will become tall if you apply a special ointment.
column3: Tall, flesh: The druid had made a special ointment that made the warriors grow tall when they rubbed it over their flesh.
column4: I need a tall outhouse so that I can stretch out while rubbing the ointment all over my body.

story: The Ghostbusters were pioneers, being the first people ever to capture a ghost in a measuring cup.
column3: The ghost who went to the Big Dipper was a pioneer.
column4: The pioneer had discovered a ghost planet on the big dipper.

story: Voice, missile, incense: Before they were going to launch the missile, they were having a service to beg favor of the Gods. Then, when they lit the incense, a booming voice came out of nowhere: "Hmmm... this smell is great, no, ambrosial. Really worthy of the Gods..."
column3: Note: The meaning of this kanji is sweet fragrance or jasmine. Careful 薫 薫 (#1812), 芳 芳 (#532), 匂 匂 (#478), 臭 臭 (#128), 嗅 smell 嗅 (#129), 茉 茉 (#2436). Story: Her sexy voice made me feel like a missile was getting ready to launch as I smelled her ambrosial incense-like fragrance.
column4: Voice missle! The new gum that is guaranteed to give you ambrosial incense-like breath!

story: Tip: New primitive: Let Tarzan = generation + tree -- because Tarzan lives with several generations of his family at the top of a tree. (This combination appears five times: 葉 (#228), 蝶 (#521), 喋 (#2158), 諜 (#2726), label (FRAME 2926)). Story: You notice Tarzan is wearing his shirt inside-out and explain to him that clothes are one-sided and that he can tell by looking at the label.
column3: In botanic gardens, the trees have labels on one side (the side facing the path) so that upcoming generations will know what they are.
column4: It is with mindless 喋 (#2158) that one-sided labels are attached to good, honourable people.

story: My sharp eye caught a glimpse of the confidential information before it went through the shredder.
column3: As the taskmaster makes me get down on my knees to clean the floor with rags, my eye catches a glimpse of her panties.
column4: I caught a glimpse of the Shredder (from TMNT)'s eyes through the small space in his mask, but I've never seen his whole face. Part of what makes him so bad-a$$.

story: Tip: primitives given in the book are: blood + happiness. But should be: drop + eye (/net) + happiness. Story: As you squeeze the last drop out of your testicles you go cross-eyed with happiness.
column3: Sometimes I teabag my friend, dropping my testicles on his eyes, because it brings me happiness.
column4: Blood flows into the testicles in anticipation of a happy experience.

story: Craft, assembly line: The sorceress was very good at her craft. She magicked an assembly line to produce all kinds of sorceress' merchandise. Shrewed businesswoman, I'd say.
column3: When assembly lines first became popular, they were so quick at their craft that some swore they had to be the work of a sorceress.
column4: The sorceress bewitches two people to carry an I-beam for her so she can build a new evil castle.

story: A taskmaster can be empathetic if she receives something.
column3: The 諄 諄 (#2706) and 惇 惇 (#2279) tall child grew up to be an empathetic taskmaster.
column4: Don't expect to receive any empathetic gestures from that taskmaster!

story: (From Greek mythology). When Perseus goes to rescue Andromeda, he finds he's made a mistake. What looked from a distance like a beautiful maiden chained to a rock turns out to be a St. Bernard tangled up in some ivy. (Andromeda was chained up a bit further down on another beach).
column3: Andromeda is a large constellation that represents the god of literature thought to inhabit Ivy League schools.
column4: The girl everyone called "Big Ivy" got a job as a stripper. She wanted to use the nickname everyone called her, but the club owner said it wasn't sexy enough, and gave her the stellar sobriquet Andromeda instead.

story: If a sheep had feathers, it could soar.
column3: [+mantixen] If a sheep had feathers it could soar. This sheep's feathers are a tad sore & so the sheep itself is slightly misshapen.
column4: I stuck FEATHERS onto my pet SHEEP and dropped it off a cliff to see if it would SOAR... it SOARED straight to the bottom and thats why it's leg is messed up.

story: The revelation brought back by the dove left Noah beaming -- the flood waters were receding.
column3: A beaming white light offers a life-changing revelation.
column4: The holy white dove surrounded by beaming light came down from the sky with a revelation to tell us.

story: "tenebrous" = "dark" or "obscure." In tenebrous nights, millet is found tied in slipknots, in crop circles.
column3: The tenebrous Slipknot forces their way into the millet of Iowa.
column4: In tenebrous light I cut some millet 黍 in half then notice a drop of something on the dagger I used. But what is it? Blood? Rain? Millet juice? I look closely, but can’t tell because the light is too tenebrous.

story: Run, cornucopia: The thief was bold, but stupid. He was running away with the cornucopia he just stole from the feudal lord. However, he was leaving an easy track to follow as the cornucopia was pouring out its riches. So, bold, but stupid.
column3: A marathon runner bold enough to race the Fantastic Four.
column4: He was so bold that he said "Of course I could run a marathon. In fact, I could run 4 of them!"

story: This character would be the sign of the snake if the last stroke didn't stop short.
column3: A common snake strives to become a sign of the snake, but stops short and never reaches its goal. (Based on mantixen's story.)
column4: Imagine finding a snake in your garden, with its mouth a little open and poking it with a stick. Nope its okay, this snake is already dead.

story: The belt of thorns around a tree is doubled in a thornbush.
column3: A thornbush so thorny, even its thorns have thorns. Note: A good example is gorse http://www.weeds.asn.au/gifs/line_art/gorse.gif.
column4: There's no way that two thorns make up a thornbush. Sorry.

story: Beings exit the spirit world through the altar when you cast a spell.
column3: "haunt" or "haunted" seems a better keyword. ("curse" is already used.) Story: That place is so haunted there's an exit sign over the altar.
column4: SPOILER: The trophy in the Triwizard Tournament was just for show, in reality Barty Crouch Jr. had cast a spell on the trophy so it would be a Portkey that would make anyone who touched it exit the school grounds and teleport to the graveyard where Voldemort was waiting.

story: Grow late, life: It had nearly grown too late to resucitate the half-drowned man, but a passer-by was able to breath life back into him, thus resucitating him.
column3: To breathe life into someone after it might have grown (too) late is to resuscitate them.
column4: 蘇る：死んだものが蘇る。 甦る：衰えたものが甦る。 However that's just a nuance found on the net. Just few dictionaries mentioned it. To breathe life into someone after it might have grown (too) late is to resuscitate them. Edit Mantixen.

story: Lazy guide to pruning: Grab a dagger and slash everything in front.
column3: Tip: imagine strokes 3 & 4 of 月 are falling because you just pruned them.
column4: In front (drops), dagger: The gardener is pruning his roses. He closes up to the one in front of him until he can see the dewdrops on the petals. Then he gets out his dagger and prunes.

story: With the right upbringing, you might become somebody beautiful.
column3: Guys don't care about what kind of upbringing the woman had, they just want somebody with a beautiful body.
column4: The best upbringing doesn't make you somebody beautiful in looks, but somebody with a truly beautiful character.

story: There are many fruits when they're plentiful.
column3: When fruits are many, they are plentiful. (word order change) Thanks mantixen ().
column4: When fruit is plentiful, it feeds many mouths. This could mean anything that is vast or abundant.

story: If you snore, your nose becomes dry. I try to remember the slightly different bottom part by wanting to hit the snoring nose with two hands but can't quite reach. KUN yomi reading いびき.
column3: If you cannot breathe through your nose, your airways become dry and you snore. Note: To remember 丌 - An old snoring cure was to stuff a pie (mathematical π) into subject's mouth. Because so many choked this cure fell out of favour.
column4: People snore when a combination of two elements occur; 1. their nose is deformed (the strange two arms) and 2. their nose is dry.

story: At the pinnacle of enlightenment, Shakyamuni Buddha had the ability to bend common household spoons.
column3: Buddha gets tired of all the meditation and becomes a rapper, Shake ya money Buddha, moves to the Pinnacle and buys this huge house where he sits all day and just chills with his homies.
column4: Shakyamuni Buddha sits in his house at the pinnacle.

story: If you mark each meter with a grain of rice, after 1,000 grains of rice you have measured out a kilometre.
column3: A kilometer is made of one thousand meters.
column4: The character 米 can also mean METRE, so METRE plus THOUSAND = KILOMETER.

story: A rin of a meter is a centimeter.
column3: Centimeter is spelt the American way. As mantixen says, it is a rin of a meter.
column4: A centimeter is as long as a piece of rice, which is oddly enough worth about a rin.

story: The portion of a meter the width of fur is a millimeter.
column3: RICE and cheap FUR are about 1 MILLIMETER thick.
column4: This is the last of the meter kanji in RTK, but if anyone's curious I went to ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/メートル and found a few more: 粆 micrometer (one millionth of a meter); 粉 decimeter (1/10 meter, already learned as flour); 籵 dekameter (10 meters); and 粨 hectometer (100 meters).

story: Unsuccessful dieter's excuse: "If I put anything in my mouth, I immediately put on a ton."
column3: The character 頓 (IMMEDIATE) is pronounced "トン". The addition of the MOUTH to the left indicates that it is used for its sound and to convey a meaning other than the normal meaning of the character.
column4: A mouth that says things immediately without thinking gets into a ton of trouble.

story: Mouth, computer: The mouth on my navigation computer tells me it's only a mile left to my destination.
column3: One RI is approximately equal to one MILE. The MOUTH indicates that this is a western measurement. (see TON).
column4: Blah, blah, blah. After a mile of listening to the mouth of the guy I was commuting with, I stuffed a computer into his mouth to shut him up. I imagine we won't be riding together tomorrow.

story: Water, computer: Some water leaked into my navigation computer and now it expresses all distances in nautical miles. Very annoying!!
column3: A ri on water is about a nautical mile.
column4: Crap, I got water into my ship's computer! Now how am I supposed to track nautical miles?

story: If you GLUE your MOUTH shut, you can't open it one INCH.
column3: The character 寸 (すん）means approx 3.03cm, or a little over 1 INCH. The addition of the MOUTH indicates that this is a western measurement.
column4: To glue your mouth shut it only takes an inch of it.

story: Mouth, shakuhachi: The hookers mouth was huge and also she was very skilled in 'shakuhachi': she could hold up to one foot.
column3: 口 + 尺 = 呎・フィート feet. Note: 尺・しゃく is being combined with 口 in same way as 哩 (#2950) to signal analogy between shaku and feet. 尺 is about 3ocm - slightly under a foot.
column4: Whenever my girlfriend puts a footlong in her mouth I want her to give me a shakuhachi.

story: This is a Brahman, a fully enlightened one. He's sitting in front of a grove of trees, legs open (looks like wind), just meditating. You run up to him asking him all sorts of crazy questions, and he looks at you and smiles. "Brah, man, just chill, man. Braaaaah#." Apparently he's a surfer brahman. You ask him the meaning of life, and he smiles, and waits...waits...waits...until a bit of wind blows by. He lets out a small fart in the wind, and nods knowingly at you.
column3: Brahman who are mediocre don't get the sweet meditation spots on the beach. Instead, they have to settle for a grove of trees.
column4: Sanskrit is the liturgical language of Hinduism, Jainism and Buddhism. Most people who speak Sanskrit willingly live mediocre lives in groves of trees to seek enlightenment from Brahman.

story: [+mantixen] A bodhisattva visits The Pinnacle to provide flowers and meditation products to the unenlightened.
column3: [+megaqwerty] This is the Bodhisattva, who wants to help release the wicked from the painful cycle of life. Of course, the most vain and wicked are the pathetic lamers in the Pinnacle. He goes to register to stand at the station and hand out products. The registrar - "Okay, buddy, what are you selling?" "Nothing," he says. "I am giving out physical products to entice true enlightment." "Whatever, dude..." He gets his license, and hands out flowers to anyone who will take them.
column4: A bodhisattva from the pinnacle sells flower-scented products to the unenlightened.

story: Phonetic ボ. Bo tree is a sacred buddhist fig tree. The lovely smell from the flowering bo tree wafts down onto the meditating monks who are silent as though muzzled. 菩薩・ぼさつ bodhisattva.
column3: We had to muzzle the flowers on the BO tree since they smelled like, well, BO. Gross.
column4: The flower shop has put a muzzle on Bo Derek and is selling her as a bo tree.

story: Babble is what comes out of Asian people's mouths until you learn their language.
column3: The kanji has the meanings of "mute" (聾唖) and "speechless" (唖然), like "dumb" used to ("struck dumb" etc). Asian mouth is mute in a way, because they don't babble so much as they do in some parts of the world.
column4: 唖然, 聾唖, 唖者, 聾唖者, 唖, 唖 (#2958) ア, おし ... Parts:口, 亜亜 (#1809) ... Note: Odd Keyword. Really Mute, and Phonetic for ア. 亜 used to be ア phonetic, but as 亜細亜 (アジア) came to be a common term, 亜 came to used as a symbol for Asia, like 米 for America, 仏 for France, 阿 for Africa, 独 for Germany, etc. ... Similars: 喋る喋 (#2158), 唖然唖 (#2958) ... Story: Am I running my mouth about things to do with Asia? Am I Babbling?

story: If you elbow a cow it's will moo. (or alternatively, a cow mooing, the sound being somewhat like ム).
column3: Elbow a cow to make it moo （ム）.
column4: Turns out that raulir is correct, According to RTK2[2nd ed. Frame 41] this is the root of the katakana ム.

story: You wanna drive a Sanskrit ka? Just add it to the road.
column3: The Sanskrit ka just seems to be a high カロrie version of the katakana カ. Hit the road, you bloated phonetic character.
column4: Ford didn't know what to call their next car, and it was ready to be released. A quick-witted Indian employee thought to himself, "why don't they just call it the 'car', so they can get this show on the road?" He raised his hand at the meeting and said, "I propose we call it the Ford Ka. No, not like 'car', the Sanskrit ka invokes a sense of reliability, safety, performance and beauty. Add to that the fact that nobody will forget its name, because it's homophonous with the actual product!

story: This and 琲 (#2968) only seem to occur in the word 珈琲 (コーヒー) where they are used phonetically. So, in practice, it might be easier to remember them as a pair and not worry about their literal meanings. STORY: For 珈: An assassin adds poison to the king's coffee. For 琲: However, fearing a plot against him, the king, summons a hapless convict from a jail cell to sample the coffee first.
column3: To cut down on カロries, the king adds a jeweled hairpin to his coffee rather than sugar.
column4: When the Jewish king added jewels to his jeweled hairpin he was lauded. When the Palestinian king put beads on his 琲 琲 (#2968) he was jailed.

story: The king is in the jail cell and is trying to escape by picking the lock with his beaded hairpin.
column3: 珈 (2962) and 琲 (2963) are mainly used for their phonetic readings in 珈琲 コーヒー coffee. To help remember the word and the two kanji, the right sides of these two kanji can be read as "カロ"+"ヒ". Coffee, the king of pick me up beverages, is low calorie.
column4: When the Jewish king added jewels to his 珈 珈 (#2967) he was lauded; but when the Palestinian king (the beady-eyed one) put beads on his beaded hairpin he was jailed.

story: It used to be that for a meeting [old] you'd meet for a day to get the small details pent in. Even then such meetings were still held under the Japanese cypress [old].
column3: For Meeting (old) 會 at 會. Pent-in + small is pictograph of "a pair of glasses with windscreen wipers" like something out of a joke shop. STORY: In the olden days we couldn't afford a roof, so we would meet alfresco. Our spectacles had built in wipers so we could continue working during inclement weather. The meetings (old) were long and would often last until sundown. Those were the days! Note: So for Japanese cypress (old) simply replace 会 in 桧 (#2558) with 會.
column4: Long ago, the JAPANESE CYPRESS [old] was the best TREE to have a MEETING. Even though everyone was PENT IN the rather SMALL area under the tree's cover, it was pleasant enough that they could be there all DAY.

story: This is a picture of a horse cart (車) from which the reins (糸) go to the mouth (口) of the horse, in which is the bit.
column3: Errata: Apparently this frame was supposed to refer to 鑾 = tinkling bell 鑾, but there's nothing wrong with the current keyword or the kanji, just the frame information.
column4: A bridle's bit was put in the mouth of the horse and connected by two threads back to the horse-drawn car.

story: The abyss [old] used to be the water you were pushed into if you lost in the arm wrestling match. (the primitive to the right screams two guys arm wrestling on a table, any one else see it?)
column3: チャレンジャー海淵, 剣淵町 淵 (#2966) エン, ふち, ... Parts:氵, 片, 一, 片＊ (cf: 片道片 (#1212), 甘肅省肅) ... Note: 異体字 for 渕渕 (#2325). Even though Heisig calls this the Old version of 渕, 淵 is on the official name kanji list, and 渕 is not. ... Story: 0ld bridge across the Old Abyss over Water from One sided to the Other Sided, with just One ropeded.
column4: Be careful on the suspension bridge lest you fall into the water of the abyss [old].

story: Mr T knows that the Roman Numeral for five is V.
column3: Yoda figured out what the V in V for Vendetta meant within the first 5 minutes. He ain't no fool.
column4: Mr. T is counting the amount of people who came to this page by not pressing the CTRL in CTRL-V. Looks like you are the FIFTH one.

story: Mr T also knows that the Roman Numeral for ten is X.
column3: Mr. T gives ten reasons he looks up to Malcolm X, then wonders out loud what happened to the other IX Malcolms.
column4: (Chinese) "What can you do with just a needle?" "You'll find out very soon, Mr T".

story: This is actually the old ten thousand yen bill in Japan - Jiminy Cricket surrounded by a wreath of flowers. It's pretty uncommon to see nowadays since it was only in print for a few days immediately after the war (MacArthur wanted a way to make sure that even the rich kept their atrocities in their consciences).
column3: Your flowers will not be safe if ten thousand [old] Jiminy Crickets come to town.
column4: The old ten thousand Yen bill showed a long tailed monkey 禺 with a flower on his head. It was the pet of the emperor.

story: I see lots of 10,000 yen notes just lying on the road and think, "Should I stop and pick them up?" But then I realise they are old 10,000's (i.e. worthless) and decide I’ll just pass through.
column3: I wonder if I can pass through this old road, it looks 10000 years old.
column4: This is a secret passthrough in Mario Kart Road - it is a flower-lined, hidden tunnel, and an awesome way to pass through directly to the finish line and beat everyone! But there's a guard there - Jiminy Cricket - that won't let anyone through - saying that it's against his conscience. You try to pay him off with a bunch of money, and he won't budge. Then you remember an item you picked up - an old １０万円Jiminy Bill. Being a collector, he accepts and lets you pass through.

story: Fire, voiced - water: After the incident where the insect made a pitiful voiced sound, you decide to free it. Immediately it is attracted to the candlelight and flies into the fire. Bugger!
column3: You were watching the poor insect bound up voicing "Help me! Help me!" (濁 (#898)), so you answered his calls for help by using a candlelight to set the evil spider on fire.
column4: Candlelight emitted by FIRE 火 (#173) lured the CATERPILLAR 蜀.

story: Tough guys like to display there force on the road.
column3: The road is where young, irresponsible males like to display how "tough" they are. It is because of them that my car insurance premiums are so high!
column4: An especially TOUGH form of discipline was used in old Japan. Criminals would be tied up or crucified on posts and put on DISPLAY and their blood would DROP onto the ROAD.

story: In old style street lamps, to light the fire you had to ascend them.
column3: Think old style lamps that you would light on fire and let them ascend to the skies.
column4: Fire can ascend from the ground and hang in a lamp [old].

story: In the old days, instead of having a micro-computer sewn into the suit of the master spy, a whole computer was carried in the back of his cloak, although it was clearly obvious that he was a spy. "What's that um.. enormous computer doing in the back your cloak?"
column3: Modern spy apparel includes microcomputers sown into the back of the top hat and scarf as seen in 裏 (#426). However, in the old days, the coal driven computer was so bulky it had to be hidden in the back of a bulky cloak. All these old spies masqueraded as hunchbacks.
column4: For some reason this makes me think of Inspector Gadget, who inside his cloak like trenchcoat, hid a huge array of computer type gadgets.

story: Parks in Japan are designed around water, rocks and trees. A park with flowers is considered to be an alternate park.
column3: In the old days parks had more flowers.
column4: One alternate type of park has flowers in it. Some do, some don't.

story: At an alternative shop you can buy strange items like metal dogtags from wars, active grenades, torture sets, etc.
column3: Understandable that the alternate shop is more successful than the regular 舗 舗 (#1982): trendy metal motif instead of that dingy cottage look.
column4: An alternate type of shop installs metal upgrades to your Segway like chrome rims and spinners.

story: The bird got tired of the mountain he lived on, so now he's flying away searching for an alternative island.
column3: Mountain, bird: On the alternative island, birds could just breed beside the mountains instead of upon one. The hippies didn't do any harm.
column4: Just break the common kanji for island 島 into its mountain and bird components. 嶋.

story: The alternative summit is so steep that the mountain is above you rather than beside you. People usually just go with the regular summit.
column3: Logically, an alternate way to arrange the primitives for 峰 峰 (#1562) is to have 山 on top where it rightfully belongs.
column4: The couple have a tryst just below the alternate mountain summit, where no one goes anymore.

story: A grove now grows on the soil of [old] plains.
column3: Only Names: Family names (Ishino 石埜, Takano 高埜) Given names: (Nonoka 埜々香, Yaya 埜々), 埜 埜 (#2979) ヤ, の ... Parts:林, 土 (cf: 禁止禁 (#1098) ... Note: Freaking Rare Kanji, Name only, Not in Nelson, Spahn listing under 野, IMEs won't even offer it as an option. ... Story: Intentional Wordplay: We went hiking in Pacific Grove, and found Amelia Erhart's Old Planes scattered in the Dirt. It turns out she never left California!.
column4: Before computers and humans were around the plains were just GROVES OF TREES growing on SOIL.

story: An ancient Japanese dragon, beautiful and terrifying. Here it is depicted standing on a piece of meat (its prey) and a description is written on the right margin. It is said to be like a snake that has three toes on its feet and can sometimes use its head as a flamethrower (kind of like a sling, but with fire instead of stones). (Note: The Japanese dragon has three toes, unlike other Asian dragons. Asian dragons generally don't breath fire, but Godzilla does, and it is supposed to be a dragon!)
column3: (insp by raulir) The ancient Japanese Dragon, now extinct, is depicted in a book of lore STANDING on a pile of freshly slaughtered MEAT. The column describes how the last Japanese Dragon was killed by a party of adventurers, who struck its SNAKE body simultaneously with a SLINGSHOT and THREE swords.
column4: The old dragon places a vase on top of the moon for target practice and then tries to hit it using his special slingshot made from a snake. It takes him three shots: "Missed... missed... Got it!" (Note slingshot & snake share one stroke).

story: An old dragon's house enjoys a lot of patronage as a modern tourist attraction. (thanks mantixen).
column3: House, dragon [old]: The house of the old dragon was filled with art pieces: he was very active in patronage, i.e. supporting artists. (He had to do something with his hoard).
column4: A Chinese dragon's house enjoys a lot of patronage from would-be disciples.

story: A Chinese dragon flying overhead can cause deafness to your ears.
column3: When the old dragon roared into my ears I suffered from a little deafness.
column4: A old dragon suffers from age related deafness in its ear.

story: The old longing is a 欲 欲 (#855) of the heart.
column3: As you get old, you develop a longing for a new heart.
column4: Longing, heart: The old man had supressed his old longing from his youth for many years, but nothing can stop longing if it comes from the bottom of one's heart.

story: A long time ago the Monkey King was kept in prison under a mountain Point.
column3: It's an old point to say that land developers don't always provide full disclosure. Brochures touting the 'New Point', an artificial hill atop the mountain, fail to mention the notorious prison on the Old Point just below.
column4: The world's supervillains, when captured, are kept in a high security prison which is hidden far below an [old] and forgotten mountain Point.

story: Russia, an old country, has everyone pent-in and drinking vodka saying "aaaaaaaaa". See mantixen's story, 或 (#2234).
column3: It used to be you were pent in by a certain country. Now we have global travel and dual citizenships.
column4: There's still a certain very old country that writes the kanji for country this way. (I'm looking at you China.)

story: The body part that gets wet when you wade through the sewers (a crafted flood underneath the ground) is your shin (thanks brian44).
column3: The right side actually has to do with a sort of undersround water tunnel, check any chinese hanzi dictionary and you will see http://www.zhongwen.com/ .
column4: (Hint: if you call 足 (#1372) "foot" (for which it is the prefered kanji) and distinguish the measurement 呎 (#2960) (e.g."foot [measurement]") you can call 脚 (#1498) legs or leg (which is what it means), freeing up “shin” for its actual kanji (脛 (#2991))) The shin is the PART OF THE BODY (月 (#13)) which gets soaked if you wade through the SEWERS (巠). [Thanks mantixen] (Kanji with "TOILET PAPER"(圣) and/or "SEWER"(巠): 勁 (#2992), 剄, 径 (#947) (/徑/逕), 怪 (#773) (var. 恠!), 茎 (#772) (/莖), 脛 (#2991), 痙, 経 (#1460) (/經), 軽 (#774) (/輕), 頚 (#2813) (/頸)).

story: The powerful stench coming from the sewers is formidable.
column3: [+mantixen] Sewer power: formidable stench.
column4: In lots of games like oblivion there is a sewers level. You can meet some formidable foes down there, so you better make sure to have enough power to take em down.

story: Old evil altar, sign of snake: In the ancient temple, they found and old evil altar with the sign of the snake imprinted on it. What evil could be enshrined within it???
column3: An altar with the sign of the snake etched into it enshrines a serpent god.
column4: At the OLD ALTAR of RTK 1 the SIGN OF THE SNAKE is forever ENSHRINed in the hearts of those who persevered. (Thanks blannk).

story: Old evil altar, chihuahua with extra leg: They opened up the old evil altar in the ancient temple. Nothing inside. But suddenly, their chihuahua grew an extra leg, and started speaking in a strange language. Time for an exorcism, one would say.
column3: When grandma's chihuahua developed the extra leg we thought an exorcism in order. We did it on a very old altar. It was not successful.
column4: Your friend, barking like a dog, is put on the altar for an exorcism.

story: People with wooden legs are renowned for dithering over whether to decorate them with a drop of paint or not.
column3: The wooden leg pirate dithers to give flowers to my love doll, cause he is afraid I will kick his ass.
column4: Note: 躊躊 (#2997) and 躇躇 (#2995) mean the same thing and are used as a unit exclusively.. 躊躇する, 躊躇う躇 (#2995) チョ(著),ためらう ... Parts: ⻊, 著著 (#1347) ... for 躇 Story: The Old School Renowned Pirate (Old School because he does not tap of the last drop off before he tucks it back in) is often accused of Diddling because of that same drop. Wait, it's Dither.

story: A samurai wearing a broken crown crafted an inch-thick floor under which to hide with his mouth glued, giving him longevity as his enemies failed to find him.
column3: 士 フ エ 一 吋→壽（寿の正字） さむらいの笛は1インチ.
column4: After the samurai's crown was broken in battle, he crafted a new one an inch thick. This would assure it both he and the crown would last, as he craved longevity and reaching old age.

story: I hesitate to have a wooden leg fitted as I'm not sure how it will affect my longevity.
column3: The man suffering from gangrene hesitated a bit, but knew he'd have to choose the peg leg if he wanted longevity.
column4: With diabetes, i hesitate to have my leg amputated. I know it will increase my longevity, but my quality of life may go down.

story: A bit of old food is stuck on one of my mandalas. What could it be? I scrape it off and taste it . . . Hmm, bean jam, I reckon.
column3: Steamed bean jam dumplings were invented as a form of Chinese take-out that could be eaten while meditating on a mandala (thanks dihutenosa).
column4: Old food, Mandela: During his imprisonment, Mandela was only given old food. Once per year, they gave him a treat: fresh bean jam. After this, you shouldn't visit Mandela's cell: to stinky! Old food primitive: (meeting, day, staples: The meeting took all day, do when we got out to have our dinner, only old food and the staples of the dinnerboxes were left. My colleagues are such gluttons!

story: The mouth on the left eats a whole box full of goods and then starts to retch them out again.
column3: In my grandmother's attic, I found a box of goods from WWII. I put some in my mouth and started to retch.
column4: Mouth, old ward: The stench decomposing bodies in the old ward made the apocalypse survivors nearly retch their innards from their mouths. Old ward primitive: Post-apocalypse: in the old ward, the survivors found all kinds of usefull goods packed in cartboard boxes.
